title: Examining Romanian Fault Lines
description: The Romanian director Lucian Pintilie made his first film in 1965, the year Nicolae Ceausescu became general secretary of the Romanian Communist Party. During the subsequent decades of Ceausescus dictatorship, which ended in 1989, Mr. Pintilie, like many independent-minded Eastern European artists, tried to work within the system and then went into exile, leaving for the West in 1973 and returning after Ceausescu was gone.

title: So Youre Pregnant? Sometimes Thats the Easy Part
description: Early on theres the birth of a baby, with doctor, nurse and father-to-be all singing, Push it out, push it on out like a high school football cheer. Vaginas are mentioned so often that you may wish Eve Ensler had never made the word fashionable in polite company. Then, just as youre writing off Rated P for Parenthood as a bad, demographically opportunistic mash-up, a new mother sings a lovely middle-of-the-night lullaby to her infant son, and her husband offers her $50 to take his turn getting out of bed to tend to the baby. (She negotiates and gets $100 and coffee from the fancy place.)

title: In Moscow, Facing a Question of Balancing or Going Quietly
description: The diagramed deal was the second board of the final of the Top 8 team event at the 10th Slava Memorial Cup, played in Moscow last month. It was a situation of interest to bidding theorists and featured a textbook defense.

title: Back Home, Some Eternal Verities Prove Irksome
description: The playwright Mark Snyder is a native of Ohio, where he has set As Wide as I Can See, a drama now at the Here Arts Center. Given the plays rigorous balance, it appears he bears a pronounced ambivalence toward the state.

title: Universal Lures Top Country Executive From EMI
description: As its takeover of half of EMI is being reviewed by regulators in the United States and Europe, the Universal Music Group has hired one of EMIs top record executives for its country division.

title: The Blink of an Eye? Oh, Please
description: According to Harry Shum, a Microsoft computer scientist, computer users will visit a Web site less if its loading time is slower than its competitors by 250 milliseconds, or one-quarter of a second. That is less time than a single eye blink.

title: Pittsburgh Cuts Loose a Revered Receiver
description: During his 14 years as a receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, Hines Ward attained a revered status.

title: For Chinese Women, a Basic Need, and Few Places to Attend to It
description: BEIJING  Wang Jianyi, 26, was in a huge hurry. She had been riding the bus for three hours. At each rest stop, the line outside the womens toilet was too long for her to use the restroom.

title: Academy Wishes Its Future Really Did Belong to the Young
description: Well, thats a wrap. After months of lobbying and hoopla the little gold guys have found their new homes on mantels and office shelves, and my self-referential stint as the Carpetbagger is drawing to a close for the season.

title: A Detergent Emerges as a Star at Daytona
description: If not for the track fire that delayed the Daytona 500 for two hours Monday night, few would have known that Tide detergent can launder grape juice stains and a track burned by a jet fuel fire.

title: West Virginia: Mine Security Chief Gets 3-Year Prison Term
description: The former chief of security for the Upper Big Branch mine, where 29 miners died in an explosion in 2010, was sentenced Wednesday to three years in prison. The official, Hughie Elbert Stover, 60, was convicted in October of lying to federal officials and obstructing the investigation into the explosion at the West Virginia mine. Mr. Stover was also sentenced to two years of supervised release and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine. Last month, a higher-ranking official, Gary May, was accused of conspiring to defraud the government in connection with the investigation.

title: The Los Angeles Schools Chief, on Teacher Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: Anna Lou Dehavenon, Who Drew Attention to the Homeless, Dies at 85
description: Anna Lou Dehavenon, an urban anthropologist, was documenting the lives of women living in a Bronx homeless shelter in the 1980s when she had an epiphany.

title: Medicare Doctor Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Peacekeeping
description: To the Editor:

title: Crafting a Bus Safety Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Prevent Another Darfur
Venezuelas El Sistema
description: The classical music reporter Daniel J. Wakin discusses the Venezuelan music education program founded by Jos Antonio Abreu.

title: Delaware Court Declines to Block Kinder Morgans El Paso Corp. Deal
description: 10:24 p.m. | Updated with El Paso statement

title: Photos of The Moment | Gareth Pugh

title: Churches Can Go Back to Schools, for Now
description: Two weeks after churches had to stop holding worship services in New York City public schools, a federal court sent pastors and congregations a different and welcome message on Wednesday: go back, at least for now.

title: Defense and Dempseys Shot Give U.S. a First in Italy
description: GENOA, Italy  It took 11 games over eight decades, but the United States mens soccer team can now boast that it has beaten Italy. The victory, on a chilly night, came in a friendly and not in a tournament, but it was sweet nonetheless for an American team being reshaped by its coach, Jurgen Klinsmann.

title: Venezuela: Fuel Still Flows to Syria
description: The head of the state-run oil company, Petrleos de Venezuela, has said that the company will continue to ship diesel fuel to Syria despite efforts by the United States and other countries to isolate the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria. If they need diesel and we can supply it there is no reason not to do it, Rafael Ramrez, the oil company president, who is also the minister of oil and mining, said on Tuesday. He confirmed that company had sent two tankers, each containing 300,000 barrels of diesel, to Syria. The State Department said it would continue to work with other countries to increase pressure on Mr. Assad to cease his crackdown on political opponents and to step down. President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela has long sided with Middle Eastern countries like Syria and Iran in defiance of Western sanctions.

title: Genetically Altered Bird Flu Virus Not as Dangerous as Believed, Its Maker Asserts
description: The scientist who made a deadly bird flu virus transmissible in mammals, touching off public fears of a pandemic, said Wednesday that the virus he created was neither as contagious nor as dangerous as people had been led to believe.

title: For Keselowski, a Steady Climb on Twitter
description: A minute-by-minute analysis of Brad Keselowskis Twitter messages during the Daytona 500 on Monday night showed that his following grew steadily, rather than explosively, according to an analysis by Twitter.

title: A Civil Right to Unionize
description: FROM the 1940s to the 1970s, organized labor helped build a middle-class democracy in the United States. The postwar period was as successful as it was because of unions, which helped enact progressive social legislation from the Civil Rights Act to Medicare. Since then, union representation of American workers has fallen, in tandem with the percentage of income going to the middle class. Broadly shared prosperity has been replaced by winner-take-all plutocracy.

title: Smartphones Have Led, and Desktops Will Follow
description: BARCELONA, Spain  These days much of the action in the world of gadgets is happening in smartphones  like their sophisticated design and the apps that run on them. That has left desktop and laptop computers looking a little dull in comparison.

title: Bad Feelings Lingering Over Brauns Victory
description: JUPITER, Fla.

title: Winter Month Indicator?
description: The price of gasoline rose higher this February that in any other previous February. Some analysts worry that this could portend very high gas prices this summer.

title: Israels Last Chance to Strike Iran
description: Tel Aviv

title: School Shooting Suspect Was Accused of Earlier Assault
description: CHARDON, Ohio  The teenager held in a shooting rampage at a high school in a suburb of Cleveland that killed three students and injured two had a troubled past, accused in 2009 of choking and punching a person, according to court documents released here on Wednesday.

title: My Morning Jacket and Jackson Browne to Headline Newport Folk Festival
description: My Morning Jacket and Jackson Browne will be the headliners at the 2012 Newport Folk Festival in July, the organizers announced on Thursday. As it has since it started in 1959, the festival will return to Fort Adams State Park on Narragansett Bay in Newport, R.I., on July 28 and 29 with a lineup featuring its usual mix of traditional folk groups and folk-rock bands. The first days bill will include Iron & Wine, Dawes, Deer Tick, Blind Pilot and Sharon Van Etten. On the second day, Conor Oberst, Punch Brothers, the Head & the Heart, and Tune-yards will play, along with several other acts. There will be a number of not-strictly-folk performances. The Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the celebrated traditional jazz outfit from New Orleans, will play the first day. The electric blues guitarist Gary Clark Jr. is slated to do a set on the second day, as is Tom Morello, the guitarist from Rage Against the Machine who also performs original folk songs as The Nightwatchman.

title: Former Goldman Partner Now a Self-Fashioned Political Pundit
description: For many former Goldman Sachs partners, an active retirement means traveling the world, becoming a regular on the gala circuit and playing hundreds of holes of golf a week.

title: In Relay Practice, Yankees Have an Answer for Valentine
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The timing that Derek Jeter displayed in making the famous flip relay to Jorge Posada in the 2001 playoffs was remarkable. The timing the Yankees displayed by practicing the same play Wednesday was too rich to believe.

title: A Big Days Coming
description: On Sunday, we commemorate one of the most seminal moments in American history, the inauguration of President William Henry Harrison.

title: Substantial Growth in Ads Is on the Way to Facebook
description: Facebooks hundreds of millions of users could soon be faced with a lot more advertising  in their newsfeed, on their mobile devices and even when they log off.

title: Davy Jones, Monkees Singer, Dies at 66
description: Davy Jones, by long-held public consensus the handsomest and most popular of the Monkees, the collectively young, longhaired, wildly famous and preternaturally buoyant pop group of the 1960s and afterward, died on Wednesday in Indiantown, Fla. He was 66.

title: Talking to North Korea, Again
description: North Korea has repeatedly vowed to rein in its nuclear program, only to renege, so skepticism is demanded. Still, the Obama administration is right to try again.

title: After Many Tough Choices, the Choice to Quit
description: WASHINGTON  The looming Senate vote on a Republican plan to give employers the right to withdraw health care coverage based on religious and moral convictions put Senator Olympia J. Snowe in a tough but familiar position: weighing her own views as a Republican centrist against pressure from fellow Republicans to support the party position.

title: Window Into Developers Relentless Quest to Get a Yonkers Project Approved
description: For Forest City Ratner, it had become a make-or-break moment: The developer had already spent roughly $70 million on a proposed 81-acre luxury mall and housing complex in Yonkers, but was one vote shy of winning the City Councils approval.

title: To Avoid Last-Minute Suit, Shell Asks U.S. Court to Rule
description: HOUSTON  In an attempt to avoid a last-minute challenge from environmental groups that could delay its plans to begin drilling for oil this summer off the coast of Alaska, Shell asked a federal court on Wednesday to review its Alaska Arctic oil spill response plan and decide whether it complied with the laws requirements.

title: Update on New York Redistricting
description: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this years elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar; the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary on Sept. 11.

title: Virginias Gift to Gunrunners
description: In 1993, Virginia enacted a one-per-month limit on gun purchases after a federal study showed that two out of five handguns taken from New York City crime scenes were purchased in Virginias freewheeling gun markets. Now the state seems determined to resume its destructive iron pipeline role. On Tuesday, Gov. Bob McDonnell signed a law repealing the gun purchase limit.

title: Iran Invokes the West to Motivate Voters
description: WASHINGTON  In the days leading up to Irans parliamentary elections on Friday, the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and other top officials have been crisscrossing their country to issue stern warnings against a vast Western conspiracy, driven by panic, to undermine the vote. The official news media have amplified the campaign: U.S. Dreads Iranians Turnout in Elections, read one typical banner on Press TV, the state-run English-language vehicle.

title: Reforming the Postal Service
description: All the free-market enthusiasts in Congress should have no problem with the determination of Patrick Donahoe, the postmaster general, to make the gravely troubled mail system smaller, leaner and more competitive. Yet most lawmakers have decried or ducked money-saving options like eliminating Saturday mail delivery and consolidating mail-processing centers  crucial parts of Mr. Donahoes reform plan. Their resistance is even stronger to possibly closing 3,653 of the nations 32,000 post offices, even though more than 3,000 offices have only two-hour workdays or less than $27,500 in annual revenues.

title: Black Eye for Ticket Reseller
description: It was the kind of disturbance that could have happened anywhere alcohol flows free. But an outburst early Monday at an Oscars party in Connecticut has also cast a shadow over a fast-growing and controversial side of the entertainment business: the online market for scalped tickets.

title: Free-Speech Argument in Appeal of Disbarred Lawyers Sentence
description: Throughout her long career, the disbarred lawyer Lynne F. Stewart has rarely minced words or stood mute. But her propensity for speaking her mind is now at the crux of an appeal of her 10-year sentence in federal prison.

title: Cavs Irving, a No. 1 Pick, Is Exceeding Expectations
description: As much as any coach in the N.B.A., Byron Scott knows the value of coaching a team directed by a sterling floor general. Scott ran the floor with Magic Johnson as a part of the Showtime Lakers in the 1980s and ran off screens while backing up Reggie Miller for the 1995 Eastern Conference finalist Indiana Pacers, whose point guard was Mark Jackson.

title: Saudi Arabia May Be Tied to 9/11, 2 Ex-Senators Say
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a decade, questions have lingered about the possible role of the Saudi government in the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, even as the royal kingdom has made itself a crucial counterterrorism partner in the eyes of American diplomats.

title: Clinton Urges Iranian Group to Complete Move
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Wednesday that a decision on whether to remove an Iranian opposition group from the list of terrorist organizations would depend in part on whether more than 3,000 of its members cooperate in moving to a new location inside Iraq.

title: For Impatient Web Users, an Eye Blink Is Just Too Long to Wait
description: Wait a second.

title: A Doo-Wop Shop Prepares to Close, Signaling the End of a Fading Genre
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  The end is near for Ronnie Is Clifton Music after 40 years on Main Avenue  yet another victim of the Internet, the economy, and changing tastes in music and shopping.

title: Iran Prepares for Elections
description: Candidates and their supporters on the ground geared up for parliamentary elections in Iran that are slated for Friday.

title: Brothers to Renew Rivalry on the Ice
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Eric Staal, the Carolina Hurricanes captain, was having a miserable season until New Years Day. Since then he has performed like the player who won a Stanley Cup and an Olympic gold medal.

title: Born to Not Get Bullied
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: In Return to the Honda Classic, Woods Is Irritated by Some Questioning
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Tiger Woodss decision to play the Honda Classic for the first time since he was a 17-year-old amateur gave instant credibility and increased visibility to a tournament once considered the weak link of the Florida swing.

title: President Offers Theme of Nation Seeing a Comeback
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has a new message: America has gotten its groove back.

title: New Light on Days Before Rutgers Students Death
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  After discovering that his roommate had set up a webcam in their room and watched him kissing a man, Tyler Clementi sent an e-mail to the resident assistant in the dormitory that said, I feel my privacy has been violated, and I am extremely uncomfortable sharing a room with someone who would act in this wildly inappropriate manner.

title: Manhattan Man Indicted in Pipe Bomb Case
description: A Manhattan man arrested last year on charges that he planned to detonate pipe bombs in New York City has been indicted on terrorism charges, the authorities announced Wednesday.

title: The Return of Sniglets
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  If you watched a television show called Not Necessarily the News on HBO in the mid- to late-1980s, you will appreciate this one. Although the practice of making up nonsense words existed well before then, the comedian Rich Hall popularized and renamed them as sniglets for a whole new generation. Sniglets, Mr. Hall said, are words that dont appear in the dictionary but should.

title: Fading Sounds of Doo-Wop
description: Ronnies Is Clifton Music in New Jersey is about to close after 40 years: a sign, many say, that doo-wop is on its last legs.

title: Lottery Numbers
Republican Who Bluntly Backed Gay Marriage Loses Some Support Back Home
description: ALBANY  With a blunt one-liner  They can take the job and shove it  describing his disregard for the political consequences of his decision to support same-sex marriage last year, Senator Roy J. McDonald, a Republican from Saratoga, became a hero to gay rights groups.

title: Retirement Throws Maines Senate Race Into Chaos
description: PORTLAND, Me.  Senator Olympia J. Snowes surprise announcement that she will retire set off frantic political calculations throughout Maine on Wednesday, with former governors, members of the states Congressional delegation and many others hurriedly weighing runs for office that they had previously ruled out.

title: Democrats Favored to Pick Up Snowe Seat
description: The retirement of Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine is about as damaging to a partys electoral prospects as these things get, turning a seat that Republicans were very likely to retain into one they will probably lose.

title: After a Costly Scandal, Binghamton Begins Rebuilding
description: VESTAL, N.Y.  Three years ago, Binghamton University students flooded onto the floor of the Events Center here, celebrating its first berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament. The university had made the expensive and controversial choice to compete at the Division I level less than a decade earlier, and the decision appeared to have paid off.

title: Romney Debases the G.O.P. Base
description: So far, the base of the Republican party has sent Mitt Romney a message: Theyre not yet convinced that hes their guy.

title: Party Purity
description: Percentage of the time senators voted with their parties.

title: Knicks Turn Slow Start Into an Easy Finish
description: To measure just how far the Knicks have come, how much has changed in a short period, one could count the number of bodies used, or the standing ovations they enjoyed or the unmitigated giddiness that overtook Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.

title: Turnaround King Tries to Convince Investors He Hasnt Lost a Step
description: Over the last decade on Wall Street, Wilbur L. Ross Jr. has been called many names, including a vulture, a turnaround king and Mr. Distress.

title: More Blacks and Latinos Admitted to Elite New York High Schools
description: The number of black and Latino students who were accepted at one of eight highly selective high schools in New York City increased from last year, according to admissions statistics released on Wednesday by the citys Education Department. The uptick for the two groups reverses a years-long decline in admissions to the schools, where admittance is based on a single test.

title: Tensions Raise Specter of Gas at $5 a Gallon
description: HOUSTON  Gasoline for $5 a gallon? The possibility is hardly far-fetched.

title: A Splash of Romance in the Search for Paint
description: ACE HARDWARE this week is introducing an ad campaign for a new line of premium paints.

title: U.S. Judge Strikes Down F.D.A. Cigarette Labels
description: A federal judge on Wednesday declared unconstitutional a Food and Drug Administration requirement that tobacco companies prominently display graphic warning labels on cigarette packages.

title: Missed Opportunity for Rivals of Romney, but Another Looms
description: MittRomneys Republican opponents have not missed their last opportunity todeliver a knockout blow to him, but they may have missed their best one.

title: Romney Sets Off Furor on Contraception Bill
description: Perhaps the question was poorly worded. Or perhaps it was a slip of a tired tongue.

title: Candidates Scramble to Create Differences
description: DETROIT  Facing big hurdles here in Mitt Romneys native state, Rick Santorum seized on the novel tactic of attacking his rival for agreeing with him.

title: Queens School Faces Heavy Demand on Eve of Kindergarten Deadline
William Gay Dies at 70; Writer Tied to Tennessee
description: William Gay, a self-taught novelist from rural Tennessee who emerged from obscurity in his late 50s with critically praised books in the Southern Gothic style, died last Thursday at his home, a log cabin in Hohenwald, southwest of Nashville. He was 70.

description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Closer: Lin and Davis Help Each Other
description: When your teams starting point guard and rising star is a relatively small player, has never played a huge amount of minutes and relies on being able to get to the basket to score, it is a good idea to have a solid backup.

title: For Some Women, the Misery of Mumbais Dance Bars Looks Like a Big Step Up
description: Beautiful Thing, a book about Mumbais notorious sex industry, and the news it brings about young womens lives will break your heart several times over, Dwight Garner writes in the New York Times.

description: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a healthy 30-year-old man with constant, stabbing abdominal pain?

description: NYT Front Page for 03/01/2012

title: North Korea: Have We Seen This Movie Before?
description: HONG KONG  Its a fair question: Is North Korea acting in good faith, offering a monitored shutdown of a nuclear facility in exchange for a quarter-million tons of food aid? Or is this a kind of diplomatic Groundhog Day, fated to end once again with the Americans duped and angry over more North Korean perfidy?

title: Face of Hope Reflects Calm in Kashmir
description: In rural Kashmir, people will listen with great care to any man who tells them how he plans to bring roads, electricity, jobs and good schools to their villages, which have been impoverished by decades of strife, Manu Joseph writes in the International Herald Tribune.

title: In Illinois Town, Scenes of Devastation
description: Updated | 4:30 p.m.At least 12 people were killed in three states after a powerful storm system ripped across the Midwest and South. As our colleagues Monica Davey and A.G. Sulzberger reported, the storms left pockets of devastation, reducing blocks and businesses in some areas to rubble.

title: Green Oasis
description: A new food co-op sprouts in Clinton Hill.

title: News Quiz | March 1, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Blast in Istanbul Injures 10 Police Officers
description: HATAY, Turkey  Ten police officers were injured on Thursday when a booby-trapped motorcycle exploded in front of the headquarters of the Turkish governing party in Istanbul, officials said.

title: March 1, 1954 | Puerto Rican Nationalists Open Fire on House of Representatives
description: On March 1, 1954, the Puerto Rican nationalists Lolita Lebron, Rafael Miranda, Irving Flores Rodriguez and Andres Figueroa Cordero entered the United States Capitols House of Representatives chamber and began firing at members of Congress, injuring five.

title: The Unsinkables
description: WHO was the unsinkable Molly Brown?WHO is Janet Kalstrom, and WHOM does she dress up as?

title: Syrian Forces Overwhelm Stronghold of Rebels in Homs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian Army overwhelmed the main rebel stronghold in the embattled city of Homs on Thursday, setting the stage for its elite soldiers to turn their attention  and superior firepower  to other insurgent redoubts farther north, despite the increasing international pressure for a cease-fire and humanitarian access.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 1, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article A Hollywood Insider and a Map of the Stars.

title: Two American Soldiers Die in Shooting at Afghan Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two more United States soldiers were killed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday when an Afghan soldier, apparently in league with a civilian, killed an Afghan tower guard and attacked a barracks with gunfire and a rocket, officials said.

title: Postcard From a New London
description: The worlds eyes will be fixed on London this summer as athletes march into town for the 2012 Olympic Games. The image of the city presented by TV networks will more than likely be familiar: The global TV audience will be treated to a romanticized version of the city, with helicopter shots of Big Ben competing for time against footage of Buckingham Palace guards staring stone-faced into the distance and double-decker buses bouncing unsteadily through too-narrow streets, writes Craig Taylor in this Sundays New York Times Magazine.

title: Republicans and Fiscal Responsibility
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: East Enders, Kissing
description: Wedding photos discovered on eBay.

title: Migratory Models
description: Theyve flocked to London in search of success.

title: Pretty as a Thousand Postcards
description: A visualization of London landmarks, as captured by hundreds of tourists.

title: Titans of the Stage
description: Theater remains rooted at the center of Londons culture. Actors like these are the reason.

title: Here Is London
description: Scenes of Londons youth, commuters, fans and more.

title: Explaining Londoners
description: 1. Does everyone drink like Winston Churchill?

title: Landmarks in Lights
description: The Olympic Stadium and the Shard.

title: Oh, London, You Drama Queen
description: An invisible bridge spans the Thames at Blackfriars. Victorian pilings jut from the river, the railway they once supported long gone. Dangling above them on this cold day, helicopters surveilled thousands of strikers and supporters processing loudly through central London. It was Nov. 30, 2011, and two million public-sector workers were on strike.

title: True Londoners Are Extinct
description: Later this year, thousands of Olympians will march into London under flapping flags, and the global TV audience will be treated to a romanticized version of the city, with helicopter shots of Big Ben competing for time against footage of Buckingham Palace guards staring stone-faced into the distance and double-decker buses bouncing unsteadily through too-narrow streets. By the end of the ceremonies, youll have seen the citys bridges so many times that youll wish they had all fallen down years ago.

title: What Would You Name Your Neighborhood?
description: There are many neighborhoods within New York City, from SoHo to Bushwick to Hells Kitchen. Each name has a story. What goes into naming a neighborhood? What makes one neighborhood in the same area different from another? What makes your neighborhood unique? What might you name it if you were in charge of giving it a new name? Why?

title: A Criminal Virus Born of Russia and the Soviet Past Spreads
description: A network of immigrants from the former Soviet Union conspired to steal more than a quarter of a billion dollars by manipulating the insurance laws in the state of New York, reports William K. Rashbaum.

title: Tibetan Writer Says China Is Blocking Her From Award
description: BEIJING  A prominent Tibetan writer living here in Beijing said on Thursday that the police had placed her under house arrest to prevent her from receiving a prize for culture from the Dutch Embassy.

title: Meet Gurgaons Top Cop: Former Engineer K.K. Sindhu
description: K.K. Sindhu, 50, became the police commissioner of Gurgaon, the fast-growing outsourcing city south of New Delhi, last November. The Indian Police Service officer studied civil engineering and worked as a resource officer with the federal Ministry of Water Resources before joining the police service in 1986. Policing is much better, he said in a recent interview with India Ink.

title: A 1,400-Horsepower Tank, Batteries Included
description: Some hybrid vehicles are engineered to be as light as possible. This one is projected to weigh around 140,000 pounds, fully equipped.

title: Fantasy Focus: Market Value vs. Performance Value
description: One way to get ready for your fantasy baseball auction or draft is to project out the stats of all the relevant players and convert those stats to dollar values (or draft slots). For example, if you think Justin Verlander will win about 18 games, strike out 240 batters and have an earned run average of 3.00 and a WHIP of 1.05, your algorithm might say hes worth $30 in a $260-budget, 12-team A.L.-only league. (This is a rough estimate, and your mileage may vary.) You might also decide those numbers make him an early second-round pick in your 15-team mixed league draft.

title: Mount Holyoke College Announces Tuition Freeze
description: Mount Holyoke College has announced that it will not increase tuition or room and board for the 2012-2013 academic year.

description: In a sign that tensions are still running high in the Maldives, hundreds of supporters of the island nations former president blocked the current president from addressing Parliament on Thursday.

description: The Internet speed maestros are now facing a daunting new challenge in mobile computing  with its explosion in traffic, vast tracts of slow-poke bandwidth, and varied software on smartphones. I wrote an article about this issue for Thursdays New York Times.

title: The Vanity of the Bonfires
description: With deadly protests still raging in Afghanistan following claims that U.S. military personnel inadvertently destroyed Korans, commentators are wondering about the fallout.

title: Europeans Forage for Green Shoots
description: LONDON  Will this week be remembered as the one in which the debt-burdened economies of Europe began to turn the corner?

title: Taking Money Out of the Company
description: In my last post, I discussed my plan to pay myself interest on the money that I had loaned to the company, and I received a lot of useful advice.

description: CVR Energy is trying to ward off Carl C. Icahns unwanted advances.

title: Scouting the Draft: Memphiss Dontari Poe
description: There were plenty of winners and losers at the scouting combine, but perhaps no player helped his stock more than Memphis defensive tackle Dontari Poe. The numbers are staggering: 6-4, 346 pounds, a 4.98 40-yard dash, and 44 bench press reps. He has a muscular physique despite weighing as much as two DeSean Jacksons, and he looked incredibly athletic in position drills. I had to take a look.

title: Financial Rally Sends Shares Higher

But in this city of medieval souks and alleyways, not to mention palatial out-of-town villas, a larger ambition blooms. Some residents, native and non-native, want the city to become a genuine art destination, one that does not just rely on the past.

title: Theater Talkback: Howard Kissel, A Man Who Relished Culture
description: Certain faces, when glimpsed in crowded rooms or public places, are beacons of reassurance, confirmations that your world is still on its axis. For me, the cultural critic Howard Kissel, who died at 69 last week, had one of those faces. And whenever I would register its presence at the theater (which wasnt hard to do, since Howard had a face that naturally loomed), I would feel a click of relief.

title: When Doctors Dont Tell the Truth
description: Every spring, a former patient and his elderly parents would drive two hours to the hospital carrying chocolates for the staff  an epicurean celebration of the mans successful liver transplant a few years earlier. The patient, tall, in his 30s and with sandy-brown hair, handed out the boxes, and his parents, their parched-earth faces beaming with joy, shook everyones hands.

title: The British Are Here
description: Craig Taylor had a rough time when he first moved to London from Canada a dozen years ago. Someone tried to pick his friends pocket. A scam artist took advantage of him. Wandering around with an ancient A-Z street atlas, he often felt lonely, duped, underprepared, faceless, friendless. But something about the city got under his skin, so he resolved to push beyond his own experience and take its measure. Happily for us, the result is Londoners, a rich and exuberant kaleidoscopic portrait of a great, messy, noisy, daunting, inspiring, maddening, enthralling, constantly shifting Rorschach test of a place, as befits the books subtitle, The Days and Nights of London Now  As Told by Those Who Love It, Hate It, Live It, Left It, and Long for It.

title: How the Grinch Stole the Lorax
description: Since its publication in 1971 The Lorax, by Dr. Seuss, has occasionally been caught up in squalls of controversy, most of it cooked up by people choosing to be outraged by the books mild allegorical moral of ecological responsibility. In our own globally warmed, ideologically fevered moment there has been a minor flurry of predictable, pre-emptive bloviation aimed at Universals movie version, Dr. Seuss The Lorax, which is supposedly part of a left-wing Hollywood conspiracy to brainwash Americas children into hating capitalism and loving trees.

Now the bad: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a lawsuit, filed by more than 80 farmers and agricultural organizations against Monsanto, which sought to protect organic farmers from litigation if their crops became contaminated by Monsantos GMO seeds. From 1997 to 2010, Monsanto sued 144 farmers for patent infringement, a number that the judge said is hardly significant when compared to the number of farms in the United States (just try telling that to the 144 farmers).

title: Now the Plutocrat Takes on Capitalism
description: When we last checked in on the investor and one-time magazine subject Jeremy Grantham a few weeks ago, he had just published an op-ed in The Financial Times declaring the United States a plutocracy. (Recall, his firm manages around $100 billion in assets.) Since then, his quarterly letter has appeared, and this time it isnt simply the American political-financial complex in his sights, but capitalism itself. (Recall again the mans authority: $100 billion.)

title: Rick Santorum and Religious Freedom
description: In a piece tinged with hysteria and largely devoid of evidence, the New Yorkers George Packer accuses of Rick Santorum of seeking to overthrow the Constitutions ban on an establishment of religion, compares American religious conservatives to Salafists and theocrats (I have some dim memory of the days when Packer was worried about overheated rhetoric in American politics), and implicitly analogizes Santorum to the Muslim extremists who have sought to execute a young man named Hamza Kashgari for blasphemy.

title: Obama Seeks to End Subsidies for Oil and Gas Companies
description: NASHUA, N.H.  With his re-election fate increasingly tied to the price Americans are paying at the gas pump, President Obama asked Congress on Thursday to end $4 billion in subsidies for oil and gas companies and vowed to tackle the countrys long-term energy issues while shunning phony election-year promises about lower gas prices.

description: Justin Long has agreed to weather the withering assessments of Jeff Goldblum when he makes his Broadway debut in Seminar beginning April 3.

title: Mark Morris Dance Group Headed to China
description: The Mark Morris Dance Group will make its first foray into China, performing in Guangzhou and Macao from May 25 to June 2, the company said on Thursday. A contingent of 18 dancers and six musicians will make the trip. On the program: Festival Dance, Grand Duo and V in Guangzhou and the Eleven and Double sections from Mozart Dances and the work Grand Duo. The visit will include master classes, workshops and question and answer sessions with Mr. Morris, the company said. Mark Morris Dance Group will begin a series of performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight.

title: Digital Notes: Indies Settle With LimeWire, and Kim Dotcom Speaks Up
description: A New LimeWire Settlement: An organization that represents independent record companies around the world has settled its lawsuit against LimeWire, the defunct file-sharing service. The size of LimeWires settlement payment was not disclosed, but the organization, Merlin, said the amount was commensurate with the $105 million settlement the major labels reached with LimeWire last year. (Merlin estimates its members market share in the United States at about 10 percent.) Merlin was founded in 2008 partly as a result of the indies frustration at not sharing in other industry settlements as well as not getting equity in MySpace Music, as the major labels did.

title: Next Geoffrion Takes the Ice in Montreal
description: In the whoosh of one pre-deadline trade, Blake Geoffrion went from a relatively obscure young player in Nashville to a prodigy upholding a proud legacy in Montreal. This could only happen in the world of the Canadiens, in whose Bell Centre hang the jerseys of Geoffrions great grandfather, Howie Morenz, and his grandfather, Bernie Boom Boom Geoffrion.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Balmain
description: Backstage at Balmain, everyone was singing Happy Birthday (in English) to the woman in charge of the hairstylist Sam McKnights team. Can I interest you in a small sandwich? someone asked, gesturing towards the catering table. Heres a Coca-Light, Karlie Kloss said, smiling, as she got up from McKnights chair. Her hair was loose and just a little wavy  what McKnight described as so nothing, created by letting hair dry without heat or product. For the few girls with unruly strands, he tamed them by straightening and working back in some wave. The clothes are quite full on, he said of a collection apparently inspired by Faberge eggs. Tom Pecheux was in McKnights camp. Barely anything, was his description of skin massaged with cream like Este Lauders Idealist. Makeup was merely a light touch of concealer and contour in Sculpt or Shadowy with brown or black mascara on brows. Why not? They are gorgeous girls, he said. Balmain is usually about glowing, fresh bombshells; these girls are slightly more rough and grungy.

title: What Next for Gas Prices?
description: As I write in Thursdays Times, gasoline prices keep going higher and higher.

title: British Museums Buy Second Titian for More Than $70 Million
description: The National Gallery in London announced on Thursday that it had secured funding to purchase Titians Diana and Callisto together with the National Galleries of Scotland for $71.7 million, thereby ensuring that the work, along with another great painting by the 16th-century master, would stay on public view.

title: Congressional Redistricting Plans Go to a Judge
description: ALBANY  Legislative leaders, unable to agree on how to reduce New Yorks Congressional delegation by two seats, submitted competing plans late Wednesday night for a federal judge to consider as she develops a redistricting plan that could be imposed by the court.

title: Rick Santorum on Obama and Unemployment
description: On President Obama and Unemployment

title: U.C.L.A. Fends Off Criticism of Discipline Problems
description: The U.C.L.A. basketball team and athletic department are on the defensive, rebutting a Sports Illustrated article about alleged serious player discipline problems. The article by George Dohrmann was published Wednesday and detailed alleged partying, drug and alcohol abuse, fights between current and former players and the failure to maintain discipline by Coach Ben Howland.

title: Jazz Musicians Expand Pension Protest
description: The musicians union for New York City has begun an advertising campaign and plans to expand protests outside of jazz clubs as part of its efforts to win pension benefits for jazz artists, union leaders said Thursday.

title: European Leaders Challenged by Rise in Joblessness
description: BRUSSELS  At their first summit meeting in recent memory at which financial markets were not baying at the door, European leaders on Thursday sought to show they could confront the social cost of fighting the sovereign debt crisis, whose severity was underlined by new jobless figures that hit a euro-era high.

title: Driving School Owners Charged in Test Cheating Scheme
description: He said he knew little to no English. Not a problem, he was told. But the driving test was in English, he said in his native Mandarin, so how could he possibly pass?

title: The Perils of Coming of Age in a Trailer Park
description: It takes real talent to make something beautiful out of a trailer park. Girlchild, Tupelo Hassmans lacerating debut novel, is the story of Rory Dawn Hendrix, a young girl growing up in the Calle, a cluster of mobile homes on a plot of dust outside Reno, Nev. Ms. Hassman is such a poised storyteller that her prose practically struts. Her words are as elegant as they are fierce. A voice as fresh as hers is so rare that at times I caught myself cheering, and it wasnt necessarily for the kid.

title: Guest Post | Tools and Tips for World Read-Aloud Day
description: Are Read Across America Day (on March 2) and World Read Aloud Day (on March 7) on your calendar this year? If not, we hope youll consider adding them  especially after hearing what this guest blogger has to say about the many interesting ways the age-old activity of reading aloud can be reconceived for 2012.

Behind the Crackdown on Insider Trading
description: If anyone had not already realized it, insider trading is the hot white-collar crime these days. Look no further than the new public service announcement by Michael Douglas  and his character Gordon Gekko  disclaiming that greed is good by encouraging tips to the F.B.I. about insider trading.

title: Apps to Stem the Flood of Catalogs and Junk Mail
description: Last fall, I wrote about a service from Catalog Choice that helps you reduce unwanted catalogs and junk mail by using snail mail.

title: Vikings Finally Have Deal on Stadium
description: After years of fits and starts, the Minnesota Vikings moved a big step closer to having a new home when the states top political leaders unveiled a tentative agreement to build a $975 million stadium next to the aging Metrodome in Minneapolis.

title: M. Wells Owners Plan a Steakhouse in Queens
description: Hugue Dufour and Sarah Obraitis, the married couple who owned M. Wells  the wildly popular diner-style restaurant in Long Island City, Queens, that lost its lease and closed last summer  plan to open a new restaurant in the same neighborhood in late fall.

title: American Idol Tops Wednesday Ratings
description: A two-hour edition of American Idol  which focused on the top 12 female performers  provided another easy ratings win for Fox on Wednesday. According to Nielsen estimates, the singing competition averaged just over 17 million viewers, although it suffered another slight drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared to last week. The downward trend for Idol in adults 18-to-49 has allowed Modern Family on ABC to get within striking distance in the advertiser-beloved category; it was just one tenth of a ratings point below Idol.

title: A Well-Deserved Defeat for the Religious Right
description: I was glad to see the Senate defeat the Blunt amendment today, rejecting an attempt by religious conservatives to weaken the separation of church and state.

title: My Bumpy Night at Robertas
description: You know that moment when a server circles back to your table to ask if everything is all right? Usually they do this within a minute or two after placing the plate in front of you. Sometimes they do it so soon you havent even had a chance to taste the food.

title: Reform Bill Scaled Back as Italians Apply Politics
description: ROME  The Italian Senate on Thursday approved a set of measures aimed at fostering economic growth, but critics said that some proposals had been watered down, a sign of the roadblocks facing Prime Minister Mario Monti as he tries to turn around Italys stagnant economy.

title: Bundesbank Fears Risks in European Central Bank Lending Policy
description: FRANKFURT  A day after the European Central Bank showered the Continents banking system with cash, the German central bank appeared to be growing more openly restive about the risk of lending to banks that would go out of business without access to cheap money.

description: A West Village hookah lounge and restaurant has agreed to pay $200,000 in back wages and penalties for underpaying about 25 employees, many of them immigrants, and firing two workers who reported the violations to the authorities, the New York attorney general announced in a statement on Thursday.

description: Chita Rivera will return to Broadway as Princess Puffer in a new production of Rupert Holmess musical The Mystery of Edwin Drood, marking its first return to Broadway since its 1986 Tony Awards triumph.

title: New Plan: Yankees Look to Cut Payroll
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Strange rumblings about fiscal restraint and lower payrolls have been emanating from the Yankees for several months, and Hal Steinbrenner, the managing general partner of the team, confirmed Thursday that he wants the payroll to be cut by about $20 million, down to the critical threshold of $189 million, within two years.

title: Cellphone Interference
description: I went on a long walk with a friend Ive known for ages. She made innumerable cellphone calls. She worried about: the modest cost of an upcoming trip, whether she should negotiate a lower price on the cabin, the destination, whether her companion would enjoy herself, and wrapping up plans. I was fed up and exhausted, and we were an hour from home. Finally, I said: I dont want to get involved. This is your bad trip. This happens fairly often with her. Should I throw in the towel?

title: 10 Questions With Rick Santorum
description: After losses in Arizona and Michigan, the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum seeks new momentum for next weeks Super Tuesday contests. Mr. Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, aims to move beyond controversies over his views on social issues and emphasize economic proposals  including his signature idea of eliminating corporate taxes for manufacturing firms. Before flying to Washington state, he sat down in an Atlanta airport on Thursday with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC. What follows is a condensed, edited version of their conversation. (Full video, divided by chapter.)

title: In Knots
description: Writing in Salon in 2009, Laura Miller noted that the canon favors books about men in boats over women in houses, and its true: the boat is the beloved vessel of the Great American Novel. Theres also the road, the battlefield, the ball field, the farm, but for better or worse, from Moby-Dick to Spartina, nothing has captured the Odyssean spirit of the American story  or the splendor and ravages of testosterone  like a boat traveling through open waters. Unless its that other favorite setting, the boarding school.

title: In Filings, Disney Rebuffs Criticism of Shareholders Advisory Service

title: A Father and Son Reunion on the Way to the Abyss
description: Early in Being Flynn, the new movie directed by Paul Weitz, Jonathan Flynn slides behind the wheel of a yellow cab as his voice, on the soundtrack, gives vent to a barrage of misanthropy. It is hard for a movie lover not to detect a wink in this otherwise perfectly ordinary scene, since Jonathan is played by Robert De Niro, the most famous taxi driver in movies. Being Flynn is a much milder movie than Taxi Driver, pursuing intimate themes rather than big ideas, but Jonathan Flynn and Travis Bickle are linked by the discrepancy between self-image and reality and also by Mr. De Niros gift for portraying alienated men at odds with themselves.

title: Flex-Fuel Amendment Makes for Strange Bedfellows
description: Faced with a bill that would require 80 percent of gasoline-burning cars and trucks to be compatible with ethanol and methanol by the 2018 model year, stakeholders who typically disagree on critical issues find themselves in a rare position. They agree.

title: Riders on the Storm
description: It is an almost inviolable rule that Hollywood attempts at surf movies are not received well by surfers. Part of it has to do with a studio tendency toward surf tropes and clichs (Cowabunga! Hang Ten!). More of it has to do with the nature of the sport itself: it breeds localism. Not just the xenophobic, occasionally violent expressions of localism that enforce the pecking order, but, more prevalent, a fierce love of place. To learn the personality of a particular wave is to become intimate with the contours of a landscape, to map that landscape and make it yours. Surfers will say that the character of a break influences the local culture. In other words, a filmmaker who wishes to get a surf spot right by its locals has his work cut out for him.

title: French Journalists Escape Syria for Lebanon
description: Updated | 6:11 p.m. Two French journalists who were trapped inside the Syrian city of Homs for more than a week arrived safely in Lebanon on Thursday, according to Le Figaro, the newspaper for which they both work.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: A Hidden Fee Is Set to Rise
description: INSIDE the interest rate quoted on your home mortgage lies a small hidden fee that has been charged by government-sponsored entities like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for more than three decades. Its an add-on rate known as the guarantee fee.

title: Midas Touch in St. Petersburg: Friends of Putin Glow Brightly
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Arkady R. Rotenberg, a former judo coach, is now a billionaire industrialist, having made a fortune selling pipe to the state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom.

title: Israel Plans Interceptor Missile Test and Gives Neighbors Early Notice
description: JERUSALEM  Israel, in an unusual move, announced on Thursday that it would soon conduct the first test of an advanced antiballistic missile system designed to intercept incoming missiles from enemies like Syria and Iran.

title: You Dont Mess With Them
description: People are wondering how the Christian right will react to the new ABC comedy GCB, based on a novel called Good Christian Bitches, but its a silly question. Long before there was a Bible Belt, this kind of woman was in the Bible  Jezebel was the first true mean girl (Revelation 2:20).

title: Ill Be Your Mirror, Or Maybe Your Killer
description: In the first moments of Beautiful Bone, a duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, Ms. Lieber clutches Ms. Smiths head to her breast. The gesture is tender and aggressive, an embrace and a smothering. The ambiguity is arresting, and the remainder of the dance, which had its debut at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday, sustains it.

title: Jerusalem Under Siege, a Sorceress Intervenes
description: CHICAGO  Given the current bloody turmoil in the Middle East you could imagine an opera director seizing on Handels Rinaldo for its contemporary relevance. The story tells of Christian forces during the First Crusade, led by their determined general, Goffredo, and the heroic knight Rinaldo, as they lay siege to Jerusalem to take down its king, Argante. The formidable king is abetted by and enamored of Armida, the imperious queen of Damascus, an expert in sorcery.

title: From Bucks: Apps to Cut Down Catalog Clutter
description: Our colleagues over at Bucks, The Timess personal-finance blog, have a cool post on apps that can help cut down on catalog junk mail.

title: Rising Even While Seated
description: The tenor saxophonist Ted Brown remained seated during his first set at the Kitano Hotel in Murray Hill on Wednesday night, and his playing often felt so retiring and interior that it barely met the minimum requirements for performance. This was a matter of aesthetic inclination, as Mr. Brown demonstrated in the finer moments of the set. You might have caught yourself leaning slightly forward then, as if to catch the nuance of an absorbing story gently told.

title: Sizing Up Health Impacts a Year After Fukushima
description: Health impacts from the radioactive materials released in the Fukushima Daiichi meltdowns will probably be too small to be easily measured, according to experts assembled by the Health Physics Society for a panel discussion on Thursday. And the area cordoned off by the Japanese government as uninhabitable is probably far too large, the experts said.

title: Theater Listings: March 2  8
description: Theater

title: In Arizona, the Bigoted Birther is Back
description: There is an argument that its best to ignore crazy people. You have nothing to gain by reasoning with the guy on the subway shouting about the end of the world. But what if the crazy guys a prominent law enforcer, and what if hes shouting about the president of the United States?

title: Serving Nostalgia at Nitehawk Cinema and IFC Center
description: If you watched last Sundays Academy Awards show, youd know that going to the movies means different things to different people. For Reese Witherspoon, growing up, it was a family outing; for Brad Pitt, it was an escape from reality. For Matthew Viragh, owner of the Nitehawk Cinema, which opened in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn last June, its nostalgia.

title: Conversations With the Stars of the Movie Goon
description: Just in time to join the debate about fighting in hockey, along comes the comedy Goon, the No. 1 movie in Canada and now available on demand to American cable subscribers ahead of its theatrical opening on March 30.

title: Cracking the Curious Case of Picassos Ghost Subject
description: A 1904 Picasso hanging in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York depicts a skeletal woman, her eyes hollow, her cheeks sunken as she presses down with all her might on an iron. The painting, Woman Ironing, from Picassos Blue Period, has long been considered one of the institutions most important works. It has also been one of its greatest mysteries. For years conservators have known that beneath the surface lies the ghost of a figure  a three-quarter-length view of a man with a mustache  which Picasso had painted over.

title: A Buyout Fund, First Backed by LVMH, Carves Its Own Niche
description: While it may share the same first letter as LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, and counts the French luxury conglomerate as an investor, L Capital would like everyone to know that it is its own firm.

title: 36 Hours: Austin, Tex.
description: THE laid-back capital of Texas has long been a haven for countercultural types, with tattoo artists, bohemian coeds and techies biking side by side along the glistening shores of Lady Bird Lake. But these days, Austin is more chic than shabby. New upscale restaurants  many that rely on local, organic ingredients  are popping up all over the city, along with bars featuring artisanal concoctions. Meanwhile, the South by Southwest (SXSW) music, film and interactive festival (this year March 9 to 18) continues to draw an affluent crowd of technology geeks and celebrities. On April 27 to 29, Food and Wine Magazine will court foodies with its first culinary fte in Texas. Then, in November, the Circuit of the Americas Formula One track will open, drawing race car fans from around the world. But the old Austin isnt hard to find: You can still hear the twang of a country guitar in many doorways and chug of Lone Star at just about any bar.

title: 36 Hours in Austin, Tex.
description: New upscale restaurants and bars are popping up all over the city, but the old Austin isnt hard to find.

title: Andrew Carnegie Was Here
description: ANDREW CARNEGIES colossal, understated mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street is closed until 2013 while the current resident, the Cooper-Hewitt museum, renovates the interior. The last of the Carnegies left the 1902 house in 1946, but Carnegie, a steel magnate, affected a much wider swath of his hill than just his Fifth Avenue blockfront.

title: 1994: Jobs
description: An ad ran by Mitt Romney's 1994 campaign for Senate, attacking Ted Kennedy's record on jobs.

title: In Paris, Celebrating Karl Lagerfeld
description: Its easy to forget that in addition to Chanel, Fendi and his newly reintroduced signature collection, Karl Lagerfeld, for the last four seasons, has also designed a collection for Hogan, a division of the luxury Italian footwear company Tods. Mr. Lagerfeld makes multitasking look second nature, so his Hogan collection was the subject of a special celebration this evening in the midst of Paris Fashion Week.

title: Q & A

description: Images from the films in the New York International Childrens Film Festival.

description: Google started its unified privacy policy on Thursday.

title: Kids Film Festival: Fear, Astonishment and the Beatles
description: The New York International Childrens Film Festival has grown into a supremely confident teenager.

title: A Sale of Knives by an Eccentric Maker
description: The reclusive blacksmith William W. Scagel lived off the grid in the woods near Muskegon, Mich. From the 1920s to the 60s, he manufactured luxury knives there, with ergonomically curved horn and antler handles, powering his home and workshop with a windmill, old submarine batteries and a Cadillac engine.

title: NBC News to Expand Presence on Radio
description: NBC News, the top-rated network news division on television, is eying growth opportunities in an old-fashioned medium, radio.

title: Sculptures That Answer Back
description: It sounds like a clich to say that the radicalism of art from the 60s and early 70s has often been sanitized from art history. But you get an idea of what was considered feasible  and whats been left out of the canon  when you look at the work of Juan Downey.

title: Were Fabulous, but Are You?
description: In recent years Eric Fischl has displayed a remarkable obliviousness to possible perceptions of his work. In 2000 he created a memorial to the tennis star Arthur Ashe in the form of a giant, Rodinesque bronze sculpture of a lumpy, naked man in the act of serving. Installed outdoors at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, it became for many fans of the game a source of consternation that the figure was nude, did not resemble Ashe and held in one hand only the stump of his racket.

title: A Survey of a Different Color
description: One of the best Whitney Biennials in recent memory may or may not contain a lot more outstanding art than its predecessors, but thats not the point. The 2012 incarnation is a new and exhilarating species of exhibition, an emerging curatorial life form, at least for New York.

title: A Personal Landscape in Patagonia
description: Thick clouds hang low over the rugged landscape, where freshly-slaughtered pigs and lambs can be found just as easily as leather-faced men on horseback. Shadowy figures emerge from mist-covered paths, lending an air of mystery to Jorge Uzons images of remote towns in Chiles Patagonia region. Rendered in black and white, his photographs feel quiet and intimate.

title: In Paris, Cloaked in Fog and Anticipation
description: PARIS

title: What Square Footage Doesnt Say
description: THE quirks of residential layout dictate that any measurement of square footage in a house will be debatable at best, agents and other experts say.

title: Collecting Emotion, and Not in Tranquillity
description: Paula Van der Oests Black Butterflies is a rending biographical portrait of the poet Ingrid Jonker, who has been called the South African Sylvia Plath because both women destroyed themselves at an early age and had what might be called daddy issues. Plath was 30 when she died of carbon monoxide poisoning in 1963. Jonker drowned herself two years later at 31.

title: Vietnams Nuclear Dreams Blossom Despite Doubts
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Inside an unheated classroom at the Institute for Nuclear Science and Technology here about 20 young government technicians from Vietnams incipient nuclear power industry kept on their winter jackets on the first morning of a 10-day workshop on radiation.

title: Holding a Mirror to Ike, and to Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bold Plan to Reshape the Central Valley Flood Plain
description: Jacob Katz stood shin-deep in a flooded rice paddy that is often dried out at this time of year. He thrust his hand into a writhing mass of baby salmon in his net and plucked three of the silver fry from the wind-whipped waters surface.

title: Stations File Suit Against Dillers Internet Distribution Company
description: Local television stations in New York filed two lawsuits on Thursday against Aereo, a start-up company backed by Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp that seeks to distribute the stations via the Internet to paying subscribers.

title: Trading Up Amid the Bulldozers
description: EVERY now and then when a new furnished model would open at Meadowbrook Pointe, an age-restricted condominium community of flats, town houses and villas in Westbury that will eventually have 720 units, Carol Uffer would stroll over from her two-bedroom villa within the complex to take a look.

title: Longing for the Beauty That Is Rome in the Form of Earthly Goddesses
description: Gianni, the gentle mamas boy and alter ego of Gianni Di Gregorio, the 63-year-old director and star of the wistful Italian comedy The Salt of Life, is every man who reaches a certain age and feels his vitality waning. Gazing into the mirror, he notices the heavy bags under his eyes and his sagging chin and is seized with a longing for his lost youth.

title: Revising the Limits for the Unlimited
description: Sometimes, all-you-can-eat does not mean all you can eat.

title: Irans Nuclear Program: Choices for Israel and the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Rehab Loans to the Rescue
description: AFTER months of searching for a mother-daughter home that they could afford in the Bergen County town where they were renting, Adrian and Rosanna Mercado came upon a Victorian with enough room for them to live upstairs and Mrs. Mercados parents to live on the first floor. The only problem was that the century-old house was in serious need of repairs.

title: The Extraordinary, Glimpsed in the Ordinary
description: These are not the parts of New York City that fire the imagination: salad bars, subway entrances, roll-down security gates, the stairs of the M15 bus, open truck windows from which drivers thick elbows hang like Sunday hams.

title: Obesity and the Military: A Retired Generals View
description: To the Editor:

title: Miracle Leads to Pairing With Woods and Westwood
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  On Wednesday night Miguel Angel Carballo sent a message to his fans that said, I need a miracle.

title: Tracing the Great Recession to a Memo 40 Years Ago
description: Heist: Who Stole the American Dream? is a documentary polemic that comes out swinging. Immediately after the films opening scene of an Occupy Wall Street demonstration, a chipper narrator announces:

title: Back to the 70s, When a Traffic Jam Could Be Art
description: Do you feel that? Constance Lewallen, a curator at the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, said to a group of journalists and students. The crowd, gathered just inside the museum entrance, stopped, looking perplexed.

title: Adult Responsibilities, but a Childs Sensibility
description: Next years Oscars, if they were to include the just-for-fun idea of outstanding performance by a setting, should have a nominee in Boy. This movie from New Zealand, filmed in a Maori village near the Bay of Plenty, belongs in the pantheon of quaint and quirky locales that make for memorable films.

title: Justin Kurzel on 'The Snowtown Murders'
description: The director Justin Kurzel discusses his film about the case of a serial killer in Australia.

title: Home-Court Edge Begins With Ball
description: Before each season, the managers for the U.C.L.A. mens basketball team do not compile reports on opposing players or strategies. Instead, they are responsible for figuring out the brand of basketball used by the Bruins opponents.

title: Expanded Playoffs Coming for 2012
description: VIERA, Fla.  Mark DeRosa, the veteran infielder for the Washington Nationals, had just finished praising baseballs expanded playoff field Thursday when he realized he did not know the format would work. Told that each league will now feature a play-in game between two wild cards, DeRosa took a moment to absorb the idea.

title: The Unfinished Fight Over Contraception
description: CAN we still be arguing about a womans ability to control her own fertility? Almost 50 years ago in Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court struck down state restrictions on contraception because they violated a right to privacy. But the issue has not gone away. Rick Santorum injected it into the presidential race by indicating that Griswold should be overturned so that states could ban contraception altogether. And the Senate just voted down a Republican effort to allow employers and health insurance companies to refuse coverage for contraceptives if they had moral or religious objections.

title: At One McDonalds, Even Calls to the Police Have Been Supersized
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: A Boatload of Lore Smuggled From Cuba
description: More than half a century has passed since the Cuban Revolution, and for perhaps a generation American policy has tilted forward, anticipating the post-Castro era. But if Fulgencio Batistas flight and Fidel Castros rise seem the stuff of newsreels (or The Godfather: Part II) to most Americans, those convulsive early years of the Communist regime remain very present to those who fled the island.

title: A Fragile Child Brings Her Parents a Strong Marriage
description: WHEN Chloe Kiev broke her arm on the monkey bars at Coleytown Elementary School in Westport, Conn., her parents were asked if they planned to sue. Those who have watched the marriage of Johanna and Marshall Kiev mature were not surprised at the response.

title: Puppies, Paintings and Philosophers
description: DENVER

title: 2012 Whitney Biennial
description: Images from the exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City.

title: A Boy Pays for Mothers Mistakes
description: The Snowtown Murders, an Australian true-crime story thats unrelenting in its singular vision of suburban rot and teenage vulnerability, is at times very tough to watch. But for those who do, this distressing infiltration of a family of young boys by a charismatic psychopath rewards with a stylistic talent that feels entirely new.

title: Bullfighters Return Stuns a Hardened Sport
description: MADRID  Five months after surviving a horrifying goring, Juan Jos Padilla, one of Spains leading bullfighters, wears a patch over his left eye and cannot chew any food, even after a series of surgeries to reconstruct part of his face.

title: Will Wall Street Ever Face Justice?
description: Sacramento

title: When the Math Says Buy
description: AS a creature of habit, Monica Giannelli was content to remain in the Greenwich Village apartment where she had lived for 10 years, ever since arriving in New York.

title: 3 Ex-Nassau County Officers Accused of Failing to Arrest Police Fund-Raisers Son
description: Three former high-ranking officials of the Nassau County Police Department were indicted Thursday on charges that they failed to arrest a student suspected of stealing more than $10,000 in electronic equipment from his high school because he was the son of a prominent police fund-raiser.

title: A Robin Hood in a Chinese Western
description: Despite its wealth of talent and unflagging energy, the Chinese action comedy Let the Bullets Fly could have trouble translating its home box-office success to Western shores. At least 30 minutes and several scams too long, the plot passes from amusing to confounding long before the final double-cross.

title: House Passes Bridge Bill After an Earmark Debate
description: WASHINGTON  The House overwhelmingly approved legislation Thursday to allow construction of a new $700 million bridge between Minnesota and Wisconsin, a project that has drawn comparisons to earmarks and required a Congressional exemption from a landmark environmental law.

title: Humbled, but Still Short of Humility
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.

title: Welcome to Uganda. Please Look Around.
description: Not quite a travelogue, not quite an art show, Kimi Takesues Where Are You Taking Me? is a cinematic trip to Uganda that explores both the viewed and the viewer.

title: Slate to Begin a Monthly Review of Books
description: Slate will introduce a monthly book review on Friday, the latest expansion of literary criticism online as stand-alone book review sections in newspapers have dwindled.

title: Growing Old Single
description: The percentage of unmarried older Americans has been rising. More than one-third of baby boomers are either divorced or never married.

title: Getting Bobby to Come Out and Play
description: Unexpectedly flouting its doomy title, Last Days Here invests the standard, washed-up rock-star tale with surprising sweetness. Observing the drug-fueled descent and attempted resuscitation of Bobby Liebling, the self-destructive frontman of the 1970s metal band Pentagram, Don Argott and Demian Fentons unfussy documentary hopes for redemption in the way that comedy movies hope for a best picture award. Which is to say, very cautiously.

title: Santorum, Defender of Free Market, Pushed in Congress to Protect Big Steel
description: WASHINGTON  As he seeks the Republican nomination for the presidency, Rick Santorum has presented himself as a defender of the free market and opponent of bailouts for Wall Street and the auto industry, saying he has been consistent in putting his principles ahead of political pressures.

title: Habitats | Kew Gardens, Queens
description: Murray and Carol Berger moved to their four-bedroom house in Kew Gardens, Queens, in 1957.

title: A Whole-Hearted, Hands-On Life
description: IN 1957, when Murray and Carol Berger moved to a red brick house with white columns in Kew Gardens, Queens, the neighborhood was considered highly desirable. Gracious brick and Tudor homes sat behind lush front lawns. Towering pin oaks, planted when the community was founded in 1910, lined quiet winding streets. The commute to Manhattan  just 16 minutes to Penn Station aboard the Long Island Rail Road  couldnt have been easier.

title: Making a Print and Making a Statement
description: Watching Manfred Kirchheimers Art Is ... the Permanent Revolution you might be reminded at first of airless instructional art programs on public television: three printmakers  Paul Marcus, a woodcutter; Sigmund Abeles, a painter and etcher; and Ann Chernow, a painter and lithographer  quietly discuss the role of artists as sociopolitical commentators while each prepares a piece. Mr. Marcuss concerns military torture; Mr. Abeless presents suicide bombers; Ms. Chernow renders a cemetery tableau about oil and war. Each also explains the chosen technique as the film (and their work) progresses.

title: Erwin Frankel Dies at 76; Brought World Music to U.S.
description: Erwin Frankel, a radio host and concert promoter who broadened the American cultural palette by introducing audiences to Andean pan flute music, the whirling dervishes of Turkey, and the notion of belly dancing as an art form fit for Carnegie Hall, died on Feb. 18 in New York City. He was 76.

title: Pletcher Loses a Derby Favorite but Retains Hope
description: Todd Pletcher says that he is handling his stables latest setback just fine, that he has learned never to dwell on the negative. Or maybe he has just grown used to getting bad news at the worst possible time.

title: That Screaming in Washington, Again
description: Brian Malones documentary Patriocracy feels as if it were made by someone who had been out of the country since the Clinton administration and upon re-entering was shocked at the polarized, dysfunctional state of the federal government. It spends a long time telling us what anyone who has been paying even a little attention to public life already knows: that politicians have paralyzed the legislative process with a rancorous sort of trench warfare.

title: Devastated Towns Regroup
description: Residents sifted through piles of debris where their houses had stood a day after a powerful storm system tore through parts of the Midwest and South.

title: Yelp Prices Its Offering at $15 a Share
description: Yelp, the online hub for local business reviews, priced its initial public offering at $15 a share on Thursday, above its expected range.

title: Awaiting a Trash to Treasure Moment
description: NICK BLANCHARD tells the story of the Hollywood location scouts who came calling on his parents one day, in their clapboard house at 4144 Victory Boulevard in Travis, on the west shore of Staten Island.

title: Looking Ahead to Dying Young
description: Churning out his propulsive garage punk from the age of 15, Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., better known by the stage name Jay Reatard, made music as though aware that he wouldnt be around for very long.

title: Serbia, Once Outcast, Is Candidate to Join E.U.
description: BRUSSELS  Serbia formally became a candidate for European Union membership late Thursday in a significant advance for the nation, once ostracized for its role in the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

title: Brauns Lawyer Critical of Collector in Drug Test
description: Ryan Braun, it appears, does not want to talk anymore about the collector who took his urine sample last October that ultimately turned out to be positive.

title: A Teenage Home Alone Gone Wild
description: The Oscars are swell, but once in a while a film comes along that is so courageous it deserves consideration for the Nobel Prize. An entire generation has been born and gone to college since the Beastie Boys defined that most basic of civil liberties: Youve got to fight for your right to party. The makers of Project X, knowing how short the teenage memory is, have now boldly, raunchily made the declaration again, preventing millions of young people from growing up without understanding that every 17-year-old is entitled to a drunken, deafening, topless, drug-filled, sex-crazed, property-destroying, life-endangering birthday.

title: The Machiavellian Temptation
description: In the 19th century, there was a hydraulic model of how to be a good person. There are all these torrents of passion flowing through you. Your job, as captain of your soul, is to erect dams to keep these passions in check. Your job is to just say no to sloth, lust, greed, drug use and the other sins.

title: 50th Anniversary of a Scoring Feat Thats as Much Legend as Record
description: When Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points against the Knicks on March 2, 1962, he did so in semi-obscurity. There were no televisions cameras, few reporters and only 4,124 spectators at Hershey (Pa.) Sports Arena, where Chamberlains Philadelphia Warriors occasionally played home games.

title: In a Yearlong Test, iPads Will Replace TVs in the Back Seats of Some Cabs
description: Two major additions are coming to the citys taxis: iPads and more ads.

title: For Obama and Netanyahu, Wariness on Iran Will Dominate Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Nearly four years ago, when Senator Barack Obama was running for president and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was head of the opposition, they met here in what aides described as a warm atmosphere.

title: More Americans Rejecting Marriage in 50s and Beyond
description: On the day she decided to sell her wedding ring, Katie Dunn tucked the gleaming band into a Ziploc bag. The ring had been designed for her nearly two decades earlier, with swirls of yellow and white gold symbolizing the romance she had prayed would endure. But as she approached her 60s, her dreams and her marriage dissolved in resentment and regret.

title: A Rebels Tale
description: A Bollywood screenwriter might blush to come up with the story of a national champion runner who becomes more famous as an outlaw. But Tigmanshu Dhulias uneven, absorbing Hindi film Paan Singh Tomar, based on real events, falls into the category of truth is stranger than cinema.

title: Four Fiscal Phonies
description: Mitt Romney is very concerned about budget deficits. Or at least thats what he says; he likes to warn that President Obamas deficits are leading us toward a Greece-style collapse.

title: Back to Nature With Wii and Cheez-Its
description: The Woods, Matthew Lessners satirical look at consumerist technoslackers who drop out of society and hope to start something of their own  a commune? a movement?  by heading back to nature in the Pacific Northwest is good for a handful of sight gags. An early shot of a young man unwinding an endless orange extension cord as he walks into the forest announces whats ahead.

title: Mets Prospect and Ace Share Road to Recovery
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  These two pitchers stand far, far apart in the baseball life cycle.

title: A Bar That Survived Prohibition Is Set to Be Uprooted Over a Lease
