description: Wednesday night was like any other at Bills Gay Nineties Restaurant and Piano Bar on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Robert R. McElroy Dies at 84; Documented Art Happenings
description: Robert R. McElroy, a photographer who documented the evanescent when he snapped hundreds of images of the Happenings art movement, a free-spirited blend of art and performance in the late 1950s and early 60s, died on Feb. 22 at an assisted-living center in White Plains. He was 84.

title: The Sun Shines Again in Miami
description: MIAMI

title: Why Irans Election Is a Farce
description: Paris

title: A Bad Amendment Defeated
description: Only one Senate Republican  Olympia Snowe of Maine, who is retiring  voted against a truly horrible measure on Thursday that would have crippled the expansion of preventive health care in America. The amendment, which was attached to a highway bill, was defeated on a narrow 48-to-51 vote. But it showed once again how far from the mainstream Republicans have strayed in their relentless efforts to undermine the separation of church and state, deny women access to essential health services and tear apart President Obamas health care reform law.

title: Home for Good
description: Los Angeles County is often called the national capital of homelessness, with more than 51,000 people lacking shelter on any given night. Homelessness there has proved to be a very tough problem to solve, especially with governments so short of revenue. But Home for Good, a collaboration by governments, businesses and charitable groups announced last month that it was making progress toward the goal of ending chronic and veteran homelessness in the county by 2016.

title: For Many Asian New Yorkers, Smoking Is Still a Way of Life
description: On a cool, damp afternoon in Flushing, Queens, Seung Jun stood outside on Main Street on Thursday, a smoker among his peers. He unsheathed a Parliament and took a long drag, as though he were taking in a breath of relief.

title: Novak Another Out-of-Nowhere Sensation
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Steve Novak is 28 and stands 6 feet 10 inches, and as he gets ready for the Knicks next game on Sunday, he is just a few 3-pointers away from being a full-fledged cult hero. Or maybe he already is.

title: Beth Israel to Pay $13 Million for Inflating Medicare Fees
description: Beth Israel Medical Center has admitted that it fraudulently inflated its fees for services to Medicare patients, deliberately deceiving the federal government into paying many millions of dollars more than their treatments actually cost.

title: Romney Reopens Whatever-It-Takes Playbook
description: When Gov. Rick Perry began rising in the polls, Mitt Romney was ready with a potent debate-night assault: under Mr. Perry, illegal immigrants in Texas received a $100,000 tuition break.

title: Where the Jobs Are, the Training May Not Be
description: As state funding has dwindled, public colleges have raised tuition and are now resorting to even more desperate measures  cutting training for jobs the economy needs most.

title: Andrew Breitbart, Conservative Blogger, Dies at 43
description: Andrew Breitbart, a conservative blogger and activist who built a national media persona by putting undercover video on the Internet to bring discredit and disgrace to his liberal targets, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 43.

title: Greek Crisis May Test the Value of Swaps
description: The restructuring of Greeces debt that is scheduled to start next week may well demonstrate how effective credit-default swaps are.

title: The Speaker and the Rainmaker
description: Once again the mighty campaign dollar trumps all. On Saturday, Speaker John Boehner is scheduled to gather in Florida with rich Republican donors, shoulder to shoulder with Representative Vern Buchanan, who is leading the fund-raising of House Republican candidates nationwide.

title: Azerbaijans Leaders Yield After a Rare Public Protest
description: MOSCOW  In a rare outbreak of civil unrest in Azerbaijan, a crowd of angry protesters massed outside the home of a provincial governor on Thursday, demanding his ouster as the house was consumed in flames, apparently the result of an arson attack. The national government responded by dismissing the governor.

title: Not What Albany Needs
description: For the second year in a row, Gov. Andrew Cuomo appears to have wrestled New York States budget into shape, this time sparing more devastating cuts to the states neediest schools and hospitals. Even the state comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, who is often at odds with Mr. Cuomo, reported recently that, over all, the new budget proposal for 2012-13 made progress toward aligning state spending with revenue on a recurring basis.

title: Successful in Business, and Tied to Putin
description: Some of Vladimir Putins friends and family who have become wealthy during his years as Russias leader.

title: The Monkey House Ends a 111-Year Run in the Bronx, a Victim of Zoo Evolution
description: Jose Ortiz, a 50-year-old taxi driver who grew up a few blocks from the Bronx Zoo, remembers how young he was when the creatures in the Monkey House captured his imagination.

title: Public Relations Defined, After an Energetic Public Discussion
description: AN effort to update the definition of public relations for an age of social media and spin doctors suggests why many people think the public relations industry could use some help with its public relations.

title: A Devastated Town Regroups
description: Residents of Harrisburg, Ill., sifted through piles of debris a day after a powerful storm system tore through parts of the Midwest and South.

title: Law Has Polling Firms Leery of Work in New Hampshire
description: New Hampshires attorney general is threatening legal action against some of the nations most prominent polling firms, invoking a state law against spreading negative information through poll questions in a way that could limit public opinion surveys in one of the nations most politically contested states.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 1, 2012

title: Yankees Take a Break to Brush Up on Their Comedic Skills
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees went through their annual off-field team-bonding exercise Thursday, an annual spring rite that Manager Joe Girardi plans for his players to increase team camaraderie.

title: Prom Night, Bloody Prom Night
description: O.K., everybody, please remember that were on our very best behavior tonight. Therell be no hooting, no teasing, no smart-aleck remarks. We will not  I repeat not  make fun of the girl with the really bad reputation. Lord knows, the poor child has suffered enough already. Is that understood? Good. Now sit down and enjoy the show.

title: Islands Unto Themselves
description: Administrivial New Puzzle Blog Alert! If you love doing cryptic crosswords, hopefully youve discovered the ones that Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto construct over at The Nation. Now, theyve started a new blog called Word Salad, which will discuss the cryptic puzzles and more! Check it out here.

title: A Round to Remember for Love
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  In his 18th career start at the Honda Classic, Davis Love III equaled the course record of 64 at PGA National Resort and Spa. Loves round included a hole-in-one at the par-3 fifth.

title: Update on New York Redistricting
description: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this years elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar; the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: Moving On, Santorum Avoids Mention of Michigan Delegate Issue
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Rick Santorum implied Thursday night that he had won the primary on Tuesday in Michigan, where he actually lost the popular vote to Mitt Romney and, as of now, is behind him in delegates.

title: When Game Changers Become Name Changers
description: Since the birth of professional athletics in the mid-19th century, athletes have made a habit of changing their names  to hide their ethnic heritage and to celebrate it, to draw attention and to remain anonymous, to proclaim everything from religious devotion to a desire for world peace to affection for the movie Teen Wolf.

title: Americas Future
description: The Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman and Bill Gates discuss the future of American competitiveness, innovation and education and the state of the current political debate.

title: Now a Knicks Backup, Davis Adapts
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Baron Davis had his first impressive outing as a Knick on Wednesday night against the Cavaliers, tallying 8 assists and 4 points in only 15 minutes.

title: Joe Thompson Dies at 93; Helped Preserve the Black String Band
description: I got the name of being a pretty good fiddle player, Joe Thompson once said. I even been to Carnegie Hall playing fiddle.

title: Manhattans Population Density, Past and Present
description: How population density in Manhattan has changed in the past 100 years.

title: $51 for 2 Minutes: German Pay Phones Anger Troops
description: When Specialist Reynald Matias was heading to Afghanistan with his Army unit late last year, their chartered flight stopped to refuel at Leipzig-Halle Airport in Germany. During a brief layover, he called his wife in Tacoma, Wash., using his debit card on a pay phone in the terminals troops-only transit lounge.

title: Should College Be for Everyone?
Leaps of Faith
description: For the past three and a half years, Republicans have struggled to explain a great conundrum. If they are the party of authentic America with a mystical connection to the will of the people, then how, exactly, did Barack Obama get elected president?

title: For Nazareth, a Loss Not Reflected in the Score
description: They lost their coach in January and will lose their school in June.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared in February
description: How the auto industry, automakers and the most popular cars and trucks fared in February.

title: In Patagonia, Caught Between Visions of the Future
description: COCHRANE, Chile  At the end of a 200-mile stretch of mostly unpaved highway, nearly impassable during the long winter months and only marginally better in summer, sits the quiet community of Cochrane.

title: A Conservative Leader Was Less So in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  As president of the Club for Growth, the politically active free-market advocacy group, Chris Chocola wields tremendous power, rating members of Congress on their fiscally conservative purism. Those who fail to meet the clubs tests can expect a club-backed primary opponent, or at least a negative advertising barrage that leaves them trembling.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper East Side co-op, a Clinton Hill co-op and a Greenwich Village one-bedroom.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An 1888 Victorian with a mansard roof in Garden City, N.J., and a four-bedroom colonial in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Getting Competitive With Yoga, Sort Of
description: The United States Yoga Federation hosts the ninth New York Regional and National Yoga Asana Championship at the Hudson Theater in Midtown Manhattan this weekend.

title: Officials Speak of Origin of Gun in School Attack
description: When the 17-year-old T. J. Lane opened fire on students at Chardon High School, killing three and wounding two, the authorities say, he held a .22 caliber Mark III Target Rimfire pistol, a semiautomatic handgun made by Ruger that retails for $449 to $559.

title: Corrections: March 2
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Everybody Inhale
description: IN a crowded place like Manhattan, there are moments when a certain question flits across peoples minds.

title: Poll Finds Wide Support for Birth Control Coverage
description: The close divide in a Senate vote Thursday over whether employers can refuse insurance coverage for contraception mirrors a sharp partisan divide among the public, according to a national poll and interviews with women around the country.

title: Bills Defeat a Blow to Home-Schooled Athletes
description: A bill that would have allowed home-schooled children in Virginia to play varsity sports at public high schools was defeated Thursday by a state Senate committee. The so-called Tim Tebow bill, named after the N.F.L. quarterback who was home-schooled in Florida but played football at a public school, was killed by an 8-7 vote of the Virginia Senates education and health committee. The bill had passed the states Republican-controlled House of Delegates last month.

title: Peres Says U.S. Must Put All Iran Options on Table
description: Days before Israels president, Shimon Peres, was to meet with President Obama, Mr. Peres said on Thursday that the United States must make clear to Iran that all options are on the table, but he acknowledged that there was disagreement over where to draw the red line that would set off military intervention.

title: The Burden of Budget Cuts
description: As state budgets for education decrease, colleges look first to cut back the most expensive majors like engineering, fine arts and nursing.

title: A Warning on the Accuracy of Primary Polls
description: After another wild polling ride in Michigan, it is time for a reflection on just how accurate primary and caucus polls have been  both in an absolute sense and as compared with past years. This discussion, of course, also has implications for the FiveThirtyEight forecast model, which is based upon the polls.

title: Nine Tables, Fast Service, Racket Welcome
description: TABLE tennis is an addiction, Saleem Majied confessed one recent Thursday night.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Brooklyn Table Tennis Club
description: The Brooklyn Table Tennis Club in Midwood plays host to a crowd that reflects the eclecticism of the borough.

title: Gingrich Narrows Focus to Georgia for Super Tuesday
description: ATLANTA  With 10 states up for grabs on Tuesday, Newt Gingrich has retreated to Fortress Georgia.

title: Gingrich Barnstorms Georgia
description: Newt Gingrichs campaign strategy starts with winning Georgia, then capturing Alabama, Mississippi and Kansas.

title: South Africa: Former Youth Leader Replies to Party
description: Julius Malema, the former leader of the Youth League of the African National Congress, fired back at the party that expelled him Wednesday, telling government radio that he was not a soldier who is prepared to fall in the battle, I will die with my boots on. Despite a rowdy show of support from close allies in his home province of Limpopo, response to his expulsion was relatively muted. Mr. Malemas controversial proposals, like nationalizing the countrys mines, won some support among the impoverished youth, but his criticism of President Jacob Zuma landed him in front of a party disciplinary tribunal. Mr. Malema was initially suspended from the party for five years, but an appeals committee increased the penalty to expulsion, arguing that he showed no remorse.

title: Preferring to Watch Putin Vote From Afar
description: Dasha Yurkevich, a blonde 9-year-old girl in a sailors hat and a green sweater dress, stood in front of the Russian Consulate in San Francisco last December, carrying a sign saying Its Not Fair in Russian. She was part of a small protest against alleged Russian ballot-box tampering in the Dec. 4 Duma, or congressional, elections.

title: An Eye on the Sky for Texas
description: John Nielsen-Gammon, the Texas state climatologist, has a standard joke: A few years ago, before the start of the most intense drought in state history, almost nobody in Texas knew he existed.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: The Closer: Barkley May Have a Point
description: Charles Barkley is not a fan of Michael Jordans tenure as owner and chief decision-maker for the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: Photographic Autobiography of Rolling Stones Will Mark Bands 50th Anniversary
description: The Rolling Stones are marking the bands 50th anniversary with a new book, their publisher is expected to announce on Friday. Hyperion will release The Rolling Stones at Fifty, a photographic autobiography with images that have not been seen before and new text from the band.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/02/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/02/2012

title: Word of the Day | eulogy
description: eulogy \y-l-je\ noun

title: At UTEP, Success Is Not All About Graduation Rates
description: In the farthest corner of West Texas  nestled between the Franklin Mountains and the United States-Mexico border, hundreds of miles from any other public university in the state  the University of Texas at El Paso and its fortress-like buildings occupy one of the states most exotic campus settings.

title: Hard Times Claim a Storied Press Outpost in Austin
description: If only Molly were here to see this.

title: Tata and Vodafone Eye Cable and Wireless
description: Tata Communications, which is controlled by Indias largest conglomerate, said on Thursday that it might bid for Cable and Wireless Worldwide of Britain to complement its operations in developing countries, Julia Werdigier wrote for the Deal Book in The New York Times.

title: Obama Gets a Facebook Upgrade
description: On Thursday, another Facebook user adopted the sites new Timeline feature, regaling followers with the minutiae typical of the worlds cyber capital of oversharing.

title: Pennsylvania: Ultrasound Bill Is Shelved
description: The State House majority leader announced on Thursday that a bill requiring ultrasounds before abortions would not be considered soon. The shift followed a national uproar over a similar proposal in Virginia, which as originally worded would have forced women to have vaginal ultrasounds. The majority leader, Mike Turzai, a Republican, canceled a debate on a bill that critics said would require invasive procedures and interfere with doctor-patient relations. A spokesman, Stephen Miskin, said, Until there is a consensus within the House and the medical community, it wont be scheduled for a vote.

title: Wilt Chamberlains 100-Point Game
description: A snapshot of Wilt Chamberlains performance and those who have come the closest to his 100-point game.

title: Montana: Judge Sends Racist Joke About Obama
description: The chief federal judge in Montana has apologized for forwarding to some of his friends an e-mail with a racist joke about President Obama, and he initiated himself a complaint of judicial misconduct. Judge Richard F. Cebull told The Great Falls Tribune, which received a copy of the joke from a recipient, that he is opposed to Mr. Obamas politics and sent it in that spirit. He admitted the joke  involving suggestions of bestiality and the presidents mother  was racist, but he said he personally was not. Judge Cebull, nominated by President George W. Bush, sent a letter to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit asking for the misconduct investigation.

title: Dignity and the Wealth of Nations
description: The significance of the Russian presidential elections this weekend can be understood by reading Why Nations Fail, a book written by two U.S.- based academics being published this month, Chrystia Freeland writes.

title: Georgia: Court Delays Ruling on Immigration Laws
description: A federal court in Atlanta said Thursday it would wait until the United States Supreme Court decided the constitutionality of Arizonas strict immigration law before ruling on similar laws in Georgia and Alabama. Georgia and Alabama created two of the nations toughest immigration laws last year, modeled in part on Arizonas, allowing the police to inspect the citizenship status of criminal suspects.

title: Texas: Primary Election Set for May 29
description: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio ruled Thursday that the states long-delayed primary election would be held on May 29, with a runoff on July 31. The judges had twice pushed back the primary because of a redistricting dispute. Black and Hispanic groups sued the state over the electoral maps drawn by the Republican-controlled Legislature, saying the maps discriminated against minorities. With the new May 29 date, Texas will hold one of the last primaries in the country, weakening its ability to influence the Republican presidential race.

title: Straight Shots on Idol, at Last, Courtesy of Jimmy Iovine
description: American Idol narrowed the field to 13 final contestants this week, but the real star of the climactic show on Thursday turned out to be Jimmy Iovine, the famed producer and record executive, who injected some much needed candor into the proceedings.

title: Newswallah: To Learn About the Poor, Live With Them
description: Katherine Boos recently published Behind the Beautiful Forevers is the latest in a series of narrative non-fiction books coming out of India. The book is set in Annawadi, a slum located near Mumbais international airport. Its central characters include Abdul, a garbage sorter, members of his family and neighbors.

title: In Delhi and Mumbai, Dueling Fashion (and Fashion Weeks)
description: In recent weeks it has been hard to miss the crowds of designers, stylists, paparazzi and models in Indias top two cities  as well as eager crowds of fashionistas sporting everything from leopard prints to rhinestones to strappy sun dresses.

title: News Quiz | March 2, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Irans Government Declares Huge Turnout in First National Vote Since 09 Protests
description: WASHINGTON  Irans government declared an enormous turnout for the parliamentary elections held Friday, calling it another epic sign of support for Iranian theocracy and a thumb in the eye of the West.

title: March 2, 1877 | Hayes Declared Winner in Disputed Presidential Election
description: On March 2, 1877, only three days before his inauguration, the Republican Rutherford B. Hayes was declared the winner of the 1876 presidential election, defeating the Democrat Samuel J. Tilden in one of the most disputed elections in American history.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 2, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Academy Wishes Its Future Really Did Belong to the Young.

title: Venezuelas Gladiators
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Two men with knives face off in a pit. Hundreds gathered around are egging them on, while on the walkway above others are picking their winner and placing bets. The men in the pit have been given no real choice: refusing to fight is generally punished by death.

title: Tornado in Illinois
description: WHERE is Harrisburg, Ill., situated in the state?

title: Syria Blocks Red Cross Aid to Rebel Enclave in Homs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian authorities on Friday blocked without explanation an officially sanctioned Red Cross convoy laden with food and medical supplies from entering a devastated neighborhood in the central city of Homs, one day after the army overwhelmed the main rebel stronghold there after a brutal monthlong siege.

title: Can Kindness Become Cool?
description: Lady Gaga started her Born This Way Foundation, with the goal of empowering and supporting children and fostering a more accepting environment. Do you think she can succeed in affecting the culture of cruelty that often finds its way into interactions among young people?

title: Pakistan Battles Militants, in Worst Fighting in Months
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The government here cemented its grip on power on Friday with strong gains in Senate elections that represented a psychological victory for the beleaguered president, Asif Ali Zardari, and should ensure his partys influence for another three years.

title: Fantasy Focus: Early Spring Notes
description: The big news of the week was the Astros curious decision to shift Brett Myers from the rotation to the closer role. This has already been dissected at length, so Ill keep it short, but while Myers is a No. 3 starter at best in terms of talent, he threw 439 innings over the past two years for Houston and that has a lot of value, particularly in keeping the bullpen fresh. Its also curious given that the Astros actually have some talent in the bullpen: David Carpenter, Wilton Lopez, Juan Abreu (12.0 K/9IP in Class AAA), and yes, even Brandon Lyon. Either way, this is really about the future for Houston, which apparently feels that to a contender at the trade deadline, a shut-down reliever has more value than a No. 3 or 4 starter. The Astros may be right there, but this does nothing but make it more likely that Houston drafts No. 1 over all in the 2013 draft.

title: Scouting the Draft: Alabamas Dre Kirkpatrick
description: In myscouting reporton the L.S.U. prospect and consensus top cornerback Morris Claiborne, I mentioned that I have him rated very closely with Alabamas Dre Kirkpatrick. After reviewing more tape of Kirkpatrick, I maintain that ranking. The only thing stopping Kirkpatrick from truly battling Claiborne to be the top cornerback off the board in April is an arrest in January in which he was charged with possession of a small amount of marijuana.

title: Determining the Level of Payments in Health Care
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: The Early Word: Competing Interests
description: In Todays Times:

title: Q&A: Cranking Up Your Broadband Speed
description: Q.

title: Putin Says He Might Seek a Fourth Term as President in 2018, if Things Are Going Well
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who is likely to win a third presidential term on Sunday, said in an interview released on Friday that he might run for president for a fourth time in 2018, which would lengthen his term as Russias paramount leader to 24 years.

title: Taking the Bait: Of Salt, Start-Ups, Financial Numbers and Insurance
description: Since closing in November for the long blizzard of a winter that never arrived, we mined some salt from the sea, posted a business plan for expansion to Brooklyn, and detailed the delay games of insurance companies. Lovely readers had things to say about each and every move, and we loved fielding their questions and observations.

title: Daily Report: Zynga Hopes to Find You New Friends
description: Zynga announced a new gaming platform that is intended to make it easier to play social games like FarmVille, Words With Friends and Mafia Wars, reports David Streitfeld on Friday in The New York Times. The platform, which is to be introduced in a trial version on Zynga.com later this month, is intended in part to reduce Zyngas reliance on Facebook. Most Zynga games are played on that social network, which derives 12 percent of its revenue from Zynga.

title: Pakistan Builds Web Wall Out in the Open
description: PARIS  Many countries censor the Internet, but few spell out their intentions as explicitly as Pakistan.

title: The Tao of Hoffman
description: And just how long have we got the magic?

title: When It Rains, It Will Really Pour
description: Early last year I attended a conference in Sacramento where state and federal scientists warned emergency planners, insurance executives and others about the danger of a superstorm riding into California from warmer Pacific waters on an atmospheric river and inundating everything in sight.

title: Austerity, American Style
description: Via Mark Thoma, Antonio Fatas has a good piece on the exceptional weakness of government spending in this recovery. I thought I might add to that observation.

title: Regional English, Tweet by Tweet
description: The Dictionary of American Regional English, the recently completed landmark project we profiled recently, is based largely on research by a team of fieldworkers who fanned out across the country some 50 years ago in vans called Word Wagons, querying Americans about their ways of talking about kitchen implements, farm animals, bodily ailments, misbehaving children, stupid neighbors and more.

title: Opinion Report: The Blunt Amendment
description: From the editorial page

title: The Microfoundation Thing (Wonkish)
description: Mark Thoma sends us to Simon Wren-Lewis on microfounded macro models (especially the DSGE models that have dominated the literature even on the Keynesian side) versus ad hoc models like IS-LM. Wren-Lewis is on my side, sort of; but Id like to add a few points, in no particular order.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Greek Crisis May Test the Value of Swaps | The restructuring of Greeces debt that is scheduled to start next week may well demonstrate how effective credit-default swaps are.

title: Dont Crimp My Ride
description: NAIROBI  What if the New York City subway disappeared tomorrow? This is the situation facing Kenyan commuters. The government has proposed a law to phase out the vans used by privately run transportation services in favor of smaller taxis and larger buses. And the operators of those classic 14-seaters, the matatus, are threatening a massive general strike across the country next week.

title: Much Ado About Mandatory Turkish Health Insurance
description: U.S. citizens concerned about a new law requiring them to sign up, and pay, for Turkish national health insurance are breathing sighs of relief this weekend.

title: Image of the Day: March 2
Narrow Choices for Iranian Voters
description: LONDON  Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Irans supreme leader, was among the first to vote in parliamentary elections on Friday, having assured the electorate that the poll would represent yet another firm slap in the face of world arrogance.

title: Divorce Rates Among Boomers to Reshape Old Age
description: The Times reports this morning that a growing number of men and women in their 50s and 60s are opting out of marriage and venturing into old age on their own. The surge has been driven by several factors, including longevity, economics and evolving social mores, according to sociologists.

title: Friday Reading: More Older Americans Rejecting Marriage
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Success Charter Wins Approval to Open a Williamsburg School
Carlyle Buys 85% Stake in Brazils Largest Toy Retailer
description: The Carlyle Group is betting big on Brazils rising middle class.

title: TimesCast | Syrian Rebels Withdraw
description: Opposition fighters announced a tactical withdrawal from their stronghold in Homs.

title: Riffraff Revisited
description: The art collective Still House occupies the fourth floor of a 19th-century warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn, across from Fairway, where the road ends and the water begins. The 7,000-square-foot space houses the studios of eight young artists, a gallery and a residency program. Were a bit bootleg and off the beaten path, says Isaac Brest, 24, one of the founders. Go to slide show >>

title: 2012 Fantasy Baseball Preview: Second Base
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy sports advice on Bats, The Fifth Down and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: British Banks Take Advantage of Cheap Loans
description: The European Central Bank is keeping mum about which firms stepped up for the latest round of cheap loans, fearful of the potential stigma.

title: Obama Says Iran Strike Is an Option, but Warns Israel
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, speaking days before a crucial meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, stiffened his pledge to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, even as he warned Israel of the negative consequences of a pre-emptive military strike on Irans nuclear facilities.

title: Fill-In | Physical Activity and Your Health
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs from this post from the Well blog, Why Its So Important to Keep Moving.

title: A Tireless Exchange
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoration
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: THE YEAR WE LEFT HOME,  by Jean Thompson (Simon & Schuster, $15.) A Midwestern family struggles for economic and emotional stability in Thompsons warmhearted novel. Over the course of 30 years, the Ericksons  including Ryan, who longs to escape his rural roots, and his sister Anita, for whom marriage and motherhood became traps more than prizes  weather the aftermath of war, farm foreclosures and bittersweet homecomings.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LIFESPAN OF A FACT,  by John DAgata and Jim Fingal (Norton; paper, $17.95.) An essayist insists that his only responsibility is to truth and beauty, not factual accuracy. His fact checker begs to differ. A fiery argument ensues.

title: Roland Mouret: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Up Front
description: On this weeks cover, Eleanor Henderson reviews Amber Dermonts first novel, The Starboard Sea. Henderson  an assistant professor at Ithaca College in Ithaca, N.Y., where she lives with her husband and two sons  is no stranger to the Book Reviews cover; her own debut novel, Ten Thousand Saints (one of our 10 Best Books of 2011), was reviewed there last year. Like Dermonts book, it also delved into the confused and sometimes reckless lives of adolescent boys. One of the things that most impresses me in The Starboard Sea is Dermonts access into the experience of a teenage boy, Henderson said in a recent e-mail. I tend to be annoyed when readers get excited by a writer who crosses over into a character of the opposite gender, as though the opposite gender is some unidentified species or something. But Dermonts commitment to seeing the world through a boys eyes seems complete to me, and I think its because of her powerful crush on her own narrator, Jason. I feel the same way about Jude, the 16-year-old protagonist of my novel  in high school, I would have liked to have a boyfriend like him, as screwed up as he is. All writers should be a little in love with their characters, I think. Because Dermont was, I fell for Jason, too.

title: Nervous System
description: Alexander Hoffmann is having a very bad day. It starts in the wee hours of the morning, when he startles an intruder in his palatial home in Geneva. The man, who bypassed the security system, is determinedly sharpening the family cutlery and has brought along some bondage gear. He slams Alex over the head with a fire extinguisher and flees. Alex, a hedge fund executive with so much money that being part of the 1 percent might seem unambitious, has to go to the hospital for scans and stitches.

title: Right Face
description: One of the peculiarities of modern conservatism is that the most coruscating examinations of its doctrines are often issued from dissidents within its own ranks. Some of the more recent renegades include the Christian evangelical David Kuo, who served in George W. Bushs administration; the economist Bruce Bartlett, who was a Reagan administration official; and the commentators Damon Linker and David Frum. But perhaps no one remains a more improbable critic than David Brock.

title: Homeward Bound
description: So these two sociologists go into a bar and the man says to the woman, What have you been up to?

title: Poisoned in Body and Spirit
description: Eliza Factors first novel, The Mercury Fountain, explores what happens when a life driven by ideology confronts implacable truths of science and human nature. It also shows how leaders can inflict damage by neglecting the real needs of real people. Though the action takes place between 1900 and 1923, the resonances feel alarmingly contemporary.

title: Changing of the Guard
description: The central character of An Ermine in Czernopol, Gregor von Rezzoris mid-20th-century masterpiece, first published in 1958, is not a person at all, but a city. Czernopol  less an invented place than the distilled essence of a number of post-imperial Eastern European cities, including the authors own birthplace  is a smug little latter-day Sodom, squalid and venal and defiantly backward, except in one crucial respect. Laughter in Czernopol, the narrator tells us, had been elevated to an art form, a folk art of unparalleled authenticity . . . well endowed with the most vivid references, not to mention all manner of innuendoes. As you can perhaps imagine, this makes the town a lively place to visit.

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Enthusiast: A look at the sort of wine and cocktails the passengers drank on the maiden/final voyage of the Titanic. Corks that survived the sinking later identified Champagne selections from Mot and Heidsieck & Co.   Robert Simonson

title: After Sunset
description: The question of whether, say, India or Nigeria are better off because of British imperialism contains an inherent contradiction: before colonialism there were no states called India or Nigeria. But to prove the horrors of imperial rule  or to dispute the historians who recommend that the United States self-consciously adopt Britains former burden  one has only to examine the catastrophic choices of British colonialists that continue to influence events today.

title: The Missing Pages
description: Its possible to make books of a certain fascination, Thornton Wilder once said, if you scrupulously leave out the essential. Wilder was commenting on The Education of Henry Adams, that masterly autobiography in which Adams purposefully excluded any direct mention of his wife, Clover, their marriage or her shocking suicide. In fact, posterity has occasionally hinted that Adams was partly responsible for Clovers death, as if omitting her from The Education suggests guilt rather than a surfeit of feeling. Adams did tell a friend that the great calamities in life leave one speechless, and three years after Clover died he wrote that he was still sad, sad, sad. He then burned some of the diaries he kept during his marriage. If Clover left a suicide note, he must have burned that too. Wisdom, he declared, is silence.

title: Parting Words
description: When Brenda Wineapple closed her laptop on Sister Brother, her dual biography of the siblings Gertrude and Leo Stein, she cried. Stacy Schiff, having written the final words of Cleopatra, was still worried. I lived a little bit in fear of her, she explains. When Doris Kearns Goodwin finished Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln, she built more shelves in her library annex (once the family garage) to hold all the books she had acquired.

title: Runway in Review
description: Ann DemeulemeesterDesigner: Ann DemeulemeesterDate and Location: Thursday, Mar. 1, Thtre de Chaillot, 1, place du TrocadroPhotos: slide show

title: On Our Radar: The Lorax
description: Calling it an example of what it pretends to oppose, A.O. Scott skewers The Lorax, a new animated film based on Dr. Seusss environmentally themed childrens book. [The New York Times]

title: Chalayan: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Morning Buzz, March 2: A Cheaper Yankees Team
description: Good morning. Expect mostly cloudy skies today, with temperatures up to the mid-40s. Prepare for rain tonight, though.

title: Leading Off: Glory Slip-Sliding Away
description: If you havent noticed  and based on regular-season ratings in most places this side of Vancouver, there is a good chance you havent  there is some weird stuff going on in the N.H.L. We not only have the games best player, Sidney Crosby, missing most of the season while in indefinite concussion limbo, but we also have the player who once battled him for that status, Alex Ovechkin, playing as if he wants to be traded to Omsk, and the once and always proud Montreal Canadiens sitting dead last in the Eastern Conference.

title: For a Call Home, a Hefty Price
description: Phone calls to loved ones are a crucial lifeline for deployed soldiers to remain connected to the lives left behind while serving their country. An article in The Times on Friday looks at how calls made from pay phones at lounges in Leipzig-Halle Airport in Germany,  are coming at unusually steep costs to American troops.

title: Yelp Shares Surge on Debut
description: Yelp got its first day pop after all.

title: The Most Welcoming Wine Region
description: PARIS  Of all the wine regions in France, the Loire Valley, some of whose red wines are featured in my column this week, might be my top choice for wine tourism.

title: NBC Finds a Winner in The Voice
description: The cellphone of NBCUniversals chief executive, Stephen B. Burke, rang early on the morning of April 28 last year. Alan Wurtzel, the companys president of research, was so excited that he had trouble speaking. We got a 5.1, he finally said. Mr. Burke was at the gym, and given the background noise, he figured he wasnt hearing correctly. I said, We got a 5.1 in the key demographic, Mr. Wurtzel repeated, which meant that Nielsen estimated that 11.8 million viewers in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic had tuned in  a breakout number for a new show.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $15,587,000
description: A penthouse that sold for $15,587,000 at the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Santorums Woman Problem
description: Rick Santorum, the improbable presidential aspirant, opposes abortion, thinks birth control promotes immorality, objects to women serving in combat positions, and has criticized radical feminists for encouraging women to join the workforce. He doesnt have much respect for modern women, and modern women dont have much respect for hima feeling theyre expressing by voting for his rival. Polling in Arizona showed that Mitt Romney carried female voters by 17 percentage points. It was closer in the Michigan primary, 5 percentage points, but everything was closer in Michigan.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Tributes From Both Sides for Andrew Breitbart and Lego Goes Pink
description: Andrew Breitbart, the conservative blogger and provocateur who attracted a lot of vitriol from his opponents while alive, was celebrated by colleagues and admirers after his sudden death from an apparent heart attack on Wednesday. A note at the top of the Drudge Report, where Mr. Breitbart once worked, read in part: I still see him in my minds eye in Venice Beach, the sunny day I met him. He was in his mid 20s. It was all there. He had a wonderful, loving family and we all feel great sadness for them today

title: Orlando Wants to Show the Commissioner Its M.L.S. Ready
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber visited Orlando Thursday for a series of meetings with the owners of the Orlando City club, the teams supporters and local political leaders to explore the citys viability as a future M.L.S. expansion market.

title: Comrades, Optimize!
description: While many look back on the Soviet Union and fixate on the politics, purges and wars, the British writer Francis Spufford, in his latest high-wire act, has devoted Stakhanovite study and considerable literary muscle to another endeavor. He tells the story of an idea, the dream that mobilized a generation, created one of historys largest industrial monsters and ultimately doomed it to failure. Red Plenty, as its title suggests, is the story of the Bolshevik promise of abundance.

title: A Place of Our Deepest Desires
description: The jacket of Geoff Dyers Zona describes it as A Book About a Film About a Journey to a Room. It is also a hall of mirrors in which the author watches himself watching (and remembers himself remembering) a movie that, according to his impressively detailed description, ends with a character looking at us, looking at her.

title: Expletives Deleted
description: Im fairly sure its a faux pas to compare a novel and a television show, but I mean it as a compliment to both when I say that Thomas Mallons new novel, Watergate, bears a certain resemblance to The West Wing. Like that much-loved NBC drama, Watergate shifts among various men and women  mostly men  working inside and outside the White House. Even when the action becomes convoluted, were propelled forward and kept highly entertained by the colorful characters, the delicious insider details, the intelligence of the dialogue.

title: For Romney and Voters, Sometimes a Missed Connection
description: 10:49 p.m. | Updated The full version of this post is available here.

title: Yankees First Lineup Missing Only a Few Names
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For the first time since Oct. 6, 2011, there is a Yankees lineup. Derek Jeter will be leading off for the first preseason game of 2012, against the University of South Florida at 1:05 p.m. Friday.

title: Shake Shack Is Heading to New Haven
description: The global ambitions of Danny Meyers Shake Shack are well known: It has already opened branches in Washington, Dubai and Kuwait City. But the New York hamburger chain may be out to boost its educational pedigree as well with its first toehold in an Ivy League town: New Haven.

title: Veiled Witness in Rutgers Case Tells of Noticing Webcam
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  As he and his new boyfriend lay naked on a bed in a nondescript dormitory room at Rutgers University, the man sensed he was being spied on.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Amber Dermont discusses her debut novel, The Starboard Sea; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jennifer Schuessler on a dictionary of regional American English; J. Hoberman talks about Geoff Dyers Zona; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Kodaks Amateur Photographers: New York
description: While the Eastman Kodak Companys early picture contests were national  and by the 1930s, international  there was no shortage of submissions from intrepid New York photographers.

title: Volvo Recalls 17,000 Models for Potential Flaw in Air-Bag Deployment System
description: Volvo says it is recalling 17,000 of its 2012 S60, XC60, S80 and XC70 models because the front and side air bags may not deploy properly, according to a document posted Friday to the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Morgan Stanley Banker Charged With Assault
description: 4:50 p.m. | Updated

title: Success in College Can Start on the Ballfield
When I Needed Help
description: Recently major eye surgery left me almost blind, jelly-legged, unable to drive, shop, cook my own meals, do the laundry, shower, safely climb the stairs  all the tasks we take for granted. All the tasks many of the frail elderly cannot do for themselves, that they generally do not want strangers in the house helping them to do.

title: Photos of the Moment | Ann Demeulemeester
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Business Day Live | March 2, 2012
description: An interview with the chief executive of Yelp as the company goes public; James B. Stewart on the inside story behind NBC's 'The Voice'; Examining pay at banks.

title: Christian Dior: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Cupcake-Dispensing A.T.M.s? Whats Next?
description: Comes word that an expanding Los Angeles-based cupcake chain will open 24-hour cupcake vending machines at three Manhattan locations this year. The chain, Sprinkles Cupcakes, which has a store on Lexington Avenue near 61st Street, tells The Daily News that the pink machines will pop up in Midtown and Downtown and on the Upper West Side.

title: What the Nanny Saw
description: Vivian Maiers photographs enveloped me in longing  not for Chicago or black-and-white photography but for the perspective of a waist-level viewfinder on a twin-lens reflex camera. Just look at Maiers man in a bow tie or the girls in their winter coats or her gloomy self-portrait. Its the world seen at the eye level of an 8-year-old.

title: Blood Sugar Sex Fatherhood
description: The most memorable image of the Red Hot Chili Peppers has to be of you guys onstage wearing nothing but tube socks over your penises. Can you still get away with that at 49?  The mood hasnt struck me in some time  maybe since the 90s  but if we were at the right place at the right time and Flea looked over at me and said, Lets go play this encore with socks, Im not above it.

title: Downton Abbey and the Fantasy of a Bygone Era
description: I agree with Ms. Chocanos thoughtful description of an imagined ideal of an enlightened aristocracy whose conservatism included a sense of responsibility, not disdain, toward those dependent on it, and Id add that the pleasure of Downton Abbey is watching noble characters endeavor to do what is right and responsible toward others irrespective of the direct personal consequences. Today were faced with the sorry spectacle of so-called leaders in business and politics seemingly always advancing their own interests, or those of their narrowly defined group, while disingenuously claiming allegiance to the greater good. The fantasy of Downton Abbey stands in stark contrast to our current reality.

title: Who Made Those Little Trees Air Fresheners?
description: Little Trees air fresheners the world over owe their rearview-mirror-dangling existence to a chance encounter some 60 years ago in Watertown, N.Y. On that particular day, Julius Samann listened to a milkman complain about one of his occupational hazards, the stench of spoiled milk. It turned out he was talking to just the right guy. Samann, a German-Jewish chemist who fled the Nazis, had studied Alpine tree aromas in the forests of Canada. He was interested in the technology used to transport and disseminate them.

title: The Curious Burden of the Giants Fan
description: Your essay on the New York Giants was a capsule of my life, although fortunately I was able to watch this years Super Bowl with my 80-plus mom at her home in Hackensack. As my parents divorced when I was about 4, and I lived with my mom, she was the one who took me to Yankee Stadium to watch the Giants play, and where I remember having my first sip of beer courtesy of another die-hard fan when I was the ripe old age of 7 or 8. Here it is, 50 years later, and nothing has changed. She always explores the many ways in which they might screw up during the game, for these are all her children and she feels for them, but when they win, her joy is indescribable.

title: Greece Confronts Its Spartan Future
description: Russell Shortos depiction of rugged Spartan entrepreneurship amid the misery of modern-day Greece is an understandable attempt at journalistic balance. Yet there can be no denying the systemic rot that has brought this storied nation to its knees. For all of Angela Merkels mishandling of the sovereign-debt crisis, the German chancellor is not the chief villain in this Greek tragedy. Decades of public profligacy, societal indolence and fiscal duplicity have made Athens the moribund man of Europe. If they wish to restore a proud nations dignity, todays Greeks ought to heed the words of one of historys greatest Stoics, the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius: Stop dithering around. In every confrontation, render what is just; from every impression, extract what is true.

title: Hail the Artisanal Pickle Maker!
description: Id like to see an article on how to obtain funding for all these artisan endeavors. Im sure most people would love to start their own business, but the financial barriers to entry prove too difficult.

title: Operating Under the Influence
description: My neighbor passes out drunk on the stoop, waking me with agonized groans; he blasts music at crazy hours; and he enjoys adult entertainment at embarrassing volumes. He is a surgical assistant at the local hospital, and I suspect he goes to work intoxicated. If an anonymous letter got him fired, patients would be safer, and with no salary, hed soon have to move out. Game, set, match. But would I be overstepping my bounds? What if he starts a downward spiral that ends terribly? Would I be responsible? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Sampling Small Plates on a Food Safari in London
description: Dining out often means making one decision after another. There is the question of where to eat. Then, once youve settled on a neighborhood and restaurant, youve got to figure out which items to order from the menu.

title: Psst, You in Aisle 5
description: Ive had fun with marketers for years. When I sign up for anything that requires personal information, I choose my identity at random. I report that Im a 19-year-old female high-school graduate in the highest income bracket, a 39-year-old Latino male homemaker with some postgraduate/advanced degree or a 75-year-old woman who describes her style as fashion forward. It certainly makes the offers I get from retailers a lot more interesting.

title: Two Women Joined by Justin Timberlake
description: In 2010, Nikki Glaser, a stand-up comic, and Sara Schaefer, a blogger for Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, met at a party and bonded over their affection for Justin Timberlake. Both felt a real connection, and despite the fact that they didnt know each other, decided that it would be fun and funny to start their own podcast about, basically, getting to know each other. They also decided they would record it in front of a few friends in the living room of Schaefers Brooklyn apartment.

title: Jonathan Chaits Sense of Snowe
description: Perfect:

title: The Ending Was Worth the Journey for a Star at Iona
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  Each of Mike Glovers 12 tattoos carries personal significance, but none is more emblematic than the eight italicized words inked on his lean left calf: If You Dont Know Me Dont Judge Me.

title: Alan Alda Asks, What is a Flame?
description: The actor Alan Alda has long been a student and communicator of science, first through the Scientific American Frontiers TV program and now as a coach and mentor to scientists eager to convey their work to the public. His main outlet for that work isThe Center for Communicating Science, a project of theSchool of JournalismatStony Brook Universityon Long Island.

title: Ohio Poll Shows Santorum and Romney Tied
description: Mitt Romneys recent victories in Michigan and Arizona may have given him a slight lift in Ohio, but Rick Santorum is still a strong and viable candidate for a number of voter groups, despite his loss in Michigan.

title: Turkey Bars Loans to Museums in New York and London
description: As part of a campaign to block loans to foreign museums with disputed objects in their collections, Turkey is refusing to lend artifacts to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, The Art Newspaper reported. The Met told the newspaper that a dozen antiquities in its collection are now being claimed by Turkey, but would not identify the individual items, saying the matter was under discussion with the Turkish authorities. And Tolga Tuyluoglu, who runs Turkeys culture and tourism office in London, confirmed to the newspaper that claims for the return of two artifacts in the British Museum and the Victoria and Albert are being pursued, adding that his government wants to resolve the issues before discussing loans for exhibitions. The British Museum had requested loans of 35 items for its current exhibition Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam, but the ministry of culture blocked them, leaving the museum to find alternatives on short notice.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A meatball contest on Friday from 7 to 10 p.m. at Brooklyn Kitchen, 100 Frost Street (between Manhattan and Leonard Streets), in Williamsburg, Brooklyn  featuring chefs from restaurants like Robertas, Gramercy Tavern, Riverpark, Vesta, The Meat Hook and The Meatball Shop  benefits programs that offer cooking lessons in public schools and programs teaching students about urban agriculture. A panel of experts will judge the contest, and a popular vote will also take place. Tickets are $50, available online.

title: Winehouse Foundation Establishes Scholarship
description: A foundation set up in memory of the singer Amy Winehouseafter her death last year from alcohol poisoning will provide a scholarship to a London theater school where she studied voice as a girl, the Winehouse family said.The scholarship to the Sylvia Young Theater School will go to a child whose family cannot afford to pay the tuition, the singers father, Mitch Winehouse, told Reuters.

title: Choosing to Have a Child With Down Syndrome
description: I support abortion rights. Ive had two abortions. Ive body-blocked protesters trying to stand in the way of women entering a womens health clinic that provides abortions. I teach about reproductive rights in classes. I have a bumper sticker advocating abortion rights. Ive written about abortion and gotten hundreds of e-mails, many of them angry in tone, from those who disagree with me.

title: Rebranded Marlins, but Same Brash Guillen
description: Jupiter, Fla.

title: Hothouse Flower
description: We lived in Harlem just, like, at the beginning of its gentrification . . . but my mom had our apartment since she was 18, she worked a retail job, but she worked on commission, so she made like, maybe, 75 or $80,000 a year, but our rent was so cheap since it was, like, rent-controlled, so our rent was, like, $300 a month for a two-bedroom apartment, so we always had extra money. I grew up very spoiled . . . like I had everything: I had computers, I had video games, I had dress-up clothes, I had lipstick, I had heels  not like, actual heels, play heels  I had dolls, I had birds, I had hamsters  my mom did a really good job of keeping me stimulated.

title: Transit Worker Falls 15 Feet in Subway Shaft
description: A transit worker fell about 15 feet in a subway ventilation shaft beneath a grate on East 14th Street Friday morning, the Fire Department said. He was not seriously injured.

title: Blackmail, Big Money and Gross-Outs Galore
description: If youve ever found yourself surfing after midnight through the cable wasteland, you may have chanced across Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job! on Adult Swim, the Cartoon Networks quirky programming block for insomniacs. Surreal live-action sketches in saturated color, lo-fi parodies of television ads and infomercials, and hits of gross-out humor predominate, courtesy of Tim Heidecker and Eric Wareheim, creators adept at cheesy effects. The show comes in at a digestible 15-minutes that ends before you know it, the satires side by side with the late-night sales pitches.

title: Manager Quits Mortuary Where Body Parts Were Lost
description: WASHINGTON  A manager at the heart of a scandal at the Dover Air Force Base mortuary in Delaware, Quinton R. Keel, has resigned, an official familiar with the case said on Friday.

title: Three Hitchens Books Returning to Print
description: Three books by Christopher Hitchens that had gone out of print will be revived in paperback and e-book, the publishers of the titles said. Twelve, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, will release the three books on April 10. The titles are The Missionary Position, a study of Mother Teresa; No One Left to Lie To, a best-selling examination of Bill Clinton; and The Trial of Henry Kissinger. Mr. Hitchens, a prolific author and columnist, died in December at the age of 62 of pneumonia, a complication of esophageal cancer.

title: A Princeton Dean Is Named to Lead Brown
description: Christina Hull Paxson, the dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton, will become president of Brown University on July 1. She succeeds Ruth J. Simmons, who said in September that she would step down.

title: Home Prices Resume Their Fall
description: Home prices in most parts of the country appeared to bottom out in the summer of 2009 and to begin a slow recovery. But now they have fallen below 2009 levels in most markets, according to the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller indexes released this week. Markets where prices peaked in 2007, rather than earlier, generally seem to be suffering the most now.

title: Nanci Griffith, a Texan in Ireland, Singing Her Politics
description: The singer-songwriter Nanci Griffith, who began a tour to promote her 20th album this week in Ireland and the United Kingdom, weaves politics and storytelling in her songwriting. From her roots in Texas to Ireland, her adopted homeland  and her new home in Nashville, where she has always been just beyond the fringes of mainstream country music  Ms. Griffith is an American songwriter with an international cult following.

title: Big-Dollar Individual Campaign Giving and the Tie to Citizens United
description: Much has been written about Citizens United, the 2010 Supreme Court decision that enabled corporations and labor unions to spend unlimited sums to support or oppose political candidates, so long as the spending was independent of the campaigns.

title: Jeff Han from Perceptive Pixel visits The New York Times
description: Jeff Han, founder of Perceptive Pixel, has come a long way from the classic 2006 TED demo, one of the very first YouTube sensations. He visited The New York Times yesterday and brought his companys new 27 inch desktop model to demo.

title: A Fight to the Last Pike
description: Among the many props that John Brown took with him on an 1857 fund-raising tour across New England was a bowie knife that he allegedly took from a vanquished foe during his Bleeding Kansas campaign. While passing through Connecticut, he met with a blacksmith named Charles Blair, who helped him use the knife as a model for a double-edged spear, mounted on a six-foot-long wooden shaft. Brown explained to Blair that such spears, cheap enough to churn out in mass quantities, would be kept by Free State Kansans in their log cabins as a last-ditch defense for themselves and their cause.

title: James Atlas, Veteran Publisher and Author, Will Edit for Amazon
description: The longtime publisher and author James Atlas has signed up with Amazon to edit a series of biographies, he said this week, following in the footsteps of another veteran, Laurence Kirshbaum, the publisher and agent who jumped to Amazon Publishing last year.

title: The Kids Who Shouted the News
description: Dan Barry narrates over a gallery of images and artifacts from the time when newsboys  the town criers of the cities, street-hardened ragamuffins  captured the countrys imagination.

title: Read All About It! Kids Vex Titans!
description: THERE is no sugar-pushing nanny traveling by umbrella this time, no conflicted lion seeking therapy from a meerkat and a warthog. Even so, the premise for Newsies the Musical, the latest Disney property to reach Broadway, seems just as rooted in Disneyesque whimsy: A dese-and-dose scrum of newsboys unites to lead a strike against the most powerful media titans of Old New York.

title: Townsend Harris Teacher Wins $25,000 Milken Award
Home Prices Declined to New Lows in 2011
description: HOME prices in the United States, which seemed to begin to recover in 2009, fell to new lows in 2011, according to the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller index of prices.

title: The Best Part About Global Warming
description: A POPULAR cold-weather complaint of recent winters  if the world is getting warmer, why is there 15 inches of snow in Central Park right now?  has been quietly laid aside this year. Schoolchildren who had anticipated snow days and sledding will tell you that the weather has been disappointingly mild; in fact, since record keeping began, the park has experienced only one warmer winter, in 2001-2.

title: Washington State Lawmaker Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Representative Norm Dicks, the top Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee and the dean of Washington States Congressional delegation, announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election.

title: Obama Backs Student in Furor With Limbaugh on Birth Control
description: 8:50 p.m. | Updated  WASHINGTON  The election-year fight over the administrations birth control policy escalated Friday, with two unlikely figures  a Georgetown University law student and the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh  taking center stage in the politically charged conflict and pulling much of official Washington into the fray.

title: The Daily Shoe | Nina Ricci
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: A Genuine Motherwell? Make Sure Before Buying
description: TALES about art forgeries are almost always intriguing. Maybe thats because of the big amounts paid by unwitting buyers. Or that the people involved invariably emerge as characters worthy of a thriller.

title: From France Avec LAmour: Another Honor for Harvey Weinstein
description: LOS ANGELES  The kid from Queens is now the toast of France.

title: Chain of Avoidable Errors Cited in Koran Burning
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American and Afghan officials investigating the Koran-burning episode that has brought relations between the countries to a new low say that the destruction could have been headed off at several points along a chain of mishaps, poor judgments and ignored procedures, according to interviews over the past week.

title: Inside the List
description: HOWL: The Wolf Gift, Anne Rices first non-Christian novel since she publicly left the faith in 2010 (after a 12-year return to the Catholic Church of her youth), is at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list this week. Rice is as responsible as anyone for pop cultures current fascination with vampires  her 1976 novel Interview With the Vampire represented a tectonic shift and a radical innovation, as the essayist Victoria Nelson puts it in her forthcoming book Gothicka, because it was the first to tell the story from the vampires point of view. Now Rice has turned her attention to that other pop-Gothic standby, the werewolf. Her new novel once again mixes vaguely philosophical inquiries about good and evil with standard horror trappings: His fingers, or were they claws, touched his teeth and they were fangs! He could feel them descending, feel his mouth lengthening! . . . His voice was guttural, roughened. . . . His hands were thickly covered with hair! Hmmm. A growth spurt, a deeper voice, hair in new places  if youre smirking here, well, Rice knows that werewolf stories have always echoed the truly scary specter of puberty. On Amazon, where shes a prolific reviewer of other peoples work, she weighed in last June on The Company of Wolves, a 1984 movie by Neil Jordan (who also directed the big-screen version of Interview). She called it a masterpiece. Werewolf films have for decades dealt with the emerging sexuality of adolescents, she wrote. But this film outdoes them all. . . . Its in a class with films like Cocteaus Beauty and the Beast. It goes deep to the very core of what the werewolf myth has always been about. Disappointingly, Rice hasnt written an Amazon review of Glen Duncans elegant, feral novel The Last Werewolf, which spent three weeks on the extended list last summer.

title: Maryland Womens Lacrosse Looks for Rebound Against Virginia
description: Very few teams in collegiate sports can get through an entire season unscathed. The Maryland womens lacrosse team, though, encountered a bump in the road sooner than it wanted to, when it lost to Duke in its fourth game of the season and Atlantic Coast Conference opener last weekend. The loss was only the fifth for the Terrapins since the opener of the 2009 season, with 67 victories in that span.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Four at Four
description: At No. 4 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is Fantastic Four: Season One, written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and illustrated by David Marquez. Its the first in a series of graphic novels from Marvel Entertainment that chronicles the early days of some of its biggest heroes, including Spider-Man, the X-Men and Daredevil. Fantastic Four: Season One has impressive art and puts a modern spin on some of the genres tropes. My colleague Adam W. Kepler and I favorably reviewed the book last month.

title: Virginia Court Rejects Climate Skeptics Demand for Records
description: Virginias crusading attorney general faces a flashing stop sign in his pursuit of a leading climate scientist. On Friday, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled that the attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli, does not have the authority to demand records of e-mails or grant applications sent by the scientist, Michael E. Mann, who formerly taught at the university and is now a professor at Penn State.

title: New High Schools Seek Students in Round Two
New to the Neighborhood: Schools Opening This Fall
Sentence of the Week: Bronze Age Beefcake Edition
description: And here we are: the final Sentence of the Week before our big Sentence of the Year competition, the runup to which began last March with Charlotte Bront, my first SOTW winner. Lets make it count. Our candidates (interspersed with my comments) are:

title: Marrakeshs White Elephant Becomes an Art Star
description: MARRAKESH  It was not quite planned this way, but the biggest star of the 4th Arts Biennale in Marrakesh may turn out to be an unfinished opera house, the towns great white elephant. Conceived in Pan-Arabic style and started 20 years ago, it was never finished and grandly squats outside the city ramparts, part mosque, part decaying Luxor temple.

title: Bankruptcys Odd Twist With Union Contracts
description: The pilots union has sued AMR, the parent company of American Airlines. And the complaint, at the end of this post, illustrates nicely one oddity in the bankruptcy code with regard to collective bargaining agreements  a point that is relevant in the many other cases pending currently that involve questions of unionized employees.

title: The Wealth of Experience
description: IVE been doing this so long I dont even think about it, Hussein Chalayan said on Friday as models cheered after a stellar show. Its just instinctual.

title: Maison Martin Margiela: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: NBC Notches a Ratings Win With Awake
description: The new NBC drama Awake was among the best reviewed shows of the television season and, by NBCs current standards, it performed respectably well in its first outing Thursday night.

title: Dancing a Hora All His Own
description: TEL AVIV

title: TimesCast | March 2, 2012
description: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin is expected to win a third presidential term in Sundays Russian election | An international soccer panel is to rule on a hijab ban.

title: F.C.C. Asks for Guidance on Whether, and When, to Cut Off Cellphone Service
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission is reviewing whether or when the police and other government officials can intentionally interrupt cellphone and Internet service to protect public safety.

title: Giant Jurassic Fleas Packed a Mean Mouth
description: Scientists have discovered the worlds oldest fleas to date  bloodsuckers that lived among (and possibly on) dinosaurs.

title: Temple Discovers That Three Is Not a Crowd in the Backcourt
description: PHILADELPHIA  Forward Scootie Randall was playing the best basketball of his Temple career late last season when a foot injury sidelined him for the Owls final seven games before the N.C.A.A. tournament. But his injury turned out to be a fortuitous development for Temple because it spawned one of the nations best three-guard lineups.

title: A.I.G. Sheds Stake in Blackstone
description: The American International Group has sold its $500 million stake in the Blackstone Group, severing a longtime direct investment in the private equity giant, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: U.N. Faults NATO and Libyan Authorities in Report
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  NATO has not sufficiently investigated the air raids it conducted on Libya that killed at least 60 civilians and wounded 55 more during the conflict there, according to a new United Nations report released Friday.

title: One More Reason to Do Research Before Buying Art
description: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about the limits of insurance coverage when that expensive piece of art hanging in the foyer turns out to be a forgery.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Doubled Over in Pain Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a 30-year-old man with a two-week history of severe abdominal pain.

description: A scene from "Casa de Mi Padre," with Will Ferrell and Diego Luna.

title: The Age of Oral Histories
description: In the Book Review, Sarah Lyall reviews Craig Taylors Londoners, an oral history of contemporary London as seen through the eyes of the citys residents and former inhabitants. Ms. Lyall writes:

title: But Is a Swallow Faster Than a Flying Circus?
description: Breaking!

title: Born of 1,000 Influences, an Original Look at Love
description: IN the course of a two-hour conversation about her movie Attenberg the Greek filmmaker Athina Rachel Tsangari invoked a practically encyclopedic range of genre inspirations: buddy movie, screwball comedy, Greek tragedy, western, musical, science fiction and  not least of all  nature documentary. (The title is a mispronunciation of Attenborough, as in David, the living legend of science and natural history television.)

description: M. has a happy quandary  or at least, happy for her. Shes pregnant  four months along  and telling friends the news. But theres one friend she hasnt told:

title: Cambodias Sweet Spot
description: ON a sunny weekday in Kep, a seaside village about halfway along Cambodias coast, the crab market was heaving. Women in straw hats and rubber boots stood knee deep in the surf shouting out prices, periodically darting into the sea to pull writhing specimens out of wicker baskets. Children of all ages ran through the stalls; it seemed as if the entire town had congregated in this one main square.

title: The Week Ahead
description: RENDEZ-VOUS WITH FRENCH CINEMA, the Film Society of Lincoln Centers annual glimpse into the state of that art, this year grows richer with the addition of Rendez-Vous + (through Thursday), a sidebar showcasing documentaries, older movies and at least one certifiable classic: Jean Grmillons LUMIRE DT, presented in a newly restored version by the Cinmathque Franaise.

title: When Innocence Isnt Enough
description: EDWARD LEE ELMORE turned 53 in January. For more than half his life, the soft-spoken African-American who doesnt understand the concept of north, south, east and west, or of summer, fall, winter and spring, was in a South Carolina prison, most of it on death row.

title: High Line Art Announces Spring Lineup
description: On Friday, High Line Art, the public art program of the New York park built on a historic elevated rail line, announced its plans for its spring 2012 season. Work on view will include, in April, a new contribution by the Scottish artist David Shrigley to the High Line Billboard series, presented on a 25-by-75-foot billboard next to the park on Tenth Avenue at West 18th Street, and films and videos in the High Line Channel series, an outdoor program featuring projections on a building to the east of the High Line at West 22nd Street after dark.

title: Ego and Envy, So It Is Written
description: THE world is full of unsung academics who toil all their lives in an obsessive quest for knowledge  and a reputation-making breakthrough in their chosen field  only to end up a footnote in someone elses brilliant career.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

description: The Mavericks and Spurs could be getting valuable players back, as Lamar Odom and Manu Ginobili are getting closer to returning to their respective lineups.

description: HYSTERICAL EXCESS: DISCOVERING ANDRZEJ ZULAWSKI is the film programmers equivalent of a banner headline. Its not exactly misleading, but the subject of this BAMcinmatek retrospective is definitely displeased.

title: An Economist Rebuts The Wall Street Journal 16 on Climate Risk
description: In a contribution to a recent Dot Earth post, William D. Nordhaus, a Yale University economist who has spent many years examining the costs and benefits of various climate policies, angrily rejected a description of his work used by 16 scientists questioning concerns about global warming in an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal.

title: For iRobot, the Future Is Getting Closer
description: BEDFORD, Mass.  Ever since Rosey the Robot took care of The Jetsons in the early 1960s, the promise of robots making everyday life easier has been a bit of a tease.

title: Chandana Kanithi and Siva Korukonda
description: THE man Chandana Kanithi was looking for did not seem that elusive  loyal and honest, a good sense of humor and, since she was a clinical psychologist, someone who was psychologically aware.

description: This report details the results of an investigation by a three-member commission on human rights and international law violations during the war in Libya.

description: Lin Dakang, a bicycle deliveryman who works for a Chinese restaurant on Manhattans Upper East Side, discusses his hectic life on the road, swerving taxis and good and bad tips.

description: Paris

title: For Pollution Monitors, Some Cash Incentives
description: For New Yorkers wondering how dirty the air in their neighborhood really is or how polluted a local beach might be, the federal Environmental Protection Agency is offering money, a mission and a title: citizen scientist.
