title: That Seat Is So Taken
description: By spring, the Dutch airline KLM plans to allow all intercontinental passengers to choose their seatmates based on data uploaded from Facebook and other sites. Of course, the most desirable seatmate of all remains ones own carry-on. To achieve this rarest of travel triumphs, simply create an indelible anti-social-networking presence. The Platonic ideal of an alienating Facebook profile  one that will keep potential seatmates far, far away  should look something like this:

title: How to Practice the Reverse Peter Principle
description: This interview with  Tracy Dolgin, president and chief executive of the YES cable sports network, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Genes on the March
description: MY mother always said I must be part Mongolian, because of my lotus-pale complexion and squid-ink black hair. Something youre not telling me? I was tempted to ask. But I knew shed visited Mongolia with my father long after I was born. What I didnt know is that one out of every 200 males on earth is related to Genghis Khan.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Michigan and Arizona primaries to Super Tuesday states.

title: Numbers That Sway Markets and Voters
description: SOMETIMES a number is just a number. But on Tuesday, when the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 13,000, it was treated as much more than that.

title: Economic Models and Economic Predictions
description: Noah Smith has a further entry in the ongoing discussion of microfoundations and all that; I have some minor quibbles, but right now I just want to pursue a train of thought Ive been having about the role of predictions in economic doctrine.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Michigan and Arizona primaries to Super Tuesday states.  Go to the slide show.

title: The Indoctrination Myth
description: THE Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum recently called President Obama a snob for supporting higher education for all Americans. There are good, decent men and women, he said, who go out and work hard every day and put their skills to test that arent taught by some liberal college professor trying to indoctrinate them. He also called colleges and universities indoctrination mills for godless liberalism.

title: Capital Gains, Ordinary Income and Shades of Gray
description: WHAT is carried interest? And why does it get the tax treatment it does?

title: Corporate Abuse Abroad, a Path to Justice Here
description: Should foreigners be allowed to use American courts to sue foreign corporations for human rights atrocities committed abroad?

title: Surveillance, Security and Civil Liberties
description: Taking office not long after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly wisely decided to beef up the Police Departments counterterrorism program significantly, to help federal law enforcement agencies avert another disaster.

title: The Truth About the Doomsday Virus?
description: Two months ago we warned that a new bird flu virus  modified in a laboratory to make it transmissible through the air among mammals  could kill millions of people if it escaped confinement or was stolen by terrorists. Now Ron Fouchier, the Dutch scientist who led the key research team, is saying that his findings, which remain confidential, were misconstrued by the press.

title: Visiting the Yankees in a Sons Memory
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Dr. Matthew Smith didnt know what he wanted when he showed up at the Yankees first Grapefruit League game on Saturday wearing one of his deceased sons many Yankee jerseys and bearing a poster of him.

title: We Know How to Spell Relief
description: Tired of sleazy political ads? They are unlikely to go away. But Ohio voters had a brief moment of relief last year when more than a score of local TV stations exercised a rarely used authority and pulled down a loathsome ad that had pirated content from a rival ad, reversed its message and misled the public.

title: The Scholar and the Rascal
description: THE right-wing provocateur Andrew Breitbart and the neoconservative scholar James Q. Wilson, who died within 48 hours of each other last week  Wilson at the age of 80, Breitbart so unexpectedly at 43  had one important thing in common: They were both prominent conservatives who arguably left their most enduring legacy in the lives of affluent, cosmopolitan liberals.

title: Take the Subway
description: OUR plan was to meet for lunch at noon in Moscow. It was to be just myself and Fyodor Lukyanov, the editor of the journal Russia in Global Affairs. He picked the restaurant. It had been snowing that day, and the Moscow traffic  already nearly impossible because the city, which 15 years ago had 300,000 cars and today hosts nearly four million registered vehicles  was even more impossible than usual. Soon the e-mailing between us started. I was first: Im running a few minutes late. Lukyanov said the same a few minutes later. Then me again: I am going to be 20 minutes late. He then saw my 20 minutes and raised me 20. In the end, I was 50 minutes late, and I beat him by two minutes. We sped through an interview about Russian foreign policy in 30 minutes, before I rushed out so as not to be late for my next appointment. As we hurriedly put on our coats, Lukyanov had one piece of advice for me, and it wasnt that the U.S. should stay out of Syria.

title: Have You No Shame, Rush?
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Second Screen, Trying to Complement the First
description: DO two screens create television-watching heaven? Do viewers want television content on their laps as well as on the main screen?

title: Snowes Sad Retreat
description: BACK in 1999, when I covered Congress, I had a kind of crush on Olympia Snowe. Many of us in the Senate press gallery did.

description: HERES what a woman in Texas now faces if she seeks an abortion.

description: MANDALAY, Myanmar  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmars democracy movement, fell ill during a campaign rally on Saturday, cutting short a speech to a large and enthusiastic crowd.

description: To the Editor:

title: Syrian Televisions Underwhelming Evidence of Foreign Backing for Rebels
description: Updated | Sunday | 8:38 p.m As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and Hwaida Saad report, the Syrian government blocked an aid convoy from entering a devastated neighborhood in the city of Homs on Saturday, citing safety concerns, a day after granting access to a state television crew.

title: The Bizarre Road of a DHL Founder
description: IMAGINE the billionaire founder of a major American corporation suddenly waltzing away from his executive duties to spend the rest of his days as a glorified sex tourist, trolling the dives and brothels of Vietnam and the Philippines for pubescent girls.

title: Super Pac! Super Bad!
description: David Brooks: Gail, weve been having our online conversations since the 2008 election, but this is the first one theyve asked us to do for the actual newspaper. Are we really ready for the big time? My view is that its like when Jennifer Aniston tried to make the leap to the big screen. A possible disaster, leading to embarrassment for all involved.

title: Love Story
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  David J. Kahn is quickly becoming the jokester of the crossword world.

title: Two Towns, Two Contrasting Models
description: The divergent economic circumstances of two towns on the French-German border are striking, and the reasons for the disparities have emerged as a focal point of the French presidential campaign.

title: French-German Border Shapes More Than Territory
description: SLESTAT, France  This ancient town in the center of Alsace boasts the extraordinary Humanist Library, dating from the 15th century. But less proudly, Slestat also has an unemployment rate of about 8 percent, much higher than towns just across the border in Germany.

title: Los Alamos Residents Brace for Layoffs at Lab
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M.  Sharon Stover remembers the stories her mother used to tell about what life was like when Los Alamos National Laboratory first opened during World War II.

title: Limbaugh Apologizes for Attack on Student in Birth Control Furor
description: In an about-face, the conservative talk radio host Rush Limbaugh said Saturday that he was sorry for denouncing as a prostitute a Georgetown University law student who had spoken publicly in favor of the Obama administrations birth control policy.

title: Creating a Niche, and Earning a Promotion
description: WHEN youre an employee of a company, no matter the size, its common to see co-workers promoted, or transferred to a different department. But there is another way to move around: by creating a new position for yourself. I did this several years ago, though I wasnt actively looking for a different job.

title: Poetry and a Pickup Truck
description: I GUESS you could say that my husband and I are free spirits. We built our greetings business by driving town to town, around the country, selling cards we wrote and designed.

title: A Man Is Found Dead in Chelsea
description: A 57-year-old man was found dead in his Chelsea apartment Friday evening, his mouth and hands bound with duct tape, the police said.

title: In a Flood Tide of Digital Data, an Ark Full of Books
description: RICHMOND, Calif.  In a wooden warehouse in this industrial suburb, the 20th century is being stored in case of digital disaster.

title: Pressed for Anecdote, Romney Recounts Tale of Missing Girl
description: DAYTON, Ohio  For the second time in a week, a man stood at town hall meeting and urged Mitt Romney to brag about his altruism. The voters anecdote of choice Saturday afternoon in Ohio concerned the time Mr. Romney shut down his Boston-based private equity company and headed to New York to help track down a colleagues missing daughter.

title: A War on Women?
description: My Sunday column focuses on the growing number of states that are adding new restrictions to abortions, cutting family planning or taking other steps that in some cases seem patronizing and insulting to women. The most remarkable example is Texas, which has received little attention that subjects many women who want an abortion to a vaginal ultrasound and forces them to hear a description of the fetus. And theres more, as I recount in the column. I find all this deeply offensive what about you? Id welcome your comments.

title: Has Putin Lost His Sex Appeal?
description: LONDON  Trust the French to detect an erotic element in Vladimir V. Putins election campaign.

title: A Movement for Change
description: As Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin runs for his third term as president, young Russians question what it will take for the promise of democracy born in 1991 to truly take hold.

title: Voting in Wukan
description: More than 6,000 of the towns 8,000 eligible voters helped elect a new village council to replace the old one, which was disbanded amid allegations of land fraud.

title: Protests Success May Not Change China
description: WUKAN, China  For the brave and canny residents who famously rose up in December and ran their corrupt leaders out of town, the election held on Saturday in this ramshackle fishing village was billed as the big payoff, a democratic reward for demanding their rights.

title: Demolished Small Towns Look for Survivors
description: By Saturday afternoon, the death toll had climbed to 37 people from the violent storms that spawned multiple tornadoes on Friday, flattening homes and buildings in more than a dozen mostly small, rural towns in southern Indiana and Kentucky, authorities said.

title: From Nominal Catholic to Clarion of Faith
description: GREAT FALLS, Va.  Rick Santorum was, in his own words, a nominal Catholic when he met Karen Garver, a neonatal nurse and law student, in 1988. As they made plans to marry and he decided to enter politics, she sent him to her father for advice.

title: Romney Traces Obamas Path on Delegates
description: WASHINGTON  The first phase of the 2012 Republican presidential campaign, ending with the 10 states that vote this week on Super Tuesday, has been about money and message. The next several months will be about maps and math.

title: Model-Morphosis | Zen Sevastyanova at Haider Ackermann
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2012 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Zen Sevastyanova of IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Stephane Marais and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

title: Early Whiff of October for Yankees and Phillies
description: CLEARWATER. Fla.  With palm trees bending in a stiff wind and players wearing jerseys with numbers in the high 80s, Saturdays Grapefruit League opener would never be mistaken for an important game.

title: World Champion Wins but Does Little to Distance Herself From U.S. Rivals
description: Jordyn Wieber, a composed 16-year-old from DeWitt, Mich., has done everything possible to become the favorite to win the all-around gold medal in womens gymnastics at the Olympics this summer.

title: A Masters Setbacks in Life Inspire Success at the Board
description: Jay Bonin embodies what it means to live in service to Caissa, the mythical goddess of chess. Bonin, 56, is a New York international master who probably has played more tournaments than anyone.

title: The Pains Before a Star Was Born
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On the night before he altered the N.B.A. universe, Jeremy Lins primary goal was to keep his job. Things could have gone better.

title: Romney Takes Washington Ahead of a Big Election Day
description: Mitt Romney won Saturdays nonbinding caucuses in Washington State, handing him a symbolic victory in his quest for the Republican nomination as he heads into the critical Super Tuesday contests just three days away.

title: Coach Who Preached Violence Rewarded It for Years
description: By the time Josh Evans got to the Houston Oilers in 1995, the bounty system  and Gregg Williams  were fixtures. Williams coached the linebackers then, but by 1997, the team had moved to Tennessee and Williams was the defensive coordinator. The bounties remained in place.

title: The Fall of the House of Underwood
description: For Josie Underwood, much was in a name. Her hilltop home, Mount Air, the dearest old home in the world, lay just a mile northeast of Bowling Green, Ky., overlooking the Louisville and Nashville Railroad that ran three-quarters away, across the Barren River. Fields of corn and wheat waved heavy in the rich bottomland looping around the north and east sides of the 1,000-acre farm, one of the largest in the region. It was, as one Pennsylvania visitor claimed, The realization of all he had read and imagined of a hospitable Southern home. Among its most distinguishing features, he noted, was the knot of slave cabins that lay off the home places east gable.

title: Celebrating Where San Franciscos Black Roots Run Deepest
description: When Michelle Long saw workers throwing out documents at her San Francisco church, Bethel African Methodist Episcopal, at a conference 12 years ago, she decided something had to be done  so she became the church archivist.

title: Companies Foreclose; Blight Follows
description: Every few weeks, Alvin Chandra cleans up the garbage that has accumulated in the vacant lot next to his granite fabrication plant on Adeline Street in West Oakland  soiled mattresses, worn-out sofa beds and piles of used fast food containers.

title: Taking Development Out of the Schools
description: Sam Borden writes Sunday about a rules change that has split the forces of soccer development in the United States. An excerpt: The United States Soccer Federation announced a new policy recently that will uncouple high school soccer and the training of top youth players, a move that is unique among major team sports in this country and, some believe, is indicative of a trend in the way the United States develops elite athletes. The shift by the federation applies to its top boys teams around the country, requiring players on those teams  known as Development Academy teams  to participate in a nearly year-round season and, by extension, forcing them and their soccer moms and dads to decide whether they should play for their club or play for their school. Read the article here, and join the discussion in the comments.

title: Stan Stearns, Photographer of John F. Kennedy Jr.s Salute to Father, Dies at 76
description: Stan Stearns, whose iconic photograph of John F. Kennedy Jr. saluting his fathers coffin on Nov. 25, 1963, helped encapsulate a nations grief, died Friday at a hospice near Annapolis, Md. He was 76.

title: Hansen Takes Charge in the Gotham and Steadies His Shaky Derby Profile
description: It wasnt just that Hansen won the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct on Saturday, but how he won. He was coming off a second-place finish in the Holy Bull Stakes at Gulfstream, where he stumbled at the start, darted feverishly to the lead, tired late and acted nothing like the kind of horse who could win the Kentucky Derby, but he did everything right at Aqueduct.

title: Theyre Gaga Over The Lady
description: HONG KONG  Much of her country is gaga for The Lady, as she is known, and crowds in Myanmar are swarming her campaign speeches and pro-democracy rallies. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was, of course, born this way: Her late father, General Aung San, led the fight for Burmas independence from Britain and remains a national hero.

title: Bulwinkleland
description: A brightly colored Quonset hut on a West Oakland street appears to be sprouting sunflowers, but it is actually the studio and home of Mark Bulwinkle, an artist. The structure and surrounding land are crammed with sculptures featuring whimsical and sometimes diabolical images of cavorting animals and people. Covering nine city lots, Bulwinkleland  as the artist calls his homestead  is jaw-dropping.

title: A Young Bush Works to Nurture Hispanic Roots Within the Republican Party
description: The seeds of political ascension for a member of the Bush family may have been planted in an Austin eatery whose name conjures up images of Janis Joplin jam sessions.

title: Austin Auteur Tries Traditional but Stays Eccentric
description: Among followers of the independent film scene, the name Bob Byington usually inspires a knowing, if furtive, smile of recognition: Mr. Byington, an Austin-based writer-director, is one of those best-kept secrets that fans prefer to keep to themselves, for fear that if everyone knows about him, he wont seem nearly as cool.

title: In Battle for Political Conquest, Ethnicity Sets the Boundaries for Both Parties
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Another Sunday Offers Another Chance for McIlroy to Claim No. 1 Ranking
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  As Rory McIlroy stalks his third PGA Tour victory, the greatest impediment is not PGA Nationals Bear Trap, the three consecutive holes beginning with No. 15 that McIlroy has played in 13 over par in 15 career rounds.

title: New Plans to Improve Performance at T.S.U.
description: With a mere 3 percent of Texas Southern University students graduating within four years  and less than a quarter earning their degree in a decade  the schools president, John Rudley, knows that people are asking Whats wrong with this institution? and What are they going to do about it?

title: Mets Say Davis Has Valley Fever
description: The Mets said they believed first baseman Ike Davis had valley fever, a fungal infection of the lungs. Davis has not been showing any outward symptoms, is not contagious and is not taking medication, the team said in a statement. The team said the infection was expected to resolve itself on its own.

title: Tar Heels Prove Too Much for Duke and Win A.C.C.
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Duke season highlights were playing on the scoreboard above center court at Cameron Indoor Stadium on Saturday night before the Blue Devils took on North Carolina in the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season finale. It was not hard to guess which play drew the loudest cheers: a 3-pointer at the buzzer by the freshman Austin Rivers that beat the Tar Heels in the teams previous meeting this season.

title: Alex Webster, Giants Running Back and Coach, Dies at 80
description: Alex Webster, a powerful running back who helped propel the Giants to six division titles and a National Football League championship in the late 1950s and early 60s and later became their coach for five seasons, died Saturday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 80.

title: Washington Keeps Romney on Winning Track
description: With 77 percent of the vote counted in the Washington caucuses, Mr. Romney won about 36 percent of the straw-poll vote there. His total may vary slightly as additional votes trickle in, but it should remain somewhere in that range, and he has been declared the winner by The Associated Press.

title: Helene Strauss and Aaron Schulman
description: Helene Lilly Strauss and Dr. Aaron Paul Schulman are to be married Sunday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Howard R. Buechler is to lead the ceremony, with Cantor Azi Schwartz participating.

description: Madeline Paradise Fleisher and Matthew Scott McKenzie were married Saturday evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Rabbi Joshua Martin Siegel officiated in an interfaith ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Protestant traditions.

title: Amanda Klearman and Adam Miller
description: Amanda Kate Klearman and Adam Joshua Miller are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Alan Freedman at the Austin Country Club in Austin, Tex.

title: Rachel Rosen, Evan Goldstein
description: Rachel Laura Rosen and Evan Robert Goldstein are to be married Saturday evening in Baltimore by Rabbi Steven Schwartz at the George Peabody Library, part of Johns Hopkins University.

title: Kimberly Rittberg and Alexander Nyren
description: Kimberly Rachel Rittberg, the daughter of Ellen Pober Rittberg of Roslyn, N.Y., and Israel Rittberg of Forest Hills, Queens, was married Tuesday to Alexander Patrick Nyren, the son of Lois S. Nyren and Neil S. Nyren of Manhattan. Rabbi Jonathan Stein performed the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Manhattan.

title: Raina Miller, Steven Fischler
description: Raina Faith Miller and Steven Adam Fischler were married Saturday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated.

title: Elana Mayerfield, Ethan Mandelup

title: Chad Schroer and Frank Spinelli
description: Dr. Chad Allen Schroer and Dr. Frank Angelo Spinelli were married Tuesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Josephine Tagliarini, a staff member of the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Jessica Nagin and Jordan Katz
description: Jessica Brown Nagin and Jordan Emanuel Katz were married Saturday evening at the Powerhouse, a party space at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Justice Michael J. Obus of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Jewish School Loses in Final of Texas Basketball Tournament
description: Houstons Robert M. Beren Academy, which successfully appealed a scheduling conflict that nearly forced it to forfeit its place in a Texas basketball tournament this week, lost to Abilene Christian, 46-42, on Saturday night in the state championship game.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: The magazine landscape in India this week was awash with cover stories assessing Gujarat and its controversial Chief Minister Narendra Modi to reflect on the anniversary of the communal riots in the state a decade ago.

description: Hockey is joining the drive to end homophobia in sports with a public-service message featuring eight N.H.L. players, including Henrik Lundqvist of the Rangers, Corey Perry of the Anaheim Ducks and Daniel Alfredsson of the Ottawa Senators.

title: China Calls for Expanded Use of Condoms
description: HONG KONG  China has just issued a new action plan to combat the rising spread of H.I.V. and AIDS, and this seems to be the takeaway: Condoms or condom vending machines should be available in 95 percent of the countrys hotels by 2015.

title: Why Romney Wants to Be Like Michael Dukakis
description: The conventional wisdom holds that the periodic rise and fall of various conservative or outside challengers to Mr. Romney  Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum, Herman Can, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas  is a sign that Republican voters have aligned into Romney and Not Romney camps. Further, it claims that Mr. Romney is benefiting since two of the Not Romney choices, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Santorum, remain available to Republican voters.

title: North Korean Leader Takes a Defiant Stance as He Visits Border
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a visit to the heavily armed border with the South, the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his troops on higher alert, escalating his militaristic language in spite of American calls to improve ties with the Seoul just a week after his country agreed to a nuclear freeze in return for badly needed food aid.

title: Schrdingers Tax
description: David Cay Johnston tells us that the usual suspects on the right are arguing that its OK to cut corporate tax rates, because they really fall on wages, not on profits.

description: The one percent, that is. Emmanuel Saez has updated his distributional estimates (pdf), and as expected the top 1% share, which fell in the crisis, has resumed its upward march.

Putin a six-year term as president on Sunday, a widely expected outcome that set the stage for a far more suspenseful post-election confrontation between the freshly emboldened leader and an opposition movement that has repeatedly rallied tens of thousands of protesters.

title: Chinese Congress Opens With Upbeat Economic Assessments, and Eyes on the Top
description: BEIJING  Chinas prime minister, Wen Jiabao, opened the annual meeting of the countrys handpicked legislature on Monday with a markedly upbeat assessment of the state of the nation, stating that threats posed by bad local government debt and soaring real estate prices were under control, that the economy was robust and that the peoples well-being is improving.

description: 11:16 a.m. | Updated  Representative Eric Cantor, a Republican from Virginia and the majority leader in the House, endorsed Mitt Romney on Sunday for the Republican presidential nomination, giving the former governor of Massachusetts important backing from a leading lawmaker known for his fiscal conservatism.

description: The acclaimed New York restaurant Le Cirque is taking its lobster salad and other recipes on the road in a series of pop-up dinners across the country.

description: This is just current government expenditures divided by the GDP deflator, starting from 1982IV and 2009II; no attempt to separate out unemployment benefits, other transfers, etc.. title: Death Toll Grows to 16 in Head-On Collision of 2 Trains in Poland
description: BERLIN  The death toll in the high-speed, head-on collision of two passenger trains in Poland rose to 16 people on Sunday, with the authorities asking how both ended up on the same track.

title: Disruptions: No More Innovation for the Fun of It
description: SAN FRANCISCO I wouldnt describe the car industry as fun. The airline industry isnt fun either. Phone companies are far from fun. Yet these industries all started out fun. They began with tinkerers and innovators, just like, say, the Internet today.

title: Cherry Blossom Deals Bloom for Centennial
description: In 1912, the first two of 3,000 trees that the mayor of Tokyo gave to Washington were planted around the Tidal Basin. The centennial will be marked by the National Cherry Blossom Festival, whose typical 16-day run will be extended to 5 weeks this year.

title: Continuing Buildup, China Boosts Military Spending More Than 11 Percent
description: BEIJING  China announced a double-digit increase in military spending on Sunday, a rise that comes amid an intensifying strategic rivalry between the United States and China in Asia and concerns in Washington about the secrecy surrounding the Chinese defense budget.

title: Explosions at Congo Weapons Depot Kill Scores
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A series of explosions at a weapons depot in Brazzaville, the capital of the Republic of Congo, killed scores of people on Sunday, according to Congolese Web sites and news agency dispatches.

title: Tar Heels Make a Statement
description: No. 4 North Carolina left little doubt as to which team was the deserving champion of the Atlantic Coast Conference Saturday night.

title: Mets to Be Cautious With Wright
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets will be without David Wright for at least their first two games of spring training as he continues to experience discomfort in the left side of his rib cage.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Vivienne Westwood
description: We need lots more sequins! We dont have enough sequins! the makeup artist Val Garland said backstage at Vivienne Westwood. She was calling for more of her custom opalescent sequin tears to be applied to Botticelli-inspired faces. Theyre beautiful, celestial beings looking up to the heavens, crying in ecstasy, she said of the models with red-pink or tea-stained lids. The look was created using M.A.C. copper walnut Sculpting Cream all around and inside the eye along with Fascinating Eye Kohl. A shell highlighter was applied along the jawline, to create the effect of gazing up into light. Mahogany and Vino lip pencils lined a mouth that was then touched with Naturally Defined Sculpting Cream and set with Prep and Prime finishing powder. Then, came the tears. Sam McKnight made a pretty and wild nest of hair using Pantene Volume Mousse and Volume and Body Hairspray and pulling two sides back leaving half the hair down, then looping it over and through where it was already tied. It took only a few pins to secure the style after he pulled out strands using what he described as a simple, childlike gesture. He thought the whole elegant mess might be made by a young girl  channeling Caravaggio, of course.

title: Dr. Seuss The Lorax Has Huge Opening Weekend
description: Pent-up demand for a family film and a well-executed marketing campaign by Universal Pictures sent Dr. Seuss The Lorax into the box-office stratosphere over the weekend. With an estimated $70.7 million in ticket sales in North America, The Lorax, about a mustachioed critter with a tree-saving mantra, was a huge No. 1 despite poor reviews. (In The New York Times, A.O. Scott called it a noisy, useless piece of junk.

title: Rhode Island Said to Dismiss Its Basketball Coach
description: The University of Rhode Island fired its mens basketball coach, Jim Baron, on Sunday, according to a source with direct knowledge of the situation. School officials met with the team around noon on Sunday to inform them of the decision.

title: Loose Talk of War Only Helps Iran, President Says
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans on the campaign trail ramped up their support for Israel in a possible military strike on Iran, President Obama used a speech before a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday to warn against the loose talk of war that could serve to speed Iran toward a nuclear weapon.

title: Romney and Santorum Tie in Ohio Poll
description: Heading into Super Tuesdays contests, Rick Santorum and Mitt Romney remain neck and neck in the major battleground state of Ohio, while Newt Gingrich leads in his native state of Georgia, according to polls released on Sunday.

description: March 4, 2012  President Obama talked about Israel, Iran, and nuclear weapons at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee meeting in Washington. (Courtesy of MSNBC)

title: Gingrich Channels Sondheim: Hes Still Here
description: Despite the long dry spell since he last won a Republican presidential nominating contest, Newt Gingrich gave the impression on Sunday that he is enjoying his self-assigned role of player/manager as he watches the political parade pass by.

title: Legal Strategy Taken by Shell Is Rarely Successful
description: WASHINGTON  The oil giant Shell filed suit in federal court in Alaska last week against a dozen environmental groups, employing a rare  and rarely successful  legal gambit in an effort to pre-empt anticipated legal challenges to its plans to begin exploration in the Arctic Ocean this summer.

title: Tap Express
description: Joshua Johnson, a Penn State student, returns to New York City a few times a month to earn tuition money by tap dancing on the subway.

title: On the Train, Tap Dancing to Pay for College
description: On a recent Friday afternoon, Joshua Johnson danced down a Q train car with an Air Jordan sneaker on his left foot to keep from slipping and a tap shoe on his right foot to play a beat as he collected money from several riders.

title: Santorum Makes an Appeal to Conservatives in the South
description: MEMPHIS  Rick Santorum fought to shore up conservative support in the South on Sunday, attending a Baptist megachurch and courting voters over ribs and pulled pork at a famous barbecue restaurant here.

description: Paris

title: Foreign Investment in Europe Starts Anew
description: PARIS  Last summer, as the mounting European debt crisis was forcing many businesses in the region to scale back, the multinational Dow Chemical made a seemingly contrarian move: rather than hunker down, it doubled down.

title: Philosophy by Another Name
description: Every professional philosopher, or student of philosophy, knows how linguistically confusing the name of our discipline can be when talking to people outside the field. They immediately assume you are in the business of offering sage advice, usually in the form of unargued aphorisms and proverbs. You struggle to explain that you dont do that kind of philosophy, at which point you may well be accused of abandoning your historical calling  unearthing and explicating the meaning of life and what the ultimate human goods are. You may then be castigated for not being a real philosopher, by contrast with assorted gurus, preachers, homeopaths and twinkly barroom advice givers. Our subject then falls into disrepute and incomprehension.

title: Dozens of Yemeni Soldiers Reported Dead in Militant Attack
description: ADEN, Yemen  Islamist militants bombarded an army encampment near the city of Zinjibar in southern Yemen on Sunday, and dozens of soldiers and militants were reported killed. Zinjibar is one of two cities that the Yemeni government has sworn to take back by force from the militants control.

title: Rangers Make It Three in a Row Against the Bruins
description: The Rangers have beaten the Boston Bruins all three times they have played this season, and the reason, simply put, is goaltending. It is why the Rangers are in first place in the Eastern Conference, and why, over the past six weeks, the Bruins have tumbled from within a whisker of first place into the jumble of teams far below.

title: A Rootless Writer, Anchored by Woe
description: The novels of Joseph Roth, with the three-generation family saga Radetzky March in the forefront, have enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of interest in recent years, so much so that Roth is now often mentioned in the same breath as Kafka and Robert Musil as one of the greatest German-language writers of the 20th century. But in the absence of a biography Roth the man has remained largely an unknown to readers, at least in the English-speaking world.

title: Quaint Martian Odyssey With Multiplex Stopover
description: John Carter, Disneys $250 million, 3-D sci-fi epic, which opens on Friday, is based on a novel, Edgar Rice Burroughss Princess of Mars, that is 100 years old and was already a little dated when it came out. Burroughs, better known for his Tarzan saga, published it in monthly installments in the All-Story Magazine starting in February 1912. It was the first thing he ever wrote, after a lifetime of failing at just about everything else, and he was clearly learning on the job.

title: Playing It Safe in Programming Philharmonic
description: Ideally, being the music director of a major symphony orchestra involves more than planning seasons and conducting concerts: it offers a chance to be a cultural leader and educator. Alan Gilberts predecessor at the New York Philharmonic, Lorin Maazel, showed scant interest in those aspects of the job. Since arriving in 2009 Mr. Gilbert has embraced them.

title: Bouquets and Bravas for the Mets Sudden Aida
description: As often happens with cover singers at the Metropolitan Opera the soprano Latonia Moore had less than a days notice to take over a major part, in her case the title role of Verdis Aida on Saturday afternoon. Violeta Urmana, scheduled to sing, was ill. (Sondra Radvanovsky had filled in for her on Tuesday.) So with just some studio coaching sessions and no rehearsal onstage, Ms. Moore, a 33-year-old Houston native, made her Met debut in the last performance of the revival of the companys 1988 production this season, with Marco Armiliato conducting. The audience loved her. When Ms. Moore took her solo curtain call at the end, she received an ecstatic ovation.

title: Stimulus Denial, Part N
description: Mark Thoma posts about another Cochrane rant, and about what John Taylor really said. Go read. I thought I should point out something else about Taylors claim (pdf) that aid to state and local governments had no effect, because they would simply have borrowed the money. Christina Romer (pdf) has already answered this, in devastating fashion:

title: More Bad News for Midprice Carmakers in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  Life is already pretty miserable for European makers of midprice cars, and from the looks of the Geneva auto show, it is about to get worse.

title: Double Feature: New Music With Old Soul
description: Some concert programs make sense before you hear a note played, their symmetries and affinities evident at a glance. With others you scratch your head and wonder what prompted a given combination. The concert played by the Manhattan School of Music Chamber Sinfonia at the schools John C. Borden Auditorium on Thursday evening fell into the second category, though not objectionably so.

title: Lusty Stomps and Seductive Whispers (Must Be Flamenco)
description: It was ladies night at City Center on Thursday, when the Flamenco Festival 2012 held its gala. Rafaela Carrasco, Olga Pericet and Carmen Corts, all eminent dancers from Spain, were the stars of the evening and its choreographers too. But the first feet to hit the floor were male.

title: Givenchy: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Heroine Is Chosen for Last Williams Play
description: The coming production of In Masks Outrageous and Austere  the final full-length play written by Tennessee Williams and a work that has never been produced for the stage  has found its heroine, the producers are to announce on Monday. Shirley Knight, left, a Tony, Emmy and Golden Globe award winner, will play Babe Foxworth, a wealthy Southern belle who is kidnapped. Ms. Knight has brought many of Williamss characters to life in the past, most notably Heavenly Finley, in the film version of Sweet Bird of Youth (1962), for which she received an Academy Award nomination for best supporting actress. In a telephone interview Ms. Knight described this character as fierce and wonderful and compared her with other strong women from Williamss plays like The Glass Menagerie and Sweet Bird of Youth. She added: There is a whole other dark comedy quality to it. Its very funny. It is unique, but you know it is his voice. Its Tennessee. It couldnt be anybody else. The play is scheduled to run from April 5 to May 26 at Culture Project and is to be directed by David Schweizer. Williams wrote the manuscript over a span of four years until his death, in 1983, and it was kept out of the public eye for years by Gavin Lambert, who worked with Williams on it and to whom he entrusted the manuscript. Mr. Lambert released the play shortly before he died, in 2005, and the work eventually reached Mr. Schweizer. Ms. Knight recalled a missed opportunity in which she was meant to star in Williamss Red Devil Battery Sign, but the production fell apart after his death. She sees this casting as a second chance. I feel like somehow this came to me for a reason, she said. I was meant to do this.

title: Deutsche Bank Names New Co-Head of M.&A. for the Americas
description: Deutsche Bank shook up the leadership of its mergers advisory team for the Americas on Friday, naming James Ratigan as a new co-head of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

description: BOSTON  In the 30 days that passed between trips to New England, the Knicks added players, momentum, confidence, a bench and a global sensation, raising their profile and their expectations to unwieldy heights.

title: Romanias Communist Past
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: No Peeking!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  When you were small, what was more fun than a game of hide and seek? You didnt need any expensive equipment, you didnt need your parents to transport you anywhere, no electronics were involved; all you needed was wide open space, and a few good places to tuck yourself until, hopefully, someone came to find you.

title: Court Papers in Spider-Man Suit Could Tarnish Reputations
description: On Broadway, profitable shows are rare, few people get rich, and rave reviews are impossible to predict. Reputation is the true lucre in theater  and reputation, more than anything, is whats at stake in the director Julie Taymors latest salvo in her lawsuit against the producers who fired her last year from Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.

title: Maximizing the Score at London Tournament
description: After the Night of the Stars charity pro-am pair tournament at the Wimbledon Bridge Club in London last month the players received commemorative booklets containing copies of the deals with hypothesized analyses.

title: Rogue, Rube or G.O.P. Star: Portraying Palin
description: Game Change the book is an authoritative 448-page retelling of all 500 or more days of the 2008 presidential campaign. Game Change the film, to be shown by HBO on Saturday night, is a reconstruction of the two months when Sarah Palin was running for vice president on John McCains ticket.

title: E.U. Considers Quotas for Women in Boardrooms
description: BRUSSELS  Frustrated that her previous efforts to get more women into the top echelons of European business have not yielded stronger results, Viviane Reding, the senior justice official in the European Union, was to announce a new effort Monday that could result in legislation requiring that women occupy up to 60 percent of the seats on corporate boards.

title: Be Careful When Playing With Matchmakers
description: Yenta, Yenta, Yenta. When did you turn into a construction worker on lunch break?

title: Bringing K-Pop to the West
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Patricia Augustin, 19, of Indonesia says she scours the Internet every day for the latest updates on Korean pop music. Paula Lema Aguirre, a high school student from Peru, says she is happiest when she sings Korean songs, especially It Hurts, the group 2NE1s single about teenage love.

title: In Indiana, Prayer Amid the Storm Cleanup
description: HENRYVILLE, Ind.  Residents of this small community filtered into church on Sunday, turning to their faith for solace two days after a tornado leveled the towns center.

title: Film Actors Join Paul Weitz Play
description: Topher Grace, above, who took many a bong hit as the sweetly geeky Eric Forman on the Fox series That 70s Show, will continue his string of anxiety-ridden characters in his professional stage debut this spring in Paul Weitzs new comedy, Lonely, Im Not, at the Off Broadway Second Stage Theater, the company has announced. Mr. Grace, 33, will play a man who once earned seven figures in corporate life but is now trying to rebuild his life after a divorce and a nervous breakdown. Starring opposite Mr. Grace will be Olivia Thirlby, below left, as a young businesswoman with her own troubles. Ms. Thirlby is perhaps best known as the friend of the title character in the 2007 film Juno, and she also played a comely campaign intern in the Off Broadway production of Farragut North in 2008. Both actors have already worked with Mr. Weitz, a writer and director who shared an Academy Award nomination for adapted screenplay for the 2002 film About a Boy. Mr. Grace starred in Mr. Weitzs film comedy In Good Company in 2004, and Ms. Thirlby is in his newest movie, Being Flynn. Lonely, Im Not, to be directed by Trip Cullman (Assistance), is scheduled to start previews on April 10 and to open on May 7. Second Stage previously mounted three other Weitz plays: Privilege, Show People and most recently Trust, starring Zach Braff.

title: A Prize for a Playwright
description: Jennifer Haley has been named the 34th winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for her play The Nether. The international award is given annually to a female playwright with an outstanding body of work in the English language. Ms. Haley, a native of Texas who lives in Los Angeles, received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by Willem de Kooning that he created for the prize. She was nominated by the Center Theater Group of Los Angeles. The Nether  a futuristic tale in which virtual reality has become the primary vehicle for human interaction and existence  was one of eight plays chosen to be given workshops and performed as part of the 2011 ONeill Playwrights Conference in July. The Philadelphia Theater Company PTC@PLAY festival will present a staged reading on Wednesday.

title: Sol Schiff, Mr. Table Tennis, Dies at 94
description: Sol Schiff, whose rocketing, flat forehand propelled him to national and world table tennis championships in the 1930s when he was still in his teens, and who later earned the unofficial title Mr. Table Tennis as an ardent advocate for his sport, died Feb. 26 in Brooklyn. He was 94.

title: State-by-State Analysis: Romney Could Win Majority of Super Tuesday Delegates
description: Although the Super Tuesday states are a mix of favorable and unfavorable terrain for Mitt Romney, his situation has improved enough that he could be on track to win an outright majority of the delegates on the night.

title: A Good Week to Be a U.S. Soccer Fan
description: Puff out your chests, fans of American soccer, because it was a good week to be you. The national team beat Italy for the first time on Wednesday, then sent its newly confident players back to their clubs to try to do even better.

title: Deepwater Oil Drilling Picks Up Again as BP Disaster Fades
description: HOUSTON  Nearly two years after an explosion on an oil platform killed 11 workers and sent millions of gallons of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, deepwater drilling has regained momentum in the gulf and is spreading around the world.

description: By the time mid-March rolled around in 2008, all of Hillary Rodham Clintons Democratic rivals for the White House except one, Barack Obama, had dropped out of the race.

title: The Big East Is Still Paying for a Fumble
description: Beginning Tuesday, teams and fans will converge on Madison Square Garden for the 32nd Big East Conference mens basketball tournament. Since the conference began using the Garden for its annual carnival in 1983, the tournament has become a popular launching pad for March Madness.

title: In Queens, Cold Weather Brings Heat to Handball
description: A steady ribbon of steam rose from a stainless steel pot at a park in Queens, a small flame licking at its underside. Every so often, Washington Giovanni Cardenas lifted the lid to pluck a round morsel from the roiling water.

title: Elections in Iran Favor Ayatollahs Allies, Dealing Blow to President and His Office
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With the bulk of seats decided in Irans parliamentary elections, it appeared on Sunday that the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has gained the ironclad majority he needed not just to bring the countrys president to heel, but to eliminate the position entirely.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Teams Could Be Held Liable for Injuries Traced to Bounties
description: The New Orleans Saints will almost certainly receive fines, suspensions and/or the loss of draft picks because of the bounty system administered by the former defensive coordinator Gregg Williams that encouraged Saints players to injure opponents  and for the apparent cover-up by team officials that followed. But that could be just the beginning of their punishment.

title: The Diabetes Dilemma for Statin Users
description: San Diego, Calif.

title: For Rondo, Memorable Game Amid Uncertainty
description: BOSTON  Rajon Rondo did something Sunday that no N.B.A. player had done in more than two decades. His triple-double of 18 points, 17 rebounds and 20 assists not only helped the Celtics beat the Knicks, 115-111, in overtime, but it also thrust him into the rarefied company of the Hall of Fame point guard Magic Johnson.

title: With Pub Crawl Replacing St. Patricks Day Parade in Hoboken, Arrests Drop
description: After the annual St. Patricks Day parade in Hoboken, N.J., led to dozens of arrests last year, the mayor decided to put a stop to a ritual that while beloved by many longtime residents, had become increasingly rambunctious in recent years.

title: James Trager, Brought Facts to the Masses, Dies at 86
description: In 1898, as history students learn, the battleship Maine blew up in Havanas harbor, but that was also the year the Bayer Company offered a new opiate cough medicine called Heroin, and the year the Kellogg brothers introduced cornflakes, which were so unpopular at first they grew stale on grocers shelves.

title: Mets Await a Key Ruling Amid More Negative News
description: A federal judges ruling Monday in Manhattan will determine the fate of the Mets owners in their protracted legal fight against the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff.

title: Williams Set for Meeting With N.F.L. Officials
description: Gregg Williams, the former New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator who is at the center of the N.F.L.s investigation into a bounty system that rewarded players for injuring opponents, will meet again with league security officials Monday in New York.

title: U.S.-Afghanistan Talks Falter Despite Leeway on Detention Facilities
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The prospects for a long-term American strategic partnership with Afghanistan appeared to be dimming over the weekend, as negotiations foundered despite a new American willingness to move up the transfer of detention centers to the Afghans to as soon as six months from now, Afghan and American officials said.

title: Lucio Dalla, Italian Troubadour, Dies at 68
description: ROME  Lucio Dalla, the Italian songwriter and singer whose music became the soundtrack for the lives of generations of Italians, died on Thursday in Montreux, Switzerland, where he had been performing. He was 68.

title: Scion Aims Online Videos at Young Buyers
description: IN Toyotas view, its Scion brand of automobiles is not just for anyone. The cars are for the young and fashionable  they are called influencers these days  who spread the word about the vehicles after encountering the companys art, music or comedic marketing.

title: Russian Turnout Includes Thousands of Eager Election Observers
description: MOSCOW  A small army of first-time election observers fanned out across Russian polling places, and hundreds of thousands of citizens watched ballot boxes via a vast network of Web cameras on Sunday, in what amounted to a huge experiment in public scrutiny of the voting process.

title: Actresss Privacy Lawsuit Challenges a Web Site
description: LOS ANGELES  Junie Hoang is famous now, in a 15-minutes sort of way.

title: Update on New York Redistricting
description: Each state must redraw its political maps to reflect the 2010 census, but New York, which has approved neither legislative nor Congressional districts for this years elections, is among the last to comply. Redistricting has become increasingly urgent because of the calendar: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: Instead of Victory Party, Spartans Get Tie for First

description: VALHALLA, N.Y.  New York Medical College was planning to change its affiliation to Jewish from Catholic when an employee approached Rabbi Moshe D. Krupka in the cafeteria, voice raised and finger wagging, and demanded, When you take over, will I be able to eat my ham sandwich here?

description: The pitch for the online course sounds like a late-night television ad, or maybe a subway poster: Learn programming in seven weeks starting Feb. 20. Well teach you enough about computer science that you can build a Web search engine like Google or Yahoo.

But the retirement last week of Israels chief justice and the swearing in of her successor turned into a kind of Rorschach inkblot test about the nature of Israeli democracy.

In that time, she has never had a more talented and hard-working bunch than the current team of fifth-grade teachers. The five have lunch together daily, using the time to plan. They stay until 7 p.m. on Fridays to prepare for the following week. On Thursday night, most of them helped at the science invention fair until it was past 8 p.m.

title: Lebanon Expects Influx of Refugees From Syria

Yet the drama does not have a happy ending for everyone, and some of the cutbacks are eventually enacted.

title: Even Smiles Count, However Exacting the Competition
description: To warm up backstage before the ninth New York Regional and National Yoga Asana Championship, some competitors slid their legs behind their heads and others curled into back bends. Michael Colwill, 46, stood still in a purple Speedo and practiced bowing. Perfecting a gentle smile, he stood on a yoga mat, secured to the stage with electrical tape, and gazed out serenely at the nearly 700 theater seats.

title: Sharing a Part of Activist History in the East Village
description: From the street, the brick tenement on Avenue C looked like any other building.But inside on Saturday afternoon, about 30 people gathered to look at a storefront space covered with graffiti and murals.

title: Drill Baby Drill, Redux
description: Its campaign season and the pandering about gas prices is in full swing. Hardly a day goes by that a Republican politician does not throw facts to the wind and claim that rising costs at the pump are the result of President Obamas decisions to block the Keystone XL pipeline and impose sensible environmental regulations and modest restrictions on offshore drilling.

title: Veto the Maps
description: New Yorks Legislature is reportedly planning to offer Gov. Andrew Cuomo a bipartisan and utterly sleazy redistricting deal. If he will approve their new gerrymandered districts for the next decade, Assembly and State Senate leaders will propose a constitutional amendment they promise will improve the way the state draws election districts  in 2022. Mr. Cuomo must keep his promise and veto the Legislatures self-serving maps.

title: Equal Protection on Sewer Bills
description: Sometimes, what seems to be a case with an obvious, common-sense answer ends up at the Supreme Court. Such is the curious case of the municipal sewer bill and the Constitution. The issue in Armour v. Indianapolis, which the court heard arguments on last week, is whether the city violated the equal protection rights of residents who prepaid their sewer bills and were not given a refund after the city changed its sewer fee policy.

title: Sweeter Than Marmalade: A Shy Couples 30-Year Romance

title: Meet Sam Schwartz
description: IF you live in New York, commute to New York, or occasionally visit what Russell Shorto called the island at the center of the world, you have experienced the indignity of our citys transportation hell. You have endured the screeching, flood-prone subways. You have surrendered exorbitant carfare to escape our eyesore airports, then lurched along congested highways, over creaking bridges and into our truck-clotted city streets. You have dodged the camping homeless at the Port Authority bus terminal, or wandered lost in the miasmal misery of Pennsylvania Station. New York City welcomes you with open arms  like the zombies in The Walking Dead.

title: Putin Wept
description: Perhaps the only unexpected aspect of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putins victory in Sundays Russian presidential election was the tear in his eye as he stepped to the microphone to address supporters outside the Kremlin walls in Moscow. Video tagged #putinwept by one incredulous blogger appeared to show Mr. Putin tearing up as he was introduced by the outgoing president, Dmitri Medvedev.

They have been less efficient at reining in larcenous government billionaires. The same state security forces, the guobao, that so eagerly go Scarface on Tibetans and poets just as happily go silent on the most brazen of Communist Party crooks.

In the days that followed, President Obama telephoned Ms. Fluke to express his support, some Republicans, including House speaker John A. Boehner criticized Mr. Limbaugh, many advertisers withdrew ads from the show, and, on Saturday, Mr. Limbaugh offered an apology. Read about the events and tell us what you think.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Kenzo
description: Shes grown up a little bit, said the hairstylist Anthony Turner backstage of the directive Carol Lim and Humberto Leon gave for this seasons Kenzo girl. Shes met the man of her dreams  and hes a rich man. In contrast to last collections loose braids, this girl has hair thats the day-after-the-night-before, meaning a mussed-up version of her date look that led to, well, spending the night. She had a little romp on the Upper East Side. To create this effect, Turner used Tigi Catwalk Sessions Series Strong Mousse with a flat brush to blow-dry hair and then pull it into a tight, low ponytail, pinning the folded-over ends up and then destroying the look a little with his fingertips. Wet Look Gel was dabbed on messy ends and the hairline at the face so that when light hit it would look as though the girl had gotten caught in the rain on her way back downtown. For more grown-up makeup, Yadim used M.A.C. Black Track Fluid liner to draw a thick contour with a bit missing; he erased part of the end with the swipe of a wet Q-tip. On cheeks was Taupe creme blush and highlighter on all the planes of the face. Then there was what Yadim called the surprise of the show  a changing gradient of lipstick meant to match the clothes that show the girl within the different rooms of her new mans pad. There was, appropriately, Sin, Dare You, Ruby Woo, Russian Red, So Chaud and Girl About Town mixed with Dare You.

title: Why Ticketmaster Wants to Be Your Friend
description: If you want to know why companies are so hot on social networking, consider this: Ticketmaster recently began asking customers to post their purchases on Facebook. Since then, the company says, it has made $5.30 in additional ticket sales each time someone has done so. That value increases to $8 when the customer also posts the location of the seats using Ticketmasters seating chart.

title: Sony Says Michael Jackson Recordings Were Stolen From Its Site
description: This could be bad for Sony, in many senses of the word: that media giant has confirmed that several tracks recorded by Michael Jackson were stolen from its Web site after it was hacked, BBC News reported. Sony has not said what Jackson tracks were taken, but in 2010 it closed a $250 million deal with the singers estate to acquire his back catalog (including best-selling albums like Thriller and Bad) and to release previously unheard recordings, beginning with a posthumous album, Michael, that went on sale in December of that year. Last April a Sony online network for its PlayStation game consoles was hacked, compromising the personal data of some 77 million users; the Sony Music Japan site and Sony Ericsson online store were also hacked in the following weeks. The BBC said the Jackson tracks were taken during this time. In May two British men, James Marks and James McCormick, were arrested in connection with the hacks and are to go on trial next January.

title: Leading Off: A Glorious Climb for Pat Summitt

title: The Breakfast Meeting: More Advertisers Drop Limbaugh and Modern Family Tops Idol
description: A seventh advertiser, ProFlowers, has abandoned Rush Limbaughs show after his attack last week in which he called a law student who testified in favor of insurance coverage for birth control a slut and a prostitute, writes Brian Stelter. title: London Calling

As a Stanford University site called Authorial London puts it, A comprehensive Web site for literary London would occupy an entire server. See for yourself  check out the pantheon hosted there. title: Maclaren Stroller Company Files for Bankruptcy in U.S.

Dealbook reports that its North American division filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy at the end of December last year, meaning that it plans to liquidate the business, although its showroom in SoHo remains open, and its products are still for sale (of the top 10 best standard strollers on the Web site Diapers.com, two are still Maclarens). Among the bankruptcy creditors are seven families whose children were injured by one of its foldable models, recalled in 2009 for its notorious ability to amputate the tip of a childs finger.
