description: Paris

title: Tribeca Festival Announces First Slate of Films for 2012
description: If it doesnt include new works from James Franco and Harmony Korine, is it really a film festival? The organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival will not have to contend with that existential question this year: among the offerings announced on Tuesday as part of its 2012 lineup are Francophrenia (or: Dont Kill Me, I Know Where the Baby Is), a hybrid documentary/fiction feature directed by Mr. Franco and Ian Olds, and The Fourth Dimension, directed by Mr. Korine, Alexey Fedorchenko and Jan Kwiecinski.

title: Santorums Super Tuesday Message: Romney Is a Liar
description: CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio  Rick Santorum closed out his Super Tuesday campaign by coming quite close to calling Mitt Romney a liar.

title: Leading Off: Madness of a Different Kind
description: The N.F.L. really hopes you are immersed in the joyful spectacle of college basketball. Virginia Commonwealth is back in the N.C.A.A. tournament! Isnt that awesome? Of course, it would take you being immersed in just about anything other than that ugliness inherent in the bounty scandal. Saint Marys, what a fabulous story! Can the Gaels pull a Butler? But the league figures, if you can sidestep all the moral and ethical issues pockmarking college sports and still embrace the game, youre getting great practice for N.F.L. season. Because theres at least a 10-morals pileup awaiting you at your next N.F.L. viewing. Did you see that double-overtime Davidson victory to make the tournament? Oh my!

title: Army Recommends Court-Martialing 4 Soldiers in Death of Private
description: An American military investigator has recommended that four more soldiers be court-martialed in connection with the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, a Chinese-American soldier from New York City who apparently killed himself last fall in Afghanistan, the military said in a statement on Tuesday.

title: Jaguar XF Sportbrake Wont Join the Westward Wagon Train
description: GENEVA  The new Jaguar XF Sportbrake introduced here wont be coming to America, but not for the reason that most readily comes to mind.

title: Chanels Fortress of Solitude
description: The Parisian fashion house always takes the show design awards, using the cavernous space of the Grand Palais in lots of different ways: constructing an enormous carousel, a gigantic lion, even an airplane cabin for the recent summer 2012 couture show.

title: The Preschool Cavity Epidemic
description: Eleven cavities? One toddler? Before you jump to any conclusions about the kind of neglect that would leave a 2 1/2-year-old in that position, read Preschoolers in Surgery for a Mouthful of Cavities. Catherine Saint Louis, a Times reporter, writes, dentists nationwide say they are seeing more preschoolers at all income levels with 6 to 10 cavities or more.

title: Fox Pulls Plug on Terra Nova
description: The most expensive television show of the season, the time-traveling family drama Terra Nova, wont be coming back to the Fox network.

title: Broadway and Morris Street, 8:19 A.M.
Mitts Grueling Journey
description: In todays column on the winding, surprising road to Super Tuesday, I make reference to an NBC/Wall Street Journal poll with some distressing news for Mitt Romney: the percentage of voters who view him unfavorably is 11 points higher than the percentage of voters who view him favorably. Thats a spread that has widened and worsened since the primaries began. And some additional observations about it, along with some historical context, are in order.

title: F.B.I. Offers Reward for News of Former Agent Missing in Iran
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation offered a $1 million reward on Tuesday for information about a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran five years ago.

title: Voting on Super Tuesday, From Massachusetts to Georgia
description: Republicans are voting in 10 states, choosing 20 percent of their convention delegates.

title: Shark Fins Are Loaded With a Neurotoxin, Study Finds
description: Shark fins contain high levels of a potent neurotoxin that scientists have linked to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimers and Parkinsons, according to a recent study published in the journal Marine Drugs.

title: The All-Big East Fear Monger Team
description: You are not allowed to say it before, during or after a game, and in most basketball circles you are not allowed to say it ever. But that doesnt change the fact that there are and always will be players who freak you out, and this years Big East tournament crop is no exception.

description: A study finds that digital health records may not cut costs; a patent challenge threatens production of a cancer drug in India; and Texas teachers buy a stake in a hedge fund.

title: Kennedy Center Announces 2012-2013 Season
description: Washington can take occasional breaks from politics this fall when the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opens its 42nd season. On Tuesday, Michael M. Kaiser, the centers president, unveiled highlights of the 2012-2013 program, which include celebrations of Woody Guthries and Bob Marleys music; a new production of Fernec Molnrs Guardsman, adapted by Richard Nelson and directed by Gregory Mosher; debuts of Lar Lubovitch Dance Company; a new production of Show Boat by the Washington National Opera; a weeklong residency with Chinese pianist Lang Lang; and the comedian David Alan Grier.

title: Paulsons Post-Traumatic February
description: Pulses may be quickening at Paulson & Company, the hedge fund giant, after one of the firms main funds lost 1.5 percent in February.

title: Police Dept. Employee Accused of Assaulting Girlfriend
description: A New York Police Department employee was arrested at 9:30 p.m. on Monday after the police said he assaulted his girlfriend and locked her in the bathroom while the couples young daughter was in another part of their home.

title: Now, Tables for (Almost) Everyone
description: Come gather in the living room, the staff told assisted living residents on Monday afternoon at Harbors Edge, a retirement village in Norfolk, Va. We have an important announcement.

title: Digital Notes: Indie Distributors Merge and Live Nation Buys Setlist.fm
description: Indie Distributors Merge: The Orchard and IODA, the two largest independent distributors of digital music, are merging, the companies announced on Tuesday. The combined firm, to be called the Orchard, will be something of a super-indie, with $130 million in revenue and deals to release the music of thousands of labels and music groups, from the Barsuk and Daptone labels to the London Symphony Orchestra and Sesame Workshop. The news was first reported on Monday night by Billboard.

title: Gingrich Promises to Move American  Embassy to Jerusalem on Day 1
description: Less than an hour after former Gov. Mitt Romney vowed to make Jerusalem his first foreign destination if elected president, one of his rivals for the Republican nomination, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, went one better, promising to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem on Day 1 of his prospective presidency.

title: New Yorks Best Bars for Watching British Football
description: A true Londoner would never support Manchester United, I was told, Craig Taylor writes in this weeks London-centric issue of the magazine. When I ran into my friend Sulimon on Sunday at Brooklyns Black Horse Pub to watch Man U. play my team, Tottenham Hotspur, he disagreed. Born and bred in Brixton, Sulimon resolutely counts himself as a true Londoner  but he has been a United supporter since age 5. A true Mancunian can never be a United supporter, he said by way of correction. Theyre all Man City supporters. The rest of the country supports United. Fighting words.

title: Super Tuesday Live Coverage
description: Ten states vote on Tuesday, and The Times will provide updates and analysis throughout the day, with live coverage of results beginning at 5 p.m. Eastern.

title: On Our Radar: Alien Plants in Antarctica
description: Scientists working in Antarctica have inadvertently introduced alien plants and tiny animals there that are likely to spread as the climate warms, researchers report. Scouring the clothes and boots of scientists and tourists visiting the continent, they found that most were carrying nonnative plant seeds. [BBC]

title: Refinancing Fees Are Reduced for Some F.H.A. Borrowers
description: In what it described as part of an initiative to lift the housing market, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it would make refinancing less expensive for certain borrowers with mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Vegetarian Spring Rolls With Shredded Kohlrabi
description: Spring rolls are quite easy to make, and make a light and delicious lunch, appetizer, side dish or snack. You can find the rice flour spring roll wrappers in Asian markets.

title: With EXP 9F, Bentley Joins the Luxury-Crossover Gold Rush
description: GENEVA  Coming off a record performance in 2011, with particularly robust sales in China, Bentley sees a limitless sales horizon. Dealers, meanwhile, want more hardware to display in their showrooms. So the Volkswagen Group subsidiary decided to go where almost every other automaker in search of sales has gone before it: to crossovers.

description: This Cheetah is not cute.

title: Panetta Warns Iran: We Will Act
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pledged to an influential pro-Israel lobbying group on Tuesday that if the pressure of diplomacy and sanctions failed to stop Iran from building a nuclear weapon, the United States was fully prepared to take military action as a last resort.

title: Kohlrabi and Celery Root Pure
description: This simple combination tastes so good to me, it hardly needs embellishment. The butter is optional. If you miss old-fashioned buttery mashed potatoes, let this be a stand-in.

description: A look at Yodit Eklund's collection, shot alongside its inspiration, Africas West Coast.

title: A Book Cover Hed Prefer to Forget
description: It was an attention-getter of a painting: Neighborhood lowlifes eyeing a blond woman. Maybe you notice the yellow dress. Maybe you notice that it has slipped off one shoulder. Maybe you notice the bra strap that has been exposed. Maybe you notice the red necklace, the red purse and the red shoes. Probably you notice something else.

title: Channel Surfing: Through the Wormhole: Will We Survive First Contact?
description: The Science Channel has labeled March Are We Alone? month, and Tuesday night a new episode of the always interesting series Through the Wormhole gets aboard the extraterrestrial bandwagon with Will We Survive First Contact? Um, theres good news and bad news.

title: Keeping His Park Safe
description: Jim Schultz has been a climber and pruner for the citys Department of Parks and Recreation ever since he started working for the agency in 1997. Here, Mr. Schultz, 47, who is clearly passionate about what he does, describes some work he and his crew did last month at Crotona Park in the Bronx.

title: On Iran, Questions of Detection and Response Divide U.S. and Israel
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met in the White House on Monday, the main subject was how to calibrate the resumption of negotiations with Iran while continuing to accelerate sanctions and sabotage against its nuclear program. But they remained divided on two central questions: If Iran decided to race for a nuclear weapon, would the West detect that in time to stop it? And even if it were detected, would an airstrike be the best option?

title: Fox Cancels the Prehistoric Drama Terra Nova
description: One of the television seasons most ambitious new series, the drama Terra Nova, about a family sent back into the prehistoric past, got word late Monday that it will have no future on the Fox network.

title: Bach at One Series Returns in New York
description: Bach at One, the flagship series of Trinity Wall Streets music program at St. Pauls Chapel, which was suspended in January, returned on Monday afternoon in a modest way. Julian Wachner, the director of music and arts, conducted 12 members of the Trinity Choir in a shortish program of motets, two by Bach, one by Heinrich Schtz. The Trinity Baroque Orchestra was represented merely by continuo players: Avi Stein, organist, and Katie Rietman, cellist.

title: Winstons Hiccup
description: I think Ill write a book today, the writer Georges Simenon was said to tell his wife at breakfast. Fine, she would reply, but what will you do in the afternoon? Winston Churchill was similarly prolific, and not just in the field of letters [1]. In his later years, he liked to boast that in 1921 he created the British mandate of Trans-Jordan, the first incarnation of what still is the Kingdom of Jordan, with the stroke of a pen, one Sunday afternoon in Cairo [2].

title: With New Hardware, Square Begins Taxi Rollout
description: If youve ever been in a rush and in a taxi cab in New York, then you know how it feels to swipe your credit card at the end of the ride and wait for the receipt to pop out so you can sign it and hand it back to the driver. This procedure does not exactly take a New York minute. (Often, you even have to convince the driver to take your credit card.)

title: Stanford Convicted by Jury in $7 Billion Ponzi Scheme
description: HOUSTON  A federal jury on Tuesday convicted R. Allen Stanford, a Texas financier, on 13 out of 14 counts of fraud in connection with a worldwide scheme that lasted more than two decades and involved more than $7 billion in investments.

title: Judge Issues Congressional Redistricting Proposal
description: ALBANY  A federal magistrate, seeking to break a legislative stalemate over how to redraw the states Congressional districts to reflect the 2010 census, has released her own proposed map that could be imposed by the court.

title: Dire Poverty Falls Despite Global Slump, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  A World Bank report shows a broad reduction in extreme poverty  and indicates that the global recession, contrary to economists expectations, did not increase poverty in the developing world.

title: Top Six Episodes of You Had to Be There
description: Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer, the co-hosts of the free weekly comedy podcast You Had to Be There, whom I wrote about in Sundays magazine, are the best girlfriends you wish you had.

title: Alabama Congressman, Under Investigation, Defends Himself in Ad

title: Singing and Drama Bring NBC a Prime-Time Win
description: NBC took full advantage of weakened competition Monday night to score an impressive prime-time performance.

title: Reviving the Constitution
description: Ever since the George W. Bush administration decided to trash the constitution, the Geneva conventions and federal law, the thought of a government lawyer talking about justice in the age of terrorism has made me cringe. Although I hoped to lose this automatic reflex when Barack Obama took office, Ive been distressed by many of his national security moves (like his administrations persistent use of the state secrets privilege to deny justice to victims of officially sanctioned abduction and torture).

title: The Principal's Role in Teacher Evaluations
Minnesota School District Reaches Agreement on Preventing Gay Bullying
description: After years of accusations that it had failed to stop antigay bullying and a spate of student suicides, Minnesotas largest school district has agreed to sweeping changes designed to prevent harassment based on sexual orientation in a plan that federal officials call a national model.

title: The Destructive Too Much Homework Myth
description: Across the country, voices are raised in protest over the skyrocketing homework load inflicted on American students. Parents challenge teachers to re-evaluate homework policies. Anti-homework nonprofits circulate no-homework pledges. Writers and filmmakers make careers out of their anti-homework stance. The current generation of schoolchildren, they say, is enslaved by four to five hours of homework a night, toiling into the wee hours of the morning with no time for family or friends, driven to drugs, cheating and mental illness.

title: Across the Primary States, Voters Weigh Principles and Pragmatism
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  Voters here in the suburbs north of Atlanta have plenty of affection for Newt Gingrich, who represented the region in the House of Representatives for two decades. But that does not necessarily mean they were all voting for him Tuesday in the Republican presidential primary.

title: "Obama's Allies"
description: Representative Spencer Bachus released an ad attacking President Obama.

title: Santana Pitches Well in First Appearance
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A brisk day of work became another baby step in the closely-watched return of Mets pitcher Johan Santana.

title: Charged as Madam, and Defended as Entrepreneur and Pig Rescuer
description: According to Manhattan prosecutors, Anna Gristina is a well-connected madam who made millions of dollars running a brothel on the Upper East Side that catered to wealthy clients, where passers-by say fancy cars were seen idling past midnight. And when she was arrested last month, they said, she was with a Morgan Stanley banker whom she had just met about expanding her business.

title: A New East Asian Import: Ozone Pollution
description: Ozone produced in East Asia can travel all the way to the western United States, where it directly contributes to ground-level concentrations of the pollutant, according to a new study in the Journal of Geophysical Research.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Financing Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

description: Britains Channel 4 News has obtained video said to have been recorded secretly in a military hospital in the Syrian city of Homs, showing patients shackled to their beds and bearing marks consistent with reports of torture at state-run medical facilities.

title: Obama Challenges Republicans on Iran
description: President Obama challenged his Republican critics to make a case to the American people for a military strike against Irans nuclear facilities if they really believe that that is the right course to follow, throwing down an election-year challenge to the men who are vying to succeed him and who say that his Iran policy has been too weak.

description: GENEVA  One of the showstoppers here is Infinitis voluptuous Emerg-E hybrid sports car, a stunning design concept with DNA extracted from the Lotus Evora.

title: Romneys Advice on Selecting a College: Let Affordability Be Your Guide
description: This week in Opinion, David Firestone reflects on an exchange between Mitt Romney and a high school senior who was worried about paying for college. The student wanted to know what Mr. Romney would do about the rising costs of college, if elected president.

description: Tonight, nytimes.com will feature live video commentary fromOp-Ed columnists and updates from reporters about developments in the ten states that are holding primaries or caucuses. The columnists appearances will be incorporated into video reports.

title: President Obama Discusses Iran
description: March 6, 2012  President Obama discusses Iran at a White House press conference. (Video: NBC)

title: Trading Small Forward for Scoring Rebounder
description: Statistics in basketball are, by nature, a qualitative means to an evaluative end. They exist to inform how well or how poorly a certain task is performed with the coldest precision; those measurements of frequency, accuracy and efficiency may not always have the context necessary to hold a life of their own, but they serve an incredibly useful descriptive purpose and guide the analysis of the game on a fundamental level.

title: Gingrich Predicts Hell Carry Georgia Decisively
description: DULUTH, Ga.  On the day his home state of Georgia went to the polls, Newt Gingrich was confident enough to risk another round of Newt Skywalker jokes by scheduling a detour to the U.S. Space & Rocket Center in Huntsville, Ala.

title: Random House to Reissue Updike Works to Mark His Birthday
description: Random House will mark John Updikes birthday this month with the re-release of some of his most beloved works, including the Rabbit series, the publisher said on Tuesday. Mr. Updike, who was born on March 18, 1932, died in 2009 after a career that produced 60 books as well as essays, criticism and poetry.

title: Pistons, Kuester Make Peace with Past
description: John Kuesters two seasons coaching the Detroit Pistons were not happy or successful ones, ending with his firing last June. But it seems that time, and his new job as an assistant with the Lakers, has healed the deep rifts between Kuester and his former players.

title: Meet Jonathan Foley, Climate Pragmatist
description: Late in 2010, Jonathan Foley, who directs the Institute of the Environment at the University of Minnesota, wrote Becoming a Climate Pragmatist, an essay published online then and the following spring in the institutes magazine, Momentum. You can get a feel for his work and views in the video above in which he explains 2009 research on planetary boundaries. I also encourage you to read his 2011 paper, Solutions for a Cultivated Planet.

title: Google Revamps Android Marketplace as Google Play
description: On Tuesday, Google unveiled Google Play, a one-stop-shop for all of Googles software services and applications.

title: Spain Struggles to Unite Regional Leaders on Cuts
description: MADRID  The Spanish government is struggling to discipline the regional governments that it blames for exacerbating the countrys fiscal problems as it faces pressure from the European Union to rein in its deficit.

title: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Before Hearing on Complaints, Bloomberg Hails Success of Letter-Grading
description: Salmonella? Down. Restaurant revenues? Up. Food sanitary practices? Way up.

description: On Wednesday at 11 a.m. EST, Im hosting an hour-long Facebook conversation about the presidential campaign. The chat will take place on my Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/AndrewMRosenthal

title: Voter Portraits: The 2012 Primaries
description: Throughout the 2012 primary season, The Times will be checking in with voters as they cast their ballots to see what is driving them to the polls.

title: How Ohio Voted Last Time
description: The polling for Tuesdays presidential primary in Ohio shows a close race. That was not the case in 2008, when 60 percent of Ohio Republicans favored Senator John McCain of Arizona, and 31 percent voted for former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas. By then, the race was essentially over. Indeed, Mr. Huckabee withdrew the next day.

title: Needing Big Run Again, UConn Opens Title Defense With Listless Win
description: There was an eerie symmetry to the University of Connecticuts arrival at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday for this years Big East tournament.

title: Behind the Texas Pensions Deal With Bridgewater
description: The Teacher Retirement System of Texas recently bought a stake in Bridgewater Associates, the worlds largest hedge fund. Its a novel investment for a public pension, so DealBook dug deeper into the purchase.

title: Keep an Eye Out for Dumplings
description: JUST for a moment, try to forget that the dumplings are staring at you.

title: What Is Modern Slavery? Investigating Human Trafficking
description: For todays lesson, we collaborated again  as we did last fall on a lesson about the famine in Somalia  with the Global Nomads Group, an international organization that creates interactive educational programs for students about global issues, to foster dialogue and understanding about the world.

title: RedFarm
description: Inside the modern Chinese restaurant in the West Village.

title: Rights Erode Before Womens Eyes
description: PARIS  This year, in the International Herald Tribunes series on The Female Factor, we thought we would look at women from all over who make a difference.

title: Assessing Debt Relief in Greek Deal
description: With Greeces debt restructuring scheduled to begin on Thursday, its worth asking how much relief the country might actually get from the deal.

title: Pirates Begin to See What They Have in Igarashi
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  After spending much of his first two years in the United States in the relative anonymity of minor league baseball, Ryota Igarashi will get a chance to make a name for himself with the Pittsburgh Pirates. But first the Pirates need to get his name right.

title: Pictures of the Day: Massachusetts and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the United States, France, Afghanistan and India.

title: Five Dishes at RedFarm
description: RedFarm, the subject of my review this week, is a dumpling fanatics dream come true: a collaboration between Joe Ng, one of the citys best dim sum chefs, and Ed Schoenfeld, a restaurateur who has spent decades introducing great Chinese cooking to New Yorkers.

title: In California, Open Season on Trophy Hunting
description: My grandfather, who died in 1929, more than two decades before I was born, was a confirmed trophy hunter, a founding member of the Boone & Crockett Club. A family album with 1880s-era photographs of his hunts shows beautiful and empty landscapes near Jackson Hole, Wyo. It also shows a moose killed in the woods of Minnesota, along with the hunters themselves and their prized hunting dogs.

title: Feting Marquee Names of the Mad Men Era
description: 5:16 p.m. | Updated The popularity of the AMC series Mad Men continues to generate interest in the real-life executives who worked in advertising during the years in which the show is set.

title: An Architect of a Deal Sees Greece as a Model
description: MADRID  Now that Greece is close to completing the largest bond write-off on record, should other debt-plagued nations in Europe follow its lead?

title: Hyundai I-Oniq Concept Aims to Keep European Automakers Pacing
description: GENEVA  Hyundai has Europes attention. Along with its Kia subsidiary, it is the fastest-growing major automaker in Europe, outselling brands that once seemed hopelessly out of its league like Toyota and Nissan, as well as European behemoths like Fiat.

title: Countering the Google Plus Image Problem
description: Google has a bit of an image problem.

title: McQueen: Changing the Perspective
description: Everybody seems to be talking about three-dimensional fashion, and the future. Tonight, at Salle Wagram, the same place where Alexander McQueen staged his dance-marathon collection, his successor, Sarah Burton, gave a magical rendering of both. The show started calmly with snowy white bell-shape coatdresses and laser-cut calf skin, resembling lace. All the models wore helmetlike white-blond wigs, their eyes shielded by visors. Then Ms. Burton turned up the volume, first with feathery and fur coats (like dandelion heads before the wind catches them), and gradually the shapes became monumental in scale. Ms. Burtons presentation was beautiful, but the monumental aspect was riveting  how it affects your eye. Tomorrow, in the McQueen showroom, Ill take a closer look.

title: Critics Notebook: Lessons in Looking
description: One of the many pleasures of going to art galleries regularly is that in addition to the formal exhibitions up front, art dealers often display unexpected gems off to the side, in project spaces, offices or even behind the reception desk: lost bits of history and unfamiliar early works by this or that artist.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Opponents to Verizon Spectrum Deal Demand a Pause
description: Verizons attempt to buy wireless spectrum from cable companies for $3.9 billion took another twist Tuesday when companies and advocacy groups opposing the purchase urged the Federal Communications Commission to pause the review process until redacted statements Verizon made to the commission are made public.

title: Potential Outcomes for Super Tuesday
description: Even before the votes are counted in the 10 Republican presidential contests being held Tuesday, the question everyone will be asking is: who won?

title: Electronic Health Records: A Study and Perspective
description: I wrote an article in Tuesdays New York Times, which was based on a study published Monday in the journal Health Affairs that casts doubt on the widespread claim that computerized patient records will cut health care spending.

title: Decanting Old Wines, and Young
description: To decant or not to decant? Its a question that I hear all the time and one that has no simple answer. As with so many wine queries, it must be answered bottle by bottle. Nonetheless, Ive tried to address some of the issues in my column this week.

title: Tips From the Times Travel Show
description: This weekend was The New York Times Travel Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where exhibitors, some clad in native costumes, dole out brochures, advice and even free Thai noodles. And for the second straight year, I was a panelist. Also for the second straight year, I was faced with a difficult post-presentation choice: stay backstage to feast on the tray of free chocolate chip cookies put out for speakers, or roam the exhibition hall upstairs, grilling the travel industry representatives for money-saving tips that dont appear in brochures.

title: Asked & Answered | Paul Dano
description: On the afternoon before his New York City premiere of Being Flynn, directed by Paul Weitz and based on a profanely titled book by Nick Flynn, the actor Paul Dano waits at the window of an unassuming West Village luncheonette. In a black beanie, thin-rimmed spectacles and gray A.P.C. button-down shirt, which he purchased at half-off, Dano orders a green tea and chicken ratatouille sandwich. Fuel for a day of hustling ahead, he says. (Hustling, for Dano, is having to dine like this with reporters like me.) Its not really why I signed up to be an actor, says the 27-year-old in a thoughtful but unapologetic manner. Dano is a smart guy with an interesting face. Hes not too cocky and he still blushes from time to time, but its clear he can hold his own against even the most intimidating actors (his former co-star Daniel Day Lewis, in their Oscar-winning, nightmare-inducing film, There Will Be Blood, comes to mind). Its part of why Paul Weitz cast him opposite Robert De Niro in Being Flynn, in which Dano plays the troubled, 20-something Nick Flynn trying to cope with the reemergence of his narcissistic alcoholic father, Jonathan Flynn (De Niro). At first, I immediately got over the fact that hes Robert De Niro, says the actor of his established co-star. But there was this one day.

title: Post-Chemo, New Hair, New Outlook
description: ONE Friday afternoon early this year, in a limestone town house on the Upper East Side, the topic of conversation was cancer things, like lymphedema, said Sherry Kreek, who is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer.

title: Aliens of All Varieties, Wandering in the Desert
description: Hari Kunzrus latest novel, Gods Without Men, reads like an unlikely mash-up of David Mitchells willfully complex 2004 novel, Cloud Atlas, and Steven Spielbergs classic 1977 U.F.O. movie, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, seasoned with some borrowings from David Foster Wallace and Don DeLillo. The book is, at the same time, a wildly ambitious novel that spans centuries; a gripping thriller about a missing child; and a sort of sci-fi tale about pilgrims of various sorts being drawn to a mysterious rock formation in the desert in search of contact with aliens or some sort of higher meaning.

title: Retrospective From the Get-Go
description: When it comes to on-court attire, few items are as important as player footwear. If you want to be all B.Y.U. about it, then yes, shorts and spandex are technically more important, but that matters only if the game is being broadcast in HD (or, heaven forbid, in 3D).

title: Racial Divide Found in Discipline in City's Schools, Echoing Findings Across U.S.
Excerpt: 'Painting Churches'
description: A scene from the Keen Company revival of Tina Howes play, starring Kathleen Chalfant, John Cunningham and Kate Turnbull.. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Super Tuesday Live Coverage
description: Ten states vote on Tuesday, and The Times is providing live updates and analysis throughout the evening.

title: Avalanche and Attacks Add to Woes of Afghans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Rather than a respite after Afghanistans frigid winter, the start of the spring thaw has brought deadly avalanches and insurgent attacks.

title: A Minimum Age? Not for This Model
description: Most male models have the shelf life of a bag of potato chips, even shorter if they are familiar with the product. So at age 32, after 12 years in the business of catwalks and ab crunches, Brad Kroenig is about the closest thing there is to a male supermodel.

title: The Art of the Magazine
description: With all the recent talk about the demise of print, it is refreshing to visit MoMAs new exhibition of artists magazines. Titled Millennium Magazines and organized by Rachael Morrison and David Senior of the MoMA library, the exhibition showcases selections from the librarys collection.

title: Convicted Art Forger Says More of His Works Are Out There
description: Wolfgang Beltracchi, the 61-year-old forger who pulled off the largest art fraud in Germany since World War II, told Der Spiegel in an interview this week that he had forged the work of about 50 different artists, including Max Ernst, Fernand Lger and Heinrich Campendonk.

title: Weighing Roches Alternatives to an Illumina Deal
description: Roche Holding must be feeling a little frustrated by the fact that Illumina has been unwilling to consider its $5.7 billion takeover offer. But thats O.K., according to the Swiss drug makers chairman, Franz Humer, because his company has alternatives in case its hostile bid fails.

title: The Morality of Disaster Relief
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  It took two days, but Gov. John Kasich finally agreed to let federal disaster teams inspect the damage from a series of powerful tornadoes that ripped through southern Ohio and several other states on Friday. That often happens when ideological rigidity is confronted with real suffering.

title: The Real Bounty Hunters
description: William C. Rhoden believes the N.F.L. should take it easy with its finger pointing in the New Orleans bounty controversy. The league sanctions violence.

title: Bolivian Chocolate With a Passport
description: Locals in the Amazon basin know about wild cacao; most of it is Criollo, the most aromatic variety, or a close relative. Recently, outsiders have begun working with indigenous groups to sell Peruvian and Ecuadorean chocolate beyond the region.

title: A Taste of Home From Ethiopia
description: Comfort food was not meatloaf and mashed potatoes for Hiyaw Gebreyohannes. He is Ethiopian, from a family that immigrated to Djibouti and then Canada before settling in Michigan, and when he finally landed in New York, he hankered for his moms home-style collard greens, split peas, lentils and such. Not finding stores that sold them ready to eat, he has created a line of fresh, organic and vegan prepared foods called Taste of Ethiopia, which he makes at Hot Bread Kitchen, in La Marqueta in Harlem. They include tart, slightly bitter collards, called gomen, with some jalapeo heat; a golden turmeric-infused salad of cabbage and carrots, tekele gomen (shown above at right); split yellow peas, or kik (at center), intensified with turmeric and the sweet heat of ginger; and spicy red lentils, or misir (at left), at once mellow and rustic with cumin and berbere, the Ethiopian spice blend. He also makes spongy injera bread. Mr. Gebreyohannes is no novice when it comes to food: his mother owns Ethiopian restaurants in Michigan and he was involved in an African-fusion restaurant in Midtown.

title: Deficits and Virtue
description: Ezra Klein and Mark Thoma both weigh in on the utterly bizarre claim that the large budget deficits were currently running are the result of a loss of self-control  as opposed to the result of the worst financial crisis since the 1930s, which has both savaged revenue and required a large rise in safety-net spending. Moreover, as Ezra points out, these deficits actually serve a useful purpose! Without the automatic stabilizers that led to rising deficits as the economy plunged, we might well be living in a full remake of the Great Depression.

description: The 2008 Republican primary in Tennessee was a relatively close election. Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas eked out a narrow 3 percentage point victory over Senator John McCain of Arizona, 35 percent to 32 percent. Mitt Romney earned 24 percent of the vote. But Tennessee voters exhibited relatively clear regional voting patterns.

title: A Vintage Skyline Filled With Valentines and Air Kisses
description: Outside, rats prowl heaps of garbage, the homeless beg for quarters and dog droppings stucco the sidewalk. But watching Make Mine Manhattan, youd never suspect that such blemishes besmirched our fair city.

title: Cultural Notes (Trivial and Self-Indulgent)
description: Im supposed to be grading papers, so its time to procrastinate and mention a couple of non-economics things some readers might be interested in.

title: Romney and the Majority Track
description: You might sometimes have seen me use the term majority track to refer to the Republican delegate math. The meaning is pretty simple: is a candidate winning a majority of the delegates that are up for grabs in a given contest?

title: Chocolate Cupcakes With Cream Filling
description: Adapted from Food & Wine 2002

title: Its Not Junk if I Made It
description: FOR Americans of a certain age, memory lane is paved in Ho Hos. This coiled snack cake was my gateway Hostess confection, tucked into my lunch with a wax-paper-wrapped peanut butter and grape jelly sandwich. I would eat them with some slightly warm milk, courtesy of the unsmiling lunch lady, whom I would run into later in life in an unsavory darts bar. Sometimes my Ho Hos were traded for Ding Dongs, the hockey-puck shaped treats that struck me as a lowbrow alternative to my working mans tiny bche de Nol.

title: Going Through Life With Rose-Colored Fixations
description: Hold on there. Before you conclude that the people profiled in My Crazy Obsession are nuts  something youre likely to do after about 30 seconds  hear this: Let he who is without his own obsession cast the first stone.

title: St. Johns Struggles Dont End With Regular Season
description: Lacking depth and experience, St. Johns could not keep up with hot-shooting Pittsburgh in a 73-59 loss Tuesday in the first round of the Big East mens basketball tournament, ending a conference season that amounted to a step backward for the program under Steve Lavin.

title: Oreos vs. Fauxreos
description: Iconic snacks like Twinkies and Fritos, alongside homemade imitators.

title: An Ad-Hoc Solution for Extra Nuclear Safety
description: As the first anniversary of Japans Fukushima Daiichi accident approaches, the good news is that the American nuclear industry is  moving ahead promptly, without waiting for bureaucratic approvals, on stocking up on equipment like pumps, hoses and generators that could be useful in a variety of emergencies.

title: Intels New Chip: A Best Defense in the Cloud
description: Intel formally issued the specs Tuesday on its new Xeon E5 processor, a chip designed for use in the servers of big data centers. It is impressive, with an 80 percent improvement in processing power. You can read about the specs from Intel and from The Register, a news site specializing in hardcore tech issues.

title: Americas Bocuse Retires in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Live Coverage: Super Tuesday
description: The biggest day so far in the race for the Republican presidential nomination  11 states weigh-in  could solidify Mitt Romneys grip on the nomination or upend the contest. Well be bringing you data-driven analysis, exit poll information, historical perspective and state-by-state results.

title: Le Bec-Fin: What a Long, Strange Trip Its Been
description: On Monday evening I was sitting at the bar at Zahav, an Israeli restaurant in Philadelphia, sipping a cocktail and listening to Shakedown Street by the Grateful Dead.

title: David Rolls Into Town, the Streets His Gallery
description: David, a tourist from Turkey  we will deal with his lack of a last name later  had trouble on the trip into Manhattan. His driver was confused as they approached the George Washington Bridge on Tuesday and headed to a toll booth leading to the lower level despite explicit instructions: David is too big for the lower level. You have to take the upper level.

title: Slide Show: PeteZaaz
description: A welcome relief from the current parade of Neapolitan pizzas, PeteZaaz, a slender slice of a shop in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, offers expertly done pizzas that break the traditional mold. Peter Entner, a veteran of No. 7, and Glen Hudson, a dough-obsessed ex-cook at Pulinos, turn out wacky but wonderful pies topped with things like purple-potato pirogi, chili con carne or coconut tofu. These and the terrific Reuben stromboli are a whole lot of fun to eat.

title: PeteZaaz
description: 766 Classon Avenue (Sterling Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 230-9229, petezaaz.com.

description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  He is what he isnt.

title: As Trial Nears for Espada, Another Now Looms
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the former State Senate majority leader now under federal indictment, may have to face two trials, rather than one.

title: Nicolas Loves Barack
description: Its Super Tuesday night in America  the biggest night of the Republican nominating season that will end in the selection of the partys candidate to challenge Barack Obama in November, as pretty much everyone on the planet knows. As part of The New York Timess live blogging of Super Tuesday night, our colleague Michael Shear over on The Caucus political blog has just put up a post about how Nicolas Sarkozy, Frances embattled president, facing the first round of his own re-election contest in just 48 days, has endorsed Mr. Obama for a second term. Given the Republicans deep animosity to most, if not all, things French  as we recently reminded the world on Rendezvous (oops)  as well as the penchant of Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor and Republican front runners, to accuse Mr. Obama of wanting to impose European-style socialism on the United States, Michael says he is certain the White House will rush right out and start making the advertisements touting Sarkos endorsement. To read his post and to follow all the news of Super Tuesday, including the state-by-state vote counts,  go to The Caucuss live blog . (Search for Merci Beaucoup?)

title: Pok Pok Wing
description: 137 Rivington Street (Norfolk Street); (212) 477-1299; pokpokwing.com.

title: More Iran War Talk From the Senate
description: President Obama may be decrying the drumbeat of war and the politicization of the Iranian conflict, but his entreaties against loose war talk did little to dampen the pounding on Capitol Hill.

title: In Youth Sports, Losing is for Champions
description: If you have a young hockey player, a skier, a hoops player or any other form of winter athlete, then you know its crunch time. March madness applies in more than just basketball. State tournaments are being played, state ski teams selected  and children (lots of them) are losing their last game or their last race of the year.

title: Drug Policy as Race Policy: Best Seller Galvanizes the Debate
description: Garry McCarthy, a 30-year veteran of law enforcement, did not expect to hear anything too startling when he appeared at a conference on drug policy organized last year by an African-American minister in Newark, where he was the police director.

title: David Visits Manhattan
description: An replica of Michelangelos David rides through the streets of New York on the back of a truck. Time lapse video by Brett Beyer.

title: Looking Back | Stefano Pilatis Eight Years at Yves Saint Laurent
description: Stefano Pilati showed his last womens collection for Yves Saint Laurent in Paris yesterday, leaving the house after eight years as creative director. A look back at the designers oeuvre brings expertly tailored suits, directional proportions and many must-have womens accessories  the big square-buckle belt (spring 05), the strappy star stiletto (spring 08) and the cage boot (spring 09), among them  to the fore. For men, Pilati made clothes that were dressed up, grown-up, controlled. For women, he had more fun and introduced things like tulip skirts and tunics, leading fashion into silhouettes that shocked and then lasted. (Can one count the number of tulip skirts that were made and worn between 2005 and 2007? Did the tunics that Pilati showed with leggings in his fall 2006 collection not prompt Skinny Jean Mania?). Balancing severity with sexiness, always, Pilati exits YSL with a legacy of looks for the books, from fall 06s flower-pouf capelet to fall 07s A-line tuxedo mini and the most recent chain-mail racer dress. See our slide show >>

title: Online and on TV, Super Tuesday Coverage
description: Coverage of the Super Tuesday primaries will blanket television news networks and news Web sites on Tuesday. The countdown clocks are already up and running on CNN and the Fox News Channel.

title: Pandora Revenue Misses Expectations
description: Plenty of media companies, big or small, would be very happy with the growth enjoyed by Pandora Media, the company behind the popular online music service Pandora. Its revenue doubled last year, and its 125 million registered users listened to 8.2 billion hours of music, according to financial results reported by the company on Tuesday.

title: Obamas Call Was a Lesson for His Girls
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, speaking publicly for the first time about Rush Limbaughs slur of a law student on his radio show last week, said on Tuesday that he had called the woman, Sandra Fluke, in part to set an example for his daughters.

title: Insights From the Super Tuesday Exit Polls
description: 11:49 p.m. | Updated The Timess polling unit is mining results of exit polls to learn about Super Tuesday voters and their priorities. This post will be updated as we crunch more numbers.Ohio Independents
