description: Pilgrimage for Pizza

title: Terra Nova Is Canceled, but Seeks New Home
description: One of the television seasons most ambitious new series, the science-fiction drama Terra Nova, got word this week that it would have no future on Fox, but the studio that produces it has begun intensive efforts to find another network willing to run the show.

title: Newark Project Aims to Link Living and Learning
description: NEWARK  Work has begun on an education-centered community featuring three charter schools and affordable housing for teachers in the citys decayed downtown, with much of the design work done by the noted architect Richard Meier.

title: Hunter College High School Names One of Its Own as Principal
In Seattle, Amazon Leads an Upswing in Office Space
description: SEATTLE  Amazon, already a large company, has been on a tremendous growth spurt. At the end of last year, the online retailer had about 56,000 employees nationwide, a 67 percent rise from 2010, and will most likely continue hiring this year.

title: Five Figures Circling, Backward, Across a Blueprint of the Whitney
description: The crucial word in Devotion Study #1  The American Dancer, Sarah Michelsons contribution to the 2012 Whitney Biennial, is study. Like much of Ms. Michelsons work, this one is relentless, formally severe, unafraid to push repetition to extreme ends. But her focus here is even narrower, zoomed in on a detail from last years acclaimed, endurance-testing work Devotion. For almost 90 minutes, while a metronome ticks, dancers walk backward in circles.

title: Dreamers Songs Adrift, Shifting Through Multiple Dimensions
description: In an onstage interview at her Making Music concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening, the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho explained her approach to From the Grammar of Dreams, a 2007 setting of Sylvia Plath texts, by making a fascinating distinction between wakefulness and dreaming. When you are awake, she told Jeremy Geffen, the moderator, you speak in sentences that move sequentially through time. But when you dream, your speech can be four-dimensional.

title: Kanye West Lets the Clothes Talk for Him
description: Harder, faster, stronger, maybe just a little bit better.

title: Peasant Pitted Against Soldier
description: With its lurid pastel costumes and swirling onstage activity, John Copleys 1991 staging of LElisir dAmore (The Elixir of Love) looks like an Easter egg display on steroids. Some of the cardboard sets and props could have been bought at a garage sale, and Nemorino sings his showpiece aria in what appears to be a forest of giant cauliflower.

title: Photos of The Moment | Chanel
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Considering the Options on Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: When Catholic and Secular Hospitals Merge
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Takes Home State of Georgia
description: Newt Gingrich has won his home state of Georgia, according to preliminary exit polls, giving him an early Super Tuesday victory in a state he had promised to win.

title: Doo-Wop Fan, Going Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: Relevance Proves Its Worth
description: PARIS

title: Romney Wins Virginia
description: Mitt Romney has won the largely uncontested Virginia primary, a win that was largely expected. Mr. Romney faced only Representative Ron Paul there because Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum failed to submit enough valid signatures to qualify for the Virginia ballot.

title: When The Family Business Is Art
description: WHAT were you doing when you were 24? Blogging about an annoying boss? Living with your parents while trying to find meaning after college? Occupying Wall Street? Couch surfing?

title: Fighting for the Chinese Enlightenment
description: BEIJING  Until Liu Ping emerged from the subway and onto a street under bright blue skies one recent Saturday, I wasnt sure shed even make it. I feared shed be stopped on her journey by security officials from Xinyu, her hometown, a common occurrence in China for people who have incurred the displeasure of local officials.

title: Web Sites Shine Light on Petty Bribery Worldwide
description: The cost of claiming a legitimate income tax refund in Hyderabad, India? 10,000 rupees.

title: SUNYs Chief, on Remedial Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A Decent Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Saints Coach and G.M. Accept Responsibility on Bounties
description: New Orleans Saints General Manager Mickey Loomis and Coach Sean Payton finally acknowledged on Tuesday the N.F.L.s investigation into the Saints bounty system, which paid players to injure opponents. The acknowledgment came four days after the league said Loomis and Payton were aware of the system and did nothing to stop it even, in Loomiss case, after the owner Tom Benson told him to put a stop to it.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander McQueen
description: Ive always done something outrageous, explained the manicurist extraordinaire Marian Newman backstage at Alexander McQueen. For at least the past five collections, she said shed veered away from a natural nail. This season called for something different. A beautiful, ethereal woman is how she described the girls with fingernails painted soft white, toenails sheer pink or beige. A pure girl, almost like a statue, was how Peter Philips imagined the models at McQueen. He used Chanels Mat Lumiere foundation on most of the girls as the primary makeup with a little brow pencil and Rouge Coco Shine lip balm. Eyelashes were curled, but only, Philips admitted, for the purpose of backstage photography, as everyone was to wear futuristic, mirrored glasses/visors, which clipped around the sides of the head. Guido Palau had the difficult task of sourcing 36 wigs in a platinum, almost yellow blond, with four in gray to go with the pink looks in particular. The wigs were fitted with identical hairlines and cuts to take the personality away, according to Palau. He was channeling manga racer characters with the slicked-back androgynous look he created with a heavy dose of Redken Forceful 23 Hair Spray. The idea was to contrast the beautiful super-romantic clothes with a futuristic hairstyle.

title: A Mirror Can Be a Dangerous Tool for Some C.E.O.s
description: Call it the curse of the chief executive.

title: F.D.A. Backs Respiratory Distress Drug for Babies
description: One of the biotechnology industrys longest losing streaks ended Tuesday when Discovery Laboratories finally won approval for its first drug, after failing on four previous tries going back to 2004.

title: Hackers Lash Out at LulzSec Leader Turned Snitch
description: Wednesday 3:51 p.m. | Updated The federal government is run by a bunch of cowards, read a post to the Twitter account of The Real Sabu, who added an unkind embellishment to describe the type of cowards he meant.

title: Not the Kind of Mark a Pitcher Wants
description: Sarasota, Fla.

title: Despite Kremlins Signals, U.S. Ties Remain Strained After Russian Election
description: MOSCOW  Now that Russias presidential campaign is over, the Kremlin signaled on Tuesday that it was prepared for its relationship with Washington to get back to normal, potentially including swift cooperation on containing Irans nuclear program amid the prospect of a military strike by Israel.

title: Pay Only for Drugs That Help You
description: ITS hard not to be outraged by the fact that the United States spends $2.6 trillion per year on health care, far more than any other country, and has no better medical outcomes to show for it. Everyone agrees that we need to cut waste from the system. And its understandable that, with reports of individuals taking $100,000 cancer drugs only to prolong survival by a few months, the high cost of drugs is one of the first targets.

title: New Orleans Group Promotes Hurricane Awareness
description: NEW ORLEANS  For most city officials here, making plans to evacuate tens of thousands of residents from the wrath of a hurricane brings to mind a tangle of logistics: bus routes, out-of-state shelters, fresh water supplies, public safety. But for one young transplant named Robert X. Fogarty, evacuation means 12-foot-tall sculptures placed strategically around town.

title: McIlroy, the Worlds No. 1 Golfer, Takes a Playful Shot at Tennis
description: DORAL, Fla.  No shot Sunday at the Honda Classic  not even his 8-foot birdie putt at No. 13 with the fans roar from Tiger Woodss birdie-eagle finish ringing in his ears  was as nerve-racking for Rory McIlroy as the ones he hit with a tennis racket Monday night during a rally with Maria Sharapova in front of 18,000 fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Stuck in Arbitration
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Riveting!: The Quandary of the Book Blurb
A Visitor in Own Building, UConn Puts Up Its Feet
description: HARTFORD  Although XL Center was filled with thousands of loyal fans, the Connecticut women wore their road blue jerseys and were assigned to the visitors bench Tuesday for the Big East Conference tournament championship game, another reminder that this season has not been so smooth.

title: Romney Wins Broad Coalition in Massachusetts
description: Mitt Romney sailed to victory in Tuesdays Massachusetts primary with a broad coalition of voters in his home state that included strong support from all age groups, education and income levels.

title: Bloomberg Defends Grading System Derided by Restaurateurs
description: A cheer went up the other night at James, a popular Brooklyn bistro, as a triumphant waiter marched into the retro-tinged dining room bearing the new gold star of the New York City restaurant trade: a framed, blue letter A.

title: Taking a Page From the Web, Magazine Pitches a Social Game
description: FOR traditional media like magazines, remaining relevant in a world of new media and social media is no walk in the park. So how about a workout in the park?

title: From Japan, Bearing Witness in Debate Over Indian Point
description: Noriyuki Kitajima stepped into the cold, clear morning air of Claremont Avenue in Morningside Heights, where he was staying on a visit from Japan.

title: Gingrich Takes Georgia, Keeping Campaign Alive With a Southern Strategy
description: ATLANTA  With a decisive victory in Georgia, Newt Gingrich saved a campaign that seemed teetering on the precipice of disaster two weeks ago. Polling then suggested that he might achieve no better than a squeaker victory in his home state, an embarrassment that could have led him to withdraw.

title: AARP Study Says Price of Popular Drugs Rose 26%
description: The prices of drugs used most widely by older Americans rose by nearly 26 percent from 2005 to 2009  nearly twice the rate of inflation  according to a report issued Tuesday by AARP.

title: The Wrong Approach to Discipline
description: Distressing new federal data on the disciplinary treatment of black students adds urgency to investigations into the treatment of minority children in a dozen school districts around the country by the Office of Civil Rights in the Department of Education. The agency, which is negotiating policies with some of these districts, needs to push for procedures that keep children in school.

title: Manning Reaches End of the Line With the Colts
description: Images of Peyton Manning are everywhere in Indianapolis  in the mall and at the airport, in a towering portrait on the side of the Colts downtown stadium, and on the walls inside where the ticket holders party.

title: Tennessee Gives Santorum First Victory
description: Rick Santorum easily defeated Mitt Romney Tuesday in Tennessee, a southern victory that will help him make the case for continuing to contest Mr. Romney for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Police Leaders Evolving Efforts to Defend Surveillance
description: It was still several hours before Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly was to meet with Muslim leaders whom he had invited to Police Headquarters on Tuesday. But the meeting was already drawing criticism, underscoring how precarious the commissioners scattershot style of aggressively defending his departments counterterrorism efforts could be.

title: Bruno Ricciotti
description: Mr. Ricciotti, 39, is the chief executive and a principal of Bond New York, an independent residential real estate brokerage. The company is involved in both rentals and sales, and represents new developments like the Ellison condominium in Harlem.

title: Voters Said the Economy Was Their Main Issue
description: Regardless of the financial condition of their state, voters in Tuesdays Republican primaries considered the economy the top issue influencing their choice.

title: The Republican Primary Voters Religious Test
description: One detail in tonights exit polls, which are run by the television networks and The Associated Press, caught my attention. More than six in 10 primary voters in Ohio, Tennessee and Georgia said its important to share a candidates religious beliefs. In Tennessee alone, three-quarters took that position. So much for not having a religious test to get into office!

title: Eastern Libya Demands a Measure of Autonomy in a Loose National Federation
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  In a symbolic gesture of defiance, militia and tribal chiefs from eastern Libya gathered here on Tuesday to demand a return to the loose federation that prevailed before Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi took power four decades ago.

title: Florida Higher Education May Face Big Budget Cuts
description: MIAMI  With three days remaining until the end of the legislative session, Florida lawmakers are moving forward with a $70 billion budget that would create the states 12th university and cut hefty amounts of money from higher education.

title: Lawmakers Death May Bring Battle for Successor
description: The death on Tuesday of Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey, a significant force in Newark politics for decades, could set off a major battle for his seat.

title: College Hunt Starts Earlier at New Breed of Schools
description: At Avenues, a for-profit school scheduled to open this fall in Chelsea, college counseling will begin with students in ninth grade. Similarly, Lman Manhattan, a for-profit school downtown, starts the formal college search process with its freshmen; in addition, seventh- and eighth-grade students can visit campuses on a three-day trip in the spring.

title: With Eyes Open Wide, Teenager Gets a Look at the Major Leaguers
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Brandon Nimmo leaned against the railing of the dugout, his elbows burrowing into the soft padding. It was the top of the ninth inning in an exhibition game Tuesday afternoon at Digital Domain Park, the stands were emptying, and many of the Mets regulars were already on their way home.

title: Rutgers Student Saw Twitter Posts by Roommate About Spying
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  As Dharun Ravi posted Twitter feeds about using a webcam to see his Rutgers University roommate in a sexual encounter with another man, one of those reading intently was the roommate himself, Tyler Clementi, an investigator testified on Tuesday.

title: Romney Appears the Ohio Winner; Santorum Strong
description: Mitt Romney appeared to pull off a narrow victory in Ohio on Super Tuesday but lost several other states to Rick Santorum, a split verdict that overshadowed Mr. Romneys claim of collecting the most delegates and all but ensured another round of intense infighting on the road to the Republican presidential nomination.

title: In First Game, Fitter Hughes Finds Life in Fastball
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  Phil Hughes came to spring training last year several pounds overweight, and the Yankees were unhappy. But according to Hughes, none of the teams officials expressed their displeasure directly to him. Hughes said they did not have to.

title: Santorum Wins Oklahoma
description: Rick Santorum has won Oklahoma, adding a second win for the former Pennsylvania senator.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 6, 2012

title: Israels Best Friend
description: The only question I have when it comes to President Obama and Israel is whether he is the most pro-Israel president in history or just one of the most.

title: Dividends Emerge in Pressing Apple Over Working Conditions in China
description: The American sweatshop opposition movement was born the day we discovered how our Nikes were stitched together. Two decades later, we are discovering how our cherished iPhones are made, giving Apple a Nike moment of its own.

title: He Should Be All Right, Massachusetts Voters Say of Their Ex-Governor
description: LEOMINSTER, Mass.  These are the voters who know Mitt Romney best  the ones who chose him as their governor a decade ago, embracing his promise to shake things up as a newcomer to elected office and positioning him for a future on the national stage.

title: Obama Scolds G.O.P. Critics of Iran Policy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday forcefully rebuked Republicans on the presidential campaign trail and in Congress for beating the drums of war in criticizing his efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis over Irans nuclear program, underscoring how squarely the national security issue had entered the election-year debate.

title: When the South Splits
description: What does it mean that the South split tonight?

title: Reminder for Chandler Resonates With Knicks
description: DALLAS  The moment would belong to Tyson Chandler. The symbolism would resonate throughout the Knicks lineup, touching every teammate, coach and staff member.

title: Gingrich Vows to Move South After Georgia Win
description: ATLANTA  In the morning we are going on to Alabama. Were going on to Mississippi. Were going on to Kansas, and thats just this week, Newt Gingrich told an enthusiastic crowd celebrating his win in Georgia, some waving Newt-a-Mania signs.

title: Robert B. Sherman, a Songwriter for Disney and Others, Dies at 86
description: Robert B. Sherman, half of the fraternal songwriting team that wrote the ubiquitous paean to togetherness, Its a Small World (After All), and that in films like Mary Poppins and Chitty Chitty Bang Bang etched dozens of tunes and volumes of lyrics into the permanent memories of generations of children and their parents, died Tuesday in London. He was 86.

title: What Do the LulzSec Arrests Mean for Anonymous?
description: On Tuesday morning, members of so-called hacktivist groups discovered that they had been betrayed by one of their own.

title: Short on Effort and Offense, Rangers Learn Lesson Against the Devils
description: NEWARK  The Rangers traveled a short distance, just across the Hudson River, to learn what might happen if their willingness to check opponents and their pursuit of the puck do not match their opponents. Their 4-1 loss to the Devils on Tuesday night at Prudential Center was a rare lapse in effort and execution.

title: Penn Loses, Securing Title and Bid for Harvard
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  For the 18th consecutive year, Penn and Princeton met on the last Tuesday night of the Ivy League season. The two have combined for 51 mens basketball championships in a league known as the Ancient Eight, and so it has not been unusual for this final matchup in downtown Philadelphia or suburban New Jersey to settle the league title and an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Before Ferry Swamped, Chef Had Idea for It
description: At the moment, its one very cold and soggy old ferry, listing heavily and partly resting on the bottom of the Hudson River at Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Gay Rights Group Fires Chief, Central in Marriage Fight
description: New Yorks leading gay rights organization has dismissed its executive director, who played a central role in the legalization of same-sex marriage last year.

title: Blue-Blooded and Tone-Deaf on Beacon Hill
description: Kathleen Chalfant and John Cunningham are transfixing as Boston blue bloods whose patrician airs and whimsical eccentricities mask the shambles their lives have become in the Keen Company revival of Painting Churches, at the Clurman Theater.

title: Par-TAY!
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Suffering from the midweek blahs? Tired of trying to scramble over the hump of humpday? Have we got a puzzle for you.

title: An Update on New York Redistricting
description: With just 16 weeks until its Congressional primary, New York still has not approved political districts. New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: Seton Hall Keeps Hopes by Routing Providence
description: Clinging to its N.C.A.A. tournament hopes, Seton Hall avoided a third consecutive loss to a conference bottom-dweller with a 79-47 win over Providence on Tuesday night in the first round of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden. The Pirates displayed some of the potential that made their late-season swoon so mystifying.

title: Suffolk County Cites Emergency in Finances
description: Suffolk may be one of the richest counties in America, but it risks running out of money next month, its top elected official said Tuesday.

title: Super Tuesday
description: Long before Super Tuesday, the Republican Party had cemented itself on the distant right of American politics, with a primary campaign that has been relentlessly nasty, divisive and vapid. Barbara Bush, the former first lady, was so repelled that on Tuesday she called it the worst shed ever seen. We feel the same way.

title: Republicans to Push Bill in an Effort to Add Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans will try this week to get back on the political message they want, job creation, and they are getting some help from President Obama and the Senate Democratic leadership, who share the need to appear cooperative on legislation to boost hiring.

title: Assuming a Heavy Mantle in a Season of Sorrow
description: Clinging to a white towel and a 1-point lead, Nazareth Coach Lauren Best nervously paced the sideline in the closing minutes against Christ the King last Thursday night.

title: On a New TV Show in China, Cue the Firing Squad
description: HONG KONG  Right up front, a disclaimer: Rendezvous declines to comment on any of the TV shows of dubious taste and suspicious odor that exist elsewhere (and seemingly everywhere) on the planet. But a weekly show in China could well set a new standard in the oh-no sweepstakes.

title: Liz Cheney: Desist!
description: WASHINGTON

title: Newt Gingrich Speaks in Atlanta
description: Newt Gingrich claimed victory in Georgia and promised to stay in the race in a speech to supporters in Atlanta.

title: Paul Speaks in N.D.
description: Ron Paul spoke early in the night to supporters at a Super Tuesday rally in North Dakota.

title: Pro-Israel Delegates Have Washingtons Ear on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee was surrounded by a gaggle of constituents on Tuesday like a quarterback in a huddle, finishing a discourse on his commitment to stopping Iran from developing nuclear weapons.

title: Do Electronic Medical Records Save Money?
description: Experts have long argued that computerized patient records will save the health system money by helping doctors reduce the number of redundant or inappropriate tests they order. A new study published in Health Affairs, disputes that, suggesting that office-based physicians who have access to electronic records of patient care are actually more likely to order additional imaging tests and laboratory tests than doctors who rely on paper records.

title: Romney Takes the Stage
description: BOSTON  With three Super Tuesday victories already in his column, Mitt Romney took the stage in front of a loud and excited  but not entirely full  ballroom of supporters to revel in what he hopes will be a night with enough wins to finally catapult him to his partys nomination.

title: Striking Down a Bad Law, Piece by Piece
description: Arizonas extremist immigration law has gone another round in federal court  and lost again. The judge who rejected several of its provisions in 2010 temporarily blocked another section last week, the one making it a crime for day laborers to look for work on the street.

title: Big Sky, Bright Sun and Melanoma
description: GUFFEY, Idaho  There is no tanning salon in this brittle bend of the Snake River, no unlimited monthly Titanium package for $39.99, no interest in getting any more ultraviolet light than necessary during a day spent working the dry canyon lands beneath the big, bright sun.

title: Under Cover of the Night, Syrians Cross Into Safety
description: ALTINOZU TOWNSHIP, Turkey  The Syrian men walked out of the fog on the Orontes River, straining as they carried two stretchers toward a Turkish ambulance just beyond the swollen banks.

title: Somali Suspects in Hijacking of Iranian Ship Face Piracy Trial in Seychelles
description: Fifteen Somali men accused of being pirates, who were captured aboard a hijacked Iranian fishing vessel by the United States Navy in January, were transferred on Tuesday to the Seychelles for trial.

title: Will Congress Party Defeats Spur Economic Reform?
description: Since the current Congress Party-led government took office in mid-2009, Indian companies and foreign investors have been waiting for policy makers to unveil a new wave of economic reforms. They are still waiting.

title: Obama Campaign Busy in Ohio, Too
description: Even as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum sweated out the returns from Ohio to see who would claim Super Tuesdays biggest prize, the Obama campaign was showing the organizational muscle in the swing state that has the Republican Party fretting for its eventual nominee in the general election this fall.

title: Good Feelings Flee Knicks Against Resilient Mavs
description: DALLAS  On a night of happy homecomings and warm sentiments, the Knicks final expression was a scowl, a mixture of frustration, disappointment and confusion.

title: Romney Speaks in Boston
description: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at the Westin Hotel in Boston.

title: Santorum Speaks to Supporters in Ohio
description: Rick Santorum spoke to supporters at a high school in Steubenville, Ohio.

title: Scrutiny of Political Nonprofits Sets Off Claim of Harassment
description: WASHINGTON  The Internal Revenue Service is caught in an election-year struggle between Democratic lawmakers pressing for a crackdown on nonprofit political groups and conservative organizations accusing the tax agency of conducting a politically charged witch hunt.

title: Corrections: March 7
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Supreme Court to Hear Dispute on Drug Patents
description: As China was becoming the worlds shop floor, India took its place as the worlds pharmacy, and in recent decades has been the largest provider of cheap, lifesaving medicines in poor countries across the globe, Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Pollack write in The New York Times.

title: America Is Stealing the Worlds Doctors
description: It was not an unusual death. Kunj Desai, a young doctor in training at University Teaching Hospital in Lusaka, Zambia, had seen many that were not so different and were equally needless. Still, this was the one that altered all his plans. A guy came in, and he had a stab wound, Desai recalled, and his intestines got injured. The operation was delayed, and the wound became infected. Whatever he was eating would come out of his belly, Desai said. A carefully managed diet would have helped the man heal, but there were no dietitians at the hospital nor any IV drips of liquid nutrients with which to feed him. He withered away to probably about 100 pounds when he died.

title: Word of the Day | impious
description: impious \im-pe-s, ()im-pi-\ adjective

title: Lessons to be Learned from IndiGo Airlines
description: It is not all doom and gloom for the beleaguered Indian airline sector, a Reuters report argues.

title: Refugees Flee Syrian Violence in Turkey
description: Thousands of Syrians have crossed the border to escape the growing conflict in their country.

title: With No Knockout Punch, a Bruising Battle Plods On
description: Mitt Romney won the delegates, but not necessarily the argument.

title: Ohios Divided Political Passions on Display in Vote
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio  Once again Ohio lived up to its reputation as a state of deeply divided political passions.

title: William Heirens, the Lipstick Killer, Dies at 83
description: William Heirens, the notorious Lipstick Killer who in 1946 confessed to three horrific murders in Chicago and then spent the rest of his life  more than 65 years  in prison despite questions about his guilt, was found dead on Monday in the Dixon Correctional Center in Dixon, Ill. He was 83.

title: Rangers Americans Most Likely on the Way Out
description: At Rangers, the players are being forced to betray a motto that has embodied the clubs fight against financial ruin.

title: Christopher Lyles, Got Synthetic Trachea, Dies at 30
description: Christopher Lyles, whose cancerous windpipe was swapped in November for a synthetic one seeded with his own cells in only the second operation of its kind, died on Monday in a Baltimore hospital. He was 30 and lived in Abingdon, Md.

title: Super Tuesday Report, 8 p.m.
description: New York Times reporters and Op-Ed columnists break down the returns on Super Tuesday and look forward to the general election in November.

title: Super Tuesday Report, 7 p.m.
description: New York Times reporters and Op-Ed columnists break down the returns on Super Tuesday and look forward to the general election in November.

title: I Paid a Bribe Website Inspires Others
description: It costs 10,000 rupees to claim a legitimate income tax refund in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad, Stephanie Storm wrote in The New York Times.

title: Africas Girl Power
description: Update: David Bornstein responded to readers in the comments below.

title: Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago Announces 2012-13 Season
description: Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago announced plans on Tuesday to produce a new drama by Tarell Alvin McCraney, the author of the critically acclaimed Brother/Sister Plays, and four other works as part of its 2012-13 season.

title: For First Time in 16 Years, Kucinich Loses His Seat
description: In a primary faceoff between two veteran Democratic incumbents, voters in Ohio delivered a victory to Representative Marcy Kaptur, a progressive from Toledo, over Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, leaving him without a seat in Congress for the first time in 16 years.

title: The Future of the Santorum Coalition
description: Rick Santorums victories in Tennessee, Oklahoma and North Dakota on Super Tuesday, and his very strong showing in Ohio, will give hope to journalists who love the horse race, without changing the underlying dynamics of the Republican contest. Bloodied, balked and widely mistrusted, Mitt Romney is still going to slog his way to the nomination.

title: British Families Feel Austeritys Bite
description: LONDON  Here in Britain, government budget cuts are in the news constantly, and you can feel the changes in day-to-day life. In my north London neighborhood, a much-loved play center my daughter often visited was shuttered a few months ago, and the Sure Start Childrens Centers that provide a host of services are being cut and consolidated.

title: Candidates on Super Tuesday
description: The Republican presidential candidates spread out across the country as voters in ten states went to the polls and caucuses.

title: Florence Wolfson Howitt, Famed for Rediscovered Diary, Dies at 96
description: Florence Wolfson Howitt, whose lifelong dream of recognition as a writer eluded her until she was in her 90s, when the diary she had kept as a teenager was found in a Dumpster and became the subject of a newspaper article and a widely publicized book, died on Tuesday at her home in Pompano Beach, Fla. She was 96.

title: The Candidates Super Tuesday Speeches
description: Watch the candidates speeches from Super Tuesday, broken down by themes.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/07/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/07/2012

title: Super Tuesday Report, 9 p.m.
description: New York Times reporters and op-ed columnists break down the returns on Super Tuesday and look forward to the general election in November.

title: Super Tuesday Report, 10 p.m.
description: New York Times reporters and op-ed columnists break down the returns on Super Tuesday and look forward to the general election in November.

title: Getting Fat but Staying Fit?
description: Does being physically fit counteract some of the undesirable health consequences of being overweight? That question, of pressing interest to those of us who exercise while carrying a few extra pounds, prompted an important new study that focused on aerobic fitness and weight swings.

title: In India, A Surge in Female Voters
description: The results for the assembly elections held across five Indian states, announced yesterday, threw up some surprises. But a welcome surprise in these elections was the high voter turn out. Voters, and particularly women voters, went to the polls in unexpectedly high numbers.

title: Data Hint at Hypothetical Particle, Key to Mass in the Universe
description: After 40 years, more evidence is being reported Wednesday that the end of the biggest manhunt in the history of physics might finally be in sight.

title: March 7, 1965 | Civil Rights Marchers Attacked in Selma
description: On March 7, 1965, state troopers and a sheriffs posse in Selma, Ala., attacked 525 civil rights demonstrators taking part in a march between Selma and Montgomery, the state capital. The march was organized to promote black voter registration and to protest the killing of a young black man, Jimmie Lee Jackson, by a state trooper during a Feb. 18 voter registration march in a nearby city.

title: Top Pentagon Officials Stress Risks in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagons top two officials said Wednesday that President Obama had asked for preliminary military options to respond to the increasingly violent Syria conflict, but they emphasized the risks and said that the administration still believed that diplomatic and economic pressure was the best way to protect Syrians from the Assad governments repression.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 7, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Is This Living Room Big Enough for My TV?

title: News Quiz | March 7, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.Good luck!

title: Sounds Like Team Spirit
description: WHO are ultras?

title: Finding Sanctuary in Japan
description: When the earthquake and tsunami hit Japan last year, all but two of the 65 homes in Aramachi, a small community in Rikuzentakata, were destroyed. Sixteen residents died. That evening, 50 survivors crowded into a small building at the Buddhist temple complex that had been at the heart of this community of farmers for centuries. Cold, wet and scared, they spent the night praying and mourning.

title: Avalanche Exposes Afghans Vulnerability to Vagaries of Climate and of Aid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The massive avalanche that crushed a village in the far reaches of northern Afghanistan this week, killing at least 50 people, was part of a pattern of extreme temperatures and heavier snowfall that has spread suffering and underscored the governments continued failings despite a decade of outside assistance and billions of dollars in aid.

title: HSBC Agrees to Sell Insurance Units for $914 Million
description: LONDON  HSBC said on Wednesday that it was selling its general insurance businesses in Asia and Latin America for $914 million as part of its plan to focus on more profitable and faster-growing businesses.

title: What Questions Do You Have About How the World Works?
description: The actor Alan Alda and Stony Brook University have teamed up on an initiative to explain science to children. The challenge is to explain what a flame is in a way that is understandable to an 11-year-old. What questions do you have about science or how the world works? How would you explain basic scientific concepts to a child?

title: Trojan Voting
description: ISTANBUL  Churchill was right. Democracy really is the worst form of government except for all the others.

title: Study Finds a Growing Student Debt Load
description: A federal report released this week suggests that as many as 27 percent of the 37 million borrowers have past-due balances of 30 days or more, Andrew Martin and Ron Lieber report.

title: Career Concerns in Chicago
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Fantasy Focus: The Old and the Boring
description: Baseball, like many other endeavors in life, goes through cycles. Whether its a juiced ball (or juiced body part) era, or a high-mound era, the only constant in the game is change. At one point there was an inefficiency in the game in which only a handful of teams were doing advanced statistical analysis (which subsequently influenced front office decisions, rather than being tossed to the side). Since the Athletics run of success and the publication of Moneyball  perhaps even before its publication  everybody has a phalanx of number-crunchers, and many of them have risen to the level of general managers, or at least are sympathetic to those types.

title: The Second-Class Status of Pre-Super Bowl History
description: In the comments section on the remembrance of the former Giant Alex Webster, a reader said of his father: He told us all yarns about Gifford, Tittle, Conerly (his favorite), Robustelli, Webster and the greatest Giant of them all  Sam Huff.

title: Maxells AirStash Outsources Your Data
description: The AirStash A02 by Maxell is an odd duck. Its basically a little USB-powered Wi-Fi hot spot with on-board storage. Using a related iPhone or iPad app, you can view the files stored on the AirStash  music, documents, photos, and movies  essentially adding up to 32GB of extra storage to your phone or tablet.

title: Tip of the Week: Bing Without the Bling
description: Like Microsofts Bing search engine, but find the large photo background distracting? If you would prefer to just focus on search task at hand, go to the URL box in your browser, type in the address http://www.bing.com/?rb=0 and hit the Enter key. A plain gray background should appear behind the Bing search box. If you like the look of Bing without bling, bookmark this version of the site for future use.

title: 6 British Soldiers Are Killed in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  British forces suffered their deadliest attack in six years when an armored vehicle struck an explosive device in southern Afghanistan, killing six soldiers, the British government announced on Wednesday.

title: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy
description: Before the media vans took over Main Street, before the environmental testers came to dig at the soil, before the doctor came to take blood, before strangers started knocking on doors and asking question after question, Katie Krautwurst, a high-school cheerleader from Le Roy, N.Y., woke up from a nap. Instantly, she knew something was wrong. Her chin was jutting forward uncontrollably and her face was contracting into spasms. She was still twitching a few weeks later when her best friend, Thera Sanchez, captain of one of the schools cheerleading squads, awoke from a nap stuttering and then later started twitching, her arms flailing and head jerking. Two weeks after that, Lydia Parker, also a senior, erupted in tics and arm swings and hums. Then word got around that Chelsey Dumars, another cheerleader, who recently moved to town, was making the same strange noises, the same strange movements, leaving school early on the days she could make it to class at all. The numbers grew  12, then 16, then 18, in a school of 600  and as they swelled, the ranks of the sufferers came to include a wider swath of the Le Roy high-school hierarchy: girls who werent cheerleaders, girls who kept to themselves and had studs in their lips. There was even one boy and an older woman, age 36. Parents wept as their daughters stuttered at the dinner table. Teachers shut their classroom doors when they heard a din of outbursts, one cry triggering another, sending the increasingly familiar sounds ricocheting through the halls. Within a few months, as the camera crews continued to descend, the community barely seemed to recognize itself. One expert after another arrived to pontificate about what was wrong in Le Roy, a town of 7,500 in Western New York that had long prided itself on the things it got right. The kids here were wholesome and happy, their parents insisted  cheerleaders and honor students, as one father said  products of a place that, while not perfect, was made up more of what was good about small-town America than what was bad. Now, though, the girls writhing and stuttering suggested something troubling, either arising from within the community or being perpetrated on it, a mystery that proved irresistible for onlookers, whose attention would soon become part of the story itself.

title: Austerity Chic
description: If the British economy is flagging, its no worse than it was in 1948, when Londons last Summer Olympics earned the nickname the Austerity Games  an irony that hasnt gone unnoticed. Luckily the citys museums are stepping in to burnish its brand: two exhibitions focused on postwar British design are making the case that the countrys economic tribulations have always coincided with periods of creative ascendancy. British Design 1948 to 2012, opening March 31 at the Victoria and Albert Museum, charts artistic upticks after the war, during the oil crisis in the 70s and after the recession in the 80s, when the creative salvage movement spurred the careers of designers like Tom Dixon. Designing Women, at the Fashion and Textile Museum, which opened March 16, focuses on the midcentury modern textile designs of Lucienne Day, Jacqueline Groag and Marian Mahler, and plays up a heroic moment of British ingenuity: three women inspired by the Bauhaus and the Secessionists rejected the chintzes and florals of the 30s and 40s and helped democratize modernism.

title: My Three Problems This Week
description: Every now and then, I like to toss out some nagging problems that I dont have answers for to see if anyone has suggestions to offer (here are three similar posts from August 2010,March 2011 and May 2011). So without further ado, here are some new problems:

When we last saw the men and women of the struggling Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce agency in a new installment of the show  in October 2010  the year was 1965 and Don Draper (played by Jon Hamm) had made a seemingly out-of-nowhere offer of marriage to his assistant and nanny, Megan (Jessica Par); Betty (January Jones) was at a crossroads; Peggy (Elisabeth Moss) was in ascendance; Joan (Christina Hendricks) was pregnant with a child that may have been fathered by Roger (John Slattery); Lane (Jared Harris) was British; and Pete (Vincent Kartheiser) was a win-at-all-costs jerk.

Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column. Being powerful and visionary, or at least thinking one is, can lead a corporate chieftain to great heights, but also to extreme narcissism. And the victims are often shareholders.

title: Europes Two Depressions

This time they point out that the slump wasnt nearly as bad this time, and recovery began much sooner  but that the pace of recovery has clearly slowed.

title: Leading Off: N.F.L., Never Figure on Loyalty
description: Lets just take a few moments to appreciate what will transpire today in Indianapolis when the Colts cut Peyton Manning, which manages to be staggering despite being altogether unsurprising. Because we all knew it would happen. The desperation by the Colts owner, Jim Irsay, to make this look like something other than a heartless business move told us that. And we have long since learned that loyalty and $5 will buy you a latte at Starbucks and exactly nothing in professional sports. Even Wayne Gretzky was traded, as was Joe Montana. If Abraham Lincoln had been an athlete, someone would have deep-sixed him as soon as his hook shot had lost its bite.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Hacker Arrest and a Terra Flop
description: A Times book critic, Dwight Garner, looks at the new crop of Kindle Singles  experiments in long-form journalism that dont quite make book length. Many left him cold: magazine articles left unedited with a lot of filler thrown in. But several  like John Hoopers reportage on the Costa Concordia disaster, Jane Hirshfield on haiku and Jonathan Mahler on Joe Paterno  are so good they awaken you to the promise of what feels almost like a new genre: long enough for genuine complexity, short enough that you dont need journalistic starches and fillers.

Beyond environmental considerations, South Carolina lawmakers say the dredging effort would give Savannah a competitive advantage over Charleston by allowing larger container ships to reach the Georgia port. [The Post and Courier]

title: McIlroy the Golfer Takes a Shot at Tennis
description: DORAL, Fla.  No shot Sunday at the Honda Classic  not even his 8-foot birdie putt at No. 13 with the fans roar from Tiger Woodss birdie-eagle finish ringing in his ears  was as nerve-racking for Rory McIlroy as the ones he hit with a tennis racket Monday night during a rally with Maria Sharapova in front of 18,000 fans at Madison Square Garden. McIlroy, 22, was in the audience to watch the exhibition between Sharapova, the former No. 1 player, and his girlfriend, Caroline Wozniacki, who began the year ranked No. 1 and is now No. 4. Toward the end of the match, which Sharapova won, 6-3, 6-4, Wozniacki summoned McIlroy from the stands and handed him her racket. More details can be found at the On Par blog.

title: Masha Gessen Talks About the Reign of Vladimir Putin

Her newest book, The Man Without a Face: The Unlikely Rise of Vladimir Putin, is a scathing account of Mr. Putins reign. Shortly after after the Russian elections on March 4, in which Mr. Putin won a contentious six-year term,Ms. Gessen discussed on e-mail his rise to power, the use and abuse of that power and the chances for change. title: A Salute to France and World Premieres for New York City Ballet Gala
description: The New York City Ballets spring benefit will have more than its usual share of French glamour and celebrity chic. The gala, to be held on May 10, will have a French theme, the company announced on Wednesday, and will feature the world premieres of two ballets. Peter Martins, the companys ballet master in chief, will choreograph a work to a score by the French composer Marc-Andr Dalbavie, and the French choreographer and former principal dancer Benjamin Millepied will stage the debut of a piece set to a commission by the young contemporary classical composer Nico Muhly, their fourth collaboration.

title: Clip: Gerhard Richter Painting
description: A scene from the documentary that looks at the artist Gerhard Richter and his creative process.

title: For Maine Senate Seat, Democrats Take a Chance
description: Eager to preserve their majority in the Senate, Democrats are rolling the dice in Maine on a popular independent former governor who is seeking Senator Olympia J. Snowes seat, in the hope that he sides with them next year if elected.

title: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Chrysler Recalls 210,000 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.s for Rust-Prone Suspension Component
description: Chrysler said it would recall almost 210,000 of its 2004-5 Jeep Liberty sport utility vehicles because rust could cause a rear suspension component to break, according to document filed early Wednesday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: On Billboards, a Bilingual Call to Nonbelievers
description: Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Call them equal-opportunity disbelievers: American Atheists, a national group that seeks wider acceptance for those who reject religion, has put up bilingual billboards aimed at Orthodox Jewish and Muslim communities in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Paterson, N.J.

title: Mets Will Be Flexible With Santanas Schedule
description: JUPITER, Fla. - Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Wednesday that the club would adjust its plans for Johan Santana daily, depending on how he felt, rather than keeping him on a strict rehabilitation schedule.

title: Kronwall Hit Draws Blood, Flyers Ire
description: 2:55 p.m. | Updated The N.H.L. announced there would be no supplementary discipline for Nicklas Kronwalls hit.

title: Mideast Din Drowns Out Palestinians
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  In the 14 months since revolution has spread across the Middle East and tension has soared over Irans nuclear program, the Palestinian leadership has found itself orphaned. Politically divided, its peace talks with Israel collapsed and its foreign support waning, the Palestinian Authority is sidelined, confused and worried that its people may return to violence.

title: Wisconsin Seeks Repeat With Season Down to Final 8
description: MADISON, Wis.  Earning the top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament for the second year in a row, the Wisconsin womens hockey team is looking to capture another national championship, beginning with quarterfinal play against Mercyhurst on Saturday.

title: Teenager From Hockey Family Tries to Rise in Tennis Ranks
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Jessica Pegula netted an easy swinging volley, then double-faulted on the next point to give back her double mini-break advantage in the second-set tiebreaker. It seemed as though her window for an upset had blown shut.

title: To Decant, or Not?
description: PARISEric Asimovs latest column in The New York Times on decanting wine reminds me that my own decanters see very little use  other than when theyre used to water the plants.

title: When Hospital Visitors Get Sick
description: The young woman was waiting for her mother to be discharged from the hospital when the pain started. My chest is hurting, she told me.

title: Vain Glorious | Swarovskis Fragrant New Aura
description: This spring, Swarovski adds fragrance to its portfolio  for the first time in the brands 117-year history  with Aura, a fruity-floral eau de parfum inspired by the transformative nature of crystal (of course).

title: 7 Charges Dismissed Against Man Beaten by Police
description: 5:11 p.m. | Updated Prosecutors in the Bronx on Wednesday dropped several criminal charges against a 19-year-old man whose beating at the hands of police officers in January was described as troubling by New Yorks police commissioner.

title: Ryanair Pokes E.U. Officials on Travel Policy
description: BRUSSELS  European Union officials do not always advocate austerity, at least when it comes to flying.

title: New M.&A. Adviser for Jefferies Unit
description: LONDON Andrew Bell, global head of mergers and acquisitions at HSBC, is leaving the firm to join the American investment bank Jefferies, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Apple Adds Sharper Screen and Speed to New iPad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple updated the iPad on Wednesday with a high-definition screen, a faster wireless connection and several other refinements, all packaged in a device without any major design changes.

title: Rio Committee Chooses Design for Olympic Golf Course
description: DORAL, Fla.  In what amounts to the first golfing upset of the 2016 Summer Olympics, Jack Nicklaus, Annika Sorenstam, Greg Norman, Lorena Ochoa and Gary Player lost out to Amy Alcott in the competition to design the course for the Rio de Janeiro Games.

title: Celebrating a Faustian Bargain
description: The music and the mythology kept an unsteady covenant throughout Robert Johnson at 100 at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night. Late in the going there came a succinct embodiment of that tension in two versions of Hellhound on My Trail, one of the most venerated tunes of Johnson, the Delta bluesman. The first take was by Taj Mahal, singing in his gruff, lean voice with a finger-picked acoustic guitar. It was an authoritative performance, evenhanded and self-contained.

title: Beauty Spots
Victories Expose Romneys Weakness, Obama Advisers Say
description: 4:31 p.m. | Updated Top Obama campaign advisers on Wednesday said that Mitt Romneys victories in Super Tuesdays Republican presidential contests illustrate his growing weakness in attracting independent, middle-income and young voters. David Axelrod, a senior adviser, likened Mr. Romneys nomination struggle to a death march that may hobble him for the general election race.

title: A Shape-Shifting Crossover From a Quiet Industry Giant
description: GENEVA  Magna Steyr, the Austrian automaker owned by Magna International, the auto parts maker, is not an automotive marque. But based on the Mila Coupic concept, the first car from the company to wear its name, that could change.

title: Claire Boucher Mines Beauty From the Dark Side
description: CLAIRE BOUCHER has never worn a meat dress. On occasion, Ms. Boucher, a Canadian synth-pop singer who performs under the name Grimes, will don a brightly colored wig onstage, but for now she prefers hair extensions.

title: What LTE Means for Apple and the Wireless Industry
description: The new iPad is Apples first mobile device compatible with the so-called fourth-generation LTE networks. The introduction of this new feature means more for the future of Apple and the wireless industry than it does for the iPad itself.

title: UConn Gets 20th Win, Which May Be Enough
description: Connecticut and West Virginia have been ordinary teams this season, giving their meeting Wednesday in the Big East tournament implications that rippled beyond Madison Square Garden.

title: The Daily Shoe | Louis Vuitton
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: LXTV Founders to Acquire Plum TV
description: The founders of the lifestyle Web site and television company LXTV announced Wednesday that they had concluded a deal to acquire Plum TV, a specialty cable channel directed at affluent viewers in such prestige locations as the Hamptons, Marthas Vineyard and Aspen.

title: A Lesson in Teaching to the Test, From E.B. White
Government, Responsibility and Happiness
description: Charles Murrays Coming Apart has attracted attention mainly for its rethinking of the nature of American inequality. Conservatives tend to be elated by Murrays cultural rather than economic understanding of inequality; liberals tend to be outraged at the suggestion that inequality is due to the moral faults of the working class. But Murrays sociology of inequality is only a preliminary to the real point of his book, which is an impassioned defense of a libertarianism that he sees at the root of the American project as envisaged by the founders of our republic. I propose to look at the argument  far more philosophical than sociological  that Murray advances for his libertarianism.

title: About Birth Control: Clearing Up Misconceptions About Contraception
description: Overview | In this lesson, students read about the current debate over health care coverage for birth control. They research the different options currently available for birth control, participate in a class forum on contraception, and discuss their own views regarding health care coverage for contraception.

title: TimesCast | The Race for the Nomination
description: Super Tuesday was not an across-the-board victory for Mitt Romney, making the race for the Republican nomination far from over.

title: Marketers Promoting a Granola Bar Hit the Trails in National Parks
description: NATURE VALLEY, the granola bar brand introduced by General Mills in 1975, is telling consumers to take a hike, but in a good way.

title: Drastic Cuts to Lead Poisoning and Prevention Funds
description: If, tomorrow, you took your toddler in for a routine checkup, and a blood test found elevated levels of lead, your next steps would be reasonably clear. Your pediatrician would hand you local health department phone numbers. Someone would come to help you figure out the source of the lead contamination, and amid your panic  because lead poisoning is serious, and its effects on mental and physical development potentially long-lasting  would be that one reassuring thing: someone was going to help you locate, and get rid of, the cause of the problem.

title: TimesCast: The Race for the Nomination
description: Super Tuesday was not an across-the-board victory for Mitt Romney, making the race for the Republican nomination far from over. Michael D. Shear reports.

title: Porsche Boxster Strikes Nose-to-Tail Balance
description: GENEVA  Particularly for the 911 and its ancestors, the uninterrupted slant-back look was a signature feature of Porsche sports cars since the companys first models appeared shortly after World War II.

title: Winter Wonders | Fashion Week Special
description: Paris Fashion Week ended today with a roar, with spotted coats roaming wild through the City of Lights. Here, a cheetah bomber with a fluoro bag translates into balanced boldness; a leopard cloak cocoons nautical stripes; and the Paris Vogue editor, Emmanuelle Alt, unleashes her inner animal with a leopard topcoat.

title: Rangers Split With Avery Is Nearly Complete
description: The Rangers confirmed Wednesday that Sean Avery had been told he will be left off the postseason roster of the Connecticut Whale, their A.H.L. affiliate. This would effectively end Averys tenure with the organization.

title: Lady Gagas Muse Tests His Poker Face
description: IT was a Friday night at St. Jeromes, a rock bar on the Lower East Side, and AC/DC blasted from the speakers, the smoke machine was set to low visibility, and the crowd wanted to party. Best of all, Luc Carl was having an awesome hair day.

title: Gingrich Spurns National Media, a Favored Punching Bag
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  When Newt Gingrich skewers the elite media, as he does almost daily, the national press most familiar with him from the campaign trail rolls its collective eyes, knowing it plays a stock villain in Mr. Gingrichs public rhetoric. But behind the scenes he is friendly and a good sport to individual reporters.

title: Digital Notes: Corbis Gets Into the Music Business
description: Licensing for the Long Tail: Corbis, the media rights clearinghouse, has started a music-licensing service on the Web intended to make money on a wider range of usages than usual. The site, GreenLight Music, is working with all the major music companies and has preset prices for songs according to how they will be used.

title: Shopping Snapshots: March 8
description: Uniqlo Undercover dresses the whole family; an easy way to work the flower-print look; and Persol sunglasses pay tribute to Capri.

title: Celebrating Robert Johnson
description: A wide range of musicians paid homage to the storied bluesman in a tribute concert at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Wall Street Says New Oversight Agency Is Too Costly
description: Wall Street banks are pushing regulators to defray the start-up costs of a new agency intended to prevent another financial crisis.

title: Ransom Center Acquires T.C. Boyles Papers
description: The papers of the writer T.C. Boyle have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, the center announced on Wednesday. The papers  meticulously organized by Mr. Boyle himself, according to a news release  include binders of manuscript material relating to almost all of his 22 books of fiction and some 140 short story files, along with correspondence with contemporaries like Russell Banks and David Foster Wallace, both of whose papers are also held at the Ransom Center.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Thailand, Pakistan, Jordan and Britain.

title: Restaurateurs Voice Anger Over Health Inspections
description: It was not as if the New York health department had threatened the citys 24,000 restaurateurs with posting a scarlet letter  or even a skull and crossbones  in their windows. But dozens of restaurant operators descended on City Hall on Wednesday to vent their ire at the letter-grading system inaugurated 19 months ago by the department to promote food safety.

title: Are Ninth Graders Ready for College Applications?
description: New for-profit schools are pushing the college counseling process younger and younger. As Jenny Anderson reports for The Times:

title: Citigroups Pandit Shows Love for Dodd-Frank
description: Is Vikram S. Pandit the anti-Jamie Dimon?

title: Relic of a Saint Is Stolen From a Dublin Cathedral
description: DUBLIN  In what seems like a surreal subplot from a Dan Brown novel, a number of irreplaceable religious relics have disappeared from churches across the country, the Irish police and a senior cleric say.

title: Adele and Houston Grammy Booms Continue
description: Three weeks after the Grammy Awards, Adele and Whitney Houston are still dominating the music charts.

description: Alan Cumming, David Byrne, Kelli OHara, Benjamin Walker and others performed.

title: Hammers, Nails and a Song or Two
description: OSKAR EUSTIS, the Public Theaters artistic director, never saw a musical as a child. Maybe thats to be expected when your mother is a scholar with a special interest in Puritanism.

title: Changes at Top of Deutsche Bank Start to Come Into Focus
description: LONDON  Anshu Jain, the incoming co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, is moving quickly to put in place his own management team in advance of his assuming joint control of the German banking giant on June 1.

description: New Haven

title: At City Hall, Restaurants Vent Letter-Grade Gripes
description: Dozens of New York City restaurateurs filled City Hall on Wednesday afternoon to voice their frustrations with the city health departments new process of assigning letter grades for food safety.

title: XL
description: ITS been a while since New York welcomed a large new gay venue to its club roster. In late January, a triumvirate of gay night-life doyens  John Blair, Beto Sutter and a relative newcomer, Brandon Voss  opened XL at the far end of West 42nd Street. It is a veritable one-stop shop for gay men of various stripes.

title: In the Age of the Smartphone, Ads Go Mobile
description: Online advertising is not intended for mere mortals to understand.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: Case Study
description: Dror Benshetrit, the sought-after designer behind Dror, is no stranger to travel. He is constantly touring cities like Istanbul, Paris, New Delhi and Tokyo to show off his innovative building systems, like QuaDror, a space-truss geometry sleek enough to be confused with art and strong enough to apply to table trestles, houses and even bridges. So when the luggage maker Tumi approached him to create its latest  and his first  line of travel bags, he thought, How complex can it be? Very, it turned out. Nevertheless, Benshetrit pushed the boundaries of what a suitcase can be, with a collection of chic, multifunctional bags: totes that become backpacks, reversible briefcases, expandable satchels and a hard-shell carry-on that, with two pulls of a hinge, doubles in size. Static objects do not work for me, he says.

title: UConn Gets a Jolt of Excitement Called Shabazz Napier
description: Part of growing up is knowing when you have acted like a fool. It is also knowing when to say youre sorry.

title: An Antiabortion Advocate Wins a Democratic Delegate
description: President Obama won the Democratic primary in Oklahoma with 57 percent of the vote on Tuesday, but it appears that a surprising showing by the anti-abortion advocate Randall Terry will cost the president one of the states 45 delegates to the partys national convention.

title: After Exercise, Relax
description: New research suggests that about 30 minutes of daily moderate activity can help you sleep better. Just dont do it within three hours of bedtime, because the energizing effects of exercise might keep you up. For more information on physical activity for older adults, download: health.gov/paguidelines/pdf/paguide.pdf.

title: Georgetown Cruises Into Quarterfinals
description: Georgetown entered this weeks Big East mens basketball tournament in a strange position. The 13th-ranked Hoyas were ranked higher nationally than all but two conference rivals, but they were seeded only fifth for the action at Madison Square Garden.

description: OPENINGS

title: Cato Institute Sends S.O.S. via the Web
description: 8:06 p.m. | Updated The Cato Institute, a libertarian research center locked in battle with the conservative billionaires Charles and David Koch over control of the organization, started a Web page Wednesday called Save Cato to lay out their case in the increasingly public fight.

title: Treasury to Sell $6 Billion Worth of A.I.G. Shares
description: The Treasury Department announced a plan on Wednesday to sell $6 billion of its American International Group shares, further whittling down the federal governments holdings in the insurance giant it helped bail out during the financial crisis.

description: While Bushwicks art scene is not new  cheap warehouses have been carved into bedbug-infested lofts for the better part of the last decade  it is turning a pivotal corner.

description: Lytro, Id like to introduce you to the new iPad. I think you both might like each other.

title: Next Stop, Bushwick
description: A Styrofoam chandelier hung from the ceiling. A piata was stuffed with candy cigarettes. An alien statue was wrapped in a Brazilian flag. But perhaps the strangest sight at the North Light Exhibition Space, a scrappy art gallery in Bushwick, Brooklyn, was the proprietor himself.

description: To the Editor:

title: How Citi Could Be More Transparent
description: Citigroups chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, likes to talk about transparency, and on Wednesday he repeated his call for new ways to compare the risks at different banks.

title: Louis Vuitton: The Trunk Show
description: Paris Fashion Week ended with a grand party on a stairwell. Or at least thats what it looked like walking into the Les Arts Dcoratifs wing of the Louvre on Wednesday night for the opening of a major exhibition on Louis Vuitton and Marc Jacobs. There were hundreds of people just standing there, crammed on the marble stairs leading into the show, presumably because drinks were not allowed inside.

title: What Makes Gasoline Prices Go Up?
description: On the day after Super Tuesday, the federal Energy Information Administration came out with a striking fact: in 2011, the United States, for the first time since 1949, exported more petroleum products than it imported.

description: To the Editor:

description: Over the course of the Great Recession and its aftermath, school district budgets have been ravaged while 270,000 teachers and other public school employees have lost their jobs.

title: What Should Be Done to Save the Postal Service?
description: To the Editor:

title: Profile in Style | Flavie and Clayton Webster
description: Known for sharp tailoring and custom leathers (Rooney Mara wore one of their jackets in The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo), the designers behind Cerre find inspiration wherever they go. Were as fascinated by huge structures, like the pyramids, as we are by tiny patterns we see in New York bridges or alleyways, says Clayton, whos half Danish. Former models, the pair met in 2000 on a train from Paris to Cologne. I chased her all around France and Spain for three months before she would even go out with me, Clayton says. Flavie quips: Im French  Im difficult. Since then, theyve traversed Europe, Senegal, Morocco and Egypt. Their new Los Angeles boutique (a celebrity magnet) has served to tame their nomadic tendencies, but they compensate by seeking creative mojo closer to home. We drive deep into the desert, Clayton says. We love finding abandoned buildings completely overtaken by nature. More

title: Say It Loud: Soul King Explained
description: R J Smith does not have to explain why his big new biography of James Brown is such a showstopper.This books sparkle speaks for itself, as does Mr. Smiths ability to take on his screaming, moaning, kinetically blessed, unbeatably shrewd subject. It takes a nervy authorial voice to describe James Brown with anything better than awe, mimicry or condescension. It takes a prescient writer to look at a picture of 9-year-old James Brown and see the boy who is father to the man: mouth unsmiling, the head tilted at an angle that sends a message  got something for me?

title: Love and Happiness. And Then Its Complicated.
description: It would take courage for any performer to sing In Buddys Eyes, the great Stephen Sondheim ballad from Follies, while standing only a few feet away from its definitive interpreter, Barbara Cook, who was in the audience.

title: Facebook Borrows $3 Billion and Increases Line of Credit
description: On its way to the public markets, Facebook is raising a huge war chest.

title: Pension Fund to Vote Against Kinder Morgan-El Paso Deal
description: One of the nations largest public pension funds said Wednesday that it would vote to block Kinder Morgans $21 billion takeover of the El Paso Corporation, citing a lack of transparency and conflicts of interest related to the deal.

title: Mario Batali Agrees to $5.25 Million Settlement Over Employee Tips
description: The celebrity chef and restaurateur Mario Batali and a business partner have agreed to pay $5.25 million to resolve a lawsuit filed on behalf of waiters, captains and other employees who claimed that his restaurants had illegally confiscated part of their tips to supplement their profits, court papers show.

title: The New iPad: Its in the Apps
description: 7:46 p.m. | Updated Claried description of iPad camera and GarageBand software.

title: Prices of Brand Name Drugs Rose Steeply, AARP Study Finds
description: AARP said Tuesday that the prices of drugs used most widely by older Americans rose by nearly 26 percent from 2005 to 2009, nearly twice the rate of inflation. The Times reported:

description: An exhibition in Williamsburg offers a cache of what might be described as designer weapons.
