description: The estate is set on 1.73 acres landscaped with palms and other tropical plants.

title: House Hunting in ... Costa Rica
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM MOUNTAINSIDE ESTATE OVERLOOKING SAN JOS

title: Exercising an Aging Brain
description: MORE and more retired people are heading back to the nearest classroom  as students and, in some cases, teachers  and they are finding out that school can be lovelier the second time around. Some may be thinking of second careers, but most just want to keep their minds stimulated, learn something new or catch up with a subject they were always curious about but never had time for.

title: Fox News Draws the Most Super Tuesday Viewers
description: Fox News Channel easily out-rated its cable news rivals on Tuesday, the Super Tuesday night of primaries and caucuses in 10 states. The channel even topped the only broadcast network, NBC, that produced a prime-time special about the primaries.

title: When Reaching for Returns, Mind the Risks
description: BY JOHN F. WASIK

title: Aging Stars in a New Role: TV Pitchman
description: THEY will always be defined by the roles they played. Robert Wagner is the suave star of It Takes a Thief and Hart to Hart. Patrick Duffy will be forever be J. R.s younger brother on Dallas (except to those who remember him as the piscine star of Man From Atlantis).

title: A Prosecutor Becomes a Champion for the Elderly
description: MARIE-THERESE CONNOLLY is using the prosecutorial skill she honed fighting nursing home fraud to add dimensions to the publics awareness of the widespread problem of elder abuse, including highlighting the costs to society of financial, physical and psychological mistreatment of older adults.

title: The Importance of a Road Map for Your Finances
description: A USEFUL way to avoid potholes on the road to retirement is an investment policy statement  an interactive atlas that will help you get where youre going and show you what to expect along the way.

title: Homework for Teachers: Their Investment Plans
description: WHEN Dan Otter started teaching in 1992, an insurance agent walked into his fourth-grade classroom in Southern California after school to try to sell him an annuity.

title: After the Storm, the Little Nest Eggs That Couldnt
description: A DECADE ago, Jonnie Worth had her eyes on retiring at age 62. Year after year, she funneled money into her 401(k), first when she worked as an event planner and later when she worked in the private banking department at JPMorgan Chase. But the financial crisis of 2008 swamped Ms. Worth. Like everyone else, I watched my retirement savings plummet, she said. I lost a big percentage of my investments.

title: Needed: Health Professionals to Treat the Aging
description: LAURA KAUFMAN no longer treats her patients in a suburban dental office. These days, she cleans teeth, does simple extractions and provides other basic care in the homes of inner-city elderly who are too frail to travel.

title: With Tax Changes Near, You Cant Wait to Plan
description: WITH 10,000 Americans turning 65 every day, financial advisers say that more than ever, people who are thinking about second acts need a life plan to account for living expenses, and also health, tax, investment and estate issues.

title: To Fall Asleep, Get Off the Couch
description: TORMENTED by pain from two decades of lower back problems, Don Cook was nearly at his wits end. Operations, traction, drugs  nothing seemed to work. At the behest of his family, he signed up for an exercise program for older people at Wichita State University, near his hometown, Derby, Kan.

title: Found: Older Volunteers to Fill Labor Shortage
description: POLICY makers and pundits warn that the baby boom wave could swamp the nations health care system. What if the 77 million boomers, who have just begun to turn 65, could help solve the health care crisis?

title: Party Workouts Are Growing in Popularity
description: Party workouts attract a range of fans, including recent transplants to New York who dont want to try to strike up friendships in bars.

title: Would You Like a Cocktail With That Workout?
description: AT first glance, the dimly lighted space on 20th Street in the Flatiron district on a recent Saturday night could have been any New York nightclub. Theres a clipboard-wielding bouncer in front of a velvet rope, a live D.J. spinning a Lady Marmalade remix, and a line to get in. But look more closely: The D.J.s turntable is perched on a dozen step-aerobics risers, the crowd is dressed in exercise gear, and the buff bouncer, who has the body fat of a Diet Coke, is asking, Do you have any injuries?

title: A Lifes Profusion of Blooms
description: Hillsborough, N.C.

title: Nancy Goodwins Garden
description: The Montrose garden, in North Carolina, thrives in a mild winter.

title: What Would Rush Limbaugh Have Said to Margaret Sanger?
description: Im reading a biography of Margaret Sanger, the birth-control activist, called Woman of Valor, by Ellen Chesler, and although Im only up to 1920 and the legalization of contraception is still a long way off, the story suddenly seems bizarrely contemporary. You can imagine what Rush Limbaugh, who came up with some choice words for a Georgetown Law School birth-control advocate, might have called Sanger, who, though technically married and the mother of three, had a number of ardent lovers, including a Spanish militant with whom she traipsed around Europe during months of self-imposed exile. Actually, she was on the lam. She had been charged in the United States with distribution of a pamphlet called Family Limitation, which discussed birth control methods and pleaded for women to know their own bodies. Under the Comstock Act, passed in 1873 and still in force in 1914, this amounted to obscenity.

title: Homes for $1.6 million
description: Homes in Vermont, Venice, Calif. and San Antonio.

title: What You Get for ... $1.6 million
description: DORSET, VT.

title: Make of It What You Will
description: With its unobtrusive, pared-down silhouette, the 606 Shelving System exemplified the German industrial designer Dieter Ramss less-is-more aesthetic when it was introduced in 1960. Its latest incarnation is aesthetically true to the original, but stronger and lighter, because its made of anodized extruded aluminum (the original was steel).

title: Sales at Kartell and Others
description: Hable Construction is discounting all hideaway storage bins up to 40 percent, through Wednesday (the Cherry Checker bin, originally $215, is $129); (718) 834-1752; hableconstruction.com.

title: A Certain Magnetic Charm
description: Adjustable lamps often have a light source that swivels on an arm or nods on a stem. Magneto, a new lamp by Foscarini, works more like a squirrel skittering on a tree trunk. Its LED-illuminated head is attached to a rod by a spherical magnet that moves up and down and spins around with a gentle push of the hand.

title: Wood, Meet Porcelain
description: While porcelain and wood seem like a natural combination, putting a wooden handle on a porcelain piece is actually a feat of engineering. It was tough to figure out how to make it work, said Thomas Ryan Barkman, who collaborated with Nancy Bauch, of White Forest Pottery. It took about a year.

title: Give a Man a Fish, for Inspiration
description: When Sean OHara was snorkeling off Bali and saw some manta rays swimming nearby, he was fascinated by how they moved. They undulate in such a soft, relaxed way, said Mr. OHara, a furniture designer in Glenmoore, Pa. Theres nothing frantic about the creature. It was that motion that inspired his design of the curvy Mobu Bench, named after Mobulidae, the fish family that includes the manta ray.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. My cats litter box is in the bathroom. What can I do to make it look better when potential buyers come to see my home?

title: Digital Devices for Luddites
description: NOBODY loves computers. I say this as someone who has led a life steeped in technology, and who considers the many computers I deal with every day to be truly revolutionary devices.

title: A Star Is Rehabbed
description: IT is hard to steal a show from Kristen Johnston. On a recent Wednesday night, at the Triad Theater on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a crowd howled as she posed and mugged, barefoot, reading from an old magazine diary written by the model Cindy Crawford. Ten minutes later, the same crowd was utterly still as Dillon Eaton, a 21-year-old from Boston, spoke haltingly about the recovery high school he credited with saving his life. The applause he received afterward made it clear  he had won the night.

title: Letters
description: Goody Bags

title: A Sleeker GTA Spano, but Is It Any More Real?
description: GENEVA  Every year here, aspiring supercar manufacturers show up with glamorous prototypes they propose to produce in limited numbers for unlimited dollars. More often than not, it is the last anyone hears of them.

title: A Clutch of Cunning Inventions
description: Every now and then, a technology product comes along thats so profoundly brilliant, the world changes forever.

title: From Japan, Percussive Gratitude
description: Amid a din of percussion and heavily amplified voices and instruments in the Rose Theater of Jazz at Lincoln Center on Tuesday evening came a remarkably understated moment. Not quiet, exactly, since it too was amplified, but simple, intimate, unexpected and soul wrenching.

title: Statue of Lemieux Includes Nod to Islanders
description: Today the Pittsburgh Penguins unveiled a statue of Mario Lemieux outside the Consol Energy Center. The statue is based on a play from a Dec. 20, 1988, game against the Islanders, when Lemieux split defensemen Rich Pilon and Jeff Norton and beat goaltender Kelly Hrudey for a goal in a 5-3 victory for the Penguins. The statue, called Le Magnifique, was created by the bronze sculptor Bruce Wolfe, who used a photo of the play in Sports Illustrated as a model.

title: Look Whos in the New White Cube
description: HONG KONG  Its about sex! Its about love! Its about abstract art! Graham Steele, the director of White Cube Asia, gestured at a crystalline Damien Hirst diamond cabinet in the private viewing room of the gallerys new Hong Kong space, which opened last Friday.

title: Art That Speaks to You, Even if It Says Scram!
description: Behind a fairly nondescript door on one of the quieter streets in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is a cache of what might best be described as designer weapons. The pieces, about 60 in all, are part of an exhibition opening Friday at Present Company called Threat: Objects for Defense and Protection.

title: Governments Role in British Bank Creates Uneasy Alliance
description: LONDON  Its hard to tell sometimes who is calling the shots at the Royal Bank of Scotland: management or politicians.

title: McQueen Blossoms Once Again
description: PARIS

title: Ready or Not, Time to Share More
description: Just when you thought you had finally figured out Facebook once and for all, here comes a whole new way to spend all your time tinkering with it. Over the next few weeks, every one of Facebooks nearly one billion members will have their profile pages forcibly updated to an ambitious new layout that Facebook calls Timeline.

title: Software for Both Solos and Sing-Alongs
description: Anyone who has ever grabbed a microphone and belted out some Bruce or Waylon in a bar knows he could do better with subtle tweaks in technique, acoustics or blood alcohol content.

title: Devotionals of Planets and Pop
description: Some years have passed since Wordless Music, the groundbreaking concert series founded by Ronen Givony in 2006 to bridge a shrinking gap between contemporary classical music and ambitious rock, has been particularly dogmatic about its titular inclination. Singers penetrated its borders relatively quickly. Still, it was at least a semantic paradox that Julia Holter, an inventive young singer, keyboardist and composer from Los Angeles, made her New York City debut in a Wordless Music event: few emerging performers get as much mileage out of a well-turned phrase.

title: The Fearsome Future Through Medieval Eyes
description: Benjamin Bagbys peculiar genius has less to do with virtuosity than with daring and imagination. His art is speculative reconstruction, and as a founder and now the driving force of Sequentia, he has mined the same musicological quarry as other medievalists. But his results have often been startlingly different from those of his peers, mainly because he is willing to take leaps that others are not. Probably his best known effort in recent years has been Beowulf, in which Mr. Bagby sang parts of the epic story in Old English to his own harp accompaniment, in what he proposed as a modern reincarnation of the antique bardic tradition.

title: Who Voted for Rick Santorum and Mitt Romney
description: Exit poll data from recent Republican primaries.

title: Musical Borrowing Under Scrutiny
description: Plagiarism? Excessive borrowing? The normal creative process?

title: Away From Stage, the Tango Turns Revealing and Intoxicating
description: Gabriel Miss, a master of Argentine tango and one of the most exciting dancers of our day, made his New York debut in 2008 at Symphony Space, with his partner at the time, Natalia Hills. Over the next two years he and Ms. Hills refined the give-and-take of their collaboration. This was, as several clips of their dancing on YouTube confirm, among the most compelling of all dance partnerships. The breakup of this team in 2011 was cause for real grief.

title: Explorations of Loss, the Personal and the Public
description: Stephen Petronio runs on drama. As he explained from the stage of the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, his companys performances in New York are about getting as many people together to make the biggest mess that we can. Such cultural chaos for this show involved a long list of artist-collaborators, including the ballerina Wendy Whelan, the composer Valgeir Sigurdsson, the design team of Gudrun & Gudrun and the visual artist Rannva Kunoy.

title: Trade Union Group, A.N.C. Ally, Holds Strikes in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  Tens of thousands of South Africans marched in the streets of the nations major cities on Wednesday in a national strike called by Cosatu, the powerful group of trade unions, a crucial ally of the governing African National Congress that is growing increasingly critical of its policies.

title: Wealth Could Be Risky Issue for Mets Owners Should They Face a Jury

description: Four women stripped and rebuilt houses and one storefront in a tiny, depressed Mississippi town, helping to spark a revival.

description: Andrij Dobriansky, a bass who sang more than 900 performances with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Feb. 1 in Manhattan. He was 81.

description: This week, The Choice introduced an occasional series called Counselors Calendar, intended to keep students on track  month by month  as they go through the admissions process. This series will provide timely information for students about what they need to know and do, and when, to help prepare them for the college application process  and for college itself.

title: Teacher Survey Shows Morale Is at a Low Point
description: The slump in the economy, coupled with the acrimonious discourse over how much weight test results and seniority should be given in determining a teachers worth, have conspired to bring morale among the nations teachers to its lowest point in more than 20 years, according to a survey of teachers, parents and students released on Wednesday.

title: Results Prove Modest in First Start for Kuroda

description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  In his quest for the truth about his countrys most notorious guest, Shaukat Qadir started where it all ended: the room where Osama bin Laden was killed.

title: As Candidates Speak in France, the Meter Is Running
description: PARIS  In a windowless room on the 10th floor of a Paris high-rise, a cohort of bleary-eyed government employees scans nearly every minute of nearly every show on nearly every major television network in France. They are counting, second by second, in the name of democracy.

title: Move to Enshrine Limbaugh With Missouris Greats Draws Ire
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  You will not find T. S. Eliot or Maya Angelou or even Chuck Berry in the Hall of Famous Missourians. Yogi Berra? Jean Harlow? Langston Hughes? No, no and no. Getting into the hall was even one caper that neither Jesse James nor Calamity Jane could pull off.

description: Peyton Manning is now a free agent, and while many teams do not have an apparent need at quarterback, every team has something to gain by acquiring one of the best players in N.F.L. history. Here is a look at what will happen if Manning takes his talents to your favorite team:

title: F.B.I. Director Warns Congress About Terrorist Hacking
description: WASHINGTON  A day after the authorities arrested several hackers from the Anonymous movement, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Robert S. Mueller III, warned members of Congress that terrorist groups might use hackers to attack the United States.

title: Franklin McMahon, Who Drew the News, Dies at 90
description: Franklin McMahon, an artist who defied journalisms preference for photographs to make a renowned career of drawing historic scenes in elegant, emphatic lines, died on Saturday in Lincolnshire, Ill. He was 90.

title: There Are Three Kinds of Apple Events
description: Ive gone to my fair share of Apple product events, and today I realized that they can all be divided into three kinds. Sometimes, you get all three, but generally you get only one or two at the same time.

description: In March, the villages of Barsana and Nandgaon in Uttar Pradesh are full of an unusual sight: crowds of men, cowering before women who are striking them with bamboo sticks.

description: Netflixs chief executive, Reed Hastings, has often compared his companys Web streaming service to HBO. That comparison is inching closer to reality.

description: Leticia Parra,a mother of five scraping by on income from her husbands sporadic construction jobs, relied onthe Planned Parenthood clinic in San Carlos, an impoverished town in South Texas,forbreast cancer screenings, free birth control pills and pap smearsfor cervical cancer.

title: An Update on New York Redistricting
description: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: Cuomo and G.O.P. Quiet So Far on Tuition Aid for Illegal Immigrants
description: ALBANY  With immigration still a contentious issue around the country, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Republican lawmakers have maintained a noticeable distance from New York State proposals that would make financial aid available to illegal immigrants at colleges and universities.

title: Laying Down His Hammer to Apply a Broom to a Troubled Union
description: When he was elected in December as the leader of the citys 25,000 unionized carpenters, Michael Bilello was helping to build the new PATH station at ground zero. After the election, he put down his tools  as they say in his trade  and went to Brooks Brothers, where he had once built a staircase, to buy a new suit. It was the only place I could find with the union label in the pocket, he said.

title: In Bonds, Bull Market for Firms
description: The Advance Auto Parts executives said the timing was right.

title: Rising Demand Eases Loss for New Jersey Home Builder
description: Hovnanian Enterprises, the largest home builder in New Jersey, reported a narrower first-quarter loss on Wednesday as it reduced write-downs and increased sales.

title: Yankees Amazed by Strongmans Feats
description: TAMPA, Fla.  What do rolling up a metal frying pan like a streudel or breaking a soda can in half have to do with baseball? Probably nothing, but they provided the Yankees with some entertainment and maybe even some motivational thought on Wednesday.

title: Babys Death Renews Debate Over a Circumcision Ritual
description: Prosecutors are investigating the death of a newborn boy who died in September after contracting herpes through a controversial practice of ritual circumcision, reviving a debate in New York over safety and religious freedom.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 7, 2012

title: In Video, Jury Hears Student Admit Posting on Roommate
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  For more than a week, jurors in the trial of a former Rutgers University student heard witnesses discuss a brief webcam feed in which he watched, from another room, while his roommate had a sexual encounter with another man.

title: Station to Oust Anchor, Ending Chuck and Sue
description: She was the local television anchor who fell off her chair, feigning boredom after a segment with Brian Williams. She was the one who scrunched up her face and wiggled her nose, imitating a groundhog on Groundhog Day. She was the one who cursed when her co-anchor missed a cue during a live promotional spot.

title: Number of U.S. Hate Groups Is Rising, Report Says
description: ATLANTA  Fed by antagonism toward President Obama, resentment toward changing racial demographics and the economic rift between rich and poor, the number of so-called hate groups and antigovernment organizations in the nation has continued to grow, according to a report released Wednesday by the Southern Poverty Law Center.

title: Troy... um, War ... You Know
description: Great armies are clashing on the stage of New York Theater Workshop. Sharpened spears fly through the air, tearing into flesh as they strike their targets. Swords clatter on shields, blood soaks the sand, and myriad souls are dispatched to the underworld. Above the fray the gods look on with studied interest, rushing to the aid of their favorites when peril threatens.

title: Liar Liar Pants on Fire
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Theres a Moral lapse, or a BROKEN PROMISE or four in todays puzzle, and gosh darn it (or words to that effect) if I didnt need help finding it. Ha ha, that wacky Bill Thompson; always hiding things on me. Maybe you noticed what he was doing right off the bat.

title: How Good Is the Housing News?
description: The housing market has shown signs of life recently. Home sales have beat expectations and pending sales neared a two-year high. But prices  the crucial measure of housing-market health  are still falling, driven down by increasing levels of distressed sales of foreclosed properties. That means the market, and the broader economy, which derives much of its strength from housing, are not out of the woods  not by a long shot.

title: At Airline, a Pensions Compromise
description: AMR Corporation, the parent of bankrupt American Airlines, pulled back on Wednesday from its previous threats to terminate all employee pension plans.

title: Settlement for the Gulf
description: The proposed multibillion-dollar settlement between BP and individuals and businesses hurt by the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is a welcome development. If a federal judge grants final approval, it could spare both plaintiffs and the company a lengthy legal battle with uncertain outcomes. It is also further evidence that BP is willing to pay serious money to atone for its errors. Now it needs to show a similar willingness to meet its obligations in pending suits aimed at assessing civil and possibly criminal penalties for environmental damages.

title: Harvard Encounters a Rare Subject
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In the last four months, the Harvard mens basketball team was ranked among the nations top 25 teams for the first time ever. It has been lauded as the springboard for the career of the N.B.A.s newest sensation, Jeremy Lin. And Tuesday night, for the first time since 1946, Harvard qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament by winning the Ivy League championship.

title: Counsel in Death Penalty Cases
description: The Supreme Court properly ruled this week that the legal standard federal courts should use in deciding if an indigent defendant in a death penalty case can get a new lawyer is whether replacing appointed counsel serves the interests of justice.

title: The I.R.S. Does Its Job
description: Taxpayers should be encouraged by complaints from Tea Party chapters applying for nonprofit tax status at being asked by the Internal Revenue Service to prove they are social welfare organizations and not the political activists they so obviously are.

title: Loss to Louisville Leaves Seton Hall in Jeopardy
description: It would have been somewhat poetic for Seton Hall Coach Kevin Willard to virtually secure his first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance Wednesday night by beating the man who gave him his start.

title: Grief and Love Among the Ruins in Japan
description: HONG KONG  It was a year ago this weekend that the earthquake and tsunami tore into Japan, and in those terrible first days my colleague in the Tokyo bureau, Martin Fackler, reached some of the most devastated towns and hamlets along the northeastern coast. Martin was alongside the first group of search teams that made their way through the muck and the debris, through the bodies and the grief.

title: Law on Condoms Threatens Tie Between Sex Films and Their Home
description: LOS ANGELES  Since the early days of X-rated films, this citys San Fernando Valley has been the industrys home. With year-round sun, access to Hollywood filmmaking expertise and beautiful young people flocking to the region from around the country, pornographic studios have filmed thousands of movies here each year.

title: Brooklyn School Coasts to State Quarterfinal Win
description: Before Wednesday nights quarterfinal game against Nazareth in the New York State Girls Catholic High School Athletic Association basketball tournament, St. John the Baptist Coach Ted Oberg said: Any team with the kind of physical talent that Nazareth possesses is always going to be a threat. If they are on their game, its lights out.

title: The Fairness of Hate Crime Laws
Knicks Fall in a Rout, Despite Anthony
description: SAN ANTONIO  The ball and the offense came back to Carmelo Anthony, as he had hoped, with open jump shots and isolation opportunities and the chance to shine. It helped him fill the box score but did nothing to reverse the Knicks untimely tailspin.

title: Nets Edge Clippers on Farmars Last-Second 3-Pointer
description: NEWARK  Jordan Farmar hit a 3-pointer from the wing with two-tenths of a second remaining Wednesday night to give the Nets a 101-100 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers at Prudential Center.

description: The slugfest between the Robot, the Rooster, the rascal and the renegade will drag on.

title: City Hall Still a Reach for Women in Mexico
description: CUERNAVACA, Mexico  The small-town party bosses told her to forget it. Her husband, too, scoffed at the idea as preposterous. And deep down, Mara Teresa Domnguez had her own doubts.

title: Romney Team Ponders How to Rise Above the Fray
description: BOSTON  Mitt Romney sought to reassure contributors, supporters and party leaders on Wednesday that his bid for the Republican presidential nomination remained on track, convening a daylong strategy session at his campaign headquarters here to recalibrate and elevate his candidacy above the tedium of fighting for delegates.

title: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Campaigns in Myanmar
description: The political dissident campaigns for a seat in Myanmars Parliament.

title: As Focused on San Jose
description: The Oakland Athletics reiterated that they hoped Major League Baseball would approve their plan to build a stadium in San Jose, Calif., and that moving there would not violate their territorial rights agreement with the San Francisco Giants.

title: M.L.S. Preview: Five Big Picture Items
description: Major League Soccers First Kick, to be followed by many thousands of kicks, comes Saturday evening in Canada, when the Montreal Impact plays its first game in its new league. This is the first post in the Goal blogs look ahead at the new season. Check back Thursday and Friday for more preview posts, including: five questions for Commissioner Don Garber; a status report on the five newest M.L.S. teams; suggestions for five M.L.S. players who deserve a look from Jurgen Klinsmann; and more.

title: Iran: U.N. Report Blasts Human Rights Offenses
description: A United Nations investigator of Irans human rights record castigated its government for what he called evidence of a striking pattern of violations of fundamental human rights guaranteed under international law. A 36-page report by the investigator, Ahmed Shaheed, a special rapporteur for the Human Rights Council, catalogued numerous examples, including violations of due process in the courts, illegal detentions, extensive accusations of torture of prisoners, and maltreatment of dissidents, minorities, journalists and women. The report praised Iran for omitting stoning as a form of capital punishment in its new penal code, but it faulted the country for its large number of executions, mostly in drug cases, which increased to at least 670 cases last year from 100 in 2003.

title: Romney Lags in Small Donors as Big Givers Hit Limits
description: Mitt Romney has more delegates, more money and more endorsements than any of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. But with a split verdict on Super Tuesday and no quick finish in sight, he is struggling to match the enthusiasm and money his rivals have harnessed from grass-roots donors.

title: Mayor of Ailing Detroit Resists Outside Takeover
description: With a team of experts preparing to recommend by the end of this month whether the state of Michigan should appoint an outside emergency manager to take over the dire finances of the city of Detroit, Mayor Dave Bing made a case on Wednesday night for letting the city fix itself.

title: Britain: Bill Aims at Human Rights Violators
description: A committee in the House of Commons on Wednesday unanimously called on the British government to introduce legislation that would seek to punish people linked to human rights abuses by denying them travel visas and freezing their financial assets. The proposed legislation is named for Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian lawyer, who died in prison after he was repeatedly denied care as his health deteriorated, prompting international criticism of Russias human rights record.

title: Armenians Are Shunning Song Contest in Azerbaijan
description: MOSCOW  The greatest cultural chasm evoked by Eurovision, the kitschy pop-song contest, might seem to lie between those who watch it and those who do not, but in fact, behind the boy bands, teenage heartthrobs, novelty acts and sequins lies real-world conflict.

title: Pat Robertson Says Marijuana Use Should be Legal
description: Of the many roles Pat Robertson has assumed over his five-decade-long career as an evangelical leader  including presidential candidate and provocative voice of the right wing  his newest guise may perhaps surprise his followers the most: marijuana legalization advocate.

title: Parking Rules for Purim
description: Because of Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Word of the Day | enterprising
description: enterprising \en-tr-pri-ziN\ adjective

title: Hospital Groups Will Get Bigger, Moodys Predicts
description: Responding to changes in health care, big hospital groups are expected to get even bigger. And some hospitals will join forces with once-unlikely partners, health insurers and for-profit companies, a new report says.

title: Super PAC Increasing Congresss Sense of Insecurity
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Jean Schmidt of Ohio never had it easy.

title: Corrections: March 8
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Shark Cartilage May Contain Toxin
description: Shark cartilage, which has been hyped as a cancer preventive and joint-health supplement, may contain a neurotoxin that has been linked with Alzheimers and Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: A Political Future for the Billionaires Sister?
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire, finished a distant third to Vladimir Putin in the presidential elections last Sunday, but he has already started forming a new party  and it seems clear he will continue to play a role as one of the few new figures on the Russian political scene as the opposition attempts to coalesce.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/08/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/08/2012

title: Obama Mines for Voters With High-Tech Tools
description: CHICAGO  With a chief scientist specializing in consumer behavior, an analytics department monitoring voter trends, and a squad of dozens huddled at computer screens editing video or writing code, the sprawling office complex inside One Prudential Plaza looks like a corporate research and development lab  Ping-Pong table and all.

title: President Pushes to Add More Credits for Hybrids
description: President Obama on Wednesday proposed sweetened tax incentives and subsidies to spur the market for alternative-power cars and trucks, promoting his all of the above energy strategy while warning against other politicians quick fixes to the latest spike in gasoline prices.

title: Kvitova Struggles for Wins in North America
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  For Petra Kvitova, the reigning Wimbledon champion, North America has hardly proved to be a land of opportunity.

title: Virginia: Pre-Abortion Ultrasound Mandate Enacted
description: Gov. Bob McDonnell signed a bill requiring a woman seeking an abortion to undergo an abdominal ultrasound first, making Virginia the eighth state to have such a requirement. Democrats and abortion rights groups criticized the legislation, which does not require the woman to look at the image, saying its effect will be to shame women. But abortion opponents say it offers the woman a chance to make a more informed decision. Mr. McDonnell softened the bill, making the requirement for an abdominal ultrasound, not a vaginal one.

title: New Hampshire: Bill Would End Requirement on Contraceptives Coverage Among Some Employers
description: The Republican-dominated State House passed a bill on Wednesday that would exempt employers with religious objections from having to cover contraception for employees. The bill would change a state law, passed in 1999, requiring insurance companies to cover contraception. The House speaker, William OBrien, sought such an exemption as a national debate erupted over a federal mandate for contraception coverage. The Senate is expected to take up the bill in April.

title: Ohio: Vatican Tells Bishop to Reopen Some Churches
description: The Vatican has ordered the bishop of Cleveland, Richard Lennon, to reopen 13 of the 50 parishes that he closed in 2010, according to advocates for the parishes. The decision was an unprecedented win for parishioners who have fought church closings across the country in recent years. Bishop Lennon, who previously oversaw the shuttering of parishes in Boston, can appeal the decision to the Vaticans highest court, the Apostolic Signatura. A spokesman said that the bishop was still reviewing the ruling.

title: Sheldon Moldoff, Batman Comic Book Artist, Dies at 91
description: Sheldon Moldoff, who drew some of the most recognizable superheroes of comic books golden age without receiving recognition in his own right until decades later, died on Feb. 29 near his home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 91.

title: News Quiz | March 8, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.Good luck!

title: Miles Under the Pacific, a Director Will Take On His Riskiest Project
description: As a boy, he used to squeeze his body into drainage pipes, snaking along to see how far he could go.

title: March 8, 1917 | Russias February Revolution Begins in St. Petersburg
description: On March 8, 1917, Russias February Revolution (so named because of the Julian calendar that Russians still used at the time) began with rioting and strikes in St. Petersburg (Petrograd). The unrest was triggered primarily by food shortages in the city, which were caused by the wider problems of a worsening economy and repeated failures on the battlefields of World War I.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 8, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Big Sky, Bright Sun and Melanoma.

title: The Republican Primary Map After Super Tuesday
description: WHO are the  four declared candidates for the Republican nomination who are still in the race?WHO do you predict will prevail to become the partys nominee in the presidential election?

description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Partners in Words, Pictures and Life
description: Before Fred Baldwin and Wendy Watriss became chroniclers of American rural life and inspired generations of photographers and scores of photo festivals around the world, there had to be a beginning.

title: What Are Your Favorite Junk Foods?
description: According to the Business section, the Oreo turned 100 this week. Meanwhile, over in the Dining section, one cook is trying to recreate the junk food of her past in her own kitchen. What are your favorite junk foods now? When you were a child? What good memories are associated with them? Be honest: How much junk food do you eat in general?

title: If Forced to Choose: Sanchez or Manning?
description: Which team among the contenders for Peyton Manning needs him most?

title: State of Indiana Tries to Make Education More Affordable By Limiting Credits
description: A new bill in Indiana, which passed Monday in the states House of Representatives, would set the college credits needed to graduate at a maximum of 120. If a university wanted more, it would have to petition Indianas Commission on Higher Education, The Associated Press reports.

title: Exclusive Preview: 'Friends With Kids'
description: Jennifer Westfeldt and Adam Scott in a scene from their new movie, in which they play friends who decide to have a baby together.

title: Jennifer Westfeldt and Jon Hamm Give Birth (to a Movie)
description: It was a bright Sunday morning, and sun was pouring through the 10 oversize windows of a former-candy-factory loft apartment. Jennifer Westfeldt  exuding a wholesome glamour in a floppy sweater and no makeup  was hamming it up with two adorable kids, whose skinny jeans and tousled hair marked them as perfectly on trend. She teased Georgia, 8, about a boy in her class. She compared notes with Caleb, 5, about some new animation. Then she tried to help Georgia squeeze into a too-small turtleneck, and the two of them seesawed, pushing and pulling until a head finally popped through, and they both collapsed in giggles.

title: California Team to Tackle the Sands of Baja in a 400-Horsepower E.V.
description: At its essence, the Baja 1000, a long-running off-road race on Mexicos Baja peninsula, is a wooly, slightly unhinged competition celebrating horsepower and torque. This year, a new vehicle class called Ultra Green will give the race an air, however subtle, of environmental stewardship.

title: The Early Word: Networks
description: In Todays Times:Brad Wenstrups surprise defeat of Representative Jean Schmidt in Ohios Republican primary on Tuesday with the aid of an anti-incumbent Super PAC was a warning to members of Congress about their uphill road to re-election, Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman write. The Campaign for Primary Accountability, the Super PAC that aided Mr. Wenstrup, is also targeting incumbents in House primaries in Alabama, Illinois and Texas.

title: Q&A: Counting Money and Minutes
description: Q.

title: BNP Paribas Sells Stake in Real Estate Firm for $2 Billion
description: The French bank BNP Paribas agreed on Thursday to sell a stake in a French real estate company for 1.5 billion euros ($2 billion) as part of the banks efforts to increase capital reserves.

title: Sod Off, Scotch
description: Twenty years ago, I was an undergrad smitten with Joyce, Wilde and Yeats. My plan was to spend that summer in Dublin studying Irish literature  and falling in love with a cozy, back-street pub, where Id settle in every evening to drink a few pints and tinker with the terrible poems in my notebook. Maybe Id meet a real Irish poet and fall for him too.

title: Umami Dearest
description: It may seem completely counterintuitive, but there is a strong connection between miso and Parmesan cheese. They are salty, complex products made from the most basic and elemental ingredients: milk, salt and bacteria in the case of Parmesan; soy, sometimes wheat or other grains, salt and bacteria in miso. Each makes use of surplus product and preserves the bounty almost indefinitely; each takes time to prepare correctly, and neither process is simple. The effort that goes into them creates intense, complex and uncommonly fine flavors of the umami family.

title: Last Dispatch From the Front (of the House)
description: My little corner of this blog is called the Start-Up Chronicle. And I have chronicled the start-up of a restaurant. From dogged inspectors to stray dogs in the kitchen, from 100 rules for servers to two P.R. firms that promised so much and delivered so little. Food and beverage were also discussed once in a while. Now that we are entering our second year in Bridgehampton and our second restaurant, in Brooklyn, the start-up is over. And so is the chronicle.

title: Weighing Risk and Reward on Peyton Manning
description: The Colts decision to release Peyton Manning has already been dissected a thousand different ways. So lets move to the next discussion point: What can Manning bring to the table and to which table should that be?

title: Central Banks Maintain European Rates
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday that emergency cash provided to financial institutions had had a powerful effect in helping steady the euro zone economy, allowing the central bank to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1 percent.

title: Late Declines Mar Best Year for BMW
description: FRANKFURT  Bayerische Motoren Werke, the German carmaker, said Thursday that its profit fell in the final quarter of 2011, marring what was the best year in its history.

title: Democracy and Its Malcontents
description: JOHANNESBURG  South Africas Constitution, which was adopted in 1996, has become a proud and ambitious blueprint for this new democracy. It lays out the three levels of government  local, provincial and national  and sets out how they interrelate. It codifies a Bill of Rights that includes not just political rights but also social and economic rights, like the rights to housing, education and health care. And it enshrines the principle of separation of powers.

title: Fascinated by Science, Why Dont We Study It?
description: LONDON  To judge from newspaper articles, book sales and TV schedules in Europe, there is a growing popular fascination with cutting-edge science and the unplumbed mysteries of quantum physics.

title: The Politics of Pandering in India
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Defeat is usually an orphan, but the election debacle of Congress, Indias ruling party, in Uttar Pradesh on Tuesday has a clear patrimony: pandering to the states 36 million Muslims.

title: Teachers' Morale Reaches 20-Year Low
On Our Radar: A Solar Storm
description: Colorful auroras? Grid or satellite disruptions? Scientists await the effects of a large solar storm headed toward Earth. It stands out because solar activity has been relatively weak in recent years. [Associated Press]

description: Fantasy and reality meet at the intersection of soccer and video games in FIFA Soccer 12s simulation of the 2012 M.L.S. season, which begins Saturday.

title: Bookshelf
description: All roads lead to Rome, but chief among them was the Via Appia, a storied path from the capital to the heel of Italy traveled by everyone from Cicero to Monty Python. Robert A. Kaster traces their footsteps in The Appian Way (University of Chicago Press, $23). In Desert Terroir (University of Texas Press, $25), Gary Paul Nabhan forages in the borderlands, where he connects dishes like capirotada, a Mexican bread pudding, to the Levantine cuisine of his Arab ancestors. High Street (V&A Publishing, $35) is a facsimile of a rare book, published in Britain in 1938, that included gorgeous woodcut illustrations of many shops of the day, from an oyster bar in the Strand to an undertaker who preferred to be called a funeral director (he said there are too many jokes about undertakers). Traveler of the Century (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30), the prize-winning Spanish novel by Andrs Neuman, is about an itinerant romantic who holes up between Saxony and Prussia, joins a local literary salon and falls for a minor noblewoman: delicious philosophical debates ensue.

title: What Makes a Mad Man Start Fires? An Interview With Matthew Weiner, Part 2
description: In the first installment of an interview with the Mad Men creator and show runner Matthew Weiner, who is the subject of an article in this weekends Arts & Leisure section, he disclosed that at the height of a tense contract renegotiation, he quit his own show.

title: Look Whos Predicting Doom for the N.C.A.A.
description: Coach Cal, thats who.

title: Trying to Train and Contain a Candidate
description: You just cant get good help anymore.

title: China Acts to Give Defendants Greater Rights
description: BEIJING  China moved on Thursday to enhance the rights of suspects and defendants in criminal cases, recommending that its handpicked national legislature adopt a series of Western-style safeguards in the most sweeping revisions to its criminal procedure code in 15 years.

title: A Band of Boy Wolves
description: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

title: How Would Santorum Do Without Gingrich?
description: One of the reasons to be skeptical that Rick Santorum could win the Republican nomination is that we now have a pretty good idea of how the vote will play out from state to state  and the coalition that he is building seems short of a majority.

description: From the editorial page

title: Syrian Official Says in Video He Is Joining Uprising
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a video statement denouncing what he called the brutal government of President Bashar al-Assad, a senior official in Syrias Oil Ministry announced on Thursday that he was switching to the opposition, in what appeared to be the highest-level defection of a government official since the start of the Syrian uprising nearly a year ago.

title: Greek Swap of Its Debt Appears to Be Secure
description: LONDON  Greece appeared to have clinched a landmark debt restructuring deal with its private sector lenders late Thursday. The deal would clear the way for the release of bailout funds from Europe and the International Monetary Fund that would save the country from default.

description: TOP STORIES

title: For Moroccans, Biennale Opened Some Secret Spaces
description: MARRAKESH  No one here can remember ever entering the cisterns beneath the ruins of Koutoubia, the great 12th-century mosque. So unlocking them as part of the 4th Arts Biennale of Marrakesh has created a buzz here, worthy, in the words of one visitor, of the opening of Ali Babas cave.

title: Stock Surge Reverses Trend in Wealth of U.S. Households
description: Household wealth in the United States, from October through December, climbed for the first time in three quarters as an increase in stock prices outstripped a decline in home values, the Federal Reserve said Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Apple Is Facing Warning on Book Prices
description: 1:55 p.m. | Updated Julie Bosman and Edward Wyatt of The New York Times report that the Justice Department, after months of investigation of pricing collusion between Apple and electronic book publishers, is talking with publishing companies about potential settlements and has been threatening a lawsuit.

description: Shares of the American International Group slid in early trading on Thursday after the Treasury Department said it would sell nearly 207 million shares at $29 a share.

description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Calvin Forbess Momma Said with a 2009 article about a mother giving her adult son a lesson on baking Irish soda bread  Nannys Recipe, Still in Demand.

title: Chief of Airbus Parent Warns on Government Meddling
description: PARIS  The departing chief of European Aeronautic Defense and Space urged European governments on Thursday to refrain from meddling in company affairs, pointing to robust earnings in 2011 and record jet orders at its Airbus unit as proof that national interests were being served by the groups recent turnaround.

title: Thursday Reading: The Value of a Road Map for Your Finances
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Two Mitt Romneys
description: I sometimes wish that Massachusetts Mitt were running for the Republican nomination. You know, the guy who supported the individual mandate, was not anti-abortion, and believed in global warming. Instead, we got Severely Conservative Mitt, who has dedicated himself to looking like the most right-wing candidate on stage, even if that means repudiating much of what he stood for previously.

description: Good morning. Today will be sunny, reaching as high as 65 degrees. Enjoy it because naturalists warn that this unusually warm winter may have a drawback (hint: its bugs).

title: A Not Quite So Dead End for the Mystery Cluster Bomb
description: The group effort to identify the mystery cluster bombs used in the war in Libya last year had to take a pause while I was at sea on another assignment, for a project in works on air power. But information continues to trickle in. Today, At War can catch you up and offer a fresh set of details.

title: Update: Another Source of Mirin for Cooking
description: In my Food Stuff column on Feb. 28, I wrote about mirin, the Japanese cooking wine, explaining how difficult it was to find any made without corn syrup and additives. I mentioned Takara brand, naturally sweet and additive free, which is sold at Sakaya, a sake store in the East Village.

title: What Theyre Saying About Messi and Apoel
description: Wednesday was one of the more remarkable days in Champions League history, with the incomparable Lionel Messi scoring five goals in Barcelonas 7-1 thrashing of Bayer Leverkusen and Apoel becoming the first Cypriot club to advance to the quarterfinals when it defeated Lyon on penalties.

title: Postcard from a Solar Rooftop
description: Billy Parish is a longtime contact from the network of young activists working to build an energy menu for America that works for the long haul. I first encountered him at the climate treaty talks in Montreal in 2005 and included his views in a piece on climate rhetoric and reality in 2006.

title: Fender Looks to Rock the Public Markets
description: Fender Musical Instruments, whose guitars have been plucked by the likes of the Beatles and other famed artists, is now aiming to rock a different stage: the public markets.

title: Leonard Joy, 81, Longtime Public Defender, Dies
description: Leonard F. Joy, who for more than two decades led New Yorks federal public defenders office, which represented some of the citys most infamous criminals, died on Sunday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 81.

title: Japan Looks Beyond Its Borders for Investors
description: AIZU-WAKAMATSU, Japan  Mayor Shohei Muroi knows it is a tough sell to get new companies to invest in this struggling industrial city just 60 miles from Japans most notorious nuclear plant.

title: Leading Off: The Classy Goodbye
description: For a little while, the ugliness in sports was put on pause. The heartless business side put away its calculators. Thoughts of the brutality of the Saints bounty system were shelved. There were no angry tantrums or posturing egos. For a little while, it was just Peyton Manning and Jim Irsay showing there is a right way for quarterback and franchise to part ways, with appreciation and tears, dignity and class.

title: Students Pay Calls to Education Panel Members, but No One Answers
Reactions to the New iPad
description: The reaction to the new Apple iPad was mixed. Enthusiasts who write about Apple on the Web always want more. But as Sam Grobart of The New York Times points out in Gadgetwise, this announcement is important for what is inside the iPad and it will be months before the full implications are seen.

title: Busy Busy Busy
description: My two actual paying jobs  writing columns and teaching courses  have gotten in the way of blogging. So a bit of radio silence until much later.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Hello, New iPad and Goodbye, Sue Simmons
description: Reed Hastings and other executives at Netflix have been in meetings with cable companies to discuss possible partnerships, Amy Chozick writes. If Netflix could get added to a monthly cable bill, that would put them squarely in competition with other premium services like HBO or video-on-demand. Partnering with a major cable operator would instantly increase the number of subscribers to Netflix, which currently has about 21.7 million streaming subscribers in the United States, according to the company.

title: Stage Scenes: Philip Seymour Hoffman
description: A look at some of the actors stage performances.

title: Searching for the Life of a Salesman
description: BEFORE most performances of the new Broadway revival of Death of a Salesman, as other cast members stretch in their dressing rooms, Philip Seymour Hoffman walks onto the stage of the Barrymore Theater and folds his barrel frame into a chair at the Loman family kitchen table. And there he sits for a half-hour or so on the purposely claustrophobic little set, preparing to become Willy Loman, that worn traveling salesman, proud father and husband, who is also the greatest tragic hero that American playwriting has produced. Sometimes Mr. Hoffman sips coffee and pages through the script, mentally tracing Willys journey into madness. Sometimes he talks with Linda Emond, the actress playing Willys wife, Linda, who also likes to visit the Loman home before curtain. And sometimes, not unlike Willy, he wanders back and forth across his own imagination.

title: Greyhound Races Face Extinction at the Hands of Casinos They Fostered
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  Not many people attend the races here at Bluffs Run Greyhound Park anymore. Aside from a few dozen aging diehards cheering the dogs from the shabby grandstand, the gambling-inclined prefer to take their chances amid the bright lights and constant action of the casino downstairs.

title: For a Declining Sport, a New Fight
description: Faced with a decline in profits, owners of greyhound tracks are pushing for legislation to cut the number of races while maintaining their other lucrative gambling operations.

title: The Peril of Online Invitations: Whos Invited?
description: Im all for online birthday invitations. What could be easier? One click to respond, a few more and its on the calendar. Easy-peasy, especially for a parent with a nice full box in the basement of suitable gifts for any birthday child. I have birthdays covered.

title: What the Deal Makers Are Talking About at Tulane
description: NEW ORLEANS  Deal makers across the country are gathering on Thursday at the annual Tulane mergers and acquisitions conference to discuss the state of deal-making. Whether or not you are here, I thought I would outline the big issues that are likely to be on peoples minds.

description: INDIANAPOLIS  Speaking here this week at the Green Truck Summit, an event held in conjunction with the Work Truck Show, Steven Chu, the head of the Energy Department, called on commercial fleet owners to consider converting their vehicles to run on natural gas, which he characterized as a no-brainer alternative to gasoline and diesel.

title: Same Position but Different Jobs for Two Point Guards
description: NEWARK  Chris Paul and Deron Williams each gave his team a chance to win Wednesday night. While the 101-100 victory was nice for the Nets, the game was a microcosm of two superstar point guards in vastly different situations.

title: That Fence Keeps Them Out, But Also Keeps Us In
description: LOCHIEL, Arizona  Fray Marcos de Niza, a Franciscan friar with a spade beard and black porkpie hat, was the first undocumented alien to enter what is now the United States. In 1539, he crossed at what became the settlement of Lochiel, Arizona. Early in the 1900s, Pancho Villa often raided Lochiel. And thats where I used to breeze into Mexico in the 1960s to visit the crumbling mud missions built by the conquistadors.

title: Japans Nuclear Energy Industry Nears Shutdown, at Least for Now
description: OHI, Japan  All but two of Japans 54 commercial reactors have gone offline since the nuclear disaster a year ago, after the earthquake and tsunami, and it is not clear when they can be restarted. With the last operating reactor scheduled to be idled as soon as next month, Japan  once one of the worlds leaders in atomic energy  will have at least temporarily shut down an industry that once generated a third of its electricity.

title: The Stuff of Life in Bitter Marginalia
description: It is a truism that academic arguments are so passionate because the stakes are so small. Footnote, a wonderful new film from the American-born Israeli director Joseph Cedar, at once affirms this conventional wisdom and calls it into question. The movies very title suggests that its concerns are marginal, esoteric, even trivial. A summary of the story  an abstract, as it might be called in a learned journal  would barely rise to the level of anecdote. A prestigious award, intended for one scholar, is mistakenly bestowed on another. Trouble ensues.

title: The Duel
description: The story thus far: In the tradition-bound old navy of the 1850s, little interest was devoted to building ironclad ships. Learning from their experiences in the Crimean War, the European naval powers drove to update their fleets, while Americas naval leaders, many with a half century of service or more, preferred to keep building wooden ships that had masts and rigging, even when they also had steam engines.

title: 36 Hours: Tallinn, Estonia
description: ESTONIA may be one of the smallest countries in Europe, but right now its 1.3 million citizens are among the continents most cheerful people. Last year the country celebrated 20 years of independence from Russia and dropped the kroon in favor of the euro, and its capital, Tallinn, was celebrated as a European Capital of Culture. Unlike many other places in Europe, unemployment is down, and theres a sense of optimism in the air, helped by companies like Skype that have their main offices here. And theres a full schedule of cultural highlights for 2012. The list includes many music festivals  this is, after all, the country that paved the way to independence with a Singing Revolution  and the premiere in May of a ballet at the Estonian National Opera, Modigliani, the Cursed Artist. Throughout Tallinn, remnants of the Soviet era are being repackaged as tourist attractions, while many of the citys chefs, inspired by the new Nordic movement, are busily creating a Baltic cuisine that takes traditional ingredients  from beet root to wild boar  and uses them in inventive ways. The Old Town still trades heavily on its medieval past but, throughout the city, a 21st-century vibe is becoming increasingly apparent.

description: Youre the surrogate charged with making decisions for an incapacitated loved one in the intensive care unit of a California hospital. Youve also agreed to be part of a study on how such decision-makers interpret information about how patients will fare.
