description: LONDON  The London Stock Exchange Group agreed on Friday to buy up to a 60 percent stake in LCH.Clearnet, an independent clearinghouse for financial transactions, for 463 million euros ($612 million).

title: Jobs Reports Offer Opportunities and Dangers for Obama and Rivals
description: The report on Friday morning that the private sector added 227,000 jobs in February provides President Obama a new opportunity to extend his slow political recovery.

title: Making a Leading Man, Many Movies at a Time
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Prediction Markets and Elections
description: Justin Wolfers, a University of Pennsylvania economics professor on leave at Princeton this year, has written frequently about prediction markets like Intrade. You can find research papers on the topic on his Web page and on the page of Eric Zitzewitz, a Dartmouth professor. The patterns in the data have made Professor Wolfers believe that these markets  where traders effectively bet on the outcome of real-world events  are a better guide to the future than experts are.

title: What the Creator of The Sopranos Taught the Creator of Mad Men
description: Theres no guaranteed way to create a hit television series, but it helps when youve trained with someone whos already done it. It worked for Matthew Weiner, the Mad Men creator, who was hired by David Chase, the creator and show runner of The Sopranos, to write for that influential HBO drama in its final seasons. The experience provided Mr. Weiner with crucial writing credits, and the lessons he learned from Mr. Chase continue to resonate in his work on Mad Men.

title: Help for College Students Who Are Illegal Immigrants
Tribe and Prejudice
description: LONDON  There is not a threat to Pakistan from Taliban ideology, Imran Khan, Pakistans former cricket captain and current political favorite, told The Guardian in a lengthy interview in Islamabad last week. Bad timing. That week also saw some of the worst atrocities committed against Pakistans religious minorities  the kind of sectarian violence more befitting of the hard-line regime in 1990s Afghanistan than of a modern democracy.

title: Opinion Report: N.Y.P.D. Surveillance
description: From the editorial page

title: King of the Dung Hill
description: In a boon to livestock farmers in Florida, diverse communities of dung beetles work to break down cow pies.

title: How Daunting Is Santorums Delegate Math?
description: Since Super Tuesday, Ive been reading a lot of coverage that ignores the challenges that the delegate count poses to Rick Santorum. Heres one quick test to see if you have a good sense for this stuff. Is Illinois a must-win state for Mr. Santorum?

title: U.S. Extends Its Run of Strong Job Growth Another Month
description: After a stretch of economic expansion so weak that Main Street struggled to detect any improvement, three consecutive months of solid employment growth have begun to lift the mood of consumers and the unemployed.

title: Tea Party Movement Takes the Long View
description: When it comes to inspiring Tea Party support, Mitt Romney often seems more burdened by his record than helped by it.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Greece Reaches a Landmark Deal With Creditors | Greece has sealed its debt restructuring deal with better-than-expected participation from private creditors, The New York Times reports.

title: Daily Report: Portrait of a Hacker
description: In The New York Times on Friday, N.R. Kleinfield and Somini Sengupta paint a portrait of Hector Xavier Monsegur, known on the Internet as Sabu. As a federal informant, Mr. Monsegur, 28, helped bring down a group of politically motivated hacktivists in Europe and the United States, who were indicted on Tuesday on computer crime charges.

title: The Perils and Promise of Free Agency
description: The funny thing about free agency is that everyone acknowledges that it begins with a frenzy of overspending and wishful, if not outright irrational, decision-making. Yet, every year, free agency somehow manages to once again begin with a frenzy of overspending and wishful, if not outright irrational, decision-making. Mistakes of the past are repeated enough to make George Santayana roll over in his grave.

title: Life on Moors
description: In the North of England, at the Western edge of Yorkshire, the accents are incomprehensibly thick, the ghosts are palpable, and the moors, dotted with sheep, seem to go on forever. Everywhere is the dry stone walling  assembled by hand with no mortar  that has lasted for centuries and defines field boundaries and ownership. This is the obdurate, timeless landscape that bred the celebrated Bront sisters and fertilized their singular literary imaginations, which have held readers spellbound since 1847, when their novels first appeared under male pseudonyms.

title: The Brick in the Wall Leaves a Gaping Hole
description: The batsman Rahul Dravid announced his retirement from international cricket on Friday afternoon at a news conference with the measured strokes and grace he was lauded for on the cricket field.

title: Top 10 Quarterbacks in Free Agency
description: Disclaimer: Remember,roughly 90 percent offree agents are free agents only because their last team didnt want them.

title: Fill-In | March Events in the News
HSBC Taps New Head of Global M.&A.
description: LONDON  Alain Renaud will take over as global head of mergers and acquisitions at HSBC, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Friday Reading: In Texas, a Bachelors Degree for $10,000
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
description: The United States recovery continued to show more fruits in the workplace in February, with the Labor Department reporting a net gain of 227,000 jobs for the month. It was the third straight month of gains exceeding 200,000  and in fact, the job growth for the previous two months was revised upward by a total of 61,000.

title: H.P. Attempts to Take On Amazons Cloud Service
description: Within two months, Hewlett-Packard will offer a large and powerful cloud computing service similar to Amazon Web Services, but with more business-oriented features, according the head of the project.

title: Creating a Sound Thats All His Own
description: George Braith has not taken a break since he first picked up the saxophone in seventh grade. When you stop playing, you lose something, he said. You got to keep it going.

title: Jobs Figures Keep Improving
description: 1:10 p.m. | Updated  to correct figures.

title: Leading Off: In College Sports, the Shadows Lurk
description: The problem with the bargain you make with yourself when you try to enjoy big-time college sports is, even in the midst of all the fun and pageantry at the best time of the year, the shadows keep closing in. Its possible to imagine this is all fun and innocence for about four minutes now. A buzzer sounds, the cheering fades and reality is soon storming the court and smashing all the illusions to pieces again.

title: What Were Reading
description: Insatiable Critic: Gael Greene realizes that her anonymity has been compromised at Empelln Cocina when the chef, Alex Stupak (above), sends out the bowl of chicharrones with a tumbler of tomatillo-caper salsa that comes unbidden. And suddenly, here comes the carrot salad that is black, muddy, silken and tangy  with, well, depths. Its like eating a Caravaggio, she writes.  Glenn Collins

title: Up Front
description: Douglas Coupland has a knack for making terms stick. He popularized Generation X. Ditto McJob. And in his review of Hari Kunzrus new novel, Gods Without Men, he may have done it again, by delineating an entire literary genre: Translit. (See his review for the definition.) Couplands innovations arent restricted to the written word, however. The author of 13 novels, a story collection and seven books of nonfiction, he is also a visual artist who has exhibited in North America, Europe and Asia. (His art is on display through March 11 at the Armory Show in New York.) Much of his work has examined the collision of technology with culture, body and spirit. Aliens didnt come down to Earth and give us technology, he said via e-mail. We invented it ourselves. Therefore it can never be alienating; it can only be an expression of our humanity.

title: Ambitious, but in a Polite Sort of Way
description: HERE is how the promising comedy career of Ed Helms almost didnt begin. As an ambitious Oberlin College undergraduate, he traveled on spring break to NBCs 30 Rockefeller Plaza headquarters to interview for an internship at Late Night With Conan OBrien.

title: Edible Selby | Inn Absentia
description: Forty or so miles north of Venice, on the slopes of Cartizze  prime prosecco country  is a charming stone house called Osteria Senz Oste. Depending on whom you ask, the name translates to Tavern Without Host or Bar Without Barkeep, and the place is exactly that. There for the taking are fresh bread, cheese, artisanal salami, chestnuts, cookies and many varieties of sparkling wine, all on the honor system  or, as the proprietor, Cesare De Stefani, phrases it, trust in the people. De Stefani, who produces the salami and prosecco nearby, asks that visitors simply leave money for what they eat and drink in a locked box on site. I thought how nice it could be for a tourist or friend to arrive here and discover my vineyard and the old house, he says, finding fresh prosecco wine to be tasted in the absence of the landlord.

title: In Ford Country, a New King Exerts Dominion
description: On Friday, Ford introduced the 2013 F-Series Super Duty Platinum pickup truck. As its name would suggest, the Platinum commands a premium price. In fact, the truck will be the most expensive model in the F-Series portfolio, surpassing even the $68,000 King Ranch Super Duty.

title: At Least Grover Norquist Is Consistent
description: Heres the strange thing about Republicans who take a hard line on illegal immigration  and who among them doesnt, these days? They profess to want smaller government that spends little, and yet demand all-out war on illegal immigrants through radically expanded police powers and blank-check spending on fences and troops at the border.

title: An Ambitious Chinese Party Chief Admits His Failure to Oversee an Aide
description: BEIJING  Jockeying to salvage his political career, the embattled Communist Party chief of Chongqing championed his success in running the central Chinese metropolis on Friday, even as he admitted failing to supervise a trusted aide who recently fled to an American consulate, causing a national sensation.

title: In India, Bank Moves To Stimulate Economy
description: MUMBAI, India  In a move meant to relieve growing stress in its financial system, Indias central bank on Friday sharply reduced the amount of money banks have to hold in reserve. The action came ahead of a scheduled policy meeting at which the bank was expected to cut the reserve ratio, but less sharply.

title: Mortgage Crisis Inspires Churches to Send Lenten Season Message to Banks
description: During the recent weeks of Lent, the Rev. Ryan Bell has led his Southern California congregation into the penitential spirit of the season. He has preached about the prophet Isaiahs admonition to loose the bonds of injustice. He has replaced his churchs ebullient praise songs with somber, reflective music. He has sent his members a list of ordinary comforts to give up until Easter, with suggestions from caffeine to Facebook.

title: Weekend TV Guide, March 9-11: Tracking U.S. Players
description: Major League Soccer returns to action this weekend, and one cannot help but notice that the league is approaching its 17th season with a bit of swagger. While TV ratings continue to disappoint, M.L.S. boasts a star-laden defending champion (the Los Angeles Galaxy), an ambitious new club (the Montreal Impact) and a television deal with a high-profile network that is looking to make some noise. M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber should be proud.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Facebook Founder Buys TNR and Google Channels Alka-Seltzer
description: The New Republic magazine, once described as the flight magazine of Air Force One, is being sold again, this time to Chris Hughes, a founder of Facebook who also ran President Obamas online campaign in 2008, write Brian Stelter and Michael de la Merced. Mr. Hughes will focus his energies on the tablet version of the magazine, which will continue its print version. Five to 10 years from now, if not sooner, the vast majority of The New Republic readers are likely to be reading it on a tablet, he said. Richard Just will remain the editor.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Hari Kunzru on his new novel, Gods Without Men; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Charles Duhigg discusses the science of habits; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Quest Software Agrees to Buyout
description: Quest Software, a provider of database applications and other corporate I.T. must-haves, said Friday that it had agreed to be taken private by a New York-based venture capital and private equity firm, Insight Venture Partners.

title: Image of the Day: March 9
The Kony Kerfuffle
description: DJIBOUTIThe only person Ive ever met who was in the Lords Resistance Army (L.R.A.) is a Ugandan man named Francis. He was abducted by the group sometime in the late 1990s, when he was a teenager, and forced to march from central Uganda to what is now South Sudan. During a firefight with the Ugandan national army, Francis escaped with his best friend. They had never spoken aloud. The L.R.A. enforced silence on marches.

title: Peter Marino Likes Playing Bad Cop
description: Youre one of the most-sought-after architects on the planet. You were brought up in Queens, but I cant quite place your accent. It sounds vaguely European. My parents spent a lot of money so I wouldnt sound like I came from Queens. I went to speech class.

title: The 2.26.12 Issue
description: EIGHT DAYS A WEEK

title: The Internship Rip-Off
description: I took an unpaid internship that I figured would give me experience and help me land somewhere in six months. Instead Im picking up coffee and dry cleaning and performing other tasks that the company would otherwise have to pay someone for. I know this is the status quo for internships, but it violates the law, and it feels deeply unethical. Taking legal recourse would hurt my career prospects. Is there anything I can demand of this company in exchange for my slave labor? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Why Is That Nice Girl From Friday Night Lights Fighting a Bunch of Ninjas?
description: A little while back, I went to the movies. There was a trailer for G.I. Joe: Retaliation, in which I saw Tyra Collette, the headstrong high schooler from Friday Night Lights, learning ninja moves. That was followed by a trailer for Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, during which I caught a mercifully brief glimpse of Stringer Bell from The Wire. And then the actual movie I came to see, Mission Impossible: Ghost Protocol, began, and there was Sawyer from Lost, walking briskly through a train terminal before being taken down by an assassins bullet. I cant believe they killed him off in the first scene! I whispered to my friend. Why? she asked. Who is that guy? I gave her a look of horror that was probably disproportionate to the situation, but I was shaken. Thats Sawyer, I gasped, from Lost! Hes one of ours.

title: Hot Tub, Ice Machine
description: The real challenge of Ouray is the mixed climbing competition: a treacherous route of ice and rock.

title: Who Made That Butterfly Chair?
description: The Hardoy chair, also known as the sling or butterfly chair, owes much of its renown as a midcentury Modernist icon to the perspicacious eye of a Rust Belt department-store scion, Edgar Kaufmann Jr. In 1940, three Argentine architects (members of an association known as Grupo Austral) presented the chair at a Buenos Aires exhibition. The design so impressed Kaufmann, then an industrial-design curator for the Museum of Modern Art, that he promptly imported one for his parents new weekend house, Frank Lloyd Wrights Fallingwater. He imported another for the museum too.

title: Last Fling of an Octogenarian
description: Where I grew up, there lived a man named David. He drove a Jaguar, spoke with a BBC accent and dressed only ever in a suit and tie. His air was patrician, which disguised  perhaps this was the point  the fact that as a child he was sent to England from South Africa by a wayward mother and brought up, modestly, by strangers.

title: Room and Boards
description: OWNER: Ryan Sheckler, 22

title: Morning Buzz, March 9: Trump Talks Football
description: Good morning. Not as pleasant as yesterday, today will be mostly cloudy with a high of 51 degrees.

title: Christian Vautier: Right-Bank Sweets on the Lower East Side
description: With chocolate, freshness counts. And its all but guaranteed at Christian Vautier Le Concept, a new boutique and cafe on the Lower East Side where truffles, chocolate-enrobed bonbons and other confections  including caramels, chocolate spreads, and fruit jellies  are made daily.

title: Identity Companies: Paid to Know About You
description: I was at the Montgomery & Co. investor conference in Los Angeles this week, where 186 promising start-ups present their businesses to over 1000 potential investors. The companies are private, so they dont give away too much financial information.

title: Seven Lean Years
description: OK, definitely a better jobs report than we have become used to. And terrific news for Obama; another six months of news like this and hell be in very good shape for reelection.

title: Im Honored
description: A correspondent tells me that Fox News has declared me a menace to society.

title: Lionel Richie to Enter Apollo Theater Hall of Fame, and Then, He Says, An Epidemic of Duets
description: In a week when Lionel Richie learns hes going to be inducted into the Apollo Theaters Legends Hall of Fame and is announced as a star of ABCs summer singing competition, Duets, we expected his excitement would have him dancing on the ceiling or partying all night long. But this former Commodores frontman-turned-solo singer-songwriter instead referred to another title in his smoother-than-smooth back catalog.

title: Open-Source A.W.S.: Creating a Thousand Clouds
description: Amazon Web Services, the cloud computing service of Amazon.com, has sparked a boom in powerful and flexible computing over the Internet. Now the same technology is entering the corporate mainstream, through open-source cloud computing.

title: Lineup Swap Wont Benefit Fields or Shumpert
description: When Linsanity struck in New York, the Knicks began floating on cloud nine. Good chemistry and an even better Cinderella story propelled the team to a successful February.

title: Lloyds Chief Eligible for Share Bonus
description: LONDON  Lloyds Banking Group, which is partly owned by the British government after a bailout, said Friday that its chief executive, Antnio Horta-Osrio, could be eligible for a share bonus of 3.35 million, or $5.3 million.

title: Table Talk | Ngams Model Chef
description: Hong Thaimees life as a former model was filled with designer clothes as she graced the pages of glossy society magazines and became the face of such brands as Pantene and Nescafe in her native Thailand. When Thaimee would slip into a dress by Lanvin, her favorite label, she would describe the experience as living in a fairly tale.

title: Marriages by Fran Drescher
description: The actress Fran Drescher is the officiant for two same-sex marriages at the Out NYC hotel in Manhattan.

title: Pint-Size Oliviers Tackling Big Themes
description: THE appeal of child actors is deceptively straightforward: They embody innocence or the shock of its loss. But the danger of overacting is ever present, as is the possibility that a child expected to act naturally may seem more stilted than an adult. Audiences can be sensitive about children cast in fraught situations and suspicious of sentimental ploys, no matter how noble the directorial intent.

title: On Our Radar: A Rare-Earths Merger
description: Molycorp, one of the Wests two main rare-earth metal mining companies, agrees to buy Neo Material Technologies, one of the worlds two main rare earth processing companies, for $1.3 billion. Rare earth metals are vital to making a range of high-tech products, including large wind turbines and electric cars, as well as oil refining. [The New York Times]

title: Still Dictating Orders, This Time at the Altar
description: UNTIL quite recently, Fran Drescher was known primarily for her comedic roles on television, including her latest in Happily Divorced, in which she plays a woman who learns that her husband is gay, divorces him, but then remains a close friend of the man.

title: Business Day Live | March 9, 2012
description: What new hiring means for the United States economy; keeping economic data secret before it is made public; and James B. Stewart on why Americans hate bailouts, even when they work.

title: Bookshelf: Poetry
description: Five new picture books introduce children to the art of poetry.

title: The Officiant Among Us
description: FOR generations, getting married meant solemnly standing before an authority figure charged with upholding the rules of civil society or religious traditions.

title: Bookshelf: Poetry
description: OUTSIDE YOUR WINDOW A First Book of Nature. By Nicola Davies. Illustrated by Mark Hearld. 108 pp. Candlewick Press. $19.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)

title: The Marriage Plot
description: When Elizabeth Weil and Dan Duane married in July 2000, they made a straightforward pact: no cheating, no dying. Other less dramatic problems might lie on the horizon, like money (both are writers) and religion (shes Jewish, hes not). Over time, neither of these issues created difficulties, but nine years and two daughters later Weil came up with the idea of improving their good marriage by undertaking a year of marital-skills improvement  a project she wrote about for The New York Times Magazine. Reluctantly, her husband agreed to the plan, even though both were aware of an old saying: If youre going to poke around the bushes, youd better be prepared to scare out some snakes.

title: Lost Generations
description: When an adviser to President Obama was quoted in The New Yorker as saying that the administrations policy in Libya was leading from behind, he initiated a season of hand-wringing about American decline, as if he had announced that the president was implementing a secret plan to make a second-rate country even worse. But whether America is leading from  or falling  behind affects more than our foreign policy. It also affects how it feels to be an American, which is a central concern of American novelists.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE HEMLOCK CUP: Socrates, Athens and the Search for the Good Life,  by Bettany Hughes (Vintage, $17.95.) Socrates, an enigma for 25 centuries, left no written legacy, and our knowledge of him comes mainly from three contemporaries  his pupils Plato and Xenophon, and the parodist Aristophanes. Hughes outlines Socrates by illuminating the world as he experienced it; the result is a multifaceted book that includes gritty details of daily life in Athens and a vivid history of the Peloponnesian War.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE STARBOARD SEA,  by Amber Dermont (St. Martins, $24.99.) Dermonts captivating debut novel, whose narrator is a boarding school student and a sailor, takes pleasure in the sea and in the exhilarating freedom of being young.

title: The Finer Points of the Game
description: Theres a lot more to playin ball than just playin ball. If youve spent time inside a hoops gym or run fives at the local street-ball hot spot, you get this. I dont think Im exaggerating when I say that pickup basketball, along with all the armchair philosophy that colors it, taught me the world.

title: Surviving the Season
description: Fifteen-year-old Willo was born after the onset of a new ice age that has left Europe in winters grip in S. D. Crocketts atmospheric first novel, After the Snow, a post-apocalyptic thriller for the post-global-warming era. A strong survivor, he lives with his family of stragglers in the hills outside the city. He wears a coat of hand-stitched skins and a dog skull as a fierce kind of hat, and when his family is taken away by the government, he goes out in search of them, following the voice of a dog inside his head. Traveling across a harsh, cold, snow-covered terrain filled with wild packs of dogs, Willo heads into the city, a bleak realm of starvation and violence. Along the way, he falls for a girl and discovers his family secrets, as well as the deep truth of who he is and where he belongs.

title: Cast Aside
description: Two and a half years ago, in the midst of the global swine flu pandemic, the Egyptian government of Hosni Mubarak had the ill-informed idea of protecting its citizens by slaughtering every pig in Cairo. Soldiers invaded sties kept by a group of Coptic Christians called the zabaleen and, amid howls of protest, butchered thousands of the animals. What the regime hadnt considered was that the swine fed off the tons of garbage gathered every day by the zabaleen  Arabic for trash collectors  who eke out a living by sorting and reselling recyclables. Without the pigs, the city was soon buried in waste.

title: Honest, Fair, Courageous and Strong
description: History is not simply what happened in the past; it is also what we choose to remember. That is why these four picture-book biographies  each portraying a spunky and clever, yet overlooked, heroine  are so welcome. Its such books as these that recall womens lives to our historical memory, and they make for terrifically entertaining reading, too.

title: Eminent Outlaws
description: To the Editor:

title: And Thats a Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Side of Paradise
description: Until about 30 years ago, most schoolchildren in Hawaii learned a version of the states history that went something like this: Christian missionaries came over in the early 1800s and handed the Hawaiians a single god, a written language and their very first muumuus. Later, American officials supported a group of well-intentioned gentlemen, many of them descendants of those missionaries, who replaced the monarchy with a democratic system. Eventually, the United States magnanimously annexed the tiny island republic. Sure, native Hawaiians gave the world entertaining things like the hula and surfboards. But really, they were the luckier ones, receiving the trifecta of monotheism, democracy and American appropriation.

title: Whispers in the Palace
description: Grigori Rasputin: faith healer, mad monk, priapic charlatan, resilient victim of assassination . . . and family man? Kathryn Harrison tackles all his identities in her new novel, Enchantments. This splendid and surprising book circles through time and around stories both real and imagined, lending a tender perspective to familiar historical events as experienced by two central characters  Rasputins daughter Maria, known as Masha, and Alyosha, the hemophiliac Romanov heir  whose physical and emotional suffering acutely remind us of the human lives behind the legends.

title: Making Plastic Credit Cards Smarter at SXSW
description: On Friday, people at the South by Southwest Interactive festival in Austin, Tex., will be among the first who are able to test a new way to make an old form of commerce a bit smarter.

title: Yankees Robertson Has Bone Bruise in Foot
description: 5:06 p.m. | Updated After four medical tests and experts poring over the results, David Robertson got the diagnosis he was hoping for Friday. Instead of something more sinister, Robertson has a bone bruise on the top of his right foot, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said, and he is not expected to miss significant time. Read the full article here.

title: Parental Quandary: Pregnant, With a Job Interview
description: Another reader wrote me with good news this week, in fact, two pieces of good news. S. is pregnant  and, after six months of freelancing while staying home with her toddler (and juggling to make financial ends meet), she just got an interview for a steadier gig.

title: World of His Fathers
description: Anthony Shadid, who died in February at the age of 43 while reporting the crisis in Syria, was one of the most intelligent, experienced and well-informed journalists covering the Middle East. In his writing, he showed a depth of intellectual inquiry and a skepticism toward conventional wisdom matched by few other correspondents.

title: M.L.S. Preview: Five Players With a Story to Write
description: The new M.L.S. season will be full of story lines, from a star-studded champion looking to defend its title to an expansion franchise looking to make a good first impression. But there will also be a host of players looking to atone, to impress, to improve. Heres a look at five who could write happy endings for their teams and themselves before the summer is out, and before the trophy is awarded.

title: Confident Men
description: Last fall saw the publication of Confidence Men, a headline-generating account of the first two years of economic policy making in the Obama White House by Ron Suskind, a leading inside-Washington writer. In The Escape Artists, Noam Scheiber, a senior editor at The New Republic, covers many of the same meetings, egos and behind-the-scenes debates. In both books, the president comes across as cerebral, well intentioned and initially nave  no match for obstructionist Republicans in Congress. Both authors portray Obamas former chief economic adviser, Lawrence Summers, as the quintessential turf-obsessed senior White House aide. Scheiber also shares Suskinds disappointment that the Obama administration did not act more aggressively to combat the economic crisis it inherited from George W. Bush.

title: Mystery Endures After Verdict Is In
description: Anatomy of a Murder

title: Between Semesters, Digital Innovation
description: ON a chilly February afternoon a line of people coiled around MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, and disappeared down the block. It was Super Bowl Sunday, but despite a smattering of Giants gear, the young-looking crowd had committed the day to From Scratch, a five-hour performance of continuous improvisation by Nicolas Jaar, an even younger-looking electronic musician and producer.

title: Marrying Up
description: Seventy-five years ago, Edward VIII swapped his kingdom for a divorce, the American-born Wallis Warfield Simpson. At this advanced date, could there possibly be anything new to add to the mountain of autobiographies, biographies, memoirs, novels and films that have accreted on this subject? The answer, surprisingly, is yes. In That Woman, Anne Sebba boldly recasts the relationship that was once considered the most romantic love story of the last century as a tale of gothic darkness with a Faustian pact at its core. The king, in Sebbas telling, emerges as a man who today might be looked on as something of a stalker.

title: A New Persian Empire Plants a Personal Flag
description: IN the beginning there was the word ... Persian.

title: From Parables to Pointillism
description: Anas Mitchell

title: Versions
description: If youre a poet outside the Anglophone world, and you manage to win the Nobel Prize, two things are likely to happen. First, your ascendancy will be questioned by fiction critics in a major English-language news publication. Second, there will be a fair amount of pushing and shoving among your translators (if you have any), as publishers attempt to capitalize on your 15 minutes of free media attention.

title: Cant Help Myself
description: Human consciousness, that wonderful ability to reflect, ponder and choose, is our greatest evolutionary achievement. But it is possible to have too much of a good thing, and fortunately we also have the ability to operate on automatic pilot, performing complex behaviors without any conscious thought at all. One way this happens is with lots of practice. Tasks that seem impossibly complex at first, like learning how to play the guitar, speak a foreign language or operate a new DVD player, become second nature after we perform those actions many times (well, maybe not the DVD player). If practice did not make perfect, William James said, nor habit economize the expense of nervous and muscular energy, he (we, that is) would therefore be in a sorry plight.

title: Standing Alone
description: Paul Grninger, a Swiss police commander, had a simple explanation for why he broke the law to help Jewish refugees flee Austria in 1938. His daughter remembered that he would repeat the words I could do nothing else. It is a humble answer, as if to say that anyone would have done the same.

title: El Paso Shareholders Approve Kinder Morgan Takeover
description: Casting aside the controversy, shareholders of the El Paso Corporation have approved Kinder Morgans bid, originally valued at $21.1 billion.

title: Strangers Abroad
description: Luxembourg sounds perfect for a spy looking for a nice dull place to retire to. As Chris Pavone dryly notes in his smartly executed first novel, THE EXPATS (Crown, $26), nobody dreams of living in Luxembourg. Nevertheless, a burned-out C.I.A. operative named Kate Moore grabs her chance to quit the agency and reinvent herself when one of the grand duchys secretive private banks hires her husband, Dexter, to redesign its electronic security systems.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: HISTORY OF A PLEASURE SEEKER By Richard Mason. Knopf, $25.95.

title: Rules for When the Chicks Return to the Nest
description: MY teenage sons are still in high school and middle school and, as is the norm, live at home. So perhaps its a little early for me to be writing about what rules to lay down if and when they move back after college.

title: Unemployment by Job Category
description: The national unemployment rate held steady at 8.3 percent in February, mainly because more people started  or resumed  looking for work. But depending on the industry, unemployment rates are all over the map.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Friday is National Meatball Day, and a number of restaurants are offering specials to celebrate. At Casa Nonna, 310 West 38th Street (Eighth Avenue), in the Garment District, an all-you-can-eat meatball special served with a side of pasta and a full carafe of wine is $35. Another Friday-only special is being served at Zero Otto Nove, 15 West 21st Street (between Fifth and Sixth Avenues), in the Flatiron District, offering a 10-ounce meatball that weighs as much as two baseballs, bathed in a tomato sauce and topped with goat cheese for $5. Through Sunday, Carmines, 2450 Broadway (West 91st Street), on the Upper West Side, will offer a complimentary order of six meatballs for every reservation of eight or more diners.

title: 2012 Mazda 3
description: With the new Skyactiv engine, the Mazda 3 is now the best performer in its class and has the best mileage, a pretty unbeatable combination.

title: Off the Charts: Relative Strength in U.S. Business Orders
description: According to a survey of manufacturers and service companies, United States companies are reporting stronger order flows than those in most other countries, while Germany is no longer reporting strong numbers, and orders are weakening sharply in some other members of the euro zone.

title: What Do Jonny Greenwood, Neil Young and Miles Davis Have in Common?
description: Alex Pappademass article on Jonny Greenwood in this weeks magazine  touches on the Radiohead guitarists work as a composer for films like There Will Be Blood and We Need To Talk About Kevin.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 21 to 30
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 21 to 30

title: Business Day Live: New Hiring
description: What new hiring means for the United States economy; keeping economic data secret before it is made public; and James B. Stewart on why Americans hate bailouts, even when they work.

title: An Outsider to Blind Passion Surveys Its Wrath
description: THERE is a fine line between mad love and pure madness. In The Deep Blue Sea Hester, the beautiful wife of a judge, falls hopelessly for a younger ex-fighter pilot who forgets her birthday, a slight that plunges her into suicidal despair. The film begins as she awakens from an unsuccessful act of desperation, and unfolds mostly over the course of a single day, exploring Hesters unraveling through flashbacks.

title: John Rosss Big Mistake
description: On March 22, 1862, John Ross, the principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, sent a hastily written letter to Brig. Gen. Albert Pike, the Confederacys representative in Indian Territory. Composed less than six months after Pike had negotiated an alliance between the Confederacy and the Cherokee Nation, Rosss letter underlined his fear that the Cherokee Nation was teetering on the edge of destruction.

title: When Love Conquers All, Even the Loss of Two Jobs
description: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | For two men in St. Louis, it seemed like a romantic way to spend their 20th anniversary: a weekend in New York, with a marriage ceremony in Central Park on Friday and a Broadway show, Priscilla: Queen of the Desert, on Saturday.

title: Whats Up? New Orders in the U.S., but Not in Most of Europe
description: BUSINESSES in the United States say that the level of new orders is continuing to rise, even as it weakens in most European countries.

title: More [Good] News about [Bad] Gestation Crates
description: Another significant victory in the fight to ban sow gestation crates: Compass Group USAwhose U.K. parent company is the largest food service company in the worldannounced that it plans to eliminate the crates from its U.S. pork supply chain by 2017.

title: Has the He-covery Become a She-covery?
description: The he-covery may be over.

title: No. 2 Official in S. Carolina Steps Down Over Charges
description: ATLANTA  The lieutenant governor of South Carolina, Ken Ard, resigned on Friday and pleaded guilty to criminal charges of spending campaign funds on personal expenses and fabricating donations.

title: L.A. Times Drops Restaurant Review Stars
description: Asserting that a star grading system was a bad fit for the Southern California dining scene, The Los Angeles Times announced on Thursday it would stop running stars with restaurant reviews. The paper said reviewers could not use stars to appropriately judge broad differences in dining choices, such as a food truck, a neighborhood ethnic restaurant, a one-time-only pop-up run by a famous chef, and a palace of fine dining.

title: Dynegy Bankruptcy Examiner Finds Fraudulent Transfer
description: The report from the court-appointed examiner in the Dynegy bankruptcy case is out, and its a bombshell.

title: Inside the List
description: OFF AND RUNNING: One recurring knock against Ernest Hemingway is that late in his career, he fell back on lazy imitations of the terse machismo that had made him famous. But any writer with a distinctive style runs the risk of self-parody. Consider Tom Wolfe, who used exclamation points and electric Kool-Aid prose to help reinvent journalism before moving on to Technicolor zeitgeisty novels like The Bonfire of the Vanities and A Man in Full. Wolfes new novel, Back to Blood, wont be released until this fall. But the books description on Amazon makes it sound like the sort of sprawling social novel that might have been churned out by a white-suited Tom Wolfe cyborg. Here it is: As a police launch speeds across Miamis Biscayne Bay  with officer Nestor Camacho on board  Tom Wolfe is off and running. Into the feverous landscape of the city, he introduces the Cuban mayor, the black police chief, a wanna-go-muckraking young journalist and his Yale-marinated editor; an Anglo sex-addiction psychiatrist and his Latina nurse by day, loin lock by night  until lately, the love of Nestors life; a refined and oh-so-light-skinned young woman from Haiti and her Creole-spouting, black-gang-banger-stylin little brother; a billionaire porn addict, crack dealers in the hoods, de-skilled conceptual artists at the Miami Art Basel Fair, spectators at the annual Biscayne Bay regatta looking only for that nights orgy, yenta-heavy ex-New Yorkers at an Active Adult condo and a nest of shady Russians.

title: Wes Anderson Film to Open Cannes Festival
description: 1960s New England will find a new home on the French Riviera: Wes Andersons Moonrise Kingdom will open the Cannes Film Festival in May, festival organizers announced on Friday. Mr. Andersons seventh feature, set in 1965, takes place on an island off the New England coast. With a cast that includes Bill Murray, Bruce Willis and Frances McDormand, its the story of a romance between a pair of precocious 12-year-olds who run away, presumably to somewhere really picturesque.

title: Toyota Recalls Nearly 700,000 Vehicles for Potential Brake Light and Air-Bag Failures
description: In an example of how small flaws can lead to big bills, Toyota announced this week that a trace of silicone grease and a steering-wheel flutter were behind two recalls covering nearly 700,000 vehicles, according to documents the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: 2012 Geneva Motor Show
description: While the vehicles featured at the show demonstrated the makers commitment to building greener cars, it was less certain that customers were ready to buy them.

title: The Get | Pomellatos New Pom Pom Pieces
description: Known for its decadent baubles, the Milanese jewelry house Pomellato is adding something new and improvisational to its couture Pom Pom collection this spring. Each piece embodies the freedom of creativity and is created around stones whose rarity, magnitude and irregular shapes render them unique, the C.E.O., Andrea Morante, says. These additions to Pom Pom  which was introduced in 2007  include 12 rings, 11 bracelets and 3 earrings set in a more daring way, one that breaks the rules of traditional fine jewelry, Morante says. Take, for example, the chandelier earrings, whose asymmetrical aquamarines are suspended almost haphazardly between pink sapphires and white diamonds, or the cocktail ring made of a cushion-cut red tourmaline bursting from a bed of flat, rose-cut diamonds. Each piece is one of a kind and timing is everything  the collection arrives at Bergdorf Goodman on March 15.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Drama Club Drama
Mitt Romney Likes Grits
description: Back in January Maureen Dowd observed that Mitt Romney has more than a little in common with George H.W. Bush. They share gee-whiz language, hokey humor, awkward stage presence, sense of entitlement and noblesse oblige. Michael D. Shear elaborated on that theme in the Caucus blog yesterday: As Mr. Bush tried to do, Mr. Romney is working to bridge two worlds inside the Republican Party: an establishment wing with which he feels comfortable and a rabble-rousing wing that has a big influence over policy and ideology.

title: Discovering Kohlrabi (Its a Vegetable)
description: Whats a kohlrabi? Before you start cooking with it, take our quick quiz to test your kohlrabi smarts.

title: How India Became America
description: Pondicherry, India

title: TimesCast | March 9, 2012
description: Dozens of youth activists win in Russia's municipal elections | Understanding hyperpolyglots, a community of people committed to learning dozens of languages.

title: The Frontrunner and His Rivals
description: Thispost-Super Tuesday analysisfrom NBCs First Read embodies everything I find exhausting and frustrating about the horse-race coverage of the Republican primary:

title: Franzen, Chabon and Lahiri Named to the American Academy of Arts and Letters
description: The writers Jonathan Franzen, Michael Chabon and Jhumpa Lahiri are among the new members named to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, The Associated Press reported. Other new members named to the group, which was founded in 1898 and is based in Upper Manhattan, include the artists Kara Walker and Lynda Benglis, the architect Elizabeth Diller, and the composers Stephen Jaffe and Tobias Picker. The new class will be officially welcomed to the 250-member society at a ceremony in May, where the artist Chuck Close will give an address.

title: The Enthusiast: Margin Call
description: This weeks Enthusiast comes from Chris Pavone, author of the new novel The Expats, a thriller about an American couple living in Luxembourg.

title: Would You Like Extra Ice, Sir?
description: In this YouTube video, a passenger on a recent Delta flight captured two unlikely seatmates in first class: a couple of penguins from Sea World. This is video proof that penguins CAN fly, wrote the poster.

title: For Woman Charged as Madam, Unusual Tie to Law Enforcement
description: A woman prosecutors say is a well-connected madam has boasted of ties to law enforcement as she ran a brothel from a building on the Upper East Side, even though no police officers or public officials have been charged with crimes in the case against her.

title: Some Dos and Donts About Leverage, Simply Put
description: I RECENTLY came across a report on the value of taking on some debt that was so simply worded and straightforward that I was startled. Those types of reports, typically, are anything but easy to understand. Theyre also usually trying to sell something that is complicated.

title: New N.C.A.A. Rules Wed Like to Break
description: With a new scandal, infraction or allegation coming out every two to three seconds in the college sports world, we thought it might be time to update and simplify the N.C.A.A. rulebook, especially as it pertains to student-athlete conduct.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bane and Doomsday Return
description: The 1990s were a glorious time for comic books, particularly at DC Comics: Superman was murdered by Doomsday, Batman had his spine shattered by Bane, and Wonder Woman ran around with biker shorts and a leather jacket. Two of the stories are revisited on the graphic books best-seller lists this week. At No. 5 on the hardcover list is Superman: Reign of Doomsday, which features the return of the foe who temporarily vanquished the Man of Steel. This time Superman has Superboy, Supergirl, Steel and other allies in his fight. At No. 4 on the paperback list is Batman Versus Bane, in which the villain, who temporarily put the Dark Knight in traction, returns to plague Gotham City. Bane is also one of the villains in this summers film Dark Knight Rises, the concluding chapter in the Batman trilogy directed by Christopher Nolan.

title: Fraud Found in Jobs Effort; Blow to Bloomberg
description: City investigators have discovered evidence of large-scale fraud in one of the agencies leading Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs signature initiative to find jobs for unemployed New Yorkers.

title: Pakistan Picks New Director for Spy Agency
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The prime minister of Pakistan appointed a new general to run the countrys most powerful intelligence agency on Friday, signaling an important change in the military leadership at a pivotal moment in relations with the United States.

title: An Impotent Outlaw in the American West
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Seedco Report March 2012
description: An Investigation charges one of New York Citys largest non-profit job placement agencies, systematically reported false placements to the citys Department of Small Business Services.

title: Israeli Airstrikes Kill Militants in Gaza
description: GAZA  Israeli airstrikes killed up to 10 Palestinians, most of them militants, in the Gaza Strip on Friday and early Saturday, and militants fired barrages of rockets at southern Israel in the worst cross-border fighting in months.

title: Book Review Podcast: Hari Kunzrus Searchers in the Desert
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Douglas Coupland reviews Hari Kunzrus fourth novel, Gods Without Men. The book focuses on a married couple and their 4-year-old autistic son who goes missing, but it also hops through time following several other characters and their relationships to a mysterious rock formation in the Mojave Desert. To describe the novel, Mr. Coupland coins the term Translit, which he explains like this:

title: Tim Speaks: Videos of a Young Polyglot Reaching Out to the World
description: A gallery of videos Timothy Doner recorded of himself speaking languages like Hindi, Pashto and modern Hebrew.

title: Adventures of a Teenage Polyglot
description: SOME people pick up a little Hebrew before their bar mitzvahs, or learn Spanish from their mothers, or can speak some Japanese from a semester abroad.

title: Adapting, Revising, Provoking
description: BROADWAY audiences have spoken. The Gershwins Porgy and Bess is a big hit at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where it opened in January. The run has been extended through September.

title: Early Exhilaration, With Flourishes
description: ALTHOUGH Carnegie Hall has made admirable strides in recent years, especially since it opened Zankel Hall in 2003, it has never been in the vanguard of the early-music movement. Until now.

title: Looking Back With Darkness And Insects
description: Mattituck, N.Y.

title: Real Fake Chicken
description: The Op-Ed columnist Mark Bittman visits a factory that is perfecting a new type of vegetarian substitute for chicken.

title: A Syrian Boys Grief on Page 1
description: Of the few photographers whove managed to make pictures inthe midst of Syrias violent uprising, Rodrigo Abd, who shoots for The Associated Press, has stood out.

title: Playing Charley in Death of a Salesman
description: The veteran stage actor Bill Camp talks about his performance in Arthur Millers classic play.

title: Charting the Stages of Teacher Data Report Grief
On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom colonial in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a five-bedroom colonial in East Freehold, N.J.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Greenwich Village co-op, a Bed-Stuy brownstone and an Upper West Side triplex.

title: Vanessa Mongeon and Chris Piccioni
description: AT the end of one of the roughest stretches of his life, Chris Piccioni was hardly on the prowl. He had lost custody of his children during a two-year divorce and had seen them move away with their mother to Los Angeles.

title: Guest Post | Teaching About Japan, One Year After the Disaster
description: (function($) {var data = {footer:{showFooter:false,button:{rightButtonText:"",leftButtonText:"",showButton:false},caption:""},images:{left:{leftImage:"http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/02/29/world/asia/lens-tsunami-then-now9/lens-tsunami-then-now9-custom1-v3.jpg",leftCredit:""},startPoint:241,right:{rightCredit:"",rightImage:"http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/02/29/world/asia/lens-tsunami-then-now9/lens-tsunami-then-now9-custom3.jpg"}}};var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper928 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container').css({marginLeft: 0,marginRight: 0});var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery);Toru Yamanaka, a photographer for Agence France-Presse, visited places in Japan destroyed by the March 2011 tsunami, photographing them from the same perspective that other photographers captured a year earlier. title: John Mayer Cancels His Tour
description: Four and a half months after undergoing surgery to remove a growth from his vocal cords, John Mayer said on his blog on Friday  that the condition had returned and he had no choice but to take an indefinite break from live performing.

title: TimesCast | Understanding Hyperpolyglots
description: March 9, 2012 - John Leland explores the growing virtual community of people committed to learning dozens of languages.

title: Caucus Click: Autograph Lines for Romney
Chris Christies Tough Talk
description: Chris Christie supporters almost invariably describe the governor of New Jersey as a tough talker and a straight shooter. His reputation is that of the non-politicians politician willing to level with the American public, to speak hard truths.

title: The Week Ahead
description: IF you like your entertainment blood chilling instead of heartwarming  and failed to succumb to the magnolia-scented charms of The Help  you might consider spending time with THE MAIDS, which opens on Thursday in a Red Bull Theater production. Like The Help, an Oscar nominee for best picture this year, The Maids considers the problems of sorely put-upon domestics, who are routinely humiliated by their affluent, self-centered employer. But because The Maids was written by Jean Genet, one of the most subversive dramatists ever, sentimentality doesnt figure in this coruscating one-act drama from 1947. The fire of homicidal rebellion glows in the hearts of the plays title characters (who were inspired by an infamous French murder case of 1933). And they do their darnedest to fan that spark into flame by acting out fantasies of their much-loathed mistresss destruction. Jesse Berger directs this in-the-round presentation of Genets identity-bending chef-doeuvre. Ana Reeder and Jeanine Seralles portray the sisters in servitude, while the wonderful J. Smith-Cameron (of televisions True Blood and the movie Margaret) is the eminently killable lady of the house. Through April 1, the Theater at St. Clements, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 325-3101, redbulltheater.com; $25 to $75.

title: Legislators Recall Governor Who Didnt Mingle
description: BOSTON  Well into Mitt Romneys tenure as governor of Massachusetts, a state legislator named Jay Kaufman developed a nagging suspicion: the governor had no idea who he was.

title: Former Times Executive Received $24 Million, According to Proxy Statement
description: Janet L. Robinsons total compensation package when she left The New York Times Company in December was about $24 million, according to the companys proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

title: Debt Insurance in Greece Must Pay Out, Ruling Says
description: Greeces debt restructuring will prompt payouts on credit-default swaps tied to the countrys government bonds.

title: TimesCast | Russia's Young Opposition
description: March 9, 2012 - Inspired by the recent growing protests against Vladimir Putin, hundreds of young Muscovites decided to run in municipal elections last weekend, and dozens won.

title: Officials Hinder Inquiry Into Afghan Air Force on Smuggling, Two Americans Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan defense officials are impeding an investigation into accusations that members of their air force are smuggling opium and weapons and that an Afghan officer who shot and killed eight American service members last year may have been involved in the suspected trafficking, two American officials said.

title: Remembering Video Music Box
description: Clips from the pioneering rap music television show include KRS-One and A Tribe Called Quest performing live and music videos by Public Enemy and MC Lyte.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $88,000,000
description: The sale of an $88 million penthouse at 15 Central Park West was entered into the city record books this week, enshrining it as both the most expensive transaction of the week and the highest price ever paid for a Manhattan apartment.

title: Failed Raid to Rescue Hostages in Nigeria Stirs Italys Anger
description: ROME  The failed attempt to rescue a Briton and an Italian who had been held hostage for months by an Islamist militant group in Nigeria set off diplomatic sparring on Friday, after Italian leaders complained that Britain had kept them in the dark about the raid, which left both hostages dead.

title: Grumbles for Britains Hurdler From Michigan
description: ISTANBUL  At this stage, it takes something remarkable for a woman to draw a bigger crowd than Sally Pearson of Australia at a hurdles event. But the sniping surrounding the nomination of the American-born hurdler Tiffany Porter as British team captain at the world indoor track and field championships was enough to do the trick.

title: After Backing a Dark Horse, Lins Agent Is Riding High
description: Of all the manifestations of Linsanity  the deployment of endless puns, the resolution of the MSG-Time Warner impasse that blacked out Jeremy Lins games, the array of Lin jerseys on Spike Lees person  one of the most telling might have been the sight of a man laughing inside a pharmacy near San Antonio last week.

title: Summers Urges Europeans Not to Neglect Growth
description: PARIS  Greece skirted disaster Friday with a landmark bond swap deal that clears the way for billions of euros in bailout funds. But, in the view of one of the worlds leading economists, who is also a former top policy maker, the fiscal straitjacket constructed by European leaders to avoid the need for a rerun of the Greek problems in other countries may create fresh issues in the euro zone.

title: Replacement for Klugman Also Bows Out of Twelve Angry Men
description: There have been a few substitutions, but the jury in the George Street Playhouses production of the courtroom drama Twelve Angry Men may finally be set. A few days after it was announced that he would replace Jack Klugman as Juror No. 9, David Canary has also withdrawn from that role.

title: One Crime Show Gains in Ratings, Another Falls
description: Two television dramas made moves in opposite directions Thursday night, with CBSs Person of Interest showing continued signs of emerging as a new crime hit for that crime-centric network, while the well-reviewed Awake on NBC, a more psychological crime drama, slid sharply in its second week on the air.

title: During Factory Visit, Obama Hails Jobs Report
description: PETERSBURG, Va.  President Obama is not claiming mission accomplished, but on Friday he hailed the latest monthly report of jobs growth by saying, Day by day, were restoring this economy from crisis.

title: Just Over the Fence
description: To the Editor: Re The Country Just Over the Fence (Feb. 26): You think Nogales built the fence? The only point you have correct is that it looks like the Berlin Wall, and for the United States, a country that prided itself on being a melting pot and helping to bring down the wall in Berlin, how eerie that we turned around and built one of our own.

title: Job Strength in Health Care and Energy
description: If there are two areas of domestic policy where the Republicans are particularly critical of the Obama administration, they are health care and energy.

title: Brains of Bee Scouts Are Wired for Adventure
description: Some honeybees are known to be thrill-seeking adventurers  the David Blaines of their hive, so to speak. Known as scouts, they fearlessly leave their hives and search for new sources of food and new hive locations for the rest of the colony.

title: Coppolas Italy for Guests, Not Moviegoers
description: BESIDES being a filmmaker and a winemaker, Francis Ford Coppola has owned hotels and resorts since the 1980s. With his latest, Palazzo Margherita, palazzomargherita.com, in Bernalda, Italy, he now owns five properties. His first, the Blancaneaux Lodge in Belize, was a result of his developing an affinity for the jungle, as people do, he said, while filming Apocalypse Now in the Philippines 35 years ago.

title: Obama Names Technology Adviser
description: President Obama has appointed Todd Park to be his top technology adviser, the White House announced on Friday.

title: New Chapter for Berlin School
description: HUNDREDS of revelers packed a cavernous auditorium in Berlin last month to hear the French singer and actress Charlotte Gainsbourg in concert for a magazine party on the eve of the Berlin film festival. Jake Gyllenhaal and Naomi Campbell were among the guests. After it ended, Andy Warhol paintings and a Frank Stella sculpture were installed as part of a gallery that opened the next day. Two restaurants and a photography gallery were also unveiled, setting the space well on its way to becoming Berlins latest cultural hot spot.

title: The Mets Are Born
description: The Mets played their first-ever spring training game 50 years ago on March 10, 1962.

title: Hotel Review: DoubleTree by Hilton in Amsterdam
description: THE UPSHOT

title: A Chicken Without Guilt
description: IT is pretty well established that animals are capable of suffering; weve come a long way since Descartes famously compared them to nonfeeling machines put on earth to serve man. (Rousseau later countered this, saying that animals shared some measure of human nature and should partake of natural right.) No matter where you stand on this spectrum, you probably agree that its a noble goal to reduce the level of the suffering of animals raised for meat in industrial conditions.

title: Proof That Theres Fun After 40 Miles Per Gallon
description: ASK the hipster waiting in line for a new iPad. Buyers and critics alike are easily seduced  sometimes too easily  by the new.

title: Qaeda Media Arm Steps Up Local Coverage in Yemen
description: Once the source of English-language militant propaganda aimed at a global audience, the media arm of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has been increasing its output of videos in recent weeks in an apparent effort to win local supporters in Yemen, where Qaeda militants control a small area of the south.

title: Enzo Ferraris Legacy Comes Home
description: MODENA, Italy

title: Looking for a Ray of Light in Europes Clouds of Gloom
description: GENEVA

title: A Champions Take on Racing Safety
description: AS the auto racing season begins, there are ample reminders that drivers, like other professionals, sometimes make career changes.

title: Retailers Add Gadgets for Shoppers at Ease With Technology
description: When Nadia Karim goes shopping, she doesnt wait around for salespeople. She saves items from apps and Web sites on her cellphone as a shopping list. And as she browses one store  recently trying on Sam Edelman flats at Nordstrom  she uses the phone to check out styles at competitors like Macys.

title: Welcome Racing Fans!
description: The 2012 Formula One season takes off in Melbourne next weekend, with the Australian Grand Prix, and the IHT has published its preview. But the big news for readers of this site is that the Formula One blog, the first ever by a regular F1 correspondent, started back in 2006, has now moved to a new home, with a broader mission.

title: Kansas Offers Santorum Chance for Big Delegate Grab
description: Its winner-take-all, sort of, in Kansas caucuses on Saturday.

title: The Uncertain Cost of Helping Illegal Immigrants Go to College
description: Much of the public debate surrounding proposals to allow illegal immigrants to receive state financial aid for college has centered on questions of legality: Would such legislation legitimize the status of people in the country without authorization?

title: The Web Is Awash in Reviews, but Not for Doctors. Heres Why.
description: For all the debate about which Web sites have the best model for reliable reviews  paid or unpaid, anonymous or real name, Angies List or Yelp or TripAdvisor  one thing is certain: a robust ecosystem exists online for restaurant and hotel reviews that has changed those industries for the better.

title: For a Shell Executive, Much Head-Scratching
description: Europe is generally considered greener than the United States, but its oil executives certainly share American oil executives enthusiasm for drilling.

title: Illinois Needs Another Help Wanted Ad After Firing Weber
description: Illinois Coach Bruce Weber has been on the way out for about half of this college basketball season, which is what a 2-12 slide to end a season will do, so Fridays actual firing of Weber came as a bit of mercy for the embattled coach. Athletic Director Mike Thomas certainly did not need much time to think about things after the final straw, the Ilinis loss to Iowa Thursday in the first round of the Big Ten tournament.

title: More Than an Onion Understudy
description: Leeks are a key ingredient in this weeks City Kitchen recipe. Though readily available, they dont necessarily end up in everybodys shopping basket. We think of them as a stand-in for onions, but they really are so much more.

title: Outside Las Vegas, an Ace of a Bike Trail
description: AS the desert sun neared its apex and Lake Mead glittered against the brown desert, the water break I was taking on Nevadas newest bike trail was interrupted by a couple of fellow riders.

title: Consumer Protection Bureau Opens Student Loan Complaint System
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau announced on Monday that it had opened a student loan complaint system for issues regarding student loans. The system was put in place for students to voice their issues with lenders.

title: Why Job Growth Is Likely to Slow
description: If you looked only at the monthly jobs report, you could start getting pretty optimistic about the American economy. The largest, broadest survey of employment  a survey of businesses  shows the best job growth in more than five years over the last 12 months, with the pace mostly accelerating in recent months. The other survey that the Labor Department does  of households  shows even faster job growth, suggesting that the business survey may be understating the economys strength.

title: Maryland Womens Lacrosse Defend Home Streak Against Syracuse
description: This weekends game against No. 4 Syracuse would not seem to be a huge challenge for No. 2 Maryland in their womens lacrosse matchup. The Terrapins are 11-0 all time against the Orange and are playing at home, where they are carrying a 36-game home winning streak, the fifth best in all of Division I sports.

title: In Geneva, Surveying the Motor Shows Pricey, and Priceless, Playthings
description: The Geneva motor show is not a sensible-shoes affair. It is the de facto home show for many makers of rarified, ultrahigh-performance automobiles. Jerry Garrett, who covered the press-preview days of the shows 82nd iteration, photographed a number of these cars, some of which were, and may forever remain, concepts. A selection appears below.

title: Your Reviews of the Physician Review Web Sites
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I tried to figure out why it has taken so long for physician review Web sites to truly take hold. Yelp has reviews of nearly every restaurant in most major cities, and TripAdvisor has hotels pretty well covered. So why is there a lack of advice on which doctor to choose?

title: Origin of Country
description: Saturday night. Were cruising up North Chester on our way to a Basque feast at Noriegas, when something catches our eye across the median. Bryce hangs a U-ie so we can get to the source: a makeshift church in an empty warehouse. Sinners Welcome reads the gothic script banner hung on a rolled up metal grate, and a young man with a shaved head and vacant eyes asks if we know the Lord. Bryce and I nod reflexively. Inside, past rows of folding chairs, another man is at the lectern, trying to strangle salvation out of an electric guitar. Its not pretty, though maybe it isnt supposed to be. A few yards away, on the sidewalk, three teenage girls furiously suck on cigarettes, like there are nutrients or redemption in them. A heavyset woman on a scooter motors toward us.

title: An Interview With Carlos Miele
description: The Brazilian fashion designer talks about his background as an artist, bringing Brazilian culture to the catwalk and the future of his brand.

title: Week in Pictures for March 9
description: Subjects include a dispute over a winning lottery ticket, and a replica of Michelangelos David making its way into Manhattan.

title: Winter Park, Fla.: An Old-Time Resort Looks Ahead
description: A sophisticated Disney neighbor, but without the lines.

title: Pictures of the Day: The West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the West Bank, Syria, Nigeria and India.

title: Evitas Buenos Aires
description: Sixty years after her death, Eva Perns legacy continues to spread throughout this city.

title: When Debating the Auto Bailout, Consider Lehmans Fate
description: Would Americans be better off if General Motors and Chrysler had simply gone bankrupt, without benefit of taxpayer assistance?

title: Norman St. John-Stevas, Dapper Tory Dismissed by Thatcher, Dies at 82
description: LONDON  Norman St. John-Stevas, a Conservative politician who coupled a dandified manner with keen intellectual and aesthetic sensibilities, and who presented a ready target for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when she began culling left-leaning Tory dissidents from her cabinet in the early 1980s, died on March 2 at his home here. He was 82.

title: Extended Race Could Pose Financial Challenges for Romney
description: The ticking sound you hear in the background of the Republican presidential primary is the fund-raising clock.

title: Restaurant Review: The Room Palma, Palma, Majorca
description: There was a time when the Santa Catalina neighborhood of Palma, on the Mediterranean island of Majorca, bustled mostly by day. The market that gives the barrio its name, which opens at dawn, was packed with fishermen, bakers and vegetable mongers. But at night the streets were mostly dead. In recent years, though, farm- and sea-to-table restaurants have begun popping up in the streets that fan out from the market and theyre drawing crowds.

title: Clyde Fraziers: A Hoops Stars Home Court
description: At Clyde Fraziers Wine and Dine, the name is only the beginning of the homage to Walt Clyde Frazier, the former New York Knicks guard-turned-sportscaster. The new restaurant, bar and lounge on the West Side of Manhattan has a wood-paneled room with a hoop and regulation foul line that diners will be able to use.

title: Where Heaven and Earth Come Closer
description: TRAVEL, like life, is best understood backward but must be experienced forward, to paraphrase Kierkegaard. After decades of wandering, only now does a pattern emerge. Im drawn to places that beguile and inspire, sedate and stir, places where, for a few blissful moments I loosen my death grip on life, and can breathe again. It turns out these destinations have a name: thin places.

title: Cabbage Flexes Its Muscles Three Ways
description: GREEN cabbage is not one of the sexier seasonal vegetables. Lacking the ruffled charm of kale or the dappled appeal of delicata squash, it is a pale, stalwart presence at the farmers market, there all winter long and ready when you want it  if you ever do.

title: From the Everyday, the Extraordinary
description: There are many words to describe the performance style of Jodi Melnick, but needy isnt one of them. Martha Graham used to say that the center of the stage was wherever she was; the same is true of Ms. Melnick. Somewhere deep in the bones of this choreographer and dancer lies a laudable power to take ordinary gestures and give them opulence. One by one, movements disappear and re-form, like a stop-motion animation.

title: Ode to Cabbage
description: There is more to cabbage than cole slaw or soup. Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make pasta with caramelized cabbage.

title: Evitas Buenos Aires
description: EVERY city has its heroes  people who, for whatever reason, leave an indelible mark. Washington is awash in monuments to past presidents. New Yorkers work and live in a grid of ancestral icons: Rockefeller Center, Peter Cooper Village, Astor Place. And Paris is studded with plaques honoring luminaries from Joan of Arc to Victor Hugo to Edith Piaf.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google Slows Book Scanning and a Grim Twitter Picture
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: Nymph Out of Water, Disturbing the Peace of City Dwellers
description: BRUSSELS  The first act of Stefan Herheims production of Dvoraks Rusalka takes place not in the librettos idyllic forest clearing but in an anonymous European city. Lights flicker behind the curtains of the apartments overlooking a quiet square, as people watch television.

title: Peer Pressure? How About, Like, Fighting to Death?
description: HERES a pop math quiz: The Hunger Games, a best-selling novel by Suzanne Collins about children killing children, is recommended for readers 12 and older. The Hunger Games movie, which shows kids killing kids, is angling for a PG-13 rating when it hits theaters March 23. To complicate matters, many readers under the age of 12 are dying to see the movie. Meanwhile, Jennifer Lawrence, the films star, is 21. She got the book at the behest of her mother, a reader and fan.

title: Parent Un-Trapped | Lets Hear It for the Boys
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: African Critics of Kony Campaign See a White Mans Burden for the Facebook Generation
description: Updated | Saturday | 12:13 p.m. As my colleagues David Goodman and Jennifer Preston explain, a viral marketing campaign to raise awareness of the suffering inflicted on African children by the warlord Joseph Kony has dominated social media conversations this week, despite concerns that the young Americans behind it might be spreading factual inaccuracies and wasting donors money.

title: Capitalizing on Cabbage
description: This weeks column is about using cabbage three distinct ways to bring out different aspects of the vegetable. I made a crunchy raw slaw with Vietnamese flavors, a caramelized cabbage and penne dish inspired by cucina povera, and a potato-leek soup variation in which cabbage adds a soft sweetness to the mix.

title: Robertsons Diagnosis Comforts the Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After four medical tests and after several experts pored over the results, David Robertson got the diagnosis he was hoping for Friday. Instead of something more sinister, Robertson has a bone bruise on the top of his right foot, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said, and he is not expected to miss significant time.

title: Romera Is Said to Be Closing
description: Romera New York, the temple of neuro-gastronomy that drew curious diners and corrosive reviews, is closing at the end of Saturday, just a half-year after opening, Eater reports.

title: At the Enzo Ferrari Museum, Housing 2 Legacies
description: As Eric Sylvers writes in Sundays Automobiles section, the Enzo Ferrari Birthplace Museum opens this weekend in Modena, Italy. Built next to the home where the founder of Ferrari was born, the museum was the last work of the star architect Jan Kaplicky.

title: Photo Replay: March 9
description: The day in sports included the world indoor track championships in Istanbul and World Cup skiing in Sweden.

title: Taking a Softly, Softly Tack at Londons Night of the Stars
description: The Night of the Stars charity game at the Wimbledon Bridge Club in London last month featured a Whos Who of British bridge stars. In addition Fulvio Fantoni, a professional bridge player, flew in with his wife, Iolanda, at his own expense.

title: Giants Release Jacobs in Money-Saving Move
description: After seven seasons and two championships, Brandon Jacobs is no longer a Giant.

title: Changing Attitudes Toward Debt
description: After the last few years, when the economy went through the depths of a recession, debt seems to have become a bad thing. After all, consumers took on too much debt  through credit cards and mortgages, mainly  in the years leading up to the recession. Banks were too free in lending them money. And now, with unemployment still high, a lot of college students who took out huge loans are having trouble keeping up with the payments.

title: What to See at SXSW?
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A Bob Marley doc? A martial arts thriller? A few feral children? Now is that moment before the film portion of the South by Southwest festival begins and audiences are sussing out what to tackle in this years robust program. Currently the longest line at the festival is for registration, but soon lines will form at several of the screening sites, including the historic Paramount theater, where the opening-night film, Drew Goddard and Joss Whedons Cabin in the Woods, will be shown.

title: Romney Releases His Playlist
description: The 19-song playlist released Friday by Mitt Romney on Facebook, called On the Road, has surely been vetted by his campaign to make his image a little more down-home.

title: Louis C.K. Withdraws as Host of Radio and Television Correspondents Dinner
description: The comedian Louis C.K. has withdrawn from his role as the host of a dinner for the Radio and Television Correspondents Association in Washington, a press representative for the comedian said on Friday.

title: A Love Story Naturally, Without Microphones
description: The Dicapo Opera Theaters delightful production of The Most Happy Fella, Frank Loessers tender, tough and melodically soaring 1956 work, boasts something no musical currently on Broadway can offer: natural sound.

title: Two Novelists Take on the Haggadah
description: AFTER a lengthy interview with President Obama in the Oval Office two weeks ago, Jeffrey Goldberg, a national correspondent for The Atlantic, had one more question, and it had nothing to do with Iran.

title: Airy Parcel, Hearty Flavors
description: A SOUFFL from mashed potatoes might sound like a contradiction in terms at first: Souffls are light. Mashed potatoes? Not so much. But the two textures can complement each other, resulting in a dish that tastes light but has an underlying heartiness.

title: Memory, in All Its Elusiveness and Ability to Shock
description: Were it just another weak and underwritten play, Flight might be easy to dismiss. Yet because it trafficks in unearned emotions by exploiting the Holocaust, Alzheimers disease and dementia, the story treads close to being objectionable as well as ineffective.

title: Leek and Potato Souffl With Ham and Fontina
description: Time: About 1 hour

title: Name Calling: Philosophy as Ontical Science
description: This is a response from the author to readers who commented on his previous essay for The Stone, Philosophy by Another Name.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 9
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Near Orlando, Fla., a Sophisticated Alternative to Disney
description: BESIDES the parts of town within the magical world of Disney, one of the most pedestrian-friendly neighborhoods in the Orlando, Fla., area is Winter Park, a brick-street enclave just northeast of downtown.
