Though businesses there have historically catered to the 9-iron set  in the late 1800s, it became the states first planned community and earned status as one of the more popular resort towns of that era  forward-thinking shops and restaurants have started appearing along the two main thoroughfares, Park Avenue and New England Avenue. With them arrives a fresh, design-centric energy that comes close to rivaling anything youll find at Disney, but without the long lines and crowds. Click the slide show for photos from Winter Park.

title: The Birds of Block Island
description: The photographer Katherine Wolkoff is known for her silhouettes of the human figure, including the ones featured in a recent cover story for the magazine.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 9
description: More Photographs

title: Up and Over One of the Three Sisters
description: Follow Matt Villano along one of the hardest hills on the River Mountains Trail.

title: Out at Sea, Relaxing in the Philippines
description: WE were floating gingerly over a forest of antler-shaped coral when I heard a Swede who was snorkeling with me shout. I popped my head above water and caught only a fragment of his declaration in the slosh of waves: Monster in a hole.

title: An Aimless Sailing Trip Off Palawan
description: Cutting anchor from civilization and all its modern amenities by exploring some of the most remote islands in the Philippines.

title: White Trumps Black in Urban Cool Contest
description: One hundred seventy degrees Fahrenheit is the approximate temperature to which chicken should be cooked. Its also the temperature that was recorded on some asphalt roofs in New York City last July during a heat wave that set a record for electricity use.

title: Nuclear Disaster in Japan Was Avoidable, Critics Contend
description: TOKYO  A year after a huge earthquake and tsunami caused nearly catastrophic meltdowns at a nuclear plant, Japan is still grappling with a crucial question: was the accident simply the result of an unforeseeable natural disaster or something that could have been prevented?

title: Perry Jones III Gets His Postseason
description: A year ago, the magazine published my cover story on Perry Jones III, then a freshman basketball star at Baylor University and a top N.B.A. prospect. That same week, the N.C.A.A. announced that it was suspending him for receiving improper benefits  primarily, modest sums of money lent by his summer-league coach to his mother so his impoverished family could stay in its home. Jones was not even aware of the loans, which had been paid back.

title: A Memorable Ride
description: The children of Soul Train, glued to the TV Saturday mornings, reminisce about what the show  its music, its fashion, its spirit  meant to them growing up.

title: Reviewing the Mazda 3
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Mazda 3, the first car from the automaker to be sold in the United States with Mazdas Skyactiv suite of efficiency-bolstering technologies.

title: Midair Surprises, and Other Special Effects
description: There is a distinguishing wit about Pam Tanowitzs choreography. Without trying to make her audience laugh, she seems to have a rare instinct for how steps, positions and groupings can be connected or taken apart to inventive, entertaining and surprising effect. Meanwhile, her keen feeling for footwork keeps supplying a bubbling stream of air into her dances.

title: Don Cornelius, Host of Soul Train, and His Legacy
description: With his sharp suits, exuberant Afro and too-cool-for-school demeanor, he was revered by generations of Americans, black and white.

title: The Children of Old Tehran Go Hollywood
description: That Shahs of Sunset, a reality show about affluent, not-so-young Iranian-Americans in Los Angeles, is coming out while war with Iran is being discussed might seem opportunistic. But Shahs could actually serve a valuable function. You can imagine the average contemporary Iranian watching it and thinking: Ah, thats why we needed the revolution. To get rid of these people.

title: When the Music Stopped for Don Cornelius
description: LOS ANGELES

title: That 70s Style, Reinvented
description: Sometimes the road to a hit single starts with a drink to calm the nerves. A year ago Nate Ruess, the frontman of the pop-rock trio Fun., was anxious about meeting Jeff Bhasker, the producer and hit maker behind artists including Kanye West and Beyonc, so he arrived early at the bar in the Bowery Hotel on the Lower East Side and had a little to drink just to make sure I was loosened up.

title: Will There Be Pink Slime in Your Childs School Lunch?
description: Pink Slime: its tasty (well, probably not), nutritious (oops, not that either) and cheap (got that right) and its probably found in a hamburger near you. Most particularly, in the hamburger or cheeseburger that almost certainly graced the lunch menu at your childs school this month.

title: Your Standard Grandeur, and a Touch of Modern Grit
description: There is a dull, quotidian sheen to the phrase standard repertory, although its primarily the more extraordinary works that are eventually categorized as such. There is of course nothing standard about much of Beethovens sublime music, unless the performance is stale.

title: Closing the Gap Between Rich and Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Week in Pictures for March 9
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a dispute over a winning lottery ticket, and a replica of Michelangelos David making its way into Manhattan.

title: A Candidates Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Money Keeping Marriage Sexy
description: HowAboutWe started like a typical dating site, targeting lonely singletons.

title: Netanyahus Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: A True Bistro, and a Destination
description: ALAINS BISTRO is in a particularly unattractive span of Nyack  a small, generic strip mall just off the highway and not far from the Tappan Zee Bridge. But youll see the restaurants glow before you even enter. And once in, you will be quickly enveloped by a welcoming, warm sensibility.

title: Nine-Person Team to Decide Fate of Mets Owners
description: The federal judge presiding over the trial of the Mets owners said Friday that a nine-person jury will decide if the men willfully blinded themselves to signs that Bernard L. Madoff may have been engaged in illicit activity during their many years of investing with him.

title: Giants Release Jacobs; Should Jets Consider Signing Him?
description: Brandon Jacobs, who always said what he thought  not always pleasing fans with his play or with his mouth  but who ultimately helped the Giants win two Super Bowls as a bulldozing running back, was released by the team on Friday.

title: Nardelli Steps Down From Most of His Cerberus Roles
description: Robert L. Nardelli is ending his formal ties to Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that installed him as the chief executive of Chrysler nearly two years before the carmaker filed for bankruptcy.

title: Californias Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying for Contraception
description: To the Editor:

title: A Winning Layout in Australia
description: When an expert declarer is in a contract that looks hopeless, he will look for a winning layout. His play wont always work, but sometimes it will, and then he will probably be mentioned in bridge news.

title: Bill Cunningham | Sun Spot
description: While there were many conflicting statements, fashion did its historical job of mirroring the world of today, which is a jumble.

title: Oh, to Bring Gold Home, and Perhaps the Bacon
description: DRESSED all in black, their silhouettes stark against the sparkling white ice, Meryl Davis and Charlie White, the only American ice dancing team to ever win the world championships, zoom around the rink, their bodies perfectly synchronized as they twirl, glide, step and spin, first to a samba and later to Strauss.

title: Off Broadway Faces Perils of Prosperity
description: The lamentations over the slow death of commercial Off Broadway theater have subsided, at least for a while. Its true that over the past decade the city has lost at least a half-dozen spaces once devoted to presenting new work unsuitable for Broadway, including the Variety Arts in the East Village, the Promenade Theater on the Upper West Side (now a Sephora) and the Century Center off Union Square. I suppose we can consider it a happy coincidence that none has become a Duane Reade. The result has sometimes been a stampede to Broadway by shows that by all rights should remain Off Broadway. Witness the recent quick flop of the musical Lysistrata Jones.

title: Well Always Have Darth
description: DADDY, lets play Star Wars. Ill be Dark Vader. This is my light saver.

title: One Year Later, Egyptian Women Subjected to Virginity Tests Await Justice
description: Egyptian protesters had a grim anniversary on Friday, one year after soldiers cleared demonstrators from Cairos Tahrir Square, and forcibly subjected some female detainees to virginity tests.

title: The Adventure Ends, So Take a Good Look
description: When Commander Shepard set out in 2007s Mass Effect to establish humanitys place in the cosmos and protect our species from extinction, no one knew if a video game could deliver a science-fiction saga to rival the best of television and film.

title: When Todays Deal Is Tomorrows Regret
description: HOW much is a $150 coupon worth? For Matt Sumell, the cost turned out to be one new relationship, as well as a little bit of pride.

title: Each Teacher Wonders, Is This the One?
description: A WEEK and a half ago, the day after the school shooting near Cleveland, a student stood in the doorway of my Bronx college classroom. He was eating half a bagel with cream cheese. It was a month into the semester, 45 minutes into the class period. I didnt remember ever having seen him before.

title: A Card-Counting Mix of Bibles, Blackjack and Cash
description: Colin Jones has toiled in the cacophonous, windowless, artificially lighted corridors of casinos across the country in an effort to beat the house with math. He has worked to master the art of card counting, long scorned by casino operators, in which players try to gain an advantage over a blackjack dealer by keeping track of all the cards seen, and then adjusting their bets.

title: Letters
description: Therapeutic Thoughts

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,892 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Raising a Pint to Style and Substance
description: ST. PATRICKS DAY is not the only occasion for lifting a pint, but it is certainly one of the grandest. Whether you are looking to celebrate the day or the year in general, you might try one of these tavern restaurants. All offer great beers in convivial settings.

title: Seven Testify to Character of Defendant in Rutgers Dorm Case
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Several acquaintances of a former Rutgers University student who is accused of using a webcam to spy on his roommate having a sexual encounter with another man testified on Friday that they had never heard the defendant say anything disparaging about gay people.

title: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz Does Edgar Allan Poe
description: Update: Yes, I do know how to spell Poes name, but not, apparently, while riding New Jersey Transit.

title: M.L.S. Preview: Five Questions for Commissioner Don Garber
description: Don Garber took over a teetering 12-team league when he was hired as Major League Soccers commissioner in 1999, and saw it reduced to 10 clubs two years later. In the decade since, he has diversified its ownership, overhauled its finances and built a foundation that has made the league an established player in the North American sports landscape, with 19 teams, a national television contracts in the U.S. and Canada, and a string of player development success stories ranging from Clint Dempsey and Carlos Bocanegra to Jozy Altidore and Brek Shea. On the eve of the leagues season openers, he answered, via email, questions from the Goal blog. For more from Garber, you can follow him on Twitter @thesoccerdon.

title: Political Geography: Kansas
description: On the Republican nominating calendar, Kansas is among the most favorable stops for Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator.

title: A Hockey Trailblazer Who Missed His Chance
description: His memory had dimmed, and glaucoma had robbed him of sight. At 92, Herb Carnegie was living in an assisted-care home in northern Toronto.

title: Konys Victims and the Kony 2012 Video
description: The recent Kony 2012 viral video has attracted widespread controversy, as well as scrutiny of the organization Invisible Children. While it has stirred questions about the role of westerners advocating to end mass atrocities in Africa, as well as useful dialogue on non-profit fiscal management, the debate has obscured the key point. Joseph Konys immediate capture and delivery to the International Criminal Court (ICC) would be an unambiguous victory for humanity. It is the solution for which affected Africans have desperately, unanimously pleaded.

title: Though One More Rally Is Set, a Protest Wanes in Post-Election Russia
description: MOSCOW  Excessive cheerfulness is not a trait generally associated with Russians, and Russian intellectuals in particular, which is one reason this citys three-month-old opposition movement has been so unusual.

title: Unlikely Star Shines in the Big Ten
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Its a good thing the rise of Jeremy Lin has prepared the public for anything. During Wisconsins 79-71 victory over Indiana in the quarterfinals of the Big Ten tournament Friday, a small group of Badgers fans began chanting, M.V.P, M.V.P., as the unheralded senior guard Rob Wilson went to the free-throw line.

title: Vonn Caps Title Run by Mastering a Weakness
description: That Lindsey Vonn won her fourth World Cup overall championship on Friday was not surprising. The victory was historic  she is now second in overall titles among female skiers  but Vonn this year has so dominated her competition that the race has been anticlimactic for months.

title: Wary but Loyal, Aide Answered Call From Giffords to Run
description: TUCSON  When Gabrielle Giffords began her first run for Congress in 2005, Ron Barber retired from his job and volunteered to help her. When she took office, Mr. Barber immediately signed on as her district director, hiring local staff members and arranging her events back home.

title: A Thai Journey Down Memory Lane
description: WANIDA REID took a roundabout route to opening a restaurant. Born into a political family in Bangkok, she remembers lingering in the kitchen and helping the housekeeper prepare food for her parents frequent dinner parties. As a teenager she immigrated to New York to live with an aunt and took the surname of her uncle, a military officer. Before long, she had enlisted in the Army herself, working as a translator in Japan. Later, she studied cosmetology, did some modeling and ran a series of beauty salons, while raising a daughter and traveling the world at every opportunity.

title: Pitcher by Trade, Barber by Skill
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  When the Mets traded for Ramon Ramirez this winter, they got a right-hander with a lively fastball, a deceptive delivery and a good command of a pair of scissors.

title: The Phony Settlement
description: Forgive me for repeating myself, but Im going to start this column with an anecdote about Ken Feinberg that Ive told before.

title: A Breach of Trust
description: The hard-fought deal that settled last years debt-ceiling fight made painfully deep cuts in spending, but it promised one thing: a years peace from the destructive Congressional battles that led to threats of government shutdowns and defaults. By signing the pact, Republican and Democratic leaders set spending levels for 2013, putting off further budget wars until after the election.

title: YouTube Subtracts Racy and Raucous to Add a Teaching Tool
description: Educators are giving YouTube  long dismissed as a storehouse of whimsical, time-wasting and occasionally distasteful videos  another look. As Google, YouTubes parent company, fine-tunes a portal that lets schools limit students access to selected content, the video-sharing Web site is gaining popularity as a trove of free educational materials.

title: From Nickname to Label
description: At Martha Clara Vineyards in Riverhead, the principal owner, Robert Entenmann, 83, is nicknamed Five-O.

title: Pad Thai, and a Whole Lot More
description: PAD THAI, the dish that defines Thai food for many people, is often a disappointment: overly sweet, dry or just plain dull. Not so at Mukda Thai Cuisine in Hicksville. Here, the stir-fry of rice noodles is only slightly sweet, and the meat in it  we ordered chicken  exceptionally moist. Best of all, it is served with a wedge of lime for an acidic counterpoint and with bean sprouts that provide crunch and a fresh taste.

title: Changing the Chemistry of Earths Oceans
description: The oceans have always served as a sink for carbon dioxide, but the burning of fossil fuels since the beginning of the industrial revolution, especially over the last 40 years, has given them more than they can safely absorb. The result is acidification  a change in the chemical balance that threatens the oceans web of life.

title: Losing It All for Another Drink
description: For Lee Remick, it was the brandy Alexanders. Admirers of the 1962 film Days of Wine and Roses remember that her character, a bright-eyed late-Eisenhower-era executive secretary, never touches alcohol until a charming, single public relations man (Jack Lemmon) comes along and introduces her to that particular dessert-sweet drink. So it may come as a surprise, in the Schoolhouse Theaters worthy production of the story, to see that character repeatedly swigging from a bottle of vodka in her first scene.

title: Two Screws Were No Match for a Brazen Subway Art Thief
description: A skateboarder, a rabbi, a balloon lady, an accordion player, a crying baby, a fisherman and a guy in a bear suit step onto the subway.

title: In a Flurry of Birdies, Watson and Rose Dismantle Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  The renovation of Dorals Blue Monster started a year early, the vision and tools wielded by the fanciful golfer Bubba Watson and not the noted architect Gil Hanse, whom the propertys new owner, Donald Trump, has entrusted with the project.

title: Better Numbers
description: The job market is showing slow and steady improvement. In February, 227,000 jobs were added. It was the 24th straight month of private-sector job gains, and the third month in a row of gains well above 200,000, the best three-month stretch in nearly two years.

title: Duke Is Short on the Court, but on Top in the Win Column
description: ATLANTA  For a few possessions here Friday night, it looked as if Duke might not get a rebound that did not hit the ground first.

title: Despite the Armys Obstruction, Egyptians Work to Build a Democracy
description: CAIRO

title: Doubts Grew Slowly Over a Palate Above Suspicion
description: Rudy Kurniawan was always the authority on fraudulent wines.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 9, 2012

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Chinas forecast of a relatively modest 7.5 percent growth rate suggests that its decades of growth may be winding down. In Texas, a jury convicted the financier R. Allen Stanford in a $7 billion fraud, and Greece won bondholders approval for a debt restructuring.

title: Harry Wendelstedt, Umpire in Five World Series, Dies at 73
description: Harry Wendelstedt, who was an umpire in five World Series during a 33-year major league career and who taught hundreds of aspiring professional umpires at his Florida school, died on Friday in Daytona Beach, not far from Ormond Beach, where the school is based and where he lived. He was 73.

title: Twin Spotlights on Dance
description: NEWARK

title: The Bad News Is Good News
description: There was one brief shining moment last week when Mitt Romney appeared to be saying something sensible about sex.

title: Bearcats Arrive, and Orange Exit
description: Most of Cincinnatis quiet run toward the upper tier of the Big East standings has been motivated by an effort to erase the stain of an incident in the seasons second month: an ugly brawl with intracity rival Xavier that resulted in four suspensions for both teams.

title: Mitt, Grits and Grit
description: Im learning to say yall, and I like grits. Things, strange things are happening to me.

title: N.Y.U.s Plan for Expansion Draws Anger in Community
description: It is perhaps the largest project ever proposed for Greenwich Village, and it has angered many residents in the area as few issues have recently. Opponents say the development would mar one of New Yorks signature neighborhoods.

title: Austin, Proud of Eccentricity, Loses a Favorite
description: Every city has its characters, but other places tend to tolerate them with a smirk or a sneer. In Austin, Tex., its more of an embrace.

title: Fighting War Crimes, Without Leaving the Couch?
Discreetly Digital, Erotic Novel Sets American Women Abuzz
description: Fifty Shades of Grey, an erotic novel by an obscure author that has been described as Mommy porn and Twilight for grown-ups, has electrified women across the country, who have spread the word like gospel on Facebook pages, at school functions and in spin classes. Or as the handwritten tag on a paperback copy in a Montclair, N.J., bookstore helpfully noted, Yes, this is THE book everyone is talking about.

title: From Private to Public
description: The successful private debt swap by the Greek government will leave most of its debt in the hands of public sector lenders.

title: Corrections: March 10
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jewish Film Festival Has Local Ties
description: DURING its first 15 years, the Hartford Jewish Film Festival established itself as an international heavyweight, growing from five films to about two dozen features and documentaries focused on Jewish issues. This years festival, the 16th, comes with a strong local bent, with at least three Connecticut residents speaking about their involvement in a particular film immediately after its screening.

title: Freed From Bondage, Into a Nowhere Land
description: Little-known fact: the day after the end of the Civil War coincided with the start of Passover. Jews in the North and Jews in the South sat down at their Seder tables to commemorate the release of the Israelites from bondage in Egypt. As Matthew Lopez posits in his tough and evocative play The Whipping Man, some of those Passover celebrants must have been Southerners who had themselves only just been freed.

title: Taking a Mulligan
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  What a nice surprise on a Saturday. I love the ocean, and opening with something that made me think of the EBB AND FLOW of the tide is a mesmerizing way to gain a toehold in the toughest grid of the week.

title: Principal Is Removed Over Findings of Falsified Student Records
description: The principal of a Bronx middle and high school was removed from the school on Friday after the New York City Education Department found that for years, the staff had falsified student transcripts and given credit for courses not taken. The practice led to an artificially high graduation rate and students receiving diplomas they had not earned.

title: Thin Men and Other Signature Works of a Long Career
description: Riverhead, N.Y.

title: Solid in Kansas, Santorum Seeks to Build Margin
description: WICHITA, Kan.  We chased all the candidates out of Kansas! Rick Santorum boomed as he took the podium one day before Saturdays caucuses in the state, which his two leading rivals are not seriously pursuing.

title: Signs of Encouragement in the Jobs Reports
description: Jobs are up again but long-term unemployment has edged down.

title: A Keeper of a Vast Garden of Art in the Hills of Brazil
description: BRUMADINHO, Brazil

title: Knicks, Unable to Contain Bucks, Lose Fourth Straight
description: MILWAUKEE  Losing at Boston, Dallas and San Antonio is one thing. Dropping a key midseason game at Milwaukee, where the Bucks had only won twice in their last nine home games, is another.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Photographer in the Sky

title: Ad Campaign for Marines Cites Chaos as a Job Perk
description: The war in Iraq is over, the troop reduction in Afghanistan is under way and Americas next war front is far from clear. If you are a military recruiter, how do market your product?

title: Health Care Exchange Rules to Be Set
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is about to carry out a major provision of the new health care law by issuing standards for health insurance exchanges, the markets where consumers and small businesses will be able to buy coverage from competing private plans.

title: Separation Anxiety Over Lost Anchor(s)
description: She came from Harlem, her broadcasts exemplifying the spirit of the city she served: vibrant, feisty, occasionally profane.

title: Nazareth Gets Revenge and Shot at Another Title
description: After losing its city basketball crown earlier this month, Nazareth appears to have regained solid footing as it seeks to defend its state title.

title: Tips From Airline Menu Makers
description: Airlines are investing in the meals they serve in their upper-class cabins by hiring star chefs and experimenting with flavors. Some experts talk about what theyve learned.

title: Vying for Campus President, Illegal Immigrant Gets a Gamut of Responses
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  Jose Luis Zelaya stood with a crowd of other students waiting to hear the news. It was election day at Texas A&M University here, and he was running for student body president. A victory for Mr. Zelaya, a 24-year-old graduate student from Honduras, would make history at Texas A&M: He would become its first Hispanic student body president  and the first illegal immigrant to hold the position.

title: The Ways of the Jedi
description: In a Midtown rehearsal space, Flynn Michael teaches lightsaber skills and finding the hero within.

title: On 50-Year-Old Tape, Sounds of Mets Awkward First Steps
description: It was 50 years ago Saturday that the Mets played their initial spring training game, an 8-0 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals. There was nothing surprising in that result, considering the Mets went on to win only 40 games all season, a record for futility that still stands.

title: Training New Jedis in the Force
description: ON a recent weeknight, Flynn Michael walked through his Jedi academy, a dimly lighted room not in some galaxy far, far away, but rather in a rehearsal space overlooking a death star of traffic on Eighth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan.

title: In Uganda, Few Can See Kony Video
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Ugandas Public Enemy No. 1, Joseph Kony, became an overnight Internet sensation to the rest of the world this week, but many here knew little or nothing about the explosive online campaign.

title: German Leader and I.M.F. Chief Split Over Debt
description: BERLIN  With a deal on Greek debt finally done, Europe will shift its attention to two of its most powerful women, friends who have dueling views about what needs to be done to prevent future Greek-like meltdowns from spreading to other economies.

title: India Eyes Muslims Left Behind by Quota System
description: MUZAFFARNAGAR, India  Along the narrow lane known as Khadar Wallah, Muslims and low-caste Hindus have lived side by side for years, bound by poverty, if not religion. Yet recently, Muslims like Murtaza Mansuri have noticed a change. Their neighbors have become better off.

title: Hatch Weighs In on Tax Status of Super PACs
description: Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, joined the fight over the tax status of Super PACS on Friday, accusing Senate Democrats of a politically motivated witch hunt for their efforts to rein in tax-exempt political groups.

title: The Science of Hanging Out
description: For Danielle Goldman, 17, a senior at the Bronx High School of Science, Sunday begins on Friday night, when she finishes her homework so shell have the weekend free. I dont wait till the last minute, she said. This work ethic  along with a project that studied neurotransmitter levels in adolescents with mood disorders  helped make her one of 40 finalists in this years Intel Science Talent Search, which concludes on Tuesday. A $100,000 award will go to the winner. She lives in Astoria, Queens, with her parents and the familys parrot, Puppy. She plans to attend Columbia College.

title: Netanyahu Says U.S. and Israeli Clocks Differ on Irans Threat
description: JERUSALEM  Addressing his home audience after talks with President Obama in Washington this week, the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, acknowledged that differences still existed in the Israeli and American timetables for contending with the Iranian nuclear program.

title: Rangers Sustain Third Loss in a Row
description: CHICAGO  The Rangers are coming home, and not a moment too soon, because they are reeling now.

title: Peter Bergman, Satirist With the Firesign Theater, Dies at 72
description: Peter Bergman, a founding member of the surrealist comedy troupe Firesign Theater, whose albums became cult favorites among college students in the late 1960s and 70s for a brand of sly, multilayered satire so dense it seemed riddled with non sequiturs until the second, third or 30th listening, died on Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 72.

title: With Extension to Sanchez, Jets Give Up on Manning
description: The Jets committed to a franchise quarterback on Friday night  their own. They bowed out of the Peyton Manning sweepstakes with a flourish, agreeing with Mark Sanchez on a new five-year contract that could be worth as much as $68.5 million. It is a handsome reward for a player whose progress stagnated last season, when the Jets lost the final three games and missed the playoffs.

title: Crime, Queens and Escaping Slavery
description: IN The Gods of Gotham (Amy Einhorn Books, $25.95), the novelist Lyndsay Faye draws on the historian Tyler Anbinders Five Points, original newspaper accounts, other nonfiction and the argot of the age to vividly conjure mid-19th-century New York.

title: Leonardo Cimino Dies at 94; Distinctive Actor
description: Leonardo Cimino, who once thought his singular appearance would make an acting career improbable but who ended up spending more than 60 years as an in-demand character actor whose roles included gangsters, grandfathers, the pope, Vincent van Gogh and Scary German Guy, died on March 3 at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 94.

title: Britain: Court Hands Qaddafi Sons Mansion to Libya
description: The Libyan government won a court order on Friday granting it possession of a $16 million London mansion bought by the playboy son of the former Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi with what a high court judge ruled were stolen Libyan government funds. The eight-bedroom house, with an indoor swimming pool, whirlpool bath and suede-lined home cinema, was bought by Saadi Qaddafi, 38, only months before the Arab Spring protests erupted that led to the overthrow of his father. Mr. Qaddafi, now in Niger, had a reputation of using the London house for cocaine parties and entertaining prostitutes, according to bodyguards who worked at the house.

title: Frisner Augustin, Haitian Vodou Drummer, Dies at 63
description: Frisner Augustin, a Haitian vodou master drummer whose deep knowledge of traditional rhythms and leadership of the Brooklyn-based Troupe Makandal made him a major force in preserving and popularizing his Afro-Haitian heritage, died on Feb. 28 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He was 63.

title: Kingmaker of Little Russia
description: COUNCILMAN LEWIS A. FIDLER peers at the audience inalow-ceilingedroom on Coney Island Avenue with the expectant smile of the newly betrothed.

title: The Power to Kill
description: President Obama, who came to office promising transparency and adherence to the rule of law, has become the first president to claim the legal authority to order an American citizen killed without judicial involvement, real oversight or public accountability.

title: Louisville Defense Overwhelms Fighting Irish
description: A relentless Louisville defense dismantled third-seeded Notre Dame, 64-50, in the second semifinal of the Big East mens basketball tournament on Friday night.

title: A Comeback of Olympian Proportions
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  In a late match on Court 7 of the BNP Paribas Open Thursday evening, an eight-time Grand Slam champion was quietly playing the biggest match of her comeback.

title: Scenes From a Dying Empire
description: Any time wall texts are mounted next to the works in an exhibition, a familiar tension arises between words and images, reading and seeing, Martha Schwendener wrote in The New York Times. There is some danger of this with the art exhibition Princes and Painters in Mughal Delhi, 1707-1857, because the context in which the images were made is so complex that it requires explanation, she writes.

title: Ohio: Rules Tightened for Wells
description: State officials on Friday instituted stricter rules for oil and gas industry disposal wells like one that scientists have linked to minor earthquakes in Youngstown. The rules, contained in a report by the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, will require a well owner to conduct and analyze geophysical tests on a new well before disposal begins and will prohibit drilling into deep Precambrian rocks that are more likely to contain seismic faults. The report found a compelling argument that the quakes in Youngstown since last March were induced by the disposal of waste liquids from the drilling process called hydraulic fracturing. The state will require the installation of pressure monitoring systems at all wells and electronic record-keeping by trucking firms that bring the waste liquids to the wells.

title: Wars Over Regulation of Rent Are Only a Sideshow
description: With a certain regularity, New Yorkers are given the opportunity to engage in a satisfyingly maddening if futile pastime: decrying the obscenities of rent regulation.

title: Reserve Bank Moves to Stimulate Economy
description: In a move meant to relieve growing stress in its financial system, Indias central bank on Friday sharply reduced the amount of money banks have to hold in reserve, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times. The action came ahead of a scheduled policy meeting at which the bank was expected to cut the reserve ratio, but less sharply, he writes.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: India Eyes Muslims Left Behind by Quota System
description: Along the narrow lane known as Khadar Wallah, Muslims and low-caste Hindus have lived side by side for years, bound by poverty, if not religion, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. Yet recently, Muslims like Murtaza Mansuri have noticed a change. Their neighbors have become better off.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: In the Hills of Brazil, an Oasis of Contemporary Art
description: A look at Inhotim, a contemporary 5,000-acre art complex in the hills of southeast Brazil.

title: Government Bail Letter: Rudy Kurniawan
description: A U.S. attorney request that a judge deny Rudy Kurniawan bail asserting that he poses a risk of flight.

title: Close Friends on a Collision Course Over Europe
description: Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, who is French, and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany are close. They are on a first-name basis, write Nicholas Kulish and Annie Lowrey. They frequently exchange text messages. Shortly after Christmas, Ms. Lagarde brought Ms. Merkel a trinket from Herms and received a recording of the Berlin Philharmonic playing Beethoven from Ms. Merkel, a classical music lover.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah said on Friday that militancy in the state during the past two decades has orphaned more than 26,000 children and widowed more than 8,000 women, Kashmir Live reports. He also said the state government is considering the idea of creating a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to inquire into the alleged cases of forced disappearances from the state, but it still needs a consensus from other stakeholders including the central government, the newspaper reports.

title: The Boss Pays Tribute to Soul, and Rocks the Apollo, Too
description: Bruce Springsteen thrilled a crowd of V.I.P.s at the Apollo Theater in Harlem on Friday night, stomping through the angry folk-rock tunes from his new album, giving the crowd muscular versions of hits from his early career and doing a few soul tunes to honor the place where he was standing.

title: Peyton Mannings Free-Agent Tour Starts in Denver
description: Peyton-palooza touched down in Denver on Friday for the first visit of Peyton Mannings free-agent tour. The Broncos, who captivated the N.F.L. last season when they made the playoffs with Tim Tebow at quarterback, are said to be a serious contender for Manning, who would allow team executive John Elway to gracefully transition the team away from the option offense it had to run with Tebow, without alienating the hordes of Tebow fans who clamored for him to start last season.

title: Beyond Mile-High Grub: Can Airline Food Be Tasty?
description: ONE of the worlds busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson in Atlanta, lies a mere 1,026 feet above sea level. Which, it turns out, is perfect for your taste buds.

title: Your Airline Food Experiences
description: If youre traveling domestically in an airlines coach class, a hot meal may seem like an increasingly distant memory  and perhaps not a fond one. Even for passengers in first and business classes, who still expect dining to be part of the flight, serving up appetizing cuisine is no easy feat for the airlines. High altitude can dull the taste buds and present particular challenges in food storage and preparation.

title: Depth Makes Vancouver a Dark Horse in M.L.S.
description: The absence of relegation in Major League Soccer means that a team can become champions one year after finishing at the bottom of the pile. Landon Donovan and Dwayne De Rosario sparked the San Jose Earthquakes past the Los Angeles Galaxy in the 2001 M.L.S. Cup final a year after the Earthquakes finished last. Donovan almost repeated the feat with Los Angeles.

title: The Early Word: Jobs
description: Todays Times

title: From Jets to Sanchez: When an Extension Looks Like an Apology
description: Did the Jets just say sorry to Mark Sanchez by adding three years and $40.5 million to his contract?

title: The Endangered Mediterranean Diet
description: LONDON  Spanish doctors meeting in Madrid this week have sounded the latest warning that the countrys traditional Mediterranean diet is under threat.

title: Redskins Bet Future on Trade to Acquire Robert Griffin
description: As the Jets began a late-night conference call to announce that quarterback Mark Sanchez had agreed to a contract extension, signaling their withdrawal from the pursuit of Peyton Manning, multiple reports said the Washington Redskins, who also were interested in Manning, had completed a blockbuster trade to acquire the second overall draft pick from the St. Louis Rams.

title: Students Seek Books For a Peopled Planet
description: Im in the early stages of designing a crowd-shaped-and-shared online learning tool on the core issues shaping the human journey in this century (i.e., the issues at the right side of Dot Earths homepage). You can call it a syllabus, an online textbook, a course.

title: The Lonesome Ghosts of a Citys Past
description: To me, theyre almost like a sleepwalkers view of the city, the filmmaker Jem Cohen said of the ghostly Polaroids he has taken of New York over the past 30 years. I might walk around for a whole night, but only shoot one or two pictures.

title: Worth the Cost of the Trip for the Ropa Vieja Alone
description: In the year since restrictions on travel to Cuba were eased for those on cultural exchange itineraries, new trips to the island have focused on art, history and music. Now theres one for foodies.

title: Q.P.R.s Ghost Goal
description: One week after the International Football Association Board voted to continue testing goal-line technology, an apparent goal by Clint Hill of Queens Park Rangers went unrewarded Saturday at Bolton. To make matters worse for Q.P.R., relegation-threatened Bolton scored a late goal to win, 2-1, in Englands Premier League.

title: The Swedish One Percent
description: Via Mark Thoma, Daron Acemoglu and James Robinson react to Allan Meltzer claiming that the top one percent is surging everywhere, even in Sweden, so its not a proper political issue.

title: Anti-Putin Protesters Struggle to Keep Up Steam
description: MOSCOW  Thousands of people thronged a concourse along a main street in Moscow on Saturday to denounce President-elect Vladimir V. Putin and to cry out together, one more time, for political freedom. They waved the flags of opposition parties, in a kaleidoscopic swirl; wore white ribbons that said, Russia demands change; and chanted now-familiar refrains: Russia without Putin! and Russia will be free!

title: The Stupid, It Freezes
description: I dont look at the WSJ much these days; it really has gone downhill since you-know-who took over, and I find that I almost never find anything there that isnt covered better either in the Times or in the FT.

title: Things Money Can and Cannot Buy Revive the 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA  The itinerary was a sports fans dream: Friday in Miami to watch the resurgent 76ers play the Heat; hop on a private jet to Atlanta to catch the 76ers take on the Hawks on Saturday; head to Indianapolis for the Super Bowl on Sunday; then rush to Philadelphia to see the 76ers play the Los Angeles Lakers at home.

title: First, Lets Pick All the Judges
description: Another Hungary post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, after the jump.

title: Teixeiras Work on Bunt Has Helped His Swing
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One of the few people on hand when the Yankees Mark Teixeira was working on his bunting skills this winter said he could not give a comprehensive scouting report on Teixeiras ability to drop a bunt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: No Talks With Syria Opposition, Leader Tells U.N. Envoy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  High-level diplomatic efforts to stop the fighting in Syria yielded mixed results on Saturday as President Bashar al-Assad shut the door on any immediate negotiations with the opposition and escalated a new military assault on the city of Idlib.

title: Variety: A  Somewhat Cranky Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  The author of todays quote wrote a series of books detailing the everyday life in Canada of his character Samuel Marchbanks. Marchbanks lived a simple life and spent his time humorously pondering many of the things we still wonder about today. In fact, the beginning of the passage that contains todays quote reads as follows:

title: Mets Infield Prospect Hounded By a Perplexing Run of Injuries
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The last time Reese Havens was able to practice with his teammates was Feb. 28. The next morning, he walked into the Mets spring training complex and told the manager that he had been feeling soreness in his back.

title: N.C.A.A. Builds Solid Brackets From a Shaky Foundation
description: The N.C.A.A., tired of hearing criticism from data geeks and television commentators about how it selects and seeds the 68-team mens basketball tournament, had a brilliant insight a couple of years ago. If these pundits were so smart, why not invite them into the process and see if they could do any better themselves?

title: Fighting Continues in Syria
description: Syrian troops pushed ahead with a new assault on the northern region of Idlib on Saturday, shelling one of the centers of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assads rule and sending families fleeing for safety as armed rebels tried to fend off the attack.

title: Lights! Cameras! (and Cheers) for a Rock Weighing 340 Tons
description: LOS ANGELES  It was 4:35 a.m. on Saturday when the block-long transporter carrying a 340-ton, 21-foot-high boulder wrapped in white plastic pulled up in front of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: Everybody Wants a Piece of Nerlens Noel
description: EVERETT, Mass.  Nerlens Noel is a 6-foot-10 basketball star considered the best prospect from the Boston area since Patrick Ewing. He is the top-ranked high school senior in the country, and hailed as the best shot blocker of his generation. The 17-year-old son of working-class Haitian immigrants, he could be worth $10 million in about 16 months when he is eligible for the 2013 N.B.A draft.

title: Deficits Push N.Y. Cities and Counties to Desperation
description: ALBANY  It was not a good week for New Yorks cities and counties.

title: WeatherMob, a Social Network Around the Local Forecast
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A mobile social network built around the weather sounds as likely to be a hit as a social network around ailing pets or French cheeses. But after landing in a very gray and gloomy Austin for South by Southwest, the dreary weather has been among the hottest topics of conversation.

title: For Rangers, a Chance to Sort Things Out
description: After losing three straight games on the road, the Rangers can take comfort knowing they will be in New York for 12 straight days.

title: A Trip Inside the N.C.A.A. Bubble
description: With the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament approaching, Nate Silver was given the chance to step into the shoes of the selection committee, which chooses and seeds the 68 teams that will take part in March Madness. As it turns out, there is an element of statistical madness  the Ratings Percentage Index  embedded in the selection process itself. Read More.

title: N.F.L. Free-for-All
description: Free agency after the lockout was a scramble last year once the new N.F.L. labor deal was signed. Teams were unsure when free agency would begin, and at least one front-office staff went home for the night to rest up for what it thought would be a frenzied start the next day, before racing back to the office when the league suddenly let the signings begin.

title: Golfer Robert Rock Has a Head for the Game, but No Hat
description: DORAL, Fla.  In the two months since Robert Rock stared down Tiger Woods to win the Abu Dhabi Championship, many people have tipped their caps to him. They include the American real estate mogul Donald Trump, who introduced himself last week and complimented Rock on his game, his victory over Woods and his hair, which is thicker than Trumps wallet.

title: Sprinting to London, and Not the N.F.L.
description: NAMPA, Idaho  Florida running back Jeff Demps affirmed his decision to focus on a track career by skipping the N.F.L. combine last month.

title: Hits, and Misses, in a War on Bribery
description: PRISON is the last place Albert J. Stanley seemed destined for. But on Feb. 23, Mr. Stanley, a legendary figure in the high-octane world of Big Oil, was sentenced to two and a half years for his role in one of the biggest bribery cases in American history.

title: Blue Jays Morrow Is Trying to Channel the Ace Within
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.

title: Religious Statues Left Behind Find Their Own Patron Saint
description: LAKEWOOD, Ohio

title: Ervings Record Forgotten, but Not Gone
description: Deron Williams scored a franchise-record 57 points to lift the visiting Nets to a 104-101 victory over the Charlotte Bobcats. That is how one news agency began an article about Williamss performance last Sunday. The news was repeated in newspapers and on television and radio, where it was also reported that Williams broke the Nets N.B.A. franchise record.

title: Remembering Japans Catastrophe
description: A year after a huge earthquake and tsunami caused nearly catastrophic meltdowns at a nuclear plant, Japan is still grappling with the crucial question of whether the disaster was avoidable.

title: Rule Changes Could Put Safety Ahead of Speed
description: The N.H.L. game today is played at a sprint, with line changes every 40 seconds and players crashing into one another at breakneck speeds, and the bodies have been piling up.

title: The Memo List: Where Everyone Has an Opinion
description: This interview with  Jim Whitehurst, president and chief executive of Red Hat, the provider of Linux and other open-source technology, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Violence Continues for Israel and Militants
description: GAZA  Cross-border violence between Israel and militant groups in Gaza continued Saturday, as Israeli airstrikes that began Friday afternoon killed several more Palestinian militants and militant groups fired scores of rockets into southern Israel, breaking months of relative calm.

title: Revisiting a $400 Million Tax Break
description: IF you saw $20 on the ground, would you stop to pick it up? Silly question.

title: Gas Price Disparity Seems Here to Stay
description: THE price of gasoline is rising, but the nation isnt sharing the pain equally.

title: With Kara Goucher
description: One of the United States top female distance runners, Kara Goucher, gave birth to her son, Colt, in September 2010. Seven months later, she finished fifth at the 2011 Boston Marathon in 2 hours 24 minutes 52 seconds, her best time by a minute. A hip injury tempered the remainder of Gouchers 2011 season, but she recovered sufficiently to finish third at the Olympic marathon trials in January in Houston, qualifying for the London Games with Shalane Flanagan and Desiree Davila.

title: Automatic Recharging, From a Distance
description: THINK how convenient it would be if you could recharge electronic devices without ever having to plug them in  or even take them out of your briefcase.

title: Grizzlies and Their Point Guard Sneak Up
description: Mike Conleys no-nonsense style of playing point guard might not receive a lot of notice, but it has the Memphis Grizzlies climbing the Western Conference standings and starting to look like a team that no one will want to face come playoff time.

title: In Charlotte, Hopes for Rental Gold Rush During the Democratic Convention
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Vani Hari hopes to cash in when 35,000 Democrats come to town for their national convention in September.

title: As Security Concerns Remain, Christians Flee Iraq
description: Iraqs dwindling numbers of Christians, driven from their homes by attacks and intimidation, are beginning to abandon the safe havens they had found in the countrys north, discouraged by unemployment and a creeping fear that the violence they had fled was catching up to them.

title: M.L.S. Preview: Five Dates to Circle on the Calendar
description: With a kickoff this weekend and a plan for its first December final, Major League Soccer will begin the longest season in league history on Saturday. Here are five dates to circle on your soccer calendar.

title: Exodus From North Signals Iraqi Christians Slow Decline
description: TENNA, Iraq  Iraqs dwindling Christians, driven from their homes by attacks and intimidation, are beginning to abandon the havens they had found in the countrys north, discouraged by unemployment and a creeping fear that the violence they had fled was catching up to them.

title: Catamounts Go Back to the Tournament
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  John Beckers strange journey to the Vermont coaching job began 18 years ago in Washington. He was a part-time assistant coach at Gallaudet University, the nations leading college for the deaf and the hearing-impaired.

title: Democrat Is Giving Up House Seat to Focus on Race for Governor
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Jay Inslee, the Washington Democrat, will hold a news conference Saturday afternoon to announce that he is stepping down from the House to concentrate on his bid for governor, his campaign spokeswoman said.

title: The Prestige Chase Is Raising College Costs
description: WITH ample reason, President Obama has grown impatient with my industry.

title: Wisconsin Gets a Boost From an Unlikely Source
description: INDIANAPOLIS  If only the game were played in Los Angeles, the movie script might already be commissioned, the actors cast and the latest rags-to-riches tale set to light up Hollywood.

title: Santorum Wins in Kansas Caucuses
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Demonstrating again his strength among conservative voters in the heartland, Rick Santorum decisively won the Kansas caucuses on Saturday.

title: Boy Is Found Dead in Brooklyn
description: Detectives are investigating the death of a 23-month-old boy in Brooklyn whose bruised body was discovered after his mother called 911 early Saturday morning to say that he was unconscious and unresponsive, the police said.

title: Hey! You Stole My Name!
description: ABOUT seven months ago I was name-jacked.

title: Letters: Next-To-Nothing Interest on Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Two Types of Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Levitated Mass Arrives in Los Angeles
description: It was 4:35 a.m. on Saturday when a block-long transporter carrying a 340-ton, 21-foot-high boulder wrapped in plastic pulled up at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: As the Uninsured Go Without Care, Health Districts Hold Reserves of Money
description: When Roron Chen went to a public clinic to try to see a doctor, she was put on the waiting list at the San Mateo Medical Center. A California state law requires counties to provide health care to people like Ms. Chen who cannot afford health insurance and have no other alternatives.

title: In the Wake of Disaster
description: A year after the tsunami, communities are still grappling with how to assess the risk of radiation exposure.

title: William Hamilton Dies at 87; Known for Death of God
description: William Hamilton was a tenured professor of church history at a small divinity school in Rochester in April 1966 when Time magazine created a sensation with a cover article featuring some of the ideas he had been writing about for years in journals read mainly by ministers and theologians.

title: Japan Finds Story of Hope in Undertaker Who Offered Calm Amid Disaster
description: KAMAISHI, Japan  Amid the grief of finding her mothers body at a makeshift morgue in this tsunami-ravaged city last March, Fumie Arai took comfort in a small but surprising discovery. Unlike the rest of the muddied body, her mothers face had been carefully wiped clean.

title: 21 Days of Rage for Some EBay Sellers
description: WITHOUT eBay, the Haggler would not be wearing pants. Strike that. Without eBay, the Haggler would not be wearing the pants he is currently wearing, which were snagged in the final seconds of a seven-day auction last year.

title: In the Wake of Disaster
description: A year after the tsunami, communities in Japan are still grappling with how to assess the risk of radiation exposure.

title: Maxwell S. Keith Dies at 87; Replacement Lawyer in Manson Case
description: Maxwell S. Keith, who defended two members of the so-called Manson family in their notorious cult murder trials, stepping in after the lawyer for one of them disappeared under mysterious circumstances, died on Tuesday in Templeton, Calif. He was 87.

title: Smartphones Should Know Their Place at Work
description: Q. Your company allows employees to bring their own portable electronic devices  like phones and tablets  to the office. Does that mean you should feel free to use them whenever you see fit?

title: Higher Fees? Lets Celebrate
description: WHATEVER happened to free checking accounts?

title: Yotam Ottolenghi
description: Yotam Ottolenghi is an Israeli-born chef and cookbook author known for dishes that emphasize vegetables. He lives in London, where he and his Palestinian business partner own four  popular food shops and restaurants.

title: Farewell to the Monkey House
description: THE Monkey House at the Bronx Zoo, oldest of the ornate Beaux-Arts animal houses that once lined the zoos stately, central Astor Court, closed late last month. Officially named the Primates House upon its opening in 1901, it was one of the last surviving remnants of the old city zoo. As with the Ape, Lion and Elephant Houses along Astor Courts Neoclassical piazza (designed by Heins & La Farge, a firm best known for its elaborately tiled New York City subway stations) visitors entered through a portico limned with totemic terra-cotta animal carvings and action scenes up along the frieze. Once inside, we would pass a series of reeking, brashly lighted tiled rooms in which the only concessions to the exhibits natural homes were a chained log, a corner-propped limb and a front nameplate with a black dot on the silhouette of the captives native continent.

title: The Go-Nowhere Generation
description: AMERICANS are supposed to be mobile and even pushy. Saul Bellows Augie March declares, I am an American ... first to knock, first admitted. In The Grapes of Wrath, young Tom Joad loads up his jalopy with pork snacks and relatives, and the family flees the Oklahoma dust bowl for sun-kissed California. Along the way, Granma dies, but the Joads keep going.

title: Crosby May Play Against the Rangers
description: CANONSBURG, Pa.  Sidney Crosby will not make his long-awaited return from concussion and neck injuries in the Pittsburgh Penguins nationally televised Sunday matinee against the Boston Bruins.

title: Wheelchair Guys Are All Alike
description: ACCORDING to recent media reports, the esteemed British physicist and author Stephen Hawking has been frequenting a Southern California sex club.

title: Go to Trial: Crash the Justice System
description: Columbus, Ohio

title: Nuclear Risk and Fear, from Hiroshima to Fukushima
description: Next month will see the publication of The Rise of Nuclear Fear, a fresh look at the history of perceptions of nuclear risk by the physicist and historian Spencer Weart, who builds this book on his 1988 work Nuclear Fear: A History of Images. Weart is best known to Dot Earth regulars as the author of the essential guide to 100 years of research pointing to a human influence on climate, The Discovery of Global Warming (heres my 2003 review of that book for The Times).

title: Lingerie and Enlightenment
description: ON my fathers side of the family were several generations of respected New York lawyers and judges. My maternal grandmother married the deacon of the Flatbush Dutch Reformed Church in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Eventually, the borough took some of their family land by eminent domain to develop the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 11
description: The Republican presidential race, Februarys job report and the conflict in Syria are among the subjects in this weeks Sunday shows.

title: A Master Carver, at Work at A&M
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Appeal of Death Row Case Is More Than a Matter of Guilt or Innocence
description: No one saw Rob Will shoot and kill Harris County Deputy Sheriff Barrett Hill in the still-black morning hours in a Houston bayou on Dec. 4, 2000. No physical evidence linked him to the murder.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Money and Influence in U.S. Elections
description: Readers discuss the effects of super PACs and Citizens United on political campaigns.

title: Elections Have Scandals, Even the Ones on Campus
description: Most politicians in Texas spent February awaiting final word on the states redrawn political maps. Court delays pushed the states primary date from Super Tuesday  when Texas could have exercised some influence  to the end of May.

title: Not-So-Crazy Republicans
description: WITH Super Tuesday in the books, the time has come to praise that most mocked, maligned and misunderstood of Americans: the Republican primary voter.

title: Mitts Rich Predicament
description: MITT ROMNEY may be as close to a walking, talking dollar sign as presidential politics has ever witnessed. If money were made flesh, it would apparently have fair skin, flawless hair and an off-key tropism toward patriotic anthems.

title: When States Put Out the Unwelcome Mat
description: There is one area, besides copper mining and home foreclosures, where Arizona is a national leader. Its at the front of a movement by states and local governments to seize control of immigration from the federal government. In 2010 it passed a law, S.B. 1070, that made the mass deportation of undocumented immigrants its official policy with a grab bag of enforcement schemes that turned federal immigration infractions into state crimes. Among other things, the law required immigration checks by local police, required immigrants to carry papers with them, and made it illegal for the undocumented to live or look for work in the state, or for people to knowingly hire, harbor or transport them.

title: Locals Try to Make Themselves Heard at SXSW
description: Bruce Springsteen & the E Street Bands performance at a so-called intimate venue will most likely be the big story of this years South by Southwest. But another part of the SXSW tradition is discovering and championing new talent.

title: Nuclear Fallout
description: I GREW up in Arvada, Colo., in the shadow of a nuclear bomb factory, so I read the just-released report on the Fukushima meltdown in Japan with special interest. Coinciding with the first anniversary of the Fukushima Daiichi disaster, the 400-page report details the extensive misinformation supplied to the public by the Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco) in collusion with Japanese officials.

title: Pass the Books. Hold the Oil.
description: EVERY so often someone asks me: Whats your favorite country, other than your own?

title: Immigration Decreases, but Tensions Remain High
description: PHOENIX  The impact of steep declines in the number of migrants illegally crossing the border with Mexico in recent years has rippled across Arizona and other border states, with federal and local law enforcement seeing big drops in crime related to illegal immigration.

title: Searching for Ancient Ithaca
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof sets sail for the Greek island of Cephalonia, in search of ancient Ithaca and traces of Homer's hero, Odysseus.

title: Odysseus Lies Here?
description: CEPHALONIA, Greece

title: Manlashes, Manscara and Mantyhose
description: USUALLY Im the one musing about the end of men.

title: Lessons From Another War
description: WE talk about generals fighting the last war, said Tim McNulty, who served as foreign editor for The Chicago Tribune during the Iraq war. I think journalists also do.

title: Are You Now and Have You Always Been?
description: What a difference a redistricting can make. As he adjusts to a new, more Democratic district, Representative Timothy Johnson, an Illinois Republican, is trying to back out of the powerful orbit of Grover Norquist, the conservative antitax campaigner who has managed to corral 95 percent of House Republicans into signing a simplistic pledge to never, ever increase taxes.

title: They Have Very Short Memories
description: House Republicans, Senate Democrats and President Obama have found something they can all support: a terrible package of bills that would undo essential investor protections, reduce market transparency and distort the efficient allocation of capital.

title: East Oakland Park May Get a Third Act
description: In Tyrone Carney Park in East Oakland, there are no swings on the playground swing set. Rusted basketball rims loom over a cracked asphalt court, riddled with weeds. The abandoned park has become a dumping ground for discarded couches and plastic lawn furniture.

title: Dickey Hit Hard by Nationals
description: VIERA, Fla. After pitching flawlessly during his first spring training start, R.A. Dickey was hit hard Saturday by the Washington Nationals, giving up five runs in three innings. Dickey needed close to 30 pitches to get out of the first inning, and all the hits against him were hard, sharp liners that went for singles or doubles.

title: Prisons Rethink Isolation, Saving Money, Lives and Sanity
description: PARCHMAN, Miss.  The heat was suffocating, and the inmates locked alone in cells in Unit 32, the states super-maximum-security prison, wiped away sweat as they lay on concrete slab beds.

title: What I Learned From Getting Knocked Around
description: I KNEW nothing about football when I started playing sophomore year in high school, but patient coaches made it clear that the answer to most questions I had about their beautifully complicated sport was that I should run full speed into another human being. Eventually, I stopped raising my hand to ask, in part because my shoulder hurt too much.

title: Obama Plans Big Effort to Build Support Among Women
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas re-election campaign is beginning an intensified effort this week to build support among women, using the debate over the new health care law to amplify an appeal that already appears to be benefiting from partisan clashes over birth control and abortion.

title: Top 10 Tight Ends in Free Agency
description: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

title: 100 Years Ago
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Iceberg! Straight ahead!

title: Security Fears Lead Groups to Rethink Work in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The management at a company that does aid and development work for the American government knows that some of its employees in Afghanistan are keeping weapons in their rooms  and is choosing to look the other way. At another company in the same business, lawyers are examining whether the company can sue the United States Agency for International Development for material breach of contract, citing the deteriorating security in Afghanistan.

title: Eichlers Modernist Homes
description: Joseph Eichler, who is best known for revolutionizing affordable midcentury home design in suburban California, is rarely associated with high-end high-rises. Yet the Summit, a luxury condominium on Russian Hill with big windows and sharp angles, attests to Eichlers contribution as a home developer to San Franciscos skyline.

title: Wright Out for Another Week
description: VIERA, Fla.  David Wright, who has been suffering from an oblique injury, will miss another week of spring training games, Manager Terry Collins said.

title: Beyond Broken Windows
description: JAMES Q. WILSON, who died last week at the age of 80, was unquestionably the pre-eminent political scientist of the last 50 years. Curiously, the commentary surrounding his death has largely focused on his justly famous broken windows theory  and to a lesser extent, his penetrating 1993 book, The Moral Sense  yet these works are only a small part of his extraordinary contribution to sound thinking about government, politics and public policy.

title: Tracing Odysseuss Footsteps
description: My Sunday column is my second and last from my Greece visit, and is a bit out of the ordinary. It essentially tells of a three millennium-old detective story that may now be solved, and I apologize for inflicting my own quixotic interest in Homer on my readers. I feel a bit like the guy in the plane who insists on showing his neighbor photos of his recent trip.

title: Centrist Women Tell of Disenchantment With Republicans
description: As baby showers go, the party Mary Russell attended to celebrate her nieces first child was sweet, with about a dozen women offering congratulations over ice cream and cake.

title: The Hassett Test
description: Mark Thoma catches Kevin Hassett playing for Team Republican; really, no surprise. But Marks catch has me thinking: what, if anything, would make reasonable, moderate conservative intellectuals accept that the GOP no longer offers them a home?

title: Got $100,000? Have a Cookie: Banks Try Luring the Top 10%
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.  Wine and cheese in the vault. After-hours appointments to suit busy schedules. And loads of marble and mahogany with not a teller in sight.

title: On Twitter, Best and Worst #airlinefood Experiences
description: Airline meals can vary, as evidenced by comments from readers who described some of their in-flight meals on Twitter. Many have been sobered by servings of something unrecognizable and colorless on their trays. Others, however, told of creative and flavorful dishes, mostly aboard foreign airlines.

title: Snippets of Saturday at SXSW Interactive
description: Were posting quick updates from South by Southwest Interactive on our brand-new Tumblr. Here are some of Saturdays posts:

title: In Europe, a Tournament With a Big Payday for Women
description: The European Womens Individual Chess Championship, which is being held in Gaziantep, Turkey, has set two precedents: its prize fund is larger than the one for this years mens championship, and it is the first tournament to have a dress code of its own.

title: Suspended Broncos May File a Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for Ryan McBean and D. J. Williams, two of the three Denver Broncos suspended for violating the N.F.L.s drug policy, are likely to file a lawsuit in state court in Colorado as soon as Monday in an attempt to overturn the rulings.

title: Reyes Conspicuous by His Absence
description: VIERA, Fla.  Wheres Jose?

title: Focusing on Pineda, but Not Too Much
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  The new Yankees pitcher Michael Pinedas pitching line was not overly impressive Saturday, but Manager Joe Girardi was pleased with the effort he saw. Pineda threw two and two-thirds innings and allowed one run on four hits, with three walks and one strikeout.

title: Top 10 Defensive Backs in Free Agency
description: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

title: Fastest Over 60 Meters, Gatlin Eyes Gold in 100
description: ISTANBUL  It was not just the gold medal that left Justin Gatlin feeling redeemed at the world indoor track and field championships. It was the time.

title: Revisiting the Big School vs. Little School Debate
description: When you are forced to revisit a previously held belief or even an old memory that has remained dormant for a significant amount of time, it has always fascinated me how there can be an immediate visceral response when given the right prompt, even if that response doesnt necessarily line up with your current way of thinking.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Super Tuesday battlegrounds to stops in Mississippi and Alabama.

title: A Course So Tamed That Even Seven Under Par Is Not a Cause for Joy
description: DORAL, Fla.  Without the nature-powered wind machine to accentuate its piercing blue waters and thick rough, the Blue Monster at Doral Resort is a model not ready for her cover shot. That the course is in dire need of a face-lift was made plain Saturday at the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship when the No. 1 player in the world, Rory McIlroy, produced the best round of the day, a seven-under-par 65, and was dissatisfied.

title: With a Solemn March, the Bowery Mourns Its Tent of Antiquity
description: The big green tent near the Bowery at East Houston Street had been patched so many times that it was now more plastic than canvas. Its purpose was to shield the contents underneath  which on any given day could include 19th-century furniture, World War II-era military patches or what was said to be the head of a mummy  from the elements and who knew what else.

title: Knicks View Chandler as Defenses Partial Cure
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks expect Tyson Chandler back Sunday to help cure some of the defensive issues that, during their 0-4 record on the road last week, undid much of what they accomplished during their Linsanity-fueled seven-game winning streak.

title: For Tar Heels, Last Shot and Next Opponent Are Both a Surprise
description: ATLANTA  North Carolinas Kendall Marshall has been labeled a guard with limited scoring value, and for good reason. He hunts teammates, not shots, and when the shot clock gets to a single digit or it is the end of the game, Marshall is usually passing to other options ahead of him in the offense, like the swingman Harrison Barnes or the 7-footer Tyler Zeller.

title: In G.O.P. Nomination Race, Geography Has Been Destiny
description: Rick Santorums victory in the Kansas caucuses on Saturday wasnt much of a surprise, but his margin was toward the high end of expectations as he took 51 percent of the vote to Mitt Romneys 21 percent. It was the largest margin of defeat for Mr. Romney in caucus or primary to date, although he lost the beauty contest primary in neighboring Missouri by almost as large a margin.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, from the Super Tuesday battlegrounds to stops in Mississippi and Alabama.  Go to the slide show.

title: The Monitors Brave Fellow
description: Henry A. Wise, a lieutenant in the Union Navy, interrupted a meeting of the Cabinet on Sunday, March 10, 1862 with important news for the president. Lt. John L. Worden, who had been injured in battle the day before, was at Wises home. Worden wasnt just any wounded officer: as the commander of the Navys first ironclad, the Monitor, he had taken on the Confederacys own fearsome iron-plated vessel, the Merrimack, in a lengthy duel. During the fighting a shell had exploded outside the Monitor s pilothouse just as Worden was looking out its slit. Lincoln immediately adjourned the discussion, saying he had to go around to see the brave fellow.

title: Corrections: March 11
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Sam A. Myers, Veteran Advance Man, Recovering From Heart Attack
description: Sam A. Myers, well known in Washington as the advance man shepherding Democratic presidents, vice presidents and presidential candidates through their many trips, foreign and domestic, was receiving get-well wishes on Saturday from his current and former charges as he recovered from a major heart attack.

title: For Stosur, a Happy Return to the U.S.
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  This week at the BNP Paribas Open, the 27-year-old Australian Samantha Stosur is playing her first tournament in the United States since stunning Serena Williams, 6-2, 6-3, in the 2011 United States Open final.

title: A Title for Nazareth, but the Celebration Is Bittersweet
description: On a bittersweet Saturday in Queens, Nazareth High of Brooklyn crushed Moore Catholic, 68-46, to capture the championship of the New York State Girls Catholic High School Athletic Association tournament.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 10, 2012

title: For Izzo, Tough Style Is Also a Winning One
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In the corner of a crowded locker room, in a hushed voice, Michigan State forward Adreian Payne sounded ashamed. He wanted desperately to please his coach, Tom Izzo, whose factory-like program specializes in toughness and churns out Final Four appearances, but Payne acknowledged he hadnt yet adjusted to Izzos coaching style.

title: Romney Looks to Illinois Primary in Battle With Santorum
description: With a challenging string of contests in the next week, Mitt Romney is eyeing Illinois as the place to make a stand in his Republican presidential nomination race with Rick Santorum.

title: How India Became America
description: Another brick has come down in the great wall separating India from the rest of the world, Akash Kapur writes in the Sunday Review of The New York Times about Starbucks and Amazon entering the Indian market. Amazon has already started a comparison shopping site; Starbucks plans to open its first outlet this summer.

title: Chris Boneau, Robert Bucci
description: Chris Alan Boneau and Robert Joseph Bucci were married Friday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, a member of the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Ira Rosenblum and Kenneth Karpel
description: Ira Rosenblum and Kenneth Karpel are to be married Sunday at Waters Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum is to officiate.

title: Sharon Mayeri, Matthew Chesler
description: Sharon Joy Mayeri, the daughter of Israella Friedland Mayeri of Brooklyn and Harold Mayeri of Pawling, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Lawrence Chesler, a son of Diane L. Chesler and Evan R. Chesler, both of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake officiated at Bridgewaters, a party space in Manhattan.

title: Sarah Wolff, Jeremy Wien
description: Sarah Eppler Wolff, the daughter of Nancy Eppler-Wolff and John H. Wolff of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Jeremy Scott Wien, a son of Rochelle B. Wien and Robert W. Wien of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Dov Katz officiated at 583 Park Avenue, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Rachel Mercier, Andrew Pascal
description: Rachel Havens Mercier and Andrew Benjamin Pascal were married Friday in the town hall of Cambridge, N.Y., where Janet DeCarlo, its town justice, officiated. On Saturday evening, Matthew Bronson, a friend of the couple, led a Jewish cultural ceremony that incorporated blessings and the breaking of a glass at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Ainsley Fuhr and Orin Kerr
description: Ainsley Fuhr and Orin Samuel Kerr were married Saturday evening at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Michael S. Beals officiated.

title: Abby Cook-Mack, David Sandler
description: Abby Cook-Mack and David James Sandler were married Saturday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Jessica D. Zimmerman officiated.

title: Elizabeth Johanningmeier, Nicholas Fifer
description: Elizabeth Victoria Johanningmeier and Nicholas Duane Fifer were married Saturday evening at the University of South Florida Contemporary Art Museum in Tampa, Fla. David A. Waterman, a friend of the bride who became a notary public for the occasion, officiated.

title: Verna Hsu and Yujin Chung
