description: Verna Chi-Fung Hsu and Yujin David Chung were married Saturday evening at the Fairmont San Jose in San Jose, Calif. Kathy Wilkerson, a Universal Life Minister, officiated.

title: Shannon Stewart and Paul Vierthaler
description: Shannon Stewart and Paul August Vierthaler were married Saturday evening at the Berg Event Space in Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Hubert Neth, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Tegins and Thad Sharp
description: Dr. Elizabeth Eileen OToole Tegins and Thad Tyson Sharp were married Saturday at the Ballinahinch Church in Ballinahinch, Ireland. The Rev. Patrick Burke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Christina Estrada, Daniel Teczar
description: Christina Michelle Estrada and Daniel James Teczar were married Saturday evening at Christ the King Catholic Church in Dallas. Msgr. Donald F. Zimmerman, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Caitlin Holcomb and Matthew Kaprocki
description: Caitlin Morgan Holcomb and Matthew Edward Kaprocki were married Saturday evening at the Southern Museum of Flight in Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Keith H. Lewis, an Anglican priest and a retired Air Force chaplain, officiated.

title: John Blair, Beto Sutter
description: John Ernest Blair and Luiz Roberto Sutter were married Tuesday evening at Out NYC, a hotel in New York. Fran Drescher, the comedian and actress, who is also a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Louisville Wins Title in Bittersweet Glimpse of Big Easts Future
description: The last time that Louisville and Cincinnati met in a league tournament title game, the Cardinals beat the Bearcats in the Metro Conference final in 1981. The three-decade gap, the defunct conference and the far-flung location of the two teams in relation to Madison Square Garden provided a fitting parallel as the Big East peeked into its future Saturday night.

title: Communist Bling: Its All the Rage in China
description: HONG KONG  They arrived at the annual meetings in Beijing  and these were card-carrying Communist Party members, mind you  as if they had just descended from Cleopatras barge, or at least had maxed out their other cards, the platinum ones, at Dior, Vuitton and Herms.

title: U.S. Sergeant Is Said to Kill 16 Civilians in Afghanistan
description: PANJWAI, Afghanistan  Stalking from home to home, a United States Army sergeant methodically killed at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan early on Sunday, igniting fears of a new wave of anti-American hostility, Afghan and American officials said.

title: Top 10 Offensive Linemen in Free Agency
description: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

description: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

description: Many news weeklies this week performed a post-mortem on the assembly election results announced Tuesday for Goa, Manipur, Punjab, Uttar Pradesh and Uttarakhand.

title: Why Speedy Robert Griffin III Must Slow Down
description: Matt Waldman is the author of the Rookie Scouting Portfolio

title: M.L.S. Preview: Five Questions for the Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls will be back in the national spotlight Sunday afternoon when they play Dallas in Frisco, Tex., in the first game to be carried by the NBC Sports Network as part of its new contract with Major League Soccer. (All of the leagues current TV deals expire in 2014, which could make for some interesting musical chairs, but thats a matter for another posting.) In 2011 the Red Bulls logged a league-record 16 ties (and in an odd twist, that record was tied by Chicago!) and narrowly made the playoffs, only to be bounced in the first round by the eventual champion, the Los Angeles Galaxy. Red Bulls management is under the gun to produce more than a win in the Emirates Cup, hosted last summer by Arsenal. Here are five questions they face entering the season:

title: 10 Years of Making Every Penny Count
description: LONDON  Loyalty and longevity are rare traits in the world of professional sports. In Premier League soccer, keeping a team manager who has not won a trophy in 10 years is almost unheard of.

title: Economists And Post-Crisis Policy
description: Henry Farrell and John Quiggin have posted their fascinating paper on the rise and (temporary, I think) fall of Keynesian economics in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

title: Egyptian Military Court Acquits Doctor Accused of Performing Virginity Tests
description: CAIRO  A military court on Sunday acquitted an army doctor who had been accused of performing forced virginity tests on women detained by soldiers when they broke up a street protest a year ago.

title: Game Change and Loyalty
description: On the day after Game Change, which debuted on HBO last night, most conversations are no doubt turning to Sarah Palin.

title: Threats and Killings Striking Fear Among Young Iraqis, Including Gays
description: BAGHDAD  A recent spate of killings and intimidation aimed at gay Iraqis and teenagers who dress in brash Western fashions is sending waves of fear through Iraqs secular circles while casting doubt on the governments will to protect some of its most vulnerable citizens.

title: Shooting in Afghanistan
description: A United States service member left his base and killed at least 16 civilians in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, officials said. Afterward, residents of Panjwai gathered outside the base in protest.

title: Disruptions: TV Makers Ignore Apps at Their Own Peril
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Every night, I get home from work, drop onto the couch and sit there surfing the Web or watching videos on my 3 1/2-inch iPhone screen. My big-screen HDTV sits powered off on the other side of the room.

title: An Anniversary of Heartbreaking Grief in Japan
description: NIHONMATSU, Japan  Nobody knows whether Hiroshi Yokoyamas elderly parents tried to outrun the tsunami that engulfed their home in Namie on the Fukushima coast a year ago.

title: Rivals Call Romney a Weak Choice for G.O.P. Nomination
description: WASHINGTON  With two key Southern primaries on the horizon this week, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich sharpened their attacks against Mitt Romney on Sunday, as Mr. Santorum bluntly declared that his leading rival cant close the deal, and Newt Gingrich called Mr. Romney the partys weakest front-runner since 1920.

title: The Lorax Stays on Top at the Box Office
description: A fuzzy orange cartoon character humiliated Eddie Murphy and one of Pixars top directors at the weekend movie box office. For the second weekend in a row, Dr. Seuss The Lorax (Universal Pictures)  featuring that fuzzy character and the voice of Danny DeVito  was North Americas No. 1 movie. It took in an estimated $39.1 million for a new total of about $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data.

title: All Eyes on Santana
description: 5:01 p.m. | Updated  Johan Santana threw 42 pitches over two and two-thirds innings, 22 of them for strikes, against the Miami Marlins. He gave up two hits and one walk while getting two strikeouts.

title: U.N. Envoy Leaves Syria Empty-Handed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After a second day of meetings with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, a United Nations envoy left Damascus on Sunday without securing a deal to end the nearly year-old conflict, which ground on with heavy shelling in the northern province of Idlib.

title: Wozniackis Golf Viewing Cut Short
description: There are celebrity couples who barely acknowledge theyre together, and then theres Rory McIlroy and Caroline Wozniacki. The two world-class athletes, as perhaps befits a pair whose initial flirtation was conducted on Twitter, are treating their romance as if its an open book.

title: Doomsday Has Its Day in the Sun
description: Theres a new modifier on the TV grid, and we should all be afraid.

title: When Scale Matters
description: Judging from comments on my North Dakota post, theres a lot of confusion about when and why differences in scale make comparisons between economies invalid.

title: Top 10 Linebackers in Free Agency
description: Disclaimer: Remember, roughly 90 percent of free agents are free agents only because their last team did not want them.

title: A.C.C. Observations: Defense, Defense, Defense
description: ATLANTA  Some more notes from the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament:

title: For Baylor, Another Weekend, Another Title
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: Chandler Returns, but With Stars Benched Late, Knicks Keep Losing
description: When time ran out on another halfhearted rally, as the minutes dwindled and the boos rained down, $37 million of star power sat fixed on the Knicks bench, the players expressions as sour as their performance.

title: Why the A.C.C. Tournament Should Get Back to Its Roots
description: ATLANTA  Walking around Philips Arena this week were some former Atlantic Coast Conference stars: Len Elmore, the Maryland center/forward. Mike Gminski, the Duke center. Eric Montross, the North Carolina center. You couldnt help thinking back to when they played, back to when the A.C.C.s core product was basketball.

title: A Few Unusual Suspects Drop By
description: Befuddlement is a common condition among audience members at concerts of contemporary classical music, probably causing some potential listeners to stay away. But is it really such a bad thing to be confused by how a sound is produced, or to wonder why a piece takes the form it does? To the contrary, a concert presented by the Talea Ensemble at the Tenri Cultural Institute on Friday evening showed how perplexity could charm and delight.

title: French Baroque Rays of Light Pierce Lenten Shadows
description: The soprano Montserrat Figueras, who died in November, was an important figure in the early-music world. A singer with an expressive, dark-hued voice, she often performed with her husband, the viola da gamba player Jordi Savall, and their two children.

title: Viewing Impressionism From the Periphery and the Present
description: For orchestras visiting New York standard operating procedure is to bring a program of blockbusters meant to show off the players power and agility, and the firmness of the conductors control. The St. Louis Symphony followed the script in past visits, but since David Robertson took over its podium in 2005, inventive programming has prevailed over showiness.

title: Just a Mom With Play Dates (and a Beretta)
description: There are two salient quirks in The Expats, Chris Pavones novel about Americans abroad. The first is Luxembourg, a place about which Mr. Pavone can be sure most readers know very little. The second is well-calibrated monotony. This books abundant treacheries and tricks arise from the fact that its heroine, Kate Moore, is bored stiff.

title: No Pole-Vault Record, but the Return of a Champion
description: ISTANBUL  On a Sunday afternoon dominated by American athletes, the pole-vault runway was back to being a zone reserved for Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia, just as it was when gold medals were a foregone conclusion, not a point of conjecture.

title: As Fed Officials Prepare to Meet, They Await Clearer Economic Signals
description: WASHINGTON  The scheduled meeting Tuesday of the Federal Reserves policy-making committee is unlikely to resolve the foremost question confronting the central bank: What happens next?

title: NYT at SXSW
description: Jenna Wortham, Brian Stelter, and Alexis Mainland of The Times participate in a Google Hangout with guests from Glancee and Buzzfeed.

title: Ishtar Lands on Mars
description: LOS ANGELES  In 1987, shortly before the release of Ishtar, Columbia Pictures realized the film was going to flop in catastrophic fashion. But rather than cut advertising spending to minimize the financial damage  as the studios top marketer advised  Columbia did the opposite, pouring even more money into ads.

title: A Crusading Suffragist Is Restored to Church Membership
description: To her many admirers, Elizabeth Bartlett Grannis was a humanitarian, social reformer and pioneering suffragist. To the First Church Disciples of Christ, which Grannis had attended faithfully for five decades, she was a disturber of the peace.

title: Exploring Identity and Race Through Two Minds
description: Dean Moss and Reggie Wilson are black. They are American. They are successful, male, midcareer choreographers who have long been engaged in pushing and prodding their art form, seeing where and how it can go.

title: A Few Final Words From Our Pulp Fiction Contestants
description: As we waded through your 500 submissions, there were sentences that, for better or worse, jumped out at us, made the eyes do a double-take, like the sight of a dame that  ahh, never mind.

title: Gaza Fighting Continues, Despite Truce Efforts
description: GAZA  Egypt and Hamas, the Islamic movement that rules Gaza, made efforts to restore calm on Sunday, as cross-border fighting between Israel and smaller Palestinian groups in Gaza simmered for a third day.

title: Wolverine Weekend
description: Volunteers spend a weekend learning to track wolverines across Montana's rugged Helena National Forest.

title: Matches Made in the Wilderness, in the Name of Science
description: HELENA NATIONAL FOREST, Mont.  On most beautiful winter Saturdays, Erika Nunlist, a college freshman, can usually be found backcountry skiing in the Rockies. But Ms. Nunlist chose to spend a recent sparkling day searching for greenish lumps of wolverine excrement.

title: For a Vanderbilt Fan, a Sweet Sunday
description: Seventeen years ago, as a sophomore at Vanderbilt, I covered the Southeastern Conference mens basketball tournament for the student newspaper. We werent very good; in my four years, the Commodores reached the N.C.A.A. tournament once, when I was a senior in 1997. We lost in the first round to Xavier.

title: Stratford Festival Names Artistic Director
description: The Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario announced that Antoni Cimolino would be its next artistic director, starting with the 2013 season. Mr. Cimolino has been a part of the festival for 25 years, starting as an actor before rising through the ranks to his current post as general director. This great theater changed my life as it has changed the lives of countless others in its almost 60 seasons, Mr. Cimolino said in a statement. He will succeed Des McAnuff, who is overseeing the Broadway transfer of the festivals production of Andrew Lloyd Webbers Jesus Christ Superstar to the Neil Simon Theater, currently in previews before its March 22 opening. In his final season as artistic director Mr. McAnuff will direct the festivals productions of Henry V and A Word or Two, starring Christopher Plummer. Referring to Mr. Cimolino, Mr. McAnuff said, He and I know that this will be a graceful and elegant transition.

title: Words of Wisdom From Jeff Bridges
description: The Dude is putting his wisdom on paper. Jeff Bridges, below, the Oscar-winning actor from Crazy Heart who also starred memorably in The Big Lebowski, is writing a book with his friend Bernie Glassman, founder of the spiritual social-action group Zen Peacemakers. The publishers said the book intends to explore the meaning of life, laughter, the movies and trying to do good in a difficult world. Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, is to release the book, tentatively titled The Dude and the Zen Master, this fall. On a movie set I do my best to keep my head and heart open, Mr. Bridges said in a statement. My favorite part of the whole deal is jamming with the other artists, getting to know them, sharing the excitement of what were up to, and inspiring each other. That means intimacy. I look for that in life as well. David Rosenthal, the publisher of Blue Rider Press, called the book a spiritual guide, an entertainment and an exceptional lesson in true friendship.

title: From Clubbed Thumb
description: The Obie Award-winning New York theater company Clubbed Thumb has announced its lineup for the 17th annual Summerworks festival, which will run from May 26 to June 30 at the Here arts center in the South Village. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, is to feature three new plays; Susan Soon He Stantons Takarazuka!!! directed by Lear deBessonet (On the Levee); Ethan Liptons Luther directed by Ken Rus Schmoll (A Map of Virtue); and Peggy Staffords Motel Cherry directed by Meghan Finn (3 2s; or AFA).

title: Untamed and Unabashed
description: Four years ago a British singer named Charli XCX began releasing hilarious, knowing and sometimes absurd electro-pop songs. She poked at the pieties of too-cool downtown girls on Art Bitch and of too-cool rich girls on !Franchesckaar! She tossed off ditties that sounded like adult parodies of childrens music, like I Wanna Be Darth Vader. She sounded world-weary but still lighthearted, a club kid zoned out on Adult Swim cartoons, a Lady Gaga preamble.

title: Sculpture and Mania of a Muse
description: Bad choreography crops up all too often, and yet nobody else today, now that Maurice Bjart and Roland Petit are no longer with us, makes the kind of awful ballet that is Boris Eifmans forte. Ken Russells more sensationalist movies seem like models of restraint beside Mr. Eifmans lurid, overemphatic, far-from-coherent oeuvre. Mr. Eifman flaunts all the worst clichs of psycho-sexo-bio-dance-drama with casual pride while he rushes headlong to commit a whole new set of artistic felonies.

title: The Old Raiders Didnt Need Bounties to Be Brutal
description: OAKLAND, Calif.

title: A Refusal to Take Any Options Off the Keyboard
description: Herbie Hancock didnt leave his funk and electronics behind just because he was booked by Jazz at Lincoln Center. On Friday night at the Rose Theater he led a trio that visited both his acoustic and his plugged-in repertory. Mr. Hancock switched, sometimes within the same tune, between his Fazioli grand piano and a Korg Kronos synthesizer. He was eager to juxtapose the multileveled intricacy of his piano improvisations with quacking, wriggling synthesizer tones, hopping between profundity and comedy.

title: From G.I. Joe to Jim Crow, a Difficult Homecoming
description: Moonlight and magnolias, a Southerner says in Deep Are the Roots, are our oldest clichs. In this play by Arnaud dUsseau and James Gow theyre part of the sweet seductions of a place where the genteel and brutal exist side by side, sometimes in the same person.

title: Santana Remains Sharp in Second Start
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Continuing his recovery from shoulder surgery in 2010, Mets pitcher Johan Santana looked sharp Sunday in his second spring training start.

title: For China, Big Deficit in Trading Last Month
description: SHANGHAI  China said Saturday that its monthly trade deficit reached $31.5 billion in February, its weakest performance in over a decade and the latest indication of slowing growth in the nations economy.

title: A Theater Tied by Heartstrings to the Old Country
description: She sang her usual repertory of tug-your-heartstring staples like Mothers Eyes, Jerusalem of Gold and Long Live the King. And after almost every song people flocked to the lip of the stage to hand Tamara Gverdtsiteli outsized bouquets wrapped in plastic. They moved their lips along with the lyrics. They whistled, shouting from the audience, Tamara, we love you so much. And they wept.

title: Do Electronic Records Cut Health Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: This Years Tony Honors
description: The 2012 Tony Honors for Excellence in the Theater, given to individuals and organizations that are not eligible in the established Tony Award categories for Broadway shows, will go to the musical licensing executive Freddie Gershon; the production supervisor Arthur Siccardi; and the Theater Development Funds Open Doors arts education program, the Tony administration committee is to announce on Monday. Mr. Gershon is being honored for creating the Broadway Junior Collection of Music Theater International, his licensing agency, to provide 30- and 60-minute versions of Broadway musicals for elementary and middle schools to produce. Mr. Siccardi has overseen technical and production needs for more than 200 Broadway shows since 1977, including Annie, Dreamgirls, My One and Only, Sunset Boulevard, Billy Elliot: The Musical, Mamma Mia! and the continuing revival of Chicago. The nonprofit Theater Development Fund, best known for operating the TKTS discount ticket booths, founded Open Doors in 1998 with the playwright Wendy Wasserstein (The Heidi Chronicles). The program recruits theater professionals to be mentors to New York City high school seniors by accompanying them to Broadway and Off Broadway shows and discussing career options in the theater. The honors will be presented at a private cocktail reception on June 9, the evening before the Tony Awards ceremony.

title: Defending Science: An Exchange
description: Last fall, after Michael Lynchs essay Reasons for Reason appeared in The Stone, he began correspondence with the physicist, mathematician and writer Alan Sokal about the nature and limits of scientific rationality. The following exchange is adapted from that original dialogue.

title: Woods Leaves With Leg Injury
description: DORAL, Fla . A week after he posted the best closing round of his pro career to spur talk of a resurgence,Tiger Woods failed to complete the final round of the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship on Sunday, casting doubt on his participation in the Masters next month.

title: Report Shows Depth of the Distress in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  While the European Central Banks emergency loan program late last year helped avoid a banking crisis, there is doubt over whether the action will promote economic growth by encouraging lending to businesses and consumers, according to a new report by the Bank for International Settlements.

title: Legitimate Ticket Resellers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mountain Man
description: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

title: Youth Triumphs in Australia at Surfers Paradise Congress
description: The final of the Open Teams at the Surfers Paradise Congress in Broadbeach, Queensland, Australia, on March 3 was between Liam Milne, Michael Whibley, Andy Hung, Nabil Edgtton and Nye Griffiths from Australia, and Alexander Smirnov from Germany; and Michael Ware from New Zealand, Fiona Brown from England, Jon Sveindal from Norway, Geo Tislevoll, a Norwegian now living in New Zealand, and Tom Hanlon and Hugh McGann from Ireland.

title: Asleep at the Controls
description: THE Fukushima meltdowns, which began a year ago this week, were a disaster  but also, at least in the United States, an opportunity. Everyone was awake and interested. Thoughtful questions, wild speculation and genuine, heartfelt public concern about nuclear safety were everywhere.

title: A Link to the Old Country
description: The Millennium Theater has emerged as the cultural hub for the largely Russian neighborhood of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

title: Cry, the Beloved Constitution
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

title: Changing the Shape of Things
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome back to another week of crossword puzzles! Its always nice to take the first puzzle off the top of the weeks pile and see Lynn Lempels byline.

title: America Is Stealing the Worlds Doctors
description: Kunj Desai, a Zambian-born doctor of Indian descent, now practices in Newark, New Jersey, where salaries are nearly ten times that at home, and he is surrounded by modern facilities.

title: The Field of 68 Includes a Striking Number of Weak Teams
description: As one of the last four teams to earn a bid to last years N.C.A.A. tournament, Virginia Commonwealth was perhaps the biggest beneficiary of the brackets expansion to 68 teams, making an improbable run to the Final Four. The new format, now in its second year, led to a number of low-wattage teams receiving invitations to this years tournament.

title: A Code of Conduct for Content Aggregators
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: An Actor Falls Short of a Star, and Other New York City Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: What Your Bracket Says About You
description: There is a good chance that you will fill out an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament bracket for an office pool sometime in the next three days. There is an even better chance that you spent the last four months focused on your family and career, not glued to ESPN. Therefore, you have only a passing familiarity with most of the teams in the tournament, and your bracket selections are just a series of guesses.

title: Obama a Frequent Flier to 2012 Swing States
description: If there is one thing a president has to do in an election year, it is to find a way to balance official duties with campaign travel. Too much focus on official duties can make an incumbent look isolated and aloof. Too much electioneering risks exposing the president to attacks that he is losing focus on the nations problems.

title: Wily, Elusive Foragers Invade Upstate New York
description: PERU, N.Y.  They roam by night, picking cornstalks clean, making off with apple crops. They have almost no natural predators, but they have razor-sharp tusks and a seemingly bottomless appetite for plants and animals. Their population can triple in one year.

title: Hanging From the Rafters, Lasting Symbols of Success and Pride
description: Dukes Cameron Indoor Stadium has wall-to-wall indoor carpeting, but it is not stretched out on the floor  it is stretched across the rafters.

title: A Strong Debut Amid Talk of the End
description: TAMPA, Fla.  If the Yankees could write their own formula for opening day and beyond, it would probably replicate what happened here Sunday. C. C. Sabathia looked sharp and was not scored upon, and the next pitcher in the game was Mariano Rivera, who threw one perfect inning.

title: Updates From SXSW Interactive, With a Video Chat
description: In between the panel sessions and festival events on Saturday, Jenna Wortham, Brian Stelter and Lexi Mainland of The Times connected with Matt Buchanan, an editor at BuzzFeed, and Andrea Vaccari, the chief executive of the mobile app maker Glancee, to catch up on the goings-on. Watch the video above.

title: New Layer of Content Amid Chaos on YouTube
description: For a glimpse at the next phase in YouTubes evolution, look no further than a stray crutch and a $20 birthday cake for Justin Bieber.

title: Nonfiction Curriculum Enhanced Reading Skills, Study Finds
description: Children in New York City who learned to read using an experimental curriculum that emphasized nonfiction texts outperformed those at other schools that used methods that have been encouraged since the Bloomberg administrations early days, according to a new study to be released Monday.

title: Alone in Public Housing, With a Spare Bedroom
description: After 40 years living in her Manhattan apartment, Shirley Jones has accumulated a lifetime of mementos: pictures of yawning babies, colonies of tiny figurines, photographs of relatives, and a small collection of stuffed animals crowded onto a chair in the living room. Ms. Jones, 70, moved into her apartment, in the Amsterdam Houses on West 63rd Street, with her son when she was 30 years old and has lived there ever since.

title: Lawyer for Banks Accuses MBIA Chief of Insider Trading
description: The nasty litigation between a group of banks and the bond insurer MBIA just got nastier.

title: Health Care Act Offers Roberts a Signature Case
description: WASHINGTON  When Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. takes his usual center seat on the Supreme Court bench on March 26, he will begin presiding over an extraordinary three days of arguments that will determine the fate of President Obamas sweeping health care law.

title: Spotting the Trends, Before They Break Out
description: MARKETERS have long tried to track trends among consumers and then race to capitalize on them. At the turn of the last century, Lillian Russell appeared in advertising for Coca-Cola. The craze for the cowboy character Hopalong Cassidy at the dawn of the television era generated licensed merchandise like lunch boxes and roller skates. And most recently, countless basketball fans went wild for Jeremy Lin.

title: A Site That Aims to Unleash the Scrapbook Maker in All of Us
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Seeking attention for your start-up? You may want to look beyond the Internet-savvy throngs clogging the sidewalks and bars here.

title: Lower Profile, but No Longer Overlooked by N.C.A.A.
description: At his home in suburban Indianapolis on Sunday night, Butler Coach Brad Stevens watched the N.C.A.A. tournament selection show with his wife, his two children and some family friends.

title: A Way Forward on Judicial Ethics
description: Last Tuesday, an alliance of government watchdog groups delivered 100,000 signatures to the Supreme Court along with a letter from hundreds of law professors calling on the justices to voluntarily adopt the code of conduct that applies to all other federal judges and to reform how they handle requests for recusals.

title: Courtside Troupe Seeks Dancers Who Defy Age and Other Stereotypes
description: As she stood in front of a dance studio mirror, Shirley Koehler struggled to keep up with a barrage of instructions from the choreographer: spin and stomp, twirl, nod and flex. And finally, slap your backside.

title: The Nuclear Implementation Study
description: President Obama and his advisers are in the middle of a once-in-a-decade study of the nuclear arsenal and nuclear war plans. For strategic and budgetary reasons, they need to further reduce the number of deployed weapons and the number kept in reserve. If this country can wean itself from its own dependence, it will be safer and will have more credibility in its efforts to contain the nuclear ambitions of Iran, North Korea and others.

title: Labor Leaders Plan to Apply New Clout in Effort for Obama
description: As the A.F.L.-C.I.O. prepares to endorse President Obama on Tuesday, labor leaders say they will mount their biggest campaign effort, with far more union members than ever before  at least 400,000, they say  knocking on voters doors to counter the well-endowed super PACs backing Republicans.

title: What Greece Means
description: So Greece has officially defaulted on its debt to private lenders. It was an orderly default, negotiated rather than simply announced, which I guess is a good thing. Still, the story is far from over. Even with this debt relief, Greece  like other European nations forced to impose austerity in a depressed economy  seems doomed to many more years of suffering.

title: Penguins Rolling While Awaiting Crosby
description: PITTSBURGH  One of the biggest mysteries in hockey is how the Pittsburgh Penguins have done so well for so long without Sidney Crosby, who is considered the worlds best player.

title: Corrections: March 12
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Devils End 5-Game Streak by the Flyers
description: NEWARK  Anton Volchenkov, a Devils defenseman with only one goal this season, formed a 2-on-1 early in the third period Sunday with Ilya Kovalchuk, who had four goals in his previous three games. Philadelphia defenseman Nicklas Grossman wisely leaned toward Kovalchuk.

title: Bigotry on the Playing Field
description: Intolerance seems to be part of the message sent to student-athletes on the sporting fields of Texas. Only under legal pressure and public criticism did the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, which organizes competitions for more than 200 schools, recently agree to accommodate an Orthodox Jewish school and reschedule a basketball game that would have violated the Sabbath.

title: Newark Runner Loses
description: Edward Cheserek of St. Benedicts Prep in Newark had his first loss of the season at the National High School Indoor Track and Field Championships at the Armory in Upper Manhattan. Cheserek lost the mile to Brad Nye of Kaysville, Utah, 4 minutes 8.67 seconds to 4:09.07. Cheserek earlier won the two-mile in 8:50.53.

title: Wall Street Protesters Complain of Police Surveillance
description: On Nov. 17, Kira Moyer-Sims was near the Manhattan Bridge, buying coffee while three friends waited nearby in a car. More than a dozen blocks away, protesters gathered for an Occupy Wall Street day of action, which organizers had described as an attempt to block the streets around the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2012

title: Attack May Derail Effort to Force Taliban Into Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The outrage from the back-to-back episodes of the Koran burning and the killing on Sunday of at least 16 Afghan civilians imperils what the Obama administration once saw as an orderly plan for 2012: to speed the training of Afghan forces so that they can take the lead in combat missions, all while drawing the Taliban into negotiations to end more than a decade of constant war.

title: For the 76ers, Strength in Numbers, Not in Stars
description: An 8-foot pull-up jump shot from a middling power forward after nice interior ball movement may sound more like good offense in a recreational league than a rally-killing play in the star-laden N.B.A.

title: Founding Family Decides to Leave Crystal Cathedral
description: GARDEN GROVE, Calif.  After decades at the pulpit here, the family of the Rev. Robert H. Schuller has cut its ties with the Crystal Cathedral, the Orange County megachurch he founded.

title: At Lunch, Bloomberg and Obama Discuss Future
description: They traded thoughts about education, ruminated on the state of immigration and discussed the federal deficit.

title: Confession Spun Across the Miles
description: He cannot stop talking, this stranger on a train. And though much of what he says isnt pleasant, you cant stop listening, either. There is, after all, something mesmerizing about confession in a smoky railroad car, delivered by someone youll never see again.

title: Young Arms and Curveballs: A Scientific Twist
description: For decades, it has been an article of faith for parents of young pitchers: Do not let them throw curveballs. The reason was simple. Contorting elbows  all in the service of ever more competitive baseball at ever younger ages  puts more strain on the joint than arms can handle.

title: Boys Death a Homicide; Man Charged
description: The death of a 23-month-old Brooklyn boy on Saturday has been ruled a homicide, and the companion of his mother has been arrested and charged in the case, the authorities said Sunday.

title: Familiarity With Drugs Helps a Group Speak for Users
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a couple of old desks, a beat-up couch and an off-white white board, the office space at 149 Turk Street, in this citys seedy Tenderloin district, is hardly remarkable. A collection of worn detective novels sits on the bookshelf, a couple of American flags hang limply from the wall and a coffee machine constantly percolates in the back kitchen.

title: Late Goal Jolts Rangers Out of Their Slump
description: In the final seconds of overtime, with the Rangers on the power play, Brad Richards would not have been faulted if he decided to shoot the puck. He had the hot hand, having already scored two goals to help carry the Rangers to overtime against the Islanders.

title: Commenting on Congress
description: There are Web sites that cover the actions and inactions of Congress. And there are Web sites that let voters contact their members of Congress and comment. CQ Roll Call wants to bridge the two.

title: Latest Stress Tests Are Expected to Show Progress at Most Banks
description: In another milestone in the banking industrys recovery from the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve this week will release the results of its latest stress tests, which are expected to show broadly improved balance sheets at most institutions.

title: The Timeless Torches
description: A dance troupe tied to the New York Liberty of the W.N.B.A. held tryouts.

title: Buckeyes Guard Has Mind Wired for Defense
description: Aaron Craft was sitting in math class during his junior year at Liberty-Benton High School in Findlay, Ohio, when he noticed the teacher had written 60 decimals from the mathematical constant, pi, on the chalkboard. Craft, who says he can retain information remarkably well, typed the number into his calculator and began to study.

title: Security Forces Kill at Least 5 in China
description: BEIJING  Two outbursts of violence involving fatal shootings by security forces took place last week in areas of China where ethnic tensions are running high, according to weekend reports by a Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia.

title: Tight G.O.P. Primaries Suggest Less-Predictable South
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  They stood beneath a Saturn V rocket, baby-carrying mothers, cross-armed men, workers in coveralls and financial planners, listening as Rick Santorum told them who they were and why they mattered.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/12/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/12/2012

title: New Internet TV Network to Feature Larry King
description: Carlos Slim Hel, the Mexican billionaire, is financing an Internet television network called Ora.tv that will feature Larry King, the former CNN interviewer, in a return to the interviewers chair.

title: Henry Doesnt Like Losing, or Questions About Losing
description: When Thierry Henry scored in the first game of his off-season loan to Arsenal, he looked as if he would have been willing to stand around for hours, hugging each and every member of the crowd of nearly 60,000.

title: Wildcats Blocks Induce Headaches
description: Anthony Davis, a freshman center for top-seeded Kentucky, has witnessed it often. An opponent maneuvers into the lane  Daviss lane  and his eyes start darting around like pinballs.

title: A Video Campaign and the Power of Simplicity
description: EVEN as the Internet era has accelerated the news cycle, sometimes to mere minutes, there is still one idea that holds true: you need a lash before you can have a backlash.

title: Bid for Grain Operator in Canada Sets Up Fight
description: OTTAWA  Viterras announcement late on Friday that it has become the subject of possible takeover bids has prompted investor interest and may lead to political controversy within Canada this week.

title: Killings Add to Worries at Soldiers Home Base
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  It has been just four months since a military jury on this military base convicted the ringleader of a rogue Army unit that shot Afghans for sport. In 2011, at least 12 soldiers here committed suicide. Last week, Senator Patty Murray criticized a military hospital here for overturning 285 diagnoses of post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: Lawrence Anthony, Baghdad Zoo Savior, Dies at 61
description: Lawrence Anthony, who abandoned a career in insurance and real estate to play Noah to the worlds endangered species, most spectacularly in rushing to the smoldering Baghdad Zoo after the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, died on March 2 in Johannesburg. He was 61.

title: Leftist Party Wins in Slovakia Parliamentary Election
description: BERLIN  Voters in Slovakia gave the left-wing former prime minister Robert Fico a sweeping mandate to return to power after less than two years in opposition, as results released Sunday showed that his party won a landslide victory in the parliamentary election on Saturday.

title: Russian Activists See Political Reprisal in Court Case
description: MOSCOW  Just a day after the latest, and possibly last, of the large protest rallies of the election season in Russia, prosecutors in a district court in Moscow filed formal charges on Sunday against the husband of one of the protest movements leaders, stirring fears of politically motivated legal reprisals.

title: Military Points to Risks of a Syrian Intervention
description: WASHINGTON  Despite growing calls for the United States to help stop the bloodshed in Syria, senior Pentagon officials are stepping up their warnings that military intervention would be a daunting and protracted operation, requiring at least weeks of exclusively American airstrikes, with the potential for killing vast numbers of civilians and plunging the country closer to civil war.

title: For Creators of Games, a Faint Line on Cloning
description: In any commercialized art form, be it movies, literature or fashion, the creators often tread a fine line between inspiration and shameless copying. Some small video game makers say that line seems to have all but disappeared.

title: Quiet Tar Heel Knows How to Lead
description: In a program with a history of flashy and outsize personalities, North Carolina forward Tyler Zeller prefers to operate quietly.

title: Word of the Day | outstrip
description: outstrip \aut-strip\ verb

title: Stairs at Home Remain a Childhood Hazard
description: When Chris Garbrandts 6-month-old son, Will, started crawling last October, she realized the stairs in her split-level home in Nashport, Ohio, were an obvious hazard.

title: Jay McMullen, CBS Investigative Journalist, Dies at 90
description: Jay McMullen, whose career as an investigative journalist for CBS News included early uses of hidden cameras and undercover reporting, died Saturday at a hospice in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for February and business inventories for January (Tuesday); import prices for February and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for February and the Philadelphia Fed index for March (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

title: Marquette Star Sees a Challenge in an Award
description: When the Marquette senior forward Jae Crowder attended the Big Easts preseason media day in New York last fall, he was a bit stunned to learn that he had received honorable-mention all-conference recognition.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Use of Public Transit Grew in 2011, Report Indicates
description: In another indication that more people are getting back to work, Americans took 200 million more rides last year on subways, commuter trains, light-rail systems and public buses than they did the year before, according to a new report by a leading transit association.

title: Selection Day: Photo Replay
description: A look at the celebrations and heartbreaks of college basketballs selection day.

title: Sarkozy, in Rousing Talk, Takes Conservative Stands
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy, trailing in opinion polls six weeks before the election, gave a rousing address to some 50,000 supporters on Sunday, striking strongly conservative notes on immigration, Islam and protectionism.

title: Greek Leaders Turn Focus to Preparing for Elections
description: ATHENS  With the ink not yet dry on a complex agreement to write down more than $130 billion of Greek debt, Greeces political leaders leaped into full campaign mode on Sunday to prepare for national elections expected in late April or early May.

title: Photo Replay: March 11
description: A look at the day in sports, from dog sled racing in Alaska to wrestling in Serbia.

title: The Reproduction of Privilege
description: Instead of serving as a springboard to social mobility as it did for the first decades after World War II, college education today is reinforcing class stratification, with a huge majority of the 24 percent of Americans aged 25 to 29 currently holding a bachelors degree coming from families with earnings above the median income.

title: An Update on New York Redistricting
description: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: At the Intersection of Politics, Religion and Government

description: Pete Thamel, The New York Times college basketball reporter, offers his predictions on the mens N.C.A.A. tournament Final Four.

title: Why Not a Massacre Tribunal in Afghanistan?
description: HONG KONG  An arrest, a presidential apology, local outrage and anger, a plea for calm and the promise of investigations  thats the usual rapid-reaction scenario after incidents like the apparent slaughter of 16 Afghan civilians, 9 of them children, by an American sergeant.

title: The Good Wife Revisits Some Core Themes
description: Sex, lies and real estate: it was a return to the bedrock themes of Season 1 on Long Way Home, Sunday nights episode of The Good Wife on CBS.

title: An Indigenous Language With Unique Staying Power
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  Legislators on the floor of Congress deliver speeches in it. Lovers entwined on Asuncins park benches murmur sweet nothings with its high-pitched, nasal and guttural sounds. Soccer fans use it when insulting referees.

title: Keeper of Islamic Flame Rises as Egypts New Decisive Voice
description: CAIRO  For more than a dozen years, Khairat el-Shater guided his family of 10 children, his sprawling business empire and Egypts largest Islamist movement, the Muslim Brotherhood, all from a prison cell.

title: Can Sarkozy, the Candidate, Make Voters Forget Sarkozy, the President?
description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the incumbent French president, has been fighting a seemingly uphill battle for re-election. Polls put him behind his leading challenger, Franois Hollande, the Socialist candidate. And even Mr. Sarkozy has conducted himself at times as if the race was already lost. He made bizarre remarks in late January to journalists, ostensibly off the record, where he seemed negative, even morose, about his chances, and last week he was talking again about losing.

title: News Quiz | March 12, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays newspaper.

title: CNN Is Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Mashable
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  CNN, a unit of Time Warner, and the social news Web site Mashable are in advanced talks that may lead to an acquisition of the site, three people briefed on the talks said.

title: March 12, 1947 | Truman Doctrine Announced
description: On March 12, 1947, in a speech before a joint session of Congress, President Harry S. Truman asked Congress to grant economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey to help those countries resist Communism. The speech established what became known as the Truman Doctrine, a policy to support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or by outside pressures.

title: An Afghan Comes Home to a Massacre
description: PANJWAI, Afghanistan  Displaced by the war, Abdul Samad finally moved his large family back home to this volatile district of southern Afghanistan last year. He feared the Taliban, but his new house was nestled near an American military base, where he considered himself safe.

description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the City Room blog post On the Train, Tap Dancing to Pay for College

title: Four Mao Too Many
description: BEIJING  Last Wednesday I tried to close my bank account. I wont pretend that the Bank of China is the most Orwellian institution in the world, but in terms of human suffering inflicted by bureaucracy, it has to make the long list.

title: Fantasy Focus: On the Outside Looking In
description: Each spring we seem to see multiple guys who appear to be no-brainers for their teams lineups or rotations, but for whatever reason (overpaid veterans ahead of them, lack of experience, etc.), they are left on the bench or in Class AAA to start the season. In these cases, just remember this mantra: talent always wins out in the end. The end may not come until May or June, but it will come. Lets look at a few of these guys.

title: Massacre Is Reported in Homs, Raising Pressure for Intervention in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian opposition activists said on Monday that soldiers and pro-government thugs had rounded up scores of civilians in the devastated central city of Homs overnight, assaulted men and women, then killed dozens of them, including children, and set some bodies on fire. Syria immediately denied responsibility.

description: 2:41 p.m. | Updated Stanford University has published an interview with Hazel Markus, one of the authors of the study, about the impact of college culture on first-generation students.

description: In January, Alan Krueger, chairman of President Barack Obamas Council of Economic Advisers, gave an important policy address in Washington in which he addressed the growing problem of inequality in America, an issue that has come to define the presidents re-election campaign.

title: How Important Is It to Have a Drivers License?
description: Long a symbol of new-found freedom and a quintessential rite of passage, many teens dream of obtaining their drivers license as soon as they are eligible. Does that describe you? Do you haveor wantyour license? Do your friends? If you live in a big city or other place where few people have cars, are there other independence-related rites of passage that compare to getting ones drivers license? Has their relevance changed over time?

title: Poll: Santorum and Romney Remain Tied
description: Republican primary voters across the country continue to be divided over Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, a split between the front-runners that has remained relatively unchanged over the last month.

title: 2 Video Web Sites in China Plan a Merger
description: SHANGHAI  Youku, a leading Chinese online video Web site, is buying its biggest domestic competitor, Tudou, in an acquisition valued at $1.1 billion.

title: China Talks of More Lending but Less Currency Growth
description: BEIJING  As China seeks a soft landing for its bubble-prone economy, senior economic officials said on Monday that they might encourage bank lending, while also hinting that the countrys currency might not appreciate as rapidly as it has in recent years  a contentious issue in the United States presidential election this year.

title: Daily Report: Pinterests Low-Key Approach
description: Tech start-ups are thronging to the South by Southwest Interactive conference in Austin, Tex., hoping to jump-start their new businesses by cozying up to Silicon Valley venture capitalists and influential bloggers. But Jenna Wortham reports in Mondays New York Times that they might do better to study the more low-key approach of Pinterest, the hottest start-up of the moment.

title: If Cutting Carbon Emissions Isnt Working, Whats Next?
description: What if it is too late to save the climate by cutting greenhouse gas emissions? What if the amount of carbon dioxide already added to the atmosphere by human activity is so great that it is going to produce big temperature changes no matter what, with big shifts in rainfall and in ocean chemistry?

title: The Closet Question: Who Would Wear This Stuff?
description: Those who know Jessica Simpson and Nicole Richie just from their less-intellectual pursuits might be surprised to learn, through the new NBC series Fashion Star, that they can actually sound quite smart when in their element. Heres another surprise delivered by this addictive little show, which has its premiere Tuesday night: Project Runway didnt exhaust the possibilities of fashion-designer television.

description: A top investor in the Sealy Corporation is pushing to remake the board of the mattress maker, taking aim at a single shareholder, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: A Reminder of the Danger of City Streets

A woman named Margaret Myers was walking home in East New York, Brooklyn, a few nights ago when she was run over by a car as she crossed a street. Ms. Myers died later in the hospital.

title: Pepsi Chief Shuffles Management to Soothe Investors
description: Indra K. Nooyis vision of PepsiCo as a company that sells nutritional products  not just sodas and salty chips  has been hailed as a sound long-term strategy by management consultants and nutritionists almost since her arrival at the company nearly six years ago.

title: Monday Reading: All-Inclusive Resorts Get More Sophisticated
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Iranian Ceremony to Honor Separation Director Is Canceled
description: A ceremony in Iran to honor the Academy Award-winning director Asghar Farhadi was canceled on Monday after the authorities there denied permission for the event, The Associated Press reported.

title: Trustee Sought for Dynegy Bankruptcy
description: The United States trustee has filed a motion seeking the appointment of a trustee in the Dynegy Holdings bankruptcy case, citing gross mismanagement by current management.

title: Leading Off: Sharpen Your Pencils
description: Today is the official N.C.A.A. tournament day to exhale, which any day now will have an official corporate sponsor. Of course, if you have any rooting interests in what is now called the First Four, this cannot be a long exhale because the games start Tuesday. But even though the N.C.A.A. can monkey with its format, it cannot accelerate the basic timetable, which says the tournament does not start until your bracket says it does. And that would be Thursday. So go ahead and throw a few inhales in with the exhale.

title: Slowdown in China Weighs on Wall St.
description: Stocks were mixed on Monday in light trading as investors weighed whether an economic slowdown in China could lead to an easing of monetary policy.

title: The Trials of Kozlov
description: MOSCOW  A few hundred people tried to save a man on Sunday. They came to Presnensky court in central Moscow, filled the courtroom, the lobby in front of it and the space outside on the street. They were of different ages, well-known writers and entertainers as well as college students and office workers. Many of them had met one another during the protests of the last three months  which, for now, have moved to this courthouse.

title: Losing the Belt
description: A number of people have asked me for a quick, easy explanation of the difference between a government and a family  basically, whats wrong with the argument that when times are tough the government should tighten its belt.

title: Miller Buckfire Hires Restructuring Executive
description: Miller Buckfire, a boutique investment bank, moved to bolster its restructuring practice, announcing on Monday that it had hired Ron Kubick as a managing director.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: What John Carter Says About Hollywood, and Sharing Credit Online
description: The Walt Disney Studios sci-fi movie John Carter was a big bust this weekend, Brooks Barnes reports in an article with a headline that says it all  Ishtar Lands on Mars. The North American box office total of $30.6 million means that Disney is likely to have to write down its losses on the movie, which cost an estimated $350 million to make and market. Why did Disney keep spending to market John Carter when it was clear that the film would not be successful, as Columbia Pictures did in 1987 for Ishtar? The relationships.

title: What Were Reading
description: Al Jazeera: On the need for a stable food supply in Egypt, where people eat more bread than anywhere else in the world.   Julia Moskin

description: Good morning. It will be a beautiful day in New York City, mostly sunny with highs in the upper 60s.

title: Differing Schools of Thought, Differing Styles of Play
description: POTSDAM, Germany  Womens soccer in the United States has always been at the top of the game. The most recent Womens World Cup, however, showed that the womens game is developing strong teams all over the world.

title: Monday Motorsports: Tony Stewart Earns First Sprint Cup Win of 2012
description: Tony Stewart won early races in the 2011 Sprint Cup chase by managing his fuel supply as other frontrunners wantonly burned through theirs. On Sunday in Las Vegas, Stewart, the defending champion, did not conserve his gas; he stepped on it to preserve a late-race advantage over Jimmie Johnson.

title: Telling the Story of New Yorks Hip-Hop Scene, Clip by Clip
description: Ralph McDaniels punched the pause button on the big flat-screen television in his Long Island studio.

title: Stroke Victim Wins Right to Seek Legal Euthanasia
description: LONDON  A British stroke victim paralyzed from the neck down and suffering from so-called locked-in syndrome won the right on Monday to seek changes in a law that would enable a doctor to end what he has called intolerable life without risking murder charges.

title: Citi Names Peter Tague Co-Head of Mergers
description: Citigroup has named Peter Tague co-head of the banks global mergers and acquisitions team, a promotion that comes as the banks advisory business struggles to compete with those of other Wall Street giants.

title: A Hacker Charms and Disappoints
description: Skilled, profane and bombastic, the hacker who called himself Sabu had loyalists and critics. He also had admirers who marveled at his antics from afar, even as they disdained his tactics. That admiration helped explain the attraction of the Anonymous movement that Sabu came to represent.

title: For Duluth, a Fourth Consecutive Trip to the Final Five
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: On Our Radar: Saluting a Colossus of Chemistry
description: Accolades flow in for F. Sherwood Rowland, who won the Nobel Prize in chemistry two decades after reporting that chlorofluorocarbons were destroying the ozone layer. He died on Saturday at age 84. He saved the world from a major catastrophe, a dean at the University of California, Irvine, says. [The Christian Science Monitor]

title: Murrays Struggles at Indian Wells Continue
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Despite being able to beat No. 1 Novak Djokovic only eight days earlier in Dubai (albeit in warmer, faster conditions), No. 4 Andy Murray of Britain crashed out of the BNP Paribas Open in his first match, losing, 6-4, 6-2, in the second round Saturday night to 92nd-ranked Guillermo Garca-Lpez of Spain.

title: Business Day Live | March 12, 2012
description: Stephen Gallagher, chief market strategist of Socit Gnrale, on market risk from Europe and what the results of stress tests might mean for the banking industry.

title: Belle on Wheels
description: If theres a barometer of the rise of urban cycling, its the proliferation of bike-share programs. Just ask Alison Cohen, president of Alta Bicycle Share, which is opening New Yorks 10,000-bike system this summer. Right now most New Yorkers think, Should I take the subway? Should I take a cab? Should I walk?  Cohen says. We want to make cycling the fourth option. Its already an option in Milan, home to the designer Marta Ferri, pictured here on one of the elegant bikes from that citys program and in clothes from her namesake label. For two and a half euros, visitors can buy a daily subscription to Milans BikeMi program on its Web site, where a station map locates available bicycles and parking spots, updated in real time. Milan is flush with bike shops as well. Ferri recommends Rossignoli, for a selection of traditional Italian bikes, and Turbolento, for an expert tuneup. She also suggests cruising the bike lane that surrounds the 95-acre Parco Sempione. Dont forget to explore narrow streets and alleys for glimpses of private gardens, Ferris adds. Milan is a secret city. Most of her beauty is hidden.

title: For Northwestern, One More Year (Thats 74 Straight) Without a Bid
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  For the first time in the 74-year history of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Northwestern mens basketball team found itself on the bubble on Selection Sunday. For the 74th consecutive year, the Wildcats, the only team from a major conference to have never received a bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament, were not among the teams selected.

title: Brooklyn Museum to Honor First Women
description: On April 18, as part of the fifth anniversary of the Brooklyn Museums Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, the museum will present the First Awards, given to 15 women who were first in their fields. Among the honorees are Sandra Day OConnor; Jessye Norman; Toni Morrison; Connie Chung; the choreographer and director Susan Stroman; Faye Wattleton, a former president of Planned Parenthood; and Chief Wilma Pearl Mankiller, the first female chief of the Cherokee Nation.

title: A Surgeons Call to Duty
description: Dr. Jacques Brs, a 71-year-old French surgeon, smuggled himself into Homs, Syria, to treat the wounded in a makeshift hospital.

description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, The Behavior Gap, was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

title: Business Day Live: Market Risk From Europe
description: Stephen Gallagher, chief market strategist of Socit Gnrale, on market risk from Europe and what the results of stress tests might mean for the banking industry.

title: French Surgeon, 71, Saves Lives in Syria
description: PARIS  At the age of 71, Dr. Jacques Brs, a veteran of war zones, left his comfortable Paris life last month to smuggle himself into Homs, the center of the Syrian revolt, to tend to the wounded and the sick.

title: State of Utah Says It Is a Happy Backer of John Carter
description: LOS ANGELES  Nothing highlights the economic puzzlement of state-supported filmmaking like a good, old-fashioned megaflop. This mornings example: Walt Disneys John Carter.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Inside 'The Cabin in the Woods'
description: From SXSW, Drew Goddard, the director and co-writer of The Cabin in the Woods, discusses his work.

title: The Case for Agents
description: Chances are, its not going to turn out well for Nerlens Noel, the subject of Pete Thamels powerful and brilliantly reported article in Sundays Times. Noel is a 610 high school basketball star who is highly coveted by at least half a dozen of the major college basketball powers. The 17-year-old son of working-class Haitian immigrants, he could be worth $10 million in about 16 months when he is eligible for the 2013 N.B.A. draft, writes Thamel.

title: Grilled Fruit With Ginger Syrup
description: Mark Bittman brushes grilled banana, star fruit and pineapple with homemade ginger syrup.

title: Video: Unlocking The Cabin in the Woods
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In The Cabin in the Woods, a group of attractive young people head to, as you might guess, a cabin in the woods. But you probably wont guess what happens next, and the filmmakers hope those who have seen wont tell. The movie, which was co-written by Buffy creator Joss Whedon and Lost writer Drew Goddard, may best be classified as a horror film, but has a fun time tweaking that genres conventions.

title: The Minimalist: Skewered Grilled Fruit With Ginger Syrup
description: Grilled fruit is unusual enough, but when you brush it with ginger syrup you get something really exciting. I learned this recipe from the chef Johnny Earles on the Emerald Coast of Florida (affectionately known as the Redneck Riviera) almost 25 years ago, and first wrote about it in 1998. He used pineapple, banana and star fruit (which looks more exciting than it tastes), but you can use any fruit that you can grill, indoors or out: stone fruit and melons would be nice, mangoes would be fantastic (the firmer the better) and apples and pears would make this a wonderful dish for fall.

title: Europe Must Defend Itself
description: After President Barack Obamas announcement this year of significant changes to the U.S. defense strategy, the world has mostly focused on the shift toward Asia and the Pacific. However. this is only one aspect of the new U.S. posture. It also has a great impact from a European defense point of view, as senior American strategists and NATO officials told me during the meeting of NATO defense ministers in Brussels last month.

title: Brasserie Pushkin, a Lavish Russian Arrival
description: Andrey Dellos, who on Tuesday will open an elaborate Russian restaurant on West 57th Street called Brasserie Pushkin, founded Caf Pushkin in Moscow in 1999 to resolve a puzzle that had confounded visitors to that city, and even some locals, for 35 years.

title: BATS Global Markets Aims to Price I.P.O. at $16 to $18
description: BATS Global Markets, the third-largest stock exchange operator in the United States, said it planned to price its initial public offering at $16 to $18 a share, according to a filing submitted on Monday. At the midpoint of that range, BATS is on track to raise $107 million at a market value of $810 million.

title: The Billionaire List Wars
description: A game of billionaire one-upmanship is raging  not between moneyed barons themselves, but over who is counting them, and how.

title: In China, Part of Railway Collapses Despite Test Runs
description: BEIJING  Chinas troubled state-run rail system suffered another setback with news reports Monday that a section of railway that already had undergone test runs has collapsed.

title: A Luxury Condo Building With Views of the Skyline, and the Prison Next Door
description: If you want to live at 100 11th Avenue, a luxury condominium building in West Chelsea with a fancy architectural pedigree, it will probably cost you a couple of million dollars, or at least $10,000 monthly rent. For your grand fee, you will get wide open vistas of the Manhattan skyline and views of the Hudson River all the way down to the Statue of Liberty.

title: Anti-Incumbent Sentiment Fuels Primary Fights in Deep South
description: Most of the attention in the Deep South may be on the Republican presidential race, but some surprises could be in store for the unsettled House delegations from Alabama and Mississippi, whose members are facing primary challenges on Tuesday.

title: Numberplay: Einsteins Riddle
Image of the Day: March 12
An Interview With Marc Puig
description: The chief executive of the beauty and fragrance group Puig talks about the challenge of bringing fragrances to emerging markets, the success of mass-market scents and more.

title: Bailout Watchdogs Criticize A.I.G. Tax Breaks
description: A special tax provision granted to the American International Group during the financial crisis is drawing attention from the former watchdogs who oversaw the government bailout programs.

title: Really? Questions About French Pine Bark
description: THE FACTS

title: Springsteen Tops Charts in Britain
description: Bruce Springsteen has still got it as far as the British are concerned. His new album, Wrecking Ball (Columbia), was the top-selling long-play recording in the United Kingdom last week, according to the Official Charts Company. It was the ninth time Mr. Springsteen, 62, has scored a No. 1 album in Britain, going back to Born in the U.S.A. in 1984.

title: Are Apps That Connect to Potential Friends Nearby a Hit or a Miss?
description: 12:58 p.m. | Updated to reflect that two of the services have promised updates on their users.

title: By Request | Cleanse in a Kit
description: Whats Hot: David Kirsch Ultimate Detox Kit

title: In Appeal, W.T.O. Upholds a Decision Against Boeing
description: The World Trade Organizations appellate body affirmed on Monday that Boeing had received at least $5 billion in improper subsidies from the United States government to develop its 787 Dreamliner and other jet models, giving it an unfair advantage over its European rival, Airbus.

title: Brooklyn Fare Plans a Manhattan Outpost
description: The neighborhood between 34th and 42nd Streets around Tenth Avenue had better get itself a name.

title: Justice Dept. Blocks Texas on Photo ID for Voting
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments civil rights division on Monday blocked Texas from enforcing a new law requiring voters to present photo identification at the polls, contending that the law would disproportionately suppress turnout among eligible Hispanic voters.

title: Sears, Once Outfitter of Westward Expansion, Now Stocks Saris
description: Long before chants of think global, buy local hit the airwaves, Richard Warren Sears and Alvah C. Roebuck created Americas first major mail-order catalog store, Sears, Roebuck & Co. by shipping goods from Chicago to rural America in the late 1800s. Farmers rejoiced as their sewing machines and flour arrived for half the price offered by small town merchants.

title: Bank Officials Cited in Churn of Foreclosures
description: Managers at major banks ignored widespread errors in the foreclosure process, in some cases instructing employees to adopt make-believe titles and speed documents through the system despite internal objections, according to a wide-ranging review by federal investigators.

title: Stairs: A Childhood Hazard, and an Easy Fix
description: Over on the Well blog, Anahad OConnor reports on a recent study in the journal Pediatrics showing that stairs pose a major hazard in the home for children:

title: Santorum Says Romneys Delegate Lead Will Fade as the Contest Continues
description: 9:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Readers Street Style: All Black
description: The best of our readers street fashion for the week of March 5.

title: Sleepless, Bored and in Pain, a Patient Watched
description: Just when it seems long past time for the age of memoir to be over  just when it seems impossible that any ailing person with literary inclinations could find anything new to say about illness, and the list of not-to-be-missed patients are people too books should be closed and locked  yet another book comes along.

title: Would You Be O.K. With a Prison as a Neighbor?
description: New Yorkers are accustomed to living with extremes, whether its the economic diversity of the 6 train at rush hour, or the way a neighborhood can flip from glitz to grit in the space of one block.

title: The Mississippi and Alabama Primaries
description: As the Republican campaign rolls into a state-by-state battle for delegates, Rick Santorums victories on Tuesday night elevated and strengthened his candidacy.

title: Two Cheers for Double Standards
description: What is a double standard? Its a double standard when you condemn an opponent for doing or saying something you would approve or excuse if it were said or done by one of your buddies. The double standard that is in the news these days concerns Rush Limbaugh, who called Sandra Fluke, a law student at Georgetown, a slut and prostitute because she told Congress that her universitys health plan should cover the cost of contraceptives.

title: Solyndra Is Blamed as Clean-Energy Loan Program Stalls
description: More than $16 billion in loans authorized five years ago by Congress to develop fuel-efficient vehicles has yet to be disbursed, with applicants for the money complaining that the Energy Department is crippling plans for greener cars and trucks at a time of rising gas prices.

title: Artifacts Show Sophistication of Ancient Nomads
description: Ancient Greeks had a word for the people who lived on the wild, arid Eurasian steppes stretching from the Black Sea to the border of China. They were nomads, which meant roaming about for pasture. They were wanderers and, not infrequently, fierce mounted warriors. Essentially, they were the other to the agricultural and increasingly urban civilizations that emerged in the first millennium B.C.

title: The Miso Primer
description: Most people have had miso one of two ways: in soup (that probably accounts for 95 percent of its use in the United States) or with fish thats been marinated in the stuff. As my recent piece on miso discusses, there are many more uses than that. But you might want a tiny bit more detail than I offered in print before you get started. Here are some of the basics.

title: Images of Afghan Victims Spread Rage at U.S. Following Massacre
description: Updated | 1:54 p.m. As my colleagues Taimoor Shah and Graham Bowley report, following the rampage killing of at least 16 civilians, 9 of them children, by an American soldier in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, Afghans posted graphic images of the victims on blogs and social networking sites.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Investigating a Mystery Illness
In Zoll Sale, a Rare Big Mandate for Brown Brothers Harriman
description: Little about Asahi Kaseis $2.2 billion deal for Zoll Medical seemed surprising when it was announced on Monday.

title: Those Not-So-Crazy Republicans
description: My column on Sunday argued that if the Republican electorate were really as bonkers and self-destructive as many journalists have made it out to be, then Mitt Romney probably wouldnt have a near-lock on the partys nomination. Rubbish, retorts Jonathan Chait: Romney is only winning because hes running against uncharismatic has-beens with no organization, because hes routinely outspent his opposition four-to-one or more, and because hes routinely tried to outflank his opponents on the right. Given enough institutional advantages and enough pandering, in other words, even a sane man can persuade lunatics to vote for him.

title: Hulu Announces a Deal for Selling Its Original Shows Overseas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Acting just like a television network, the online video Web site Hulu is joining with a third-party distributor to sell its original shows overseas.

title: Google to Announce Venture With Belgian Museum
description: PARIS  Google, which organizes the worlds information digitally, is linking up with a precursor that aimed to do something similar, on paper.

title: Reasons That Vitamin D May Matter
description: At least once a week, someone, usually a woman over 50, asks me about vitamin D. Perhaps a routine checkup has revealed a deficiency, prompting the doctor to recommend an over-the-counter supplement or, in severe cases, large prescription doses to correct the problem.

title: TimesCast | March 12, 2012
description: Details emerge about the attack in southern Afghanistan by an American soldier that left at least 16 civilians dead | A French surgeon recalls volunteering in the Syrian city of Homs.

title: Showtime Sets Return Dates for Homeland and Dexter
description: In the department of much-buzzed-about cable serials that dont take 17 months between seasons, Showtime said on Monday that new episodes of its hit drama Homeland will resume on Sept. 30, along with additional installments of its long-running thriller Dexter. Homeland, which is produced by Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa and adapted from Gideon Raffs Israeli series Prisoners of War, last fall introduced viewers to the bipolar C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison; the rescued soldier Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis); and Saul Berenson (Mandy Patinkin), a veteran analyst with a truly spectacular beard.

title: Russian Opposition Urges U.S. to End Cold War Trade Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  Prominent organizers of antigovernment demonstrations in Moscow urged the United States Congress on Monday to end cold war-era trade restrictions against Russia, saying that leaving them in place would only help President-elect Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Albany Redrawing Political Map With Old Lines of Thought
description: ALBANY  This was the year New York State lawmakers were going to stop protecting incumbents by gerrymandering political maps to improve their re-election chances.

title: Out of Jail, Ex-Professor and His Crossbow Fight South Koreas Judiciary
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The image on the cover of Kim Myung-hos self-published book neatly captures his attitude toward the South Korean judiciary. It shows Mr. Kim, a former mathematics professor, standing defiantly, a law book in one hand and a crossbow in the other.

title: French Velorution
description: It is counterintuitive that Paris, the host city of the Tour de France finish line, was ever not a bicycling capital, but until it got a bike-share program  and an expanded network of bike lanes  cycling was not a mainstream mode of transportation there. Now its de rigueur, thanks to the Vlib systems more than 20,000 bikes at 1,800 stations. The Vlib app, available on iTunes, tells you where to find the nearest station and the number of bikes there. And at a little more than $2 a day, the price is hard to beat. (Bring your American Express card, though; Vlib machines are not compatible with Visas and MasterCards that do not have a European chip.)

title: Alderson Updates Injuries to Byrdak and Wright
description: 2:46 p.m. | Updated

title: Gas Rewards Cards That Lessen the Sting of High Prices
description: With gas prices edging toward an average of $4 gallon, it may be time to consider a credit card that gives you cash-back rewards at the pump.

title: Following Shooting, Bullying Is Again in the Spotlight
Possible Unintended-Acceleration Hazard Prompts Investigation of the Ford Taurus
description: 6:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Scott Becher joined Zimmerman Advertising, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group, in a new post, as an executive vice president and managing director, leading the agencys partnership marketing team. Mr. Becher had been leading his own agency, Sports and Sponsorships, for the last 15 years.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Targeted Killing
description: In my post last week about Attorney General Eric Holders recent national security speech, I focused on the good news, and promised Id come back to the parts that I found disturbing. This enraged several readers, who more or less accused me of selling out the Constitution to assist the Democratic president, and apparently didnt believe Id come back to the topic in due time.

title: Kevin Smiths New Deal Celebrated at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The director Kevin Smith doesnt have a movie at this years South by Southwest festival, but he does have a movie deal. He was on hand at a party this weekend to celebrate his partnership with the distribution company Phase 4 Films. The Canadian company will release a series of films under a Kevin Smith and SModcast Pictures Presents label. Mr. Smith will choose the films and take them on the road for special screenings, much like he did with his last film Red State.

title: Ads for Method Celebrate the Madness
