description: A brand that has been striving mightily to enliven one of the most prosaic categories in consumer marketing is putting on a happy face.

title: Before Wolves May Be Hunted, Science, Faith and Politics Clash
description: Once again, science, religion and politics have become entwined in a thorny public policy debate. This time, however, the discussion is not about abortion, birth control or health insurance mandates.

title: Tostadas With a Healthy Foundation
description: Years ago, when a series of sodden leftovers taught me what bad idea it was to reheat pies and quiches in a microwave, it occurred to me that the microwave might be a perfect tool to create a chip that isnt fried. Its bad for crusty things because it draws liquid out from the center of foods, so crusts always become soggy. But if you put a plain corn tortilla in the microwave and zap it until all of the moisture is drawn out of it, the result is something resembling a chip.

title: M.L.S. Week 1: Oh Canada, Oui
description: An old soccer rivalry was reanimated Saturday in the Pacific Northwest when the expansion Montreal Impact played their first game in M.L.S., losing to the Vancouver Whitecaps, 2-0.

title: Next Goal for Delaware: Winning a Game in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md.- The University of Delaware womens basketball team completed what head coach Tina Martin calls stage two of their season goals on Sunday. The Hens won the Colonial Athletic Association conference tournament for the first time in school history.

title: Childhood: Vitamin D Means Fewer Fractures for Girls
description: Higher amounts of vitamin D in the diet are associated with a lower risk for bone fractures in teenage girls, a new study has found.

title: Romney on the Rope Line
description: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at a campaign stop in Mobile, Ala., on Monday.

title: Capturing a Vanishing View of Park Slope
description: I knew it was going to go away, like everything does.

title: India Orders Bayer to License a Patented Drug
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias government on Monday authorized a drug manufacturer to make and sell a generic copy of a patented Bayer cancer drug, saying that Bayer charged a price that was unaffordable to most of the nation.

title: Student Crossword | Basketball
description: Cleveland Cavaliers star who was sign-and-traded to the Miami Heat in 2010? Things that occasionally shatter during slam dunks? Knicks player who caused Linsanity? Play our crossword (PDF) this month to test yourself on the answers to these and many other basketball-themed questions.

title: Caucus Click: Romney Works the Rope Line
description: After his campaign event in Mobile, Ala., was canceled due to rain, Mitt Romney spoke to supporters who waited outside along the rope line.

title: Spain Agrees to a Further Deficit Reduction
description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers won an agreement from Spain on Monday to take additional steps to reduce its bulging budget deficit in order to ease the latest threat to the euro zone, now that Greece has agreed with a majority of its private creditors on terms that will release bailout money.

title: Prevention: Prostate Risk Is Lower After Circumcision
description: A new analysis has found evidence that circumcision may reduce the risk for prostate cancer.

title: Promising Results for Specialized High School Tutoring Group
Join a Walking Tour From 1968
description: Many of you have joined us in our recent obsession with the whirlwind walking tour of 1968 Manhattan found in the filmmaker Hollis Framptons Surface Tension.

title: Bruce Hornsby Musical Gets a Reading  and a New Name
description: The York Theater Company will present a reading of the Bruce Hornsby musical Stranger next week as part of its Developmental Reading Series. Titled SCKBSTD when it had its premiere last year at the Virginia Stage Company in Norfolk  the name referred to a vanity license plate  the dark musical is about a mysterious man who unnerves a small town as he drives around in an old Dodge. Based on an original story written by Mr. Hornsby, who wrote the music and lyrics, Stranger features lyrics by Chip deMatteo and a book by Clay McLeod Chapman.

title: Asked & Answered | Paul Smith
description: Sir Paul Smith might be fashions biggest cycling fan. Long before he took up tailoring, Smith raced bikes, as a teenager in Nottingham, England. Though his competitive career ended early, after a bad accident when he was 16, his enthusiasm for the sport never wavered. A lover of cycling design, Smith has collaborated with Rapha on clothing and with Mercian on a limited line of cycles. Here, he offers sartorial tips for city cyclists.

title: As Rockets Fly, New Conditions Shape Fight in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Cross-border fighting between Israel and Palestinian militant groups in Gaza continued for a fourth day on Monday, with the Palestinian death toll rising from Israeli airstrikes and the militants rockets reaching farther into Israel.

title: Need Help Filling Out Your Bracket?
description: Stomach in knots trying to figure out the Murray State-Colorado State winner? Head spinning over which No. 12 seed will send home a No. 5? Feeling confused over why the first round is now the second round and wondering why those eight teams are playing on Tuesday? You need to make an appointment with The Timess N.C.A.A. experts. Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis will be doing a 30-minute video hangout on The Timess Google+ page on Tuesday at noon, holding Bracket Office Hours. So print out your bracket, plug in the webcam and bring along your questions.

title: Things Adult Medicine Could Learn From Pediatrics
description: Twenty-eight years ago, I wrote about drawing blood for the first time, about the pain of the patient and the self-doubt of the medical student. In my first clinical experience, I was learning a strange new color code: red-top tube for blood chemistries, purple top for hematology, green top, yellow top, and so on.

title: Springtime in Chelsea
description: Printed Matter, an art-book store in Chelsea, has been an indispensable resource for New York Citys art community for decades. The store, which often asks artists to design installations for its front window, most recently asked Sara Cwynar (who is also a designer here at the magazine) to create one with springtime as the theme. Cwynar looked to her personal archive of images and objects to create this green physical collage. The window will be up through March.

title: Drilling Down: Facebook Timeline Changes the Game
description: In my latest This Week in Small Business post, Christopher S. Penn, a marketing specialist, offered some advice on making the best use of Facebooks new Timeline feature. As a follow-up, I went back to Mr. Penn with a few questions.

title: Romney Team Sees a Plus in Gingrichs Persistence
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Mitt Romney has tried for weeks to snuff out Newt Gingrichs presidential ambitions, but his stubborn survival has become a welcome relief for Mr. Romney.

title: Study Disputes Oil Sands Restoration Pledge
description: Most television viewers in Canada have witnessed attempts by the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers to buff the environmental image of oil sands. One of its commercials depicts a pleasant forest that an oil company manager says was created on land reclaimed from an oil sands open pit mine.

title: The Downside of Switching to a Tougher Conference
description: While everyone dissects the 68 mens college basketball teams that will play in the N.C.A.A. tournament this week, its also worth pondering some that wont be participating.

title: TimesCast | After the Afghanistan Attack
description: March 12, 2012 - Details emerge about the attack in southern Afghanistan by an American soldier that left at least 16 civilians dead, 9 of them children.

title: Behind the Poster: In Masks Outrageous and Austere
description: In Masks Outrageous and Austere, the final full-length play written by Tennessee Williams, is a darkly comic, highly theatrical work about a wealthy woman named Babe Foxworth who gets kidnapped by a mysterious corporate entity. The premiere production of the work  its never been produced for the stage  begins performances next month at Culture Project. Shirley Knight stars as Babe, and David Schweizer directs.

title: High School Teammates May Have Tournament Reunion
description: I grew up in Ames, Iowa, a town of about 60,000, home of Iowa State University. I graduated from Ames High, loyal and true am I. But as proud as I am of being from Ames, I couldnt imagine a day when the N.C.A.A. selection committee would be accused of conspiring a tournament matchup between two Ames High graduates.

title: Oprahs Network Gets Big Boost From Interview With Houstons Daughter
description: Its all about the bookings.

title: How to Get Your Comments Past the Moderator
description: As most readers probably know, The Times moderates comments, meaning we delete the ones that dont meet our standards. The rejection rate on this blog usually hovers around 5 or ten percent, but its been rising recently (up to 25 percent, in one case) so I figured I should provide a refresher on how to play by the rules.

title: Small-Picture Approach Flips Medical Economics
description: CHICAGO  Even as she struggled to manage her Type 2 diabetes, Fannie Clines condition spiraled downward. It was not uncommon for Mrs. Cline, a 69-year-old retiree, to have dizzy spells, some so bad that they landed her in a hospital emergency room near her home here on the South Side.

title: Beauty Spots
description: STAY DRY

title: Researchers May Have Found Evidence of Lost Leonardo Masterpiece
description: Efforts to find a lost masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in Florences Palazzo Vecchio have shown possible signs of success, researchers in Italy say.

title: What Europe Could Have Learned From the U.S. Bank Bailout
description: Was the United States government savvier about its banks than the Europeans?

title: Front-Row View of the Madoff Civil Suit
description: The trial against Saul Katz and Fred Wilpon, the owners of the New York Mets, will be the first case related to Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme that could provide insight into how Mr. Madoff interacted with long-time investors. But this being a civil suit, this case may not provide the closure that a typical criminal prosecution would bring.The trial in the lawsuit filed by Irving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee representing victims of Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, is scheduled to begin next week.

title: No Luck, but Grace Under Turbulence
description: THE first time I flew, I was 12 years old. I was alone and was going to Boston. We landed and were going down the runway and then stopped because emergency vehicles went roaring past us. I found out later that another flight hit a sea wall at Logan and everyone was killed.

title: The Millennials Check In
description: The hotel industry, struggling to recover from the depths of the recession, has begun to contemplate a group of travelers it sees as crucial to its economic growth  those in their 20s to mid-30s who are obsessed with technology, social media and design.

title: Look of The Moment | Audrey Tautou
description: The Look: Parisian Pouf. Springs favorite  white  turns girly on a sweet silhouette with full shoulders.

title: Risks: More Red Meat, More Mortality
description: Eating red meat is associated with a sharply increased risk of death from cancer and heart disease, according to a new study, and the more of it you eat, the greater the risk.

title: Religion and the Social Crisis
description: Yuval Levin has one of the most perceptive takes on Charles Murrays Coming Apart that Ive read to date:

title: How Long Beach State Got In
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Three games in three days would decide everything, and Dan Monson, the Long Beach State mens basketball coach, wanted to tune out his teams players. He did not want to hear their music. He did not want to watch them eat.

title: More Thoughts on Game Change
description: I notice that my post on Game Change drew more than the usual number of comments from readers, and the robustness of that reaction dovetails with the volume of e-mails and calls Ive received from fellow writers and from political insiders I know. The issue of whether John McCains campaign workers did a great or lousy thing by sharing so many inside stories about Sarah Palin  and sharing stories in particular that cast her in a negative light  apparently provokes heated discussion.

title: Magazine Reports That Ducati May Join Volkswagen Group Portfolio
description: Ducati was considered a relative bargain when the private equity firm Investindustrial expanded its ownership stake in the motorcycle manufacturer in 2008. Last year, reports surfaced that the firm was shopping Ducati to major automakers, with Daimler, the BMW Group, Mahindra & Mahindra of India and Volkswagen all on the short list of interested parties.

title: App Smart Extra: More Singing Apps
description: Last weeks App Smart column featured apps for singers and aspiring vocalists, with Glee Karaoke and VoiceJam taking top billing.

title: Sizing Up the Top 25
description: New to the rankings: No. 17 Louisville, No. 20 Vanderbilt, No. 21 New Mexico, No. 24 St. Marys.

title: Group Suggests That Qaddafi Aided Sarkozys 2007 Campaign
description: PARIS  A spokesman for Nicolas Sarkozy on Monday sharply denied a suggestion by the investigative group Mediapart that the French presidents 2007 election campaign received up to 50 million euros, or more than $65 million, in illegal financial support from the late ruler of Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: The Passing of F. Sherwood Rowland
description: I was saddened to learn today of the passing on Saturday of F. Sherwood Rowland, a remarkable scientist, engaged citizen and professor best known for sharing the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for work revealing the impact of synthetic chlorofluorocarbons on the atmospheres protective ozone layer. (Heres the seminal 1974 Nature paper on these consequential chemical reactions in Nature by Mario J. Molina and Rowland.)

title: Childbirth: A Different Way to Remove the Placenta May Save Mothers Lives, a Study Finds
description: Delivery without pulling on the umbilical cord may be a simpler way to keep some women from bleeding to death in childbirth, a new study has found.

title: A New Chef at Adour
description: Adour, Alain Ducasses restaurant in the St. Regis hotel in Midtown, has a new chef: Julien Jouhannaud, who has worked with Mr. Ducasse for more than 10 years, most recently as the executive chef at Adour in the St. Regis in Washington.

title: Senate Democrats Ready Jobs Bill, Aides Say
description: 4:31 p.m. | Updated Senate Democrats are expected on Tuesday to unveil their version of a small-business financing bill that passed last week in the House, with the Senate legislation including three of the six House provisions, as well as other measures to extend credit to small businesses, Democratic aides said.

title: Revisiting the She-covery
description: Mike Konczal has a good post at the New Deal 2.0 blog, pointing out that much of the recent rise in female employment  the subject of my post on Friday  is a result of statistical fluctuations.

title: Defendant Wont Testify in Rutgers Case
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Dharun Ravi sat largely expressionless for three weeks as friends testified in a courtroom here that he set up a webcam to spy on his roommate and another man as they had sex in his Rutgers dorm room in the days before the roommate, Tyler Clementi, committed suicide.

title: With the New iPad, New Questions Over the Meaning of 4G
Merkel Defends Germanys Nuclear Power Deadline
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany defended over the weekend her governments decision to phase out nuclear power by 2022 and replace it with renewable energy sources, dismissing critics who said the government would never make the deadline.

title: The Massacre in Kandahar
description: Ive been trying to think what I can add to the extensive coverage of the horrible massacre in the Kandahar region of Afghanistan. I havent come up with anything terribly original, but didnt want to let this shameful event go unmentioned.

title: Playing Up a Scotsmans Lawn Expertise
description: A CAMPAIGN is celebrating the green, green grass of home with a new brand character who is meant to bring to life a familiar line of lawn-care products.

title: Defense Lawyers Tangle in Brothel Case
description: A woman accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side reappeared in court on Monday for a hearing, but much of the spotlight was stolen by her dueling lawyers.

title: Pedal Pusher
description: Earl Blumenauer (above), who represents most of Portland, Ore., in Congress, insists that Washington, D.C., is a bikeable town. But then, Blumenauer would insist every city is a bikeable town. A passionate advocate of cycling, he founded the 170-member Congressional Bike Caucus and led a successful charge to put bike lanes up the middle of Pennsylvania Avenue. He bikes to work on Capitol Hill most days, and to the White House, occasionally confusing security guards. Blumenauer suggests visitors make good use of the citys bike-share program, Capital Bikeshare, or rent a bike from the Bikestation at Union Station. He also recommends riding on the Capital Crescent Trail; along the C&O Canal; on the upper Rock Creek Trail; and at the National Arboretum, a secret gem.

title: New York Is Worlds Top City to Do Business, Study Finds
description: Anybody who has tried to hail a cab in Midtown during a rainstorm will not be surprised by the results of a survey released on Monday that ranked New York City as the most competitive city in the world.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, the West Bank, Afghanistan and India.

title: Two Broncos Seek to Reverse Suspensions
description: Lawyers for Ryan McBean and D. J. Williams, two of the three Denver Broncos suspended last week for violating the N.F.L.s drug policy, have asked a state court judge in Colorado to reverse their suspensions, arguing that the N.F.L.-appointed arbitrator mishandled their appeals.

title: As It Warned, Yahoo Sues Facebook Over Patents
description: Yahoo stepped up its new feud with Facebook on Monday, suing the social-networking giant and accusing it of infringing on 10 patents tied to an array of Web technologies.

title: North Carolina Loses 15 Scholarships in N.C.A.A. Ruling
description: North Carolina was the latest school to test the N.C.A.A.s will to hand out tough punishments for programs run amok and found the N.C.A.A. still has some will to hand out tough punishments.

title: Off Broadway Welcomes Old Jews Telling Jokes
description: One would be hard pressed to find a more honestly titled theater production than Old Jews Telling Jokes, an new Off Broadway show that promises to reinvent classic Jewish jokes and perform them on stage. Co-created by the authors Peter Gethers and Daniel Okrent and directed by Marc Bruni (Fanny), the project is inspired by the Web site oldjewstellingjokes.com which, true to its name, hosts videos of older Jewish raconteurs telling some of their favorite jokes.

title: Approval Ratings, Gas Prices and Statistical Noise
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  This analysis was written and published before I had seen the results of the new New York Times/CBS News poll  which had President Obamas approval ratings dropping all the way down to 41 percent. That certainly weighs the evidence more in the direction of Mr. Obamas numbers having declined from their February peaks  and makes Novembers election look more like a toss-up than one that leans toward Mr. Obama.

title: Long Beach States Road to the Tournament
description: The 49ers won the Big West tournament, securing the leagues automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: New Worries About Sleeping Pills
description: Talk about sleepless nights.

title: Fury Grows Over Afghan Killings
description: Afghan anger grew on Monday, a day after the massacre of at least 16 civilians, nine of them children, in a rural stretch of southern Afghanistan, allegedly by a veteran Army staff sergeant. Over at The Lede blog, our colleague Robert Mackey picked up on videos posted by one of the local Afghan news agencies, Pajhwok Afghan News. The videos show distressing, graphic images of the dead.

title: Courage Far Beyond Fashion
description: IF you were to host a party for 500 guests to celebrate five courageous women from around the world, where would it be? How about the United Nations cafeteria?

title: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial
description: Surgery for epilepsy is usually seen as a last resort for patients when medications do not work, and it is often delayed for many years after the failure of drug treatment. Now a randomized, controlled trial suggests that surgery as soon as possible after the failure of two antiepileptic drugs is a significantly better approach than continued medical care.

title: Scene City: Diller-Von Furstenberg Awards
description: Tina Brown, Diane Von Furstenberg, Jessica Alba, Oprah and others celebrate International Womens Day.

title: Meatloaf Cakes
description: Adapted from Ann Romney

title: Mitt Romneys Blue-Collar Birthday Meal
description: RONALD REAGAN had his jelly beans, Poppy Bush had his pork rinds and Mitt Romney has his  meatloaf cakes?

title: Can Corals Toughen Up After a Warming Crisis?
description: In 2010, record warm ocean temperatures across much of the tropics led to catastrophic coral bleaching. The devastation approached the scale of a 1998 calamity in which 16 percent of the worlds reefs died.

title: Digital Notes: Sony Offers $8 Million Settlement Over Royalties
description: Ending a six-year dispute, Sony has offered an $8 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit over royalties for digital music. The case, originally filed by the Allman Brothers and Cheap Trick, was one of the first in what is now a wave of litigation by artists accusing major record companies of underpaying royalties by counting downloads as sales, like CDs, instead of as licenses, which pay much higher rates. (Royalties might be anywhere from 5 percent to 20 percent for sales, while 50 percent on a license is standard.)

title: One Death That Haunts Many Lives
description: Carol Anshaws beautifully observed new novel, Carry the One, begins with a terrible accident in the summer of 1983: very late at night, after Carmen and Matts wedding, a car filled with some seriously stoned and sleepy wedding guests turns onto a two-lane road, accelerates through a dip, and then, suddenly, horribly, strikes a young girl named Casey Redman. She is dead at the age of 10.

title: All the Jobs Are Moving to Mars
description: Ethan Lipton, a wry singer-songwriter whose heavy-lidded affability and retro facial hair make him look like a doomed sidekick in a 70s cop movie, grinned upon learning that one collaborator after another had independently used the word Everyman to describe him. Here, and I thought I was fancy, he said.

title: The Hawk Cam Is Back for Another Season
description: The Hawk Cam is rolling once more.

title: The fabulous art of the nomads of Kazakhstan, the marriage formula; and lost in space.
description: The fabulous art of the nomads of Kazakhstan, the marriage formula; and lost in space.

title: Whats Your Meatloaf Recipe?
description: A mix of ground beef, bread crumbs and onions, Ann Romneys meatloaf recipe  her husbands birthday favorite  breaks no new ground. But thats not really the point. Meatloaf is not about new tricks. Its about familiarity: the way you like to do it, the way you always do it, maybe even the way your great-grandmother did it.

title: Colleges Winter Break Finally Ends
description: The NBC comedy Community has finally come to the end of its gap semester.

title: Sentence of the Month: February
description: Thanks to everyone who voted in our last Sentence of the Week competition. The winner  just beating out Richard Rorty (Nietzsche, at his worst, gestured towards some narcissistic and inarticulate hunks of Bronze Age beefcake) and John Jeremiah Sullivan (She was complicated, deeper than the other teens on One Tree, which in teen-show terms meant that she often wore flannel shirts)  is Fyodor Dostoevsky:

title: Building With Eddie Borgo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Discussing Manning, Romney Touts Ties to Football Team Owners
description: CENTREVILLE, Ala.  On Monday afternoon, Mitt Romney called into the Paul Finebaum Radio Network, an enormously popular daily sports talk show based out of Birmingham, Ala., that on most days concerns college football, and particularly the acrimonious partisan battle between Auburn and Alabama fans. It also routinely features some of the more colorful callers in the sports talk radio landscape.

title: With Focus on Player Safety, General Managers Propose New Icing Rule
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Reacting to concerns over player safety, N.H.L. general managers moved closer to changing the leagues icing rule Monday.

title: Two Cheers for Double Standards
description: In his Campaign Stops column, Stanley Fish writes:

title: A Moscow Show Trial on the Bosphorus
description: Another post from a colleague, this time about Turkey, from Dani Rodrik at Harvards Kennedy School. Dani is a first-rate economist, who has staked out important ground as a critic of conventional wisdom on trade and development; you can read some of his ideas on his blog, where this will be cross-posted. Hes also personally involved in the matters discussed below: his father-in-law is the lead defendant in the case.

title: Q&A: Screaming for Google Ice Cream
description: Q.

title: Building A Caste Society
description: Thomas Edsall has an excellent piece on growing educational stratification in America, specifically how access to higher education is increasingly being denied to the children of the less affluent. And as he says, this is very much about policy. One graphic he links to (ppt) but doesnt include is just stunning: heres the declining value of Pell grants compared with college costs:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitter Acquires Posterous, and Facebook Bigamy Case
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Nate Silvers March Madness
description: Nate Silver, the author of The Timess FiveThirtyEight blog, presents the probability of each of the 68 teams winning the N.C.A.A. national championship.

title: The Fineries of Ancient Nomads
description: A sampling of artifacts from the nomadic societies of the arid Eurasian steppes, which are on exhibit at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World.

title: Top Challenger in Egypt Vote Is an Islamist, and Moderate
description: CAIRO  One spent a career working beside Hosni Mubarak, the former president. The other spent years in his jails.

title: A Little-Known Guest Arrives to Make an Impression
description: As the Boston Symphony Orchestra enters a second year without a music director, a parade of guest conductors continues to cross its podium. Some are legitimate candidates to succeed James Levine, who resigned last March, though two heavyweight contenders had to cancel appearances with the orchestra this season: Riccardo Chailly, for health reasons, and Andris Nelsons, for the birth of his baby.

title: Overnight A, C and E Subway Riders, Time for Confusion
description: The traveling subway-repair show known as Fastrack brings it shut-down-the-trains-at-night-and-get-tons-of-work-done madness to the A, C and E lines this week, after successful runs on the 4, 5 and 6, the B, D, F and M and the 1, 2 and 3.

title: In a Pashas Seraglio, Even Flowers Turn Frisky
description: The sublime and the ridiculous can coexist in disconcerting proximity. Witness Alexei Ratmanskys 2007 production for the Bolshoi Ballet of the 19th-century ballet Le Corsaire, which on Sunday was broadcast live to cinemas worldwide (including in Manhattan). Actually Le Corsaire (The Pirate) in any modern production is often ridiculous. Only in Mr. Ratmanskys version does it touch on the sublime  and more so in this broadcast than when I saw this staging live in 2007 in the relatively cramped conditions of the London Coliseum.

title: Coming Soon: The Wearable, Online, All-the-Time Baby Monitor
description: From the department of the inevitable: the Exmobaby wireless, biosensor baby onesie. Its washable, rechargeable and transmits information up to 100 feet. Soon, very soon, you can monitor your babys ECG, skin temperature, and movement, and have constant alerts sent to your PC or mobile phone.

title: East Village Record Store Other Music Starts a Label
description: Other Music, the East Village record store that purveys everything from electronica to indie rock, is starting its own record label later this month with an eye toward showcasing underground music in New York and reissuing albums by foreign artists, one of the stores owners, Josh Madell, said on Monday.

title: Nymphs, a Moor, and Lovers Roam About
description: The New York Theater Ballets Signatures series juxtaposes old and new. Usually the vintage stuff  forgotten or rarely performed works by master choreographers  is best, but sometimes, as in the program performed on Friday at Gould Hall, the balance is more even.

title: Premiere for Cello and Orchestra, Inspired by a Poem
description: Through its invaluable First Music program, the New York Youth Symphony has commissioned works from more than 100 emerging composers since 1984. The orchestras concert on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall brought the premiere of That Blue Repair, a kind of mini-concerto by Chris Rogerson.

title: Pairings: Coq au Vin Blanc
description: Just as Oregon borrows from Burgundy in vineyards planted with pinot noirs and chardonnays, that region also inspires dinner. The iconic boeuf bourguignon would not be the best choice with chardonnay, but this version of coq au vin, replacing Chambertin with chardonnay, couldnt be better. I went light with it, omitting the bacon lardons. And I gave a nod to Oregons truffle crop by finishing the sauce with a gloss of black truffle butter. Its a modest investment that elevates the dish. A generous slab of unsalted butter (especially if its high-fat European-style) could also bolster the sauce, though with less foxy intrigue.

title: Oregon Chardonnay Speaks Up
description: IN the beginning, there was chardonnay, and it was not good.

title: New Albums From VCMG, Brad Mehldau Trio and Henry Cole and the Afrobeat Colective
description: VCMG

title: New York Times/CBS Poll
description: A New York Times/CBS survey shows that Republican primary voters remain divided over the leading candidates.

title: Romantic Staples, With Texture and a Tangy Bite
description: The Dresden Philharmonic traces its history back nearly six centuries, to independent civic bands that flourished between the 16th and 19th centuries. But the orchestra as we know it today was actually founded in 1870, so depending on how you look at it, it is either one of the worlds oldest orchestras or nearly 30 years younger than the New York Philharmonic.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 7 through 11 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 878 said they were registered to vote.

title: Life on Mars? Funds to Find Answer Fade
description: Just as NASA is on the cusp of answering the most fascinating questions about Mars  is there, was there or could there be life there?  the money needed to provide the answers is about to be abruptly withdrawn, a victim of President Obamas budget request for 2013, scientists say.

title: Excerpt: 'Community'
description: The NBC sitcom returns this week.

title: Obamas Rating Falls as Poll Reflects Volatility
description: Despite improving job growth and an extended Republican primary fight dividing his would-be opponents, President Obama is heading into the general election season on treacherous political ground, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: New York States Pension Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpt: 'Fashion Star'
description: Elle Macpherson hosts the new fashion competition show on NBC.

title: No Pity for Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifts in TV Viewing
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons From France
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Aid for North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Cultivating Character
description: To the Editor:

title: A Partnership Aims at Streamlining Security
description: CLEAR, the company that provided expedited airport security clearance to travelers who agreed to background checks, went out of business with heavy debts in 2009  dashing expectations that private enterprise would soon become a major partner with the government at airport security checkpoints.

title: Daylight Savings Links
description: Read these in sunlight at 6 p.m. while you get ready to complain about the heat:

title: Inside the Stratfor Attack
description: 1:58 p.m. | Updated Adding clarification from the F.B.I. regarding how much of Stratfors data it was able to salvage.

title: Facebook Confronts a Familiar Opponent in Fight With Yahoo
description: Yahoos lawsuit against Facebook on Monday over allegations of patent infringement offered interesting nuggets of information, including the 10 technologies in question.

title: At Elite Colleges, Too Much Hubris?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ask About Raptors in New York City
description: Now that Hawk Cam 2012 is up and running, its time to Ask the Expert. New York City Audubons director of conservation and science, Susan Elbin, responded to readers questions about the behavior, habitat, ecology and conservation of hawks and other birds of prey that live in the city. What are the major factors that put hawks  and other birds  at risk? What can humans do to help conserve and protect the wild birds of New York City?

title: Taking the Plunge
description: Q. If I find myself in a free-falling elevator, is there any position that might increase my chance of survival? (Climbing on top of other people is not an acceptable answer.)

title: Visions for the Last Section of the High Line
description: Initial designs for the third and final section of the High Line were released Monday by Friends of the High Line. Section 3 will wrap around the striking stretch of rail yards at the center of the Hudson Yards project.

title: Where the Curly Haired Go to Be Coiffed
description: Looking for a blowout in Manhattan? The options are infinite and often overwhelming. Looking for someone to carefully coif your curls? You can count the options on one hand. Miss Jessies, the product line that specifically caters to curly manes, has just opened Miss Jessies CurlBar in SoHo, offering an alternative to Dry Bar. There, loyal disciples and newcomers alike can stop in or make an appointment for services like a wash & go or a curly haircut.

title: Polling in Deep South Has Posed Challenges
description: The polls suggest a tight race in Alabama and Mississippi, which will hold their primaries on Tuesday. Our polling-based forecasts show Newt Gingrich with a very small lead in Alabama and Mitt Romney with an equally small one in Mississippi. Rick Santorum seems to have fallen to third in both states, but remains in striking distance.

title: Refining the Formula That Predicts Celebrity Marriages Doom
description: In 2006, Garth Sundem and I confronted one of the great unsolved mysteries in social science: Exactly how soon will a given celebrity marriage blow up?

title: Robertson Ditches the Boot
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Dave Robertson, without the protective boot on his foot, breezed through the clubhouse Monday afternoon without a trace of a limp. That was probably the most encouraging sign that he would indeed be ready for opening day.

title: Americas Fossil-Fuels Jobs Boom
description: With gasoline prices spiraling higher and weighing on economic confidence, President Obama called over the weekend for further investment in a clean-energy future. But there is a flip side to that increasing pain at the pump: a huge jobs boom in fossil fuels industries.

title: Team Tracks a Food Supply at the End of the World
description: One recent morning at the bottom of the world, Kim Bernard spotted two humpback whales gorging in the Southern Ocean not far offshore. Dr. Bernard, a biological oceanographer, was spending the austral summer at Palmer Station, the United States research outpost on an outcropping off the western Antarctic Peninsula.

title: Devils Keep Pushing on Offense, and Keep Winning
description: NEWARK  Not only did the Devils lose a lot last season, but they were not much fun to watch, either. They were last in the N.H.L. in scoring, by a wide margin, and their power play was near the bottom of the league. No wonder they missed the playoffs for the first time in 14 years.

title: Libyas Franchise Fiasco
description: LIBYAS new electoral law, passed by the National Transitional Council last month, provides guidelines for selecting the countrys first-ever democratic government. Many, including the United Nations, hailed the laws passage as a significant step down Libyas rocky political road.

title: Sawfish Have Nose for Attacks, and for Strategy
description: A new study details the way the sawfish uses its trademark long, toothy snout to swiftly and fiercely attack prey.

title: Chimpanzees Show Skills in Managing Conflict
description: A teacher might intervene when two fifth graders get rowdy on the playground, and it turns out that chimpanzees also have such arbitrators.

title: When Snow Fleas Surface, Winter Study Comes to a Close
description: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

title: Looking Again at the Skulls (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Battling Nature (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Canines in the Wild (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Costly Diagnosis (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Kennedy, Cargo Workers See the Future
description: He is as unlikely a trend spotter as they come, working in a cargo warehouse at Kennedy International Airport.

title: At Detroit, Son Joins His Father for the Ride
description: DETROIT  Keri Gaither, the athletic director at the University of Detroit, apologized in advance for looking a little tired. Ray McCallum, the coach of the universitys basketball team, said he was not getting enough sleep, either.

title: Jets Re-Sign a Leader on Defense for 3 Years
description: The Jets accomplished one of their off-season priorities, re-signing defensive tackle Sione Pouha to a three-year contract. Pouha, one of the leagues dominant run-stoppers last season, would have become an unrestricted free agent Tuesday.

title: Contractor Pleads Guilty to One of Many Tax Charges
description: An 83-year-old demolition contractor who made and lost fortunes while repeatedly running into problems with the authorities pleaded guilty on Monday to failing to file state tax returns on his personal income for three years.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Millennium Bomb-Plot Sentence; Calls it Too Light
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal appeals court on Monday overturned the 22-year prison sentence for Ahmed Ressam, the Algerian national known as the Millennium Bomber, who plotted to set off explosives at Los Angeles International Airport on Dec. 31, 1999. The court deemed the sentence too lenient.

title: Conflicted, and Often Getting a Pass
description: NEW ORLEANS We are all totally conflicted  get used to it.

title: Trade Issues With China Flare Anew
description: HONG KONG  A month after Vice President Xi Jinpings visit to the United States and Europe, the brief trade policy dtente between China and its two biggest export markets is about to end.

title: President Recapturing Groups Won by G.O.P. in 2010
description: While President Obama is locked in a tight race for re-election, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll found him faring well against the top Republican candidates among some important groups that abandoned Congressional Democrats in 2010.

title: Bike Thief
description: The filmmaker Casey Neistat conducts an experiment in New York City, locking up his own bike and brazenly trying to steal it, to determine whether onlookers or the police would intervene.

title: For Better or Worse, Cabrera Takes Over at Third
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Detroit Tigers Miguel Cabrera paused, searching his memory for his favorite position to play. He ran through the time he had spent during his professional career in right field, left field, shortstop, first base and third base, and said what he liked about each.

title: S.E.C. Close to Bringing Cases on 2 Brokerage Firms
description: Federal regulators are close to bringing cases against two brokerage firms that trade stocks of privately held companies, the first legal actions resulting from a yearlong investigation into the buying and selling of shares of closely held Internet start-ups.

title: Wine Dealer Was Trusted by His Allies
description: Like many other wine enthusiasts, Paul Wasserman trusted Rudy Kurniawan. They met in Los Angeles in 2002, when both were part of a group that gathered to taste Burgundies  not the old, rare bottles that were selling at auctions for thousands of dollars, but wines of recent vintages that were interesting to serious students.

title: A Rejection of Discrimination
description: When Texas lawmakers were writing one of the nations most restrictive voter-identification laws last spring, they rejected a proposal to allow voters to use other forms of ID beyond a narrow list. They rejected another suggestion to help voters without an ID card apply for one. And when a lawmaker offered an amendment to offer free access to birth certificates in order to get a card, instead of charging $22, they rejected that, too.

title: The Challenge of Stopping Griner and Baylor
description: Brittney Griner, Baylors 6-foot-8 junior center, may yet be considered the greatest player ever in womens college basketball. But she has not won a national championship to help elevate her star into that firmament.

title: Bike Thief
description: I was 20 years old when I moved to New York City on a Friday in June 2001. I brought all the clothes I could fit in a big duffel bag, along with my bicycle. Monday morning I was to report to my new job as a bike messenger. Saturday, my first full day in Manhattan, my bike was stolen.

title: Go Ahead, Do Your Worst
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I try to be fair in my puzzle write-ups, really I do.

title: Rick Santorum Still Isnt Crazy
description: The comments on my column about Rick Santorum and the separation of church and state were voluminous and often passionate. Once we set aside those readers who call religion a disease, a superstition and an obstacle to serious thought, and discount those who think that by identifying Santorum as a Republican and Justices Scalia, Thomas and Rehnquist as conservatives theyve made an argument, and disqualify those who describe me as an indoctrinated Catholic (who knew?) and a right wing kook (please tell Fox News), we are left with some serious questions about the history of religion clause jurisprudence, the scope of the establishment clause, the status of secularism as a middle or common ground and the accuracy of Santorums account of John F. Kennedys speech to the Houston Baptists.

title: Yet Another Curb on Abortion
description: Republicans on Capitol Hill chose an odd way to mark International Womens Day on Thursday. The Judiciary Committee in the Republican-controlled House held a hearing to promote a mean-spirited and constitutionally suspect bill called the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act.

title: Dream Act for New York
description: The Dream Act is an aptly named-but-star-crossed piece of federal legislation that would open a path to legal status for young unauthorized immigrants who pursue college degrees or serve in the military. Its goal is to help ambitious youths who were brought here as children and are American in all but the paperwork.

title: Use of Homeless as Internet Hot Spots Backfires on Marketer
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Which product at this years South by Southwest technology conference received more attention than perhaps any other?

title: Horror in Kandahar
description: The massacre of at least 16 civilians in three Afghan villages by an American soldier on Sunday was an unspeakable horror. The United States said Monday that an investigation is under way. It must be fast, transparent and conclusive so that Afghans can see that America is committed to justice and responsive to their outrage. The punishment must be swift.

title: Is MF Global Getting a Free Pass?
description: Its sure starting to look as if Jon Corzine is going to get away with it.

title: F. Sherwood Rowland, Cited Aerosols Danger, Is Dead at 84
description: SAN FRANCISCO  F. Sherwood Rowland, whose discovery in 1974 of the danger that aerosols posed to the ozone layer was initially met with disdain but who was ultimately vindicated with the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, died on Saturday at his home in Corona del Mar, Calif. He was 84.

title: On Eve of Albany Policy Push, Cardinal Focuses on Good Will
description: ALBANY  The cardinal explored the Capitol like a curious tourist on Monday, commenting loudly as he gazed from side to side at the paintings and historic treasures outside Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos office.

title: Corrections: March 13
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Disappearance of Dolan
description: CHICAGO  An anniversary of sorts quietly passed on Monday, and the Knicks owner, James L. Dolan, celebrated in a manner appropriate to the occasion: by remaining blissfully, stubbornly silent.

title: The Fertility Implosion
description: When you look at pictures from the Arab spring, you see these gigantic crowds of young men, and it confirms the impression that the Muslim Middle East has a gigantic youth bulge  hundreds of millions of young people with little to do. But that view is becoming obsolete. As Nicholas Eberstadt and Apoorva Shah of the American Enterprise Institute point out, over the past three decades, the Arab world has undergone a little noticed demographic implosion. Arab adults are having many fewer kids.

title: Judge in Case From Yonkers Raises Doubts on Evidence
description: A federal judge in Manhattan indicated on Monday that she had serious questions about whether the government had proved a key part of its corruption case against a former Yonkers councilwoman accused of selling her vote to approve a proposed luxury mall and housing complex in return for thousands of dollars in secret payments.

title: Link to a Young, Softer Steinbrenner Dies
description: George Steinbrenner was a collegian with a powder-blue Plymouth convertible when he met Mary Jane Schriner in the summer of 1949. She was 16 and dreaming of a writing career. He was 19, nearly a quarter-century from buying the Yankees.

title: White House Outlines Plan to Help With Job Search
description: Obama administration officials said a proposal to consolidate two existing job training and placement programs would help hundreds of thousands of people get training they need to find work.

title: In Battle With Media, a New Tactic in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador  The fight goes on for Rafael Correa, the president of Ecuador, who has been in a relentless donnybrook with his countrys news media almost from the day he took office five years ago.

title: President Obamas Approval Rating Drops
description: New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: European Airlines and Airbus Seek to Ease Emissions Rule
description: Airbus and Europes biggest airlines on Monday called on the European Union to find a compromise on aviation carbon curbs, warning that Europes emission limits on foreign carriers could lead to retaliation.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2012

title: Bitter Rivalry Thaws, if Briefly, on a Street in the Dominican Republic
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Maybe in some parallel universe, it would not be shocking to see David Ortiz, slugger for the Boston Red Sox, and Ivan Nova, starting pitcher for the Yankees, hugging, laughing and dancing together to commemorate an important baseball victory.

title: One-Way Wantonness
description: Hussy. Harlot. Hooker.

title: Intel Talking to Networks About Internet TV Service
description: Intel has held preliminary talks with entertainment companies recently about creating a service for accessing television shows over the Internet.

title: MF Global Customers Said to Get Offers for Their Claims
description: The thousands of MF Global customers whose lives and businesses were derailed after $1.6 billion vanished in the collapse of the brokerage firm have now received offers to sell their claims and recoup nearly the entire shortfall, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: NYT at SXSW
description: Alexis Mainland of The Times hosts a Google Plus Hangout with Rick Webb, an angel investor and co-founder of the Barbarian Group, an Internet marketing firm.

title: Mets Pack a Whole Lot of Troubles Into 2 Days
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the Mets, it is probably not quite the way they wanted to start the week. Their star third baseman, who has yet to play in a spring training game, gets a cortisone shot in the side. Their only left-handed reliever is prepped for unexpected knee surgery. Their bullpen catcher is arrested on drunken-driving charges several hours after attending a team bowling party. And a member of the 2011 Mets is suspended for 50 games after a second positive test for a recreational drug.

title: Support for Afghan Fight Drops Among G.O.P. Candidates
description: Amid a series of bloody and troubling episodes in Afghanistan that have inflamed Afghan opinion against the United States, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich are now calling for a reassessment of American policy there  suggesting that it may be time to withdraw troops sooner than the Obama administration has planned.

title: The New iPad Is Already Scarce
description: If you havent ordered the new iPad already online and you dont plan to brave the lines likely to form later this week when it goes on sale in stores, dont expect to get your hands on the device anytime soon.

title: Young, Black and Male in America
Snippets From SXSW Interactive: Monday Updates
description: Were posting quick updates from South by Southwest Interactive on our Tumblr. Here is a sampling of Mondays posts:

title: Valentine and Red Sox Set to Visit Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Boston Red Sox come to Tampa on Tuesday for the first time in spring training. More interesting is that it will be the first meeting between the Yankees and the Red Sox since Boston hired the outspoken manager Bobby Valentine in December.

title: Rushworth M. Kidder, Ethicist, Dies at 67
description: Rushworth M. Kidder, an academic-turned-journalist who founded a research institute dedicated to mapping approaches to ethical dilemmas, propounding his ideas in books, speeches and seminars, died on March 5 at a nursing home in Davie, Fla. He was 67.

title: Hague Court to Decide Where Former Dictator of Chad Will Be Tried
description: PARIS  International judges in The Hague are hearing a complex case this week that boils down to a single and unusual question: which country has the right to try Hissne Habr, the former president of Chad, who has been indicted in two nations in connection with political killings, torture and a host of other brutalities.

title: Suspects Sought in Death of Chelsea Man
description: The police on Monday named two suspects in the death of a Chelsea man found bound and gagged with duct tape in his ransacked apartment this month.

title: SXSW Video: Rick Webb, Angel Investor
description: Lexi Mainland chats in a Google Plus Hangout with Rick Webb, angel investor and co-founder of the Barbarian Group, at South by Southwest Interactive.

title: Sports Replay: March 12
description: Soccer, spring training and other images from the day in sports.

title: For Some in Vietnam, Prosperity Is a South Korean Son-in-Law
description: QUANG YEN, Vietnam  In the end, Bui Van Vui lived only three months in the new house that two of his daughters, married to men in South Korea, had helped him build here. Dying of throat cancer, he had exhorted the anxious contractor to hurry, scribbling on scraps of paper after he could no longer speak.

title: Seattle Gets the Street View on the Quality of Its Lights
description: SEATTLE  This city has a noble notion of itself at the leading edge. Its jets, coffee, computers, environmental activism and philanthropy have all been celebrated for remaking the globe.

title: G.O.P. Split Over a Bid to Revise Budget Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The House is bracing for a rancorous showdown over a 2013 budget plan that has already divided Republicans because of a push by conservatives to cut spending below the level both parties agreed to in last years deal to raise the federal deficit.

title: The Hypocrite in Everyone Else
description: The continuous stream of reports detailing inconsistencies on the part of politicians makes it hard to believe that the rest of us might be as bad as they are.

title: Explaining Paterno Firing
description: Penn States board of trustees issued a statement explaining its rationale for the firing of Joe Paterno on Nov. 9. In the statement, the trustees essentially reiterated that they moved to fire Paterno in part because he did not tell the police what he knew about a suspected 2002 sexual assault of a young boy by the former assistant Jerry Sandusky.

title: Nitkowskis Winding Path Could Lead Back to Flushing
description: Years ago, C.J. Nitkowski completed a kind of triple play for a New York ballplayer. He starred for St. Johns and played for the Mets and the Yankees among his eight major league stops in a career that stretched from 1995 through 2005.

title: Knicks Play Better, but Their Losing Streak Gets Longer
description: CHICAGO  The ball had squirted loose, been gathered up, launched and bounced loose again, before finding its way, inevitably, back to Derrick Rose. A few steps and one leap later, Rose was in flight, soaring over the paint, between Baron Davis and Tyson Chandler and bearing down on the basket.

title: Britain to Join Obama in Discouraging a Strike on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Britain will add its voice to President Obamas in discouraging an Israeli military strike on Iran when Prime Minister David Cameron begins a three-day visit here this week, a senior British diplomat said Monday.

title: No Drastic Moves Planned by G.M.s
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  N.H.L. general managers and league officials, relatively satisfied with the measures they have taken to promote concussion safety over the past couple of years, are sticking with the status quo at their annual three-day meetings.

title: Church Puts Legal Pressure on Abuse Victims Group
description: Turning the tables on an advocacy group that has long supported victims of pedophile priests, lawyers for the Roman Catholic Church and priests accused of sexual abuse in two Missouri cases have gone to court to compel the group to disclose more than two decades of e-mails that could include correspondence with victims, lawyers, whistle-blowers, witnesses, the police, prosecutors and journalists.

title: Word of the Day | deference
description: deference \de-f-rn(t)s, def-rn(t)s\ noun

title: Champions League Preview: Inter and Bayern Plot Their Escapes
description: Arsenals memorable failure against Milan last week notwithstanding, no lead is insurmountable in the Champions League, especially when your team can run out some of the worlds best players to try to erase it. (Scratch that: 7-0 in the second half is pretty safe.) But theres a big difference between staring at a 4-0 deficit, as Arsenal was entering the second leg, and trying to climb out of a 1-0 hole. Inter Milan and Bayern Munich are happy to be facing a one-goal deficit on Tuesday.

title: Turkey: Court Frees 4 Journalists Accused in Plot
description: An Istanbul court on Monday released four journalists from jail, where they had been awaiting trial on charges that they were part of a plot to overthrow the government. Human rights groups have accused Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans government of repressing freedom of speech through a mixture of intimidation and arrests. Two of the journalists, the award-winning investigative reporters Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik spent more than a year in prison after being accused of being part of an illegal terrorist group. Both men have denied the charges. According to the Journalists Union of Turkey, about 100 journalists are currently imprisoned. The government disputes that figure and insists that most of the jailed journalists were arrested for activities other than reporting.

title: Iran: Critical U.N. Human Rights Report Denounced
description: Iran issued an angry rejoinder to a United Nations Human Rights Council report that castigated its record, calling the contents false, fabricated, biased and a reflection of manipulations by certain Western countries and their cronies on the council, a reference to the United States and its allies. First circulated last week, the 36-page report by Ahmed Shaheed, a former foreign minister from Maldives, found what he called evidence of a striking pattern of violations of fundamental human rights guaranteed under international law, offering numerous examples of illegal detentions and maltreatment of prisoners, dissidents, minorities and women. The report, commissioned after Irans crackdown on the political opposition following the disputed 2009 presidential election, also criticized Iran for its large number of executions. Irans own High Council for Human Rights said the report amounted to nothing more than the repetition of a barrage of unsubstantiated and biased contentions.

title: Iraq: Gunmen Kill at Least 11 in Separate Attacks
description: At least six people were killed Monday by gunmen who robbed jewelry stores in the eastern Baghdad neighborhood of Shaab, security officials said. Militant groups frequently rob the stores to finance their operations. Two store owners were killed in the assaults, as well as two police officers and two soldiers, Iraqi security officials said. One attacker was killed, one was wounded and the rest escaped with gold and cash, the police said. Also on Monday, in Tarmiya, north of Baghdad, five bodyguards for a local council were assassinated, the Iraqi police said.

title: At Funeral, Recalling Many Sides of Reporter
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.  No matter where she was, in some war-torn region on the other side of the world or on the Gothic campus of Yale University, Marie Colvin was always trailing clouds of glory and pandemonium, a former college roommate remembered on Monday.

title: Coney Island Boardwalk Closer to Concrete
description: One speaker waved an ugly chunk of concrete, while another rhapsodized about the slant of sunlight on real wood. But in the end, the New York City Public Design Commission voted to allow the citys parks department to install a section of plastic and concrete to replace aging wood planks on a small section of the Coney Island Boardwalk.

title: An Update on New York Redistricting
description: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: FiveThirtyEight Picks the N.C.A.A. Bracket
description: The long march of the Republican nomination hasnt been very friendly to those political writers who were hoping to enjoy March Madness. But I did dust off the FiveThirtyEight N.C.A.A. forecasting model, which is back with a fresh set of projections for this years mens field. You can find those forecasts here.

title: U.S. Supporters of Iranian Group Face Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a year, prominent former American officials have been giving well-paid speeches in support of an Iranian opposition group that is fighting to reverse its 15-year-old designation by the State Department as a terrorist organization.

title: India Starts Letting Students Do Lab Experiments Online
description: India has begun work on a large online laboratory network, allowing students with Internet access to carry out scientific experiments remotely, Christopher F. Schuetze writes in The New York Times.

title: India Orders Bayer to License a Patented Drug
description: The Indian government on Monday authorized a drug manufacturer to make and sell a generic copy of a patented Bayer cancer drug, saying that Bayer charged a price that was unaffordable to most of the nation, Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Pollack write in The New York Times.

title: On West Coast, Looking for Flotsam of a Disaster
description: SAN FRANCISCO  John Anderson, a plumber by trade and a beachcomber by passion, has been trolling the shores of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State for more than three decades, and along the way has discovered almost every kind of flotsam one can imagine: toys, refrigerators, even the occasional message in a bottle.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/13/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/13/2012

title: Michigan: Detroit May Avoid Imposition of Outside Manager
description: State officials expect on Tuesday to present Detroit leaders with a proposed consent agreement aimed at saving the city from fiscal ruin, a spokeswoman for Gov. Rick Snyder said Monday. Details were in flux, but such a deal would, at least for now, prevent a more extreme fate in which the state would appoint an outside, emergency manager to take over operations in Detroit, which is at risk of running out of money this spring. Under a consent agreement between the state and its largest city, Detroit leaders, who had vehemently objected to an outside manager, would likely be required to meet certain measures, officials said, or risk the appointment of an outside manager later.

title: Watch Your Language! (In China, They Really Do)
description: HONG KONG  Scaling the wall. Buying soy sauce. Fifty cents. A mild collision. May 35. Mayor Lymph. River crab.

title: Albert Abramson, Holocaust Museum Backer, Is Dead at 94
description: Albert Abramson, who became a principal force in the creation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington by using the same pragmatic approach that had made him a successful developer of apartments, offices and malls, died last Tuesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 94.

title: Peter Novick, Wrote Controversial Book on Holocaust, Dies at 77
description: Peter Novick, a history professor at the University of Chicago who stirred controversy in 1999 with a book contending that the legacy of the Holocaust had come to unduly dominate American Jewish identity, died on Feb. 17 at his home in Chicago. He was 77.

title: U.S. Officials Debate Speeding Afghan Pullout
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is discussing whether to reduce American forces in Afghanistan by at least an additional 20,000 troops by 2013, reflecting a growing belief within the White House that the mission there has now reached the point of diminishing returns.

title: News Quiz | March 13, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.Good luck!

title: Is Your Pilot Getting a Paycheck?
description: If youre flying an Indian airline these days, thats a legitimate question.

title: March 13, 1964 | New York Woman Killed While Witnesses Do Nothing
description: On March 13, 1964, a 28-year-old woman named Catherine Kitty Genovese was raped and killed in two separate late-night attacks near her home in Kew Gardens, Queens. Police found that at least 38 people had seen the attacks or heard Genovese scream, but no one intervened and just one woman called the police.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 13, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article With a Solemn March, the Bowery Mourns Its Tent of Antiquity.

title: Devastating, Unexplained Attack in Afghanistan
description: Note: The article and accompanying photographs contain graphic content that may not be appropriate for all students.

title: Why Some Countries Go Bust
description: By his own admission, Daron Acemoglu is a slightly pudgy and fairly nerdy guy with an unpronounceable last name. But when I mentioned that I was interviewing him to two econ buffs, they each gasped and said, I love Daron Acemoglu, as if I were talking about Keith Richards. The Turkish M.I.T. professor  who, right now, is about as hot as economists get  acquired his renown for serious advances in answering the single most important question in his profession, the same one that compelled Adam Smith to write The Wealth of Nations: why are some countries rich while others are poor?

title: Polands Great Adventure
description: Poland is a country of endless Carnival and great disappointment. The Carnival is obvious, and the disappointment is explicable, because things were expected to be different.

title: Do Social Media Campaigns Like Kony 2012 Stunt or Stimulate Real Change?
description: After Invisible Childrens Kony 2012 video went viral, logging more than 70 million views in one week  some experts criticized the campaign, calling it dishonest and even dangerous. Others have suggested that campaigns like these give young people a false sense of accomplishment and discourage real engagement in social issues. What do you think? Have you watched Kony 2012? Do you feel like awareness campaigns like this stimulate or stunt real activism among young people?

title: Militants Attack at Memorial for Massacre Victims
description: PANJWAI, Afghanistan  Militants riding motorcycles attacked a high-level Afghan government delegation during a memorial service on Tuesday in the village where an American soldier is said to have killed 16 people, mostly children and women, in a door-to-door rampage two days earlier.

title: Peter Thiel, Who Paid Students to Drop Out, Will Teach at Stanford
description: Peter Thiel, a co-founder of PayPal who paid students to drop out of school, will teach at Stanford this spring, Reuters reports.

title: Would a Higher Top Tax Rate Raise Revenues?
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Fantasy Focus: Endgame Targets
description: On many occasions, our internal discussions at RotoWire concluded with a statement along the lines of we want to draft off next years cheat sheet.

title: The Odds of March
description: Will you win your N.C.A.A. bracket this year?

title: Cunningham Legacy to Continue in France?
description: Since the Merce Cunningham Dance Company disbanded on Dec. 31, the matter of keeping Cunninghams dances and technique alive, in the classroom and onstage, has been in question. Robert Swinston, a veteran company member, has applied to become the director of the Centre National de Danse Contemporaine in Angers, France. If appointed, he plans to bring two former company members with him  Daniel Madoff and Melissa Toogood  and to start a small group that would perform Cunningham works as well as new dances.

title: Trying to Decide Whether to See Red
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  On Tuesday, Day 2 of the N.H.L. general managers meetings, a big topic on a busy agenda will be the move to put the red line back into effect. That would make two-line passes illegal, as they were before the 2004-5 lockout.

title: Assessing Mosss Signing With San Francisco
description: Before signing on with Jim Harbaugh, Randy Moss caught passes from him. Harbaugh, the Niners coach and a former N.F.L. quarterback, threw to Moss in a workout Monday morning.

title: Gurgaon Rape Peculiar Case, Police Say; Question Victims Statement
description: India Ink spoke Tuesday with K.K. Sindhu, Gurgaons commissioner of police, about a womans allegation that she was gang-raped in the outsourcing mega-city south of Delhi early on Monday morning.

title: The Early Word: Competition
description: In Todays Times:

title: Most of Citys Voters Back Polices Surveillance of Muslims, Poll Finds
description: Updated, 12:15 p.m. | As the controversy deepens over the New York Police Departments efforts to monitor and map local Muslim communities, a majority of New York City voters say that the police have been effective in combating terrorism, and reject the notion that the departments counterterrorism program has unfairly focused on Muslims, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

title: Debt Crisis Provisions Hurt Bundesbank Profit
description: FRANKFURT  The Bundesbank, Germanys central bank, said Tuesday that its profit plunged last year as it set aside money to cover risks from the sovereign debt crisis, a result that is certain to inflame a debate about the role the country plays in financing weaker countries in the euro zone.

title: Manning vs. Tebow in Denver
description: When the Fifth Down last contemplated Tim Tebow, it was after the Broncos loss to the Patriots in the playoffs:

title: Dozens Dead After Ferry Capsizes in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI  Rescuers were searching for survivors on Tuesday after a ferry carrying as many as 200 passengers capsized in Bangladesh, killing at least 24 people with many more feared dead.

title: Uttar Pradesh Elections Sees Jump in Politicians Facing Criminal Charges
description: When Akhilesh Yadav brought his political party to power in Uttar Pradesh, the largest state in India, he declared that no callousness in law and order will be tolerated in the notoriously crime-infested land.

title: In Latest Jobs Bill, a Billion-Dollar Business Is Now Small
description: Bipartisanship returned, however briefly, to Capitol Hill on Thursday, when the House passed, by an overwhelming margin, a bill ostensibly intended to make it easier for start-up companies to raise capital. What this bill does is, it provides a real shot in the arm to entrepreneurs, small-business men and women, removes red tape, allows small businesses an easier time to go about starting up, as well as retaining and creating jobs, Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, said after the Jump-Start Our Business Start-Ups Act sailed through the House on a 390-to-23 vote. (All 23 opponents were Democrats.)

title: Penalties for Redskins and Cowboys Will Cost Them Cap Space
description: Two teams known for big spending will now have a lot less money to offer free agents.

title: In Indias Northeast, Peace and Foreign Ties Quietly Spread
description: In this three part series, the author, a journalist from the Northeast, looks at the quiet transformation happening in once strife-torn region, which could affect trade and geopolitics throughout Asia.

title: Daily Report: A SXSW Stunt Backfires on Marketer
description: It was a marketing idea that sounded good to someone.

title: Same, Same But Different
description: An Israeli air strike on Gaza that killed the leader of the Popular Resistance Committees, Zuhair al-Qissi, on Friday led to four days of crossborder violence. Some 200 rockets rained on Israel, and retaliatory airstrikes killed 25 Palestinians.

title: Turning Up the Heat With Sun Dont Shine
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  After an unseasonably cold and rainy weekend here, the skies have cleared and sunlight has made its return. The warmth is being felt on the streets and on the big screen, particularly in Sun Dont Shine, in South by Southwests Emerging Visions section.

title: Slicing Silicon Thinner to Cut the Price of Solar Cells
description: A California company has unveiled a radical new way to make the silicon wafers that are the basic ingredient of most solar cells, cutting silicon consumption by 90 percent and eliminating the need to use glass and heavy backing to keep the cells rigid.

title: Ex-Murdoch Executive Reportedly Arrested
description: LONDON  Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International, the British newspaper division of Rupert Murdochs media empire, was arrested early Tuesday on suspicion of obstruction of justice, according to a person with knowledge of the arrest. Her husband, Charlie, a friend of Prime Minister David Cameron from their days at Eton three decades ago, was also arrested, the person said.

title: Events in Afghanistan Could Shape 2012 Race
description: So much about the 2012 presidential election is predictable: it will be about gas prices and health care; the deficit, spending and jobs; cultural issues and gender politics; immigration and federal taxes.

title: Leaving Well Alone
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Leaving Well Alone

title: Appetites of a Poetry Virtuoso in America
description: Several people in my life revere Jack Gilbert. They push photocopies of his poems solemnly across tables at me, as if they were salary offers or handguns or unusual drugs. Here, they say. Read this.

title: Tuesday Reading: New Worries About Sleeping Pills
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Unannounced Truce Calms Violence in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Both Israel and the Islamic Jihad militant group in Gaza indicated Tuesday that they would abide by an Egyptian-brokered truce ending four days of cross-border fighting, but each warned that maintaining the calm would depend on the actions of the other side.

title: Opinion Report: Restricting Abortion
description: From the editorial page

title: Fallout Continues Over Teacher Rankings
Las Vegas Sands Faces $375 Million Suit by Former Macau Partner
description: HONG KONG  Las Vegas Sands, the casino operator controlled by the billionaire Sheldon G. Adelson and his family, is facing a new $375 million lawsuit over how the company won a lucrative gambling license in Macau.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MF Global Customers Said to Get Offers for Their Claims | The thousands of MF Global customers whose lives and businesses were derailed after $1.6 billion vanished in the collapse of the brokerage firm have now received offers to sell their claims and recoup nearly the entire shortfall, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: Apollo to Acquire Water Park Operator for $703 Million
description: Apollo Global Management will buy Great Wolf Resort, the nations largest indoor water park operator, for $703 million, as the private equity firm pushes further into the hospitality and leisure industry.

title: At Turnaround Meeting, the Big Question Was 'Why?'
Check In, Roll Out
description: Savvy hotels across the country are riding the urban-cycling trend, offering two wheels to guests at no additional charge.

title: Syria Expands Assault, Hitting Rebel Enclaves in City in North
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Emboldened by faltering diplomacy and a Russian pledge to keep supplying weapons, Syrias armed forces assaulted insurgent enclaves in the northern part of the country on Tuesday, invading the city of Idlib in an expanded campaign to crush the year-old uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

title: For Albanys Latest Struggle, Blame Air-Conditioning
description: You want to know what the root of the trouble is in New Yorks struggle to create new Congressional districts? It isnt political sclerosis in Albany, though that is generally a safe bet. No, New Yorks problem is air-conditioning. Truly. Air-conditioning has been hurting the state politically for more than half a century, and it will keep doing so.

title: Afghanistan: When Even the Danes Turn on the War
description: LONDON  Denmark is in Afghanistan to secure Denmark. That is the bald official message that has sustained a Danish contribution to NATO-led operations in Afghanistan for a decade.

title: Image of the Day:  March 13
The Breakfast Meeting: Rebekah Brooks Arrested and Wi-Fi via the Homeless
description: The British police on Tuesday morning arrested Rebekah Brooks, the former top executive of Rupert Murdochs News International, and her husband, The Associated Press reported. The arrests are part of the investigation into phone hacking. A total of six people were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice, the police said in a statement.

title: Los Tigres del Norte Banned in Mexican City
description: The government of Chihuahua, Mexico, one of the cities most afflicted by violence in that nations drug war, has forbidden the norteo band Los Tigres del Norte to play there after a performance that included songs the government said glorified drug traffickers.

title: Leading Aluminum Companys Chairman Quits in Dispute
description: MOSCOW  A big shareholder in a leading aluminum company stepped down as chairman on Tuesday in a dispute with another wealthy Russian owner about whether the company, Rusal, should focus solely on aluminum or also keep a foothold in other mining ventures.

title: Morning Buzz, March 13: Rockets in the Sky
description: Good morning. The day will start overcast and possibly rainy before breaking to a slightly cloudy 70 degrees by the afternoon.

title: What Were Reading
description: Travel and Leisure: Noma was just the beginning: Adam Sachs on how Copenhagen got to be the new epicenter of the food world. As one chef puts it: Noma is teaching us is to do our own thing. Not everyone has to forage and use sea buckthorn and pine needles. The point is to do something that other people dont    Jeff Gordinier

title: British Regulator Fines Credit Suisse Executive
description: LONDON  The Financial Services Authority has fined Nicholas Kyprios, head of European credit sales at Credit Suisse, for disclosing confidential client information, the latest in a number of prominent actions by the British regulator.
