title: Marine Invaders, Coming to a Coast Near You
description: Molgula manhattensis, the sea grape, is a greenish globule that sticks to oyster shells and can ruin aquaculture. Didemnum vexillum, fondly referred to as rock vomit, forms yellowish spongy mats over not just rocks but nonmobile creatures as well, ultimately suffocating them. Diplosoma listerianum, which has no common name (D-List, anyone?), drapes itself in crusty layers over corals, grasses and other organisms.

title: Press-ganging the Turkish Media
description: ISTANBUL  The British say it about the police force, but the same may be true of the press: that a country gets the one it deserves. Woe is Turkey.

title: Terrell Thomas Agrees to New Deal with the Giants
description: 3:00 p.m. | Updated The Giants secured one of their biggest potential free agents on Tuesday shortly before N.F.L. free agency even began.

title: Do Most Mississippi Republicans Think Obama Is a Muslim?
description: There is not a shred of truth to the rumor that President Obama is not really an American citizen, or that hes secretly a Muslim. And yet the stories wont die, because people keep repeating them and unscrupulous politicians are happy to capitalize on them.

title: Votes Are More Against Than For in 2 Southern States
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  Voters in Alabama and Mississippi went to the polls on Tuesday morning to settle what appeared to be a three-way-tie in the latest primaries for the Republican presidential nomination. A win in either or even both states for Mitt Romney, unforeseeable in the polls just days ago, seemed more and more possible in recent days, and could help his campaigns claims that he is the inevitable nominee. It would also give Mr. Romney a victory in one of the most conservative parts of the country, and help ease concerns about his acceptance by the Republican base.

title: In Egypt, Rival Ultras Meet to Show Common Cause
description: CAIRO  Mere months ago, fans of Al Ahly and Zamalek clashed on the streets. On Sunday night they stood side by side, red alongside white, a hand of one often resting in unspoken friendship on the shoulder of another.

title: Trial Near, Mets Owners and Trustee Argue Fair and Foul
description: The owners of the Mets want the Hall of Fame pitcher Sandy Koufax to testify at their federal trial. The court-appointed trustee suing them says Koufax would be a distraction.

title: Spokes People
description: New York isnt the only major American city to go the way of the bicycle. Chicago is getting a public bike share this summer and 100 miles of new protected bike lanes by 2015, all part of Mayor Rahm Emanuels plan to make his city the most cyclist-friendly in the country. For now try Chicago B-Cycle, a bike share with a few stations near the Lakefront Trail, an 18-mile path along Lake Michigan. Cruisers, hybrids and more can be rented at the McDonalds Cycle Center (312-729-1000), a state-of-the-art facility for commuters. Or buy your own: Working Bikes Cooperative (773-847-5440) sells restored discarded bikes on the cheap; J. C. Lind Bike Company (312-643-1670) and Copenhagen Cyclery (773-456-0024) carry the best Danish cargo bikes; Method Bicycle (312-965-8635) makes bespoke steel frames. Nothing heralds the citys status as a cycling stronghold quite like the newly opened Heritage Bicycles General Store (above; 773-245-3005), a bike shop-cafe where you can order a custom bike, get a tuneup, scarf a soup-and-salad lunch and tank up on Stumptown coffee, an export from that other great bike town, Portland, Ore.

title: Business Day Live | March 13, 2012
description: An I.B.M. executive talks about the changing digital landscape for retailers; Binyamin Applebaum previews a federal reserve meeting; and Start-ups compete for attention at South by Southwest.

title: Palin-Focused Film Game Change Draws Big Audience to HBO
description: Riding outstanding reviews and a flood of attention because of the controversy around its portrayal of Sarah Palin, the HBO film Game Change attracted a big audience for the pay-cable channel Saturday night.

title: Honored for His Service After Two Decades on a City Bus
description: Jefrick R. Dean Sr. has worked for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for 22 years. More than two decades of lurching on a city bus, dealing with the occasional unruly commuter, and delivering repeated tutorials in MetroCard swiping and general bus etiquette might drive lesser New Yorkers to distraction. But Mr. Dean, who will be 52 in July, has no plans to retire, which is good news to his passengers on the round-trip run from East New York to downtown Brooklyn.

title: Business Day Live: Retail Sales Increase
description: An I.B.M. executive talks about the changing digital landscape for retailers; Binyamin Appelbaum previews a Federal Reserve meeting; and start-ups compete for attention at South by Southwest.

title: Scale and Energy Booms, Continued
description: My posts on the North Dakota energy boom, and its lack of implications for state that actually have a significant number of people, have gotten quite a few comments. So Ive hit on what I think is a useful comparison: North Dakota versus Pennsylvania.

title: Wheelies: The Payload Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: What Teaching Students Can Learn from Poor, Urban Schools
description: Hesston College is a small, two-year college in Kansas with the slogan Start Here. Go Anywhere. Last month, a group of education majors did go somewhere: their professor took them to observe education at work in the inner city of Tulsa, Okla. For Hesston students, accustomed to doing their classroom observation in fairly affluent and rural areas, the trip was what their professor described as cross-cultural.

title: BB&T Restructures BankAtlantic Deal
description: The BB&T Corporation retooled its planned takeover of BankAtlantic on Tuesday in an attempt to appease a judge who previously blocked the deal for the beleaguered Florida bank.

title: Out There | Fair Games

title: Boston Mobsters Companion to Plead Guilty to Helping Him Evade Capture
description: BOSTON  Catherine Greig, the companion of the Boston mobster James (Whitey) Bulger, is expected to plead guilty to charges that she helped him evade capture for 16 years, say relatives of his alleged murder victims who were briefed on the matter.

title: N.F.L. Strips Cowboys and Redskins of Salary Cap Room
description: Free agency opens in the N.F.L. on Tuesday, but two teams known for big spending have a lot less to spend.

title: Alabama Governor Says He Voted for Santorum
description: Rick Santorum received an Election Day gift on Tuesday morning when he learned that Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama had voted for him in the states primary.

title: Leading Off: The New Superpower
description: In the N.C.A.A. universe, the womens basketball tournament continues to operate as its own smaller galaxy, its stars not quite as shiny, its bracket creating no madness. Its through no fault of the women players, who have developed in great leaps and now boast another level of star in Baylors Brittney Griner, but as the mens tournament fills our sky, you need a telescope to find the women.

title: Thomas Puccio, Ex-Prosecutor and Lawyer for Notorious Clients, Dies at 67
description: Thomas P. Puccio, a tigerish New York lawyer who won fame prosecuting congressmen in the 1980s Abscam scandals, then switched sides and defended Claus von Blow, corrupt politicians, an accused rapist who ran off to the ski slopes of Europe and other notorious clients, died on Monday in New Haven. He was 67.

title: At Shareholder Meeting, Disney Commits to Hire 1,000 Veterans
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Companys senior executives decamped to Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday to conduct their annual meeting for shareholders and made sure as always to bring a piece of positive news: Heroes Work Here.

title: Rocking the Friendly Skies
description: Even the most devout lover of magazines draws the line at rooting about in the seat pocket in front of them for something good to read. Next time Im on a plane, however, I just might do that, inspired by this fascinating article about a Chinese punk-rock band that an old high-school friend sent me on Facebook. Published in United Airlines Hemispheres Magazine, it profiles a band called Carsick Cars and contains anumber of memorable details, including this:

title: Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire to Protest Chinese Rule
description: An 18-year-old Tibetan monk, Gepey, died Saturday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibetan areas, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.

title: Who Bit My Border?
description: You probably dont think much about the border between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. And when you do, you might not think much of it. It looks so straightforward and simple: following the 141st meridian east, it neatly splits the island of New Guinea [1] in two almost equal halves. The western half is part of Indonesia, while the eastern half forms the bulk of the independent state of Papua New Guinea, which also consists of the Bismarck Archipelago [2] and several smaller islands.

title: Q. and A.: Tracking the Elusive Wolverine
description: In Mondays paper, I wrote about a new group called Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation that is working to link outdoors types with researchers who can benefit from their back-country skills and data-gathering. I reported from western Montana, where Gregg Treinish, the groups founder, was jointly leading a weekend expedition of a dozen volunteers tracking the wolverine.

title: Glencores Potential Bid for Viterra May Face Challenges
description: LONDON  Deals can be like city buses. You wait a long time for one, then two show up at once.

title: Political Geography: Alabama
description: Our state-by-state profile of the Republican electorate  a mixture of analysis from local experts, demographic data and past voting results  lands today in the Deep South, first in Alabama, then in Mississippi.

title: His District Likely to Be Cut, Congressman Eyes Gillibrands Senate Seat
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Bob Turner, a Republican who unexpectedly won a House seat in a closely watched special election last year, has decided to run for the United States Senate in New York, seeking to oust Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat.

title: The High Cost of Insider Trading
description: The cost of insider trading is well known on Wall Street. Shuttered firms, frightened portfolio managers, costly lawsuits and expensive compliance.

title: TimesCast | March 13, 2012
description: The former editor of News International is said to have been arrested | Truce calms four days of cross-border fighting in Gaza | High stakes for the Republican candidates in two Southern states.

title: At One Mississippi Polling Place, Sharp Divisions
description: DIXIE, Miss.  Here in the heart of Dixie, Miss., a little town outside of Hattiesburg, voters filed into the Dixie Community Center in a trickle, often commenting on the mostly empty parking lot.

title: Bachelor Finale Brings an Uptick in Ratings
description: A parade of quickly collapsed reality show romances has not completely dimmed interest in ABCs The Bachelor. The finale of the latest edition (Ben Flajnik picked Courtney for those keeping score) raised the shows ratings enough to hurt the NBC songfest, The Voice.

title: Newport Jazz Festival Announces Lineup
description: The Newport Jazz Festival will be anchored this year by the guitarist Pat Metheny, the drummer Jack DeJohnette and the vocalist Kurt Elling, among dozens of other acts, George Wein, a festival founder, announced on Tuesday.

title: Adding a Colorful Gloss to a Black-and-White World
description: WASHINGTON  Random observations upon strolling through a new exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery here:

title: Target of Llodras Racial Slur Says Fine Is Not Enough
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Save for the chilly breeze that often blows through the desert air after sunset, it is hard to imagine a more perfect setting for tennis than mountain-lined Indian Wells, home of the BNP Paribas Open.

title: Kyrgyzstan Wants Military Role to End at U.S. Base
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  One of Kyrgyzstans top defense officials told Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Tuesday that a crucial United States air base here should have no military mission when its lease expires a little more than two years from now. The request creates a potential hurdle to American plans to withdraw from Afghanistan in 2014.

title: Share the Road
description: Bike shares are sprouting in cities all over the world: Taipei, Tel Aviv, Barcelona, Berlin and Mexico City, to name only a few. For the five mapped below, find out how many bikes and docks are at each station with the Spotcycle app.

title: The View from B.Y.U.: A Team That Counts on Defense
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Mets Injuries Start to Wear on Collins
description: The Mets injury beat kept going Tuesday, and the frustration is starting to wear on Manager Terry Collins.

title: The View from Iona: Suspense, and Then a Selection
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Obama Promises Thorough Inquiry Into Afghan Attack
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama pledged on Tuesday that a thorough investigation would be conducted into the bloody rampage by an American soldier in Afghanistan.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Evaluating Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Unspooling Laughs at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In addition to genre films, South by Southwest is known as a testing ground for comedies, a way for filmmakers and studios to gauge audience reaction.

title: A Boy Sergeant Fights at New Bern
description: On March 13, 1862, an imposing convoy of Union transports lay at anchor in the middle of coastal North Carolinas Neuse River. During the early morning hours, a portion of the convoy steamed toward land, pulling small boats packed with thousands of soldiers  a division-size invasion force commanded by Ambrose E. Burnside, a bewhiskered brigadier whose star was on the rise.

title: Beltran Visits Mets; Says He Misses the Food
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Carlos Beltran returned here Tuesday with his new team, the St. Louis Cardinals, and said that his knees were good, that he missed the cooking in the Mets clubhouse and that he was eager to check out pitcher Jon Nieses new nose.

title: Employers Dangle Carrots for Behaviors That Help Lower Costs
description: More big employers are dangling financial incentives to persuade workers and their families to adopt healthier behaviors and help control health care costs, a new survey reports.

title: General Motors and NASA Pair Up to Design Interstellar Work Glove
description: General Motors has retrained its focus on technology destined for outer space. Those awaiting the worlds first galaxy-hopping private aircraft, however, may be disappointed.

title: A Greener Strategy for New Yorks Runaway Sewage
description: New York State and city officials announced Tuesday that they had wrapped up an agreement under which the city would commit more than $2 billion in public and private investment to new environmental techniques to help prevent the flow of untreated sewage and storm water into city waterways when it rains.

title: Dell to Buy Security Services Provider for $1.25 Billion
description: Dell said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy SonicWall, a privately held provider of data security measures for businesses, to continue expanding its corporate services offerings.

title: Guidebooks, Schmidebooks: 5 Hidden Gems in New York City
description: How many times have you heard this?: We stumbled on this place that wasnt in our guidebook  In this age of hyper-documentation, where theres hardly a vending machine on Earth that hasnt had the merits of its candy selection debated on TripAdvisor, guidebooks are still the trusty standby for travelers tackling a new city. Yet, in a way, theyre also the enemy: stick just to whats in the guidebook, and making a discovery  a place best known to locals and a few intrepid travelers  becomes unlikely at best. Every trip needs a Christopher Columbus moment or two.

title: On Bravo TV Show, Avery Says Hes Retired
description: Having been set free by his minor league team to pursue any and all television appearances without interference from a hockey season, Sean Avery was all smiles during an episode of Watch What Happens Live! on Bravo. When asked about his hockey future by Nicole Richie, Avery said: I am officially retired. I threw my skates in the Hudson.

title: Citi Customers Can Deposit Checks With Their Phones
description: Citibank is the latest bank to add remote deposit capture, which lets customers snap a photo of a check with their phone and with the touch of a button, deposit it into their bank account. No trip to the A.T.M. required.

title: One Schlep Forward
description: My dad and I waited at the Aeroflot check-in counter at Kennedy Airport, the only two people in line without payos, side curls, and zizit, the knotted threads that hang from the waists of Orthodox men. Six Hasids schmoozed in Russified Yiddish as a Hispanic porter pushed their trolley of bulging suitcases.

title: Asked & Answered | Gideon Lewis-Kraus
description: The excerpt in our summer travel issue, One Schlep Forward, is about a Hasidic pilgrimage to Uman, Ukraine, one of three sacred journeys that Gideon Lewis-Kraus undertook for his forthcoming book, A Sense of Direction (Riverhead Books). (The others took him to an ancient cathedral in northwestern Spain and across the Japanese island of Shikoku.) A frequent contributor to N+1 and Harpers Magazine, Lewis-Kraus recently returned to Japan to report on the relationship between cats and the Internet for Wired. In the following interview, he talks about his book and how taking a trio of pilgrimages has affected his more secular travels.

title: Shes Back, Branding Irons in Hand
description: IT was a bleak afternoon on the outskirts of Manhattans garment district. At street level, wholesalers peddled costume jewelry and satin prom gowns.

title: Crosby Eyes Thursday Return Against Rangers
description: Sidney Crosby will be in the lineup for the Pittsburgh Penguins when they play the Rangers at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

title: Obama Campaign Fears Uphill Climb Raising Super PAC Money
description: The warning came from David Plouffe, President Obamas top political adviser: The Koch brothers and Republican super PACs have pledged hundreds of millions of dollars to defeat Mr. Obama, he told a dozen wealthy Democrats gathered in a Silicon Valley office suite. Do not believe what you read about all the money the president will raise himself, Mr. Plouffe urged them. He needs your help.

title: Blue Bottle Coffee Comes to Midtown
description: On Tuesday morning, the newest Blue Bottle Coffee opened at Rockefeller Center. The small, sleek shop is located underground on the concourse level, and its built for speed. The room is divided into two sections, each with its own line and coffee setup: a Strada machine, extra-long drip bar, iced drinks, pastries and granola baked at the Blue Bottle Coffee roaster in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Its made-to-order coffee with the Midtown rush in mind.

title: Prime Suspect Arrested in the Killing of Argentine Folk Singer
description: The police in Colombia have announced the arrest of the man they say is responsible for the killing of the Argentine folk singer Facundo Cabral, who was on tour in Guatemala last summer when he was shot to death on his way to the airport. The authorities described the man, Alejandro Jimnez Gonzlez, a Costa Rican, as involved in the leadership and direction of an organized mafia engaged in money laundering and other criminal activities throughout Central America. According to news reports from Colombia, Mr. Jimnez, 37, was arrested when he arrived there on Monday aboard a cruise ship.

title: Race, Republicans and Realignment
description: So long as Im arguing with Jonathan Chait about the nature of the Republican Party, I should say something about his recent case for treating white ethnocentrism as the core of contemporary conservatism. Here, from hissometimes-perceptive, sometimes-less-so essay on the Republican Party in 2012, is Chaits race-based readon the making and unmaking of a conservative majority:

title: In Vibrant Color
description: Photographs from the exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery.

title: Reading Between the Tree Rings
description: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory  at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

title: 2012 Fantasy Baseball Preview: Outfield
description: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy sports advice on Bats, The Fifth Down and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: In Otherwise Dour Report From Fed, the Tiniest Touch of Optimism
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve on Tuesday offered a slightly more upbeat account of the American economy, but added that it planned to continue its efforts to improve growth.

title: Terrorist Was Not Killed in Airstrike, Malaysian Official Says
description: MANILA  A major terrorist linked to Al Qaeda who the Philippine military maintains was killed last month probably escaped alive, a senior Malaysian police official said.

title: In Missouri, Romney Attacks Obama for Rising Gas Prices
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo.  Standing in front of a jungle gym, Mitt Romney spoke to voters crowded onto picnic benches here Tuesday morning and attacked President Obama over rising gas prices.

title: Hands Give a Lift, Now They Can Get One
description: DORIAN GRAYS countenance may have had the texture of a babys behind, but did anyone ever look at his hands?

title: Sarah Palin: Stop Using My Words Against Me
description: Sarah Palin is unhappy. A new Barack Obama campaign ad quotes her out of context, she says, as part of an effort by the far Left to divert everyone from the real issues that the president doesnt want to talk about.

title: Afghan Killings Reverberate in Congress
description: The case of an American soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians has roiled political support in Congress for the military campaign in Afghanistan, with a prominent Republican senator accusing his partys candidates for president of undermining the nations military commanders.

title: Organized Labor Sets Course for Election
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  As the A.F.L.-C.I.O.s winter meeting opened here on Tuesday, its political director mapped out organized labors plans for the 2012 campaign and how unions will respond to what he says will be $500 million in super PAC ads backing Republicans.

title: Goldman Hires a New P.R. Chief
description: Richard Siewert Jr., the man Goldman Sachs has been courting to lead its public relations effort, has been officially hired, according to an internal memo from the investment bank.

title: N.C.A.A. Bracket Office Hours
description: The Timess sports department experimented for the first time on Tuesday with Google+ video hangouts for a discussion about the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis were on hand to answer questions and give their opinions about how to fill in this years bracket. Thanks to some technical issues, the conversation sometimes steered off course, but Pete, Connor and some Times readers still supplied plenty of food for thought for those looking to predict this years path to the Final Four.

title: In a First, Europeans Act to Suspend Aid to Hungary Unless It Cuts Deficit
description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers agreed Tuesday for the first time to punish one of their members for flouting the blocs budget rules, deciding to suspend payment to Hungary of nearly 500 million euros in development money next year unless it makes progress on reducing its deficit.

title: Ray Dalios Former Assistant Tells All
description: Ray Dalio has been in the news quite a bit lately.

title: Canada Bends Rules for Madonna Concert at the Plains of Abraham
description: OTTAWA  Although more than 252 years have passed since a battle was fought on the Plains of Abraham in Quebec City, it remains an area fraught with historical significance.

title: Our Readers See Stars, and Ask Why
description: After The Los Angeles Times announced last week that its restaurant reviewers would no longer give out stars , a couple of commenters on Diners Journal suggested that The New York Times should follow suit.

title: A Menagerie in the Lake
description: There was room enough for everyone in the Prospect Park Lake on Monday: from left, a double-crested cormorant, a Canada goose, a red-eared slider turtle, a ring-billed gull and a mallard seemed to coexist quite peacefully.

title: Photo Replay: March 13
description: The day in sports included cricket in Bangladesh, Champions League soccer in Italy and horse racing at the Cheltenham Festival in England.

title: Denmark Cant Avoid the Radar
description: SOME chefs storm into the city like an invading navy, gunships of publicity thundering on the horizon.

title: Acme
description: Inside the shabby-chic bistro from the Danish chef Mads Refslund.

title: Site to Be Seen | Avenue 32
description: Live since December 2011, Avenue32.com is helping to usher in fashions next generation, one click at a time. The concept: showcase recent design-school graduates alongside industry staples (Preen, Thakoon Addition, and Dean Harris jewelry, for example) in the form of a comprehensive online shopping experience.I worked for a young designer and know how many of them struggle to control the way their brands are portrayed online, says Roberta Benteler, a co-founder of Avenue32.com, which is based in London but quickly converts pounds to dollars for United States visitors. The site was born out of the desire to create a platform that supports the customers and designers needs alike with an exciting and fresh brand mix.

title: Five Dishes at Acme
description: This week I review the reborn Acme on Great Jones Street, a shabby-chic bistro with food from Mads Refslund, a Danish chef who helped found one of the worlds most celebrated restaurants. Foodies who come for Mr. Refslunds cooking rub elbows with an art- and fashion-world crowd cultivated by Jean-Marc Houmard and some of Acmes other owners at their previous restaurants, notably Indochine.

title: Mets Make Room for Prospective Tenant
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It looks like a giant unfinished basement, and smells like one. And the Mets future here could ultimately depend on whether this cavernous structure is finished, and furnished with another major league team.

title: AOL Slashes Staff at AIM Unit; Wider Cuts Expected
description: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

title: Musicians Union Objects to Taylor Dance Companys Use of Recorded Music
description: The New York musicians union has denounced the Paul Taylor Dance Company for performing at Lincoln Center without a live orchestra, which the company said was far beyond its means. The union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, promised to distribute leaflets and provide outdoor performances to bring attention to the issue before the Taylor companys first show of a 21-performance run at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Political Geography: Mississippi
description: By the time Mississippi held its Republican presidential primary in 2008, Senator John McCain of Arizona had all but secured the nomination, so the results are not terribly helpful in foreshadowing todays contest. Mr. McCain won the state with 79 percent of the vote. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, earned just 13 percent, and Representative Ron Paul of Texas received 4 percent. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, had dropped out weeks earlier.

title: Activism or Slacktivism? The Stop Kony Campaign as a Teachable Moment
description: Note to Teacher | This lesson suggests showing photographs and videos of brutality wrought in Africa by Joseph Kony and the Lords Resistance Army. The slide shows, videos and articles contain graphic material that may not be appropriate for all students.

title: Kerrey to Start TV Ads in Senate Race
description: Former Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who hopes to be the next Democratic senator from Nebraska, is about to air his first television advertisements.

title: Rising Tide of Jobs Lifts Most States, Not All
description: The job market seems to be thawing and employers are gradually hiring, but a lot still depends on geography. Nevada continued its run as the state with the highest level of joblessness in January, with a 12.7 percent unemployment rate, down from 13.8 percent a year earlier, according to the Labor Department.

title: The Brief Return of the Woman Who Wasnt There
description: Readers will approach The Woman Who Wasnt There: The True Story of an Incredible Deception knowing how its going to end. Tania Head, who claimed a place in the publics heart for having narrowly escaped death in the south tower of the World Trade Center  Americas most famous survivor, the authors call her  will be revealed as an impostor.

title: Is There a Chief Comments Moderator?
description: My post yesterday on Times commenting rules, and how to get through the @#&$* and Hitler filters, drew questions about the moderation process, starting with whether we have a chief moderator.

title: A Few More Words of Advice About Your Bracket
description: Before the 2011-12 college basketball season began, The Quad ran an analysis that showed field goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin are the statistics most correlated with teams reaching the Final Four. With that in mind, we now answer a six pack of questions you might consider before filling out your brackets. Of course, results may vary.

title: Nasdaq Finishes Above 3,000, Its Best Since Dot-Com Bubble
description: Stocks rose to new heights on Tuesday, in part on stronger retail sales data, pushing the broad market to levels last seen in June 2008 and the Nasdaq composite index to close above 3,000 for the first time since 2000.

title: Trying to Attract the Perfect Customer
description: In my last blog post, I wrote about how my advertising agency wound up spending a lot of time going after a customer we hadnt initially identified as needing our services  and how we then analyzed our list of current customers and realized that most of those highly treasured companies on our roster sought us out, not vice versa.

title: Planet Hollywood in Times Square to Cohabit With an Italian Restaurant
description: When the first Planet Hollywood opened near Carnegie Hall more than 20 years ago, it sparked a wave of casual restaurants cluttered with memorabilia from movies and other forms of entertainment.

title: Metropolitan Opera Offers New App for for iPads
description: Now you can prop yourself up in bed with Aida, Salome and Gilda. The Metropolitan Opera said on Tuesday that it was extending its opera on-demand service to iPads through a new app. The app is free but the streaming service starts at $14.99 a month, giving viewers access to several hundred radio and television broadcasts and more recent Live in HD transmissions to movie theaters, with more to be added regularly.

title: Top-Seeded Orange Lose Key Player on Defense
description: Syracuse announced Tuesday that center Fab Melo would not play in the N.C.A.A. tournament, a move that decreases the top-seeded Oranges chances of playing for the national title.

title: Insider Trading Charges Center on Alcoholics Anonymous Meetings
description: The governments sweeping crackdown on insider trading has focused on hedge fund trading floors and corporate boardrooms. On Tuesday, it reached into Alcoholics Anonymous.

title: Up to His Neck in Blood, Shark Heads and Deadlines
description: It seems impossibly retro in this computer-generated age, but at least one guy is still creating creepy movie effects out of resin and blood bottles.

title: Deadly Mosque Arson in Belgium Attributed to Sunni-Shiite Friction
description: LONDON  An arsonists attack on a Shiite mosque in a Brussels suburb that left its 46-year-old imam dead provoked shock and grief among Belgiums Muslim population on Tuesday, but the authorities there attributed the attack to tensions between the Shiite and Sunni communities  not a new case of the so-called Islamophobia hostility that has been rising in Europe.

title: In Taurus Inquiry, Safety Agency Requests Information on 1.52 Million Additional Vehicles
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has requested information on a further 1.52 million vehicles to assist in its investigation of 395,000 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models. The sedans became the subject of an investigation after owners claimed on the agencys Web site that loose cruise control cables caused throttles to become stuck, resulting in unintended acceleration.

title: In Alabama and Mississippi, Romney Competes in Unfavorable Terrain
description: Demographically, the primaries in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday should not be favorable to Mitt Romney.

title: Why Children Need More Chores
description: Are Americans raising a generation of dependent children?

title: S.E.C. Charges Three Former Mortgage Executives With Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges on Tuesday against three former executives at Thornburg Mortgage, once the nations second-largest mortgage company after Countrywide Financial, saying that they hid the companys deteriorating financial condition at the onset of the financial crisis in 2008.

title: 15 of 19 Big Banks Pass Feds Latest Stress Test
description: The Federal Reserve had a key take-away from the latest round of stress tests: most big banks are in good shape.

title: Saying Hello With Youthful Exuberance
description: For two young musicians out to make a lasting first impression, it would be hard to pick a more appropriate selection of pieces than those chosen by the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the pianist Yekwon Sunwoo on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: On a Bench in Paris, a Look at a Life Not Yet Lived
description: Hindsight may always be 20/20, but the clarity of Simon Van Booys Hindsight is much harder to determine.

title: Chinas New Law on Detentions Puts Spotlight on Black Jails
description: Chinas highest legislative body is expected to approve changes on Wednesday for dealing with accused criminals that the government says will protect suspects rights and activists worry enshrine a loophole that would legalize secret detentions for many political dissidents.

title: Obama Files a Complaint Over China
description: WASHINGTON  If there was ever any doubt about the political salience of China in an election year, it was erased Tuesday, when President Obama stepped before cameras in the White House Rose Garden to announce a procedural move in a long-running trade dispute with China over rare earth metals.

title: Specialists in Rare Earths Say a Trade Case Against China May Be Too Late
description: HONG KONG  Even as the United States, the European Union and Japan jointly filed a trade case Tuesday against China over its export restrictions on strategic rare earth metals, many specialists could not help wondering whether it was too little and too late for Western and Japanese manufacturers.

title: TimesCast | Rebekah Brooks is Arrested
description: March 13, 2012 - Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International was arrested, according to sources. She was among six people taken into custody relating to the phone hacking scandal.

title: Muddled Economic Picture Muddles the Political One, Too
description: WASHINGTON  The final major economic turning point of President Obamas first term seems to have arrived. The question is which way the economy will turn.

title: Charity Officer Is Charged With Stealing
description: ALBANY  The top financial officer for a Bronx charity started by State Senator Rubn Daz Sr. was arrested on Tuesday on a charge of stealing at least $75,000 from the organization.

title: Dolphins, Pursuing Manning,  Trade Brandon Marshall
description: As Jay Glazer first reported, the Dolphins kicked off the free-agency period with the first big move, trading wide receiver Brandon Marshall to Chicago for two third-round picks.

title: The Tax Man Cometh for a Former Lehman Banker
description: The home of Bradley H. Jack, the former Lehman Brothers banking chief who has been arrested twice for allegedly forging drug prescriptions, may be sold at auction after he failed to pay property taxes. Bloomberg News reports Mr. Jack owes $271,923 on his 20-acre waterfront house in Fairfield, Conn.Read more

title: TimesCast | The Southern Primaries
description: March 13, 2012 - Hawaii, Alabama and Mississippi are voting on Tuesday for the Republican nominee.

title: TimesCast | Truce Calms Gaza Violence
description: March 13, 2012 - An Egyptian-brokered truce has apparently ended four days of cross borderfighting between Israel and forces inside Gaza.

title: Tokyo Tunes Up
description: That Tokyos subway system is one of the most efficient in the world hasnt slowed a recent two-wheel invasion of the citys streets. An aboveground alternative to the rush-hour crunch, bicycles also proved to be one of the more reliable forms of transportation after the 2011 earthquake; with trains halted and taxis in gridlock, desperate commuters bought out local bike shops. The citys many flat roads are ideal for cruising, even if the numerous unnamed streets pose a challenge. Local riders swear by the navigation-meets-social-networking app Navinko, available on iTunes, but if youve left the iPhone at home, consider joining the Tokyo Great Cycling Tour, a guided one-day ride that includes rentals.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Endorses Obama
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Although it came as no surprise, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nations main union federation, gave President Obama its powerful endorsement on Tuesday, promising to deploy hundreds of thousands of union volunteers on his behalf.

title: Updates From Alabama and Mississippi Primaries
description: The Times is covering Tuesdays primaries and caucuses and providing live updates and analysis. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

title: Study Warns of Economic Damage in a Keystone Pipeline Spill
description: A report released on Tuesday by Cornell Universitys Global Labor Institute concludes that the economic damage caused by potential spills from the Keystone XL pipeline could far outweigh the benefits of jobs created by the project.

title: Irish Coffee, American Ingenuity
description: FOR a holiday that has come to involve so much alcohol, St. Patricks Day is badly in need of a good drink. Beer, even tinted green, is too workaday. Stout is too stolid. Sweet liqueurs like Irish Mist and Baileys Irish Cream are just too everything.

title: St. Bonaventures N.C.A.A. Double Feature
description: St. Bonaventure doesnt get to celebrate many moments of basketball glory, but suddenly, its luck has runneth over. Not only has the womens team risen to a new level, grabbing a No. 5 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament after a 29-3 season, even after losing the conference tournament final to Dayton, but the mens team made a surprising run through the Atlantic 10 tournament and grabbed an automatic bid when it toppled Xavier in the final on Sunday.

title: New Pastry Chefs at Le Bernardin and Jean Georges
description: IN a coincidence on a cake plate, two of the citys highest-profile pastry chefs left their jobs at the end of last year. Their replacements at Le Bernardin and Jean Georges have been named, and this next generation is now busily tending to the trades ganaches, meringues, herbal syrups and flecks of gold leaf.

title: La Tour dArgent Products Now Sold in New York
description: A line of products from La Tour dArgent, the venerable Paris restaurant overlooking Notre-Dame, is now being sold in New York. Jars of preserves in uncommonly aromatic flavors, including raspberry-violet, orange with orange-flower water and apricot-amaretto, are among the standouts. The line also includes clementine, and strawberry made with two kinds of berries, the regular cultivated kind and a variety called gariguette, which comes from Provence and is similar to fraises des bois. Breton butter cookies, a tea blend and a fig and grape chutney are also available.

title: I Was a Cookbook Ghostwriter
description: YOU. Girl with the notebook. Out.

title: Right-Bank Sweets on the Lower East Side
description: With chocolate, freshness counts. And its all but guaranteed at Christian Vautier Le Concept, a new boutique and cafe on the Lower East Side where truffles, chocolate-enrobed bonbons and other confections  including caramels, chocolate spreads and fruit jellies  are made daily. It is owned by Mr. Vautier, a Parisian chocolate maker and the executive pastry chef at the Grand Intercontinental Hotel in Paris. I did not want to have a French product sent over here to sell, said Mr. Vautier, whose partner is Aditi Malhotra (right), a graduate of the French Culinary Institute. Ms. Malhotra, whose family has been in the hotel and restaurant business in India and New York, is making the chocolates, often with unusual fillings like Sichuan pepper ganache. She also makes pastries, including chocolate mousse, macarons and profiteroles. The bright shop, its springtime colors in step with the season, also offers teas and Dallis Brothers coffee.

title: An Inconvenient Statement, Retracted
description: Energy Secretary Steven Chu on Tuesday walked away from his oft-quoted pre-Cabinet statement that the United States should deliberately raise gasoline prices to discourage consumption.

title: For a Shamrock Toast, Drinks With Irish Ties
description: The lineage of Innis & Gunn beers is complicated. They are brewed and bottled in Scotland, but their claim to fame is the time they spend in whisky and rum casks, giving them rich, alluring depth. The latest, Irish Whiskey Cask Scottish Stout, with a shamrock-green label, is aged in Irish whiskey barrels. This brown beer, with 7.4 percent alcohol, evokes coffee and ginger in its aromas and tastes toasty, with a refreshing, bitter chocolate finish. In an odd way, it suggests Irish coffee.

title: Volkswagen Has Fun Giving Away ber-Hard-to-Get Kraftwerk Tickets
description: Volkswagen of America has come up with a clever way to remind consumers of its German heritage  or should that be klever?

title: New York State Set to Add All Convict DNA to Its Database
description: ALBANY  New York is poised to establish one of the most expansive DNA databases in the nation, requiring people convicted of everything from fare beating to first-degree murder to provide samples of their DNA to the state.

title: It Probably Helps to Know the Secret Handshake
description: More than a dozen ordinary-looking white-collar types walk into the theater, chatting with one another in quiet voices. For a second, they seem as if they were part of the audience. But theyre actually the actors, and after much mingling, they sit down in rows of chairs on the stage, and an initiation begins.

title: Syrias Losing Battle to Control the News
description: Updated | Wednesday | 9:07 a.m. Nearly 12 months into the uprising in Syria, government attempts to stifle news coverage by barring independent reporters from the country are still being confounded by a network of activists who have now posted more than 40,000 video clips on YouTube, offering glimpses of protests and documenting a violent crackdown on dissent.

title: The Basics, Still Filling an Arena
description: Primordial equals durable for the Black Keys, a two-man band  Patrick Carney on drums, and Dan Auerbach on guitar and vocals  originally from Akron, Ohio, and recently transplanted to Nashville. Visuals aside, their concert on Monday night could easily have taken place in 1973. It was a set full of stomping drumbeats and distorted guitar riffs carrying mostly declarations of woman trouble and other mental distress.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Making Highlight Work, and News Link Symbols
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

title: Which Cover Would You Choose?
description: For our latest cover, we came up with a lot of options. We narrowed them down to five and opened up our official N.Y.T. Magazine Polling Station. The rules are simple: the entire staff votes on their favorite cover by dropping a wooden chip (coffee stirrer) into an upside down paper cup with a slit cut into it. Its the closest we ever get to a focus group (thankfully), and the staff seems to enjoy it. The polling station is located right in front of my office, so I get to listen to all of the heated debates. Full disclosure: The majority does not always rule, but it gives us a good idea about what people like and dont like:

title: For a Professional Midwest Palate, a First Taste of a Dirty-Water Dog
description: In her 30-some years as food critic for the Grand Forks, N.D., Herald, Marilyn Hagerty has reviewed the Dippin Dots at a hockey rink, sung the praises of grilled salmon with North Dakota Prairie Sauce, and made her way through countless portions of lutefisk. But she has never reviewed a hot dog.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bangladesh, Belgium, India and Uganda.

title: The-Dream
description: The-Dream, a k a the singer-songwriter and record producer Terius Youngdell Nash, performed at S.O.B.s on Monday night.

title: Linking Extreme Poverty and Global Terrorism
description: These days, I spend most of my time hiking the rolling hills and valleys of Kuria, a remote district in rural Kenya. Im on a very different career path now than I was before, as a Marine patrolling streets and alleys in Iraq. In my new work, I travel from shamba to shamba (the Kiswahili word for farm) talking and working with farmers who live in extreme poverty. As we walk through their fields, I often see unwelcome flashes of my past. Peaceful Kurian villages transform into rows of Iraqi huts destroyed by rocket-propelled grenades. While gazing into the eyes of a Kurian farmer who is pleading with me to help her children who havent eaten in three days, my vision blurs and Im looking into the eyes of a screaming Iraqi farmer who just had his family shot to pieces right in front of him. I watch our Kenyan farmers roll out their planting strings to properly space fertilizer and seed, and in my minds eye, I look through my scope at untrained, desperate farmers rolling out fuse lines that lead to poorly disguised road-side bombs next to the main supply route south of Baghdad. Two worlds, blurring together as I walk.

title: After 244 Years, Encyclopaedia Britannica Stops the Presses
description: After 244 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica is going out of print.

title: R&B Purist, Wrapped in a Cloak of Hip-Hop
description: When something, or someone, gets under the skin of The-Dream, he makes it known. Last year, in the down time between major-label albums, he released 1977, a free album through his Web site that was recorded under his real name, Terius Nash. The year before hed split from his wife, the singer Christina Milian, and 1977 bore all the scars of a brutal heartbreak: he was petulant, nasty and unforgiving.

title: Competing Narratives at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  This year, eight films are vying for South by Southwests narrative prize. Below is a look at three of those films, with comments from their directors on how they aimed for something different in the cinematic approaches.

title: Dining Calendar
description: For Passover

title: Floridas Stearns Keeps Birther Doubts Alive
description: Facing a difficult primary campaign, Representative Cliff Stearns, Republican of Florida, has waded into the controversy over the legitimacy of President Obamas birth certificate.

title: A Disorder That Stops the Music
description: Just because youre a hypochondriac, to paraphrase Joseph Hellers wry comment on paranoia, doesnt mean you arent sick. And the brilliant Canadian pianist Glenn Gould was, in a phrase uttered at a medical conference over the weekend, a world-class hypochondriac. He was also a perfectionist, easily frustrated.

title: Female Voters and the Republican Primary
description: All of the talk about birth control and abortion laws seems to have had little effect on the ways women are voting for the two leading Republican candidates, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, at least according to exit polls in the primaries.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Scorecard: Bank Stocks After the Stress Tests
description: Bank stocks climbed as the results of the Federal Reserves stress test were released on Tuesday, two days earlier than planned.

title: Whats at Stake in Alabama and Mississippi
description: Its hard to say who is going to win in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday night. Polls in these states have a poor track record, and they project a close race anyway, although Rick Santorum is somewhat off the lead lap in Mississippi.

title: Digital Notes: Turntable.fm Says It Has Reached Deals With Labels
description: Sometimes its best to go legit.

title: Ageless, Like Armani
description: THERE are no urine tests for fashion designers, no central governing body to verify if they are enhancing their performance in any way. When Giorgio Armani steps out for his warm bath of applause after each runway show, he looks strikingly the same: tight shirt caressing piles of muscle, skin the color of a lovely vintage bag from the Portobello Market, a bushel of hair long and white and slick. Some years ago, he arrived at his current age, and then just stopped. Cryogenics, Botox, rubdowns with salted blubber and lavender-scented gels: whatever hes using, its working.

title: New York Stagecraft Plies the High Seas
description: Before Diane Paulus reached Broadway directing rowdy hippies in Hair and tormented lovers in The Gershwins Porgy and Bess, she cut her teeth in big-budget theater by making sure that Minnie Mouse and Snow White didnt trip over each other during The Golden Mickeys, a 50-minute musical awards-show takeoff she staged for Disney Cruise Line in 2003. Ms. Paulus found herself wrangling with Disney lawyers over the neckline for Cruella de Vil (designs for famous characters can be sacrosanct) and spending lavishly on the show (a forerunner to the so-called event theater that interests her).

title: Ruth Barcan Marcus, Philosopher-Logician, Dies at 90
description: Ruth Barcan Marcus, a philosopher esteemed for her advances in logic, a traditionally male-dominated subset of a traditionally male-dominated field, died on Feb. 19 at her home in New Haven. She was 90.

title: With Controversial Leader Gone, Charter Makes Bid to Stay Alive
Microfoundations, Micro Payoffs (Wonkish)
description: There has been an ongoing discussion in the econoblogosphere about the usefulness or lack thereof of microfoundations in macroeconomics, which in practice means trying to write down models in which aggregate behavior is justified in terms of the actions of utility-maximizing individuals with rational expectations. I upset even New Keynesians, such as Simon Wren-Lewis, with my observation that the crusade for microfoundations has had only one success, the prediction of stagflation after an extended period of high inflation, and that this success is 35 years old.

title: Bain Defends Itself Amid Attacks on Romney
description: Bain Capital sent a letter to its investors late Tuesday that for the first time addressed the presidential campaign of the private equity firms founder, Mitt Romney, and defended its record on job creation.

title: More Weight Given to More Partisan States
description: Both Democrats and Republicans use formulas that give states delegates based not just on their popluation, but also on party loyalty in past elections.

title: Web Site Publishes Freedom of Information Requests Sought by California Congressman
description: An Internet site that promotes openness by the federal government has beaten Representative Darrell E. Issa to the punch, publishing copies of tens of thousands of Freedom of Information Act requests assembled for Mr. Issa last year as part of an investigation he is conducting into the federal governments responsiveness to such inquiries.

title: From North Dakota, a Fresh Eye on Street Food
description: Her glowing review of the Olive Garden in Grand Forks, N.D., has turned her into an Internet superstar. And so Marilyn Hagerty, restaurant critic for the Grand Forks Herald, came to New York on Tuesday to turn her critical eye on Manhattans food scene.

title: In Private Equity I.P.O., a Shareholder Fear of Losing Favor
description: The Carlyle Group, one of the worlds largest private equity firms, is brimming with deal makers who have made billions for themselves and their fund investors. Yet they appear to be struggling to persuade people to buy into their most important deal yet  an initial public offering of the firm.

title: U.S. Sets Roster for Olympic Qualifying
description: Regional qualifying for a berth in the London Olympics starts later this month, but United States under-23 national team coach Caleb Porter still has some spade work to do in filling the final spot on his 20-man roster.

title: Exploring an Impetuous, and Tentative, Office Romance
description: Almost the only time you see the word gamine these days is in a sentence that also refers to the French actress Audrey Tautou, a market she cornered in the 2001 film Amlie. Ms. Tautous gamineness  gaminality? gaminocity?  is about all that her new film, Delicacy, has going for it. Its a lightweight romance that occasionally shows a sense of humor but seems afraid to turn it loose.

title: An Artist at Work, Looking and Judging
description: Gerhard Richter may not fling paint at the canvas, Jackson Pollock-style, but as Corinna Belz shows in her documentary Gerhard Richter Painting, he can be his own kind of action painter.

title: The Alabama and Mississippi Primaries
description: Republicans voted in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday, as well as Hawaii and American Samoa.

title: The Red Line and the Ringette Line: Whats the Difference?
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  The N.H.L. general managers rejected a measure that would have made the two-line pass illegal, as it was before the 2004-5 N.H.L. lockout. So N.H.L. defensemen will still be able to make long-bomb passes from deep in their own end all the way to the far blue line  like this one by the Rangers Michael Del Zotto:

title: Highlights of the Exit Polls in the Deep South G.O.P. Primaries
description: 10:32 p.m. | Updated The Timess polling unit is analyzing the results of the exit polls in Alabama and Mississippi as Republicans in those states vote for a nominee. This post will be updated as we crunch more numbers.

description: A leading forecaster of advertising spending is increasing its predictions for growth this year and in coming years, both worldwide and in the United States.

title: Auto Bailout Is Looking Better to the Public
description: Those Eminem and Clint Eastwood advertisements just might have worked: Americans seem to be changing their minds about the once-loathed auto bailout.

title: Time Grows Short for Magic to Move Howard
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Magic chief executive Alex Martins said on Tuesday that the team had not made a decision on whether to trade the star center Dwight Howard, but that it would have several potential trading partners, including plenty of teams that would take him without any assurances of having him next season.

title: Lawyers for Man Accused in Terrorism Plot Make Case for Dismissal
description: Lawyers for a man who was charged under a seldom-used state terrorism statute argued on Tuesday that the law was too unconstitutionally vague to be applied in this case and that the evidence presented to the grand jury was not legally sufficient to support the charges.

title: Picking Up the Tempo at the Right Time
description: Peyton Siva added an unlikely flourish to the end of a season defined by struggle: a ride around the Madison Square Garden court atop the shoulders of his 6-foot-6 teammate Chane Behanan while Louisville celebrated a Big East tournament championship.

description: To the Editor:

description: Donald F. Smith, a champion of high-style cabaret who founded both the Mabel Mercer Foundation and the New York Cabaret Convention, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 79.

description: To the Editor:

Well be bringing you exit poll results, data-driven observations, historical context and the final electoral verdicts in both states.

description: To the Editor:

title: Who Gets the Breaks and Benefits
description: Tax breaks offered by the federal government tend to overwhelmingly favor the richest segment of the population, while entitlement benefits and other federal social benefits are more evenly distributed.

title: Minoru Mori, Builder Who Changed the Face of Modern Tokyo, Dies at 77
description: TOKYO  Minoru Mori, a developer who helped shape Tokyos skyline with towering buildings and then turned his attention to China, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 77. The cause was heart failure, officials of his company, Mori Building, said.

description: ORLANDO, Fla.

Caught in Egypts Political Cross-Fire
description: Washington

description: With the contests in Mississippi and Alabama almost over, the candidates will soon shift their attention to Missouri and Illinois.

title: New Interest in Hacking as Threat to Security
description: WASHINGTON  During the five-month period between October and February, there were 86 reported attacks on computer systems in the United States that control critical infrastructure, factories and databases, according to the Department of Homeland Security, compared with 11 over the same period a year ago.

title: The Human Cost of Animal Suffering
description: Until a couple of years ago I believed that the primary reasons to eat less meat were environment- and health-related, and theres no question that those are valid reasons. But animal welfare has since become a large part of my thinking as well. And I say this as someone not known to his friends as an animal-lover.

title: Iraqs Tribal Chiefs Step Into the Breach With Swift Justice
description: ISHAQI, Iraq  Fearful of a future as violent as the past, and exasperated by corrupt and incompetent politicians, the men who hold power here have seized the moment of American departure and national political chaos to administer their own form of justice: expelling suspected insurgents and their families from this town with the threat of death.

title: Obama Introduces Cameron to Hoops in Ohio
description: It might not be the most glamorous way for an American president to celebrate a visiting British prime minister. But on Tuesday evening, Prime Minister David Cameron found himself chomping on a hot dog and watching a college basketball game in Dayton, Ohio. He was there as a guest of President Obama, who was eager to introduce him to one of his passions.

title: A New Species in New York Was Croaking in Plain Sight
description: The croak gave it away.

title: 20 Charged as U.S. Says Heroin Ring Is Broken Up
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  They were accused of flooding the streets with millions of dollars worth of heroin, operating a major distribution ring that extended from Brooklyn to Suffolk County.

title: Capitalism, Version 2012
description: David Rothkopf, the chief executive and editor-at-large of Foreign Policy magazine, has a smart new book out, entitled Power, Inc., about the epic rivalry between big business and government that captures, in many ways, what the 2012 election should be about  and its not contraception, although the word does begin with a C. Its the future of capitalism and whether it will be shaped in America or somewhere else.

title: Nuclear Agency Head Calls for New Standards
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission needs to rewrite its standards to address what it considers high consequence events in view of last years nuclear accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan, the commissions director said Tuesday. Addressing 3,000 nuclear experts from 34 countries, the chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, said that despite the disaster the plant probably met the agencys safety goals because it did not result in big radiation doses to the general population. The accidents immediate health consequences were very close to nothing, with little to no long-term health effects, he said. But the destruction of reactors, the mass evacuations and the destruction of property were clearly unacceptable, Mr. Jaczko said. The commissions great challenge is to be proactive in identifying previously unforeseen risks, primarily natural disasters.

title: For Two-Way Referee, Its N.F.L. One Day, College Basketball the Next
description: Four years ago, Gene Steratore was working as an official in a mens basketball game between Loyola (Md.) and Niagara. The game was tight, and at one point, Steratore made a critical call in Niagaras favor that brought Loyolas coach, Jimmy Patsos, stomping down the sideline in his direction.

title: Day 1: Bills Seek Williams as Dolphins Trade Marshall; Manning Remains Unsigned
description: The most prominent free agent, Peyton Manning, remained unsigned Tuesday, but the impact of the passing game shaped the first day of N.F.L. free agency. The early blockbuster moves centered on teams vacuuming a deep class of wide receivers and the aggressive push by the Buffalo Bills to lure the top available pass rusher.

title: Lawyers Give Final Presentations in Dorm Spying Case
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  In the days before he killed himself, Tyler Clementi did not act as though he was intimidated by the discovery that his roommate had used a webcam to watch him kissing another man, a lawyer for the roommate said Tuesday.

title: Rivalry Kicks Off With New Face and Added Fire
description: TAMPA, Fla.  An eager contingent of about three dozen reporters from two continents peppered Bobby Valentine with questions Tuesday about the rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, and his new place in it.
