description: Scorecard for New Bank Stress Tests

title: Worker Tells Court He Lacked Math to Measure Crane Part
description: The employee responsible for finding a replacement part for a tower crane that ultimately collapsed on the Upper East Side in 2008, killing two workers, testified on Tuesday about his own difficulty with the basic math of measuring key components.

title: Marilyn Hagerty, Food Critic
description: Marilyn Hagerty, a food critic from North Dakota, reviews a New York hot dog.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 13, 2012

title: Santorum Takes 2 Races in South; Romney Is Third
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Rick Santorum captured twin victories in the Alabama and Mississippi primaries on Tuesday, overcoming the financial advantages of Mitt Romney and the Southern allegiances to Newt Gingrich on a night that amplified his argument that the Republican nominating fight is becoming a two-man race with Mr. Romney.

title: In Spat With Law Student, a Governors Tongue Is, Once Again, Too Sharp to Hold
description: Among the targets of Gov. Chris Christies sharp tongue have been Democrats; Newt Gingrich; Raymond W. Kelly, the New York City police commissioner; and people who did not believe state flags in New Jersey should be lowered for Whitney Houston.

title: Anthony and Knicks Cant Play Together
description: As they steeled themselves late Monday for a grinding, gripping final 12 minutes in Chicago, the Knicks broke into two factions along the bench. At one end, a swarm of players gathered around the coaching staff. At the other, Carmelo Anthony sat stoically, a towel over his shoulders, alone.

title: An Officer Had Backup: Secret Tapes
description: One night in October 2009, a team of police officers, led by a deputy chief, raided the home of a police officer named Adrian Schoolcraft, and dragged him out of his bed and to the psychiatric emergency room at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. He was held for six days in a locked ward. No judge was involved. There was no hearing.

title: Delegate System Gives Small States Outsize Clout at Convention
description: One person, one vote is not a concept that either party pays much heed to when it comes to nominating candidates for president  as was vividly underscored Tuesday by the seemingly outsize number of delegates that were at stake in the Alabama and Mississippi Republican primaries.

title: Second Woman Denies Running a Brothel
description: A second defendant who was indicted last month and accused of running a brothel on the Upper East Side turned herself in to prosecutors on Tuesday.

title: In Espada Fraud Trial, a Focus on Politics and Lavish Spending
description: In his quarter-century in New York politics, Pedro Espada Jr. has had a career marked by turbulence and accomplishment; despite multiple investigations and repeated accusations of fraud, he still rose to become majority leader of the State Senate.

title: Corrections: March 14
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Campaign Finance Lessons for Disillusioned Asian-American Group
description: Concerned about the dampening effect that a fund-raising scandal involving the city comptroller could have on Asian-American voters, the New York City Campaign Finance Board held a workshop on Monday night on the dos and donts of campaign finance.

title: Dont Tread on Us
description: Hillary Clinton has fought for womens rights around the world. But who would have dreamed that she would have to fight for them at home?

title: The Fed Stays the Course
description: The Federal Reserve acknowledged on Tuesday that it is not certain which way the economy is going. It saw signs of improvement, but its outlook is cautious. It plans to continue near-zero interest rates through 2014 and bond purchases through June to keep borrowing costs low. The stock market responded enthusiastically. Without more help  from Congress, the White House and the Fed  it is hard to see how the fledgling recovery will take off.

title: U.N. Leader Says Assad Must Shift Syrias Course
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should not delude himself that he can survive the Syrian uprising without significant reforms, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said Tuesday.

title: Keeping Score: Bryant Has the Stats Of a Not-Quite-M.V.P.
description: During his stint as the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, Mike Brown witnessed two most valuable player seasons by Clevelands prodigal son, LeBron James. Now the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, Brown is pushing his new star, Kobe Bryant, for M.V.P. consideration.

title: Breaking Down the Alabama Vote: Conservatives Divided
description: Voters in Alabama were closely divided on Tuesday over whom they favored for the Republican nomination. Perhaps most telling, more than half of Alabama voters said Mitt Romneys positions on the issues were not conservative enough, while about the same number said that Rick Santorums and Newt Gingrichs positions were just about right. That meant that Mr. Santorum and Mr. Gingrich essentially split the support of crucial conservative voting groups in the state known as the Heart of Dixie.

title: Breaking Down the Mississippi Vote: Religious, but Pragmatic
description: With a very conservative electorate and potentially the highest number of evangelical Christians in any Republican contest this year, Mississippi would seem to be a better demographic fit for Rick Santorum or Newt Gingrich than for Mitt Romney.

title: Detention for Immigrants That Looks Less Like Prison
description: On a patch of Texas farmland near the Gulf of Mexico, immigration officials on Tuesday unveiled one of the most visible results of a three-year-old plan to overhaul the nations immigration detention system: a brand-new center intended to provide a less penal setting for detainees.

title: In Africas Vanishing Forests, the Benefits of Bamboo
description: In the district of Asosa, the land is thick with bamboo. People plant it and manage the forests. They rely on its soil-grabbing roots to stabilize steep slopes and riverbanks, cutting erosion. They harvest it to burn for fuel, to make into charcoal sticks to sell to city dwellers and to build furniture.

title: Hapi Holiday!
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  The quote above is an actual cheer from my old alma mater, the Bronx High School of Science.

title: Gov. Cuomos Word
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo vowed that he would veto politically warped and self-serving election maps. If he does not veto a shameful and cynical compromise being offered this week by legislative leaders in both parties, New Yorkers will be stuck with gerrymandered districts and Albanys status quo for another decade.

title: Help for Student Borrowers
description: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is right to take on the poorly regulated, private student lending industry. Too often, college students are lured by schools or lenders into ruinously priced loans, even when they are eligible for affordable federal loans that offer hardship deferments and broad consumer protections.

title: Hurting Victims Advocates
description: The Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests, known as SNAP, has played a critical role in making public the horrific crimes of pedophile priests and holding the Roman Catholic Church accountable for the crimes. Now the church is using a tactic that could cripple SNAP by embroiling it in costly litigation in which it is not a party.

title: Though Not at Their Best, Rangers Find a Way to Win
description: The Rangers performance Tuesday night against the Carolina Hurricanes was often erratic and undisciplined. But two positives emerged from the game at Madison Square Garden: the Rangers managed to win, 4-2, and the line of Brad Richards, Marian Gaborik and Carl Hagelin may be emerging, just at the right time, as a powerhouse.

title: Iran May Not Open a Site to Inspectors
description: Iran signaled on Tuesday that it was unwilling to grant a request by international nuclear inspectors for unfettered access to a restricted military complex that they suspect may house a chamber designed to test explosives used in atomic weapons triggers.

title: In Sudans Nuba Mountains, Government Rocket Attacks Sow Fear, Witnesses Say
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ryan Boyette, an American aid worker living in one of the most active war zones in Africa  Sudans Nuba Mountains  was in a thatch-roof office on a clear January day when he heard two thunderous blasts.

title: Charges Not Dismissed in Yonkers Corruption Case
description: A federal judge who sharply questioned whether the government had proved a fundamental part of its corruption case against a former Yonkers councilwoman has refused, for now, a defense request made on Tuesday that she dismiss crucial charges before the case went to a jury.

title: For Wartburg College, Titles Are Twice as Nice
description: The best and least heralded rivalry in sports can be found in Division III wrestling, where either Wartburg College in Waverly, Iowa, or Augsburg College in Minneapolis, has won the national championship since 1995.

title: For Gingrich, an Alabama Celebration Deferred
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Newt Gingrichs election night party is in a hotel ballroom next door, as it happens, to a party for the Alabama Republican Party. There are some differences between the two rooms.The partys party has a repast of breaded portobello mushrooms and assorted cheeses. There are no snacks at the campaigns party. There are white tablecloths at the Republican Party event; it is standing room only at Newt 2012, where a sparse crowd of about 100 is beginning to fill in.

title: Rising Sea Levels Seen as Threat to Coastal U.S.
description: About 3.7 million Americans live within a few feet of high tide and risk being hit by more frequent coastal flooding in coming decades because of the sea level rise caused by global warming, according to new research.

title: In El Salvador, Prisons Packed to the Bars
description: The countrys 19 prisons were built to hold a total of 8,000 prisoners  today, 24,000 are stuffed into them. And El Salvador is far from unique in Latin America.

title: Inmates Lament: Rather Be Dead Than Here
description: SAN SALVADOR  In a prison called Hope, there is little of it to go around.

title: Home Base of Accused Soldier Has Faced Scrutiny
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  A soldier from Los Angeles blamed the combination of dangerous deployments and the gloom and gray that units encounter when they return to this sprawling military base in the often cloudy Pacific Northwest.

title: A Nation With Too Many Tax Breaks
description: With the presidential election in sight and a deadline looming at the end of the year to cut trillions from the deficit, the partisan debate over the budget has become an existential battle over the purpose of government.

title: After Apology, National Advertisers Are Still Shunning Limbaugh
description: IN place of paid advertisers, public service announcements now fill some of the time between Rush Limbaughs monologues on radio stations, a consequence of an ad boycott against the conservative talk show host that is now nearly two weeks old.

title: Souths One-Two Punch a Heavy Blow to Gingrich
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Hoping for one more rebirth, Newt Gingrich was bitterly disappointed on Tuesday, losing two primaries in the South, where he had staked his claim, and he will find it increasingly difficult to argue that he is the candidate Republicans are seeking in 2012.

title: A San Francisco District Begins to Reduce Blight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The names of the citys storied neighborhoods roll off the tongue: Pacific Heights, North Beach, the Mission, Haight-Ashbury, the Castro.

title: The Full Text of the Federal Reserves Statement on Interest Rates
description: The following is the full text of the statement released on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: Wait. Wasnt Obama Winning?
description: Why arent President Obamas poll numbers higher? Thats the question unsettling the Washington conventional wisdom this week. Amid improving economic growth, a grim and grinding Republican primary campaign and the White Houses skillful exploitation of Rush Limbaughs boorishness, Obamas reelection was being taken almost for granted in many political circles. But then came a pair of surveys  one from the Washington Post and ABC and one from the New York Times and CBS  that showed the presidents approval ratings sinking this month back toward the lower 40s after a steady winter climb.

title: Santorum Speaks After Victories
description: Rick Santorum spoke to supporters after winning both the Mississippi and Alabama primaries.

title: Detroit Officials Criticize States Proposal for Fiscal Oversight Panel
description: With Detroit expected to run out of cash this spring, state officials in Michigan proposed a restructuring deal with the city leaders on Tuesday that would establish a joint advisory board to address the citys financial troubles without a state-appointed emergency manager.

title: Despite Calls for Alternatives, Another American Is Expected to Lead World Bank
description: WASHINGTON  Once again, the next head of the World Bank will be an American.

title: An Update on New York Redistricting
description: New York is now among the last states in the nation to tackle the redistricting required as a result of the 2010 census. And the urgency is growing: the states Congressional primary is scheduled for June 26, and its legislative primary for Sept. 11.

title: Homework Trumps Gut Instinct in Retail Brokering
description: When Donald G. Fisher, the founder of the Gap clothing chain, began expanding in Manhattan in the 1990s, he would stand in front of a space, see how many people walked by, and say, Hey, this looks like a good spot, said Robert K. Futterman, the founder of the retail brokerage RKF, who represented the company in some leases.

title: Bruce C. Ratner
description: Mr. Ratner, 67, is the chairman and chief executive of the Forest City Ratner Companies, which owns and operates 11 million square feet of property in the New York area, including the MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn and the Frank Gehry-designed 8 Spruce Street in Manhattan.

title: Radulov, Who Left Predators for Russia, Nears Return
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Forward Alexander Radulov, whose departure from the Nashville Predators to Russia in 2008 touched off a brief signing war between the N.H.L. and the Kontinental Hockey League, is close to returning to Nashville.

title: Road for Santorum Depends on the Next Move by Gingrich
description: Once again, Americans are waking up to headlines about multiple primary-night victories for Rick Santorum over the man who is still widely considered to be the most likely Republican nominee this year, Mitt Romney.

title: The Closer: Redskins Shop for Bargains
description: On the first day of free-agent signings, the Redskins did not sign Randy Moss, an enigmatic future Hall of Famer. They did not throw $55 million at Vincent Jackson. They did not trade for the frequently disgruntled Brandon Marshall.

title: New Solar Panels Blossomed Despite a Tough Year for the Industry
description: Last year seemed like a dark one for the solar industry: stiff competition from China drove American manufacturers to layoffs and even bankruptcy, while the low price of natural gas and the loss of a critical government subsidy weakened incentives for new solar developments. And then there was the long shadow of Solyndra, whose bankruptcy after receiving federal loans cast a pall over other green-energy endeavors.

title: Do Statins Make It Tough to Exercise?
description: For years, physicians and scientists have been aware that statins, the most widely prescribed drugs in the world, can cause muscle aches and fatigue in some patients. What many people dont know is that these side effects are especially pronounced in people who exercise.

title: Crane Clips Scaffolding Under Brooklyn Bridge
description: A crane on a barge being towed by a tugboat accidentally hit the scaffolding on the underside of the Brooklyn Bridge about 8:15 p.m. Tuesday, damaging about 20 feet of scaffolding. The bridge appeared to be undamaged, officials said. The crane connected with some of the sheet metal under the bridge, said a United States Coast Guard spokesman.Vehicle traffic was never halted.

title: Word of the Day | distill
description: distill \di-stil\ verb

title: Tension Over a Campus Gift, and a Potential Recipient
description: NORTHFIELD, Mass.  As historic school campuses go, the one in this rural New England town is just about perfect, with pretty buildings of brick and stone scattered along a gentle hill.

title: Gingrich Speaks in Alabama
description: Newt Gingrich spoke to supporters after losing the Mississippi and Alabama primaries.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/14/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/14/2012

title: Somalia: Islamist Rebels Vow to Eject Aid Agency
description: The Shabab Islamist militant group, which still controls a few large patches of Somalia, said Tuesday that it was expelling the Save the Children aid agency because it had distributed expired food and tried to bribe Shabab officials. The Shabab, who are vehemently anti-Western, have kicked out several other aid agencies in recent years. Save the Children, based in Westport, Conn., said that it was looking into the allegations and that it would continue its operations in other parts of Somalia. The Shababs area of control has been steadily dwindling in recent months.

title: Hospitals With Radioactive Materials Expose Weakness in Antiterror Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Ten years into a campaign to make radioactive materials harder for terrorists to steal, Congressional auditors have found one hospital where cesium was kept in a padlocked room but the combination to the lock was written on the door frame and another where radioactive material was in a room with unsecured windows that looked out on a loading dock.

title: China: New Aircraft Carrier Is a Vintage Soviet Model
description: Chinas first aircraft carrier, a 1980s Soviet warship that has been refitted with modern weaponry, will go into service later this year, state-run media quoted a top navy official as saying on Tuesday. The carrier, once called the Varyag, has been undergoing sea trials since last August. The military unveiled a new carrier-based jet fighter last spring, the J-15 Flying Shark, but the ship currently sports only full-size models of aircraft, the newspaper China Daily stated. The paper quoted Rear Adm. Cao Dongshen, a deputy at this months annual meeting of the National Peoples Congress in Beijing, as saying that the ship would be used for training, experiments and scientific research.

title: A Family Feud, With Billions in the Balance
description: HONG KONG  It has been a bad week for the wealthiest woman in Asia.

title: George Kerchner, Led a D-Day Maneuver, Dies at 93
description: George Kerchner, who as an Army Ranger was decorated for bravery in leading his company up the face of a towering cliff to seize a battery of German big guns overlooking the American invasion beaches of D-Day, died on Feb. 17 in Midlothian, Va. He was 93.

title: Santorum Sweeps Two Southern States
description: Rick Santorum captured twin victories in the Alabama and Mississippi primaries on Tuesday, overcoming the financial advantages of Mitt Romney and the Southern allegiances to Newt Gingrich.

title: Guatemala: Ex-soldier Sentenced to 6060 Years for 1982 Massacre
description: A former soldier was sentenced late Monday to 6060 years in prison for his role in the 1982 massacre of 201 Mayan peasants in the village of Dos Erres during Guatemalas civil war. Pedro Pimentel Ros, part of a group of 17 soldiers accused of the killings, was ordered to serve 30 years for each killing and an additional 30 years for crimes against humanity. A former member of the elite Kaibiles military unit, Mr. Pimentel was deported last July from the United States, where he had been employed as a maintenance worker in Santa Ana, Calif. Four other former soldiers were sentenced to similar terms last August for their involvement in the massacre. Guatemalan law allows convicts to serve a maximum of 50 years, but the sentence assures that Mr. Pimentel, who is in his 50s, will spend the rest of his life in prison.

title: Jean Giraud, the Comic-Book Artist Known as Moebius, Dies at 73
description: Jean Giraud, a French comic-book artist whose dark, intricately drawn fantasy worlds exerted a profound influence on graphic novels worldwide and on American science fiction films like Alien, Tron The Fifth Element, and Avatar, died on Saturday at his home outside Paris. He was 73.

title: In Indian Homes, Phones and Electricity on Rise but Sanitation and Internet Lagging
description: Indias households have, overall, become more comfortable in the past 10 years, but hundreds of millions of people still lack basics like electricity, toilets and a convenient water source, according the Housing Census that was released Tuesday by Home Secretary R. K. Singh. The survey looks about 330 million households in India.

title: Numbers Tell Only Part of Dravids Story
description: It is hard to find anyone with a bad word to say about Rahul Dravid, Huw Richards writes in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | March 14, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: Panetta Is Safe After Breach Near His Plane at Afghan Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A tense visit to Afghanistan by Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta got off to an alarming start on Wednesday when a stolen pickup truck sped onto a ramp alongside a runway at a British military airfield and crashed into a ditch as Mr. Panettas plane was landing.

title: Why I Am Leaving Goldman Sachs
description: TODAY is my last day at Goldman Sachs. After almost 12 years at the firm  first as a summer intern while at Stanford, then in New York for 10 years, and now in London  I believe I have worked here long enough to understand the trajectory of its culture, its people and its identity. And I can honestly say that the environment now is as toxic and destructive as I have ever seen it.

title: Indias Billionaires Hit by Weak Economy
description: The number of Indian billionaires fell substantially in the past year, according to Forbes magazines recently released list of the worlds billionaires, while the numbers in emerging market rival Brazil rose dramatically. Increased transparency in Brazil and a slowing economy in India have contributed to this shift.

title: 22 Children Die in Swiss Bus Crash
description: LOMMEL-KOLONIE, Belgium  In this tidy town on the Belgian-Dutch border, children at the t Stekske elementary school would dream from first grade on about the annual ski trip to the Alps, recalled Vicki Emmers, 28, a former pupil.

title: March 14, 1900 | U.S. Officially Adopts Gold Standard
description: On March 14, 1900, Congress ratified the Gold Standard Act, which officially ended the use of silver as a standard of United Stares currency and established gold as the only standard. The New York Times reported that President William McKinley used a new gold pen and holder to sign the bill.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 14, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the Sunday Magazine article Pie Fidelity.

title: Wen Calls for Political Reform but Sidesteps Details
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao issued a sharper and more urgent call on Wednesday for political change in China, warning that the nation risked a return to the chaos of the Cultural Revolution unless the governing Communist Party overhauled its leadership structure and cleared the way for economic reform.

title: Homeless People as Internet Hot Spots?
description: WHAT is South By Southwest?

title: Foxwoods Is Fighting for Its Life
description: Nearly everything about the Foxwoods Resort Casino is improbable, beginning with its scale. It is the largest casino in the Western Hemisphere  a gigantic, labyrinthine wonderland set down in a cedar forest and swamp in an otherwise sleepy corner of southeastern Connecticut. Forty thousand patrons pack into Foxwoods on weekend days. The place has 6,300 slot machines. Ten thousand employees. If you include everything  hotel space, bars and restaurants, theaters and ballrooms, spa, bowling alley  Foxwoods measures about 6.7 million square feet, more than the Pentagon.

title: A Festival for Talent and Possibility
description: It was a gray day in Moscow as Fred Baldwin and Wendy Watriss ducked out of their hotel to meet their contact, whom they found two blocks away, his face nearly hidden in his raincoat. They hopped into a car and drove off, finally arriving at a small village just outside the suburbs.

title: Irans President Unfazed in Parliamentary Grilling
description: Lawmakers in Iran subjected the president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to an unprecedented interrogation on Wednesday, questioning his economic policies, cabinet appointments and tense relationship with the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in a publicly broadcast parliamentary session that seemed intended to humiliate the president in the final few years of his tenure.

title: How Do You Feel About Zoos?
description: When and where have you visited zoos in your life? How did those visits affect you? For many New Yorkers, the closing of the Bronx Zoos 111-year-old monkey house is the end of an era. Do you think, in general, that zoos are essential for educating humans about animals, or do you think theyre too cruel to the animals to be worth what they might bring to humans? Why?

title: Women Give Rolling Stones Tribute What It Needs
description: Apologies to Adam Levine and the rest of Maroon 5, but the people most likely to have moves like Jagger, these days, are women. At least, that was the case on Tuesday night, at the benefit produced by the City Winery owner Michael Dorf at Carnegie Hall, where dozens of musicians took part in a tribute to the Rolling Stones. Performing all 21 tracks from the bands classic collected-hits album, Hot Rocks 1964-1971, on the 40th anniversary of its release, it was the ladies who had Mick Jaggers cocky strut and sex appeal, not to mention the outr outfits.

title: Long View: The Origin of the Budget Briefcase
description: The elaborate ceremony of Indias Budget Day, in which the finance minister formally presents the countrys budget to Parliament, is in itself a giant colonial holdover, harking back to a similar budget speech that has been delivered by Britains Chancellor of the Exchequer for many decades.

title: Syria Opposition Group Is Routed and Divided
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The main Syrian exile opposition group suffered a serious fracture on Wednesday as several prominent members resigned, calling the group autocratic, dominated by the Muslim Brotherhood and powerless to help Syrian rebels as government forces, having flushed insurgent strongholds in the north, swept into the rebellious southern city of Daraa.

title: More College Students May Be Asked to Declare Sexual Orientation
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated  Officials of the University of California system have proposed asking incoming freshmen to identify their sexual orientation, a move that might cement such declarations as an emerging topic in the college admissions process.

title: An App for Watching for Personal Data Breaches
description: Want to know if your identity has been stolen? Or if your or your childs Social Security number is being pawned off on the Internet?

title: How Is the Payroll Tax Cut Doing?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Peyton Manning Is Said to Have a Final Four
description: After being dumped by the only N.F.L. team he has ever played for, Peyton Manning is being recruited as if he were a high school hot shot all over again. Hes probably flattered by the attention.But he has never been one for drama, and he would surely like to get this over with. (The teams have their reasons for wanting it over, too.)

title: Driving Rams Natural Gas Pickup Truck
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Chryslers Ram division claims to have built the first factory-direct pickup to run on gasoline and compressed natural gas, an alternative fuel that Fred Diaz, Rams president and chief executive, described as a near-term, viable option for lessening this countrys dependence on crude oil.

title: Fantasy Focus: The Silent Auction
description: Through shrewd drafting, clever planning and superb trading, you won your keeper league last year. Congrats! Hope you enjoyed the spoils, money and adulation of your peers. But now that your keeper deadline is approaching, there may be one other residual from your victory. In many leagues, especially keeper leagues, draft picks are tradable. In fact, chances are you may have parted with some picks last season to ascend that peak. But now you have a surplus of players to keep, and its incumbent on you to maximize your value in trading them off. But its easier said than done  the other owners know that you have a surplus, and naturally value their picks, especially if they traded off some of their talent last season to compete better in the future. One method that worked well for me this year is the Silent Auction.

title: Bombers Strike Twice in Southern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two deadly explosions struck in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday, claiming at least nine lives in the second day of violence since an American soldier went on a rampage and killed 16 civilians.

title: Test Driving a Pilot Teacher Evaluation System
Poll Finds Most City Voters Support Release of Teacher Ratings
In Poll, New Yorkers Give High Grades to Letter Grades
description: Now those ABCs have earned an A themselves.

title: Congolese Warlord Convicted, in First for International Court
description: PARIS  Thomas Lubanga, a rebel leader from the Democratic Republic of Congo, was found guilty on Wednesday of recruiting and enlisting boys and girls under the age of 15 and using them in war, in the first ruling by the International Criminal Court since it began its work 10 years ago.

title: Can The Killing Make a Comeback?
description: In an ideal world  or, at least, in Veena Suds ideal world  we would be talking about her history as a Hemingway-loving womens-studies major at Columbia, or the time she took a master class with Spike Lee at N.Y.U. film school, or her years as a gloomy loner growing up in Cincinnati, reading Helter Skelter and wearing a Jennifer Beals perm  anything, basically, other than the ending of the first season of the show she created for AMC, The Killing, and why so many people hated it so much.

title: For B Corps, a New Corporate Structure and a Triple Bottom Line
description: A native of Australia, Prue Barrett, 36, started Agrodolce for Fast Foodies, her first company, six months ago in Brooklyn. Her goal? Package and sell slow-cooked provisions  stocks for meat and fish, chutneys, caramelized onions  that can be mixed with fresh ingredients to build fast but wholesome meals.

title: Daily Report: The End of the Line for Encyclopaedia Britannica
description: After 244 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica is going out of print, Julie Bosman reports in Wednesdays New York Times.

title: A Reminder That Science Can Override Pressure
description: The recent death of F. Sherwood Rowland, who, working in 1974 with Mario Molina, discovered that the ozone layer was endangered by a lucrative class of chemicals, is a reminder of the perennial determination of industries to undermine scientific findings that could cost them money or markets.

title: Reacting to Goldman Executives Resignation Letter
In Indias Northeast, Youth Crave Global Links, Development
description: In the second of a three-part series, a journalist from the Northeast examines the peace that is quietly breaking out across the once strife-torn region.

title: Public Exit From Goldman Raises Doubt Over a New Ethic
description: Behind closed doors, it is a conversation that has been taking place with increasing urgency on Wall Street in recent years: making money is good, but is making more money always better, even if it comes at the expense of clients?

title: Brooklyn Student Takes Third Place in National Intel Competition
Opinion Report: Student Loans
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Goldman Executive Resigns via Public Letter | In a frank opinion column for The New York Times, Greg Smith, a Goldman Sachs executive, explained on Wednesday why he was resigning from the firm.

title: Questions Raised After Third Horse Dies on HBOs Luck
description: 8:57 a.m. | Updated

title: Gloom and Broom
description: A few quick thoughts on the morning after Rick Santorums southern sweep, as Ive seen it called:

title: Post-Traumatic Filmmaking in Japan
description: IT has long been assumed that filmmakers should tread carefully in the wake of tragedy. Whether confronting war or genocide, a terrorist attack or a natural disaster, the importance of bearing witness bumps up against the danger of trivialization and exploitation. In the annals of catastrophe cinema Japans triple disaster has proved to be an unusually accelerated case. Within months of the powerful earthquake and tsunami of March 11, 2011, which killed thousands and caused the reactor meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, there were already enough movies on the subject to constitute an all-but-instant subgenre.

title: Side Show
description: In bike-mad cities like Amsterdam and Copenhagen, cargo bicycles  the station wagons of the bike lane  are staples. Usually equipped with storage cabs in the front or back of the frame, cargo bikes are used to haul groceries, yard-sale finds, even small children. Now theyre showing up stateside in cities like Portland, Ore., where this hybrid of sorts, called the Fremont, is produced. Conceived by the design firm Ziba and Signal Cycles, the bike features a small side trailer that holds an expandable, Filson-like canvas satchel. Go to ziba.com/thefremont.

title: Morning Buzz, March 14: Selling a Sugar Factory
description: Good morning. Today will be sunny and unseasonably warm, with highs around 70.

title: Image of the Day: March 14
Poll Positions
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli attack on Iran is not a matter of days or weeks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Israeli television last week. But its also not a matter of years. Months then?

title: The Wheels of Justice Grind Slowly to a Verdict
description: LONDON  A decade after the International Criminal Court came into existence to try the most heinous crimes against humanity, its judges on Wednesday delivered their first verdict.

title: Class-Action Settlements at Decade Low in 2011
description: The last year has not been great for a big portion of the financial services industry: banks, deal makers and the like.

title: Day Made: Clint Eastwoods Wife Gets a Reality Series
description: In a show business career that spans more than half a century, Clint Eastwood has distinguished himself as an actor and director, winning multiple Academy Awards, portraying unforgettable gunslingers and vigilantes and performing automobile-advertising voice-overs that make you want to stand up and recite the Pledge of Allegiance. But it wasnt until now that he could count himself in the rarefied company of Bruce Jenner and Kelsey Grammer as the husband of a reality-television star.

title: Wednesday Reading: Five Hidden Gems in New York
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bloomberg: The White House no longer reveals which wines its serving at its state dinners. Why?  Eric Asimov

title: A Tale of Two Resource Booms, Continued
description: Still looking for better ways to express the point that resource booms are not a serious way to create jobs in the wider economy, even if they can make a big difference in sparsely populated regions. So, two more charts.

title: Wright Returns to Mets Camp With Muscle Tear
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  David Wright returned to the Mets clubhouse Wednesday after receiving a cortisone shot Monday from a team doctor in New York.

title: Beware of Mr. Baker and Gimme the Loot Win Grand Jury Prizes at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The grand jury award for best documentary feature was given to Beware of Mr. Baker at the South by Southwest film awards on Tuesday night, while Gimme the Loot received the grand jury award for best narrative feature.

title: Salty Dog Story
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Santorum Wins and Pops Off at Fox News, and Horse Troubles at Luck
description: Rick Santorums victories in two Southern primaries on Tuesday raised the prospect of the Republican presidential primary becoming a two-man race between Mr. Santorum and the front-runner Mitt Romney. For that to happen, however, Newt Gingrich (who finished second in the primaries, in Mississippi and Alabama) would have to drop out of the race. On Tuesday night, Jeff Zeleny reported, Mr. Gingrich showed no signs of thinking that way: The elite medias efforts to convince the nation that Mitt Romney is inevitable just collapsed. If youre the front-runner and you keep coming in third, youre not much of a front-runner.

title: Beijing Expands Safeguards for Criminal Suspects
description: BEIJING  Chinas national legislature enacted new safeguards for criminal suspects and defendants on Wednesday, but upheld the right of the police to hold certain suspects in secret residential locations for up to six months, ignoring a last-minute online campaign by critics to curb police authority.

title: Another Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire to Protest Chinese Rule
description: A Tibetan monk in his 30s, Jamyang Palden, set fire to himself on Wednesday in the town of Rongwo in the Chinese province of Qinghai to protest rule by China, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.

title: The Vulnerable President
description: In this weeks Campaign Stops column, I took a break from commenting on the Republican primaries (I fear my take is growing a bit predictable) to write about President Obamas unexpected polling dip and the search for explanations:

title: Macro Retrogression
description: Backward moves the macroeconomics debate:

title: Willem Dafoe on The Hunter
description: At South by Southwest, the actor discusses his role as a mercenary on the hunt for the last Tasmanian tiger.

title: What Shall We Call This Frog?
description: As The Times reports this morning, theres a new frog in town, or at least a newly identified one: a variety of leopard frog first spotted on Staten Island in 2009 that has now been declared its own species, based in part on its unique one-cluck mating call.

title: Peter Whitfield Talks About the History of Travel Literature
description: Peter Whitfields Travel: A Literary History covers a broad genre of writing that includes work by missionaries, empire builders, thrill seekers and satirists. The book ranges from the travel stories of the Bible and the ancient Greeks to 20th-century wanderers like Patrick Leigh Fermor and Bruce Chatwin. In a recent email exchange, Mr. Whitfield discussed his expansive definition travel writing, Christianitys influence on the genre and the best travel books of the 20th century. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

title: Climate Change Envoy to Lead Influential Institute
description: The World Resources Institute, a respected and highly data-driven environmental research organization, has named a new president: Andrew D. Steer, a British-born economist and human development expert who has spent the bulk of his career at the World Bank.

title: Leading Off: First Four Gives Madness a Whirl
description: The thing about madness is, its rather tricky to pin down. It doesnt like to be stereotyped. You know, always living up to that heart-stopping last-second shot at the end of a great game can be a lot of pressure. So, sometimes it throws a little variety into March instead. Like, oh, two gigantic comebacks at the end of scattershot games that people have a hard time remembering is the new N.C.A.A. first round. Oh, and maybe pulling the rug out from under the No. 1 seeds star center by getting him ruled ineligible. Yeah, that kind of stuff.

title: Zynga Plans to Sell $400 Million of Shares
description: Zynga said on Wednesday that it planned to sell additional shares, three months after the social game giant went public, to let some investors trim their holdings.

title: At White House, Obama and Cameron Genial and Joking
description: Citing the common heritage and shared aspirations of their two nations, President Obama and David Cameron, the British prime minister, met at the White House on Wednesday morning, with an day-long agenda scheduled to include Afghanistan, unrest in the Middle East and the global economy.

title: Lessons in Peace
description: Learning about the importance of peace can be tricky when your definition of war is your little brother clobbering you over the head with a toy truck. This month brings two very different picture books, both built around very different  you could say nearly opposite  ancient traditions: yoga and the hunt; but both bring an age-appropriate message about cultivating peace and harmony.

title: A Period of Mourning
description: To the Editor:

title: The Language of Sailing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fox Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: The First WASP?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lured by Visions of Real Estate Profits, Nonprofit Group Stumbled
description: PATERSON, N.J.  At the height of the housing boom, a luxury development arose here that was carved out of a 19th-century brick-and-brownstone factory building, with 14-foot ceilings, oversize windows and granite countertops.

title: How to Avoid That Cramped Seat
description: THERE you are, stuck in the middle seat again. This time you ended up in the row that doesnt recline. The guy in front of you has leaned his seat all the way back, pushing the top of your laptop down just far enough to make it impossible to watch a video. You turn to the onboard menu, hoping a snack might ease your suffering. But by the time the flight attendants reach your seat, everything but the trail mix has been sold out. Sound familiar?

title: F. Sherwood Rowland, Who Opposed Freon in Cars, Is Dead at 84
description: F. Sherwood Rowland, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for connecting the abundance of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, in the atmosphere to an expanding hole in the earths ozone layer, died Saturday at the age of 84. His work led in 1987 to the Montreal Protocol, an international treaty that called on industry to cease using ozone-depleting chemicals, a move that ultimately forced the automotive industry to redesign air-conditioning systems in vehicles.

title: Report Maps U.S. Risks from Rising Seas in Warming World
description: Justin Gillis of The Times has summarized new research pointing to rising odds of costly coastal flooding coming from greenhouse heating of the planet. The nonprofit group Climate Central, which pursues a novel mix of original research and climate communication, is behind the new work, which is being published in the journal Environmental Research Letters. The group has produced a batch of maps and other resources building on the work.

title: No Dribbling and No Passing, but Free Throws Are Nonstop
description: CENTRALIA, Kan.  With thestart of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament this week, the countryis once againcontemplating the art of the free throw  mainly, why so many of the uncontested 15-foot, 1-point shots are missed.

title: Business Day Live | March 14, 2012
description: What it means for Citigroup to fail its stress test, and Joshua M. Brown on a high-profile Wall Street resignation.

title: Ugandan Gay Rights Group Sues U.S. Evangelist
description: A Ugandan gay rights group filed suit against an American evangelist, Scott Lively, in federal court in Massachusetts on Wednesday, accusing him of violating international law by inciting the persecution of gay men and lesbians in Uganda.

title: Business Day Live: Leaving Goldman
description: What it means for Citigroup to fail its stress test, and Joshua M. Brown on a very public Wall Street resignation.

title: Rising Concerns Over Student Loans, Public and Private
description: College students and their advocates are increasingly concerned about student loans, both those administered by the federal government and those made by private lenders.

title: Another Furor in India Over Planned Appearance by Rushdie
description: NEW DELHI  Salman Rushdies plans to speak publicly in India are stirring controversy yet again.

title: On Capitol Hill, George Clooney Testifies About Sudan
description: To a nation weary of wars and just learning of Ugandas Joseph Kony, the actor George Clooney is trying to bring new attention to an old abomination: Sudan.

title: Q&A With Portland Timbers Owner Merritt Paulson
description: The Portland Timbers began their second season in Major League Soccer with a resounding 3-1 win against visiting Philadelphia Monday night before another full house at Jeld-Wen Field in Oregon. The Timbers have quickly evolved into one of the signature club operations in M.L.S. and burst into popular culture with a spot on the hipster satire TV show Portlandia. The video clip is above. There is a lot more to the Timbers than a shout-out on TV  the producers contacted the club and worked with the supporters group, Timbers Army in a natural fit for the club. Episode 8 of the shows second season included cameos by the Laverne & Shirley star Penny Marshall and the Trail Blazer player LaMarcus Aldridge, and featured members of the rabid Timbers Army.

title: Company in CityTime Payroll Scandal to Pay $500 Million
description: Updated 11:44 a.m. | The main contractor that ran the scandal-ridden CityTime automated payroll project for New York City will pay over $500 million to resolve a federal criminal investigation into its conduct, the federal authorities announced on Wednesday.

title: Bancroft Prize for History Goes to Three Scholars
description: The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious annual honors for historians, has been awarded to three scholars for books published last year.

title: Cocktail Conference to Mix Whiskey With Macbeth
description: The quality of the drinking at the site-specific Off-Broadway show Sleep No More is going to climb steeply at the May 14 performance. There has always been a bar at the fictitious McKittrick Hotel, where this free-form, wordless, immersive deconstruction of Macbeth takes place. But you cant take your drink with you as you follow the performers over the six-floor playing space.

title: Live Blog: Obama and Cameron News Conference
description: President Obama and David Cameron, the British prime minister, appeared at a news conference at the White House Wednesday afternoon and we live-blogged the event. The heads of government discussed at length their not dissimilar approach to the war in Afghanistan, where both face disillusionment over the mission. Other issues raised were the ongoing economic sanctions on Iran and the conflict in Syria.

title: The View from South Florida: A Slow Pace Is Part of the Strategy
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Comics Critics Weigh In on Latest X-Men Origins Story
description: At comic book stores Wednesday is X-Men: Season One, the second in a series of graphic novels that chronicle the beginnings of Marvels biggest heroes. The first wave includes the Fantastic Four, Daredevil and Spider-Man.

title: Romney Camp Shrugs Off Losses, Saying Lead Is Solid
description: Having fizzled once again in the South, Mitt Romneys presidential campaign is increasingly arguing that outcomes are not the only things that matter. Their premise: Mr. Romney can  and will  win even while losing.

title: Dont Rile the Spy Who Came Out of the Flower Shop
description: The idea of the spy next door, trying to trade in stolen documents and silenced Walther PPKs for P.T.A. meetings and home repair, has been explored in films like Mr. and Mrs. Smith and the Spy Kids movies and in the recent NBC series Undercovers.

title: On Our Radar: Leveling the Plowing Field
description: As developing countries struggle with weather extremes like drought that devastate crops, female farmers are not being factored into decision-making and strategizing, according to international agriculture experts. Women make up 43 percent of the agricultural labor force in those countries, they say, yet they struggle with restrictions on their ability to buy, sell or inherit land, open a savings account, borrow money or sell their crops at market. By failing to consider this, some Western aid efforts may miss the mark or even contribute to gender equalities, they add. [EurekaAlert]

title: The Future: No Lattes, No Movies
description: Thanks to the Elder Index, I now know that if I were a single adult over age 65 in good but not excellent health, renting a one-bedroom apartment in Essex County, N.J.  where I actually do live, and where in a few years I will most likely be that reasonably healthy old person  I would have to pay $28,200 a year to meet my basic needs.

title: The Jabra Supreme With a Boom Is a Bust
description: I had high hopes for the Jabra Supreme Bluetooth headset ($100). I like headsets with a boom (that protruding arm some headsets have) because it gets the microphone close to your mouth, usually meaning better sound quality on the receiving end and less yelling on the sending end.

title: 6 Tips for Better Portraits
description: Why do people look so blank, so vacant, so unnatural in portraits? Peter Hurley, a leading head-shot artist for actors, celebrities and executives, said people look like badly embalmed cadavers because they try to pose, but lack the skill to look natural doing it. Even professional models, experts at a certain haughty look, seldom know how to look natural. I have to deprogram them into something that is more real, said Mr. Hurley.

title: Video: Willem Dafoe, the Great Outdoors and The Hunter
description: AUSTIN, Tex. The actor Willem Dafoe is no stranger to nature. When he was a child, he enjoyed fishing trips in Canada. But those brushes with the outdoors didnt prepare him for the landscape of Tasmania.

title: Afghanistan News Roundup: Panetta Visit and Bombings
description: 4:54 p.m. | Updated  Our colleague Elizabeth Bumiller reports that Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is unhurt and safe in Kabul after his trip there got off to an unscripted start. A stolen truck sped onto a runway ramp at the British military airfield as his plane was landing. Pentagon officials said the Afghan driver emerged from the vehicle in flames. There is no further report on the mans identity or condition.

title: The President and His General
description: In the pantheon of Confederate commanders, the team of Robert E. Lee and his brilliant subordinate, Thomas J. Stonewall Jackson stands at the fore. The two had developed a mutual admiration while serving together in the Mexican War. Later, during the Civil War, Jacksons lighting-fast brigades and audacious battlefield style provided Lee with an invaluable tool against often much larger Union forces.

title: Former Intern at Charlie Rose Sues, Alleging Wage Law Violations

description: Coach Mike DAntoni has failed to inspire a team-first mentality with the Knicks. Its time for a new coach, says William C. Rhoden.

title: After Massacre, Aerial Recording Caught U.S. Soldiers Return
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, mostly children and women, was recorded on surveillance video returning to his military outpost in southern Afghanistan after the attack, according to an Afghan government official who saw the video. The video appears to back up American officials insistence that there was only one gunman.

description: Constant Contact has been one of the big success stories when it comes to online companies that specialize in serving small businesses. Some half a million of them count on the companys Web-based help in building, managing and creating marketing campaigns around customer e-mail lists.

title: Memories of the Foul Line
description: Wednesdays article about the fastest free-throw shooter in the, well, most anywhere, brought back fond memories of lonely, desperate moments at the foul line for people in the sports department. (O.K., mostly the memories were bitter, but nevertheless.)

title: Is SaveLocal a Better Deal Than Groupon?
description: Groupon, LivingSocial and other daily deal Web sites have by most accounts been a mixed blessing for small businesses. Yes, those half-off coupons hold out to small businesses the promise of unprecedented online reach to potential new customers. But that opportunity comes at the cost of having to offer bargain-basement discounts, with no guarantee that the bargain-seekers will ever return and pay full price.

title: Santorum Wins the Very Conservative Vote, Again
description: Rick Santorum certainly earned his victories last night in Alabama and Mississippi. The base of the Republican Party, particularly as it is represented in these primaries, is far to the right politically, angry and driven by an intolerant brand of evangelical Christianity.

description: David Brooks: I know you and Rick Santorum are not exactly ideological soul mates, but youve got to admit theres something impressive going on here. Everybody counts the guy out and what happens? He works hard and just keeps winning.

title: Rangers Sather Takes Time to Talk About Avery and Crosby
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Rangers General Manager Glen Sather usually blows past reporters on his way out of N.H.L. meetings without any comment to reporters beyond not now boys, Ive got a plane to catch.

title: After Knicks Win in a Rout, Expressions of Gratitude to DAntoni
description: Despite obliterating the Portland Trail Blazers, 121-79, on Wednesday in Mike Woodsons debut as interim coach, many Knicks players sounded mournful in the locker room when discussing the resignation of Mike DAntoni. Jeremy Lins eyes were tinged with sadness.

title: Voters Like Teachers Public Ratings and Restaurant Grading, Polls Find
description: Poll results released today find New York City voters broadly supporting two of the citys rather controversial public-grading measures: effectiveness ratings for teachers and sanitary ratings for restaurants. In the poll on teacher ratings, SchoolBook reports, 58 percent of voters approved of the release of teacher data reports, even though a purality of voters found them flawed. On restaurant ratings, which are widely criticized by restaurateurs as misleading, support was overwhelming, Diners Journal reports, with 82 percent of voters supporting the issuing of letter grades.

title: Points of View | Matt Ducklo and Matthew Monteith at Herms
description: At a glance, the photographs on view in Matt Ducklo & Matthew Monteith: Minds Eye, which opens on Friday at the Gallery at Herms, appear to be relatively straightforward shots of people looking at art. But for both photographers, there is an element of blind faith at work here. For the past six years, Ducklo has documented visually impaired visitors interacting with sculptures on touch tours of museums like MoMA and the Met. Monteith spent the better part of a year at the American Academy in Rome where he captured tourists looking at the citys many monumental attractions, seeking the precise moment when the artwork infiltrates the viewers imagination and the act of looking becomes an act of seeing. You dont know how they are experiencing the work, but you know how it looks like they are experiencing it, says Ducklo regarding the slippery nature of perception. At the very least, says Cory Jacobs, who curated the show, the photos make you slow down and take notice of how quickly we tend to pass things by.

title: At Disney Channels Upfronts, Excited Shrieks and Hot Dogs and Pizza
description: High-energy music, punctuated by the happy screams of children, provided the soundtrack for an upbeat upfront presentation by the cable channels owned by the Walt Disney Company.

title: Banking on a Walgreen-Rite Aid Merger

title: Amid the SXSW Avalanche, a Chance to Discover
description: Everybody wants in on South By Southwest Music, the annual convention and showcase that runs through Sunday in Austin. The vast majority of the more than 1,200 acts performing on, it seems, every level surface in Austin  clubs, outdoor stages, warehouses, ballrooms, garages, backyards, a bridge  are still hopefuls, trying to reach beyond a local following or a do-it-yourself Web presence. Official SXSW showcases are surrounded by unofficial ones with yet more performers. (Hail The Austin Chronicle and sched.org, which have  bless them  collated both official and peripheral events. ) Amid this avalanche of music, theres still some chance to get discovered or discover something by serendipity.

title: Senate Passes 2-Year Transportation Bill

title: MTA to Introduce Public Art App
description: For many years the most underrated art museum in New York City has also, oddly, been the one with by far the most visitors, millions a day: the subway system. Since 1985, the Arts for Transit program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has commissioned permanent works by both well-known and lesser-known artists for the subway and also the commuter rail system. But finding these works, in a system that can sometimes feel like a lab-mouse maze designed by a sadistic scientist, has never been easy.

description: The Cowboys landedKyle Orton as a backup to Tony Romo on Wednesday, and Todd Archer of ESPN sees it as a sharp move:

title: Interpreters, the Hidden Heroes of the Afghan War
description: In March 2010, a United States Army platoon was on patrol in Paktika Province in eastern Afghanistan when it encountered a large improvised explosive device, or I.E.D. The platoon had spent the day near Mullayan, a hostile area where several Afghan soldiers had recently been killed. As evening approached, one of the platoon members suddenly called for a halt. He had noticed some black rubber on the road. It was a buried I.E.D. Typically, if a bomb is located, United States forces must wait for an explosive-ordnance disposal team to disarm the device. But the sun was setting and the platoon would most likely be attacked at night. Faced with this predicament, the man who had found the I.E.D. calmly pulled out his knife, dug out the device and dismantled it. Thanks to him, every member of the platoon returned safely.

title: Remember That Study Saying Abortion Makes You Crazy?
description: In 2009, the Journal of Psychiatric Research published a study that claimed to find a link between abortion and long-term mental illness. Right-wing groups seized on it as justification for a series of nasty laws requiring women to be counseled that having an abortion could, using the technical terminology, drive them bonkers.

title: Two Documentaries on Bullying Take Different Approaches
description: I was bullied. From the third-grade boys who twisted my name up until I hated the sound of it, to the sixth-grade girls who wrote the mean notes about my glasses and braces and left them, quite purposely, for me to find, every time we moved when I was young, I found myself marooned in a new school where I felt neither safe nor happy. If Im honest, Id still prefer not to talk about it. What kind of kid was I, after all, that so many other children saw me as a target? How uncool can I possibly have been that I took it all so very seriously, when I should have just brushed away what was obviously unimportant?
