description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company season that opened at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday night is historic. Bringing this great troupe to Lincoln Center for its first season there, it shows how richly this companys dancing projects into the heights and depths of the multitier house: a marvel. If youre used to watching dance in the Koch Theater, then you cant help feeling that the three dimensions of its stage space come alive in unfamiliar ways; the very air onstage seems to have a new texture.

title: After 5 Books, a Measure of Peace
description: LONDON  It would be foolish to overthink the similarities between Edward St. Aubyn and Patrick Melrose, the protagonist of his celebrated series of five wrenchingly sad, laceratingly witty novels. Certainly there are parallels  both come from aristocratic privilege, both had horrific childhoods and horrific heroin addictions, both speak in hyperfluent prose  but they go only so far.

title: The Musical Colors of the City of Light
description: Many things drew young American composers to Paris after World War I. The city was a cultural hotbed that took all modern music, from radical to eclectic styles, seriously. For those grappling with what it meant to be an American composer, living in Paris and gaining some perspective actually helped. Also, as Virgil Thomson put it, if you were going to be a starving artist, you might as well starve in a city where the food was good.

title: Mr. Nice Guy, Except When Hes Onstage
description: ANYONE thumbing through Tom Hewitts Playbill biography and noticing a regional production of Titanic might assume he played the iceberg.

title: On Location | Harlem
description: Bray Poor and Nicole Betancourt turned a run-down Harlem town house into a bright and open family space.

title: A Harlem House That Can Baby-Sit
description: EXPANDING the footprint of their houses and apartments is a luxury few New Yorkers have. So it is not surprising that when Nicole Betancourt and Bray Poor, an artistic couple with two young children, decided they wanted a courtyard in their Harlem brownstone, they created one inside the house: By removing parts of the floor and ceiling, they carved out an interior opening that permits light, sound and smells to travel up and down three floors, keeping the family connected.

title: A Pianists Escalating Insurgency
description: Jazz has always been an adaptive art, possessed of certain essentials but receptive to variation at every turn. The pianist-composer-bandleader Vijay Iyer knows this as well as anyone. He has made a serious study of it, in theory as well as practice, and his last decade or so of music making can partly be understood as a pertinent provocation.

title: Restoring a Trove at Howard
description: WASHINGTON  Antiquated. Depleted. Grossly underfunded.

title: Weighing the Risk of Sea-Level Rise
description: The response to my article in the Wednesday paper on rising sea levels suggests a strong public hunger for more information about the risk. People have been e-mailing us with questions, so let me offer a few more details.

title: Blending Sideshows and a Greek Tragedy
description: Martha Graham wasnt known for her comedies, but that doesnt mean she wasnt a comedian.

title: Intel Competition Was 'Brutal' but Rewarding, 3rd-Place Winner Says
Coach Was Doomed Without Walsh
description: Mike DAntoni never stood a chance once Donnie Walsh left Madison Square Garden last June as a paid consultant under an unofficial gag order. Coach DAntoni was tied to President Walsh in a rare demonstration of teamwork and civility within the Knicks front office. But once the big man, James L. Dolan, undermined the no-nonsense Walsh last season, the renaissance was destined to give way to another Knicks era of confrontation and chaos.

title: For Nathan Hale, Perhaps Another Regret
description: Back in 1776, Nathan Hales only regret was that he had but one life to lose for his country.

title: Friends Who Take Parody Seriously
description: Community returns to NBCs schedule on Thursday, attitude at least partly intact.

title: Homes for $830,000
description: Properties in Minneapolis, Charleston and Utah.

title: What You Get for ... $830,000
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Allison Transmission to Raise $600 Million in I.P.O.
description: Allison Transmission, the vehicle transmission systems maker owned by the Carlyle Group and Onex, raised $600.3 million in its initial public offering.

title: Billboards Hot 100 Singles Chart Starts Tracking Online Listening
description: Billboard magazine is changing the way it ranks songs on its Hot 100 singles chart to take into account online music-streaming services like Spotify and Rhapsody, responding to a major shift in how people are consuming music.

title: When Opponents Err, Its Time to Cash In
description: The Spring North American Bridge Championships, hosted by the American Contract Bridge League, have just begun in Memphis.

title: Dude, Check Out Those Spoons
description: CHICAGO

title: Manly Goods From the Housewares Show
description: Coffeemakers, knives, smokers and other items that seemed to be aimed at men from the International Home and Housewares Show.

title: DNA Database Deal Reached in Albany
description: ALBANY  State lawmakers have agreed on a bill to make New Yorks DNA database among the most expansive in the country, requiring people convicted of any crime to give samples, according to Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, a Brooklyn Democrat.

title: Excerpt: 'Missing'
description: The new ABC thriller stars Ashley Judd as a former C.I.A. agent trying to find her kidnapped son.

title: Itsy-Bitsy Spider, Not
description: These eight-legged creatures will have a starring role in a new exhibition, Spiders Alive!, that opens in late July at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.

title: On Highlight, Everyone Is a C.E.O.
description: I followed the herd and downloaded the Highlight app to my phone the other day.

title: Is It Safe to Play Yet?
description: LAURA MacCLEERY was four months pregnant when she parked herself on the couch and started an inventory of the chemicals in her Alexandria, Va., town house. First, Ms. MacCleery, 40, a lawyer and womens health advocate, collected 70 products in a pile: things like makeup, shampoo, detergents and sink cleaners. Then she typed the names of the cosmetics into an online database called Skin Deep, created by the Environmental Working Group (ewg.org/skindeep), a research and advocacy organization.

title: Sliding Into Home: The Barn-Door Look, on Wheels
description: The latest product line from the hardware manufacturer K. N. Crowder brings barnyard technology into urban homes.

title: European Artisans Online, at Envielife
description: Envielife.com, a new Web site run by Christi Rogers, an interior designer, and Maria Capotorto, a product designer, will sell home furnishings by artisans from France, Italy and Spain.

title: Sales at Alessi and Others
description: A+R is discounting all David Trubridge lighting by 15 percent, through Sunday, with the code TRUE18 (the 23 1/2-inch diameter Floral light in natural, originally $500, is $425); (800) 913-0071, aplusrstore.com.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We own an older home that had its original trim removed during a previous renovation. Should we reinstall the chair rail and crown molding before putting it on the market?

title: Medicine Cabinets
description: RICHARD FINE arrived for a photo shoot wearing a navy jacket, a bright yellow sweater and silver metallic boat shoes  not what one expects from a pharmaceutical executive. But then again, Help Remedies, the company of which he is a founder and the chief executive, defies expectations as well.

title: The Architect Harry Gesner, Still Riding That Wave
description: Harry Gesners life story is so exciting that a new monograph on his work reads like a John Buchan tale, or the next Laura Hillenbrand project, instead of the usual jargon-infested coffee-table book about a venerable architect. As Houses of the Sundown Sea, by Lisa Germany and out next month from Abrams, recounts, the movie-star-handsome Mr. Gesner surfs and water-skis like a pro; he survived Normandy, though he nearly lost both legs; he audited architecture classes at Yale, turning down a chance to study with Frank Lloyd Wright, who admired his drawings; he tussled with leading men, like Marlon Brando and Errol Flynn, and fell in love with leading ladies, like a young June Lockhart; he raided tombs in Ecuador; and, for a while, he was a single father to his first child and only daughter, whom he lost custody of when she turned 5 and her mother decided shed like her back.

title: Puzzle Solved, and a Lamp Is Born
description: The N1R table lamp by David Nosanchuk, a New York designer, started as an experiment in two-dimensional shapes. I was interested in using lines and drawings to generate a series of horizontal and vertical plates that would come together and create this 3D puzzle, Mr. Nosanchuk said.

title: Drawing on Inspiration
description: WHEN I was 12 going on 20, and mashing stacks of black jelly bracelets up my arms, painting my fingernails a frosty blue and wearing my hot-pink-and-black tiger print tank top five out of seven days of the week, I fell in love. Hard. With John Taylor, the bass player for the band Duran Duran.

title: Red-Carpet Treatment for Turkish Rugs
description: Stepevi, a Turkish rug company known for its rich, textural designs, will open its first North American outpost next week in SoHo. The company was started about seven years ago (although the family behind it has been in the business since the early 1900s) and currently has showrooms in London, Paris, Milan and Istanbul. SoHo was the natural next step, said Aysegul Yurekli Sengor, the managing director and wife of the founder, Cem Sengor.

title: Shopping for Medicine Cabinets
description: Outfitting the bathroom with a cabinet that shows off whats inside.

title: Comments
description: A selection of recent comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from letters and postings at nytimes.com.

title: Before Applying to U.S. Colleges, Indian Students Should Be Able to Answer Why?
description: Latha Ramchand, a native of Thiruvanandapuram, Kerala, who was raised in Mumbai, is now the dean of the C.T. Bauer College of Business at the University of Houston. Readers can post comments at the end of this essay.

title: SXSW Interactive: The Comedown
description: At first, this years South by Southwest seemed like a bust. Gray skies, relentless rain, labyrinthine taxi and registration lines and traffic jams put a damper on the start of the show. But a few days in, after the sun came out in a blaze of glory, people pulled off their ponchos and started to mingle. After that, the conference was in full swing  and a couple of games on Foursquares foursquare court, dozens of panels, some barbecue and a cameo by a famous rapper later, the whirlwind week ended just as quickly as it began. Here are some of the crucial takeaways from the week.

title: Lenses to Ease the Strain From Staring at Screens
description: If I moved my computer monitor close enough to see the screen clearly, it was nearly in my lap. If I left the monitor where it should be, I had to lean forward awkwardly. During my annual eye exam, I told my optometrist about my workstation discomfort and the strain it was causing my eyes, neck and back.

title: Takeover Defense, Goldman Style (Circa 1960s)
description: It has not been a good day for Goldman Sachs, with an employee leaving and saying Goldman no longer is dedicated to its clients interests.

title: Achieving a Runners High With a Little Data Help
description: Data analysis has infiltrated even amateur sports, largely because of the mobile phones ability to track performances on a moment-by-moment basis.

title: Gastrointestinal Infection Deaths More Than Doubled
description: Deaths from gastrointestinal infections more than doubled in the United States from 1997 to 2007, to more than 17,000 a year from 7,000 a year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Wednesday. The infections cause vomiting and diarrhea. Of those who died, 83 percent were over 65. Two-thirds of the deaths were caused by a bacterium, Clostridium difficile, which people often contract in hospitals and nursing homes, and which has become virulent and resistant to treatment. The second leading cause was the highly contagious norovirus, which has been a scourge on cruise ships and in prisons, dormitories and hospitals.

title: The Firestorm Over Goldman Sachs
description: To the Editor:

title: For Futures Industry, MF Global as Topic A
description: Boca Raton, Fla.  It was the $1.6 billion gorilla in the conference room.

title: Sensitivity Training for Eight-Legged Exhibits
description: IN a workroom on the fifth floor of the American Museum of Natural History in New York, six tarantulas are about to undergo sensitivity training.

title: Exhibition Recalls Slam-Bang World of Pulp Magazines
description: COMIC book characters like Superman and Spider-Man have inspired devoted fans and been celebrated and vilified as theyve leapt from printed page to live-action films, animated series, musicals and memorabilia. Yet were the pulps, those throwaway dime-store magazines of old, the forebears of such passionately followed multimedia crossovers? The exhibition Orange Pulp: the Pulp Magazine & Contemporary Culture makes a strong case.

title: Titanic the Ship, 100 Years Later, Becomes a Bandwagon
description: MAYBE, if you are a Titanic-themed museum steaming along toward the outsize centennial of the ships sinking, size does matter.

title: Set Aside a Day for Museums? Minnesota Thinks Bigger
description: MAY is typically the month for honoring mothers, the armed forces and the flowering of spring. In Minnesota, May is now Minnesota Museums Month, the countrys first monthlong, statewide celebration of museums. It is the creation of several Twin Cities museum administrators, who expect it to become an annual event.

title: Trade Sanctions as a Test of U.S.-Russian Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Museums Giving It the Old College Try
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.

title: Want to See Cuba? Your Museum Might Take You
description: SOME large American museums, and an increasing number of smaller ones, offer domestic and international trips  with Cuba currently all the rage  that enliven the museums images and at the same time help increase membership and raise money.

title: Come for the Art, Stay for the Shopping
description: DRAWING on her experience as co-owner of the lifestyle store Zona, Franci Sagar has created an environment at the Museum of Arts and Design in which it is tempting to linger.

title: With Technology, Adding Context to the Costume
description: WHEN Deborah Nadoolman Landis first began work for the coming show Hollywood Costumes at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, she wanted to provide visitors with iPads that would let them observe an outfit, view a relevant movie clip and watch interviews with those involved with the film.

title: Spreading American Art Beyond Its Borders
description: ELIZABETH GLASSMAN likes to call the Terra Foundation for American Art, which she heads, a museum without walls, but it wasnt supposed to be that way.

title: Using Tough Love, Crean Is Restoring Hoosiers to Relevance
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. Tradition seemed lost, a new and less-esteemed identity was forming and, yet, Tom Crean said when he became Indianas coach in 2008, he expected to win national championships.

title: For the New Barnes, Everything Old Is Old Again
description: THE Manhattan architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien are known as modernists. But in much of their latest building  the new Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia  modernism wasnt an option.

title: Electronic Health Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet the New Boss, in the Shadow of the Old Boss
description: FOR any museum director, the chance to lead a renowned institution is a career-defining moment  especially when his or her predecessor has run it for two decades or more. For Christoph Heinrich, now the director of the Denver Art Museum, the moment arrived in October 2008, when he was the museums curator of modern and contemporary art. He was driving to Aspen with Lewis Sharp, the museums longtime director, when Mr. Sharp suddenly asked if he would be interested in the top job.

title: At Galleries, Cameras Find a Mixed Welcome
description: LAST year, Anne Hawley, the longtime director of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, in Boston, was admiring an 18th-century French painting at the Louvre.

title: From Good to Great, for Curators
description: FOR two immersive weeks in January, 11 curators selected from museums large and small gathered by day at the Center for Curatorial Leadership in New York for classes taught by professors from Columbia Business School in topics from endowment management to moral leadership to organizational alignment  subjects entirely absent from the typical education of a museum curator.

title: A Gallery for the Public to Curate
description: MUSEUMS are among the last bastions of high-culture authority these days. No matter how many comment cards visitors fill out, its unlikely that, say, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is going to initiate an exhibition or move a picture slightly to the left based on feedback from the public.

title: Birminghams Civil Rights Institute Personalizes a Struggle
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

title: Who Wants to Donate to a Billionaires Museum?
description: WHEN Eli Broad, the art collector and philanthropist, decided to build a museum in downtown Los Angeles, he named it The Broad. That pretty much ruled out asking anybody else for money, said Barry Munitz, a governor of the Broad Foundation. The museum, about to break ground on a Diller Scofidio & Renfro building, will have an initial $200 million endowment and has no plans to seek outside funding, according to Joanne Heyler, who will be its director.

title: Preserving the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: How an Acquisition Fund Burnishes Reputations
description: IF Alex Nyerges, the director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, has an extra spring in his step lately, it may have something to do with the $70 million gift the museum is receiving from a trust created long ago: $60 million of it was designated for the museums endowment for art purchases, pushing that total to more than $156 million.

title: From Show and Look to Show and Teach
description: THERE have been many strange sightings outside the Whitney Museum of American Arts Marcel Breuer building over the years: a giant birds nest precariously perched on the cantilevered entrance; a neon sign that spelled out Negro Sunshine; and a giant replica of a toy fire truck parked at the curb for nearly three months, to name a few. So it is hardly surprising that recent passers-by dont seem at all curious at the sight of tall black shipping containers rising from the sculpture court.

title: Obesity and Other Targets of Childrens Museums
description: CHILDRENS museums do not usually have exhibitions that involve crawling through a giant digestive system.

title: Teaching Children the Value of Pre-Web Pages
description: SQUEEZING paint from a tube is too tame for the sixth graders in Ida Owenss art class. They prefer making their own with malachite (a green mineral), spinach and cochineal  or dried insects. They love cochineal, said Ms. Owens. To them its working with bugs.

title: Hoping That Art Helps With Healing
description: Boston

title: The Home-Schooled Dont Just Stay at Home
description: IN June 2010, Lenora Todaro was looking for ways to build on her home-schooled 8-year-old twin boys interest in knights, castles and other aspects of medieval history. I thought of architecture, recalled Ms. Todaro, who then reached out to the Center for Architecture, a public gallery space in New York.

title: HBO Ends Production on Luck
description: HBO said on Wednesday that it is ending further production on its high-profile drama Luck, one day after the announcement that a third horse involved in the show had been injured and euthanized.

title: A Three-Bedroom Apartment in a Historic Macau Neighborhood
description: An apartment in Macau, a peninsula off southeastern China, in the historic Sai Van neighborhood.

title: House Hunting in ... Macau
description: A THREE-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN A HISTORIC MACAU NEIGHBORHOOD

title: Public Rebuke of Culture at Goldman Opens Debate
description: Until early Wednesday morning, Greg Smith was a largely anonymous 33-year-old midlevel executive at Goldman Sachs in London.

title: What to See and Where to See It
description: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer:

title: Name It; Clients Are Called It
description: Are you a Muppet or a Clancy? A Bobblehead or a Clampett?

title: As Syria Deals With Unrest, Olympic Team Keeps Its Focus for a Day
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah International stadium was nearly empty. Syrias soccer team, forced to play its home matches on foreign soil after an uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, had about 20 supporters in attendance for an Olympic qualifying match against Malaysia on Wednesday.

title: For Museum of Negro Leagues, a Big Opportunity
description: KAUFFMAN STADIUM, home of the Kansas City Royals, will become the hub of Major League Baseball in July when it hosts the All-Star Game for the first time since 1973, the year it opened. And Bob Kendrick is hoping the attendant swirl of publicity will extend to the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum, about seven miles away at the fabled intersection of 18th and Vine Streets.

title: Hospitals Arent Hotels
description: Pittsburgh

title: Rescuing the Stories Behind Latino Art
description: Some of art historys most telling monuments dont end up under museum spotlights. Theyre found, when and if theyre found, in desk drawers and office file cabinets that no one has cracked in years, or in library stacks, or in jumbles of personal papers boxed up in an artists studio.

title: Broad or Dainty, Crocodilian Snouts Pack Same Chomp
description: Through the ages, the basic crocodilian plan for dispatching prey has been simple but effective: chomp down hard and hang on tight.

title: Mets Off to a Fast Start in the Attrition Competition
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets may not have won a World Series in more than a quarter of a century, but when it comes to injuries, they have taken the title twice over the past four years and appear ready to contend again.

title: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum
description: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum is hoping to capitalize on crush of out-of-town visitors expected when the All-Star Game comes to Kansas City in July.

title: In Reactions to Two Incidents, a U.S.-Afghan Disconnect
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The mullah was astounded and a little angered to be asked why the accidental burning of Korans last month could provoke violence nationwide, while an intentional mass murder that included nine children last Sunday did not.

title: Defiant Orange Players Say They Can Still Win
description: PITTSBURGH  Syracuse guard Scoop Jardine stayed up to watch the N.C.A.A. tournament games Tuesday night. That meant that he enjoyed two furious comebacks  courtesy of Brigham Young and Western Kentucky  but was also forced to endure some harsh criticism of his own team, courtesy of just about every analyst on television.

title: Jobs Bill Stalls as Congress Fights Over Agency
description: WASHINGTON  A fight over a small export credit agency is dividing Congress and holding up a popular bipartisan jobs bill.

title: The Harvard of the South Meets the Vanderbilt of the North
description: ALBUQUERQUE  In academia, Vanderbilt aspires to be Harvard. In basketball, Harvard aspires to be Vanderbilt. But the phrase Vanderbilt of the North has yet to catch on in Cambridge, Mass., the way Harvard of the South has in Nashville.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,893 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Thank You for Obamas Donors, Dinner With Clooney and Cameron
description: Rock stars, Hollywood celebrities, and senior White House officials will all be in attendance at Wednesdays state dinner, where President Obama will fete the British prime minister, David Cameron, on the occasion of Mr. Camerons visit to the United States.

title: Goldman Executives Letter Draws Backers, Detractors and Satirists
description: If Greg Smith hoped to generate some buzz around his departure from Goldman Sachs, then he succeeded.

title: On Eve of Prison, Blagojevich Keeps Talking, but Some Tune Out
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich stepped into his front yard on Wednesday for a last goodbye.

title: Suspect in Afghan Deaths Flown to Kuwait as Evidence Arises That He Acted Alone
description: WASHINGTON  The American staff sergeant suspected of killing 16 Afghan villagers was flown to Kuwait from Afghanistan on Wednesday, American officials said.

title: A Path to Opportunity Through the Greens
description: AZUSA, Calif.  Lizette Salas had been working toward the highest stage of womens professional golf since age 7. The daughter of Mexican immigrants, she used golf to become the first in her family to earn a college degree. She had spent much of last year traveling to tournaments on the L.P.G.A. Futures Tour in a truck with her father, sometimes sleeping in rest areas to save money. So with the last full-status tour card on the line in Decembers L.P.G.A. qualifying tournament, Salas put her lifelong survival instincts to work.

title: Seeking to Preserve the Past, but Stumbling on the Present
description: MOSUL, Iraq  On land where Assyrian kings once reigned, an Iraqi farmer named Araf Khalaf surveyed the scrap of earth that has nurtured three generations of his family. It is little more than a mud hut and a scraggly vegetable patch, yet his land has become a battleground, one pitting efforts to preserve Iraqs ancient treasures against the nations modern-day poor.

title: Luring Stanley Cup Viewers With a Torrent of Games
description: TURNING the Stanley Cup playoffs into a must-watch television event lasting for weeks in the spring is no easy feat. Many Americans did not grow up with the game, few know who the players are and watching 10 weeks of playoffs is a big time commitment.

title: Juveniles Dont Deserve Life Sentences
description: Boston

title: Contractor Strikes $500 Million Deal in City Payroll Scandal
description: A major government contractor agreed on Wednesday to pay a record $500 million to avoid federal prosecution for its role in the scandal-tarred CityTime project, an effort at modernizing New Yorks payroll system. The project was plagued by widespread fraud and weak oversight and became a lingering embarrassment for Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs administration.

title: Deal Reached for Former Site of St. Vincents Hospital
description: A new public school will be created and a historic building in Greenwich Village will be preserved as part of a deal intended to placate opposition to a plan to build luxury housing on the site of the former St. Vincents Hospital.

title: Guest List for State Dinner Includes Big Names and Ordinary People
description: Most people have probably heard of the actor George Clooney by now. But the name Elaine Brye might not ring a bell outside of Winona, Ohio.

title: Blagojevich Heads to Prison
description: Rod R. Blagojevich, former governor of Illinois, is to begin his 14-year sentence for corruption on Thursday.

title: New iPad: A Polishing of the Old
description: On Friday, the new iPad goes on sale. Be sure to ask for it by name: the iPad.

title: The Senate Overachieves
description: Good news, frustrated American citizens! Congress is not a clogged up, hidebound legislative slug after all.

title: Receiver Is Given a Record Extension
description: Calvin Johnson might be the best receiver in the game, and the Detroit Lions paid him that way Wednesday, giving him an eight-year extension worth up to $132 million, the most for a receiver in history.

title: V.C.U. Has Been There, Hopes to Do It Again
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  This time last year, Coach Shaka Smart and his Virginia Commonwealth Rams were just happy to be in the N.C.A.A. tournament. That was before V.C.U. won a First Four game, before it went on a tournament run for the ages, before it made the Final Four.

title: Fortunes Turn, as Does Style, for Santorum
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  The pickup truck that carried him through Iowa is long gone, replaced by a small motorcade of S.U.V.s. There was a police escort, and a phalanx of Secret Service agents.

title: Crosby Is Ready to Face the Rangers
description: Sidney Crosby is widely considered the best hockey player in the world. With Crosby returning to the Pittsburgh Penguins, who have won nine straight games, Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, Rangers General Manager Glen Sather believes the equation is simple.

title: Despite Losses, Sticking to a Refrain
description: ROSEMONT, Ill.  Newt Gingrich was back on the campaign trail Wednesday, a day after losing two critical Southern primaries, focusing on the next Republican battleground  Illinois  as if his Tuesdays losses were just a bump in the road.

title: Divided on the Right
description: Just a few weeks ago, it seemed implausible that the Republican nomination fight would not be resolved by the August convention. But Rick Santorums primary victories in Alabama and Mississippi on Tuesday make that a real, if still distant, possibility. If the convention becomes as disorderly as the primaries, it will reflect a party consumed by anger and frustration, led around by its most extreme base, and lacking any sense of forward direction.

title: Congress Presses Apple on App Privacy
description: Two congressmen sent Apple a followup letter Wednesday asking Timothy Cook, Apples chief executive, to provide questions about privacy problems within the companys iTunes App Store.

title: In New York, a Pep Talk to Big Donors
description: A day after losing Mississippi and Alabama to Rick Santorum, Mitt Romney took his campaign to a state where he had no public schedule, no time carved out to mingle with voters, and no rallies or town halls.

title: Worker Who Hid Lottery Win Must Share $38.5 Million Prize
description: There were some dark twists in the plot line, inevitable, perhaps, when friends fight over $38.5 million in lottery winnings.

title: Ovechkin Is Tested by Trying Season
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Alex Ovechkin did not score the winning goal Tuesday for the Washington Capitals in their 5-4 victory over the Islanders. Matt Hendricks did. But Ovechkin had two goals in regulation and another in the shootout, and he broke into a triumphant gap-toothed smile as he was the first to hug Hendricks at the end of the game.

title: Big Biters
description: Researchers found that the force of a crocodilians bite increases with the size of the animal.

title: Espada and Son Lived Well, but Deny Theft From Nonprofit
description: In opening arguments on Wednesday in the trial of a former state senator and his son, who are accused of embezzling hundreds of thousands of dollars from a nonprofit health care network, there seemed to be little disagreement that the defendants had lived large.

title: Mr. Sarkozy on the Low Road
description: President Nicolas Sarkozys re-election campaign in France is getting a little desperate, and more than a little ugly. Although new polls show him the likely top vote-getter in next months first-round voting, they also show him running well behind Franois Hollande of the Socialist Party in the decisive May runoff. To try and close that gap, Mr. Sarkozy has been fishing for far-right voters by assailing foreign immigrants, foreign imports and even the dietary laws of French Muslims.

title: Questions as Banks Increase Dividends
description: Emboldened by the Federal Reserves passing grades on stress tests of banks, some of the nations biggest financial firms are racing to dole out billions of dollars in dividends.

title: Death on Escalator M.T.A. Had Once Hoped to Replace
description: Officials with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were trying on Wednesday to determine to what extent an escalator that they had hoped to replace at a Long Island Rail Road station may have caused the death of an 88-year-old woman.

title: Hope for a Good Transportation Bill
description: Against heavy odds, Congress may yet produce a decent national transportation bill that would make needed investments in roads, bridges and mass transit without undermining environmental protections or providing handouts to big polluters.

title: Clerical Abusers and the First Amendment
description: Religious institutions have constitutional protections, but they are not above the law. Unfortunately, that has not stopped the Roman Catholic Church and other religious groups from arguing that the First Amendment shields them from civil lawsuits for negligent supervision and retention of employees who sexually abuse children.

title: Witness Intimidation Cited in British Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  In what could prove to be one of the most damaging chapters yet in the scandal enveloping Rupert Murdochs tabloid newspapers in Britain, Scotland Yard arrested a former chief reporter for The News of the World on Wednesday on suspicion of intimidating a witness, the first time the police have raised the specter of witness tampering in the course of their investigations.

title: A Drill to Replace Crucial Transformers (Not the Hollywood Kind)
description: The electric grid, which keeps beer cold, houses warm, and city traffic from turning to chaos, depends on about 2,100 high-voltage transformers spread throughout the country.

title: Faith and Begorra
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Happy almost Saint Patricks Day! I had a tough time parsing this theme, for want of an apostrophe. Since there can be no diacritical marks in an American crossword puzzle, it took me a while to get that we were speaking in brogue.

title: Inspired by Brecht, and Zombies
description: From a show called The Deepest Play Ever: The Catharsis of Pathos, youd expect overstatement, and thats what you get with Geoffrey Decas ODonnells musical satire, revived at the New Ohio Theater and retooled from a 2006 incarnation. What you dont get is boredom, given its phantasmagorical riffing on Brechts Mother Courage (among countless influences cited in the program). Oh, there are more subtitles: The Post-Post-Apocalyptical Allegory of Mother LaMadre and Her Son Golden Calf or: Zombies Will EAT Your Brain! An Epic Tragidramedy.

title: Private Businesses Fight Federal Prisons for Contracts
description: As chief financial officer of a military clothing manufacturer, Steven W. Eisen was accustomed to winning contracts to make garments for the Defense Department.

title: Viral Video, Vicious Warlord
description: Id like to thank the makers of the Kony 2012 video for goading me to write about Joseph Kony. With about 100 million views, it is now one of the most viral videos of all time.

title: New York Lawmakers Vote to Limit Public Pensions
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers on Thursday morning approved a hard-fought measure to cut the retirement benefits for future public employees in New York City and across the state, dealing a defeat to labor unions at the end of a dramatic all-night session.

title: Jury in Rutgers Spying Case Asks Judge for Clarification
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  The jury in the trial of a former Rutgers University student accused of invading his roommates privacy by using a webcam to watch him in an intimate encounter began deliberations on Wednesday and asked the judge to define two crucial terms.

title: With Video, Obama Looks to Expand Campaigns Reach Through Social Media
description: When presidential candidates have a message they want voters to hear far and wide, they have typically turned to that old campaign standby: the television ad.

title: Lottery Numbers

title: Russia May Let NATO Use Airfield as Afghan Hub
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin expressed willingness on Wednesday to allow NATO to use an airfield in the heart of European Russia, in a city best known as Lenins birthplace, as a transit center for moving troops and nonlethal cargo into Afghanistan.

title: Visiting History Where It Happened
description: Some of the most infamous scenes of the Civil Rights era unfolded in the blocks surrounding the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute.

title: G.M.s Breathe Easy as Meeting Ends
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  The N.H.L. general managers meeting that concluded Wednesday had a very different feel from the previous two, when major on-ice injuries led the G.M.s to recommend rules aimed at reducing an alarming spike in reported concussions.

title: Women Figure Anew in Senates Latest Battle
description: WASHINGTON  With emotions still raw from the fight over President Obamas contraception mandate, Senate Democrats are beginning a push to renew the Violence Against Women Act, the once broadly bipartisan 1994 legislation that now faces fierce opposition from conservatives.

title: A Changed Coach Emerges From a Career in Ruins
description: PITTSBURGH  Technically, Southern Mississippis Larry Eustachy is not one of the first-time coaches in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Eustachy has actually been to the tournament three times before, including in 2000 when he led Iowa State to a 32-5 record and the Round of 8, and was named the national coach of the year by The Associated Press.

title: In 1956, a Racial Law Repelled Harvards Team
description: It has been a long time since anyone in the nation noticed or cared where the Harvard mens basketball team was playing. But Thursday, the Crimson will be among the competitors in the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in 66 years. Their dream is to get to the Final Four in New Orleans.

title: Gingrich Casts Himself as the Key to Stop Romney
description: Confronted with intensifying pressure to get out of the presidential race, Newt Gingrich is trying a new argument for continuing his campaign: Conservatives cannot block Mitt Romneys path to the Republican nomination without him.

title: Bromance Blooming
description: Although Gonzaga Coach Mark Few readily admitted he has no idea what a bromance is  what is the term again? he asked an inquiring reporter  he did not hesitate to agree that his affection for West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins might be strong enough to qualify for the label.

title: Changing Universities and His Outlook, Iowa State Forward Excels
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Iowa States Royce White settled into the car seat next to his grandfather for the eight-and-a-half-hour ride and immersed himself in honey buns and Adele. Those may seem to be odd choices for snack and entertainment for a muscled and agile 6-foot-8 forward who grew up in Minneapolis listening to hip-hop.

title: Ecosanctuary Plans for Wild Horses Add Tourism to the Mix
description: CENTENNIAL, Wyo.  This was prime horse country once, in the old Western working way of bridles, bits and sweat. Leather tack from those days still hangs, cracked and preserved in the arid dust, on the wall of the 1906 vintage hay loft at the Wilson place.

title: Despite Southern Losses, Gingrich Still Has Eyes on Tampa
description: Palatine, Ill.  Flashing camera phones and a standing ovation greeted Newt Gingrich Wednesday night as he walked on stage to address more than 400 area Republicans gathered at a Lincoln Day Dinner in the suburbs of Chicago.

title: Center Bulks Up; Wichita St. Flexes Muscles
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The story of how Garrett Stutz helped transform Wichita State into an unlikely N.C.A.A. tournament contender began with a Pop-A-Shot rivalry with an 11-year-old.

title: Pierre Schoendoerffer, French Filmmaker, Dies at 83
description: Pierre Schoendoerffer, a celebrated French film director and novelist whose experience as a prisoner during the Indochina War fueled his cinematic quests for meaning, and even beauty, in the travails of those who fought, died on Wednesday in a hospital near Paris. He was 83.

title: Girlfriend of Crime Boss Changes Her Plea to Guilty
description: BOSTON  Catherine Greig, the girlfriend of James (Whitey) Bulger, changed her plea to guilty on Wednesday, softly admitting in court that she fled with Mr. Bulger in 1995 and helped the legendary crime boss hide out, avoiding trial for multiple murders, for 16 years.

title: After School Tragedy, a Pre-emptive Strike Against Trauma
description: LOMMEL-KOLONIE, Belgium  In this tidy town on the Belgian-Dutch border, children at the t Stekske elementary school would dream from first grade on about the annual ski trip to the Alps.

title: Nets Win, but Thoughts Are on Howard
description: NEWARK  As the war for leverage raged on between the Magic and Dwight Howard with less than a day before the N.B.A.s trade deadline, the Nets  a hopeful suitor for Howard  won by 98-84 over the Toronto Raptors on Wednesday night.

title: Tom Murrin, Alien Comic Performance Artist, Dies at 73
description: Tom Murrin, a performance artist whose frenetic shows fashioned kooky narratives out of found objects and homemade masks and made him a longtime favorite in the downtown avant-garde arts scene in New York, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Announcing My Win-a-Trip Winner!
description: Congratulations to Jordan Schermerhorn of Rice University, the winner of my 2012 win-a-trip contest! We had a terrific field of contestants, and the Center for Global Development in Washington sifted them down to the finalists. In the end, I went with Jordan in part because I admired her writing and thought she would bring an unusual skill set and passion to the trip. Shes an engineer who wants to work in global health, and yet she has never been abroad, and she had very strong recommendations from her professors.

title: Mets Face Burden of Proof in Fraud Case
description: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the owners of the Mets would be required to prove at their trial that they were not willfully blind to red flags that Bernard L. Madoff was engaged in illegal activity. The Mets are being sued by the trustee for Madoffs victims for more than $300 million.

title: Jets Re-Sign Folk and Have Eye on Schilens
description: The Jets re-signed Nick Folk, who made 19 of 25 field-goal attempts last season, but they will probably bring in another kicker to compete with him during training camp.

title: Five Years Later, Yankees Chamberlain Hopes to Write Another Feel-Good Story
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As he continues to be unmercifully swarmed by opposing N.B.A. defenses, the Knicks Jeremy Lin might want to consult Joba Chamberlain, who once had the same issue with midges.

description: The Republican Party has a big problem. Huge!

description: President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, hosted a state dinner for Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain and his wife, Samantha Cameron on Wednesday night.

title: Noble Fleming, Arbiter of Tea Taste, Dies at 92
description: Noble Fleming, who for nearly 50 years sipped and sniffed from teaspoons and fine china cups to ensure the quality of tea for millions of Americans, died on Feb. 24 at a nursing home in Saint-Vaast-la-Hougue, France. He was 92.

title: With Arms for Yemen Rebels, Iran Seeks Wider Mideast Role
description: WASHINGTON  In the past several months, Iran appears to have increased its political outreach and arms shipments to rebels and other political figures in Yemen as part of what American military and intelligence officials say is a widening Iranian effort to extend its influence across the greater Middle East.

title: U.S. Backs Antismoking Ad Campaign
description: For the first time, the federal government will directly attack the nations tobacco addiction with a series of advertisements highlighting the grisly toll of smoking, a campaign that federal health officials hope will renew the stalled decline in the share of Americans who smoke.

title: Upstart Leader in China Is Ousted From Party Post
description: BEIJING  Bo Xilai, the brash Communist Party chief of the Chongqing municipality in Chinas southwest, has been removed from his post, an unmistakable sign that recent scandals in that city have put an end to his political ambitions and complicated the national leadership transition that will take place in the fall.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/15/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/15/2012

title: Russia: 2 Arrested After Bands Protest at Cathedral to Remain Jailed
description: A Moscow court ruled on Wednesday that two women accused of participating in a punk prayer service against Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin by a rock band made up of masked feminist activists in front of the altar of Christ the Savior Cathedral last month must remain in pretrial detention until April 24. The women, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, were arrested on March 3, on the eve of Russias presidential elections, which Mr. Putin won after a wave of protests appeared to threaten his rule. They face up to seven years in prison. A video of the performance circulated on YouTube. Mr. Putins spokesman has said that he found the performance offensive. Russian Orthodox Church leaders have said that the bands actions were blasphemous and that the women should be prosecuted, although not necessarily imprisoned. Yet some church activists have said that the case is politically motivated and have called for their immediate release. The womens lawyers said there was no proof that they participated in the performance.

title: Late-Night Comedians Riff on Goldman Op-Ed
description: Leave it to Stephen Colbert to rename Greg Smith, the Goldman Sachs investment banker who very publicly resigned on Wednesday and explained why in a New York Times Op-Ed column. He is Banker-dict Arnold, the Comedy Central satirist declared on his show Wednesday night, riffing on Benedict Arnold, the Revolutionary War traitor.

title: Six Monks vs. One Warship
description: HONG KONG  Asia has seen varying displays of hard power and soft power in recent days, as the region struggles to come to grips with some frozen and seemingly intractable conflicts.

title: Another Furor Over Planned Appearance by Rushdie
description: Salman Rushdies plans to speak publicly in India are stirring controversy yet again.

title: Gambia: Ruling Party Faces Scarce Opposition for Parliament
description: Campaigning for Gambias March 29 parliamentary elections began on Wednesday, with President Yahya Jammehs party facing no opposition for more than half of the seats. Mr. Jammehs Alliance for Patriotic Re-Orientation and Construction will field candidates for all 48 seats, according to statement from the Independent Electoral Commission that was handed to reporters in Banjul, the capital. A group of opposition parties has pledged not to take part in the election, which they expect to be rigged. Mr. Jammeh has ruled the West African nation for 17 years.

title: Tibet: Another Monk Sets Himself Afire
description: A Tibetan monk set fire to himself on Wednesday in the town of Rongwo in the Chinese province of Qinghai to protest rule by Beijing, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group in London. The monk, Jamyang Palden, who set himself on fire in a square in front of the Rongwo Monastery, is believed to have survived. He was said to be in his 30s. The authorities took him to a hospital, but monks brought him back to the monastery for fear that he would be arrested, Free Tibet said. At least 27 Tibetans have set themselves ablaze in the last year, and at least 18 have died. About 500 monks gathered in the square after the self-immolation on Wednesday, and some held up pictures of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, Free Tibet said. The International Campaign for Tibet, another advocacy group, said its sources had confirmed the self-immolation, which took place about 9 a.m. Rongwo is in the county of Rebkong, called Tongren in Chinese, an area on the border of Tibetan and ethnic Han lands.

title: Struggling Kingfisher Announces Cutbacks
description: The Indian airline Kingfisher said Wednesday that it would scale back overseas flights to cut costs and attract funding from skeptical investors, while the countrys aviation regulator accused it of reneging on a recovery plan and British Airways said it had suspended a code-sharing pact with the airline, Reuters reports.

title: Panetta Says He Was Not the Target of an Attack
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Thursday that he did not believe that the Afghan who crashed a stolen pickup truck near his plane, and then emerged from the truck in flames, was trying to attack him. But the Afghan was an interpreter working for coalition forces at the complex where Mr. Panetta was landing, raising the possibility that he knew someone of importance was arriving.

title: News Quiz | March 15, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.Good luck!

description: Google search, I.B.M.s Watson Jeopardy-winning computer, credit-card fraud detection and automated speech recognition.

title: March 15, 1965 | President Johnson Calls for Passage of Voting Rights Act
description: On March 15, 1965, addressing a joint session of Congress, President Lyndon B. Johnson called for new legislation to guarantee every Americans right to vote. Open your polling places to all your people, he declared. Allow men and women to register and vote whatever the color of their skin. Extend the rights of citizenship to every citizen of this land.Johnson made the speech in response to events in and around Selma, Ala., where civil rights leaders were organizing a voting rights campaign. Eight days earlier, state authorities violently suppressed a march by black demonstrators in an incident known as Bloody Sunday. Two voting rights demonstrators, a young black man and a white minister, were killed by white men in separate episodes around Selma.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 15, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Religious Statues Left Behind Find Their Own Patron Saint.

description: I just published my2012 defensive tackle rankings, and Washingtons Alameda Taamu is all the way down at No. 12. Ive seen Alameda ranked as high as No. 3 in this class, but Im missing what others are seeing in him.

title: For Women Workers in Gurgaon, Strict But Toothless Laws
description: The issue of womens safety in Gurgaon has come into the spotlight this week, after a woman who said she worked for a pub there was gang-raped as she was leaving work. More than 150 people gathered Wednesday night in front of the Sahara Mall, where the pub is located, in protest.

title: Ordeal in Pakistan Ends for 2 Swiss Hostages
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Swiss couple held by the Taliban in northwestern Pakistan for eight months turned up at a military checkpoint early on Thursday and were flown by helicopter to Peshawar and then Islamabad, where they were handed over to the Swiss Embassy, officials said.

title: Fafsa Completion Rates Are Available Online
description: Heres an incentive to hurry up and finish filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid: the federal government is now posting completion rates, by high school, online.

description: The Giants may yet lose receiver Mario Manningham and cornerback Aaron Ross as free agents, but the team gained one Wednesday with the former Cowboys tight end Martellus Bennett.

title: Fantasy Focus: Projecting Playing Time
description: A colleague of mine, Todd Zola, once said something to this effect: If I could know in advance the rate stats (average/on-base percentage/slugging) for the entire player pool, or the number of games each would play, Id rather know the playing time. I took that to mean three things: (1) Playing time is often harder to predict than performance; (2) Opportunity often trumps skill; and (3) Performance often begets playing time, so you could infer that a less established player was both playing well and staying healthy if you knew he had 550 at-bats.

title: Sports Tales Cast India as the Villain
description: Indian athletes who are not cricket stars usually have to endure corrupt officials, humiliation and poverty. Olympians die in penury and in want of medical attention. Some have had to sell their gold medals, Manu Joseph writes in the International Herald Tribune.

title: Peyton Manning Has History of Choosing Tennessee
description: Peyton Manning has done it before. He has made a surprising announcement about his football future that has made people in Tennessee deliriously happy. In the video above, he declared that he would stay at Tennessee for his senior season instead of turning pro.

title: Indias Budget 2011: What Was Promised, What Was Delivered
description: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee made some lofty promises during his budget speech on Feb. 28, 2011. For the most part, the government has been unable to keep its word, in part owing to the inability to pass reform in Parliament, but also exacerbated by an economic slowdown and high oil and food prices. Here is a list of projections made in in the 2011 budget and how they have measured up over the year.

title: Damascus Puts on Pro-Assad Rally, but Protesters Wont Be Silenced
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  It was a struggle to reach Ummayad Square in Damascus, where many thousands of Syrians had gathered on Thursday to cheer President Bashar al-Assad. The city had come to a near-standstill for what the government billed as a Global March for Syria  a celebration, went the official narrative, of steadfastness in the face of a foreign-inspired conspiracy that had fueled a year of senseless violence.

title: For L.I.U., the Look Back to its Powerhouse Era Is a Long One
description: Long Island University is a No. 16 seed in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, a team expected to be no obstacle for Michigan State when they meet Friday in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Going Back to High School, Undercover With Badges and Baggage
description: Is popular culture like a river, flowing relentlessly forward so that no one ever steps in the same waters twice? Or is it like a coral reef  or, less organically, a landfill  formed out of the continuous accretion of new matter? If two wildly dissimilar objects have the same name, does it make any sense to compare them? If so, how? Please forgive the philosophical tenor of these questions: Ive just seen 21 Jump Street, and it has left me in a ruminative mood.

description: Four researchers in Scotland say that revising the recommendation that mothers breast-feed exclusively for six months might ultimately result in more breast-feeding.

title: Whisper of the Wild
description: Setting off in the predawn gloaming of central Alaska, we were the sounds of swishing snow pants, crunching boots and cold puffs of breath. As sunrise gradually lightened the late November sky, we took visible shape: a single-file parade on a narrow white trail traveling west, deeper into Denali National Park and Preserve. It was three degrees and so still that when we pulled up to rest, I heard no wind, no sibilant leaves, just a barely perceptible ringing in my ears. Tundra swans, kestrels and warblers had all flown south. Grizzlies were asleep in their dens. We tramped over frozen streams and paused to discover water still trickling faintly in hollows below. To the north, a morning blast of pink and orange brightened snow-shrouded Mount Healy at the edge of the Alaska Range; to the south  where the sun is always rising or setting during winter at a latitude just three degrees shy of the Arctic Circle  an alpine ridge remained covered in shadow and alder.

title: Carlyle Expands Board and Reports 2011 Profit
description: The Carlyle Group disclosed on Thursday that it had filled out its board with seven new members, and that it earned a healthy profit last year, as the private equity giant prepares to go public within the next few months.

description: Agence France-Presse  Getty ImagesPresident Bashar al-Assad voted in a February referendum as his wife, Asma, looked on.

title: The Liu Wen Express
description: Slipping into a pair of blue Marc Jacobs pants in the back of a rented van in Yongzhou, China, the model Liu Wen was feeling an unusual degree of jitters. Changing clothes on the go is standard practice for models shooting on location, and she liked the look: Its tomboy style, she said. I feel its my style. And under most circumstances  long travel, bad weather, unexpected wardrobe glitches  Chinas first bona fide supermodel has a reputation in the industry for being gracious and professional. But as the van pulled up to her old middle school, she peered worriedly out the curtained windows at a waiting crowd: hundreds of frantic teenagers in white uniform jackets, spitting images of her recent former self. Its getting crazy here, she said. The students were chanting, Liu Wen, Liu Wen and were armed with cellphone cameras and notepads for autographs, eager for the return of their schools most famous alum. Im not that big a celebrity, she said. Im just an ordinary person.

description: SHANGHAI  A Standard Chartered banker has been detained by the police in eastern China on suspicion that she aided a wealthy client who was accused of having fled the country with millions of dollars in state assets.

Thursday Reading: New Guidelines Call for Less-Frequent Pap Smears
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Cisco to Buy NDS, a Video Services Firm, for $5 Billion
description: 6:43 p.m. | Updated Cisco Systems said on Thursday that it planned to buy the NDS Group, a provider of content streaming and security software, for about $5 billion to help expand its next-generation video services.

title: Bleeding the Patient
description: Brad DeLong and Larry Summers have a paper in progress about fiscal policy in a liquidity trap; some of the analytics here. The bottom line, fleshed out with a lot of evidence, is one that others  including me and Christy Romer  have been arguing for a while: expansionary fiscal policy under these conditions doesnt just aid the economy in the short run, it may well even improve the long-run fiscal prospect. And austerity may be self-defeating even in fiscal terms.

title: Why Hungary Matters
description: A quick note here: Im actually kind of shocked at some of the comments on Kim Lane Scheppeles latest post here. Not the ones accusing her of lying or getting her facts wrong; thats part for the course, with my own experience being that the more solidly grounded in evidence I am the more hysterical accusations of dishonesty I get.

title: A Day to Toast The Godfather, and New York
description: Some of you may consider this an offer you can refuse, but others will want to note an event of enduring cultural import that took place 40 years ago Thursday. The Godfather, a film as firmly rooted in New York as Manhattan schist, opened that day in five theaters around the city.

title: Virginity Tests, a Trial for Egypt
description: CAIRO  On Sunday,an Egyptian military tribunal acquitted an army doctor of performing so-called virginity tests on seven female protesters last spring. This is not merely a setback for womens rights in this patriarchal country. Its also a troubling precedent for government accountability, one year after the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Daily Report: A Roundup of iPad Reviews
description: The critics are weighing in on the new iPad, which could easily have been called the iPad 3 if Apple wasnt trying so hard to be less predictable. The consensus seems to be that this is no radical reinvention, just an evolution of the iPad 2. In other words, its a bit predictable.

title: Image of the Day: March 15
Karzai Calls on U.S. to Pull Back as Taliban Cancel Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai insisted Thursday that the United States confine its troops to major bases in Afghanistan by next year as the Taliban announced that they were suspending peace talks with the Americans, both of which served to complicate the Obama administrations plans for an orderly exit from the country.

title: C.F.D.A. Awards Are Announced
description: 7:54 p.m. | Updated Going into the nominating process for the annual fashion awards presented by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, there was a lot of debate as to what celebrity or cultural figure would be named this years icon. After awards have been handed out to Michelle Obama, Iman and Lady Gaga in recent years, there was a bit of a feeling of whos left?

title: Who Is Pierre Poutine?
description: MONTREAL  Its election day. The phone rings. Its an automated call from Elections Canada informing you that, due to circumstances beyond their control, your polling station has been changed. You scramble to find a pen to jot down the new address. Turns out, its miles from where you live.

title: On Our Radar: The Dead Zone in the Gulf

description: Stocks advanced on Thursday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index above 1,400 for the first time in almost four years, as data showed manufacturing in the New York region unexpectedly increased and jobless claims declined.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: The cinnamon challenge  trying to down a spoonful of the powdered spice without water, and without gagging or worse  has become a viral parlor game on YouTube. But viral maybe be understatement when it comes to the health hazards: Doctors warn that it can cause choking and lung damage, and schools are urging students (and staff) to desist.   Patrick Farrell

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Obamas YouTube Strategy, and Luck Ends
description: The Obama re-election campaign is putting great stock in a 17-minute online documentary narrated by Tom Hanks that the campaign hopes will spread across the Internet via social networks. The documentary goes live Thursday night on YouTube, Jeremy Peters reports, and is a prime example of the importance political campaigns now attach to Web video, which is changing from a passive experience to one that can be harnessed to fund-raising and organizing.

title: Fiona Apple Returns, Still Enraged and Self-Lacerating
description: AUSTIN, Tex. The baleful, anxious, doleful, enraged Fiona Apple was back in full force on the first night of SXSW, playing in the backyard amphitheater of Stubbs. It was her first concert crowd outside Los Angeles in years. Very slender, wearing a black and red dress, she blurted out Youre imaginary! to the audience between songs.

title: Poetry Pairing | Jabberwocky
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Lewis Carrolls Jabberwocky with O Frabjous Day! a 2007 review of a childrens book by Christopher Myers that presents the famous poem, which the reviewer calls the greatest nonsense verse in the English-speaking world, in the context of a basketball face-off.

title: The View from Montana: An Upset of Wisconsin Would Come as No Surprise
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Theater Talkback: The Trade-Offs From Page to Stage
description: Reading and theater-going are largely separate activities. Though they walk side by side through my life, occupying more waking hours than any other activities, the lines between them seldom blur. Reading is private, even in a subway car; theater is a collective experience, in which youre always on the same page (literally if not figuratively) with a lot of other people.

title: Good Jobs and Bad Jobs
description: Often missing in the jobs, jobs, jobs conversationJohn Boehners promise to focus on jobs, the fight over whether Democrats or Republicans are responsible for the lack of jobs, the paeans to private-sector job-creators, the denigration of public-sector job-creatorsis that some jobs are better than others.

title: Crazy Is As Crazy Does
description: In a follow-up in the great are Republicans crazy? debate, Jonathan Chait complains that I mischaracterized his predictions about the Republican primary, and demands that I address his substantive points instead of just comparing our track records as prognosticators. Heres his most legitimate complaint:

title: Leading Off: Entering the Zero Productivity Zone
description: It is officially time to celebrate the two days a year when American productivity goes in the toilet and its a good thing. Thursday and Friday are like a little escape hatch from the usual grind, with N.C.A.A. tournament games going non-stop and while the Puritans of the business world can wring their bony hands over paying people who are suddenly obsessed with the fate of Virginia Commonwealth, the proper response is: tough noogies.

title: Better Economic Forecasts, From the Cloud
description: Someday soon, the Federal Reserve may be dead, at least for economic information. Blame it on, or credit it to, cloud computing.

title: Bank of Communications of China to Raise $8.9 Billion
description: Bank of Communications, one of Chinas largest financial institutions, said on Thursday that it planned to raise $8.9 billion through a share sale as it looked to shore up its capital reserves.

title: Witness Intimidation Alleged in Arrest in Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  In what could prove to be one of the most damaging chapters yet in the scandal enveloping Rupert Murdochs tabloid newspapers in Britain, Scotland Yard arrested a former chief reporter for The News of the World on Wednesday on suspicion of intimidating a witness, the first time the police have raised the specter of witness tampering in the course of their investigations.

title: Labors Take on the Economy
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When labor leaders talk publicly, its often to make angry, off-the-cuff statements to denounce a company that is taking a tough line on wage increases or to lambaste a lawmaker who is sponsoring anti-union legislation.

title: Business Day Live | March 15, 2012
description: Susanne Craig on the reaction inside Goldman Sachs to a public rebuke; why marriage is for rich people; and Evelyn M. Rusli discusses why brokers who trade private shares have run afoul of regulators.

title: Le Bec-Fins New Chef Is Walter Abrams
description: Walter Abrams, who was the chef de cuisine at Spruce in San Francisco and had been a sous-chef at the French Laundry, in Yountville, Calif., will be the new chef at Le Bec-Fin in Philadelphia, which closed this month upon the retirement of Georges Perrier. The new owner is Nicolas Fanucci, who plans to reopen it in late spring.

title: The Tools of Tree-Ring Research
description: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

title: Inner Workings of Senators Troubled Trial Detailed
description: WASHINGTON  At least two federal prosecutors involved in the botched ethics trial of the late Senator Ted Stevens intentionally withheld and concealed significant evidence from the defense team that could have resulted in his acquittal, a court-appointed investigator has concluded.

title: More Homeowners Seek Reverse Mortgages at Earlier Age
description: Reverse mortgages have always been viewed as a last resort  something that older retirees could turn to when they desperately needed to supplement their dwindling incomes. But in the wake of the housing markets collapse and high unemployment, a new study has found that people are using reverse mortgages to alleviate more urgent financial pressures, like paying off debt.And homeowners are applying for these loans at much younger ages than they have in the past.

title: Wheelies: The Luxury Fishing Lodge Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Antismoking Campaign
description: A relatively modest ad campaign will be the governments first directly financed attack against tobacco addiction.

title: The View from B.Y.U: After a Record Comeback, Ready for Game Two
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: The Girl on Fire | Inside the Los Angeles Premiere of The Hunger Games
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Creature Comfort
description: On the road with the girl who talks to capuchin monkeys (and ocelots, and kangaroos and )

title: 36 Hours: Long Beach, Calif.
description: AT the mouth of the Los Angeles River, shipping cranes flex across the skyline  an industrial panorama that suits Long Beachs gritty reputation. But while the citys maritime character remains, its rough edges have been smoothed in recent years  the downtown waterfront transformed by redevelopment, the busy port now welcoming both cargo vessels and cruise ships. Along with its sandy shore, a compact downtown of low-rising Art Deco towers, and unassuming neighborhoods where Craftsman bungalows are ringed by tropical gardens, Long Beach has excellent museums, ethnic enclaves and a tangle of Southern California subcultures. Layered, urban and unexpected, it is a city apart from the sprawl and strip malls that define the outer edges of Los Angeles.

title: 36 Hours: Long Beach, Calif.
description: Explore Long Beachs museums, restaurants, jazz clubs and vintage boutiques.

title: Unions Urge Curtailment of Super PACs
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Leaders of the nations labor unions  which some experts say benefited from the Supreme Courts Citizens United ruling in 2010  said on Wednesday that the ruling needed to be overturned for the good of American democracy,

title: Getting Doctors to Think About Costs
description: My first formal lesson on health care costs occurred one afternoon on the wards when I was a medical student. The senior doctor in charge, a silver-haired specialist known for his thoughtful approach to patient care, had assembled several students and doctors-in-training to discuss a theoretical patient with belly pain. After describing the patients history and physical exam, he asked what tests we might order.

title: Babys First Bling
description: Last week we pierced our 6-month-old daughters ears. I know what youre thinking: what kind of parents are you?

title: Why Cisco Paid $5 Billion for NDS
description: On Thursday, Cisco Systemsannounced its intention to pay about $5 billion, including assumption of debt, for the NDS Group, a British software company that serves the cable television industry. Underlining its intentions, Cisco also published a blog post about the acquisition.

title: Coca-Cola and LOral Offer Ambitious Goals for 2020
description: Two giant advertisers with ambitious goals to grow even larger offered their peers a glimpse of their strategies at a marketing meeting in New York.

title: The Usual High Expectations Mingle With Uncertainty
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Pat Summitt plays games and puzzles on her iPad to help her remain alert. Her sense of humor remains acute, along with her ambition to win a ninth national championship. But anyone who has been around her can sense inevitable changes seven months after Summitt revealed that she had symptoms of early onset Alzheimers disease.

title: Tortorella Wont Discuss Crosby, Penguins; Lundqvist Still Out
description: John Tortorella is nothing if not consistent. As any follower of the Rangers would expect, Tortorella declined Thursday morning to share his feelings on the return of Sidney Crosby or the importance of tonights game against the Penguins at Madison Square Garden.

title: Whats Really Happened to Rail Fares in the Last Nine Years
description: The annual presentation of the Railway Budget in Parliament is a staid affair usually featuring the minister in charge reeling off a list of new lines to be built or stations to be refurbished. For the last nine years, no minister has dared to announce an increase in ticket prices, though they have often raised the cost of transporting freight.

title: Wall Streets Latest Campus Recruiting Crisis
description: Wall Street, once a magnet for Americas best and brightest, is facing a recruiting problem.

title: Dimon Urges High Road in Goldman Controversy
description: For JPMorgan Chase, now might be a good time to poach a few Goldman Sachs clients.

title: Ruling Gives Edge to U.S. in Its Appeal of Citi Case
description: 6:15 p.m. | Updated with additional details

title: Video Shows Large Protest by Tibetan Monks in China
description: A day after the self-immolation of a Tibetan monk and reports of large protests in response, the advocacy group Free Tibet posted new video and photographs offering a rare glimpse of monks inside the highly restricted and restive part of western China.

title: Discovering a New Photo, Perhaps, of Ellis Islands Annie
description: Updated, 2:02 p.m. | Annie Moore seems to resurface every St. Patricks Day, the poster child of immigration to America. Arriving in New York with her two younger brothers in 1892, the little rosy-cheeked Irish girl was the first foreigner greeted at the nations new immigration station on Ellis Island.

title: Reyes to Play Against Mets, Short-Haired and Happy
description: JUPITER, Fla  Jose Reyes is set to be in the lineup Thursday when his new team, the Miami Marlins, meets his old team, the Mets. Reyes had not attended any of the three previous spring training games between the teams.

title: Photos of The Moment | Santigold at SXSW
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: At Obama Rallies, Fainting Spells Resurge
description: 3:44 p.m. | Updated For President Obama, the fainting spells are back.

title: Rolling Stones Say No Tour This Year. Maybe 2013
description: The Rolling Stones will not tour to celebrate their 50th anniversary, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards told Rolling Stone magazine in an item published on Wednesday. Mr. Richards, who is 68, said 2013 was a more realistic goal for the aging rockers.

title: Interactive Feature: A Chorus of Criticism for Goldman
description: Since the financial crisis, Goldman Sachs has faced a wave of criticism from politicians, regulators, protesters and writers. Now, a Goldman executive who resigned publicly on Wednesday is joining the chorus of detractors.

title: Business Day Live: Reaction Inside Goldman
description: Susanne Craig on the reaction inside Goldman Sachs to a public rebuke; why marriage is for rich people; and Evelyn M. Rusli discusses why brokers who trade private shares have run afoul of regulators.

title: College, Farther and Farther Out of Reach
description: Last week I wrote about how state cuts to public colleges meant shifting more of the burden of educating students onto the federal government. As state subsidies fall, tuition rises, and needy students look to federal subsidies like Pell Grants and Stafford loans to make up the difference.

title: TimesCast | March 15, 2012
description: The Taliban suspend peace talks with the United States | President Obama's campaign will release a 17-minute video.

title: Courting Puerto Rico, Santorum Does Damage Control
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Rick Santorum spent part of Thursday trying to calm a firestorm of criticism he created here Wednesday when he said that if Puerto Rico became a state, it must make English its primary language. His remarks prompted one delegate who had been pledged to him to quit.

title: Quandary Considered: Pregnant, With a Job Interview
description: S. is two months pregnant with her second child, and six months into a period of freelancing thats left her and her husband juggling to make ends meet. This week  today, in fact  she has a job interview for a steady, at-home, part-time job at a small company.

title: In New Space, Pearl Theater Will Feature a New McNally Play
description: The Tony Award-winning writer Terrence McNally (Master Class, Ragtime) will have a world-premiere production of his new play, And Away We Go, Off Broadway next year. The play travels through time to show the similarities among chaotic theater companies in ancient Greece, Elizabethan London, Versailles and 20th-century America.

title: The View from Syracuse: Now, Its Up to the Seniors
description: Syracuses seniors are the sparks for the Orange. When the team fell to Cincinnati in the Big East tournament semifinals. Scoop Jardine and Kris Joseph turned the ball over a combined nine times.

title: Oklahoma States Parks Chases Elusive Wrestling Title
description: Throughout the college wrestling season, The Quad will follow some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: A Meter So Expensive, It Creates Parking Spots
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The maddening quest for street parking is not just a tribulation for drivers, but a trial for cities. As much as a third of the traffic in some areas has been attributed to drivers circling as they hunt for spaces. The wearying tradition takes a toll in lost time, polluted air and, when drivers despair, double-parked cars that clog traffic even more.

title: Obama Defends Energy Policy, Hitting Back at Presidential Candidates
description: LARGO, Md.  In what has become a weekly ritual, President Obama on Thursday defended his administrations energy policy, in the face of relentlessly rising gasoline prices, to an American public that believes he can do more to ease the pain at the pump.

title: Hammer Museum to Poll Public for a New $100,000 Art Prize
description: A former MTV executive who helped found the E! television network has announced a gift to the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles to begin a new $100,000 artist award that has overtones of reality television, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: Omnivores Delight
description: The first thing you are meant to see when you arrive in Tongeren, which bills itself as the oldest town in Belgium, is a statue of Ambiorix, the leader of the Eburones, the hometown tribe that defeated the Romans circa 55 B.C. But for some reason I miss this landmark in favor of a humongous branch of H&M dominating the village square.

title: Louisville Becomes Center of Basketball World for Kentucky Schools
