Fifteen years after that memorable game, however, Loyola (Md.) could not come close to matching its neighbors historic performance.

title: Can Indias Mr. Fix It Spur Growth?
description: The stakes are high for Indias finance minister, Pranjab Mukherjee, as he delivers the annual statement of the Union Budget.

title: Chelseas Di Matteo Is Managing Just Fine, Thank You Very Much
description: It seemed appropriate for Chelsea that the first significant rebound from the departure of Andr Villas-Boas should happen in the Champions League, a competition that has claimed more than one managerial victim in the Roman Abramovich era. Ever since Abramovich bought the London club in 2003, the Champions League has represented the promised land. Even the Special One, Jos Mourinho, couldnt deliver what his arrival had been billed to guarantee.

title: Britain: 2 Sentenced for a Robbery Videotaped During the Riots Last Year
description: The videotaped robbery of a Malaysian student during last summers rioting, which drew nearly six million hits on YouTube and a personal condemnation by Prime Minister David Cameron, resulted in prison terms for the two muggers on Thursday. The video, filmed by a passerby, showed the two men pretending to help the student, Ashraf Rossli, after another youth in a London neighborhood had robbed him of his bicycle and broken his jaw. After helping Mr. Rossli to his feet, the two men stole his cellphone and other items from his backpack. The bicycle thief, sentenced separately, received a seven-year prison term. One of the men who looted the victims backpack, Reece Donovan, 24, was sentenced to five years in prison, and the other, John Kafunda, 22, received a term of four years and three months. Of the 3,000 people arrested for robbery, violence and property destruction during the riots, nearly 1,000 have been jailed, with average sentences of 14 months.

title: Xavier Tries to Heal a Self-Inflicted Wound
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Xavier Coach Chris Mack is fond of telling his team that the games everybody remembers most are the ones played in March. That may be true, but its going to take quite a run in the N.C.A.A. tournament to make people forget about the game that has already defined the Musketeers this season.

title: Spring Break Gets Tamer as World Watches Online
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  Ah, Spring Break, with its copious debauchery, its spontaneous bouts of breast-baring, Jager bombing and aprs-binge vomit.

title: Hope for a Bergtraum Comeback Is Far Away, in Student Homes
Crosby Blends In as Penguins Stand Tall Against Rangers
description: Sidney Crosby sat back in his stall, a black Penguins cap low over his smiling face, telling reporters that he was glad he had not wrecked his teams winning streak.

title: House G.O.P. Hesitates on Birth Control Fight
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans, unsure how to proceed, have slowed their efforts to overturn a federal rule requiring employers, including religious institutions, to provide female employees with free health insurance coverage for contraceptives.

title: Bad Loans at State-Run Banks Add to Indias Woes
description: When people talk about Europes government debt problem they mean something easy to describe: countries that borrowed more money than they can easily pay back, but in India, its a bit more complicated, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York times.

title: Early Glimpse of Missouri Caucuses Shows Support for Santorum
description: BRUNSWICK, Mo.  Mitt Romney and his campaign advisers pride themselves on vigorously pursuing every delegate in every corner of the country in their quest to secure the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Colorado Holds Off U.N.L.V.
description: ALBUQUERQUE  The Colorado Buffaloes carried the momentum from their four-game sweep of the Pacific-12 Conference tournament into the Pit and stormed to a 20-point lead over Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: Meet the Principals
A Rare Tough Race for Jackson in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  It was a Saturday morning and Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois was dashing from news conference to news conference, racking up new political endorsements for the list he has been flaunting here lately. By the end of the day he had squeezed in a speech at an education conference, held a get-out-the-vote rally and made an appearance at an event for a candidate running for the State Legislature.

title: Service Economy Keeps India Afloat
description: Indias poor industrial growth is dragging down the overall economy, according to the Economic Survey released on Thursday, while the service sector appears to be keeping the economy afloat at its current growth rate of just under 7 percent.

title: Hatch Supporters Make Strong Showing in Utah Caucuses
description: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah  The Tea Party-inspired drive to oust Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a six-term Republican, got a bit more complicated on Thursday night.

title: Democratic Senators Issue Strong Warning About Use of the Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON  For more than two years, a handful of Democrats on the Senate intelligence committee have warned that the government is secretly interpreting its surveillance powers under the Patriot Act in a way that would be alarming if the public  or even others in Congress  knew about it.

title: Maine: Court Approves Resort Near Moosehead Lake
description: The Maine Supreme Judicial Court has cleared the way for a development project in the forested Moosehead Lake region. The court found that state regulators did not violate procedural rules when they approved the project in 2009. The developer, Plum Creek, has proposed building two resorts and hundreds of houses near Moosehead Lake in the west central part of Maine, with additional land set aside for conservation. A lower court had found that the states Land Use Regulation Commission had not followed proper procedure before signing off on the project.

title: North Korea Says It Will Launch Satellite Into Orbit
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea announced Friday that it planned to launch a satellite into orbit next month, threatening to scuttle a new agreement with the United States that had briefly raised hopes of easing diplomatic and military tensions surrounding the Norths nuclear weapons program.

title: Texas Schools Face Bigger Classes and Smaller Staff
description: SAN ANTONIO  Ask Phyllis Causey what time she goes to lunch, and the third-grade teacher will give a very specific answer: 11:55 a.m.

title: A Performance of Relentless Stillness, With Live Score
description: Eiko, the female half of Eiko and Koma, the contemporary movement arts duo who have performed together for some 40 years, hurled her small frame onto an oblong pile of canvas and feathers on the floor of the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

title: When a Phone Disappears at Airport Security, No Ones in Charge
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Inquiries on Violence at Occupy Protests Move Slowly
description: More than four months after an Occupy demonstration shut down the Port of Oakland and devolved into violence, at least nine separate investigations into the ways police officers dealt with the protests in Oakland and on University of California campuses in Davis and Berkeley remain unresolved.

title: Budget 2012-13: Overview of the Economy
description: Economic growth:

title: Budget 2012-13: Taxes
description: Individual income up to 2 lakh, or 200,000 rupees ($4,000) will be exempt from income tax.

title: Online Sex Trade Is Flourishing Despite Efforts to Curb It
description: Early this month, the social networking Web site itspimpin101.net fell into disarray after its founder, Kelly Surrell, was fatally wounded in a shooting while driving his Bentley in East Oakland.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays newspaper.

title: Budget 2012-13: Infrastructure, Industry and Agriculture
description: Infrastructure: 60,000 crore, or 600 billion rupees in tax free bonds for infrastructure building.

title: SXSW: What a Difference a Year Has Made for Sharon Van Etten
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  If youve been to more than one South by Southwest, its easy to get cynical and think its just the same thing year after year, with more expensive branding deals. You see some of the same bands over and over, and hear the same gimmicks and retro signifiers, and things start to blend together. (For a few years there it didnt help that every other band name seemed to include Crystal, Bear or Wolf.)

description: Inclusive development spending in 2012-13:

title: March 16, 1968 | U.S. Soldiers Massacre Vietnamese Civilians at My Lai
description: On March 16, 1968, during the Vietnam War, United States troops under the command of Lt. William L. Calley Jr. carried out a massacre of about 500 unarmed men, women and children in the village of My Lai.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 16, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Lights! Cameras! (and Cheers) for a Rock Weighing 340 Tons.

title: Sea Levels and Flood Risks Rise in U.S. Coastal Areas
description: WHO conducted research about sea levels and potential flooding in the United States?

title: Amelia and the Animals
description: Robin Schwartz was looking to do something with her young daughter, Amelia.

title: Should the R Rating for Bully Be Changed?
description: Teenagers and others  including some members of Congress  are petitioning to have the rating lowered from R on the movie Bully, a documentary that tells the stories of five young people subjected to harsh treatment by their peers. Do they have a case? Are movie ratings important? Should the MPAA reevaluate the movies rating? Does a film like this have the potential to help more people talk about bullying and bring about change?

title: Budget 2012 Analysis: Did Mukherjee Deliver?
description: This morning, I asked whether Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee would step up to the plate and deliver a budget statement which would do anything to try to boost Indias anemic growth performance.

title: 4 Gulf States Shun Syria as Turkey Warns Citizens to Leave
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias diplomatic isolation deepened on Friday as four more Persian Gulf states moved to close their Damascus embassies in protest of the violent suppression of a year-old uprising.

title: New Details Show Panetta Was at Risk in Attack
description: WASHINGTON  An Afghan interpreter in a speeding truck tried to run down a top American commander and his British deputy, forcing the two and others to scatter as Defense Secretary Leon E. Panettas plane taxied toward them at a military base in Afghanistan, defense officials said on Friday.

title: Bye Bye, Bo
description: One day Prime Minister Wen Jiabao makes a strong call for political reform. The next day Bo Xilai, the charismatic head of the megalopolis of Chongqing, is axed. A rare public firing by the Chinese Communist Party, Bos dismissal on Thursday has commentators wondering whats in store for Chinas leadership transition later this year.

title: Why Go to College? Readers Weigh In
description: Recently, we posed the question Why go to college at all? and asked Dale J. Stephens, the founder of UnCollege and something of a heretic in the world of higher education, to share his reasons why college need not be a foregone conclusion.

title: North Korean Groundhog Day Comes Late
description: Just two weeks ago, Mark McDonald, Rendezvouss Asia blogger, asked whether North Koreas deal to trade food for the resumption of negotiations to abandon its nuclear program were in good faith or  a kind of diplomatic Groundhog Day.

title: The Early Word: Courting the Hispanic Vote
description: In Todays Times:

title: Capital Gains vs. Ordinary Income
description: In a column titled Capital Gains, Ordinary Income and Shades of Gray, the Harvard economist N. Gregory Mankiw, who advises Mitt Romney in his presidential campaign, offers a fine teaching piece on the tenuous and often confusing line between ordinary income and capital gains under our tax code. As Professor Mankiw reminds us, the highest tax rate on ordinary income is now 35 percent while that on capital gains is only 15 percent.

title: Bills Relevant With Mario Williams, but Realism Needed
description: O.K., so maybe we didnt foresee the Buffalo Toronto Bills making the biggest splash in free agency this off-season. As the esteemed Bills writer Mark Gaughan pointed out in The Buffalo News, In the 20 years the NFL has used an unrestricted free-agent system, the biggest Buffalo signing was a $7 million-a-year deal given to guard Derrick Dockery in 2007. Williamss annual salary is more than double that. In all, hes reeling in $50 million in guarantees.

title: Fantasy Focus: Notable Health Risks
description: Heres my general feeling about what to do with some of the bigger health risks entering 2012:

title: Ciscos Bold Networking Start-Up
description: Three of Ciscos top engineers with a strong record in building some of the companys most important products are in negotiations to create a new type of network switch for data centers, according to people with knowledge of the talks.

title: Daily Report: Pressure Builds Over App Store Fraud
description: Consumers are beginning to complain that Apples iTunes Store, and in particular its App Store, which the company portrays as the safest of shopping environments, is not so secure, report Brian X. Chen and Evelyn M. Rusli on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Karzai Lashes Out at NATO Over Deaths
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The last thing President Obama did before going to bed Thursday night was to call President Hamid Karzai, whose day was just getting started here.

title: Hello, My Name Is Dunk  I Mean Doug  Anderson
description: OMAHA  Doug Andersons first name might as well be Dunk. The most compelling reason  maybe the only reason  to watch Detroit take on Kansas in Friday nights late Midwest Regional mismatch is to see what manner of flying tomahawk monstrosity the 6-foot-6 Anderson drops on the second-seeded Jayhawks.

title: Whit Stillmans Family Album
description: The filmmaker talks about photographs from his youth.

title: Solving Problems: Hiring, Visiting Competitors, an Old Web Site
description: Thanks to everyone who took the time to chime in on the three problems I wrote about last week. As usual, I got good advice from the commenters. Heres a summary, with some further thoughts on what actions Ill be taking.

title: Exclusive Preview: 'Damsels in Distress'
description: A scene from Whit Stillman's new film, starring Greta Gerwig.

title: Whit Stillman and the Song of the Preppy
description: Looking more like a wayward preppy trying to get into the Harvard Club without a tie than a legendary indie filmmaker mounting a comeback, Whit Stillman limped up to a RED digital camera and peered at a set dressed to resemble a girls dorm at a coed liberal arts college. This was back in October 2010. Since the start of the month, Stillman had been leaving his Manhattan sublet before sunrise and commuting to Staten Island, where, amid the banana trees and Greek Revival architecture of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden, he was shooting Damsels in Distress, his first movie in 12 years. Dressed in khakis, a white shirt and a blue blazer, Stillman was in some distress himself, having strained the plantar fascia of his right foot running in loafers for a subway train. He would be 59 in January  more than twice the age of most of his cast and crew  and given his perfectionist tendencies in the editing room, he would surely be 60 by the time the movie was released. I dont like to say Im pushing 60, he said. I prefer to say Im pulling 59.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury to Step Down at End of Year
description: LONDON  After a decade of struggling inconclusively to keep the worldwide Anglican Communion from breaking apart over intractable issues like women clergy, gay bishops and same-sex marriage, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury, announced Friday that he would step down at the end of the year to take up a senior position at Cambridge University.

title: When Barack Met David: A Trans-Atlantic Love Story
description: LONDON  This is intended as a quick catch-up for American readers who may have inexplicably missed the top news story of the week: you just had a visit from the British prime minister. And, by the way, his name is David Cameron.

title: India Proposes Higher Taxes and Slower Spending
description: MUMBAI  Indias finance minister said Friday that the country would raise taxes and slow growth in spending in an effort to lower its swelling budget deficit.

title: Where Are the Republican Elder Statesmen?
description: As the Republican primaries drag on, some in the party are longing for a savior  an elder statesman or wise veteran who has the stature to quietly pull a candidate aside and nudge him out of the race for the good of the party.

title: Battle of the Buyout Kings: Who Took Home the Most in 2011?
description: In the private equity worlds perennial battle for the title of wealthiest magnate around, it appears that Stephen A. Schwarzman has maintained his lead for another year.

title: On Our Radar: Focus Returns to Fuel Efficiency
description: As gasoline prices head higher, a look at some  fuel-efficient models. [Associated Press]

title: Why Receivers Have Ruled Free Agency
description: If the first three days of free agency told us anything, its that the wide receiver position is considered more valuable than ever. Six of our top 10 free-agent receivers are already signed, while several others have been picked up or given new contracts. Traditional thinking has long been that a good offense needs a playmaking star at No. 1 receiver, a reliable possession target at No. 2 and a darting third-down maestro in the slot at No. 3. But look closer at the transactions this week and youll see that these roles are becoming less relevant.

title: Having Your Ducks in a Row Bodes Well for Reality-TV Success
description: Even reality takes practice, a lesson that has not been learned by many makers and stars of workplace reality shows. They think that a moderately unusual occupation  alligator wrangling, sports-memorabilia hawking, storage-locker rummaging  and a camera are all that is necessary to make a watchable show.

title: Head of British Financial Regulator to Step Down
description: LONDON  Hector Sants, the chief executive of Britains financial regulator, will step down at the end of June, as part of a major overhaul to the countrys policing of financial markets.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Lean Times for Dewey & LeBoeuf | Five years after the merger that created Dewey & LeBoeuf, the corporate law world is again abuzz over the firm, but for less auspicious reasons.

title: Financial Crisis, the Musical
description: LONDON  Bankers are the stars of a new musical comedy that opened this month in the West End, the capitals theater district.

title: About the Rampage in Panjwai
description: DURHAM, North Carolina  When I read that a U.S. soldier went berserk last weekend in Panjwai, Afghanistan, rampaging door-to-door and slaughtering 16 Afghan villagers, I thought first of the victims and then of the doors.

title: Opinion Report: Solitary Confinement
description: From the editorial page

title: What They Said: Budget 2012-13
description: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee presented the annual budget in Parliament on Friday. The proposals in the new budget have evoked mixed reactions from Mr.Mukherjees political colleagues and analysts.

title: Friday Reading: Spring Break Gets Tamer Amid Online Viewing
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Eight School Employees Cited for Sexual Allegations
Now Blooming | Out of Sync
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: High-End Takeout at Gastronomie 491
description: There is no shortage of restaurants along Columbus Avenue in the West 80s where you can pick up or arrange delivery of a pizza, a container of dumplings or some mac and cheese. Still, Nicole Ahronee (above), a former jewelry designer who lives in the neighborhood, felt a need for a market and cafe dedicated to those who enjoy fine dining at home.

title: Deutsche Bank Announces Management Shake-Up
description: LONDON  Deutsche Bank announced changes to its management team on Friday, a sign that the incoming co-chief executives of the German bank are looking to put their stamp on the group before they assume joint control.

title: Morning Buzz, March 16: A Stolen Rabbit in SoHo
description: Good morning. Today will be overcast with a 50 percent chance of precipitation, possibly including thunderstorms, and highs in the low 60s.

title: Fill-In | When the Food Writer Is a Ghost
Afghan Prisons Invasive Searches of Female Visitors Stir Fear of Slipping Rights
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Women visiting relatives at a notorious mens prison on the edge of Kabul have in recent weeks been subjected to invasive body-cavity searches at the order of the prisons commandant, who has told guards and American officials that the measure is needed to keep out contraband, Western and Afghan officials said.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Kitchn: Beer, cheddar, chives: all excellent things to add to a bread dough for St. Patricks Day.   Julia Moskin

title: German Museum Ordered to Return Collection of Posters Seized by Nazis
description: BERLIN Germanys leading historical museum must return a collection of more than 4,250 rare posters seized by the Nazis to the American son of a Jewish dentist who fled Germany, the countrys highest court for civil affairs in Karlsruhe ruled on Friday.

title: Hope for a Bergtraum Comeback Is Far Away, in Student Homes
U.P.S. Still Talking to TNT Over $6.4 Billion Takeover
description: LONDON  The United Parcel Service said on Friday that it was still talking to the Dutch shipping company TNT Express about a potential takeover, which values the European outfit at roughly 4.89 billion euros, or $6.4 billion.

title: Strange Justice
description: Texas justice has rarely been kind to homosexuals. Take, for example, the case of Calvin Burdine, who was sentenced to death in 1984 for the murder of his male companion. Burdines court-appointed lawyer, when not dozing, referred to his client as a fairy. The prosecutor, meanwhile, demanded the death penalty by arguing that gays actually look forward to the rewards of prison life. Sending a homosexual to the penitentiary, he claimed, certainly isnt a very bad punishment for a homosexual. Astonishingly, a federal appeals panel first upheld the verdict on the grounds that nothing in the law guarantees a defendant the right to a fully conscious attorney. Burdine eventually won a new trial, at which he was again convicted, but this time sentenced to life in prison  a veritable candy store, it was said, for a pervert like him.

title: A Life in the Balance
description: This much we know to be true: On a cold winter weekend in early 1982, somebody murdered 76-year-old Dorothy Edwards. Apparently she knew the perpetrator, since she let him into her handsome home on a quiet side street in Greenwood, S.C. The crime itself was horrific. She was beaten with a blunt object, stabbed repeatedly  one ear was almost severed  probably sexually assaulted; her body was stuffed into a bedroom closet, where it was discovered on Monday afternoon, Jan. 18. The next day the police arrested Edward Lee Elmore, a 23-year-old handyman whom Edwards had recently hired to do a few odd jobs around the house. He was formally charged with first-degree murder on Jan. 21, tried in the second week of April, found guilty by a jury that deliberated for two and a half hours, and sentenced to death.

title: Tending His Gardens
description: In August 1827, a 33-year-old slave named James F. Brown ran away from a plantation in Maryland. Before he escaped, he wrote a letter explaining his actions and vowed that once he had earned enough money he would reimburse his owner, Susan Williams, to prove that I dont mean to be dishonest but wish to pay her every cent that I think my Servaces is worth. Browns letter reveals much about his character. He was orderly and moderate. He hated to do something that was criminal but felt he had no choice. His had not been a hasty or unreasonable decision. He was only taking the freedom that had rightfully been given by his previous master, who had promised it before his death.

title: Fear Factor
description: With Osama bin Laden dead, American troops leaving Iraq, the economy still sputtering and Congress locked in yet another budget showdown, one thing that seems clear is that Washington will very likely cut military spending sometime soon. This will come as welcome news to David C. Unger, author of The Emergency State and an editorial writer for The New York Times. In this angry new book, Unger deplores what he sees as Washingtons obsession with security and overreliance on military and intelligence capabilities, arguing that they are dangerous perversions of the countrys Jeffersonian traditions.

title: The Enthusiast
description: When John Leonard died in 2008, it did not immediately register that we had lost one of the last and best of a nearly extinct breed, the lifelong book reviewer. Some might prefer the more dignified label literary critic, or cultural critic (he did write extensively about television and other subjects); but Leonard himself did not insist on dignity. His roots and manner were journalistic  he fit into the world of newspapers (including The New York Times Book Review, which he edited in the 1970s), magazines (Harpers, The Nation, New York), radio (Fresh Air) and television (CBS Sunday Morning)  and that casual, accessible tone may be why, for all his erudition, he is usually not discussed in the same breath with other literary arbiters who radiated more gravitas.

title: The Embalmer of Small Things
description: Right now a novels length seems a neutral force. Over here, you have Haruki Murakami and Peter Nadas lying silent for years, then storming the shores of consciousness with thousand-page dreadnoughts; over there, the Argentine writer Csar Aira, pumping out books of one-tenth the size that can still put knots in your brain.

title: While You Were Gone
description: The darkly comic world of Heidi Julavitss latest novel contains warring psychics, missing people whove deliberately vanished themselves, twisted avant-garde filmmakers, absent mothers, striving academics, plastic surgery enthusiasts, Sylvia Plath obsessives  and the people who love to hate and pursue all of them. Beneath this hyperactivity, the novel deals, fundamentally, with the economics of revenge and a daughters search for her mother. It is told in Julavitss signature style: sharp-eyed, sardonic, hilarious.

title: Means of Escape
description: There is an ancient class of vessels, found in Roman tombs, called lachrymatories: tiny glass flasks, often shaped like tears, into which mourners are said to have collected the spill of their weeping eyes. This entrancing image flitted through my mind as I read Peter Camerons new novel, Coral Glynn. By the end of this sad, beautiful, absorbing story of love missed, love lost, love found, I was thinking that this must be what its like to slip into a bath of hot tears.

title: The Devil They Know
description: Satantango, the latest novel by the Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai to be translated into English, takes place over a few rain-sodden days in a dying hamlet. The local estate has been closed, its animals hocked, its mill shut down. Perhaps a dozen residents remain. Like the surrounding buildings, they are rife with rot.

title: Unwinnable Wars
description: Irina Ellison, a 30-year-old university lecturer, has seen her father die from Huntingtons disease, his motor skills destroyed, his memory erased. Genetic testing has told her she is likely to meet the same fate. Cleaning out her fathers study after his death, she finds a letter to a Russian chess champion named Aleksandr Bezetov in which her father asked: How do you play a game when you know it is lost from the start? Aleksandr never replied. Looking for a last adventure and moved by the alluring symmetry of finding answers to her fathers question, Irina decamps to Russia to track down the chess player and demand an answer.

title: Against Interpretation
description: In courts and law schools across America, the most intense legal battles are fought over theories of constitutional interpretation. From the originalists on the right to the living constitutionalists on the left, each of the warring camps claims that it has discovered the true faith and accuses its opponents of hypocrisy. Now comes Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III with a bracingly clear and bipartisan message: All the theories are bunk! According to Wilkinsons Cosmic Constitutional Theory, the theories have given rise to nothing less than competing schools of liberal and conservative judicial activism, schools that have little in common other than a desire to seek theoretical cover for prescribed and often partisan results. As a result of their cosmic theorizing, Wilkinson concludes, liberal and conservative judges and justices are too quick to second-guess the choices of legislatures, and the casualty is our inalienable right of self-governance.

title: Without Gods
description: During the 19th and early 20th centuries, religion lost influence, but the religious impulse lingered on. Some people sought salvation in the secular religions of politics  in Communism, fascism and various utopian experiments. Others saw artists, musicians and writers as Holy Men, who could provide transcendence and meaning, revealing timeless truths on how to live.

title: Reclaiming the Kremlin
description: A joke from Soviet times describes the minister of agriculture on a trip to Sweden, marveling at the acres of irrigated hothouses, the markets piled high with vegetables and fruits, comparing this profusion with the barren shelves of home.

title: Putins List
description: Were an announcement made by President Obama that the White House intended to draw up a list of 100 books all Americans would be made to study and then be tested on, few would mistake it for a surefire vote winner. But during this years presidential campaign season, another candidate evidently thought it was. In January, during the run-up to Russias March 4 election, the front-runner, Vladimir Putin, proposed a canon of 100 Russian books that every school leaver will be required to read at home . . . and then write an essay about one of them. Reading, according to Putin, is not just an elective individual activity, but one that has decisive implications for the nation. State policy with regard to culture must provide appropriate guidelines, he wrote in an essay in the Nezavisimaya Gazeta newspaper, and culture shapes public consciousness and . . . patterns of behavior. The Kremlins duty, Putin explained, is to counter the decline in literacy and restore Russia as a reading nation.

title: Up Front
description: Cristina Garcas fiction  from her first novel, Dreaming in Cuban, through her fifth, The Lady Matadors Hotel  is known for traversing continents, cultures and generations, and for telling the stories of families, friends and strangers thrown together and torn apart in uncertain times. This age of upheaval, dislocation and migration offers extraordinary and unprecedented opportunities for human reinvention, she said via e-mail. How does one construct and reconstruct identity in a changing world? This has remained my core obsession from my very first book.

title: Editors Choice
description: GODS WITHOUT MEN,  by Hari Kunzru (Knopf, $26.95.) Related stories, spanning centuries and continents, and all tethered to a desert rock formation, emphasize interconnectivity across time and space in Kunzrus relentlessly modern fourth novel.

title: Paperback Row
description: 1861: The Civil War Awakening,  by Adam Goodheart (Vintage, $16.) Goodhearts exhilarating account leads us through the months between Abraham Lincolns election to the presidency in 1860  followed quickly by the secession of the Confederate States  and July 4, 1861, when Lincoln delivered his first message to Congress, laying out the case for war.

title: When the Voice in Your Head Just Keeps Talking
description: ARDENT, even obsessive, fans of the novelist David Foster Wallace almost rival their idol in the torrents of words they use to detail their devotion. And if there is one constant within this torrent, its the extent to which readers see their own consciousness reflected in his novels and essays. Writing in 2008, soon after Wallace hanged himself at 46, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of Wallaces astounding voice: Hyperarticulate, plaintive, self-mocking, diffident, overbearing, needy, ironical, almost pathologically self-aware (and nearly impossible to quote in increments smaller than a thousand words)  it was something you instantly recognized even hearing it for the first time. It was  is  the voice in your own head.

title: The Possibility of an Island
description: "You want to know why I am the way I am?" Zita Cobb asked.Shes a slender woman in her early 50s, with close cropped hair that gives her a certain iron-pixie mien. She has the distinct composure one often finds in people whove done well in the business world, brisk good humor layered over a fierce intensity. She was speaking in her office in a small building on Fogo Island, a freckle of land that lies off the northeast corner of Newfoundland, Canada, with a population of 2,700 or so scattered across a series of fishing communities with names like Seldom, Joe Batts Arm and Tilting. Its a place so singular and remote that it has its own peculiar time zone, 1.5 hours ahead of Eastern Standard Time  though in truth it feels like its hundreds of years behind: when its 10 p.m. in New York, its 1825 on Fogo Island.

title: Apple and Google: Redwoods in the Web Garden
description: The consumer Internet was thought to be a verdant garden where thousands, and perhaps millions, of flowers would bloom. Much of that has come to pass, but the Web turns out to be a mighty fine place for giant redwoods as well. Apple and Google  with a combined market capitalization of about $750 billion  have become so large that they all but blot out the sun, threatening to leave offline businesses struggling in the shadows to survive.

title: Desserts to Your Door, From Baking Bean
description: Clarice Lam (right), the executive chef of The Chocolate Room, in Park Slope and Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, has introduced her own oven-to-door pastry service, with delivery throughout New York City. Called The Baking Bean (her nickname is Bean, for her runway-ready figure), it takes orders by phone and online for an array of cakes, pies, tarts, cookies, croissants, chocolate bark and other candies, none of which duplicate what Ms. Lam makes for the Chocolate Room.

title: Leading Off: Ignominy Makes N.C.A.A. Visit
description: You know the N.C.A.A. tournament is off to a wobbly start when the banner moment of the first day of its Round of 64 was a Connecticut player missing a meaningless dunk at the end of an ignominious defeat for the defending champion, followed by No. 1 seed Syracuse staving off an even more ignoble fate by the length of a misguided referees whistle. On each sideline, there were two suddenly old men raging against the universe, and their crowning achievement is Jim Boeheim can say he didnt become the coach of the first No. 1 team to be bounced by a No. 16. How inspiring.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Teens From Bully Protest R Rating, and Lessons of Kony 2012
description: Teenagers and parents who appear in the documentary Bully made a personal appeal to Christopher Dodd, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America, to change the movies rating to PG-13 from R, The Hollywood Reporter reported. The film, which was produced by Harvey Weinstein, who joined the parents, tells the story of bullying in middle school and high school. It received the R rating because of some of the language used, which is particularly unfortunate, the parents say, because it means those who most need to see the movie, wont be able to.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief Told Managers Not to Exploit Goldmans Woes
description: Greg Smith can probably scratch Morgan Stanley off his list of future employers.

title: Image of the Day: March 16
The Limits of a Duty of Trust and Confidence
description: To prove insider trading, the government must show that passing the information involved a breach of a duty of trust and confidence to maintain its confidentiality. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges  that test the limits of what can constitute that duty when it accused a broker of trading on and passing information he learned through a relationship formed at Alcoholics Anonymous.

title: Brewers Braun Draws On His Store of Support
description: Phoenix

title: In Delhi, Business Leaders Greet Budget With Grumbles
description: They came dressed mournfully in dark blazers to watch the finance minister of India deliver the federal government budget for the forthcoming financial year.

title: Reading Club | Navigating Love and Autism
description: Update: Deadline extended to April 6.

title: Crowds Gather for the Latest Version of the iPad
description: 4:02 p.m. | Updated  to add report from Seattle.12:02 p.m. | Updated to add brief report from San Francisco Apple store.

title: For Ryan Braun, the Road Awaits
description: PHOENIX  There were two roster sheets on the bulletin board in the Milwaukee Brewers clubhouse Thursday. One was the travel list for a charity game in Tucson, the other the travel list for a game in Surprise, Ariz. The players traveling were highlighted in yellow. Ryan Brauns name was not highlighted at all.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $17,070,000
description: A three-apartment penthouse combination that sold for $17.07 million in the Laureate on the Upper West Side was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: At War Shout Back: The Sergeant, the Strain of War and a Call for Your Thoughts
description: A clearer, though still quite incomplete, picture is emerging of the American staff sergeant accused in the killings of 16 Afghan villagers on Sunday in the Panjwai district of Kandahar Province.

title: The View From St. Bonaventure: Two Teams to Cheer For
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012. Pete Thamel of The Times has a story on St. Bonaventure here.

title: Drunken Fruit Flies
description: Male fruit flies that were denied the opportunity to mate turned to alcohol more often than those that were permitted to copulate, scientists find.

title: Inside the List
description: APOCALYPSE THEN: The historian Elaine Pagels has been a popular, though polarizing, figure ever since she introduced readers to early competing views of Christianity in her 1979 book The Gnostic Gospels, which won the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award. That book, her first for a mainstream audience, received a mostly dismissive review in our pages from the Rev. Raymond E. Brown, a biblical scholar and Catholic priest who concluded, in his last sentence, that the gnostics chief adversary, crusty old Irenaeus, had been right, after all, to regard the gnostics as the crazies of the second century. But Pagelss analysis of the early church struck a nerve, and not just at the time. As Laura Miller noted recently in Salon, a badly garbled version turned up in The Da Vinci Code in 2003 and proceeded to blow the minds of many readers. Coincidentally (or not), 2003 is also the year Pagels scored her first New York Times best seller, Beyond Belief: The Secret Gospel of Thomas. Her next book, a study of Judas written with the Harvard professor Karen King, also landed here, in 2007, and now Pagels is back. Her latest effort, Revelations: Visions, Prophecy, and Politics in the Book of Revelation, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 10. Reviewing the book in The New Yorker this month, Adam Gopnik highlighted Pagelss argument that Revelation is essentially an anti-Christian polemic . . . written by an expatriate follower of Jesus who wanted the movement to remain within an entirely Jewish context, as opposed to the Christianity just then being invented. Gopnik continued: The scarlet whores and mad beasts in Revelation are the Gentile followers of Paul  and so, in a neat irony, the spiritual ancestors of todays Protestant evangelicals.

title: Business Day Live | March 16, 2012
description: Indias plan to tackle public debt, and Apples new iPad goes on sale.

title: The Gay Film That Changed Your Life
description: With several new books, films and film series, gay people are trying to preserve their film history at a time when young gay audiences and mainstream Hollywood alike dont seem interested in becoming consumers or conservators of gay cinema, as this article from Arts & Leisure documents. To get a sense of which gay films are worth another look, or a first one, ArtsBeat asked several notable figures to talk about the gay film that changed their lives. Their answers, edited and excerpted below, ranged from the traditional (Boys in the Band) to the daring (Querelle) to the head-scratching (Bless the Beasts and the Children). Leave your own answers in the comments section.

title: Keepers of the Gay Film Legacy
description: IN front of the IFC Center in the West Village on a recent Monday night a largely gay crowd waited in line for a sold-out screening. It wasnt the latest gay rom-com that had packed them in but rather Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean, Robert Altmans 1982 film, based on Ed Graczyks 1976 play, about female friends who reunite at a Texas Woolworths on the 20th anniversary of James Deans death. The films gay cred is considerable: besides starring Cher  goddess to drag queens everywhere  it features Karen Black as a sympathetic transsexual character.

title: Vengeful Streak Puts Ivanovic on a Winning Streak
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  Ana Ivanovic is generally regarded as one of the nicest people in tennis. With a quick smile and an approachability perhaps betrayed by her model-like looks, Ivanovic, a former W.T.A. No. 1 and 2008 French Open champion, manages to stay polite and above the media cattiness that can ensnare other players of her caliber.

title: Parental Quandary: My Sons Girlfriend Is Bulimic
description: D.s sons girlfriend is sick, and both she and her son know it. After every meal she eats in D.s house, she throws up in the bathroom. Theres no mystery here: Ds son knows his girlfriend has a problem, and hes talked to her about it. D.s older sons girlfriend has talked to her  and even recommended a therapist. But nothing has changed. D. feels like she should do something  but what?

title: Subaru Recalls 320,000 Foresters to Replace Noncompliant Part on Rear Seat Belt
description: Subaru is recalling about 320,000 of its 2009-12 Foresters because the rear seat belt may not securely hold a child safety seat or restraint, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Washington Square South, 10:31 A.M.
Crispy Chips and Tostadas: From the Microwave?
description: The traditional tostada is made by toasting or frying a tortilla into a crispy flat chip that is covered with beans, cheese and other toppings. But in this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman comes up with a surprising solution for cooks who dont want to deep-fry their dinner but still enjoy a crispy tostada. Ms. Shulman makes the case that the microwave is the perfect place to make crispy and healthful tostadas and tortilla chips.

title: Business Day Live: The New iPad Goes on Sale
description: Indias plan to tackle public debt, and Apples new iPad goes on sale.

title: Where Divorce Can Be Denied, Orthodox Jews Look to Prenuptial Contracts
description: CHICAGO  Before a packed house of 350 men and women at a Jewish educational center, Beverly Siegel suggested three questions that religious Jewish women should ask before divorcing: Do I get a get? Do I not get a get? Hmm, what kind of get should I get?

title: Vain Glorious | Thakoon for Nars
description: In one of the seasons more colorful collaborations, the designer Thakoon Panichgul of Thakoon has made a limited-edition series of lacquers for Nars based on the brights from his spring runway. The prints in that collection were inspired by the rich color palette of India  the spices, the holy festivals, Panichgul says. According to the designer, when the Nars team, who did the beauty look for the show, first saw the color boards, we immediately realized that it made perfect sense to do a nail project together. The Thakoon for Nars polishes ($18) will be available May 1. Go to narscosmetics.com.

title: Dance in India
description: Scenes from Nrityagram, a village far from the madding crowd that is completely given over to the pursuit of dance.

title: In India, Eternal Rhythms Embody a National Spirit
description: NRITYAGRAM, India

title: Economic Indicator: Where You Eat
description: The relative sales trends of different types of restaurants provide an indication of the health of the economy. When Americans feel better about their finances, they are more likely to eat at restaurants with full service, including bringing the food to the table, rather than at restaurants with limited service. At the moment, both the restaurant sales and the falling unemployment rate indicate the economy is doing better than the Gross Domestic Product figures would seem to show.

title: Barcelona and Real Madrid on Opposite Sides of Champions League Draw
description: Barcelona will take on Milan in the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League in the highest profile of four matchups drawn Friday morning in Switzerland. The first legs of the home-and-home quarterfinals will be played March 27 and 28, with the returns on April 3 and 4.

title: In Sit-Down Restaurants, an Economic Indicator
description: Have you been eating more at restaurants with waiters rather than fast-food joints?

title: The Rookie of the Year, One Year Wiser
description: ONE year later there was no jaw-dropping upset, no demure acceptance speech, no fresh affront to Justin Biebers watchful fan cabal. This time around Esperanza Spalding caused less of a stir at the Grammy Awards, where shed prevailed as best new artist in 2011, shocking a field that included Mr. Bieber and another platinum-selling megastar, the rapper-crooner Drake.

title: Live Updates: N.C.A.A. Mens Tournament, Day 2 of Round 2
description: The second full day of the mens N.C.A.A. basketball tournament features 16 games. Zach Hillesland will bring you up to speed with live updates. For the latest scores and full schedule of games, view our live scoreboard.

title: Worries for Wizards
description: The Chinese company with the license to make Harry Potter clothing has run into a bit of a problem. Its auditor quit with a letter that makes it sound as if it suspects fraud.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Saturday is St. Patricks Day, and here are some specials at restaurants across the city  from flowing taps of beer to boiled bacon and cabbage:

title: Jury Finds Spying in Rutgers Dorm Was a Hate Crime
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  A former Rutgers University student was convicted on Friday on all 15 charges he had faced for using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with another man, a verdict poised to broaden the definition of hate crimes in an era when laws have not kept up with evolving technology.

title: Mortal Cops Cling to Life on the Air
description: A RECENT episode of the police drama Southland ended with a gang member stabbing Detective Lydia Adams in the stomach during a routine arrest. Only the audience knew she was pregnant and running late for an ob-gyn checkup.

title: Photos of The Moment | Bruce Springsteen at SXSW
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: An Outsider Who Followed His Own Path
description: SEVEN years ago, at his home in Marino, Italy, near Rome, the enormously prolific German composer Hans Werner Henze fell into a mysterious semi-coma. Weeks went by without signs of improvement. All thought the end was near, and goodbyes were said. After two months, to everyones surprise, Mr. Henze suddenly woke up, rose from his bed and calmly went back to work on his 15th opera, Phaedra.

title: The Second Act Of an Indie Success Story
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Small-Town Sentiments, Bass From the World Over
description: Carly Rae Jepsen

title: How Wall Street Has Fared After Bears Fall
description: Friday is the four-year anniversary of Bear Stearnss fire sale to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share, one of the signal moments of the financial crisis.

title: Monkey Bars Belinda Chang Resurfaces
description: Belinda Chang, who had many people in the restaurant business wondering where she went after leaving Monkey Bar about two months ago, is back on the scene. She has become the beverage director for the Culinary Concepts Hospitality Group, a company in partnership with Starwood Hotels that uses menus created by Jean-Georges Vongerichten.

title: Dear FloFab: Whats the Etiquette for the Tight-Table Squeeze?
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Mar. 19  24
description: THE Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Gardens striking but bunkerlike circular Washington building, designed by Gordon Bunshaft, has prompted many an artist and designer to dream of intervention. Next year, if things stay on track, the museum will realize a long-planned project to cover its interior courtyard with a temporary inflatable bubble, an architectural souffl that will meld the outside and inside of the museum and provide space for installations and performances. But in the nearer term the doughnut-shaped structure will become the plaything of the artist Doug Aitken, who is turning it into a movie in the round.

title: The Attack on Voting Rights
description: Ive written fairly often here about voter ID laws. Republican-controlled state legislatures frame these measures as attempts to combat voter fraud (a fictitious problem). But its an open secret that they disproportionately affect minorities, the poor and other groups who tend to support Democratic candidates, making it more difficult for them to participate in elections.

title: The View From Duke: Are the Blue Devils Underrated?
description: Is it possible the Duke Blue Devils may be underrated heading into the N.C.A.A. tournament?

title: Bell Canada Agrees to Buy Astral Media for $3.4 Billion
description: OTTAWA  Bell Canada, Canadas largest telecommunications company, extended its move into the media business on Friday by agreeing to pay 3.38 billion Canadian dollars (about $3.4 billion) for Astral Media, the owner of several prominent cable television channels including HBO Canada.

title: Author, Author!
description: In 1861, a former slave named Harriet Jacobs published her autobiography, adding her testimony to that of abler pens to convince the people of the Free States what Slavery really [was]. Quoting the book of Isaiah, she asked her audience to give ear unto her speech as she told the tale of her escape from bondage.

title: The Druids
description: An Irish band sympathetic to the I.R.A. perform at Kelly Ryan's Bar in the Bronx.

title: The Butterfly Plans a Summer Landing
description: In the Altamarea Group of restaurants (Marea, Ai Fiori and others), Eben Freeman is to cocktails and drinks what Michael White is to food. As head of bar operations and innovation, he has taken the lead in The Butterfly, a small restaurant and bar scheduled to open this summer.

title: Dynegy Defends Its Actions After Accusations of Fraudulent Transfer
description: Dynegy is striking back.

title: The View From St. Louis: Billikens, Explained
description: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Look of The Moment | La Seydoux
description: The Look: Plum Brandy. A jewel-tone top with a modest neckline and long sleeves tucks sleekly into the cinched waist of a full gypsy skirt.

title: At SXSW, Springsteen Draws an All-Star Guest List
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Bruce Springsteen, of all people, used the word Twitterverse during his South by Southwest concert at ACL-Live at the Moody Theater, a 2,700-capacity room here where the public television series Austin City Limits is staged. On Thursday morning in his SXSW keynote speech he had praised the Animals, particularly the song We Gotta Get Out of This Place  about the son of a hard-working father, looking for a better life  as the source for every song Ive ever written. (The Animals didnt write the song; its by Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil.) Mr. Springsteen then demonstrated how similar the Animals bass line in Dont Let Me Be Misunderstood was to the one in his own Badlands, accusing himself of successful theft (although he actually switched it from a minor to a major key and changed its contour.)

title: Will Lin Start? The New Coach Says Yes
description: 1:16 a.m. | Updated Jeremy Lin would be starting for the Knicks at point guard Friday night. Of that, there was no doubt, Coach Mike Woodson said before the game.

title: Fans Rush Back for the Return of Community
description: Maybe absence really does lead to fondness: The return of NBCs cult-favorite Community on Thursday night generated the shows best ratings for this season by far, and the best entertainment numbers for NBC in that time period in 14 months.

title: Clooney Among Protesters Arrested at Sudans Embassy in Washington
description: The actor George Clooney, his father, Nick Clooney, and Representative James P. Moran of Virginia were among more than a dozen protesters arrested Friday outside the Sudanese Embassy in Washington. The arrests were confirmed by a spokeswoman for the congressman and a spokesman for the Secret Service, which made the arrests.

title: Fresh Takes on the Job Market for the Unemployed
description: Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, appeared on the WNYC radio program The Takeaway on Friday to discuss listeners stories about being unemployed and trying to get back into the job market. Callers asked about moving to take a new job, supplementing income after a cut in pay and starting a small business. You can listen to the complete segment here.

title: With Visit to Goldman, Bloomberg Says, Chin Up
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thought Goldman Sachs could use a friend.

title: Green Bay Looks to Play Bigger than Seeding
description: Wisconsin-Green Bays womens basketball team is done questioning the N.C.A.A.s wisdom in seeding it seventh in the Kingston region. The Phoenix felt they merited a better seed, due to their 30-1 record and winning the Horizon Leagues regular season and tournament titles.

title: Book Review Podcast: David Oshinsky on Lawrence v. Texas
TimesCast | March 16, 2012
description: The leader of the Anglican Church announces his resignation | The author Jonathan Haidt on why America is so divided.

title: Disneys Alice Musical Is Said to Hire Rob Ashford
description: The Broadway director and choreographer Rob Ashford (How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying) has been hired for a stage musical adaptation of Tim Burtons 2010 film version of Alice in Wonderland, according to Variety. A spokesman for the producer, Disney Theatrical Productions, declined to comment on Friday, and Mr. Ashford did not return a phone call seeking comment.

title: Morgan Miller and Minh Nguyen
description: RELATIONSHIPS born of the passion and excitement of the presidential campaign trail are known to be fickle. With ballots counted and confetti swept away, only the most resilient survive the succeeding election cycles.

title: First Woman to Win Man Asian Prize Condemns North Korea, China
description: HONG KONG  Kyung-sook Shin, the first woman to win the Man Asian Literary Prize, used the black-tie gala dinner in Hong Kong on Thursday to make a statement about North Korea.

title: Photos of The Moment | Chairlift at SXSW
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Draw Something, a New Twist on Pictionary, Charms Mobile Gamers
description: Every so often, a new mobile gaming craze sweeps across smartphone screens around the world  think Angry Birds, Words With Friends, Tiny Tower.

title: Trees Up for Grabs in New York City
description: New York City will start giving away trees on Saturday, just in time for spring planting.

title: How to Be a Pioneer Woman Without Ever Leaving the Couch
description: Every night before I peel the plastic seal off a cup of tapioca and watch The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills on my big-screen TV, I read a chapter of Little House in the Big Woods to my daughters, who are 5 and 3. For the first few chapters, Pa mostly tramps around in the woods, shooting at things. First Pa shoots a deer and smokes the meat. Next he catches a bunch of fish and salts the meat. One lucky day, he wanders up on a bear thats about to eat a pig. He shoots the bear, then lugs it home, along with the bonus pig. The family celebrates!

title: Obama Calls Karzai and Reaffirms Withdrawal Date
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan early on Friday morning and reaffirmed with him that American troops will complete their withdrawal by the end of 2014, the White House said in a statement.

title: Yanks Pettitte, 39, Signs On for Comeback
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Saying he was ready to go back to work, Andy Pettitte announced Friday that he was returning to the Yankees.

title: Dennis Kozlowskis Homecoming, of Sorts
description: Nearly seven years after he reported to prison, L. Dennis Kozlowski has a view of Central Park from his home once again  only the new place is a little smaller.

title: Who Made That Lawn Mower?
description: Before a British inventor named Edwin Beard Budding conceived of the mower, the cropped lawn was the province of the landed gentry, who would employ teams of men to trim grass with scythes. But lawn care was far from Buddings mind when he invented the push mower. His original brief was to solve a mechanical problem for a clothing mill regarding the production of guardsmens uniforms. Budding was asked to come up with a way to cut all the tufts and bobbly bits off the nap of the cloth, writes Brian Radam in Lawn Mowers and Grasscutters: A Complete Guide. Budding soon realized the device had other applications. In 1830, he filed a patent for a machine that, when pushed and pulled, would cause a cylindrical blade to rotate over a stationary shear, cutting grass and collecting the clippings. The mower may have put the scythe men out of work, but it enabled the English fashion for grass carpets.

title: The 3.4.12 Issue
description: How flattering to have the worlds best newspaper dedicate an issue to our very own capital city. . . . [It is] a beautifully photographed, earnestly researched cultural brochure for Manhattanites who have bought their Olympic Games tickets and booked rooms at the Dorchester but remain anxious not to make a faux pas. . . . Most bizarre was the advice that the item that could best illustrate the notorious expense of London was the price of a box of imported Lucky Charms (a kind of sugary American cereal). Apparently, they sell for $14 in a [Primrose Hill] grocery. Believing this to be typical of the cost of eating in London could lead many an innocent American to make an expensive mistake. And this summer, therell be no shortage of unapologetic London shopkeepers, hoteliers and cabbies to help them make it.

title: Why Are They Always Apologizing?
description: Your exquisitely perceptive article on Londoners gets everything right, except what they really mean by sorry  although the writer is correct in concluding that it doesnt mean sorry. When I emigrated to New York in 1959 (from Essex, no less), I was repeatedly asked why I was always apologizing, whereupon I stopped saying sorry and asked myself the same question. Clearly, I realized, it means, Whatever you or I just did to the other and whose fault it is, lets just forget about it and move on. Not bad for one word.

title: 'Oh London, You Drama Queen'
description: This years Olympics are going to be magnificent. Only a minority of people share your snobbery toward the Games (which is evident by the number of people who tried to get tickets). The fact remains that although there will be inconveniences, the majority of Londoners cannot wait to welcome the world to their city. Because lets face it, this city and its people are pretty bloody fantastic! Down with the gloomsters!

title: Midtowns Irish Elite
description: For the last five years, Billy Redmond has been the proud owner of a million-dollar apartment in the heart of Manhattan. Ive been in it once, he said. Its lovely! We were sitting 3,000 miles away, talking property on a drizzly winter evening, over a pint at a famous Dublin pub called Doheny & Nesbitt. Redmond, a balding and gregarious insurance broker, was explaining his reasons for buying, sight unseen, a condominium unit in a project called the Centria, in a city he had visited only twice, briefly, as a tourist.

title: Minority Report
description: My daughters biological father is Hispanic; the man I married when she was a year old, and who subsequently adopted her, is white, as am I. Now shes a teenager. While filling out her school applications, I checked the box marked Hispanic. My husband felt that was dishonest, saying she is not culturally Hispanic. Furthermore, he says, she is not suffering from any disadvantages as a result of her familys background and she doesnt need any special consideration. I say we should simply offer the truth. What do you think? NAME WITHHELD

title: True Londoners Are Extinct
description: This charming, chatty article [by Craig Taylor], much like the city itself, in which one becomes immersed in a series of local scenes and remarks, seems to have aroused angst on both sides of the Atlantic. When I was a teenager 30 years ago, London was my first trip alone from home. The weather was awful, the food was awful and the 6-pound-a-night hotel was awful  and I fell instantly in love. Comparisons with New York, Paris, Dubuque, anywhere else, are odious. London is an ancient artifact, a unique collection of ever evolving cultural habits, a collection of people joined by the common interest of liking the idea of it. Even the Welsh boy Dylan Thomas saw in her the long friends, the grains beyond age, the dark veins of her mother. For the open-minded, it is alwaysa delight.

title: Building the American Dream in China
description: Daniel Gillen is afraid of heights. The young American architect didnt think to tell me this until we had already climbed up a construction ladder and started walking gingerly across the curved roof of an unfinished building in northeastern China.

title: How My Daughters Learned to Eat Like the French
description: When we first moved to France, social gatherings involving food made me anxious. Despite their French father, our daughters had thoroughly North American eating habits; Sophie, 5, and Claire, 2, often whined (a serious faux pas), reacted negatively to food being served (even worse) or refused to eat (the worst offense of all). But our familys invitation to a reunion dinner with Philippes university friends was nonnegotiable.

title: What a Buyer Wants
description: LUXURY ROOFTOP GARDENS

title: Is Tammy Baldwin Our First Gay Senator?
description: When writing about your Senate campaign in Wisconsin, the press consistently refers to you as the first out lesbian elected to Congress. Are we to assume that Congress is full of closeted lesbians?  Thats never been the way Ive construed it. I think it was written in a similar fashion when I was first running for the State Assembly back in 1992. So much attention was focused on whether the electorate was ready, whether this sort of history could be made.

title: In Havana, Family-Run Dining Goes Upscale
description: ON a mild January night, the unlighted street in the artsy Havana neighborhood of Vedado was quiet and filled with shadows. But as my companions and I climbed the steps of Le Chansonnier, the glow of chandeliers gleamed invitingly through the wrought-iron windows, and a low burble of music drifted onto the street.

title: Private Dining in Havana
description: Family-run restaurants are gaining popularity in Cubas capital city.

title: Napoleon Is Lost, Long Live Napoleon!
description: SOON after Abel Gances Napoleon had its premiere in Paris in 1927, he wrote a letter to his audience, soliciting open eyes and hearts. I have made, he wrote, a tangible effort toward a somewhat richer and more elevated form of cinema. He had created a film towering in ambition, scale, cost, narrative and technical innovations, and believed that nothing less than the future of the cinema was at stake. His audacity had merit. The origins of the widescreen image can be traced to Napoleon, which also featured hand-held camerawork, eye-blink-fast editing, gorgeous tints, densely layered superimpositions and images shot from a pendulum, a sled, a bicycle and a galloping horse.

title: Day 2 at South by Southwest
description: Scenes from the South by Southwest Music festival in Austin, Tex.

title: A Forecast for Low Returns, and Advice for Investors
description: THE stock market seems to have found its footing lately, touching levels not seen since early 2008.

title: Sleepwalking in Fantasy Worlds Like This One
description: SARA DRIVER, the subject of a series that begins at Anthology Film Archives this week, recently confessed to feeling a bit sheepish about the idea of a retrospective in her honor. Her compact body of work is composed of two features, one medium-length film and a short, and she has not directed since 1994. Instead of a retrospective Im calling it a flashback, she said with a laugh.

title: Slide Show: Scenes From Day 2 of the South by Southwest Music Festival
description: More Photographs

title: Jean Renoirs Plunge Into the American Mire
description: A RIVER runs through the work of Jean Renoir, manifesting itself in various forms  from the Seine in Boudu Saved From Drowning (1932) that delivers a force of nature disguised as a shambling bum to the doorstep of a bourgeois bookseller to the Ganges that curls through the background of The River (1951), providing an eternal context to the story of a first love.

title: F1 and Its Champions Hit the Track in Melbourne
description: MELBOURNE  Formula One cars hit the race track Friday for the first time this season in the opening practice sessions for the Australian Grand Prix on Sunday. Just about the only certainty in the results was that the record six world champions taking part in the series this year are, for their part, in top shape.

title: A Rare Setback for Maryland Lacrosse
description: The No. 6 Maryland Terrapins womens lacrosse team has surely gone through some highs and lows this past week. After a shoddy offensive performance led to a late-game loss to No. 4 Syracuse on Saturday, the Terps made a complete 180 and dominated Richmond Tuesday night in an 18-9 win.

title: Supreme Court to Release Same-Day Recordings of Health Care Arguments
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would release same-day audio recordings of the arguments over the constitutionality of the health care overhaul law. The arguments will be heard over three days starting on March 26.

title: Share a Car, Risk Your Insurance
description: At first glance, the idea of person-to-person car sharing appears to be the perfect solution to any number of problems.

title: He Was Robbed, Then Became Champion
description: Before Sergio Martinez became a most unlikely boxing world champion, he spent his formative years as the most likely robbery victim in the small Argentine barrio he called home. Thieves did not rob Martinez once, or twice. They robbed him at least 10 times.

title: Caucus Click: A Place for Romney at Breakfast
Crash and Boom
description: On a rainy Saturday night in Lisbon, A Vizinha, a rustic cafe lined with tins of sardines and sacks of rice, was packed with the citys young style set  new-media girls in baggy sweaters and floral scarves, skinny boys with fussy facial hair and engineer caps. They had come here, to Bica, a grubby hillside neighborhood, for a show: an organist, David Maranha, and jazz drummer, Gabriel Ferrandini, were churning out a chaotic and deafening soundscape. It growled and hummed, shrieked and snapped, above a single-note drone from a maxed-out little amp.

title: Help Us Choose Our Summer Movies Cover
description: Few special sections of The New York Times promise as much escapist pleasure as the annual Summer Movies issue of Arts & Leisure. As a result, the editors usually commission an illustration  illo is the in-house term of art  for the cover that tends to be playful, wistful or just plain fun. This spring, we asked students at the Savannah College of Art and Design to submit their own illustrations to be considered for the cover of this years section, which will be published the first week of May. Some 100 entries were narrowed down by faculty members, and 25 were sent to The Times. Our editors narrowed the field down to 10 finalists, and here are their submissions.

title: In New York City, Island Music Dance Clubs
description: Where to go in New York to hear island music.

title: This American Life Retracts Episode on Apples Suppliers in China
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated The weekly public radio program This American Life said on Friday that it was retracting a critical report about Apples suppliers in China because the storyteller, Mike Daisey, had embellished details in the narrative.

title: The Clubs of Curaao
description: The island has several places to watch and dance to live music.

title: Sampling Caribbean Sounds
description: The Caribbean doubles as a stunningly prolific and diverse music studio. Every island produces a home-grown soundtrack, inimitable in language, accent, tempo and rhythm. Jamaicas is the one you know best. Roots reggae in the vein of Bob Marley is still alive and well, but to truly experience contemporary Jamaican music, visit the capital, Kingston, and get to know dancehall music at one of the citys nightly street dances, like Weddy Weddy Wednesday on Burlington Avenue, at the home base of Stone Love, one of Jamaicas most famous sound systems. Or spend an evening at Club Fiction (67 Constant Spring Road; 876-631-8038; fictionloungeja.com), where youll hear some of the islands best D.J.s spin the latest dancehall.

title: Songs of Politics, Imported From Ireland
description: Live music tonight, read the little sign outside Kelly Ryans bar in the Bronx on Thursday. The Druids, direct from Ireland.

title: 14 Music Videos From the Caribbean
description: For this weeks travel section, Baz Dreisinger writes about the island of Curaao and its music scene. But the music scene can be heard all over the Caribbean. Below is a small sampling of some of the popular bands.

title: Curaao After Dark
description: ON one of many late nights in Curaao, I found myself in a musical tower of Babel. The setting: a sleek iron-and-glass nightclub, Tu Tu Tango, near Willemstad, the Caribbean islands capital. The crowd: well-heeled local men in their 30s, high-heeled ladies in skintight get-ups, Dutch women in sundresses, 20-somethings wearing gold chains and Yankees caps. The soundtrack: a mix of English, Spanish, hip-hop argot, Jamaican patois, Portuguese  or was that Papiamentu, Curaaos native Creole? Beats evoked Puerto Rico, Holland, Brazil, the Jersey Shore. Just when I felt primed to classify, the rhythm morphed and the language veered off to another continent.

title: More Island Music: New York City
description: There is one Caribbean island that does not demand a long flight: Manhattan. The number of West Indians in New York City renders it unofficially tropical even during cruel winters, which means Caribbean music pervades the citys night-life scene.

title: The View from Detroit Mercy: Father and Son Lead Resurgence
description: Throughout the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Niners Reportedly Competing for Peyton Manning
description: And you thought March Madness was limited to college basketball .

title: Local Previews of the London Games
description: MOST fans of the Olympic Games will be consigned to watch from their living room sofas or follow along on their office computers as the 2012 Summer Games in London begin this July.

title: Peer-to-Peer Car-Sharing and Big Insurance Questions
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at the many insurance questions that come up about the burgeoning peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. The basic question is this: If you turn your car into a Zipcar, in effect, what are the odds that you could end up in some sort of trouble if someone rents your car and then crashes it and hurts someone?

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Casting About for Poppies Among the Dorothys
Ivanovic vs. Bartoli: Breaking It Down
description: Ana Ivanovic walked to the baseline at 3-3, 40-15 in the first set of her quarter-final encounter with Marion Bartoli at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells and rocked a 112 m.p.h. ace down the middle to hold serve.

title: Billy Campbell, of AMCs The Killing, Enjoys Sailing Tall Ships
description: BILLY CAMPBELL, a leading man in AMCs newest drama, The Killing (its second season starts April 1), didnt have much sailing experience before 2000 when he signed up to be part of the crew of the Sorlandet, a 186-foot Norwegian square-rig sailing ship built in 1927.

title: Another Comment About Your Comments on Comments
description: I wrote the other day about our comments policy and warned readers that moderators look out for obscenity, irrelevance, spamming, trolling, Hitlering and just plain uncalled-for personal meanness. Our community manager wrote a follow-up post answering some of your questions. And that, of course, led to even more questions.

title: Despite Bold Talk on Syria, Turkey Sees Limits of Its Power
description: ISTANBUL  As the lethal crackdown by the Syrian government intensifies, Turkey has been struggling in the face of a spiraling crisis on its doorstep that is exposing the limits of its leadership in the region.

title: 5 Spots for 7 Pitchers, One Named Pettitte
description: The news that the left-handed pitcher Andy Pettitte is coming out of retirement to attempt a comeback with the Yankees gave the teams preseason a jolt of electricity.

title: Cody Simpson Gets His Toys R Us Moment
description: Its been a busy week for Cody Simpson. The tween dream from Australia released a new single, So Listen, a collaboration with the hip-hop star T-Pain, and is in the studio wrapping up his first album. And he announced plans to join Big Time Rush on its summer tour. Next on the 15-year-old Simpsons ascension to pop idol: the cover of a Toys R Us catalog.

title: Golden Ticket
The Computers Next Conquest: Crosswords
description: Whats a 10-letter word for smarty pants?

title: Indias Blast Inquiry Tests Ties to Israel and Iran
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian warrants issued this week for three Iranian citizens in connection with an attack last month in which assailants on a motorcycle attached a magnetic bomb to the back of an Israeli diplomatic vehicle here, coupled with new accusations about the bombing, seem certain to worsen the deepening crisis between Israel and Iran.

title: Syrian Volunteers Pick Up Land Mines Planted by Their Army
description: Human Rights Watch called on Syrian government forces to stop planting land mines along the countrys borders with Turkey and Lebanon this week, citing the danger posed to refugees fleeing the violent crackdown on dissent in the country.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Teenage Dreams
description: On the hardcover list this week is Superior (at No. 8), written by Mark Millar and illustrated by Leinil Yu. The story is about a nerd with multiple sclerosis named Simon Pooni who finds himself with the powers of a fictional hero named Superior. The special abilities, however, come at a price.

title: Four Artists, in Their Own Words
description: These four artists have moved farther afield  beyond the Brooklyn quartet of Williamsburg, Greenpoint, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick  to find compatible and affordable neighborhoods.

title: Follow the Drips of Paint
description: THE race to anoint the latest neighborhood for New Yorkers eager to pursue careers in the arts is never-ending.

title: To Be a Hotel and Gay in New York
description: ON a recent Saturday night at the new XL nightclub on West 42nd Street, revelers danced with abandon on a sunken floor while the D.J. Manny Lehman spun a percussive house mix, lights flashed, go-go boys undulated on raised platforms and bartenders busily mixed cocktails. Im really not the party-all-night type, but I stayed pretty late, given that my bed was a short walk away through a couple of glass doors that lead to a Manhattan hotel lobby.

title: Six Gay Hotels Where the Welcome Mats Have Always Been Out
description: Chelsea Mews Guesthouse344 West 15th Street (212) 255-9174 chelseamewsguesthouse.com

title: Rutgers Official Says Verdict Will Not Affect Admissions
description: A Rutgers University official said he did not expect a jurys decision to convict Dharun Ravi of hate crimes will negatively affect admissions at the New Jersey school.

title: Longhorns Rally Falls Short
description: NASHVILLE  Entering Texas game against Cincinnati Friday, the Longhorns Rick Barnes found himself in an unusual role for a coach who has been to 17 consecutive N.C.A.A. tournaments.

title: Dim Corner of SoMa Brightens
