description: NEAR the corner of Mission and Seventh Streets in San Francisco on a recent Sunday, a woman and her 30-something son sidestepped two scruffy men passed out against the side of a building. This is where the restaurant is? she asked skeptically, turning to her son, who was taking her to brunch at the recently opened AQ  (1085 Mission; 415-341-9000; aq-sf.com).

title: Hotel Review: Surf & Sand Resort in Laguna Beach, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: In Racist Chant at N.C.A.A. Game, Echoes of European Hooligans
description: A racist chant by some members of the University of Southern Mississippis band during an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament game sparked outrage and an immediate, regretful response from university officials.

title: Wolfpack Prove They Belong
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio After North Carolina State narrowly sneaked into the N.C.A.A. tournament, Coach Mark Gottfried gathered his players and urged them not to be happy with just being a part of the bracket. The theme of the meeting was simply to stay hungry.

title: A Time of Green Matzo Balls and Yiddish Theater
description: Come with us back in time to the Jewish Rialto. Were on Second Avenue and 12th Street, outside Maurice Schwartzs fabled Yiddish Art Theater, on our way to the Rumanian-Jewish restaurant Moskowitz & Lupowitz, managed by Louis Anzelowitz. And the telephone exchange is Gramowitz, the old joke goes.

title: For Romney and Santorum, a Battle of Chicago Versus Illinois
description: It is tempting to think of Illinois as being displaced on the political map  a Northeastern state trapped in the body of a Midwestern one.

title: Styled to a T | Krochet Kids
description: The People

title: Asked & Answered | Krochet Kids
description: Real men dont eat quiche, but it seems that they do crochet. Thats the lesson learned in talking to the men behind Krochet Kids International, a nonprofit that teaches women in impoverished nations how to crochet, exports their goods and then gives back the proceeds from the sales. The three founders  Kohl Crecelius, Stewart Ramsey and Travis Hartanov  recently took part in a conference call to chat about how the group came together. What follows is an edited version of that conversation.

title: Homegrown Fashion in Central Berlin
description: In Berlin, Mitte may have gone mainstream, but its alleys still become the fashion strasse of the moment.

title: Having Twins With a Surrogate  in India
description: After weeks in the heat at a fertility clinic in northeastern India, I received the most profound and life-altering gift one could possibly imagine: two beautiful daughters from our surrogate, Vaina, courtesy of the medical magic of Dr. Naina Patel.

title: G.O.P. Freshmen Not as Defiant as Reputation Suggests
description: WASHINGTON  House freshmen have been caricatured as the face of Republican intransigence in Congress, portrayed as a diverse and cacophonous mob standing in the way of Republican leaders and legislative compromise.

title: Putin Needs Higher Oil Prices to Pay for Campaign Promises
description: MOSCOW  In American presidential politics, high oil prices are a problem. For Vladimir V. Putins new presidential term in Russia, they will be a necessity  crucial to fulfilling his campaign promises to lift government spending by billions of dollars a year.

title: TimesCast | Head of Church Resigns
description: March 16, 2012 - The leader of the Anglican Church announces his resignation.

title: Expert Answers on E.M.D.R.
description: July 30 12:45 p.m. | Updated Dr. Shapiro responds to additional reader questions about E.M.D.R. and fibromyalgia, memories of child abuse, the costs and length of treatment, controversies surrounding the treatment, whether its effective for sexual perpetrators, and more. See her responses below.

title: Moving Uptown to the Intersection of Avalon and LaCrosse
description: ORANGE, Calif.

title: Another Step Forward for Hyundai
description: The redesigned Azera makes the most of its second chance, fully justifying its reintroduction to the big sedan class.

title: Bin Laden Plot Against Obama Outlined in Documents
description: WASHINGTON  A terrorist whom Osama bin Laden wanted to assassinate President Obama was himself killed in a drone strike last year, shortly after evidence of the plot showed up in documents seized by the SEAL team that killed Bin Laden in Pakistan.

title: Investing With a Long-Term View
description: The stock market has been doing better lately. Some economic gauges are indicating growing strength in the American economy. So why are some financial advisers to wealthy families telling their clients to prepare for a sustained period of low investment returns?

title: As Black as We Wish to Be
description: Paris

title: Send Us Your Questions for the S.B.A.
description: It has been a challenging time for the Small Business Administration  though, in truth, its almost always a challenging time for the S.B.A.

title: After Albany All-Nighter, Lawmakers Say: No More
description: ALBANY  Three lawmakers have a plea for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature: No more all-nighters.

title: Creighton Overcomes Low-Scoring Effort
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Creighton brought gaudy offensive numbers and boy wonder appeal to the N.C.A.A. tournament with Doug McDermott, the sophomore all-American who came in averaging 23.2 points per game. But Alabama and its equally intimidating defense still forced the game it wanted: A tight, low-scoring grind that was almost enough to knock off the No. 8 Bluejays.

title: Arkansas Freshman Takes Heat on Tax Proposal
description: When Representative Rick Crawford this week broke with his Republican Party and proposed a millionaires surtax, it was hailed in some circles as a crack in the ice that could turn into a significant breach.

title: Jeff, Home and the Duplass Brothers
description: In Jeff, Who Lives at Home, the main character, Jeff (Jason Segel), finds beauty in the mundane. When writing and directing their films, the brothers Jay and Mark Duplass say they often approach their characters the same way Jeff approaches the world: with an eye open to possibilities. Jeff, Who Lives at Home is their fourth feature in theaters. They answered questions about it during an interview at the Toronto International Film Festival last fall.

title: The Derby for Mr. Euro, and Lots of Other Top Jobs, Is Just Getting Started
description: BRUSSELS  Having failed to secure the presidency of the European Central Bank last year, Germany may get a chance to name the next Mr. Euro.

title: Record Prices at Amelia Auctions
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.

title: For GMC, 100 Years of Hard Labor
description: TO many people shopping for new vehicles, there is little to differentiate the trucks sold by Chevrolet and GMC beyond the logos on the grilles. But to collectors, GMC holds claim to a hard-working personality distinctly its own.

title: Whats In a Nameplate?
description: GMC, which is celebrating its 100th year, holds claim to a hard-working personality distinctly its own.

title: Ts Spring Travel Issue
description: The spring travel issue of T kicks off in China, where the model Liu Wen leads a tour through her home province of Hunan, charting remarkable changes in her native land (and in herself). The personal journeys continue with Daphne Merkins meditation on the allure of Haworth, England, home to the Bront sisters; Gideon Lewis-Krauss pilgrimage to Ukraine with his gay dad and 50,000 Hasids; Ethan Hausers trip to California in search of the Bakersfield sound; and Lynn Yaegers spree through a mammoth Belgian flea market. Elsewhere, Jim Lewis reports from Newfoundland on an ambitious plan to save tiny, gorgeous Fogo Island, and Kevin Gray finds that in the midst of crisis, Lisbons creative scene is flourishing. Along the way, we touch down in Mumbais hottest neighborhood, check out the biggest New York hotel opening of the year and serve up a smart and stylish guide to the most bike-friendly cities around the globe. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Links Pursued in Killings of 3 French Army Parachutists
description: PARIS  Investigators in southwestern France searched Friday for a suspected serial killer after two shootings over the past week left three parachutists in the French Army dead and another critically wounded. The motive for the attacks was unknown, as the antiterrorism police and specialists in serial murders were called to assist in the investigation, officials said.

title: Childhood: 940 Saturdays, and Youre Done
description: Nine hundred and forty Saturdays: I didnt do that math, Dr. Harley Rotbart, author of No Regrets Parenting, did. Between the day your child is born, and the time he or she turns 18, you get 940 Saturdays  and 260 of them, Dr. Rotbart just reminded me, are gone by her fifth birthday.

title: Did History Play a Role in DAntonis Departure?
description: While many have brushed off Mike DAntonis departure as the Knicks coach as a product of his stubbornness, for the real answer to why DAntoni resigned, we would be wise to look at his past.

title: Buried Beneath Jewels, an Aromatic Treasure
description: UNLESS your pantry happens to resemble a Middle Eastern or South Asian market, you will probably need to do a little shopping to make this traditional Persian rice dish with the lovely name, javaher polow, or jeweled rice. But it is well worth it, and most good supermarkets can supply what you require.

title: Battery S.U.V. Conversions From Amp Qualify for $7,500 Federal Rebate
description: Amp Electric Vehicles, the Cincinnati-based start-up, converts the Jeep Grand Cherokee to run purely on battery power. The conversion process is not cheap, with the Amp Cherokee, featuring a 40-kilowatt-hour battery pack and a manufacturer-estimated range of more than 100 miles, listing for just under $60,000 in 4-wheel-drive form.

title: A Rebate for Low-Flush Toilets
description: Low-flush toilets may soon grow more appealing under a Bloomberg administration plan to get New Yorkers to conserve more water.

title: Perfect for Roast Chicken (and Impact): Javaher Polow, or Persian Jeweled Rice
description: I was going to roast a chicken for dinner guests the other night, and wondered what to serve with it. Javaher Polow, or Persian Jeweled Rice, came to mind. It is a dish I absolutely adore, studded with dried fruits, fragrant with saffron and spices and showered with almonds and pistachios. It never fails to impress and is so delicious I would eat it even without the chicken.

title: As Cars Are Kept Longer, 200,000 Is New 100,000
description: HOW far can a modern car really go? Given the increasing age of vehicles on American roads, we may be on the verge of finding out.

title: Editors Letter
description: A few months ago, Stephen Heyman, who oversees our coverage of books, gave me a copy of Gideon Lewis-Krauss A Sense of Direction (forthcoming from Riverhead Books) and urged me to read it. Its an account, by a young essayist, of undertaking various pilgrimages; and it culminates with his account of a trip to Uman, Ukraine, for the High Holidays with his brother and father  a gay ex-rabbi who came out at age 46, much to the confusion of his grown sons. A small excerpt of that story appears in the pages that follow, and I hope you will find it as charming and disarming as we do. On the one hand, its like a literary version of Mike Millss Beginners, almost entirely populated by Hasids; on the other, its a wonderful exploration of the stories we tell ourselves to justify and impart narrative weight to our curiosities and compulsions.

title: Design Break: Airline Safety Cards
description: As a graphic designer, I pay particular attention to the designs I come across in daily life. A beautiful menu design may influence my approach for a feature on a restaurant, or a clever billboard advertisement may inspire me to play with a new integration of text and imagery.

title: St. Patricks to Undergo a Three-Year, $177 Million Renovation
description: Take one good, long last look at St. Patricks Cathedral, a defining landmark of New York City. It is about to disappear for two or three years under a cocoon of scaffolding, inside and out, that will permit a $177 million rehabilitation project to unfold, the most extensive work at the cathedral in generations.

title: Chinas Hunger for Ivory is Killing Cameroons Elephants
description: HONG KONG  The killing began in early January and has continued for months.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Belgium, West Bank and Yemen.

title: TimesCast | Is America Divided?
description: The author Jonathan Haidt talks with The Timess Sam Tanenhaus on why America is so divided.

title: Gators Find Their Strength Under the Boards
description: OMAHA  Last March, Virginia forward Mike Scott and guard Jontel Evans made a pact that neither would cut his hair until the Cavaliers qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament. So when Virginia took the court Friday against Florida for its first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance since 2007, both had abandoned cornrows and poof-out looks for closer-cropped cuts, with Evanss mother handling the scissors.

title: Early Signs of Spring at Amelia Island
description: The Amelia Island concours, the premier East Coast event for connoisseurs of high-end automobiles, set a sales record this year.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: Greg Smith introduced Muppets into the Goldman Sachs lexicon, a casino lawsuit was revived in Macau, Yahoo sued Facebook, and the S.E.C. won a legal victory against Judge Jed S. Rakoff. A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: In Hong Kong Elections, Some Chinese See Enviable Openness
description: HONG KONG  The three candidates to become the next chief executive of Hong Kong engaged in a vituperative, televised debate on Friday evening in an election campaign that is being closely followed in mainland China.

title: In a Month Full of Riches, A Globally Seasoned Feast
description: Some nights a critics job feels impossibly good and divinely difficult: how even to begin to get at, through words, the quicksilver, complex art youve just experienced? What to say to readers, other than Please stop reading and purchase a ticket for this show?

title: Composers Versus Tyrants in a Festivals Conclusion
description: The New York Philharmonic and its audience have been chest-deep in Beethoven this month, thanks to the orchestras Modern Beethoven festival, conducted by David Zinman.

title: When You See Your Opponents Err, Its Time to Cash In
description: MEMPHIS  The opening event at the Spring North American Championships here was the Baldwin North American Open Pairs. Played on Wednesday and Thursday, it was won by two Canadians from Ontario, Jordan Cohen and Barry Senensky. They finished less than a board ahead of a married team, Rozanne and Bill Pollack of Basking Ridge, N.J. Third were Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif., and Steven Love of Laguna Niguel, Calif.

title: No Longer Lonely, a Birthday Boy Plays at His Party
description: When asked on Thursday night at Symphony Space if he had any advice for younger composers, David Del Tredici said, Follow your bliss, follow your inspiration.

title: Chic in Review | Winners, Losers and Nominees
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Jets Sign Stanton and Schilens
description: After three days of relative inactivity on the free-agent front, the Jets signed a No. 2 quarterback and bolstered their receiving corps Friday.

title: Reviewing the Hyundai Azera
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Hyundai Azera, which sits between the Sonata and Genesis in the ascendant Korean automakers sedan firmament.

title: Republicans Reportedly to Propose Trimming Discretionary Spending
description: Republicans on the House Budget Committee are settling on a new cap for discretionary spending in the coming fiscal year, dipping slightly below the spending limit set in July after hard-fought negotiations over raising the nations statutory borrowing limit.

title: Caucus Click: Obama Hovers Over Chicago
Kony 2012 Director Is Detained and Hospitalized
description: Updated | 11:17 p.m. Jason Russell, who directed and starred in the Kony 2012 video that has been viewed more than 100 million times this month, was detained by the San Diego Police Department on Thursday, accused of masturbating in public and vandalizing cars, NBC San Diego reports. He was later hospitalized after an evaluation.

title: From Far Away, Teams Come Together
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The geographic diversity represented on the rosters of Murray State and Iowa State roster is one of the more interesting storylines here.

title: Culinary Comforts by Way of Poland
description: SHORTLY after moving to New Jersey, with its rich Italian-American culture, I began wishing I had been born with that genetic understanding of parmesan, guanciale, truffles and olives. Now, after a couple of visits to Rozmaryn, in Trenton, Im feeling the same way about Polish ingredients like cabbage, pork, beets and potatoes.

title: In Puerto Rico, Romney Weighs In on Statehood
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Mitt Romney arrived here Friday afternoon and marveled at what he described as an aggressive and energetic  enthusiastic audience, who chanted his name and applauded as he took a makeshift stage at a private aviation terminal.

title: Friday Night Music: More Sarah Jarosz
description: Substance tomorrow, maybe; right now Im tired, Im decompressing from a couple of very hard weeks, and I want some simple pleasure. So here it is:

title: Fighting Absurdity With Absurdity
description: In his famous satirical essay A Modest Proposal, Jonathan Swift suggested that impoverished Irish citizens should sell their children as food for the rich. A young healthy child well nursed, is, at a year old, a most delicious nourishing and wholesome food, he wrote, countering heartlessness attitudes towards the poor with absurdity.

title: A Long Soak Brings Out Dried Corns Earthy Flavor
description: IVE long adored hominy, the earthy dried corn kernels you find in pozole, the chile-laced Mexican stew. But until recently, I had never actually made it from scratch. Laziness is to blame. The canned hominy can be gummy, but it is so convenient, and so much easier to find in my neighborhood than the dried kernels, that I always end up taking that shortcut.

title: Bonnies Forget to Shoot a 3 at the Most Crucial Time
description: NASHVILLE  St. Bonaventure last won an N.C.A.A. tournament game in 1970, and even that victory came with a caveat. Bob Lanier injured his knee, keeping him from playing in the Final Four and costing the Bonnies a possible shot at John Woodens mighty U.C.L.A. Bruins.

title: Going Beyond Standard Diner Fare
description: FROM the outside, the restaurant Relish resembles the string of diners that occupied this building in Kings Park for more than 50 years. The inside, though, reflects the renovations carried out by Donny Brown, one of the two owners, before Relish opened in September, and the decoration by his wife, Christy. The spare but appealing dining rooms have apple-green booths and banquettes, cream-colored wainscotted walls, attractive framed mirrors and wall sconces filled with fresh flowers.

title: Generation Y Stands Up for Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Greens in Spring
description: Winter greens are tastiest in springtime. Melissa Clark demonstrates how to trim and slice kale and collard greens.

title: North Korea in Contrast
description: The few Western photographers allowed to visit North Korea in the last two decades have returned with remarkably similar images. The highly secretive Communist government allowed them to photograph little else but the extravagant pageants honoring their supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, or the immaculate subways in Pyongyang.

title: Hoyas Advance Behind Their Size and Shooting
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Since appearing in the Final Four in 2007, Georgetown has been synonymous with N.C.A.A. tournament futility. But the Hoyas 74-59 win over Belmont on Friday represented a first step toward changing that.

title: Arguing Over a Lesson in Security From 9/11
description: At a hearing Wednesday on the Police Departments security plans for the new World Trade Center site, the head of the areas community board broached a topic she called the elephant in the room: the location of a permanent command center for the so-called World Trade Center campus.

title: Regulating Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Please Wont You Be My Inspiration?
description: FOR decades he showed up in his trademark cardigan and sneakers. He sang to us and smiled. And in the measured cadence of his familiar voice he spread the unconditional love: Youve made this day a special day, by just your being you. Theres no person in the whole world like you, and I like you, just the way you are.

title: Thwarting Church Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: Untouchable Pensions May Be Tested in California
description: When the city manager of troubled Stockton, Calif., had to tell city council members why it was on track to become the biggest American city yet to go bankrupt, it took hours to get through the list.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 16
description: Subjects include auditions for the Libertys dance troupe, a subway mural that appealed to a thief and a luxury condo with a prison next door.

title: For Murray State Player, Game Begins on Top
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Murray State wore bright yellow sneakers in its N.C.A.A. tournament victory over Colorado State on Thursday, matching the trim on its uniforms. The shoes were the second-most noticeable aspect about the Racers.

title: Better Than Chicken
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Primary Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian That Throws a Few Curveballs
description: A TINY shopping strip on a quiet stretch of Quaker Ridge Road is an unlikely spot for a terrific Italian restaurant, but that is where you will find Da Giorgio. And it may well be that the restaurants patrons wish it were even more inconspicuous. The place is small  the long, narrow dining room seats only 45  and regulars know they need a reservation, especially on weekends.

title: How to Trim Collard Greens and Kale
description: This weeks recipe, a pozole-inspired pork stew, calls for collard greens, but if youd like to substitute kale, go right ahead. The video above will even show you how to trim both. Then be sure to give the greens a good rinse in a colander before adding them to the pot.

title: N.Y.U.s Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Prepares for Kansas States Size
description: PITTSBURGH  In the aftermath of Syracuses surprisingly tight victory over North Carolina-Asheville on Thursday, Coach Jim Boeheim said more than once that Fab Melos absence had nothing to do with the Oranges inconsistent play. When top-seeded Syracuse faces No. 8 Kansas State in the Round of 32 on Saturday, however, the center position  and the hole left by Melo, who was declared ineligible Tuesday  figures to be more significant.

title: London Is Eating New York's Lunch
description: Why is London so attractive to wealthy traders? One of the reasons is the relative lack of enforcement against criminal activity. New York authorities have prosecuted 66 people for insider trading, with 57 convictions or guilty pleas since 2009. By contrast, the Financial Services Authority in the U.K. has secured very few criminal convictions: the first major one being in 2009, when Christopher McQuoid, former general counsel at TTP Communications, went to jail for telling his father-in-law to buy shares when he heard that Motorola was planning to take over the company.

title: The Gambling Epoch
description: You know how history books help you keep track of things with their pithy period labels? The Roaring 20s. The Industrial Revolution. The Pleistocene Epoch. The Ages of Reason, Enlightenment, Gilded, Stone, Bronze and Dark.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Inside the New iPad, and Satellite Surveillance
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: Sound and Fury, Set in the 20th Century
description: Even the bleakest of Shakespeares tragedies, like Macbeth, are punctuated by an occasional moment of comic relief. Verdi wanted to avoid making his Macbeth too pretty, and broke with bel canto convention when writing the music for the opera. But the dark-hued score is sometimes incongruously lightened by his trademark cheery oom-pah-pah orchestral accompaniments, which (in his early works in particular) often results in an odd pairing of serious lyrics and upbeat music.

title: No Magic for Vermont as North Carolina Romps
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  North Carolina has a glorious history in the N.C.A.A. tournament, complete with five national championship banners. Vermont has had its moment, too  in 2005, when the Catamounts arrived as 13th seeds and knocked off No. 4 Syracuse, one of those magical upsets that only a tournament like this can produce.

title: Fed Revises Its Numbers on Stress Test for Citigroup
description: The Federal Reserve made an error in its stress test of Citigroup that led it to overstate a crucial measurement of losses on the banks mortgages, the central bank acknowledged on Friday.

title: Romantic Rendezvous for Spring
description: WITH spring on the horizon and a bit of romance in the still-nippy air, a tte--tte at a charming French restaurant can be a perfect bridge between winter and the warm-weather pleasures of dining en plein air. Here are three favorite spots, offering good food, attentive, intelligent service and inviting atmospheres that encourage, if not romance, a cozy kind of joie de vivre.

title: The Power Couple
description: Cynthia Rowley and Bill Powers are seen and photographed everywhere and they really dont care if you think theyre overexposed, overcommitted, over-stimulated, caffeinated or otherwise.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,894 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Young Nation Acquires a Taste for Splendor
description: Just because rebels were dumping tea into Boston Harbor doesnt mean they didnt want nice teapots. And furniture. And coats of arms.

title: Everywhere at Once
description: THE runway presentation at the futuristic IAC Building on the West Side Highway had gone off without a hitch. The boldface guests had come backstage and said their congratulations  Rebecca Romijn, Lauren Bush, Kelly Rutherford and Allison Sarofim among them. The news media had done interviews, and the staff was headed to Acme, the new NoHo hot spot.

title: Norfolk State Shocks No. 2-Seeded Missouri
description: OMAHA  As a first-time participant in the N.C.A.A. tournament  the Division I version, anyway  Norfolk State is understandably unfamiliar with certain traditions. Center Kyle OQuinn, for instance, briefly forgot that he was supposed to shake hands with his Missouri counterpart at midcourt during pregame introductions before backtracking to do it.

title: Week in Pictures for March 16
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include auditions for the New York Libertys dance troupe, a subway mural that appealed to a thief, and a luxury condo with a prison next door.

title: Its About Immigrants, Not Irishness
description: Brooklin, Me.

title: Bill Cunningham | On Point
description: Its as true as ever: American fashion is dominated by comfort. The first definitive fashion trend of spring is the flat ballet slipper.

title: N.C.A.A. Mens Tournament Photo Replay: March 16
description: Tournament action included No. 15 Norfolk State upsetting No. 2 Missouri and Florida State outlasting St. Bonaventure.

title: The New iPad Screen, Under a Microscope
description: When most people get their new iPad today, they probably wont do what Lukas Mathis, a science and software engineer from Switzerland, did with his new tablet.

title: Its Not Easy to Catch a Glimpse of This Apartment Burglar
description: Nathan Fenton popped the question 10 years ago, and she said yes, and they got married, left New York for a while, returned and found an apartment in Washington Heights, where he arrived one afternoon last week and stuck his key in the door. It did not budge.

title: U.S. Identifies Army Sergeant in Killing of 16 in Afghanistan
description: The military on Friday identified the soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers earlier this week as Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, a 38-year-old father of two who had been injured twice in combat over the course of four deployments and had, his lawyer said, an exemplary military record.

title: How Charter Schools Can Hurt
description: MY daughter is a kindergarten pupil at P.S. 261 in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. She started there in September, and she loves everything about it: her friends, her teachers and her school-related activities, like Girl Scouts. Intense excitement accompanied both the post office project earlier this year and the Halloween Day Characters Parade, in which her class dressed up as the Three Little Pigs.

title: Must. Sleep. Now.
description: COILED viper-like within the word insomnia is the terrifying omnia. Why does sleeplessness seem all-powerful? Because some nights I cant get down into the Valley regardless of how many Dolls I lash to my burro.

title: Guptas Lawyer Says Goldman Executive Was Source of Insider Tips
description: Federal prosecutors have recordings of a Goldman Sachs executive leaking confidential information about technology stocks to Raj Rajaratnam, the former hedge fund billionaire convicted of insider trading, a lawyer disclosed Friday during a court hearing.

title: West Coast Works Come to the East End
description: Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A., 1945-1980, an aggregation of dozens of exhibitions at museums and galleries that got under way in Southern California last fall, celebrates the emergence of Los Angeles as a contemporary art center after World War II. On the East Coast, meanwhile, a much more modest show, drawn from the collection of a single art patron, pays homage to the same phenomenon. That show, EST-3: Southern California in New York: Los Angeles Art From the Beth Rudin DeWoody Collection, is at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.

title: Art Between the Cracks
description: BUT is it art?

title: My Roommate, Gloria
description: IF young feminists believed in fairy tales, then moving to New York City and winding up with Gloria Steinem as your roommate would definitely count as one.

title: City Removes John Dewey High School Principal
Magics Howard Clouds Future for Nets and Williams
description: Orlando, Fla.

title: On the Ice and Under It, Nature Thrives
description: Expectations are high when David Attenborough and the BBC Natural History Unit get together. Beginning with Life on Earth in 1979, they have set the standard for plush nature shows studded with arresting moments, and their latest, the seven-episode Frozen Planet (beginning on Sunday on Discovery), has its share of spine-tinglers.

title: California Concerts, Awash in Cellists
description: LOS ANGELES  On its face, the Los Angeles Philharmonics subscription concert at Walt Disney Concert Hall on Thursday evening might have seemed routine. The program, conducted by Neeme Jarvi, followed an old formula  overture, concerto, symphony  and the repertory was familiar: Dvoraks Carnival Overture and his Cello Concerto, with Ralph Kirshbaum as soloist, followed by Shostakovichs Fifth Symphony.

title: Gloria Steinem, a Woman Like No Other
description: IN 1970, when the Senate was first debating passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, a featured speaker was Gloria Steinem, a 36-year-old magazine writer with a growing reputation as a forceful advocate of womens issues.

title: Editor Not Ready to Write an Ending
description: Robert Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, received a lifetime achievement award from the National Book Critics Circle last week, and next month he will get another, from The Paris Review. Neither award is likely to stop the kind of speculation that invariably takes place whenever too many New York intellectuals remain too long in one room: Mr. Silvers cant stay on forever, presumably, so who is going to succeed him?

title: Ups and Downs of Hip-Hop Pioneers
description: MICHAEL WRIGHT, better known to the world as Wonder Mike, the old-school M. C. on the 1979 Sugarhill Gang hit Rappers Delight, is a precision guy, he said in a recent phone interview.

title: Rosie ODonnell Talk Show Is Canceled by OWN
description: Rosie ODonnells 7 p.m. talk show on OWN, Oprah Winfreys struggling cable network, is being canceled after just five months.

title: Artists Find Benefactors in Web Crowd
description: In the last year alone, money troubles have pushed the New Mexico Symphony to close, New York City Opera to slash its budget by two-thirds and the State of Kansas to eliminate all public financing for the arts.

title: Modern Movement With an Ancient Monster
description: Although Martha Graham started out opposed to ballet, in her later years she invited a few ballet stars to perform with her company. These were mainly men  Rudolf Nureyev, Mikhail Baryshnikov  and in Graham, the men are often just props. Margot Fonteyn made an appearance, and after Grahams death, so did Natalia Makarova, but they did not attempt signature Graham roles.

title: No Surprise: Meat Is Bad for You
description: I did not intend to broadcast an anti-meat mini-series this week, but there are so many angles to this argument that sometimes one gets carried away.

title: Marquette Looks Up, but Wont Slow Down
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Football was canceled at Marquette on Dec. 9, 1960. Yet there is a team on campus that looks as if it could move the chains 10 yards, take down a running back or trample a quarterback.

title: Kansas State Sets Up Melting Pot on the Plains
description: PITTSBURGH  Kansas States Angel Rodriguez heard the chants. It was impossible for him not to hear them, standing at the foul line late in the first half Thursday and trying to make his free throws as some members of the Southern Mississippi band chanted, Wheres your green card? in his direction.

title: Immigration Detainees Get a Better Prison
description: Federal officials this week unveiled a new immigration detention center in rural Karnes County, Tex., the first designed and built to reflect the Obama administrations effort to stop treating all detainees like criminals. The center is brightly painted and looks more like a school than a prison, with dormitory-style rooms, a gym, library, medical office and soccer field. Detainees can move around freely, exercise, watch TV and use computers. They can also attend their hearings in rooms hooked up for video conferencing with judges in Houston and San Antonio.

title: Surprise at Indias Polls Reveals a New Kind of Leader
description: NEW DELHI

title: The High Price of a Baseball Winning Streak
description: It could have been 1955 again. At the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, it was the opening night of a new production of Damn Yankees, and the orchestra began the overture. Those familiar songs  Heart (miles and miles and miles of heart), Whatever Lola Wants, Goodbye, Old Girl  were instant reminders of why this Faustian baseball musical won seven Tony Awards 56 years ago. This is a first-rate, frequently thrilling revival, even if it does have one disappointing flaw. But that comes later.

title: Ackerman Had to Safeguard Pride Before Retiring, Colleagues Say
description: On Thursday afternoon, Representative Gary L. Ackerman was visited at his home by Rory I. Lancman, a state lawmaker and political rival. Mr. Lancman, who was mulling a run against Mr. Ackerman, dropped by to say that he had had a change of heart and would not run after all.

title: Randall Terry Loses His Delegate to the Democratic Convention
description: The Oklahoma Democratic Party has ruled that Randall Terry, the anti-abortion leader who captured 18 percent of the vote in the states Democratic primary on March 6, is not entitled to a delegate to the National Democratic Convention.

title: Gov. Cuomo Succumbs
description: By agreeing to a deeply flawed deal with state lawmakers, Gov. Andrew Cuomo gave in to Albanys secretive and undemocratic ways of doing business.

title: Teacher Accusing Officer of Rape Says She Feared Being Killed
description: The teacher who prosecutors say was raped at gunpoint by a drunken off-duty police officer last August wept on Friday as she testified that she had feared her attacker would kill her even if she followed his commands to remain silent and keep her eyes closed.

title: In Missouri, the G.O.P. Fight for Delegates Enters Round 2 (Post-Beauty Contest)
description: BRUNSWICK, Mo.  Mitt Romney and his advisers pride themselves on vigorously pursuing every delegate in every corner of the country in their quest to secure the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Road to Ruin
description: More and more as the years dissolve, every time I get behind the wheel I think how remarkable it is that anyone who drives, or rides  or in New York City, walks  is alive.

title: 49ers Join the Teams Contending for Manning
description: It only seems as if Peyton Manning has been looking for a new job for much longer than a week, with the helicopters and private jets and endless footage of him as he gets into another car.

title: From Bondage, Art
description: The first museum exhibition devoted to Winfred Remberts work offers a harrowing account of a mans odyssey through the Jim Crow South.

title: A Republican Talks Sense on Taxes
description: Just when House Republicans are about to provoke a new budget war, one of their own members has broken ranks and proposed a tax increase on the rich. Representative Rick Crawford, a freshman Republican from Arkansas, says the only serious way to begin cutting the deficit is to combine new tax revenue with spending cuts. On Thursday, he introduced a bill calling for a 5 percent surtax on incomes exceeding $1 million.

title: Odyssey Through Jim Crow Era, Carved in Leather
description: Most histories of the segregated South and the civil rights movement have taken the form of books, films or music. Winfred Remberts is carved in leather. You could call it folk art, since he wasnt trained in any art school  he learned the craft in prison  and like many folk narratives, it is couched firmly in the details of simple, everyday life. But the work on view at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, which has distinct echoes of Jacob Lawrence, Elizabeth Catlett, Romare Bearden and Mexican revolutionary art, also offers a harrowing account of one mans odyssey through the Jim Crow South.

title: This Trickster Season
description: The clock jumped ahead to spring on March 11. The calendar will jump ahead to spring in the early morning on Tuesday. And spring itself? Here in the Northeast, it has been wandering around, premature and a little lost, all winter long.

title: Woodss Distractions Detailed by His Ex-Coach
description: It may say just about everything you need to know about being part of Tiger Woodss inner circle that Hank Haney, his swing coach from 2004 to 2010, became paralyzed with fear over asking Woods for a popsicle.

title: Justice Department Investigation Is Sought in Florida Teenagers Shooting Death
description: MIAMI  Nearly three weeks after an unarmed teenager was killed in a small city north of Orlando, stirring an outcry, a few indisputable facts remain: the teenager, who was black, was carrying nothing but a bag of Skittles, some money and a can of iced tea when he was shot. The neighborhood crime watch volunteer who got out of his car and shot him is white and Hispanic. He has not been arrested and is claiming self-defense.

title: When Businesses Cant Stop Asking, How Am I Doing?
description: A commercial transaction, in its simplest form, involves a customer paying for goods or services. But these days, that is just the first step.

title: Ron Pauls Campaign Raised $3.3 Million in February
description: Is the Ron Paul money train slowing down?

title: Politicians Swinging Stethoscopes
description: Lets take a look at sex and state legislatures.

title: Price of Gas Matters to Voters, but Doesnt Seem to Sway Votes
description: WASHINGTON  Stacy Hawks is angry that the rising price of gasoline is squeezing the profits of her fathers produce company and draining the wallets of friends who drive trucks. She is angry that the government has not acted to reverse the trend.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 16, 2012

title: Oysters, Vinyl and an Expert Sound System
description: Let there be spring. Let there be oysters and music and people in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, who dont make us all feel old.

title: He Helped Split a Jackpot, but His Share Is Still Zero
description: Perfeito Esteves was the fill-in guy on a paving crew laying asphalt on Interstate 80, a few miles from the Delaware Water Gap. It was his first day on the job, and a couple of the other men on the crew asked if he wanted to join their betting pool and chip in $2 for lottery tickets.

title: The Curious Case of Trayvon Martin
description: He said that Tray was gone.

title: On-the-Spot Details About Stores Near You
description: APP CityMaps

title: V.C.U. Wins Games and Defies Stereotypes
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Virginia Commonwealth seems to fit neatly into a familiar N.C.A.A. tournament narrative, that of plucky underdog or midmajor misfit. The Rams belong to the Colonial Athletic Association and became a darling of last seasons tournament. Their latest win, over Wichita State on Thursday, solidified that image.

title: The Good, Bad and Ugly of Capitalism
description: On Wednesday, Howard Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of Starbucks, will take the podium at his companys annual meeting and talk about the importance of morality in business.

title: St. Louis Gets Memphis to Play Its Game
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  From the age disparity between their coaches to their opposite styles of play, St. Louiss 61-54 victory over Memphis in the West Region on Friday night was a study of contrasts.

title: Corrections: March 17
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Ohio (Just Ohio) Ousts No. 4 Michigan
description: NASHVILLE  The Michigan football coach Brady Hoke dismissively refers to rival Ohio State as Ohio, a mocking nickname thats a quirk of one of the countrys fiercest rivalries.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Acting, Dining, Roasting

title: G.O.P. Leaders Attack Democratic Senator, but Leave Candidate Selection to the Primary
description: ROCHESTER  As New York Republicans gathered on Friday to begin choosing a candidate for the United States Senate, they directed sharp attacks at the Democratic incumbent, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, accusing her of blindly following President Obama and having an unremarkable record after three years in office.

title: U.S. Clarifies Policy on Birth Control for Religious Groups
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration took another step on Friday to enforce a federal mandate for health insurance coverage of contraceptives, announcing how the new requirement would apply to the many Roman Catholic hospitals, universities and social service agencies that insure themselves.

title: Pushing the Envelope
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ill admit it: I have a totally innocent, completely professional, cruciverbal crush on David Quarfoot. There, I said it.

title: In Belarus, a Plea for Mercy That May Be Too Late to Help
description: MOSCOW  Any moment now, in a basement or courtyard somewhere in Belarus, two young men are to be put to death. They were arrested, tried and convicted for carrying out a deadly bombing last year at a subway station in Minsk, the Belarussian capital.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A renewed interest in food on airlines and a highly public resignation by a Goldman Sachs executive director were among the weeks top stories.

title: Rutgers Case Jurors Call Digital Evidence Crucial
description: Dharun Ravi was not accused of causing the death of Tyler Clementi, his Rutgers University roommate who jumped off a bridge after Mr. Ravi used a webcam to spy on him kissing a man in their dorm and then talked about it on Twitter.

title: Santana Throws 65 Pitches, Giving Up 5 Runs
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana was scheduled to throw 60 pitches Friday against the Detroit Tigers as part of his recovery from shoulder surgery. He ended up throwing 65 pitches over two and two-thirds innings, getting roughed up in the process by the Tigers. He gave up five hits and five runs, four of them earned.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: How to Make a Tournament Float
description: SPECIAL POST  If you ever need help pulling off a heist, Helene Hovanec is the woman to call. To pull off a heist successfully, so Ive heard, you need a combination of smarts, cunning, bravery and stealth, and Ms. Hovanec, who has been responsible for coordinating the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament for Will Shortz since 1993, has all of these qualities in abundance.

title: Jogging Shoes and Magic Tricks
description: Sunday, when many find respite from the burdens of the workweek, is a different kind of escape for Thomas Solomon, who makes his living breaking out of handcuffs and leg restraints. Mr. Solomon, 47, an escape artist and magician who lives in SoHo, may not always stick to his strict regimen of rehearsals on the weekend, but he does try to keep fit by jogging and by reading up on the voluminous literature of magic. He is scheduled to be handcuffed on Sunday by New York police officers and make an escape from a cold, outdoor water tank at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.

title: Police Detain Maker of Uganda Video
description: SAN DIEGO  A co-founder of Invisible Children, the nonprofit organization whose video Kony 2012 has become an Internet sensation, was detained by the San Diego police on Thursday, after they said he was found in the street in his underwear, screaming and interfering with traffic.

title: Health Law Hearings: Justices Plan Daily Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would release same-day audio recordings of the arguments over the constitutionality of the health care overhaul law. The arguments will be heard over three days starting on March 26.

title: In Dance, Crazy Is Good
description: WERE at war here, Denise Vale declared to the eight elite modern dancers rehearsing on the stage, make that battlefield, of the darkened Joyce Theater on Thursday.

title: Fast and Fearless Lehigh Stuns Duke
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Lehigh took an eight-game winning streak into the N.C.A.A. tournament and did not seem to notice that its opponent in the South Region on Friday was a few levels higher than its Patriot League competition.

title: Knicks Win Second Straight Under Interim Coach
description: Strip away the weeks tumult, the stunning change on the bench and the consternation that followed, and you would swear that the Knicks were still riding high on the fumes of their February magic.

title: At the PTA, Clashes Over Cupcakes and Culture
description: THE Cupcake Wars came to Public School 295 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, in October.

title: Purdue Hangs On Against St. Marys
description: OMAHA  Robbie Hummel wasnt dazzling in his first N.C.A.A. tournament action in three years, and Purdue squandered a 13-point second-half lead. But Terone Johnson and Lewis Jackson made sure Hummel and the Boilermakers earned a chance to play one more game.

title: Sentiment Aside, a Move Has Its Risks
description: The Yankees understand the folly of sentimental decisions. When they need to be bloodless, they can. Ask Bernie Williams and Jorge Posada, who gathered their championship rings and went home when the Yankees decided they were no longer useful.

title: Chris Hackett and the Madagascar Institute
description: A builder and an art collective known for fabricating flamethrowers, jet-powered carnival rides and other devices built for mayem.

title: Building a Better Apocalypse
description: ON Chris Hacketts personal periodic table, the worlds most interesting, and abundant, substance is an element he calls obtainium. Things classified as obtainium might include the discarded teapot that he once turned into a propane burner, or the broken beer bottle he used to make a razor, or the 9-millimeter shell casings he acquired some time ago, melted in a backyard foundry (also made of obtainium) and cast into brass knuckles for a girlfriend.

title: Colorado Win Boosts Pac-12, Too
description: ALBUQUERQUE  There were plenty of reasons for the Pacific-12 to add Colorado when it expanded to a dozen teams last year: expansion of conference territory, entry to another top-20 Nielsen television market and the addition of a football program that won a national championship in 1990 and was a perennial top-25 team until a recent decline.

title: Lessons on Vice, Liberties and the Law
description: Last weekend in Missouri, Rick Santorum, proclaiming his commitment to those places not on the coasts, took an opportunity to denigrate New York City, reviving a conservative meme that casts urbanism as the sinful twin of a mythic and decent real America. Anyone seeking further evidence of the candidates Victorian orientation could find it in this particular strain of cultural partisanship, which imagines cities not as they now are but as they once were, long ago  squalid places ripe for moral renewal.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Rick Santorum, Then and Now
description: Rick Santorums failed 2006 re-election bid to the Senate helped shape the conservative positions that characterize his presidential campaign today.

title: Venezuela: Chvez Returns Home
description: President Hugo Chvez returned home from Cuba on Friday, three weeks after flying to Havana to have a cancerous lesion removed from his pelvic region. His arrival was broadcast live on national television as he walked off the plane and was met by cabinet ministers and an escort of white-clad cadets holding gleaming swords. I have promised I am going to live, and we will live and continue victorious, he said in a speech from the tarmac. Mr. Chvez, 57, was diagnosed with cancer last year and twice had surgery in Cuba. Last month he said tests had found a lesion in the same spot as last years cancer, requiring another operation. He will now undergo radiation therapy. Mr. Chvez has never said exactly what kind of cancer he has. He is running for re-election in October and the return of his illness casts a shadow over the campaign.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Hong Kong: Woman Jailed for Role in Helping Pregnant Mainlanders
description: A 41-year-old woman from mainland China was sentenced on Friday to nine weeks in prison for having taken a job with a mainland health care company that involved arranging for at least two other mainland Chinese women to travel to Hong Kong to give birth. While she pleaded guilty and was sentenced for working in Hong Kong without obtaining approval from the immigration authorities, the high-profile prosecution was part of an effort by the Hong Kong government to stanch a surge in mainland Chinese women traveling to Hong Kong to give birth in the semiautonomous territory.

title: The 2006 Ad Wars
description: The 2006 campaign for Rick Santorums Pennsylvania Senate seat featured a flood of advertisements. Watch a selection of the negative ads run by each candidates campaign.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Passionate Persona Forged in a Brutal Defeat
description: Rick Santorums prospects for re-election to the Senate were not rosy when friends and advisers urged him in 2005 not to risk making things worse.

title: Vatican: Leaks Set Off Inquiry
description: Pope Benedict XVI has appointed an investigative panel to determine how high-level documents claiming corruption and mismanagement at the Holy See were leaked to the Italian news media, according to an article published by the Vatican newspaper, LOsservatore Romano. The Vatican secretariat of state, which oversees the administration of the Holy See, will also initiate a thorough investigation of all Vatican departments, and an internal tribunal will conduct a criminal investigation. Vatican observers say that the scandal has unsettled the church hierarchy, giving rise to rumors of internal discord.

title: Romney Is Endorsed by Chicago Tribune
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill.  The Chicago Tribune endorsed Mitt Romney on Friday, four days before a primary that is seen as crucial firewall for Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Point Guard Is Leading St. Johns Somewhere
description: Nadirah McKenith is the starting point guard for the St. Johns womens basketball team because she has to be labeled something. Although only 5 feet 7 inches, she cruises into the lane to block shots, seize rebounds or take charges, often adjusting her headband as she heads upcourt.

title: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills 14
description: A Turkish helicopter crashed into a house in Kabul on Friday, killing at least 12 Turkish service members and 2 civilians. The deaths were the single largest loss of life for Turkey in Afghanistan. NATO said that it was investigating the cause of the crash, but that there was no insurgent activity in the area when the helicopter went down.

title: Eritrea: Raid Called a Diversion
description: The government said Friday that the recent Ethiopian attack inside Eritrea was provocative but that Eritrea will not be entrapped by such deceitful ploys, signaling a possible easing of tensions. Ethiopia announced Thursday that it had sent forces inside neighboring Eritrea to attack rebel bases, which raised worries that the two countries might go to war again. From 1998 to 2000, Eritrea and Ethiopia fought over a disputed border town, killing more than 50,000 people. Relations have been poisonous since then, with Ethiopia accusing Eritrea of harboring militants who have killed tourists inside Ethiopia. On Friday, Eritreas Foreign Ministry said that Ethiopia staged the recent attack to divert attention from the border issue and Ethiopias myriad internal problems.

title: Caucuses Buzz in Utah as Hatch Rallies Allies
description: PLEASANT GROVE, Utah  Becoming a delegate to the Utah Republican Convention does not usually confer automatic access to the corridors of power, each delegate being just one of 4,000 seated when the gavel bangs down next month to open the event.

title: Dishing Dirt on Woods and His Rivals
description: One subject readers are probably eager to read about in Hank Haneys new book about his time as Tiger Woodss swing coach is Woodss relationships with other golfers.

title: Form Holds for Michigan State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The prelude to Michigan States 89-67 victory over Long Island University on Friday involved a team from the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference that was playing some 750 miles away in an arena in Omaha.

title: An Irish Tradition With an Only-in-America Star
description: GREENVILLE, Ohio  For those feeling down about the United States and its place in the world, meet Drew Lovejoy, a 17-year-old from rural Ohio. His background could not be more American. His father is black and Baptist from Georgia and his mother is white and Jewish from Iowa. But his fame is international after winning the all-Ireland dancing championship in Dublin for a third straight year.

title: Simin Daneshvar, Eminent Iranian Author, Dies at 90
description: Simin Daneshvar, who was the most potent surviving symbol of the vibrancy of 20th-century literature in Iran, died on March 8 in Tehran. She was 90.

title: Jerome Albert, Who Helped Bring Space Age to Coney Island, Dies at 74
description: Jerome Albert, who with his father, Dewey, created and operated Astroland, the space age-themed amusement park that breathed new life into the Coney Island Boardwalk in the 1960s, a time when it was losing its lure, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: A Call to Fire Prosecutors in Botched Stevens Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska called on Friday for the summary dismissal of two federal prosecutors who came under particular criticism in a report about the botched ethics trial of Senator Ted Stevens, while lawyers for the two complained that their clients had been smeared.

title: Tibetans Protest in Northwest China
description: BEIJING  Thousands of Tibetans took to the streets of a city in Chinas northwest Qinghai Province on Saturday after the death of a farmer who set himself on fire at a Buddhist religious site, according to Tibetan exile groups. It was the second large protest in Qinghai this week.

title: Cuts Threaten Access to College Placement Tests
description: Because of a federal budget cut, thousands of low-income students across the nation may not be able to afford the fees for their Advanced Placement exams this spring  exams that could save them thousands of dollars in college tuition.

title: Xavier Regains Early Season Form to Beat Notre Dame
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Xavier spent the better part of a season trying to rediscover the team that was once ranked as high as No. 8 before tumbling out of the national consciousness back in December.

title: Obama Parries Criticism as Fund-Raising Eats Into His Schedule
description: ATLANTA  Friday marked another stage in President Obamas springtime metamorphosis into full-fledged campaigner: his first daylong trip out of the capital devoted solely to fund-raising. He gripped and grinned through five campaign events in Chicago and Atlanta, where the actor and producer Tyler Perry played host to Mr. Obama at his house and television studio.

title: South Florida Muscles Past Temple
description: NASHVILLE  Inelegant would be the most polite way to describe the way that South Florida plays basketball. The Bulls are a burly group wed to the weight room, artless on offense and unrelenting on defense.

title: Kansas Coasts Past Detroit
description: OMAHA  Doug Anderson of Detroit delivered one of his highlight-reel dunks midway through the first half, a flying reverse on a fast break that left Kansas Coach Bill Self shaking his head and the Titans with a 2-point lead.

title: Mexico Official Resigns
description: Mario Vzquez Raa, an Olympic official from Mexico, resigned Thursday from various high-ranking positions, citing an internal political battle over his succession. Vzquez Raa, 79, stepped down as president of the Association of National Olympic Committees, a post he had held for more than 30 years. He also surrendered his spot on the International Olympic Committees executive board and his presidency of the Olympic Solidarity Commission, which gives grants to national organizations to help athletes from smaller countries.

title: Higher Taxes and Slower Spending Proposed in the Budget
description: Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee said Friday that the country would raise taxes and slow growth in spending in an effort to reduce its swelling budget deficit, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times.

title: Blast Inquiry Tests Ties to Israel and Iran
description: The warrants issued by Indian authorities this week for three Iranian citizens in connection with an attack last month in which assailants attached a magnetic bomb to an Israeli diplomatic vehicle here, coupled with new accusations about the bombing, seem certain to worsen the deepening crisis between Israel and Iran, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times.

title: Surprise at Indias Polls Reveals a New Kind of Leader
description: Akhilesh Singh Yadav came through New Delhi this week for a victory lap of sorts, more than a week after he upended Indian politics, Jim Yardley writes in the Saturday Profile of The New York Times, about Indias youngest chief minister.

title: The Weekend Word: Liability to Asset
description: Todays Times:

title: F1 Qualifier: The World Turned Upside Down Down Under
description: MELBOURNE  Formula One qualifying today proved that we are set for a completely different season from the last two. Sebastian Vettel and his Red Bull team do not look set to dominate again, as Lewis Hamilton took the 20th pole position of his career in a McLaren Mercedes, while his teammate, Jenson Button, finished second. In third was the surprise Romain Grosjean of the Lotus team, who has returned to Formula One after a couple of years away and a false start in his first effort in 2009.

title: Two Blasts Strike Near Security Agencies in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two large explosions, believed to be car bombs, struck the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Saturday morning, hitting intelligence and security buildings in busy sections of the city and killing or wounding dozens of civilians and security personnel, Syrian state news media reported.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Noori, the first cloned Pashmina goat in the world, was born last week in the Kashmir valley. A team of six scientists and three researchers from the Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agriculture Science and Technology pioneered the breakthrough (The Indian Express).

title: Scouting the Draft: U.S.C.s Nick Perry
description: I have analyzed four edge rushers in this years draft class:Whitney Mercilusof Illinois,Courtney Upshawof Alabama,Melvin Ingramof South Carolina andQuinton Coplesof North Carolina. Consensus rankings have Coples as the drafts top rusher, followed by Upshaw/Ingram (interchangeable), then Mercilus.

title: Harbaugh, Manning, Alex Smith and Circle of Quarterback Life
description: In the Bay Area, Jim Harbaughs relationship with Alex Smith was the focus of much of the coverage of the 49ers renewed interest in Peyton Manning.

title: Soldier Assassinations Mystery in France
description: LONDON  French police this weekend were investigating the motive behind the killing of three soldiers in two separate shootings in southwestern France, including a potential link with the militarys role in the Afghan war.

title: Last Nazi Death Camp Guard to Be Tried Dies Free
description: LONDON  John Demjanjuk, a convicted Nazi death camp guard, died on Saturday in a home for the elderly in southern Germany at the age of 91.

title: Belarussian Is Executed Over Attack on Subway
description: MOSCOW  A man sentenced to death in connection with the bombing of a subway station in Belarus has been executed, the mans family said Saturday.

title: A Camp Where Extreme Is the Name of the Game
description: For children these days, summer camp isnt just about making smores and tubing down creeks.

title: After Camps, New Horizons
description: Pete Pin spent five months last year photographing a small Cambodian community that has settled in the Bronx. The quiet photographs  of a woman cutting green beans on the floor, of a man walking in winters first snow  are part of a long-term project documenting Cambodian refugees in the United States.

title: Two Walks Through Paris in Spring
description: Paris is known as a great city for walks, and on Sunday, that may be truer than usual.

title: The New Cardinal Takes On an Old Cathedral
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan likes to tell a story about a cleric at Christ Church in Manhattan  Episcopal, Presbyterian, Methodist; hes not entirely certain  complaining good-naturedly about the enormous influence of St. Patricks Cathedral. It seems that a prospective donor, arriving at Pennsylvania Station, instructed a cabdriver to take him to Christ Church.

title: Budget Madness
description: I think I need a shower. Talking Points sends us to a badly written article in The Hill about the CBOs latest budget estimates. If you read the article very, very carefully, you might be able to figure out that the CBO only shows Obama increasing deficits relative to a very unrealistic baseline, which among other things assumes that all the Bush tax cuts expire; relative to CBOs alternative scenario, which represents a continuation of current policy, Obama actually cuts deficits substantially. But a casual read  and the headline  would leave you with the impression of Obama the wild spender.

title: Photos of The Moment | Blood Orange at SXSW
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: End of Luck and Racings Future
description: As has happened many times, a dead horse has set back the hopes of thoroughbred racing of ever again becoming a major sport.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: The Puzzlers Descend on the Marriott
description: SPECIAL POST  Saturday morning is a special time at the A.C.P.T.

title: Outdoor Skating, Winters Joy in Canada, Feels Effects of Changing Climate
description: OTTAWA  Outdoor ice skating rinks are the hubs of many Canadian communities, the basis of national legends (particularly the backyard rink where Wayne Gretzky learned to play hockey) and the source of some of its best-loved stories (The Hockey Sweater by Roch Carrier). Now a study by climate scientists suggests that they may be doomed.

title: Jack White Shows Hes Still Into Blues-Rock
description: From the looks of it, Jack White was turning country. The guitarist and singer who has led the White Stripes, the Raconteurs and the Dead Weather appeared at the Stage on Sixth with a band that included a pedal steel guitar, bass fiddle, mandolin and violin along with keyboards and drums.

title: When Colleges Dedicate Courts, Squabbles Often Follow
description: When teams took the floor Thursday for the Round of 64 of the N.C.A.A. tournaments South Region in Louisville, Ky., they were in KFC Yum Center, but they were playing on Denny Crum Court. The East Region teams competed in the Pit in Albuquerque but played on Bob King Court.

title: Rutgers Verdict Repudiates Notion of Youth as Defense
description: He was just a jerky kid.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Variety: A Really Tough (for Me) Cryptic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Its not you, its me. Im obviously not ready for cryptics outside of the Cox & Rathvon realm, because this one Nothnagled me into oblivion.

title: Number of Women Coaching in College Hockey Dwindling
description: MINNEAPOLIS  For five years, Laura Slominski approached her job as a college womens hockey assistant coach with the same passion that had made her an all-conference forward and captain at the University of Minnesota. It seemed a natural extension of her wish to teach and mentor young women.

title: Gulf Widens Between U.S. and a More Volatile Karzai
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Americans in Afghanistan are demons.

title: After Surprising Loss, Duke Faces an Uncertain Future
description: Following Dukes shocking upset loss to Lehigh in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, just one thing is clear: the Blue Devils were not dynamic enough to live up to expectations in 2012. What follows now for Duke fans and players is a summer of uncertainty.

title: Flyers Goalie Ilya Bryzgalov Finds His Groove
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Just 35 seconds after giving up his first goal in nine days, Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Ilya Bryzgalov was scored on Thursday. He slammed his stick on the ice. He did not appear to be thinking about the record he had set.

title: The Future Is Another Country
description: Simon Wren-Lewis has another very good blog post, this time on the very weak case for demanding fiscal austerity right now, even if you believe fiscal consolidation is needed in the long run. I want to tie this together with Brad DeLongs preview of DeLong-Summers on fiscal policy in a liquidity trap.

title: Closing the Book on an October Epic
description: The Texas relief corps collapsed in an extra-inning loss to the Cardinals in the 2011 World Series. Now the Rangers want to put it in the past. Read Tyler Kepners full story here.

title: John Demjanjuk, 91, Dogged by Charges of Atrocities as Nazi Camp Guard, Dies
description: The stranger settled in Cleveland after World War II with his wife and little girl. He became an autoworker and changed his first name from Ivan to John. He had two more children, became a naturalized American, lived quietly and retired. His war and the terrors of concentration camps were all but forgotten.

title: Prized Recruit Happy Back Home in Delaware
description: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.  Late one night in February 2009, the Delaware womens basketball coach, Tina Martin, received a startling text message from Elena Delle Donne, one of the sports most hyped prospects in years.

title: Same As They Ever Were
description: Rick Perlstein takes on the perception that conservatives have gotten crazier, and argues that they havent  they were always like this. Its an excellent read, and you should go read it.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: Meet Dr. Fill
description: SPECIAL POST  Most people who come to the A.C.P.T. show up with a good supply of pencils, some lucky talismans and perhaps a sweater to stay warm in the chilly ballroom. Dr. Fill, a special guest of the tournament this year, showed up with just a briefcase.

title: A Monument to a Sioux Warrior, Its Completion Date Somewhat Unclear
description: CRAZY HORSE, S.D.  It was to be the largest sculpture in the world: a granite portrait of a Sioux leader on horseback whittled out of a mountain in the Black Hills here. In scale and complexity, the carving would dwarf the imposing collection of presidential profiles on nearby Mount Rushmore.

title: Spy Chief and Torturer for Qaddafi Is Captured
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Abdullah el-Senussi, the former intelligence chief and brother-in-law of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was arrested Saturday at an airport in Mauritania, the authorities there said, in the most significant capture of a former official of the Qaddafi government since the apprehension of the dictators son Seif al-Islam by Libyan fighters in November.

title: Twelve More Partners Leave Dewey Law Firm
description: Twelve partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf resigned late Friday, the latest in a wave of departures for the beleaguered law firm.

title: Closing the Book on an October Epic, the Rangers Bullpen Moves On
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  Lisa Nathan did not sleep well last Oct. 27. Her husband, Joe, was beside her in bed at their home in Knoxville, Tenn., watching Game 6 of the World Series on television. As the fortunes of the Texas Rangers and the St. Louis Cardinals cratered and spiked, Joe Nathan could not help waking up Lisa, over and over, with bursts of spontaneous excitement: Oh, my God! This is crazy! Wow!

title: How Not to Attract Tourists
description: As Americans, we like to imagine our country as we think of ourselves: open-hearted and welcoming; efficient and practical; easygoing, above all, Mark Vanhoenacker writes in The New York Times. These values are the foundation of our culture, of an open economy fueled by ideas and immigration, and of our soft power  Americas ability to change the world simply because it is admired.

title: Bands, Bands, Bands
description: Three of Fridays keepers:

title: Zeroing In on Mystery of an Old Site Called Hades
description: WASHINGTON  For decades, affluent families have flocked to Spring Valley, a quiet neighborhood hugging the northwestern boundary of the nations capital. True to its name, magnolias are blooming and daffodils carpet the yards.

title: 30 Seconds With Robert Griffin III
description: Robert Griffin IIIs career statistics at Baylor were impressive: 10,366 passing yards, 78 touchdowns and only 17 interceptions. He also rushed for 2,254 yards and 33 touchdowns. But there is one number in particular that has raised his profile. Griffin, the 2011 Heisman Trophy winner, ran the 40-yard dash in 4.41 seconds last month at the scouting combine.

title: Regulatory Staff Endorses Gas Pipeline for New York City and New Jersey
description: A proposed natural gas pipeline that has faced opposition from groups in both New York and New Jersey has won the endorsement of the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has final approval over the $850 million project.

title: Defiant St. Louis Church Wins Archdiocese Suit
description: ST. LOUIS  A decadelong dispute between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Louis and a local Polish parish has taken a big step forward with a state judges ruling that the parish has rightful control of its assets and property.

title: Ellison Puts His Money Where His Forehand Is
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  The most powerful man in the stadium sits in the front row, behind the north baseline, wearing a baseball cap and fist-pumping for his favorite players.

title: Baseball Balance Found in Tsunami Aftermath
description: TOKYO  Asking the driver to slow down, Arizona Diamondbacks reliever Takashi Saito gazed out the car window trying to remember where his grandparents house was. It was not that he forgot; everything in the vicinity had been reduced to rubble that was strewn on either side of a now desolate road that seemingly stretched to nowhere.

title: Unhappy With the Owners, Many Fans Root for a Mets Loss in Court
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Even before their trial starts Monday, the owners of the Mets, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, have been found guilty by one jury of their peers: Mets fans.

title: Photo Hack Day winners visit The New York Times
description: The three first-, second- and third-place winners of the February 26 Photo Hack Day visited The New York Times to demo the projects and talk about whats next for them and their work.

title: Keeping Score: Tournaments Stars Dim After March
description: March brings the word bracket to the national lexicon and turns previously little-known college basketball players into stars.

title: Cant Acknowledge Failure? Dont Apply
description: This interview with  Tracey Matura, general manager for the Smart car unit of Mercedes-Benz USA, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Shopping Fast Doesnt Necessarily Mean Shopping Well
description: The first week of N.F.L. free agency is often described as a feeding frenzy, but that metaphor does not really fit. Schools of mackerel do not swim away from tiger sharks with $42.5 million contracts.

title: Conscious of Safety, but Condoning Fights
description: Canadiens General Manager Pierre Gauthier made perhaps the most intriguing statement during last weeks meetings with his N.H.L. counterparts.

title: In Yemen, New Leader Faces Threats in the South
description: ADEN, Yemen  For all the challenges that Yemens new president faces, none may be more imperative than the unsettled state of the south, where many are eager for secession and a security breach has allowed an Al Qaeda affiliate to grow strong.

title: Combative Pitino Critiques Officials
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Louisville Coach Rick Pitino believes the level of criticism of the officiating in this N.C.A.A. tournament is unwarranted. Except, that is, when he is the one criticizing.

title: Barriers to Change, From Wall St. and Geneva
description: EVEN now, after all weve been through, something is still wrong with Wall Street.

title: Out of N.B.A., Working for U.S.A.
description: When Mike Krzyzewski takes a seat on the United States bench to lead a team full of N.B.A. players atthe London Olympics this summer, he could well be joined by two unemployed assistants but no coaches with N.B.A. jobs.

title: Getting to 1,144
description: Mitt Romney needs about half of the remaining delegates to secure the Republican nomination before the convention in August.

title: The Danish Doctor of Dread
description: The way we negotiate anxiety plays no small part in shaping our lives and character. And yet, historically speaking, the lovers of wisdom, the philosophers, have all but repressed thinking about that amorphous feeling that haunts many of us hour by hour, and day by day. The 19th-century philosopher-theologian Soren Kierkegaard stands as a striking exception to this rule. It was because of this virtuoso of the inner life that other members of the Socrates guild, such as Heidegger and Sartre, could begin to philosophize about angst.

title: With Pettitte in Mix, Rotation Is Rattled
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Now that the exclamation point has settled in  Andy Pettitte is back!  here come the question marks.

title: Our Workplace: How Three Companies Innovate
description: The reshaping of the modern workplace also involves new approaches to innovation. Here, executives at Google, General Electric and DreamWorks Animation summarize their companies paths to creativity.

title: All Odds Aside, G.O.P. Girding for Floor Fight
description: CHICAGO  For the first time in a generation, Republicans are preparing for the possibility that their presidential nomination could be decided at their national convention rather than on the campaign trail, a prospect that would upend one of the rituals of modern politics.

title: Back to Missouri, in Search of a Second Victory
description: HAZELWOOD, Mo.  Rick Santorum dashed from caucus to caucus in affluent neighborhoods of suburban St. Louis on Saturday morning, frantically wooing voters in an effort to secure a dominating victory in the Missouri caucuses. The goal was to keep alive momentum from this weeks victories in Alabama and Mississippi as he goes in to Tuesdays hard-fought primary in Illinois.

title: Romneys Make a Push Through Puerto Rico
description: BAYAMN, Puerto Rico  Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, came to Puerto Rico for a short trip, and left, in the words of Mrs. Romney, knowing how to par-tay.

title: Spring Training With a Flash
description: Adoring baseball fans waiting for their heroes. Sock drills by minor league pitchers. Pre-workout rookie skits. And 8-year-olds shagging fly balls hit over the fence during batting practice.

title: Second Effort by Jardine Leads Top-Seeded Syracuse to the Round of 16
description: PITTSBURGH  Syracuse has endured all measure of scandal and strife over the past few months. After its latest problem  the ineligibility of center Fab Melo  the Orange became a popular upset pick among bracket analysts.
