Without Melo, the thinking went, Syracuse would have an abyss in the heart of its vaunted zone defense that would be impossible to overcome.

title: Letters: Trying to Catch Runaway Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: King of the Sky
description: Ron Akana, 83, may be the longest-serving flight attendant in the United States.

title: 63 Years Flying, From Glamour to Days of Gray
description: DENVER  As the crush of passengers boarded United Flight 618 to Hawaii here last month, they passed by a silver-haired flight attendant in bifocals who greeted them with an Aloha, welcome aboard.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: Puzzle 1 Update
description: SPECIAL POST  With Puzzle 5 about to start, the stats for Puzzle 1 are starting to roll in.

title: Sergeants Wife Kept a Blog on the Travails of Army Life
description: She detailed her pregnancy, with her husband a world away. She described the knot she got in her stomach from missing him. She wrote of her disappointment after he was passed over for a promotion.

title: Portrait of Army Sergeant Accused of Killing Afghans Emerges From Wifes Blog and Public Records
description: After an extraordinary six-day blackout of public information, a complex portrait of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales is emerging from public records and his wifes blog posts a day after he was identified as the solider accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers.

title: Suspects Multiple Tours Call Attention to War Strain
description: WASHINGTON  Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier accused of killing 16 civilians in Afghanistan last week, was deployed four times to Iraq and Afghanistan over a decade, a record of combat that at the very least suggests high levels of stress. He was particularly upset about being sent to Afghanistan, his wife wrote last year on her blog, and the family had hoped to be stationed in Germany, Italy or Hawaii instead.

title: Sims Is Hoyas Playmaker in the Post
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Henry Sims spent his summer working with the former Georgetown big men Roy Hibbert and Jeff Green to try to perfect his role in the Hoyas offense. The off-season work made the 6-foot-10 Sims the most recent Georgetown center to serve as the linchpin of the Hoyas Princeton offense.

title: Pettitte Drawn Back Into a Brotherhood
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: In New Office Designs, Room to Roam and to Think
description: SEATTLE

title: When Office Technology Overwhelms, Get Organized
description: HOW do you think most workers would respond if you asked them, Do you feel more productive now than you did several years ago? I doubt that the answer would be a resounding yes. In fact, even as workplace technology and processes steadily improve, many professionals feel less productive than ever.

title: Open Doors, From Open Minds
description: With offices designed by NBBJ, the Gates Foundation and Russell Investments embrace the idea that less space per worker can enhance the working environment, not degrade it.

title: Making Sure Your Exit Music Is Loud and Clear
description: WEVE all dreamed about it at one time or another  that exquisite moment when we finally muster the courage to tell the boss what we really think.

title: U.S. Faces a Tricky Task in Assessment of Data on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  While American spy agencies have believed that the Iranians halted efforts to build a nuclear bomb back in 2003, the difficulty in assessing the governments ambitions was evident two years ago, when what appeared to be alarming new intelligence emerged, according to current and former United States officials.

title: Helping Managers Find, and Fix, Their Flaws
description: MANY management coaches teach executives specific skills toward becoming better mentors, delegators or supervisors.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: Inside the Judges Room
description: SPECIAL POST  Ive competed and Ive judged. Judging is better. You might feel differently.

title: That Wishful Thinking About Tax Rates
description: AT least since Calvin Coolidge, politicians have trumpeted the supply-side benefits of cutting marginal income tax rates. Lower rates will unleash economic growth and the cuts will largely pay for themselves  or so its often said. Yet careful studies find little evidence of such effects. Perhaps its time to reform tax policy based on facts, not worn-out assumptions.

title: War Is Brain-Damaging
description: FIVE years ago I saw a television report about Iraq war veterans in California who were being treated for a new kind of brain injury. I was stunned to watch a female soldier who could no longer recognize her daughter. So I tracked down the therapist treating her and began a nine-month journey in which I interviewed dozens of vets with traumatic brain injuries and their families, eventually turning their heart-wrenching stories into a play.

title: Can Joachim Gauck Make Germany Likable?
description: Washington

title: Woodsons Approach Runs Straight Line From Broad Ripple to N.B.A.
description: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson could perhaps receive no higher compliment than being called a mans man by Bill Smith, a coach who regularly made men of boys. But Smith, Woodsons coach at Broad Ripple High School in Indianapolis, refused to take credit. He did for Woodson only what Jumping Johnny Wilson and Dr. Sander J. Kleis had done for him.

title: Age and Its Awful Discontents
description: MY mother died in 2004, two days short of her 94th birthday, and 40 years and two months to the day after the death of my father. He died at 65; for the preceding four or five years he had been in poor health.

title: First, They Came For The Golf Courses
description: Speaking of madness on the right: Ted Cruz, who apparently has a reasonable chance of being a US Senator from Texas, decries George Soross plot to eliminate the worlds golf courses.

title: In Mexico, a Kidnapping Ignored as Crime Worsens
description: MATAMOROS, Mexico  They have spotted their stolen vehicles at stoplights, driven by the same gunmen who used them to take their entire family captive last July. They have reported the brazen abduction to every branch of Mexican law enforcement, only to be ignored, or directed someplace else.

title: The Soul of the New Hacktivist
description: IN 1988, a Cornell graduate student, Robert Tappan Morris, let loose a computer worm on the fledgling version of the Internet. He said it was meant to be an experiment, but the code he wrote spun out of his control, affecting roughly 50,000 computers connected to the network at the time. Mr. Morris, who happened to be the son of a National Security Agency scientist, became one of the earliest convicted hackers.

title: In Need of a Game Change, Santorum Plays Small Ball
description: What was Rick Santorum doing in Puerto Rico this week?

title: Police Powers in New York
description: Attorney General Eric Holder is rightly reviewing the constitutionally suspect surveillance practices that the New York City Police Department has employed against law-abiding Muslims. The Justice Department should also review other practices  chief among them, stop-and-frisk  that have virtually eliminated the presumption of innocence and that treat citizens, and even entire communities, as suspect even after they are proved innocent.

title: A Memorial Effort Spans Decades and Generations
description: It was to be the largest sculpture in the world: a granite portrait of a Sioux leader on horseback whittled out of a mountain in the Black Hills here. In scale and complexity, the carving would dwarf the imposing collection of presidential profiles on nearby Mount Rushmore.

title: Fluoridation Debate, Redux
description: Remember all of that cold-war-era paranoia about fluoridation in drinking water? It is hard to believe, but decades after its value in preventing tooth decay was clearly demonstrated, questions are again being raised.

title: Southern Upstart, New York Swagger
description: OMAHA  Three times in the final minutes of Norfolk States 86-84 upset of Missouri on Friday, a Spartans supporter in the stands behind press row called out to Marv Albert, who was about 30 feet away broadcasting the game on TNT.

title: The Banks Win, Again
description: Last week was a big one for the banks. On Monday, the foreclosure settlement between the big banks and federal and state officials was filed in federal court, and it is now awaiting a judges all-but-certain approval. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve announced the much-anticipated results of the latest round of bank stress tests.

title: Obama Sets Gas Prices? Just Another G.O.P. Myth
description: Jeff Bingaman, chairman of the Senate energy committee, complained the other day of widespread misunderstanding about rising oil prices. He was being senatorially polite.

title: Cat Got Your Brain
Bypassing the Password
description: IMAGINE sitting down at your work keyboard, typing in your user name and starting work right away  no password needed.

title: Why Bilinguals Are Smarter
description: Editors Note: Were resurfacing this story from the archives to show you how learning a second language can improve how you think.

title: Movement According to Martha Graham
description: Denise Vale, the colorful rehearsal director for the Martha Graham Dance Company in Manhattan, teaches the style she learned under Martha Graham.

title: Staten Island Man Is Fatally Stabbed While Celebrating His Engagement
description: Antonio Lacertosa had wanted to see what was going on when an argument broke out outside a restaurant on Staten Island where he and his fiance were celebrating their recent engagement with friends and relatives early Saturday, one of his sisters said.

title: Is Elvis a Mormon?
description: TRUST Mitt Romney to be on top of the latest trend of the superrich: the trophy basement.

title: Agonies of an Archbishop
description: IN February of 2008, the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, delivered an address on the fraught subject of Islam in English Law. The speech, which circled around the question of whether a civil justice system could accommodate Islamic legal codes, was learned, recondite and occasionally impenetrable. The headlines it generated were not: The head of the Church of England, the newspapers blared, had endorsed Shariah law in Britain. Which he had  sort of, kind of, in the most academic and nuanced and trying-not-to-offend-anyone way imaginable.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: Candidates sought to earn delegates in Missouri, Illinois, Alabama and Puerto Rico.

title: Kamala Harris
description: Kamala Harris is Californias attorney general and the first woman of African and South Asian descent to serve in that position. She recently wrested $18 billion from financial institutions accused of mortgage misdeeds for her states beleaguered homeowners.

title: My Personal To-Do List? The Concierge Has It
description: WHEN Jonathan Swanson, a warehouse associate at Mercedes-Benz USA, was planning his honeymoon, he didnt log on to a travel Web site or start a Google search. Instead, he picked up the phone and called Circles, a 24-hour personal concierge service that is a free benefit available to Mercedes-Benz USA employees.

title: Obama Sips a Guinness, Again
description: President Obama, whose Irish lineage and Guinness-drinking cred were confirmed on a visit to Ireland last May, dropped in at an Irish bar on St. Patricks Day to sip another pint of Guinness and banter with patrons.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 18
description: Politics will again be a major part of the Sunday talk shows, with the Republican nominating contest shifting to Illinois on Tuesday. On ABCs This Week and CNNs State of the Union, Rick Santorum will talk about the momentum he has gained from his victories in Alabama and Mississippi last Tuesday, and Mitt Romney will make another appearance on Fox News Sunday.

title: Sold on Backpage.com at 16
description: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof interviews a former child prostitute who speaks out against sex trafficking on Backpage.com.

title: Disruption Closes a Missouri Caucus Before Vote
description: 8:31 p.m. | Updated ST. PETERS, Mo.  Voters here in St. Charles County did not get a say on Saturday in who will be the next Republican presidential nominee after a disorderly caucus caused organizers to adjourn before delegates were selected.

title: Haneys Book on Woods Is About Golf, but Also Gets Personal
description: Tiger Woods and his people have been quick to dismiss the coming book by his former coach Hank Haney, The Big Miss, which will be released later this month. In an interview with ESPN.com, he called it disappointing, self-serving and about money. He grew angry with questions about the book at a news conference at the Honda Classic last month, after excerpts were released by Golf Digest.

title: Ohio State Sends Gonzaga, Marchs Original Underdog, to Early Exit
description: PITTSBURGH  One day after surprising victories by Norfolk State, Lehigh and Ohio shredded N.C.A.A. tournament brackets, it would have been fitting if seventh-seeded Gonzaga  the so-called original Cinderella story  pulled an upset of its own against No. 2 Ohio State on Saturday.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, with photographs from Missouri, Illinois, Alabama and Puerto Rico.  Go to the slide show.

title: Rear-End Collisions
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Wow, what a weekend for puzzles. Three of my favorite constructors  David Quarfoot, Byron Walden and Mike Nothnagel  contributed outstanding grids that made for an exciting solving weekend.

title: Where Pimps Peddle Their Goods
description: I WENT on a walk in Manhattan the other day with a young woman who once had to work these streets, hired out by eight pimps while she was just 16 and 17. She pointed out a McDonalds where pimps sit while monitoring the girls outside, and a building where she had repeatedly been ordered online as if she were a pizza.

title: The Living After the Dying
description: I SAT down to watch How to Survive a Plague, a new documentary about the history of the AIDS epidemic, expecting to cry, and cry I did: at the hollowed faces of people whittled to almost nothing by a disease with an ugly arc; at the panicked voices of demonstrators who knew that no matter how quickly research progressed, it wouldnt be fleet enough to save people they loved; at the breadth and beauty and horror of the AIDS quilt, spread out across the National Mall, a thread of grief for every blade of grass beneath it.

title: Forget the Money, Follow the Sacredness
description: In the film version of All the Presidents Men, when Robert Redford, playing the journalist Bob Woodward, is struggling to unravel the Watergate conspiracy, an anonymous source advises him to follow the money. Its a good rule of thumb for understanding the behavior of politicians. But following the money leads you astray if youre trying to understand voters.

title: My Lifes Sentences
description: In college, I used to underline sentences that struck me, that made me look up from the page. They were not necessarily the same sentences the professors pointed out, which would turn up for further explication on an exam. I noted them for their clarity, their rhythm, their beauty and their enchantment. For surely it is a magical thing for a handful of words, artfully arranged, to stop time. To conjure a place, a person, a situation, in all its specificity and dimensions. To affect us and alter us, as profoundly as real people and things do.

title: With Return of Crosby, Penguins Dont Miss a Beat
description: NEWARK  At the N.H.L. general managers meeting in Florida last week, Lou Lamoriello of the Devils was asked how he felt about the imminent return of the Pittsburgh superstar Sidney Crosby.

title: Your Brain on Fiction
description: AMID the squawks and pings of our digital devices, the old-fashioned virtues of reading novels can seem faded, even futile. But new support for the value of fiction is arriving from an unexpected quarter: neuroscience.

title: The Way We Read Now
description: THE case against electronic books has been made, and elegantly, by many people, including Nicholson Baker in The New Yorker a few years ago. Mr. Baker called Amazons Kindle, in a memorable put-down, the Bowflex of bookishness: something expensive that, when you commit to it, forces you to do more of whatever it is you think you should be doing more of.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How to Rate Teachers
description: Readers react to an educators ideas for fairer evaluations.

title: Reader Comments on the Trafficking of Girls Online
description: Ive often written over the years about human trafficking abroad, from Cambodia to India to Pakistan. But we dont have the moral authority to complain about other countries until we clean up our own act, and today I focus on sex trafficking right here at home. In fact, the young woman whose story I tell in my column, Alissa, was sold by pimps right outside my office in mid-town Manhattan. (You can also watch a video of Alissa giving me a tour of the streets.)

title: Manning Works Out for Titans
description: Quarterback Peyton Manning worked out for the Tennessee Titans on Saturday morning, completing a cycle of workouts and physicals for the three teams that are known to be finalists to sign him after a weeklong frenzy that has dominated free agency. Manning is likely to pick his new team this week.

title: Boltons Muamba Critically Ill After Collapsing During F.A. Cup Game
description: Bolton midfielder Fabrice Muamba was in critically ill condition in a London hospital late Saturday after collapsing late in the first half of an F.A. Cup quarterfinal against Tottenham at White Hart Lane.

title: Russias Scandalous It Girl Remakes Herself as an Unlikely Face of Protest
description: MOSCOW  It is tempting, these days, to imagine that the political change that took place in Moscow this winter was a mirage. With Vladimir V. Putins first-round victory on the books, and major antigovernment protests called off for the moment, most people seemed to slide back, with regret or relief, to routines they abandoned five months ago.

title: Ethel Winter, Dancer With Martha Graham, Dies at 87
description: Ethel Winter, who brought natural lyricism and startling passion to the Martha Graham Dance Company as a leading dancer there from the 1940s through the 60s, and who mentored hundreds of students at the Juilliard School, at the Graham school and abroad, died on March 10 in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: In Iceland, a Teenage Duel and a Battle of the Sexes
description: Iceland has a rich chess tradition. The country has 12 grandmasters, which may be the largest number, per capita, in the world. And as host of the 1972 world title match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, it has a place in chess history.

title: Murry Bergtraum Wins 14th Girls City Title in a Row
description: Overcoming what its coach called a season-long, emotionally draining situation, Murry Bergtraum of Manhattan won its 14th straight girls city basketball title Saturday.

title: St. Patricks Day Parade
description: It was a sea of green on Fifth Avenue as big crowds gathered for New York Citys 251st annual St. Patricks Day Parade.

title: With a Vital Substitution, Marquette Escapes
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Marquettes Davante Gardner, a 6-foot-8 sophomore, sat and sat on the bench in the second half Saturday while two guard-oriented teams slugged it out trying to find consistent points in a ragged offensive game. Gardner later said he did not play well in the first half and did not expect Coach Buzz Williams to be put him back in the game.

title: Scores Arrested as the Police Clear Zuccotti Park
description: 1:09 a.m. | Updated  Scores of Occupy Wall Street protesters were arrested on Saturday night as police officers swept Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan and closed it.

title: Militants Free American No One Knew Was Missing
description: BAGHDAD  An American man who said he had been kidnapped nine months ago by Iraqi militants was handed over to United States officials in Baghdad on Saturday night in a bizarre and murky series of events that caught diplomats here by surprise.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: Tournament Update After Puzzle 4
description: SPECIAL POST  The leader board has changed markedly.

title: A Legend-to-Star Conversation at Michigan State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Earlier this week, when Magic Johnson called Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo, the Spartans current star, Draymond Green, happened to be sitting in the office. So Izzo passed the telephone to Green so he could talk to Johnson, a Spartans legend.

title: Once Ignored, a Mountain Hawk Has Gained Everyones Attention
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The scouts did not notice, the phone did not ring all that often and the scholarship offers did not pour in for C. J. McCollum when he was a 5-foot-6 high school guard in Ohio hoping to play college basketball.

title: Romney Brushes Off Criticism Over Bain Purchase in China
description: Mitt Romney reacted yesterday to Bain Capitals purchase of a Chinese video surveillance company, while the Obama campaign accused him of utter hypocrisy on China.

title: Ohio Star Passed Up the Majors
description: NASHVILLE  As upsets percolated all over the country Friday and office-pool wagers turned into donations, the question again arose about how teams like Ohio, Lehigh and Norfolk State could compete with traditional powers like Michigan, Duke and Missouri.

title: Isner Pushes Past Djokovic and Into the World Top 10
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  John Isner is the sort of underdog who takes out the goliaths not with a slingshot, but with a rocket launcher.

title: Coptic Pope Dies in Egypt Amid Churchs Struggles
description: CAIRO  Pope Shenouda III, who led the Coptic Orthodox Church in Egypt for four decades, expanding the churchs presence around the world as he struggled, often unsuccessfully, to protect his Christian minority at home, died on Saturday after a long illness, state media reported.

title: Crosby Carries Penguins Past Devils
description: NEWARK  Sidney Crosby sparkled in Game 2 of his second comeback tour, helping the Pittsburgh Penguins to their 11th win in a row, a 5-2 domination of the Devils on Saturday at Prudential Center.

title: A Missed Shot and an Unlikely Star Lift Wisconsin
description: ALBUQUERQUE  With Vanderbilt trailing by 59-57 and with the clock down to its dying seconds, guard John Jenkins had the shot he wanted  from the right side, beyond the 3-point arc.He knew it.His teammates knew it.So did Wisconsin.

title: Santorum Sees in Illinois a Direct Path to Nomination
description: EFFINGHAM, Ill.  Rick Santorum told crowds in Illinoiss conservative downstate that a victory Tuesday would be the key to his nomination.

title: 911 Calls Add Detail to Debate Over Florida Killing
description: MIAMI  It was raining the night of Feb. 26 when George Zimmerman, a crime watch volunteer, set out to patrol his neighborhood in his sport utility vehicle, as was his habit. Several break-ins had been reported in the area in recent weeks, and Mr. Zimmerman was especially alert.

title: Corrections: March 18
description: FRONT PAGE

title: You Think Youre a Frequent Flyer
description: PARIS  Singapore Girl he is not.

title: Majerus Is Back, and Reporters Are Happy
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Coach Rick Majerus has St. Louis in the Round of 32 in his fifth season with the program. But the ninth-seeded Billikens, who will face No. 1 Michigan State, are not the only beneficiary of Majeruss pearls of wisdom.

title: Indiana Holds Off V.C.U. as Resurgence Continues
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Just when it seemed Virginia Commonwealth would add another basketball program steeped in tradition to its list of N.C.A.A. tournament victims the last two seasons, Indiana continued its basketball resurgence instead.

title: N.C.A.A. Mens Tournament Photo Replay: March 17
description: Wisconsin edged out a victory over Vanderbilt, and Ohio State held tough against Gonzaga in tournament action.

title: Youth Hostel
description: At the Fishermans Wharf Youth Hostel at Fort Mason, a bunk runs less than $30 per night and includes a decent breakfast. About 20,000 visitors from more than 90 countries  including North Korea, Saudi Arabia and the Cook Islands  stayed here last year, experiencing the Bays prime real estate at a subprime price.

title: Knicks Ride Defense and Bench to Third Straight Win
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In what Jeremy Lin called a horrible defensive first quarter, the Knicks starters looked as if they had forgotten the urgency that Coach Mike Woodson has preached, while playing about nine miles from where Woodson went to high school.

title: Unemployed Is Bad Enough; Unbanked Can Be Worse
description: Joey Macias has lived without a bank or credit union account for more than a year. To pay his bills, Mr. Macias, a 45-year-old San Francisco resident, waits for his unemployment check to arrive in the mail and then cashes it at a Market Street branch of Money Mart, the international money-lending and check-cashing chain. He keeps any leftover cash at home or in his wallet.

title: Norfolk States Roots Run Through New York City
description: Norfolk State had only just polished off its upset of second-seeded Missouri on Friday night when Chuck Granbys phone started ringing. And ringing.

title: Scientists Look Far to the North to Explain Young Whale in San Francisco Bay
description: Recent sightings of a gray whale and her infant calf swimming near Alcatraz and Sausalito in San Francisco Bay illuminated a likely repercussion of melting polar ice, scientists said.

title: Path for a Housing-Aid Plan Runs Through a Tangle of Competing Interests
description: San Francisco civic leaders are bickering over new subsidies for affordable housing in the most expensive city for renters in the United States.

title: Not Every Election Is Such a Big Drama
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Push Comes to Shove Over Water Restrictions
description: FLOYDADA  J. O. Dawdy, who has been a farmer for 36 years, is so worried about getting enough groundwater that he is considering a lawsuit to protect his right to it.

title: 2 Arrests in Death of Man Found in Chelsea Apartment
description: Two suspects in the death of a Chelsea man found bound and gagged in his apartment two weeks ago were arrested in Orlando, Fla., on Thursday and brought back to New York about 9 p.m. Saturday night, the police said.

title: Kentucky Is Just Too Good for Iowa State
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Kentucky should at least be susceptible to some anxiety in a close game, something that exposes their youthfulness and hinders this blur of talent. They have a senior, Darius Miller, who comes off the bench, but they start three freshmen and two sophomores, and they should show some cracks when pressured.

title: Its Not Texas, but the Barbecue Can Fool You
description: Can you take barbecue out of Texas and still call it Texas barbecue? A growing number of restaurateurs born or bred in Texas say you can, and they are opening establishments across America where customers can be indoctrinated into the unique tradition of Lone Star barbecue  smoked meat ordered by the pound, served on butcher paper, without sauce or utensils.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 17, 2012

title: The One Who Got Away
description: NASHVILLE  After scoring 30 points in a stunning upset of Duke on Friday, the world got its introduction to Lehigh guard C.J. McCollum. He hails from Canton, Ohio, and his outburst will live forever in slow-motion highlights.

title: Rural Community Colleges Battle Financial Squeeze
description: SNYDER The coffers at Western Texas College are about as dry as the windswept West Texas plains that surround it. Reductions in state financing have been a literal drain  last year, the college cut costs by emptying its N.C.A.A. competition-size pool.

title: Avalanches Goalie Masters the Rangers
description: After the Pittsburgh Penguins drew closer in the standings, the last thing the Rangers needed was to run into a hot goaltender. But that was what happened when they faced Semyon Varlamov at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

title: Caught in the Cross-Fire
description: Villagers in southern Yemen are often caught in the cross-fire between government soldiers and Qaeda-aligned militants attempting to impose strict Islamic law.

title: Driving Harrison Barnes
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Back when North Carolina forward Harrison Barnes and Creightons Doug McDermott were helping Ames, Iowa, High to 53 consecutive victories and two state championships from 2008-10, they were more than just teammates.

title: Late Surge Powers Baylor Over Colorado
description: ALBUQUERQUE  For 32 minutes, underdog Colorado answered every Baylor run with a surge of its own. Then Brady Heslip and the Bears said, Enough.

title: Christine Terada and Keith Schuricht
description: Christine Ayumi Terada and Keith Kaiji Schuricht were married Saturday at the Loulu Palm Estate, a party venue and plantation house in Haleiwa, Hawaii, on the Island of Oahu. The officiant was the Rev. George W. Scott, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the chaplain of the Punahou School in Honolulu, which the bride attended.

title: Rebecca Emmanuel and Henry Rooney
description: Rebecca Ribka Emmanuel, a daughter of Karen S. Emmanuel and Tsegai Emmanuel of Ruston, La., was married Saturday to Henry Michael Rooney, the son of Joann P. Rooney and Michael F. Rooney of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Hiruy Bereket Gebremichael performed the ceremony at the Zion Lutheran Church in New Orleans.

title: Jasmine Benyamin, Ash Lettow
description: Jasmine Benyamin and Ash James Lettow were married Saturday at the Cornerstone Gardens in Sonoma, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Indano, a Presbyterian minister, led a ceremony that included Lutheran, Roman Catholic and Assyrian traditions.

title: Bianca Harris, Barry Jonas
description: Bianca Blair Harris and Barry Jonathan Jonas are to be married Sunday at the Tarrytown House Estate, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor Moshe Weiss is to officiate.

title: Sarah Becker and Zachary Zimmerman
description: Sarah Rachel Becker, a daughter of Dr. Margaret A. Yacovone and Dr. Jeffrey A. Becker of Silver Spring, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Zachary Kardon Zimmerman, a son of P. K. Fields and Scott K. Zimmerman, both of Los Angeles. Rabbi Alan C. Stein is to officiate at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Lauren Manning, Timothy OMalley
description: Lauren Elizabeth Manning and Timothy Patrick OMalley were married Saturday at the Breakers, a resort in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Robert Duggan, a retired Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Tabitha Oman and Myron Manternach
description: Tabitha Russell Oman and Myron Gerard Manternach were married Saturday evening at the Tabard Inn in Washington. Judge Pauline Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, whose chambers are in Washington, officiated.

title: Barbara Karenko, William Saxton
description: Dr. Barbara Ann Karenko and William Michael Saxton were married Saturday evening at the Cairnwood Mansion, an estate in Bryn Athyn, Pa. The Rev. Frank F. Sparks, an American Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Margaret Peterson, Andrew Laird
description: Margaret Gabrielle Peterson, a daughter of Andrea H. Peterson and Carl E. Peterson of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., Saturday to Andrew Charles Laird, a son of Vicki J. Laird and William C. Laird of Metamora, Ill. The Rev. Paul G. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, where he is the pastor.

title: Laura Sirulnik, William Zysblat
description: Dr. Laura Raquel Sirulnik and William Zysblat were married Thursday at their home in New York. David G. Beslow, a Universal Life minister and a nephew of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Benjamin Miller and Sean Reisman
description: Benjamin Edward Miller and Sean Peter Reisman were married Friday at the Staten Island Marriage Bureau. Edison Stewart, a deputy city clerk, officiated. On March 31, Rabbi David Gruber is to lead a religious ceremony at the Saint Paul Hotel in St. Paul.

title: Elizabeth Marshall and Jeffrey Leeds
description: Elizabeth Sunderland Marshall and Jeffrey Thomas Leeds were married Friday evening at their home in New York. Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officiated.

title: Catherine Milne, Matthew Bloom
description: Catherine Elizabeth Milne and Matthew Adam Bloom were married Saturday evening at the Deering Estate, a historic mansion, in Miami. The Rev. Nelson Velez, who is affiliated with St. Jude Counseling Ministries, officiated. Rabbi Arthur Pedowitz participated in the ceremony, which included Christian and Jewish elements.

title: Siva Rights the Cardinals Ship
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  As New Mexico mounted a late comeback, Louisville turned to the player who revived its championship hopes over the past month. Sure, guard Peyton Siva produced relatively ordinary statistics Saturday, but he also calmed the Cardinals and quelled the comeback.

title: Billionaire Founder of Red Bull Dies in Thailand
description: HONG KONG  A founder of the Red Bull empire, a self-made Thai billionaire who came up with the original formula for the high-octane energy drink, has died in Bangkok.

title: Action-Packed Win for a Top Middleweight
description: Sergio Martinez was expected to dominate his unheralded opponent Saturday night, but midway through the fight, he found himself a little off balance and struggling to land meaningful punches. Still, Martinez, the middleweight champion, did not panic.

title: Officials Are Saying: Get Out of the Lane
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Two controversial calls by officials came in the first two days of the N.C.A.A. tournaments main draw, but that doesnt necessarily mean there is a larger controversy brewing.

title: Wisconsin to Meet Minnesota for Title
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Purdues Tall Challenge
description: OMAHA  Kansas, with the 6-foot-10 power forward Thomas Robinson and the 7-foot center Jeff Withey, brings a significant inside presence to its third-round Midwest Region matchup against Purdue on Sunday. Thats something the perimeter-based Boilermakers usually cant handle. Purdue is 0-7 against teams with productive post players, and 22-5 against everybody else.

title: Dharun Ravi Case Raises Issue of Homophobia in Indian-American Community
description: I suppose it was inevitable. These days South Asian faces are prevalent in every arena of all-American life  doctors, lawyers, actors, designers, politicians, rappers, activists, socialites, Little Leaguers, Girl Scouts. But now, thanks to former Rutgers student Dharun Ravi, it appears we have assumed a new mantle: the bully.

title: Arrests at Zuccotti Park
description: Scores of Occupy Wall Street protesters were arrested on Saturday night as police officers swept Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan and closed it.

title: Florida Braces for Hostile Neutral Crowd
description: OMAHA  Billy Donovan knows what its like to be an N.C.A.A. tournament darling (see: Providence, 1987). And he knows how much crowds at N.C.A.A. tournaments love darlings. (Ditto.)

title: North Korean Missile Could Be in Japanese Cross Hairs
description: HONG KONG  The last time this happened, when North Korea said it was launching a satellite using a long-range missile, Japan said it had the right to shoot the thing down.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: I live in a house of slamming doors and broken dreams. I am no longer myself, I am convinced that I am starring in somebodys tragic film, Meena Kandasamy writes in an intensely moving and personal tale of domestic violence in Outlook magazine. Kandasamy, a poet, activist, translator and scholar, shares her harrowing experience of being married to a violent man and subjugated to severe emotional and physical abuse. Having discovered that he was previously married and has yet to divorce his wife, she leaves him and finds that her marriage is not valid  there is no point in asking for a divorce. Finding no recourse in the law, and no possibility of punishment, she seeks solace in family, friends and poetry.

title: Henson and Tar Heels Holding Breath
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The verdict is not in on John Henson, the 6-foot-11 North Carolina forward who missed the opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament with an injured left wrist. The top-seeded Tar Heels might not know until the 5:15 p.m. game time on Sunday if he will play against No. 8 Creighton in a Midwest Region third-round game at Greensboro Coliseum.

title: In Delhi, Rushdie Issues a Battle Cry
description: Back in the day, when he was a playboy in London, the most common nickname for him was Im the Dim   Salman Rushdie about the Pakistani cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan in a speech Saturday in India

title: Manningham to 49ers, Who Await Manning Decision
description: The 49ers have given Peyton Manning another reason to choose San Francisco. On Saturday, the team agreed to terms on a two-year deal with the former Giants wideout Mario Manningham, as first reported by ProFootballTalk.com.

title: Statehood Support Should Help Romney in Puerto Rico
description: Forecasting the outcome of the Republican primary in Puerto Rico is tricky. No polling has been done in the race, and it is an outlier in almost every sense.

title: On the National Mall, Art in the Round
description: The landscape of Washington appears fixed, iconic. The Capitol building, the monuments  Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln  are all instantly recognizable and they are illuminated each evening. But this spring the skyline is changing. The Hirshhorn Museum has commissioned a groundbreaking work of whats being billed as liquid architecture from the artist Doug Aitken, a site-specific installation that will envelope the Hirshhorns spherical building with 11 high-definition screens and alter the cityscape of the National Mall from March 22 to May 16.

title: The Collapse of Employment-Based Coverage
description: Reed Abelson at Economix points us to a startling study on the effects of the Great Recession on health insurance. You can see similar trends in the Census data, but for whatever reason this survey  carried out by a highly reputable group  is even stronger. Heres the key picture:

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: An Upset!
description: SPECIAL POST  There has been an upset!

title: A Hardware Stores Four-Legged Star
description: Franklin is classified on Facebook as a public figure in Brooklyn, N.Y. His likes include Babe: Pig in the City and Crest Hardware and Urban Garden Center, a plug for the store in Williamsburg where he can often be found rooting through mulch. He has blue eyes, the inspiration for his name  as in Frankie Blue Eyes  and mellows out while listening to classic rock radio.

title: A Casino for Gamblers Who Dont Smoke
description: In efforts to rejuvenate Atlantic City, casinos and resorts have leaned on celebrity chef-run restaurants, sprawling spas and mega-nightclubs. The latest opening adds a new dimension: a smoke-free environment. Casinos are exempt from New Jerseys nonsmoking law, but when the 1,800-room Revel opens in stages starting April 2, it will be Atlantic Citys only nonsmoking casino resort, intended to appeal to the 81 percent of American adults who do not smoke.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: Going Into the Finals
description: SPECIAL POST  In an unprecedented turn of events, two people who will likely be in the finals are going in with errors from the Saturday puzzles.

title: In Yemen, U.S. Teacher Is Shot Dead by Two Men
description: An American teacher affiliated with a missionary organization was shot and killed by two men on a motorcycle in the central Yemeni city of Taiz on Sunday, according to Yemeni officials.

title: Disruptions: Time to Review  F.A.A. Policy on Gadgets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On Monday morning Im going to drive to the airport, check in for my flight to New York, then head to the airport bookstore for a stack of magazines to read on the plane. Ill do this reluctantly because I will carry both an Amazon Kindle and an Apple iPad packed full of reading material in my bag.

title: Ambassador Defends Afghan Presidents Demon Comments
description: Afghanistans ambassador to the United States sought to defend his president, Hamid Karzai, on Sunday after the Afghan leader was criticized for comparing the United States to a demon.

title: The View from St. Louis University: A Tough Matchup With the Spartans
description: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Santorum Wont Be Pinned Down on Brokered Convention
description: Rick Santorum on Sunday refused to say how he intends to play the endgame of his fight for delegates with Mitt Romney, even as his campaign was preparing behind the scenes for a brokered convention.

title: Porn in the USA
description: No special insight  I just wanted dibs on this now that Rick Santorum has decided to focus on our most pressing national issue.

title: How Bad The Debate Is
description: Many pundits still like to pretend that were having something resembling a rational national debate, with members of both parties saying reasonable things given their views about how policy works. And when you find a politician saying something not at all reasonable, theres a lot of false equivalence  surely both sides do it, even if you dont have any, you know, actual examples from one side.

title: Peace March in Damascus Is Cut Short by Authorities
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian authorities briefly detained 11 members of one of Syrias most moderate opposition groups during a demonstration in central Damascus on Sunday. The move signaled an expanded crackdown and dismayed the protesters, who have called for dialogue with the government and, unlike many other activists, have opposed the use of violence in the yearlong uprising.

title: Belarus Censured for Executing 2 in Subway Bombing
description: MOSCOW  Belarus confirmed in a government television report on Saturday night that the two men convicted of bombing a subway station last year in its capital had been put to death.

title: Doubled Over
description: I have to go back to the hospital, the man told his worried wife. A terrible abdominal pain had been his constant companion for the last 10 days and had steadily worsened over the past 48 hours. As they drove back to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, the hospital they left just five days earlier, the car was quiet; she was frightened, and he was focused on the pain that seemed to intensify with every passing minute.

title: Santorum Faults G.O.P. for Favoring Urban Wealthy
description: HERRIN, Ill.  Rick Santorum has accused President Obama of waging class warfare, of dividing America, the 99 versus the 1.

title: For Red Bulls, Prognosis Negative
description: Two games. Two goals allowed in each. Two losses. Too much?

title: Excerpt: Falling Slowly From Once
description: Steve Kazee and Cristin Milioti in a scene from the musical Once, at New York Theater Workshop. The show has transferred to Broadway. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Ethics Fight Over Domain Names Intensifies
description: PARIS  A boardroom dispute over ethics has broken out at the organization that maintains the Internet address system after its most important supporter, the United States government, reproached the group for governance standards said to fall short of requirements requested by the global community.

title: Romneys Make Pitch to Women Before Illinois Primary
description: MOLINE, Ill.  With the Republican primary race turning into a long and protracted slog for delegates that could potentially last until the convention, Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, made an appeal on Sunday morning to a coveted group of swing voters: women.

title: Hawks Steering Debate on How to Take On Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Even before President Obama declared this month that I have Israels back in its escalating confrontation with Iran, pro-Israel figures like the evangelical Christian leader Gary L. Bauer and the conservative commentator William Kristol were pushing for more.

title: 21 Jump Street Leads the Way at Movie Theaters
description: Movies based on television shows often lead to box-office disaster (Bewitched in 2005, Land of the Lost in 2009), which makes the ones that do succeed quite impressive: Over the weekend, a comedic remake of 21 Jump Street was a big No. 1 at North American theaters, selling an estimated $35 million in tickets. 21 Jump Street, starring Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum and released by Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, cost about $42 million to make and succeeded because  brace yourselves  it was actually funny. It received strong reviews, and moviegoers under age 25, the target audience, gave the film an A score in exit polls.

title: How Hunger Games Built Up Must-See Fever
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Selling a movie used to be a snap. You printed a poster, ran trailers in theaters and carpet-bombed NBCs Thursday night lineup with ads.

title: Freuds Radical Talking
description: Death is supposed to be an event proclaimed but once, and yet some deaths, curiously enough, need to be affirmed again and again, as if there were a risk that the interred will crawl back up into the world of the living if fresh handfuls of dirt are not tossed on their graves. One such member of the living dead, accompanying the likes of God and Karl Marx, is Sigmund Freud. How often one hears, thanks recently to the fetishization of neuroscience, that psychoanalysis is now bunk, irrelevant, its method decadent and dangerous, as the recent David Cronenberg film, A Dangerous Method, informs us.

title: Brazil Bars Oil Workers From Leaving After Spill
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Brazilian court has ordered 17 employees from two American companies, the oil giant Chevron and the rig operator Transocean, to surrender their passports, barring them from leaving Brazil as authorities prepare to file criminal charges in days in connection with an offshore oil spill involving the companies.

title: The Delirious Spirit of the Tarantella
description: The tarantella, according to timeworn southern Italian tradition, is a folk-dance style with a mission. According to some sources, the conventional form of the dance is named for Taranto, the coastal city in Apulia where it took hold. A more colorful explanation, widely accepted in the 16th and 17th centuries, held that the dances accelerating triple-time whirl helped to sweat out the effects of tarantism: a delirious condition caused by the bite of an indigenous wolf spider, the tarantula.

title: The Power of Plutocratic Pettiness
description: Via Rich Yeselson, Alec MacGillis has a fantastic piece in the New Republic (unfortunately paywalled) about how hedge fund managers love for Obama has turned into blind, spitting hatred. His main argument is that its all about feeling disrespected:

title: Santorum and the Ghost of Arlen Specter
description: Rick Santorum continues to be haunted by his previous support for Arlen Specter, his one-time fellow Republican senator from Pennsylvania.

title: N.C. State Sends Georgetown to Another Early Exit
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  After President Obama selected North Carolina State to advance to the Round of 16, Wolfpack Coach Mark Gottfried sought to explain the pick as simply a move to curry favor among the states voters in the coming presidential election.

title: Syrians Mourn Bombing Victims
description: In Damascus, while some Syrians attended a funeral for victims of Saturdays bombings, others demonstrated nearby in support of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Isner Gambled Against Djokovic and Won Plenty
description: John Isners biography at the ATP Tour Web site lists playing poker as one of his hobbies.

title: Even a Player Who Made It Knows the Value of a Backup Plan
description: Im a living example that hard work and perseverance pays off. It was a hard road for me. Everybody is not going to be in my shoes, and youre going to have to be able to decide what you want to do in life when hit with that harsh reality that you didnt make it.  Royal Ivey

title: Spirited Strings Enliven Work of a Composer Once Banned
description: The composer Erwin Schulhoff, born in Prague in 1894, was one of many artists whose works were branded as degenerate by the Nazis. Schulhoff, of German-Jewish descent, also faced persecution because of his left-wing political beliefs. He died in 1942 in the Wlzburg concentration camp in Bavaria.

title: Mortgages for Drilling Properties May Face Hurdle
description: The Department of Agriculture is considering requiring an extensive environmental review before issuing mortgages to people who have leased their land for oil and gas drilling.

title: Cross the River, Find the Passion
description: On Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, Bogna Bartosz was singing the alto part in Bachs Magnificat in D (BWV 243). Her aria, Esurientes implevit bonis, comes near the end, and she dispatched its burbling runs with perfect evenness. Not a single note popped out or receded unduly: the line was one scrupulous, straight shot.

title: A.C.P.T. 2012: And the Winner is
description: SPECIAL POST  Well, you know by now, right?

title: From 60s Patchouli and Free Love to Darker Days a Half-Century Later
description: Lauren Groffs Arcadia is so immersed in the life of a hippie commune that patchouli ought to waft off its pages. Its a novel of the 1960s and 70s in which acid is dropped, groats are served, Froggie Went A Courtin is sung, a cult leader is worshiped and somebody literally hugs a tree. An outhouse at Arcadia smells like wet muskrat. Children are reared in a Kid Herd. This does not sound like everyones cup of rose-hip tea.

title: In Crosswords, Its Man Over Machine, for Now
description: Score one for humans and their subtle, quirky, pattern-matching brains.

title: A Wave of Military Memoirs With You-Are-There Appeal
description: Now that American involvement in Iraq and Afghanistan is winding down, the warriors are telling their stories.

title: Feeding Hunger for The Hunger Games
description: The Hollywood reporter Brooks Barnes reports on Lionsgates new interactive marketing campaign for The Hunger Games.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Yale Rep Casting
description: Tracy Letts, Johanna Day, Glenn Fitzgerald and Parker Posey will portray suburban couples who share the same last name in The Realistic Joneses, a new play written by Will Eno (Middletown), commissioned by the Yale Repertory Theater. The theater is to announce the casting news on Monday. Mr. Letts and Ms. Day will play Bob and Jennifer Jones, who learn that their new neighbors John and Pony Jones (Mr. Fitzgerald and Ms. Posey) have more in common with them than a surname. Directed by Sam Gold (Seminar), the production is scheduled to run at Yale Rep from April 20 to May 12, with opening night set for April 26.

title: Lutheran Pastor Elected as Germanys President
description: BERLIN  A rights activist and former Lutheran pastor was overwhelmingly elected as Germanys 11th postwar president on Sunday, putting former East Germans in the nations two highest offices at a time when it is being called on to assume a greater leadership role in Europe.

title: In Memphis, Pre-emptive Bid Paints Picture for Declarer
description: MEMPHIS  At the North American Championships here the two-day Lebhar Imp Pairs was decided on Saturday evening. The winners by a convincing margin were Hailong Ao of Herndon, Va., and Jian-Jian Wang of Clarksville, Md.

title: You Need a Rubens? Sorry, Sold
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  Theres nothing unusual about hearing French, Italian, German or even Russian spoken at the European Fine Art Fair. But this year, as the doors to the cavernous convention center here opened for the invitation-only preview on Thursday, Chinese was also a noticeable part of the mix.

title: Pacific Northwest Ballet Wins $25,000 Grant
description: Pacific Northwest Ballet has been named the second recipient of the Rudolf Nureyev Prize for New Dance, a $25,000 grant designed to encourage large ballet companies to create new works. The award was presented in Seattle on Friday to Peter Boal, the companys artistic director. The ballet plans to use the money to commission a new work by Alejandro Cerrudo, the resident choreographer for Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, with a New York premiere at the Joyce Theater during the 2013-14 season.

title: Former Rodale Publisher Joins Harper Imprint
description: Karen Rinaldi, the former publisher of Rodale Books, will join the Harper imprint of HarperCollins in April to start a line of health and wellness books, the publisher said Sunday. Ms. Rinaldi, as a senior vice president and executive editor, will publish roughly 24 titles a year on subjects like science, nature, sports, food, relationships and the environment. Jonathan Burnham, the publisher of Harper, said in a statement that Ms. Rinaldi would help generate a list that stands for the very best and newest in the field. Harper has published fiction by Ann Patchett, Barbara Kingsolver and Michael Chabon, and Going Rogue by Sarah Palin. It has also acquired a memoir by Amanda Knox, the Seattle student who was acquitted in October of charges that she murdered her roommate and was freed from an Italian prison.

Maybe its just because it conforms to some Northerners stereotype I have about Texas, but at South by Southwest almost anything Americana-flavored  country, folk, alt-country, cowpunk  sounds great to me. You encounter it even before you show your badge to anyone, in the Waylon Jennings on the van radio from the airport or the twangy din from the musicians who set up along Sixth Street, the chaotic festival thoroughfare here. And during the festival itself, it can be a comfort from some of the fly-by-night indie trends as well as a source of innovation.

title: Art Critics Awards
description: The American chapter of the International Association of Art Critics has announced the winners of its annual awards for artists, curators and institutions for excellence in art exhibitions in 2011. The 24 winners, selected by the 400 critics and others who make up the associations membership, include an installation by Sarah Sze on the High Line (best project in a public space); the exhibition Bye Bye Kitty!!! at the Japan Society (best show in a nonprofit gallery or space); the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty (best architecture or design show); and Paula Cooper Gallerys presentation of The Clock by Christian Marclay (best show in a commercial gallery in New York). Awards will be presented on April 2 in New York.

title: Russian Prima Ballerina Beyond the Ballet Domain

But only the men ventured far into modern dance. Ballet technique is at its most specific when applied to its leading women, few of whom have roamed outside its privileged and brilliant enclosure. Today, however, one Russian ballerina exhibits some of the old Nureyev-Baryshnikov eagerness to move beyond the ballet domain: Diana Vishneva.

It was her fourth of eight performances at the 26th annual South by Southwest Music Festival, the four-day music-business convention enfolded by five nights of showcases that ended on Saturday night, bringing more than 2,000 acts  songwriters, bands, rappers, D.J.s and more  to perform all over Austin, with a long Internet afterlife.
