title: Zayo to Buy AboveNet for $2.2 Billion to Extend Fiber Network
description: The Zayo Group agreed on Monday to buy AboveNet, a provider of fiber optic networks for businesses, for $2.2 billion in cash to tap into demand for ever-faster data connections.

title: Flush With Cash, Apple Plans Buyback and Dividend
description: Apple announced on Monday that it would at last return some of its cash pile to shareholders in the form of dividends and stock buybacks, at a cost of more than $10 billion a year for the next three years. But it is attracting so much cash  $1 billion a week in the last holiday season alone  that the move will not put a dent in Apples coffers.

title: Spoiler Alert? Walking Dead Cast Announcement Follows Minutes After Finale
description: Warning: this post contains spoilers about the Walking Dead season finale.

title: Big Data for the Rest of Us, in One Start-Up
description: The best insight into the current state of the Big Data business may be a five-person start-up in Palo Alto, Calif. While the industry mostly gathers lots of data, or stores it in new cloud-based databases, the start-up, ClearStory Data, is building the biggest possible base of data consumers.

title: Styled to a T | Ionna Vautrin
description: The Designer

title: More About Europes Two Depressions
description: A slightly updated version of the figure:

title: Standing By the Bankers, Right or Wrong
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, who has waged municipal war on guns, sugary soft drinks, tobacco and cars that enter Manhattan in excessive numbers, visited the headquarters of Goldman Sachs a few days ago to let its chief executive and its employees feel the mayoral love.

title: The Mighty Wurlitzer in Action
description: Read the comments on todays column and youll find many, many references to the alleged fact that the estimated cost of the ACA has risen by a trillion dollars  which happens to be a complete lie.

title: Russian Star Headed to Predators
description: Alexander Radulov, the two-time most valuable player of the K.H.L., has bought out the remainder of his contract with the Russian club Salavat Yulaev Ufa and will join the Nashville Predators of the N.H.L. later this week, his Russian agent said Monday.

title: Republican Senate Hopefuls From N.Y.
description: Wendy Long, and Rep. Bob Turner on their hopes to win Sen. Kirsten Gillibrands U.S. Senate seat.

title: Apple Elevates Markets, Especially the S.&P. 500
description: The Standard & Poors 500 advanced on Monday to the highest level since May 2008 as Apple said it would pay a dividend and buy back $10 billion of its stock.

title: Mets Owners Agree to Settle Madoff Suit for $162 Million
description: The owners of the Mets scored a major legal victory  one that might well preserve their control of the team  when the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs vast fraud agreed to abandon hundreds of millions of dollars in claims against them.

title: Koodankulam Nuclear Project Gets a Green Light
description: Speaking out Monday in favor of going ahead with work on the Koodankulam nuclear reactors, Chief Minister J. Jayalalitha of Tamil Nadu put an end to the deadlock over the project. Ms. Jayalalitha issued a statement saying that in accordance with a cabinet decision on Monday, immediate steps will be taken to help open the plant.

title: Leading Off: Ohio Big in Elections, and N.C.A.A. Tournament Too
description: Of all the possible outcomes from the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. tournament, it was more likely you would have chosen two No. 15 upsets and a Duke platform-dive out of the first round than predicted we would all be talking about the state of Ohio. Yes, Ohio. If youre a presidential candidate, you know this state well. If youre a basketball fan, not so much. Sure, Ohio State flew high for a while this season and yes, once Bob Huggins willed Cincinnati into the national conversation for a referee-terrifying stretch of seasons, but, really, not since the days of Oscar Robertson has anybody focused the college basketball klieg lights here for more than a few minutes. And there are several generations of basketball fans who are now searching Wikipedia to find out who Oscar Robertson is. (Trust us, the Big O was big.)

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: The trouble with Greece, summed up in the sad tale of an entrepreneurs failed attempt to build a business selling olive-oil products. One fly in the ointment: his unwillingness to oil palms with bribes.  Patrick Farrell

title: Image of the Day: March 19
Move at U.N. on Carnage in Sri Lanka Sets Off Fury
description: GENEVA  An American-led initiative calling on Sri Lanka to account for the carnage that ended its civil war three years ago has become the focus of a diplomatic dispute in Geneva and anger in Sri Lanka.

title: I Get By With a Little Help From My Parents
description: Nearly 1 in 10 American adults regularly receive money or financial assistance from their parents or other family members, according to a poll conducted by the Pew Research Center.

title: Morning Buzz, March 19: Saying Goodbye to Pay Phones
description: Good morning. It will be another beautiful day in New York City, with highs in the low 70s.

title: Daily Report: Apple Announces a Dividend
description: Apple announced Monday that it would pay a regular quarterly stock dividend of $2.65 a share beginning in the quarter that starts in July, and its board authorized a $10 billion share buyback  moves that will use up some of its cash hoard of nearly $100 billion to reward investors.

title: Peace March in Damascus Is Cut Short by Authorities
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian authorities briefly detained 11 members of one of Syrias most moderate opposition groups during a demonstration in central Damascus on Sunday. The move signaled an expanded crackdown and dismayed the protesters, who have called for dialogue with the government and, unlike many other activists, have opposed the use of violence in the yearlong uprising.

title: On Our Radar:  A Plastic-Eating Monster
description: Operating a machine known as the Plastic-Eating Monster, a start-up company in Niagara Falls, N.Y. is melting milk jugs, water bottles and grocery bags from landfills and dumps in a large tank to produce No. 6 fuel oil. [NPR]

title: Good Wife Watch: Everythings a Negotiation
description: Such mixed feelings. In a key scene of Sunday nights Good Wife episode, Gloves Come Off, I enjoyed seeing Diane (Christine Baranski, wonderful as always) cut Alicia Florrick down to size when Alicia (Julianna Margulies) ambushed her at the elevator and demanded an immediate answer to her request for more money. Well, Diane said, her face a mask of disappointment. Everybody changes. End of the week, Alicia. Or you can clean out your desk right now.

title: Rexnord Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: After several aborted takeoffs over the last six years, an initial public offering of the Rexnord Corporation is headed for the runway.

title: Before Illinois Primary, Santorum Talks of Brokered Convention
description: Rick Santorum again raised the specter of a brokered Republican convention on Monday as he sought to appeal to conservative voters in Illinois to deliver another setback to Mitt Romneys presidential ambitions in the states primary on Tuesday.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Feeding Hunger Games Fans, and the Theater of Journalism
description: The marketing effort behind the movie The Hunger Games has been a marriage of traditional methods  billboards, magazine covers  and social-media promotions guided by Lionsgates marketing division, Brooks Barnes writes. No doubt the film, which opens on Friday, had a built-in advantage because of the many young fans of the book series. Even so, feeding the flame online has been a preoccupation for a year for Lionsgate, with a strategy that included hooking in the blogs, a series of well-timed contests at Twitter and Facebook, a YouTube channel, a Tumblr blog, etc.

title: Atera Will Sow a Wild Spring Mix in TriBeCa
description: Here comes Atera, at the juncture of two trends hitting New York from east and west: the wild-foods cuisine of Scandinavia and the influx of chefs from Portland, Ore.

title: Video Shows Damage in Syrian Capital
description: Updated | 1:53 p.m. Residents of the Syrian capital, Damascus, reported heavy fighting early on Monday in one of the few areas of the city where the opposition has taken to the streets. As my colleague Anne Barnard reports, The fighting started around 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. with several explosions, activists and residents said, followed by automatic-weapons fire and helicopters circling with searchlights, in a wealthy area of the citys Mezze district that is home to business people, United Nations offices and diplomatic residences.

title: Senate Debates So-Called Small-Business Bill
description: The Senate has taken up the Houses so-called JOBS bill, which ostensibly makes it easier for small companies, and many large ones as well, to seek investment in the capital markets, and there are conflicting and confusing reports about what will become of the Houses handiwork on the Senate floor. Though described as a small-business bill, the Houses legislation, as we reported on Tuesday, eases disclosure and oversight requirements for small and giant corporations alike, and some critics of the Houses work had hoped Senate Democrats would temper some of the JOBS bills more controversial provisions.

title: Vain Glorious | The Scents of Summer
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Voices From the New York State Republican Convention
description: New York Republicans gathered on Friday in Rochester to begin choosing a candidate to challenge the Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a Democrat, for one of the states United States Senate seats.

title: How Wall Street Deals With Conflicts
description: Life is full of conflicts of interest: Physicians make money off of their patients, lawyers earn fees from their clients, and every retail transaction is about generating a profit from the customer.

title: Monday Motorsports: McLarens Button and Hamilton Put Red Bull on Notice
description: With the opening race of the 2012 Formula One season, the McLaren Mercedes MP4-27 proved it wasnt just a pretty face.

title: Falling for the Lottery Trick
description: When 24-hour news channels debuted, we wondered how theyd fill up the time. Now we have an answer. Just consider the life-changing stories that appeared during the last week:

title: Arcapita, a Bahraini Investment Firm, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Arcapita Bank, a $7.4 billion Bahraini investment firm that owns the clothier J. Jill, filed for bankruptcy protection in Manhattan on Monday after it was unable to extend a $1.1 billion credit line set to expire next Wednesday.

title: Childbirth: Small Babies May Weaken Mothers Hearts
description: A full-term pregnancy with a small baby may cause changes in a womans cardiovascular system that increase her risk for heart disease later in life, new data suggest.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Sokolove on Casinos That Crash
description: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story on casinos. Sokolove is the author of three books: Warrior Girls, about the epidemic of injuries among young female athletes; The Ticket Out: Darryl Strawberry; and Hustle: The Myth, Life, and Lies of Pete Rose. His last cover story for the magazine was on the double-amputee Olympic hopeful Oscar Pistorius.

title: Business Day Live | March 19, 2012
description: Mets owners settle Madoff suit | Apple announces plans to spend its cash | Larry Kantor of Barclays on whether dividends are returning | A peek inside the marketing strategy for The Hunger Games.

title: Prevention: Doctors Weight Affects Obesity Diagnoses
description: Overweight doctors may be less likely than other physicians to discuss diet and exercise with patients, and less likely to make a diagnosis of obesity.

title: Risks: Sugary Drinks Linked to Heart Disease
description: A man who drinks one 12-ounce sugar-sweetened drink a day sharply increases his risk for heart disease, according to a large epidemiological analysis.

title: An Accused Soldiers Family Life, Seen Through a Blog
description: Everything can change in a single instant.

title: Dot Shot: Hudson River Locked in Ice on March 18 (2007)
description: Russ Cusick, a photographer who uses a panoramic camera, posted the image of the Hudson River Valley, above, on his Flickr page over the weekend.

title: Business Day Live: Hollywoods New Marketing Strategy
description: Peter Lattman on the Mets owners settling a Madoff suit; Evelyn M. Rusli on Apples plans to spend its cash; Larry Kantor of Barclays on whether dividends are returning; and a peek inside the marketing strategy for The Hunger Games.

title: Street Style: Peplums
description: The best of readers photos from the week of March 12.

title: For Conservatives on Health Law, Its Repeal or Nothing
description: As Republicans observe the second anniversary of President Obamas signing of the health care law this week, a new motto is emerging that could hurt the laws implementation: Repeal or nothing.

title: Divided Government and the Investor
description: In a recent survey, Gallup asked people with $10,000 or more in investable assets about the factors hurting the investment climate. The deficit and the unemployment rate ranked highly. But a politically divided federal government came in first.

title: Another Smeared Peephole, and an Additional Clue
description: There is a pocket of Manhattan where a bizarre rule of thumb has emerged in recent weeks: coming home to your apartment and finding Vaseline smeared on your peephole is good news.

title: Starting Tonight, Ginnys Supper Club Looks Back in Harlem
description: When Marcus Samuelsson and Andrew Chapman opened Red Rooster a little over a year ago in Harlem, they had a rather featureless downstairs space that was occasionally used for community activities, and increasingly for music. But plans were percolating.

title: Viterra Says It Is in Exclusive Talks on a Sale
description: OTTAWA  Viterra, the Canadian grain marketing and shipping company, confirmed on Monday that it was now in exclusive negotiations with a potential buyer.

title: Denver Defeats Duluth, and Both Teams Head to the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Broncos Go for Greatness Again
description: Peyton Manning, one of the greatest quarterbacks in N.F.L. history, will continue his career with the Denver Broncos, concluding a fevered free-agent pursuit and at the same time perhaps accomplishing something that seemed unthinkable just three months ago: the end of the Broncos career of Tim Tebow.

title: Activist Said to Be Missing in China
description: BEIJING   Liu Ping, a rights activist who has angered officials in China with her advocacy of free elections and support of labor and womens rights issues, has been missing since early this month after she was detained in Beijing by security personnel from her hometown, according to an advocacy group.

title: Links for a Very Early Spring
description: Good: Ag-gag bills are now dead in Illinois, Indiana and Florida.

title: Low-Interest Auto Loans, Thanks to the European Central Bank
description: FRANKFURT  As it moved boldly in recent months to avert a credit squeeze and a rash of bank failures, the European Central Bank might also have subsidized the market rollout of Volkswagens newest subcompact.

title: Payout on Greek Credit Swaps Is Set
description: The payout on credit default swaps linked to Greeces government bonds was decided on Monday, resolving one of the crucial subplots of the European debt crisis.

title: TimesCast | March 19, 2012
description: Clashes erupt in a wealthy area of Damascus | A theatrical success is revealed as flawed journalism.

title: For Delaware, Another First
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.- The University of Delaware womens basketball team made history on Sunday.

title: People Watching | Charles Bello
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: New Look at an Old Memo Casts More Doubt on Rehnquist
description: WASHINGTON  In 1952, a young Supreme Court clerk wrote a memorandum that would come to haunt him.

title: Six Convicted of Conspiracy in Zimbabwe for Watching Arab Spring Videos
description: A judge in Zimbabwe convicted six men on Monday of conspiring against the government after they were arrested last year for watching videos of protests from the Arab Spring, according to the wife of one of the men.

title: Beyonc to Resume Performing in May
description: For the first time since giving birth, Beyonc plans to return to the stage in May with a series of concerts at a new resort in Atlantic City, her publicist, Yvette Noel-Schure, said on Monday. Beyonc, a Grammy-winning singer, will appear over the Memorial Day weekend  on May 25, 26 and 27  to inaugurate a 5,000-seat hall at Revel Resorts, a casino scheduled to open in April.

title: Zimbabwe Convicts 6 Who Viewed Revolt News
description: JOHANNESBURG  Six political activists in Zimbabwe who gathered last year to watch and discuss television news broadcasts of the Arab Spring protests were convicted on Monday of conspiring to commit violence in an effort to overthrow the government.

title: Marist and St. Bonaventure, Two Womens Mid-Majors Headed for Second-Round Clash
description: The feel-good teams of the womens N.C.A.A. tournament have emerged, with Marist and St. Bonaventure capturing hearts and fans with their first-round wins on Sunday.

title: My Beautiful 5-Pound Cabbage
description: Who says farmers markets are too expensive? It depends to a great extent on what you buy, where your market is and which stands you buy from. My farmers market is not in a fancy part of Los Angeles, and the prices reflect this. Last week I couldnt believe the size and beauty of the cabbages one farmer was selling by the piece. I bought one for $2, took it home and weighed it: five pounds on the dot. It made five terrific meals, all with ingredients I had on hand.

title: Scenes From 100% Day
description: Last Fridays 100% Day was an experiment, an unstructured work day for developers, for project and product managers, and for designers at The New York Times. They could choose what they were going to work on, and where, and with whom.

title: Two Graduate Schools Provide Incorrect Data
description: Two colleges  the University of St. Thomas in Minnesota and the University of Houston in Texas  provided faulty data for the latest U.S. News and World Report graduate school rankings, Inside Higher Ed reported on Monday.

title: A Preliminary Guide to the National Mortgage Settlement
description: More than a month ago, the federal government and 49 states announced a $25 billion settlement with the five biggest mortgage servicers to provide help to borrowers who lost their home in a foreclosure or who are having trouble making their mortgage payments.

title: Which Team Is the Best Fit for Tim Tebow?
description: One of the biggest N.F.L. free-agent dramas is over, but it leads right into another off-season potboiler.

title: If Marshall Is Out, Will the Tar Heels Turn to Stilman White?
description: The basketball gods giveth and the basketball gods taketh away.

title: Santorum on the Rope Line
description: Rick Santorum spoke to reporters as he greeted supporters on the rope line.

title: A Wall St. Firm Advises Greece, With Discretion
description: ATHENS  In unmarked offices here on a dusty block choked with strip clubs and burned-out buildings, several dozen employees of a Wall Street firm spent months poring over bank loan portfolios as Greece struggled with its debt crisis.

title: Hollis Framptons Mysterious Woman in White
description: The sped-up stroll through 1968 Manhattan that makes up the middle portion of Hollis Framptons conceptual film Surface Tension has a cast of many hundreds if not thousands: the men, women and children who flash by walking down the street, holding hands, ducking into doorways, reclining on the lawn in Central Park.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Walt Barron joined Peter Mayer Advertising, New Orleans, in a new post, vice president and director for planning and strategic development. He had been a group strategy director at McKinney, Durham, N.C.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: A Sixth Season of Jersey Shore Is Spawned at MTV
description: Despite declining ratings  to say nothing of declining civilization  and the pregnancy of a cast member, MTV isnt ready to say goodbye to Jersey Shore just yet. On Monday the cable channel announced that it had ordered a sixth season of the reality series that gave the world Michael Sorrentino (better known as the Situation) and Nicole Polizzi (a k a Snooki), who in turn will be giving the world a Snooki Jr. in the months to come.

title: Hennessy Goes Wild for the Pursuit of Achievement
description: Captain Ahab had his white whale. Don Quixote had his quest to restore the age of chivalry. Dorothy wanted to find a way to get home to Kansas. Now, a campaign for a Cognac seeks to celebrate aspiration and the pursuit of goals.

title: A Chinese Activist Disappears
description: Liu Ping, the subject two weeks ago of a Female Factor article and a Rendezvous post by Didi Kirsten Tatlow, has disappeared, Chinese human rights activists said on Monday.

title: Federer vs. Isner: Breaking It Down
description: You never exactly know when, if at all, you will have a chance to beat Roger Federer in an ATP Tour final.

title: A Speed Record on the Power Grid
description: Its not Guinness Book of World Records material, but electric company technicians and researchers may have set a speed record in replacing a transformer as part of a drill to determine how the power grid could recover from an attack or a natural disaster.

title: Caucus Click: Santorum Calls Romney a Government Heavyweight
description: Rick Santorum, in response to being called an economic lightweight by Mitt Romney, called the former Massachusetts governor a government heavyweight as he spoke to reporters on Monday morning at a campaign stop in Dixon, Ill.

title: Rocket Plunge to Deep End of the Planet
description: For centuries, the daredevils known as submariners have slipped beneath the waves in vehicles made for horizontal travel. Their craft are basically underwater ships. Even submersibles, small vessels that dive unusually deep, follow the horizontal plan.

title: For Librarian, a Less Wholesome Job That Wasnt
description: Mistaken identity is an occupational hazard for people who are mentioned even fleetingly on the Internet. Still, consider Peter Agrees shock when he searched the Web for references to his mother.

title: Calories Are Everywhere, Yet Hard to Track
description: Americans are having a passionate love affair with something they cannot see, hear, feel, touch or taste. That something is calories, billions upon billions of which are consumed every day, often unwittingly, at and between meals.

title: Throttling Victor Claims His Prize From AT&T
description: Over the weekend, Matt Spaccarelli, the California student who won a small-claims court fight against AT&T over its throttling, or slowing of data, of his smartphone, received the $850 check that the cellphone carrier had to pay in damages. Their fight is over for now, but to Mr. Spaccarelli, the issue of throttling remains largely unaddressed.

title: Really? Carrying a Cold Bottle Aids Exercise
description: THE FACTS

title: A British Invasion of Brands
description: I think Americans are much more into Downton Abbey than we are, Nicky Kinnaird, the British founder of the London-based beauty store Space NK, said recently with a laugh. Thats just fine for us. They may not be able to wear the period clothes in real life, but they can spray on an English scent and feel like theyre there.

title: The White Sox Do a 180
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  When the Chicago White Sox named Robin Ventura their manager in early October, they informed their employees via e-mail. As soon as the message landed, Jerry Reinsdorf heard an emphatic reaction to the hire.

title: Mark Thompson, Head of the BBC, to Step Down
description: Mark Thompson, who has overseen the British Broadcasting Corporations television channels, radio stations and Web sites since 2004, will depart the public broadcaster later this year, he said Monday.

title: Prominent French Families Battle Over a Missing Monet
description: PARIS  More than 70 years after it was plundered by the Nazis, a missing painting by Monet that depicts the shimmering blue rapids of the Creuse River has pitted two of the wealthiest and most prominent families in France against each other.

title: Encyclopedias, Wikipedia and Times Topic Pages: Research Resources and Ideas
description: Last week, Encyclopaedia Britannica announced that, after 244 years, it was going out of print. That inspired us to collect and update our resources and ideas around how and where to research, and to pose questions for students about searching for and using information in the digital age.

title: Santorum Sees Parallels Between Himself and Reagan
description: DIXON, Ill.  Standing before the statue of a young Ronald Reagan on horseback, Rick Santorum repeatedly drew parallels to the insurgency both represented in the Republican Party, and he called on Illinois voters to give him an upset victory in the primary on Tuesday.

title: Bisher, the Loss of a Legend
description: The press room at the upcoming Masters just got a lot quieter and a lot less fun. For the first time in more than 50 years, legendary Atlanta columnist Furman Bisher wont be filling it with his booming laugh and charming cantankerousness. Bisher always showed up like a force of nature, so full of life and bluster that people managed to be surprised when he died Sunday at age 93. He had battled time like he battled his sports column topics, relentlessly and with such flair that you always thought he would win.

title: Case Study | The Pull of Pelforth
description: There are thousands of beers made in or imported to the United States, hundreds of which are dark. I love dozens of them, and certainly appreciate the cornucopia of splendid beers available here. And yet the one I crave in my heart of hearts  and brave ridicule to mention  is a large-production, molasses-dark, blue-collar French beer called Pelforth Brune, brewed since 1937 in the town of Lille, near the Belgian border.

title: Unraveling Some Mystery Surrounding the Homes of a Reclusive Heiress
description: On the top floor of 907 Fifth Avenue, there is an apartment with intricately carved plaster ceilings, dark wood paneling and ancient wood-framed windows, flecked with bits of stained glass, that look out onto the entire expanse of Central Park. But perhaps the most remarkable characteristic of this imposing space is not its detail, but the fact that nobody has lived there for decades.

title: Three Officials Announce Bids to Replace Ackerman
description: At least three elected officials in Queens have decided to compete against one another in the Democratic primary in June to fill the seat of Representative Gary L. Ackerman, who unexpectedly announced his retirement last week.

title: Uganda Attempts to Counter Image Presented by Kony 2012
description: He has posted a long video to YouTube and sent Twitter messages to celebrities, but so far Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi of Uganda has yet to match the explosive virality of the original campaign against the wanted warlord Joseph Kony.

title: Viruses Recruited as Killers of Tumors
description: THE HYPOTHESIS

title: How Minnesota Won the Womens Hockey Title
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Romney Assails Regulatory Drain on Economy
description: CHICAGO  Mitt Romney came to the University of Chicago Monday afternoon, the day before Illinoisans head to the polls to vote in their Republican primary, and assailed President Obamas economic policies in a 19-minute speech that was the first major policy address he has given in weeks.

title: After Critics Notice, Mad Men Replaces a Song, for Historic Accuracy
description: Much of the recent coverage of the return of Mad Men has celebrated the shows scrupulous attention to 1960s detail. On Monday, TV reporters got a sense of how seriously the shows creator, Matthew Weiner, takes that obligation.

title: Ebola: Advances Suggest Possible Cures for Fearsome Hemorrhagic Fevers
description: Ebola and its relatives, like Marburg virus, above, are considered among the most fearsome in nature. People infected with these long, wire-shaped filoviruses often bleed to death from every orifice, so the bugs make ideal villains for apocalyptic films like Outbreak and 28 Days Later.

title: Bartender Will Bring His Busy Past to The Butterfly
description: The bar program at The Butterfly  the new Michael White restaurant scheduled to open in TriBeCa this summer  will be part Wisconsin, part Eben Freeman.

title: A Map of Taste
description: Q. Are taste buds really divided into sections on the tongue that sense four different flavors?

title: TimesCast | Fighting in Damascus
description: March 19, 2012 - In Syria on Monday, clashes erupted in a wealthy district of Damascus.

title: Why Titans Might Have Missed on Manning
description: For the last few weeks, the Titans owner Bud Adams has been reminding people that hes 89 years old. He did so again on Monday in an interview with The Tennessean, upon learning that the Titans would not land Peyton Manning.

title: Verizon Fined $140,000 After Electrocution Death
description: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | Verizon was fined more than $140,000  the maximum allowed by law  for safety violations after the 2011 electrocution death of a technician in Brooklyn, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced on Monday.

title: Killings of Officer and 5 Others Detailed as Mob Trial Begins
description: The off-duty police officer was ambushed by gunmen, and left to die in the street outside his home in Brooklyn.

title: Other Voices: When Narrative Comes Before Truth
description: The environment writer Keith Kloor, blogging on climate and communication at Collide-a-Scape and the Yale Forum on Climate Change and the Media,* is an able and dogged pursuer of reality amid heaps of online invective and hype.

title: The New York Times Magazine in Amsterdam
description: Starting Thursday, March 22, The New York Times Magazine Photographs exhibition at Foam museum in Amsterdam will be showing photographs that have appeared in the magazine over the past 30 years. The exhibition is co-curated by Kathy Ryan, our photo director, and Lesley Martin of Aperture Books, and will feature works from contributing photographers like Lee Friedlander, Nan Goldin, Jeff Koons, Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. Below, a selection of memorable photographs that will be on display.

title: TimesCast | Theater as Flawed Journalism
description: March 19, 2012 - A theatrical success is revealed as flawed journalism.

title: Daisey Revises Steve Jobs Monologue After Dispute Over Facts
description: Mike Daisey, the theater monologist who has come under criticism for embellishing details about a Chinese factory for his one-man show about Apple, The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, changed some of the disputed language during the shows final performances at the Public Theater over the weekend, according to a spokesman for Mr. Daisey and executives at the Public.

title: Political Malpractice, Deficit Edition
description: Greg Sargent has more bang-your-head-against-the-wall material about the Obama administrations pivot to deficits. Quoting a new book by David Corn:

title: How Long Does It Take to Recover From a Marathon?
description: I ran my first marathon this month. It went well, and despite my fears, I had fun. I met my goals  qualified for the Boston Marathon with nearly half an hour to spare and came in second in my age group. But the big surprise was my coachs advice the next day.

title: Added Sugars Pile Up on Childrens Plates
description: Older children consume more sugar than younger ones do, boys consume more than girls, and white children consume more than black or Mexican-American children, according to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics. And they all consume too much.

title: Santorum Writings Voice Strikingly Consistent Views
description: He objected to Mitt Romneys insistence that the tenets of Mormonism are not in conflict with traditional Christianity. He said there was good reason to doubt the theory of evolution and argued that intelligent design should be taught in schools. And when critics questioned Rick Santorum on even the most innocuous matters, like his support for stronger federal oversight of pet stores, he fired back.

title: Carr and Stelter on a Retraction by This American Life
description: David Carr, the Media Equation columnist, wrote on Monday  about the decision by the public radio show This American Life to retract an episode on the factories in China that make Apple devices. The episode was based on a one-man show by Mike Daisey, The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs. Mr. Carr and Brian Stelter discussed the differences between theater and journalism.

title: Desperate Housewives Case Ends in Mistrial
description: LOS ANGELESLike so much else in Desperate Housewives, the motivation behind Edie Britts death will remain a mystery for at least a little longer.

title: Lani Kai
description: 525 Broome Street (Sullivan Street), SoHo; (646) 596-8778; lanikainy.com.

title: Numberplay: Picking Items from a Bag
description: Probability calculations are notoriously tricky, and the correct answers are often counterintuitive. As Martin Gardner put it: In no other branch of mathematics is it so easy for experts to blunder as in probability theory. In the early days of probability, it was commonplace for even great mathematicians to make mistakes. Nowadays the theory is well-established, and straightforward techniques for determining probabilities are available. But even in modern times, experts can often get egg on their faces in simple probability problems, as was seen in the famous brouhaha caused by the Monty Hall problem.

title: Dont Know Much About (Musical) History
description: Too funny not to share. From SXSW, a cute sing-along of This land is your land, led by Bruce Springsteen:

title: Now, About Your Bracket (Monday Edition)
description: With the first week of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament complete, the value of The Quads analysis on the statistics most correlated to reaching the Final Four has become clearer.

title: U.S. War Game Sees Perils of Israeli Strike Against Iran
description: WASHINGTON  A classified war simulation held this month to assess the repercussions of an Israeli attack on Iran forecasts that the strike would lead to a wider regional war, which could draw in the United States and leave hundreds of Americans dead, according to American officials.

title: Under Pressure From Regulator, MBIA Pays No Bonuses
description: MBIA did not award bonuses to its top executives in 2011, but only after its regulator pressured the beleaguered bond insurer to withhold the payouts, people briefed on the matter said.

title: The Annual Appointment Loses Some Relevance
description: For nearly three generations, women have been taught that annual Pap smears, mammograms and visits with their doctor were essential to good health.

title: $200 Million Write-Down for John Carter, Disney Says
description: Walt Disney Studios said on Monday that it would take a write-down of about $200 million tied to the science-fiction megaflop John Carter.

title: Report on Ousted China Official Shows Effort at Damage Control
description: BEIJING  Communist Party leaders sacked Bo Xilai, the powerful party chief of metropolitan Chongqing, after being told that he had schemed to remove his police chief and impede a corruption investigation involving his family, according to a preliminary report on Mr. Bos actions circulated among government officials.

title: Lani Kai
description: Inside the cocktail lounge in SoHo, which has expanded its dinner menu to include Hawaiian-inspired dishes.

title: Gut Infections Are Growing More Lethal
description: Gastrointestinal infections are killing more and more people in the United States and have become a particular threat to the elderly, according to new data released last week.

title: Caucus Click: A Taste of Jazz for Romney in Illinois
Double Trouble From Mountain Pine Beetles?
description: The evolution of mountain pine beetles to produce two generations of beetle per year instead of one has probably been a factor in the unparalleled damage that insects have caused in pine forests in the western United States and Canada over the last decade, according to a new study.

title: Digital Notes: Judge Sides With Megaupload Over Police Raid
description: Judge Faults Police Over Megaupload Raid: In the latest twist in the story of Megaupload, a New Zealand judge has ruled that the police used the wrong kind of order when raiding the home of the sites founder, Kim Dotcom, leaving open the possibility that millions in assets could be returned to him. Justice Judith Potter of the High Court concluded that in carrying out the raid on Mr. Dotcoms home in Auckland in January, the police made a mistake by using a restraining order that gave Mr. Dotcom no chance to offer a defense, according to a report by The New Zealand Herald. Justice Potter granted a new order on a temporary basis, but said she would still rule on whether Mr. Dotcom would be get his property back.

title: Apple Sells 3 Million New iPads in First Weekend
description: 5:09 p.m. | Updated  Adding information on preorders.

title: In the Kellogg Family, Dads in a Booth, Nicks at the Hoop
description: NASHVILLE  The Ohio sophomore guard Nick Kellogg hit two critical 3-point shots late in the second half to propel the No. 13 Bobcats to the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Williams Partners to Buy Caiman Eastern Midstream for $2.5 Billion
description: Williams Partners agreed on Monday to buy Caiman Eastern Midstream, a subsidiary of Caiman Energy that focuses on processing shale gas and liquids in the Marcellus Shale, for $2.5 billion, in the latest deal in the oil and natural gas patch.

title: Times Square Lights Up Citys Economy, Study Finds
description: Times Square may be the place hardened New Yorkers go out of their way to avoid, but its importance as a magnet for commerce as well as tourists has risen rapidly in the last few years, according to a study to be released this week.

title: Romney Misleads on Obama and Energy Prices
description: In a television interview on Sunday and a Web video released on Monday, Mitt Romney said that President Obama has sought higher gasoline and energy prices and called on the president to dismiss three cabinet officers Mr. Romney claims have abetted him.

title: Walking Dead Finale Caps Record Season
description: The season finale of AMCs horror drama The Walking Dead posted spectacular ratings on Sunday night and was the most-watched episode in the series.

title: The Link Between Reading Level and Dropout Rates
description: In 2010, President Obama, along with Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, Gen. Colin Powell and his wife, Alma Powell, co-chairwoman of Americas Promise Alliance, a youth organization, introduced Grad Nation, a plan to reverse Americas high school dropout rate. Even putting aside the obvious benefits to individual students, they argued that high school graduates fuel the economy, while dropouts cost taxpayer dollars. The alliances latest report, issued on Monday, shows that were making progress, but not fast enough  and highlights some of the reasons that every year, more than a million students dont make it to graduation on time, if at all.

title: At Heart of Health Law Clash, a 1942 Case of a Farmers Wheat
description: WASHINGTON  If the Obama administration persuades the Supreme Court to uphold its health care overhaul law, it will be in large part thanks to a 70-year-old precedent involving an Ohio farmer named Roscoe C. Filburn.

title: A Night of Winners and Almost Winners
description: Part of the fascination of singing competitions is the lovely, flawed idea that you can use them to extrapolate the current and future states of opera.

title: Greeces Socialist Party Changes Leaders
description: ATHENS  Greeces finance minister, Evangelos Venizelos, formally assumed the leadership of the beleaguered Socialist Party on Monday, saying he would strive to put the country back on the path to economic recovery and restore the faith of austerity-weary citizens.

title: Cheers Come Early at an Old-Fashioned Affair
description: Throughout the first movement of Griegs Violin Sonata No. 2 in G, there is a restless triplet theme. The violinist plays it; the pianist nervously echoes. They chase their way up and down the scale before the movement seems to close with a flourish, the violinist playing two sweeping chords in the works home key.

title: Even Before Broadway Openings, Newsies and Evita Show Box Office Strength
description: The new Disney stage musical Newsies got off to a strong start on Broadway last week, grossing $735,991 for its first six preview performances at the Nederlander Theater  or about $123,000 per performance, more than the musical Rent grossed when it set the Nederlander house record of $864,321 for eight performances in 2008. The new box office data was released on Monday at the same time that Disney Theatrical Productions  which mounts the film studios properties on Broadway  announced that Newsies would run through August 19, instead of closing as originally planned on June 10.

title: Mick Taylor to Play the Iridium
description: Mick Taylor, the guitarist best known for his work with the Rolling Stones during the early 1970s, will perform six shows at the Iridium in May, the club announced on Monday. Mr. Taylor joined the Stones in 1969 at 20 after playing with John Mayalls Bluesbreakers for several years. He brought a smooth, lyrical guitar style to the bands often jagged sound and is credited with helping shape some of its best albums, among them Let It Bleed, Sticky Fingers and Exile on Main Street.

title: Slimmer Majority of Americans Champions Renewables, Poll Finds
description: The partisan battle over the cause of the increase in gasoline prices has escalated as the average price of a gallon has crept closer to $4, with Republicans accusing President Obama for investing too much in alternative sources of energy at the expense of conventional fuels and Democrats blaming geopolitics and instability around the Persian Gulf.

title: Illinois Tip Sheet: Must-Reads From a Political Pro
description: Illinois might be the Land of Lincoln and Barack Obama, but its just as famous for Al Capone and Rod Blagojevich.

title: Storms Passed, an R&B Realist Sings of Survival
description: The soul singer Bettye LaVette knows about suffering. In her rendition of the grinding blues lament The Forecast (Calls for Pain), at the Caf Carlyle last week, this song of deep foreboding culminated with her repeated feral cries of the word pain.

title: Singing Gershwin Ella Style, Salt Added
description: Who would dispute that George and Ira Gershwin, Ella Fitzgerald and Nelson Riddle were pop-jazz Olympians whose combined talents on the 1959 album Ella Fitzgerald Sings the George and Ira Gershwin Song Book resulted in a masterpiece of the LP era? Any notion of recreating that album, or even part of it, in concert is a daunting challenge. The list of contemporary musicians who could equal their talents is very short.

title: Jets Fill Hole by Signing Safety LaRon Landry
description: The Jets bolstered their depleted safety ranks Monday by signing LaRon Landry, who spent the previous five seasons with Washington. Landry, the Redskins first-round pick in 2007, joins the starter Eric Smith and Tracy Wilson as the only safeties under contract for the Jets.

title: The Get | Alexandra Moosallys Carrot Necklace
description: This spring, the jewelry designer Alexandra Moosally is adding edibles to her selection of whimsical gold and pav pieces. The most delicious one of the bunch: a carrot charm necklace made of 18-karat rose gold with sparkling white diamond tops. I grew up in a large Mediterranean family with a lot of focus on food, says Moosally, who also added an apple (for New York City), an artichoke (her favorite) and a cherry (for the girly girls) to her Foodie collection this season. More than a menu item, too, the carrot is symbolic of Moosallys past life as a lawyer. (She practiced law for eight years; the carrot and stick idiom, in which the stick stands for punishment and the carrot for reward, is one she keeps close.) Consider us on our best behavior.

title: Woman Leaves Trail of Trash-Can Fires in Midtown
description: A woman who the authorities said was in her 50s led police officers and firefighters on a chase through Midtown Manhattan on Monday for more than an hour, as she set at least 15 trash cans on fire.

title: Supreme Court Challenges to Obamas Health Care Law
description: Over three days starting March 26, the Supreme Court heard challenges to President Obamas signature achievement, the 2010 health care law.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, Egypt, Afghanistan and Indonesia.

title: What Hath Bell Labs Wrought? The Future
description: In todays world of Apple, Google and Facebook, the name may not ring any bells for most readers, but for decades  from the 1920s through the 1980s  Bell Labs, the research and development wing of AT&T, was the most innovative scientific organization in the world. As Jon Gertner argues in his riveting new book, The Idea Factory, it was where the future was invented.

title: Readers Respond: Robert Bales and the Strain of War
description: Last Friday, we asked you, our readers, to write in with your thoughts on what the case of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales means inside the military, and what implications the killings might have for the larger war effort. You didnt disappoint in your responses. With nuanced and thoughtful comments, At War readers took up the issues that existed well before the case against Sergeant Bales created a reason for so much introspection across the armed services.

title: Pastors Fiery Remarks at Santorum Rally Reverberate
description: Rick Santorum attended a revival-type church service on Sunday night in Louisiana, where the Rev. Dennis Terry, pastor of the Greenwell Springs Baptist Church, offered some fire and brimstone in a videotaped sermon that on Monday was going viral because of his fiery comments.

title: The Bronts Are Here to Mess With Your Head
description: I feel like Ive just been to therapy.

title: Amid Wall Street Giants, a Firm Thinks Small and Exclusive
description: When courting new business, Wall Streets deal makers often point to their long client lists as proof of deep industry knowledge.

title: Ruffled Feathers on the Way to Swanhood
description: Too sophisticated for its intended audience and too shrill for the grown-ups in tow, Lucky Duck is a rare miscalculation for the New Victory Theater. This raucous reboot of The Ugly Duckling fable ends up nestling uneasily between bratty and brainy. Its neither fish nor waterfowl.

title: Amazon.com to Acquire Manufacturer of Robotics
description: Amazon.com is buying an army of robots.

title: To Infinity and Beyond: Bart, Lucy and the Gang
description: We who live within get-the-shotgun distance of Grovers Mill, the spot in central New Jersey that Orson Welles chose for his panic-inducing War of the Worlds landing in 1938, are naturally reluctant to endorse the promulgation of fake alien arrivals via a broadcast medium. But theres a darned good one in progress on the Science Channel, part of a month of programs on the theme Are We Alone?

title: Family Trees Startling Roots
description: Thirty-nine lashes well laid on her bare back and an extension of her indentured servitude was Elizabeth Bankss punishment for fornication & Bastardy with a negroe slave, according to a stark June 20, 1683, court document from York County, Va. Through the alchemy of celebrity and genealogy, that record and others led to the recent discovery that Banks, a free white woman despite her servitude, was the paternal ninth great-grandmother of Wanda Sykes, the ribald comedian and actress.

title: Sony Extends Contract of Music Executive
description: Sony has extended the contract of the man who will oversee its music publishing business, a division that is poised to greatly expand if Sonys bid for EMI is approved.

title: Albums From Wiz Khalifa, Melanie Fiona and Lost in the Trees
description: WIZ KHALIFA

title: A Master of Timing, Even When the Music Has No Beat
description: The gala for the Paul Taylor Dance Company last week featured a film that began by telling the history of American modern dance in three stages: First there was Martha Graham, then there was Merce Cunningham, then there was Paul Taylor, who let the sun shine in. A burst of applause followed from the audience, and then the film turned its focus to Mr. Taylors Aureole, created 50 years ago.

title: More About Chefs, Their Recipes and Who Writes Cookbooks
description: What is a ghostwriter, anyway?

title: Uptown Palazzo Project
description: When the Andrew Freedman Home opened in the Bronx in 1924, it looked like a limestone luxury liner sailing up the Grand Concourse, a grandiosity that advertised its odd function: a privately endowed retirement home for the formerly well-to-do, those who might have lost their money but not their manners or manorial tastes.

title: Strolling in the Park, Succumbing to Temptation
description: If New York City Opera is to have any success in its new manifestation as a scaled-down, roving company, then every production will have to be a must-see event. It finally has one, with the director Christopher Aldens new production of Mozarts Cos Fan Tutte, which opened at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College on Sunday afternoon.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Mobile Data Leaks, and Rising and Falling Game Apps
description: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

title: By Her (Couture) Hair You Shall Know Her
description: IT wasnt your traditional sample sale. On a recent lunch hour, a stream of well-coiffed professional women descended upon a salon in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. They werent tearing through boxes of designer shoes or ripping through racks of clothing. These women came looking for something more personal: wigs.

title: Santorum Waves Away Economics
description: MOLINE, Ill.  Defying almost all conventional wisdom about the 2012 election, Rick Santorum said the race would not turn on the economy and so it wasnt important if unemployment and growth rates rose or fell.

title: In Illinois, Santorums Chance at Nomination Is Slipping Away
description: A quick glance at the map might tempt you into thinking that the Republican nomination is roughly an even battle between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, with Mr. Romney tending to prevail in the Northeast and the West, and Mr. Santorum in the Midwest and the South.

title: British Journalists Held for a Month in Libya Had Reported on Revenge Attacks
description: Two British journalists detained last month by a Libyan militia that accused them of spying were released without charge by Libyas government and allowed to fly home on Monday, Reuters reports.

title: For E.V. Drivers, a Stretch of Oregon Interstate to Relieve Range Anxiety
description: Until better batteries are developed, most electric cars will be range-challenged. But with the opening of the first section of the so-called West Coast Electric Highway on March 16 in Oregon, battery vehicles can travel for longer distances, at least along and immediately beyond the corridor.

title: Hi! Im a Nutria
description: In this animated short by the filmmaker Drew Christie, a rodent living in Washington State defends criticism that he is an invasive species and asks, How long does it take to become a native?

title: Paul Taylor Dance Company
description: Scenes from works in repertory at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: Scouting the Draft: Wisconsins Peter Konz
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofDallasCowboysTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Hi! Im a Nutria
description: According to family legend, my grandfather and his brother, after realizing that they were knee deep in a losing venture, released their nutria in western Washington State in the early 1960s. They had been raising the rodents to sell for their fur, which would be made into coats and hats. Since my grandfather died before I was born, I have never been able to fully corroborate these events. However, this episode has forever been emblazoned in my mind as both an act of short-sighted ecological vandalism and a sign of humanity.

title: The Perfect Proposal: A Victory and a Yes
description: TUCSON  As competitions go, the USA Swimming Grand Prix meet last month was decidedly low-key, another in a series of mile markers leading to the Olympic trials in June. So why, before the 100-meter backstroke final, did Matt Grevers feel as nervous as he had at the 2008 Summer Games in Beijing?

title: Oprah Winfrey Network to Lay Off 30
description: OWN, Oprah Winfreys cable channel, said on Monday that it had decided to lay off 30 people in a restructuring of its operations in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Automation Is Considered for Checking IDs in Airports
description: The Transportation Security Administration has spent a lot of money on technology to keep dangerous items off planes  with mixed results  but has been slower to address another risk: travelers who are using a fake boarding pass or identification.

title: The Siren Song of Energy Efficiency
Spring Gets Ahead of Itself
description: THE first day of spring isnt what it used to be. In fact, over the past several decades spring weather has been arriving earlier in most parts of the United States. This shift affects all aspects of life  from when flowers bloom to when animals migrate and have babies  the very things that make spring magical.

title: Strained by Sanctions, Iran Eases Money Policy
description: Pressured by tightened Western economic sanctions and a burgeoning black market for dollars, with Iranian citizens desperate to buy them, Irans central bank has loosened its strict foreign exchange policy, allowing money traders there to sell dollars for rials at the unofficial market rate, rather than the artificially fixed official rate.

title: Being Human
description: Im going to be doing family stuff the next two days; little if any blogging.

title: At Prospect Park, a Transformation Is Behind Schedule
description: Inside the fencing proclaiming Lakeside is for you at the southeastern end of Prospect Park, tractors sat beneath a canopy covering a future outdoor hockey rink.

title: Reimagining Prospect Park
description: A major construction project expected to be completed in fall 2013 will bring the park closer to the original vision of its designers, Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux.

title: Honeymoons for Coaches Can End Abruptly
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Being Acquisitive, With an Emphasis on More Media Muscle
description: IT is dj vu all over again, Madison Avenue style, as an agency holding group is, for the second time in two months, buying a leading independent media shop.

title: Supreme Court Examines Roles of Jury and Judge in Setting Fines
description: WASHINGTON  The ostensible question at a Supreme Court argument on Monday was how large a role the jury must play in setting fines against corporations found guilty of environmental crimes. But the real issue in the case, as the justices questioning made clear, was whether the court remained committed to the logic of a 2000 decision that said the Constitution sometimes bars judges from making factual findings that lead to increased punishments.

title: Arnold S. Relman and Marcia Angell
description: A video interview with two former editors of The New England Journal of Medicine who for decades have been warning of a growing medical industrial complex.

title: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory.

title: A Drumbeat on Profit Takers
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The old crusaders are getting just a little creaky: Dr. Arnold S. Relman, 88, has a hearing aid and the hint of a tremor; Dr. Marcia Angell, 72, osteoporosis and arthritic hands. But their voices are as strong as ever.

title: The Boycott Question in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: It Might as Well Be Kentucky and the Round of 15
description: Nashville

title: What Do Declining Birthrates Mean for the World?
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit for Online Content
description: To the Editor:

title: The Health Law Mandate
description: To the Editor:

title: Romney Makes Final Pitch to Illinois Voters
description: PEORIA, Ill.  On the eve of the Republican primary in Illinois, Mitt Romney made his final pitch to voters at Bradley University on Monday night, where he lambasted the policies of President Obama for attacking economic freedom day in and day out.

title: Publicity Push as Health Laws Court Date Nears
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Capitol Hill have put together a highly coordinated two-week renewed assault on the health care law, seizing on the legislations second anniversary and the next weeks oral arguments before the Supreme Court concerning its constitutionality.

title: Photo Replay: March 19
description: A view of the day in sports, a tough one for the Tigers new third baseman, Miguel Cabrera.

title: Brooklyn Voters to Fill State Senate Vacancy
description: Three months after State Senator Carl Kruger resigned and pleaded guilty to bribery, voters in south Brooklyn on Tuesday will choose his successor for the 27th District in a special election.

title: Republicans Seek Tax Simplification
description: Republicans on the House Budget Committee on Tuesday will propose a drastically simplified tax system that strips away tax deductions and credits, eliminates tax brackets and leaves only two individual tax rates, 10 percent and 25 percent.

title: An Air Travel Manifesto From Fliers Themselves
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I offered some suggestions for a draft of an On the Road Column Airline Consumer Manifesto. This is an interim follow-up, with comments and suggestions from readers.

title: Helton Welcomes Old College Buddy to Denver
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  An old college buddy of Todd Heltons is moving to Denver. A fellow named Peyton Manning.

title: From Colts to  Broncos? The Wild Ride of Peyton Manning
description: If the two-week Peyton Manning Derby felt like a whirlwind to fans, imagine how it must have felt for Manning. The life of an in-demand millionaire may appear glamorous on the surface, but a closer look reveals a long succession of endless meetings, carefully choreographed flights, and long rides in suspicious-looking vehicles. Here is a recap of the major events of a 15-day turning point in N.F.L. history.

title: A Desperate Housewives Mistrial
description: LOS ANGELES  Like so much else in Desperate Housewives, the motivation behind Edie Britts death will remain a mystery for at least a little longer.

title: For 2nd Year, a Sharp Drop in Law School Entrance Tests
description: Legal diplomas are apparently losing luster.

title: U.S. Completes Sale of Mortgage-Backed Securities, Earning $25 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department announced on Monday that it had finished selling the $225 billion in mortgage-backed securities it bought to help stabilize the markets during the worst of the financial crisis.

title: Mets and Madoff Victims Trustee Now Unlikely Allies
description: The settlement between the owners of the Mets and the trustee representing the victims of the fraud orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff ends a rancorous legal fight between two parties that were willing to dig in their heels and openly point fingers.

title: BP Settlement, Milestone for Some Victims, a Setback for Others
description: Denise Spivacke Haralson and her husband, Larry, figured that they almost had their money. They had settled Mr. Haralsons claims against BP for the losses he suffered as a construction worker in the economic slump after the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: Growing Antitax Movement Shows Irish Stoicism Wearing Thin
description: DUBLIN  Throughout the European financial crisis, Ireland has won plaudits for the way it has handled austerity. But growth has stalled here once again, and an incipient tax revolt is being taken as a sign that even this most stoic of nations is becoming fed up.

title: Mortars and Other Sundries That Interest Customs
description: MY parents tell me my first real trip was on a Polish sea boat when I was about 2 years old. I must have enjoyed it a lot, because today traveling doesnt bother me at all. Ive learned to just take things as they come.

title: Make the Punishment Fit the Cyber-Crime
description: New Haven

title: A Journal Stands Out in Prestige and Longevity
description: It is an antique that outperforms all the newer models: The first issues of The New England Journal of Medicine were peeled off a hand-operated letterpress in January 1812, and two centuries later it remains the oldest continuously published general medical journal in the world, and the most prestigious.

title: Air Canada Supplier Falters, Then Airline Offers Reprieve
description: OTTAWA  The company that acquired most of Air Canadas aircraft maintenance operation locked out about 2,300 employees on Monday and filed for court protection from creditors.

title: Suspect Was Once Accused of Financial Fraud
description: The soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians this month ran afoul of financial regulations more than a decade ago when he worked as a stockbroker. He was fined for defrauding a couple from Columbus, Ohio, and when the fine was not paid he was suspended from the brokerage industry, officials said on Monday.

title: The Military Path to Justice Could Be Lengthy
description: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales has yet to be formally accused of the act that the Army suspects him of committing: the nighttime massacre of 16 Afghan civilians in a village a mile from his post.

title: Sharp Response Meets Return of Protesters
description: In September they began to gather, their encampment growing by the week. The police, confronted with a populist movement that put down roots in the financial district, were unsure of how to respond to Occupy Wall Street. At some marches, protesters were arrested for veering off the sidewalk into the street; at others, the police ordered protesters off the sidewalk.

title: When the Good Do Bad
description: Its always interesting to read the quotations of people who knew a mass murderer before he killed. They usually express complete bafflement that a person who seemed so kind and normal could do something so horrific.

title: Use of Conflict Minerals Gets More Scrutiny From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  An iPhone can do a lot of things. But can it arm Congolese rebels?

title: The Sentence as a Miniature Narrative
description: I like to imagine a sentence as a boat. Each sentence, after all, has a distinct shape, and it comes with something that makes it move forward or stay still  whether a sail, a motor or a pair of oars. There are as many kinds of sentences as there are seaworthy vessels: canoes and sloops, barges and battleships, Mississippi riverboats and dinghies all-too-prone to leaks. And then there are the impostors, flotsam and jetsam  a log heading downstream, say, or a coconut bobbing in the waves without a particular destination.

title: Chess Players Whose Moves Most Matched Computers
description: Chess Players Whose Moves Most Matched Computers

title: On Primarys Eve, Romney Cuts to General Election
description: CHICAGO  Republican voters have yet to give Mitt Romney a green light to begin a formal campaign against President Obama, so Mr. Romney paid a visit to the presidents old neighborhood here on Monday for yet another audition to show he is tough enough to win the general election.

title: To Detect Cheating in Chess, a Professor Builds a Better Program
description: When it comes to cheating, chess might seem all but invulnerable. After all, the board and its pieces are out in the open for all to see.

title: A Wave of Military Memoirs With You-Are-There Appeal
description: Julie Bosman, a media reporter for The New York Times, writes: Bookstores have been flooded with first-person accounts that have emerged from the wars, especially by members of the Navy SEALs, that offer insider looks at combat and harrowing real-life drama.

title: Many Kinds of Catholic
description: If Catholicism is measured by obeisance to the pope, his cardinals and the letter of Vatican law, then Rick Santorum is the best Catholic to ever get this far in presidential politics.

title: Senate Seeks to Toughen a Bill Aimed at Start-Ups
description: WASHINGTON  A decade after the dot-com bubble popped and Enron became synonymous with spectacular fraud, Congress is on the verge of scrapping numerous safeguards against investment fraud and allowing some small companies to sell stock to the public with minimal disclosure or oversight.

title: Squashed Eyeballs Are a Danger for Astronauts
description: Space is not good for your eyes  unless you are nearsighted, in which case it might help a bit.

title: New Congressional Lines Imposed by Federal Court
description: ALBANY  A panel of federal judges, lamenting what they called an unwelcome failure of state government, imposed on Monday a court-drawn revision of New Yorks Congressional districts.

title: Broncos Fans Rejoice Before the Ink Is Dry
description: DENVER  Dusty DeGroff is a lifelong Broncos fan. He also fervently backs Tim Tebow.

title: Honeybees Benefit From Queens Promiscuity
description: Scientists have long wondered why honeybee queens, compared with other social insects, are so promiscuous  why mating with many males seems to result in a healthier hive.

title: Ferns Fling Their Spores With a One-Two Catapult
description: Unlike most other plants, ferns reproduce without seeds or flowers. Instead, they use spores, which are flung out into the world by a structure called an annulus, which sits on the underside of the leaves.

title: The Mets Switch Teams
description: Fifteen months ago, Irving Picard, the trustee managing the Madoff bankruptcy, and Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, reached an astonishing settlement with the widow of one of Bernard Madoffs wealthiest investors.

title: Keeping Score: Team May Need to Keep Wright for Fan Base
description: When Fred Wilpon returns to Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Tuesday, feeling triumphant, he will encounter a Mets team that has played poorly this spring and done little to dispel the notion that the 2012 season will be long and difficult.

title: Doubt Cast on Defendants Romantic E-Mails
description: A lovelorn defendant accused of conspiring with a former Yonkers city councilwoman to sell her vote was accused on Monday of fabricating e-mails in which he expressed desire for her, a one-sided relationship that has been the heart of his defense in a federal corruption trial in Manhattan.

title: A Refreshing Twist
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This might not matter to solvers as much as it matters to constructors. Sooner or later, though, I have to believe it will matter to you.

title: In Crackdown on Unlicensed Taxis, City Runs Out of Room
description: In a bid to clear the streets of unlicensed taxis, dozens of newly hired officers at the Taxi and Limousine Commission have, in recent weeks, flagged down, fined and seized so many cars that New York City has run out of space to keep them.

title: Candidates Disclose Fund-Raising
description: President Obama raised $45 million in February, his campaign announced on Monday, a significant increase over the $29.1 million he raised in January. Mitt Romney raised $11.5 million for the same month, according to his campaign. And Rick Santorums campaign said on Monday that he had raised more than $9 million, almost as much as Mr. Romney.

title: The States Get a Poor Report Card
description: State governments have long been accused of backroom dealing, cozy relationships with moneyed lobbyists, and disconnection from ordinary citizens. A new study suggests those accusations barely scratch the surface.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 19, 2012

title: At UConn, Freshmans Jersey Fits Her Just Fine
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Maybe Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis had a little nerve for asking to wear the No. 23 jersey at Connecticut only months after Maya Moore, the four-time, first-team all-American, was done with it. But No. 23 has been Mosqueda-Lewiss number, too.

title: Before Games, Workers Win a Big Event
description: LONDON   Enveloped in a warm, glimmering haze, the Olympic Stadium looks like a vast, silvery spaceship come to unlikely rest in the working-class East End.

title: You Scratch My Back. ...
description: With their eye on campaign cash, President Obama and lawmakers from both parties have decided they can all get more from corporate constituents if they cooperate to enact legislation that big donors want.

title: In Texas Tradition, Museums That Enshrine the Quirky
description: McLEAN, Tex.  No one can remember if the brassiere factory on Kingsley Street here put up barbed wire to keep intruders out. These days, hundreds of strands of barbed wire draw people in.

title: Injustice in a Sentencing Law
description: The Armed Career Criminal Act has long been a source of confusion for federal judges who are required to apply it in criminal cases. The act ratchets up sentences to a mandatory minimum of 15 years for felons who illegally possess guns and have three prior violent felony convictions. Some judges have misinterpreted this statute, with grievous results, as happened in the case of John Joel Foster. He could end up serving 15 years in prison rather than 27 months for possession of a firearm because the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit wrongly categorized 20-year-old crimes as violent felonies.

title: Seeding the Southern Continent
description: The word is propagule. It means any detachable part of a plant that can be used for reproduction  a spore, a seed, a broken bit of stem or root. The burrs that stick in your socks after a walk in the woods are propagules. Wherever humans have gone, we have inadvertently carried propagules with us, changing patterns of biodiversity as we do so. As it happens, we carry propagules even to Antarctica, one of earths most pristine places.

title: Interviews with a medical power couple; a disturbing rise in gastric distress; and a filmmaker takes the plunge.
description: Interviews with a medical power couple; a disturbing rise in gastric distress; and a filmmaker takes the plunge.

title: After Dropping Gloves, Rangers Clinch Playoff Spot
description: The Rangers clinched a playoff berth Monday night by beating the Devils, 4-2, but the game at Madison Square Garden will probably be better remembered for a brawl immediately after the opening face-off that will again call into question the role of fighting in hockey.

title: The New Suburban Poverty
description: In many of Americas once pristine suburbs, harbingers of inner-city blight  overgrown lots, boarded up windows, abandoned residences  are the new eyesores. From the Midwestern rust-belt to the burst housing bubbles of Nevada, California and Florida, even in small pockets of still affluent regions like Du Page County, Ill., the nations soaring poverty rates are visibly reclaiming last centurys triumphal crabgrass frontier. In well-heeled Illinois towns like Glen Ellyn and Elgin, unkempt, weedy lawns blot the formerly manicured, uniform and tidy landscape.

title: Sizing Up Louisville and Michigan State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  After a 65-61 victory over ninth-seeded St. Louis on Sunday, No. 1 Michigan State advanced to face fourth-seeded Louisville in the Round of 16. The coming West Region semifinal matchup will present an interesting contrast in personnel.
