title: Ex-Adviser Tells Court He Gave Inside Tips
description: Scott Allen, a former investment adviser, pleaded guilty on Monday to charges that he had supplied nonpublic information to a friend in a $2.6 million insider-trading scheme involving drug company acquisitions.

title: John Cowles Jr., 82, Dies; Led Minneapolis Newspapers
description: John Cowles Jr., a Minneapolis newspaper executive and philanthropist whose support for arts, sports and entertainment helped elevate the Twin Cities cultural community to national prominence, died on Saturday at home in Minneapolis. He was 82.

title: Uganda Tries to Counter Harsh Image in Web Video
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  In its own way, Uganda is trying to claim its moment in an unfortunate spotlight.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,895 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Yemeni Official Puts Uprisings Toll at Over 2,000 Martyrs
description: At least 2,000 Yemenis were killed during the year of political unrest after popular protests broke out seeking the ouster of the entrenched authoritarian president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, Yemens minister of human rights announced in a speech to the United Nations.

title: Correction: March 20
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Word of the Day | frugality
description: frugality \fr-ga-l-te\ noun

title: Florida: Civil Rights Inquiry Into Teenagers Shooting
description: The Justice Department has opened a civil rights investigation into the case of a black teenager killed by a volunteer community watch member in Florida, according to a statement from the department. The teenager, Trayvon Martin, 17, was fatally shot while walking in a gated neighborhood near Orlando on Feb. 26. The volunteer, George Zimmerman, 28, who is white and Hispanic, said he had acted in self-defense. The Justice Departments civil rights division, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States attorneys office for the Middle District of Florida are investigating the facts and circumstances of Mr. Martins death, according to the department statement.

title: Mulgrew to Walcott: Use Loan Forgiveness to Retain Teachers
China: Thief Who Stole Museums Purses Is Sentenced
description: Shi Baikui, a 27-year-old farmer, was sentenced on Monday in Beijing to 13 years in prison for stealing nine 20th-century purses encrusted with gold and jewels from an exhibition at the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City last May. Five of the purses were found on the palace grounds, apparently dropped as the thief fled. The court said that Mr. Shi had thrown away the remaining four purses the day after the theft after realizing they would be hard to sell; three of the purses are still missing. The official Xinhua news agency said that the total value of those three purses was $23,800.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/20/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/20/2012

title: Ibanez Is Fighting to Show Yankees They Made the Right Choice
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Raul Ibanez has a friend who is a member of the Navy SEALs, and he recalled a time in San Diego when his buddy pointed to a patch of the Pacific Ocean.

title: New York Redistricting
description: Compare the old Congressional district boundaries to new ones drawn up by a court-appointed magistrate.

title: Arizona: Giffords Aide Will Seek a Full Term
description: Ron Barber, who was a top aide to Representative Gabrielle Giffords and was injured in the same shooting that nearly killed her, said Monday that he would run this fall in the newly created Southern Arizona Congressional district. Mr. Barber has been campaigning to complete Ms. Giffordss term in a June special election, in which he will face one of four Republicans seeking their partys nomination. Mr. Barber had not publicly said he would not run for the full term in the fall, but several Democrats said last month that they expected him only to complete Ms. Giffordss term. Four Democrats had already begun collecting signatures to get on the ballot for the August primary. Mr. Barber said that he spoke to each of them Monday and that he expected at least two to step out of the race. What I learned quickly is that the campaign is really exciting and energizing, Mr. Barber said Monday. I realized that I might be able to make some impact in half a year, but that it would take longer to make a real impact.

title: Searchers Find Body of Balloon Pilot Who Saved 5 Before Being Swept Off
description: ATLANTA  A hot-air balloon pilot who was swept thousands of feet into the clouds by a surprise storm seconds after five skydivers leapt to safety was found dead in the deep south Georgia woods Monday, his deflated balloon draped over the basket that held his body.

title: An American Jihadist in Somalia Claims His Colleagues Want to Kill Him
description: Updated | Tuesday | 10:52 a.m. Omar Hammami, an Alabama native who traveled to Somalia in 2006 to join a radical Islamist group, has apparently come to regret his choices.

title: A Ferrari Crash in Beijing Leads to More Political Intrigue
description: HONG KONG  The real March Madness, at least in Asia, has been the precipitous fall of Bo Xilai, one of Chinas most flamboyant (and now disgraced) Communist Party bosses. The story has read like a John le Carr rewrite of Raymond Chandler, with the forced singing of red anthems from the Maoist era, rumors of cloak-and-dagger corruption, the Eliot Ness of China staging a late-night attempt to defect to the United States, his subsequent detention by State Security agents (under what is creepily being called vacation-style treatment) and an unprecedented public smackdown of Mr. Bo by Prime Minister Wen Jiabao.

title: Why Germans Believe Joachim Gauck Can Redeem Their Country
description: Germany, mostly, has a squeaky-clean image when it comes to corruption. Transparency International, the global anti-corruption watchdog, ranks Germany 14th least corrupt out of 183 countries in its annual survey, writes Judy Dempsey in her latest Page Two column.

title: News Quiz | March 20, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: Attacks Strike as Iraq Plans to Welcome Arab Leaders
description: BAGHDAD  As Iraq prepares to showcase itself to the world next week with a highly anticipated gathering of Arab leaders, a string of suicide attacks and car bombings on Tuesday morning offered a bloody reminder that insurgent violence still wreaks havoc with the countrys tenuous stability.

title: If Bilingual Is Good, Is Trilingual Better?
description: Being bilingual, it turns out, makes you smarter, Yudhijit Bhattacharjee writes in an op-ed in The New York Times. It can have a profound effect on your brain, improving cognitive skills not related to language and even shielding against dementia in old age.

title: Niners to Alex Smith: Never Mind
description: Awkward.

title: Gunman May Have Filmed Attack at French School
description: TOULOUSE, France  A day after an attack outside a Jewish school here killed a rabbi and three young children, the French authorities offered fresh details on Tuesday of an assault that has stunned the nation and terrorized the city, saying the lone gunman seemed to be filming his actions as he coolly shot his victims to death.

title: March 20, 1995 | Japanese Cult Carries Out Sarin Gas Attack on Tokyo Subway
description: On March 20, 1995, in Tokyo, 12 people were killed and more than 5,500 others sickened when packages containing the poisonous gas sarin leaked on five subway trains.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 20, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the television review The Closet Question: Who Would Wear This Stuff?

title: Culture and Race in Arizona Schools
description: WHO is Matt de la Pea, and WHAT novel did he write?

title: WhoSay Targets Indian Celebrities
description: Celebrities in India are increasingly using social media sites like Facebook and Twitter to connect with their fans  actors Hrithik Roshan and Amitabh Bachan and composer A.R. Rahman are just a few examples of active users.

title: The Best Nanny Money Can Buy
description: It took Zenaide Muneton 20 seconds to convince me that she was the perfect nanny. Short and dark-haired, she has a goofy, beaming smile and knows how to make everything fun for a little kid. Time to brush your teeth? She shakes her hands and does a pantomimed teeth-brushing dance. Bath time? She pumps her arms up and down in a going-to-the-tub march. After I told her Id love to hire her, she smiled and thanked me.

title: Romance and Ruin, All in the Air
description: For the most part, the photographs recount celebratory moments plucked from a history riddled with tragedy. They chronicle the early days of the dirigible, or airship, up to the fateful 1937 crash of the Hindenburg over Lakehurst, N.J., which killed 36 and put a quick end to the age of the airship.

title: Into Thin Air
description: Last month, North Korea agreed to suspend nuclear efforts and missile launches in exchange for U.S. food aid. Last Friday, it announced that it would use a long-range missile to launch a satellite into orbit in mid-April, to mark the 100th anniversary of state founder Kim Il-sungs birthday. Whither the negotiations?

title: Where Is the Line Between Truth and Fiction?
description: On Friday, This American Life retracted its presentation of Mike Daiseys solo theater show The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs after discovering that Mr. Daisey had fabricated portions of it. Is it acceptable that the show  which helped shine a spotlight on labor practices at factories in China that manufacture Apple products  is true in spirit but not, in many ways, in fact? Or, as some critics contend, was Mr. Daisey being disingenuous and misleading in presenting the story as nonfiction when many parts were fictionalized?

title: Syrian Insurgents Accused of Rights Abuses
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Armed Syrian defectors took their uprising into the heart of a heavily guarded and wealthy district of Damascus on Monday, clashing with security forces in what activists and residents called the most intense fighting in such a strategic area since the protests against President Bashar al-Assad began a year ago.

title: Three for Three in College Acceptances, With Nine More to Go
description: A letter. An e-mail. A phone call. All methods that colleges use to notify students of admissions decisions. It seems as if every day, a friend of mine is being accepted somewhere. Every day, certain hopes are being fulfilled, while others are being diminished.

title: The Early Word: Illinois
description: Mitt Romney went to President Obamas Chicago neighborhood on Monday to show how tough he could be if he becomes the Republican presidential nominee. In a Political Memo, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny write that the results in the Illinois primary today could test whether Mr. Romney can regain for good the sense that he will inevitably become the partys nominee.

title: Fantasy Focus: Precious Dollars
description: With Tout Wars, an elite mixed-league auction, coming up this weekend, I am completing the final steps in my preparation. Last season, the 15 teams in the league (which has a $260 budget) purchased 45 players for $1 each. Three of each teams 23 starting spots filled with the minimum bid may not seem all that high, but that does translate to 13 percent of the player pool, which should serve as an indication that there is an art to controlling the endgame by carefully nominating players after your opponents have all fallen to maximum bid positions of $1.

title: The Origin of Modern Republican Fiscal Policy
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take. He also talks with Catherine Rampell about this post on todays Business Day Live video.

title: Deutsche Borse to Appeal Blocked Merger with NYSE Euronext
description: Deutsche Brse has decided to appeal the decision by European antitrust regulators that blocked its planned merger with NYSE Euronext.

title: In India, History Literally Rots Away
description: Nations such as Russia and China destroyed historical documents and artifacts in fits of revolutionary zeal. India has taken a much easier route: it has allowed many priceless papers and other items to slowly disintegrate in, or be stolen from, institutions starved of funding, bereft of proper facilities and trained staff, and lacking proper security.

title: Pakistani Parliament Demands End to U.S. Drone Strikes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A major parliamentary review of relations with the United States opened on Tuesday with calls for an end to drone strikes and for an unconditional apology for an American attack that killed Pakistani soldiers last November.

title: As Woes Recede, Europes Public Offerings Find Favor
description: LONDON  After months of economic uncertainty caused by the European debt crisis, investors are starting to venture back into the Continents financial markets.

title: 2013 SL65 AMG Muscles In on SLS AMG Roadster
description: Though AMG, the in-house performance division at Mercedes-Benz, has been wringing triple-digit horsepower and torque gains from the German brands V-8 engines, its engineers have not wrenched on the automakers stout 6-liter V-12 in a few years.

title: Tensions With Iran: Accidents Can Happen
description: LONDON  It is supposed to be a time of hope and new beginnings for the people of Iran as on Tuesday they began celebrating the 13-day New Year festival of Nowruz. But the omens are not good.

title: Making Sense of Campaign Fund-Raising Totals
description: It has become a ritual every four weeks  the moment when the presidential campaigns reveal how much cash they hauled in over the previous month.

description: TOP STORIES

title: The Mystery of Why Manning Chose Denver
description: For weeks, weve been waiting for Peyton Manning to tell us where. Now were waiting for him to tell us why. Why Denver?

title: After 2 Years of Testing, Venmo Opens Payment Service to Public
description: After more than two years in beta testing, Venmo, a mobile payments service that lets people send money to their friends, is opening its doors to the public on Tuesday.

title: Shares Fall on Concerns of a Slowdown in China
description: Stocks declined on Tuesday, ending a three-day advance for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as commodities fell on concern about a Chinese economic slowdown.

title: Opinion Report: The JOBS Act
description: From the editorial page

title: Of Human Bondage
description: LONDON  After I announced the dates for my wedding last year, colleagues and acquaintances in Pakistan began asking whether I was having a love marriage or an arranged marriage. I didnt think the question was inappropriate or offensive: arranged marriages  in which a third party, often a family member, plays matchmaker with the consent of the couple  remain the norm in conservative societies and across many socioeconomic groups. I had expected to be grilled.

title: Daily Report: Some Sites Bypass Google Maps
description: When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory, Quentin Hardy reports in Tuesdays New York Times.

A Race Out the Door
Jefferies Posts $77 Million Quarterly Profit
description: 3:49 p.m. | Updated

title: House G.O.P. Lays Down Marker With New Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans thrust their vision of a smaller government, a flatter tax code and a free-market Medicare system into the 2012 election season on Tuesday, banking that fears over surging federal deficits will trump longstanding voter allegiances to popular government programs.

title: Political Geography: Illinois
description: As FiveThirtyEight has discussed, the political and cultural divide between the Chicago area and the rest of Illinois is stark.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Annual Exam for Women Loses Some Relevance
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Deutsche Bank Cuts Top Managers Pay
description: Anshu Jain, the incoming co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, took a 23 percent cut in his compensation last year after the European sovereign debt crisis and turmoil in financial markets prompted a loss in the investment banking division.

title: The $180,000 Nanny: Worth Every Penny?
description: For an article titled The Best Nanny Money Can Buy in next Sundays Times Magazine, Adam Davidson talked with Zenaide Muneton, a nanny represented by the Pavillion Agency, which specializes in finding domestic workers for New York Citys wealthy. When you add in the perks  an annual bonus and a $3,000-a-month rental apartment  she makes considerably more than that $180,000 salary. She accompanies her employers on vacations and does an impressive tooth-brushing dance.

title: A Florida Law Gets Scrutiny After a Teenagers Killing
description: MIAMI  Seven years after Florida adopted its sweeping self-defense law, the shooting of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, has put that law at the center of an increasingly angry debate over how he was killed and whether law enforcement officers have the authority to charge the man who killed him.

title: Indian Jewelers Put Their Work on World Stage
description: For centuries, India has been the worlds back office for jewelry making. A main supplier of precious stones, the country was also the worlds sole source of diamonds until they were discovered in Brazil in 1729, Gayarti Rangachari Shah writes in The New York Times.

title: Why Its Sometimes O.K. to Bad-Mouth an Old Boss
description: There is now one more person out of work in this great country of ours, Greg Smith. If you havent heard, he is the man who recently quit his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs, doing so in dramatic fashion.

title: Face Time | Isabelle Fuhrman
description: I met up with the beautiful young actress Isabelle Fuhrman during her recent trip to New York. Fuhrman, who is in The Hunger Games (opening March 23), was with her lovely mother, Elina, so we got to have some real girls time  it was fun! Isabelles energy, honesty and curiosity were refreshing. So was her interest in her latest discovery, makeup. I would recommend seeing The Hunger Games. I have a feeling she will rock it as well as she does a red lip!

title: We Aint Got Dames: Edna Everage Plans Her Retirement
description: Take a long last look at Dame Edna Everage and say goodbye, possums: at the end of a coming stage tour she will take off her garish glasses and wisteria-colored wig and return to being Barry Humphries, the actor and comedian who has portrayed the outspoken, outrageous character in various incarnations for more than half a century.

title: Glencore to Buy Viterra of Canada for $6.2 Billion
description: OTTAWA  A consortium led by Glencore International reached a deal to acquire Viterra, the largest Canadian grain handler, for $6.2 billion, a widely anticipated transaction that will expand the commodities traders presence in agriculture.

title: A Trip Abroad Thats Unlikely to Inspire the Mayor
description: A good thing about a mayor who believes he already knows pretty much all he needs to know is that hes not likely to acquire really bad habits as he floats around the world.

title: Image of the Day: March 20
Into the Apocalypse With an Unruffled Tour Guide
description: How well should a historian write? Thats a complicated question, but its hard to disagree with George Orwell, who thought that any exemplary book should not only be an intellectual but also an aesthetic experience.

title: Fury in Israel at Remark Linking Gaza to Toulouse
description: JERUSALEM  Israels leaders on Tuesday strongly censured the European Unions foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, for remarks made a day earlier in which she was perceived as having equated the killing of three children at a Jewish school in France with the death of children during the fighting in Gaza.

title: Teixeiras Exit Creates a Job Opening at FIFA
description: NEWS ITEM: SO PAULO (Reuters)  Ricardo Teixeira severed his ties with footballs international governing body on Monday, a week after he resigned as head of the Brazilian Football Confederation and organizer of the 2014 World Cup. Teixeira said he was stepping down from FIFAs executive committee for personal reasons. He had been a member of the committee since 1994 and until recently was seen as a possible successor to FIFA president Sepp Blatter.

title: Do You Have to Be Rude to Manage Like Steve Jobs?
description: Over the years there have been questions about the management style of Steven P. Jobs, co-founder of Apple. Many have asked if Mr. Jobs was, well, to be blunt, a jerk.

title: Morning Buzz, March 20: The Onions Moving Sale
description: Good morning. Well have a mix of sun and clouds today with temperatures rising to the mid 60s.

title: Times Changes Policy on Visits to Web Site
description: 10:12 a.m. | Updated One year after The New York Times Company introduced a pay wall on the Web site of its flagship newspaper, the company said Tuesday it would now require visitors to the site to pay for access after reading 10 free articles, down from the threshold of 20 that was established when the system was initiated.

title: Linsanity to Make Its Mark on Volvo Cars
description: Jeremy Lin, the New York Knicks breakout point guard, shared a podium with executives from Volvo Cars in Manhattan on Monday afternoon to announce a two-year marketing partnership.

title: What Were Reading
description: Reuters: The 8-ounce Sweet Burn? $4.99. The 16-ounce Field of Greens? $7.99. And so, the first Starbucks juice bar (called Evolution Fresh) opened Monday in Bellevue, Wash., near Seattle. Coming next: the national rollout. On the menu are vegetable juices, smoothies, wraps, soups and of course, mucho quinoa and kale. No baristas at the Mighty Wurlitzer, though: the juice mashers are called mixologists.  Glenn Collins

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Rick Santorum, Journalist; and John Carter Slays Disney Earnings
description: Newt Gingrich isnt the only Republican candidate with a long written record. Rick Santorum, writes Jeremy W. Peters, has built up a large journalistic rsum over his career, with contributions to many newspapers and a two-year stint as a columnist for The Philadelphia Inquirer. But unlike Ron Paul, who has disavowed some of the articles that appeared under his name, Mr. Santorum will have no trouble owning up to his work, which includes attacks on climate change scientists and Hollywood (although he found the movie Juno to be heartening).

title: Something Old, Something Fresh
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Something Old, Something Fresh
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Right Angle
description: Ward Bennett (1917-2003) was one of designs great American success stories. He left home at 13, created dresses and window displays, met Brancusi and studied painting with Hans Hofmann  before he was 30. When he turned to design, his clients included David Rockefeller, Gianni Agnelli and Jann and Jane Wenner. Bennett used industrial materials before they were chic and insisted that his furniture be comfortable. Many of his designs went out of production, leaving aficionados to hunt the secondhand market. But now Herman Miller is adding several Bennett pieces (including the Scissor chair and I-Beam table shown here) to its Herman Miller Collection, a portfolio of products for home and office that also includes classics by the Eameses, Nelson and Noguchi; contemporary designers like Sam Hecht, Leon Ransmeier and Ayse Birsel; and the Italian brands Magis and Mattiazzi. (The collection will make its debut this month; go to hermanmiller.com) As Ben Watson, the companys executive creative director, says, We are celebrating our design heritage, but were not just looking backward.

title: Leading Off: A Match Made in Legend Heaven
description: Now that it is done, it seems so obvious. Of course Peyton Manning would sign with Denver. Theres the legendary quarterback-turned-personnel-guy; a seasoned, adaptable coach; a defense so good that Tim Tebow could win going 3 for 27. And hey, Manning stays in the horse family, going from the Colts to the Broncos. Even Darwin would approve.

title: Bernanke, Back to the Classroom
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, looks like a professor. He talks like a professor. Indeed, he used to be a professor.

title: Their Better Halves?
description: You know the political season is heating up when the spouses begin appearing here, there and especially on television talk shows, and on Monday night we had a twofer: on Piers Morgan Tonight, Karen Santorum, who assured us that Rick wont trample over womens freedoms as much as he sometimes seems to itch to, and on the Late Show with David Letterman, Michelle Obama, who told us how exceedingly intelligent Bo, the first Portuguese water dog in the White House, is.

title: On Our Radar: Madagascars Biodiversity
description: Why are so many species almost entirely limited to Madagascar? Scientists hypothesize that some animals arrived there on floating islands carried by ocean currents after plate tectonics separated Madagascar from Africa and other continents. [LiveScience]

title: James Beard Awards Are Late (but Welcome) to the Bar
description: The outstanding-wine-program category of the James Beard Awards was born the same year the food-world prizes were first given out: 1991. Now, 21 years later, the Beard Foundation has finally gotten around to honoring the other half of every restaurants liquor regimen.

title: Doubts About High-Stakes Tests and Their Effect on Teachers
Decoding the Secret Service Names
description: 11:54 a.m. | Updated Whats in a name? And whats in a code name that a man running for president chooses for himself?

title: In China, Call to End to Physicals for Government Applicants
description: HONG KONG  The Beijing Yirenping Center, a civil rights group, called on Monday for an end to physical examinations that the government administers to applicants for civil service posts to determine whether they have sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Barclays Sheds Capital From Its Investment Banks Name
description: Unusually for a bank, Barclays has decided that it needs a little less capital. So to speak.

title: Business Day Live | March 20, 2012
description: Bruce Bartlett on the origin of Republican fiscal policy; Freelancer.coms chief executive on outsourcing; and former Bear Stearns employees on how Wall Street has changed.

title: Citi Credit Card Lets You Redeem Points at the Register
description: When I went to pay for a sandwich at a Manhattan cafe last week, the credit card I pulled out of my wallet elicited three consecutive Wows from the cashier. I see a lot of credit cards, he told me, and Ive never seen one like that before.

title: Calling All Carnivores
description: Ethically speaking, vegetables get all the glory. In recent years, vegetarians  and to an even greater degree vegans, their hard-core inner circle  have dominated the discussion about the ethics of eating. From the philosopher Peter Singer, whose 1975 volume Animal Liberation galvanized an international movement, to the novelist Jonathan Safran Foer, who wrote the 2009 best seller Eating Animals, those who forswear meat have made the case that what we eat is a crucial ethical decision. To be just, they say, we must put down our cheeseburgers and join their ranks.

title: Mining Tax Clears, but Gillard on Shaky Ground
description: SYDNEY  Prime Minister Julia Gillard celebrated on Tuesday the passage of a controversial tax on profits generated by Australias enormous mining boom, a much needed legislative victory for the embattled leader, who recently survived an embarrassing leadership challenge from within her own Labor Party.

title: Spring Comes to a City Woodland
description: For weeks now, something resembling spring has hung awkwardly in the air. January was oddly balmy, February disquietingly snowless. Even with the calendar still declaring winter, forsythias, phlox and magnolias were already abloom.

title: Debunking Sugar-Consumption Myths
description: The sugar mythology:* Kids get their sugar from soda and fruit juice.* Theyre overwhelmed with sugar in processed school lunches and from school vending machines.* Low-income kids are the ones who are really in trouble, what with the no-fresh-food deserts and the fast-food marketing and the obesity crisis.

title: 10 Questions for Jim Messina
description: Jim Messina, a top adviser to President Obama, left the White House a year ago to manage Mr. Obamas re-election campaign. His task is creating an incumbent presidents version of the political machine that the 2008 campaign manager, David Plouffe,, now a top White House official, built for an insurgent promising change we can believe in. John Harwood of The Times and CNBC sat down with Mr. Messina at the campaigns Chicago headquarters. What follows is a condensed, edited version of their conversation.

title: Regulators Approve New Derivatives Rules
description: Regulators approved new rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market on Tuesday, aiming to raise competition and impose more rigorous risk management on an industry that played a central role in the financial crisis.

description: The late Theodore J. Forstmann was a colorful financier known for the prodigious collection of companies he bought and sold, from Gulfstream Aerospace to General Instrument to IMG.

title: Hidden Bombs in Indias Budget for Foreign Investors
description: A proposal by the Indian government last week to change its tax code retroactively to 1962 in order to collect capital gains taxes on offshore acquisitions involving Indian assets has sent shudders through corporate executives, investors and lawyers.

title: North Korea Complicates Nuclear Talks With Plans
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When regional powers gather in Seoul next week to discuss nuclear terrorism, they will have to deal with another urgent matter: how to pressure North Korea to cancel its plans to launch a satellite, President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea said Tuesday.

title: Wantful, Gift-Giving Start-Up, Announces Funding
description: When it comes to sending people birthday and Christmas gifts, I would likely win the award for: Worst. Gift-giver. Ever. Not only do I pick terrible presents for people, but worse, I have half-written birthday cards stuffed around my house that never actually made it to the post office.

title: How Housing Prices Burden the Economy
description: Matthew Yglesias, the Moneybox columnist for Slate, is the author of The Rent Is Too Damn High, a short new electronic book. The title refers to an obscure political party in New York: The Rent Is Too Damn High Party. In the book, Mr. Yglesias argues that high rent  by which he means both rents and purchase prices  is a major drag on the American economy and society. The real value of Yglesiass book, John Mangin wrote at The Washington Monthlys Web site, lies in its explanatory power, and in its potential to recast an important issue.

title: Business Day Live: The Origins of G.O.P. Fiscal Policy
description: Bruce Bartlett on the origin of Republican fiscal policy; Freelancer.coms chief executive on outsourcing; and former Bear Stearns employees on how Wall Street has changed.

title: Vatican Inquiry Finds Progress in Irish Abuse Scandal
description: VATICAN CITY  The Roman Catholic Church in Ireland has made excellent progress in addressing a sexual abuse scandal and reporting new abuse cases directly to the Vatican, but would-be priests need better screening and training, according to a summary of a nearly yearlong investigation issued by the Vatican on Tuesday.

title: Illinois Votes in Rare Turn in Spotlight
description: PEORIA, Ill.  Entering the First English Lutheran Church on Tuesday morning, voters in the Illinois Republican primary had to first walk between two network news trucks parked out front. Through one windshield, one could see a monitor glowing in the predawn with live footage from inside the church gymnasium, where eight voting booths stood waiting.

title: Another Pastor Controversy
description: Political campaigns have a way of repeating themselves. In 2008, Democrats blamed President George W. Bush for high gas prices; now Republicans are blaming President Barack Obama for high gas prices. In 2008, Mr. Obama promised hed reduce the countrys dependence on foreign oil; now the Republican candidates are promising to reduce the countrys dependence on foreign oil. In 2008, Mr. Obama had a pastor controversy; now its Rick Santorums turn.

title: Russia Seems To Soften Its Support For Syria
description: MOSCOW  The foreign minister of Russia, the Syrian governments most powerful supporter, used some of his harshest language on Tuesday in criticizing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his violent repression of a year-old uprising there, saying that Mr. Assad had committed many mistakes and that no one is inviting him to Moscow should he resign.

title: All Hail Sealand
description: I was about 10 years old when I declared the independence of my bedroom. On a blank page ripped from my school notebook, I meticulously traced the rooms floor plan. From National Geographics maps, I borrowed the colored edge and dotted line that mark international borders. The threshold of my room now marked the entrance to my own separate kingdom (or republic; I hadnt quite figured that out yet).

title: The Strange Career of Frank Dawson
description: Francis Warrington Dawson, my great-grandfather, was born in London in 1841. That wasnt his original name, however: Christened Austin John Reeks, he was born into an educated, upper-middle-class Catholic family. After graduating from school, he took a European Grand Tour before university; then his father declared bankruptcy. An aunt, Mrs. Dawson, offered to pay his university tuitions, but died shortly thereafter. Instead, Austin took up writing as a career.

title: Invisible Evidence Restores a van Gogh Attribution
description: It was a van Gogh, then it wasnt a van Gogh and now its a van Gogh again, maybe this time for good.

title: Humpback Whales Yield Some Sonic Secrets to Science
description: David Rothenberg, a musician and environmental philosopher, is a fairly frequent voice on this blog when the subject is animal sounds and behavior. His latest book, Survival of the Beautiful, is on aesthetics and evolution. You may have caught his recent jam with emerging cicadas. Rothenberg, who wrote the widely discussed book on whale communication, Thousand Mile Song, reflects below on some recent research focused on the remarkably variable songs of humpback whales. Heres his Your Dot contribution on the evolving music of humpbacks:

description: The first string was back on the field for every broadcast network on Monday night for the first time since NBC introduced the current season of its powerhouse singing show, The Voice, and a shake-up in the standings was evident.

title: Tony Winners Join Prince of Broadway
description: Tony winners Linda Lavin (Broadway Bound), LaChanze (The Color Purple) and Shuler Hensley (Oklahoma!) will be part of the 12-person cast singing material from shows created by Broadway producer/director Harold Prince in Prince of Broadway, a musical tribute due to open in New York in November.

title: China Quietly Relaxes Controls on Foreign Capital
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government has begun making it much easier for foreign investors to put money into Chinas stock market and other financial investments, in a slight relaxing of more than a decade of tight capital controls.

title: Baked Giant White Beans With Cabbage
description: This slow-baked bean and cabbage dish is luxurious in both taste and texture. The limas become soft and pillowy after their long, slow simmer, while releasing some of their starch into the bean broth; the cabbage sweetens over time and almost melts into the velvety broth. Baked beans with cabbage traditionally contain a ham bone or some salt pork for flavor, but I get that rich umami flavor with Parmesan rinds.

title: New York Maps Viable Offshore Wind Power
description: A new study mapping out habitats in and around the waters off New York was released on Tuesday, bringing the state a step closer to determining the potential for wind energy projects offshore.

title: A Legacy of Pain
description: In todays column I wrote about Rick Santorum and American Catholicism and the churchs child sexual abuse crisis, and I wanted to circle back to that last item in this post, which is also a postscript.

title: For Titanic Anniversary, the Books Go On and On
description: In her book How to Survive the Titanic, an elegant account of the infamy that hounded J. Bruce Ismay, the chairman of the company that owned the ship, after he fled the sinking giant in a lifeboat, Frances Wilson writes, The need felt by survivors to tell their tales was, from the start, overwhelming and the need of those who were not on board to read their accounts, to see the films, to repeat the experience and work it through, to raise the Titanic and watch her go down again and again is one of the shipwrecks most peculiar effects.

title: U.S. General Sees No Sudden Afghan Drawdown
description: WASHINGTON  The top allied commander in Afghanistan told Congress on Tuesday that he would not be recommending further American troop reductions until late this year, after the departure of the current surge forces and the end of the summer fighting season.

title: Bobcats Battling N.B.A. and A.C.C.
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Ordinarily, the dominant color among fans attending Charlotte Bobcats games is blue. Saturday was St. Patricks Day, however, so Time Warner Cable Arena was a sea of green. During timeouts, a man dressed as a leprechaun, wearing curved springs on his legs, used a lacrosse stick to hurl T-shirts into the crowd.

title: Comics Are Now Selling Laughs by the Download
description: Stand-up comedians of a certain era knew they had arrived when Johnny Carson invited them to a desk-side seat on The Tonight Show. A generation later, the gold standard was getting a solo comedy special on HBO. But in the Internet era, the yardstick for success has been redefined.

title: In Auckland, New Zealand, a Frugal Trifecta
description: Auckland is New Zealands biggest city and the place youll almost certainly fly into if you come from the United States. Its also quite a pleasant spot. That may sound like damning with faint praise  you dont fly halfway around the world for pleasant. But New Zealand is probably best known for its scenery and countryside and outdoor adventure, so having a pleasant gateway to get adjusted is a great bonus  and not something you get everywhere (looking at you, Managua).

title: In the Bronx, Painting Together at an Open-Air Gallery
description: TATS Cru put out the call on Friday.

title: Santorum Campaign Sees Delegate Gap Narrowing
description: CHICAGO  As Rick Santorum awaits the results of the Republican presidential primary here Tuesday that may or may not go his way, his campaign contends that it is gaining steam in the less visible  but more important  contest for delegates.

description: The Commerce Department said on Tuesday that it would impose tariffs on solar panels imported from China after concluding that the Chinese government provided illegal export subsidies to manufacturers there.

Thousands Mourn Coptic Pope in Cairo

description: New York City Audubons director of conservation and science, Susan Elbin, has been responding to readers questions about hawks and other birds of prey in New York City. Following is her third and final set of responses, with additional answers provided by her colleague, John Rowden, the associate director of citizen science and outreach for New York City Audubon.

title: Many Americans Struggling to Pay Medical Bills
description: All eyes will be on the United States Supreme Court next week as it hears arguments in the challenge to the Affordable Care Act. But while debate over health care reform swirls in the political arena, roughly a third of Americans are in families struggling in some way to pay medical bills, a recent study finds.

title: Harry Potter Actor Is Jailed for Role in London Riots
description: In his performances as Vincent Crabbe in the Harry Potter movies Jamie Waylett is known for his physical menace and mischief making, but these real-life qualities have seen the actor sentenced to two years in jail for his involvement in the 2011 London riots, BBC News reported.

title: Brooklyn Students Propose Ways to Improve Relations at Shared Campuses
Dueling Iranian New Year Greetings from Obama and Khamenei
description: The leaders of Iran and the United States issued starkly divergent New Year messages to Irans home audience on Tuesday, with President Obama calling for a new relationship that would end Irans prolonged isolation, and Ayatollah Ali Khamenei exhorting fellow citizens to beware of enemy plots and to buy only domestically made products.

title: Candidates Look to Exceed Expectations in Illinois
description: The pattern is pretty clear now.

title: Obama Exempts Japan and 10 European Nations From Iran Sanctions Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday exempted Japan and 10 European nations from biting sanctions intended to punish those who continued to purchase oil from Iran.

title: The American Flag: A Street Style Star at SXSW 2012
description: Among all the cut-off jeans and boots donned at SXSW, the American flag emerged as an unlikely favorite.

title: The Ryan Budget 2.0
description: The new House Republican budget looks a lot like last years House Republican budget, and is likely to earn the same sort of reactions: If you loved Paul Ryan 1.0 youll love 2.0 as well; if you considered the first iteration a nightmare of social Darwinist cruelty then the second iteration probably wont change your mind. But for those of us who considered last years document a brave rough draft in need of substantial improvement, the good news is that it has been significantly improved: The proposed Medicare reform, which is the centerpiece of the budget and far and away its most important and courageous component, has been revised in the direction of the proposal that Oregon Democrat Ron Wyden and Ryan co-sponsored earlier this year, which means that it includes (among other things) a more realistic vision of how fast the proposed premium support for Medicare recipients would grow and a traditional fee-for-service Medicare as one of the options competing for those premium-support dollars. For a longer version of why this shift makes sense, I recommend reading Yuval Levins Weekly Standard piece on Medicare reform; for the shorter version, suffice to say that Ryan 2.0 addresses the fairest liberal attack on the original budgets Medicare proposal, making its vision for entitlement reform more plausible as policy and politics alike.

title: Pro-Romney Group Spent More Than $12 Million in February
description: A super PAC supporting Mitt Romney spent more than $12 million in February, most of it on ads attacking his rivals, as Mr. Romney battled them in seven primaries and caucuses that month, according to campaign filings released on Tuesday. The group, Restore Our Future, raised about $6.4 million, more than some of the candidates in the race are expected to report.

title: Motherlode Book Club: Some Assembly Required, in Progress
description: The six members of the Motherlode Book Club panel for Anne and Sam Lamotts Some Assembly Required are reading Ms. Lamotts story of finding out that her son, Sam (whom many of us think of as the baby from Operating Instructions), was about to become a father at age 19. The subtitle is A Journal of My Sons First Son.

title: TimesCast | Illinois Primaries
description: March 20, 2012  Republican voters go to the polls in the Illinois primary as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum continue to battle for the nomination.

title: Former Merce Cunningham Dancers to Teach Choreographers Works
description: Four former Merce Cunningham company dancers have received fellowships to teach some of the choreographers works this spring and summer. The fellowships, $6,000 each, represent the latest effort to keep the Cunningham flame alive after his  death in 2009 and the companys dissolution last year.

title: Caucus Video: Illinois Holds Republican Primaries
description: Republican voters head to the polls in the Illinois primary as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum continue to battle for delegates. Michael D. Shear reports.

title: Brooklyn Teacher Accused of Sexually Abusing Student
description: A physical education teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested on Tuesday after the police said he grabbed the buttocks of a 16-year-old female student. He is at least the sixth New York City school worker charged in two months with a sexual offense against a student.

title: Saying No to an Optional Iris Photo Has Its Consequences
description: As fellow Occupy Wall Street protesters who had been arrested on Saturday were being arraigned, Dallas Pesola remained in a holding cell on Sunday night, essentially being punished for not submitting to what was supposed to be a voluntary photograph of his irises.

title: Does Motivation Matter? Debating the Legal Category of Hate Crime
description: Overview | Should crimes committed out of intolerance and bigotry be prosecuted and sentenced differently than other crimes? In this lesson, in the context of the Dharun Ravi case, students debate whether or hate crime laws protect against intimidation and bigotry or whether they are unnecessary and unfair.

title: ESPNs Web Site for Women Adds a Sponsor
description: An effort by ESPN to appeal to women is getting some additional marketer support as a brand becomes the first in its category to advertise with the company, according to ESPN.

title: 2 Federal Reserve Nominees Make It to a Confirmation Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Two of the White Houses nominees to fill vacancies on the Federal Reserve board moved closer to confirmation on Tuesday after a routine Senate hearing.

title: Dan Hurley Leaving Wagner to Coach Rhode Island
description: Dan Hurley is leaving Wagner and to become the mens basketball coach at Rhode Island. He will be introduced at a news conference Wednesday, Rhode Island officials said Tuesday.

title: From 1982, Glasses More Than Full
description: ATLANTA

title: Old-Fashioned or Newfangled, the Old-Fashioned Is Back
description: AS is his habit, Matthew Weiner, the creator of Mad Men, is revealing few details about the fifth season of the hit series, which will return to AMC on Sunday after a 17-month absence. We dont know if the charismatic sphinx Don Draper has married his secretary or pulled his flailing advertising firm out of the fire. But one prediction is a safe bet: Mr. Draper will dip his beak into an old-fashioned or three.

title: Home of Chicago Rail Cars Set to Undergo Renovation
description: CHICAGO  At its peak, the town of Pullman housed upward of 12,000 people in a parklike setting 12 miles south of downtown Chicago. They worked at the Pullman Palace Car Company, and spent their time and money in housing, schools, churches and stores built just for them by George Pullman, the companys founder and one of the worlds wealthiest men.

title: Woodsons Challenge: Scoring Production
description: After the departure of Mike DAntoni, the Knicks won their first three games under the replacement coach, Mike Woodson. They have not only won, but have done so convincingly. Over the span, the Knicks have outscored their opponents by an average of 23.7 points.

title: A Chance to Meet the 'Hunger Games' Cast
description: Melena Ryzik interviews four "Hunger Games" fans waiting in line at a Manhattan Barnes and Noble to meet the film's cast.

title: Shoot First, Claim Self-Defense Later
description: In late February, 28-year-old George Zimmerman called 911 to report that a real suspicious guy was walking down the street in Sanford, Fla. He decided to follow the suspicious guy, and later that night Mr. Zimmerman shot and killed him with a 9 mm handgun. The suspicious guy was a black 17-year-old named Trayvon Martin. He was unarmed, carrying only a bag of Skittles, a can of iced tea and a cellphone.

title: Act Now! Send Us Your Questions for Karen Mills and the S.B.A.

title: Southern Miss Revokes Band Members Scholarships After Taunts
description: Southern Miss responded to one of the uglier moments of the N.C.A.A. tournament by revoking the scholarships of five of its pep band members for taunting Kansas State guard Angel Rodriguez. The school announced the discipline on Tuesday.

title: North End Grill
description: Inside Danny Meyers new seafood restaurant in Battery Park City.

title: Veteran Crew Sets Imaginative Course
description: AT times I wondered if North End Grill was trying to look dull on purpose.

title: Experiences in Nature From Our Readers and an 18th-Century Philosopher
description: Kim Tingleys article in this weeks magazine  explores the work being done by Davyd Betchkal and his team in Alaska to preserve the quickly disappearing sounds of pure nature. It has inspired many commenters to write about their own experiences in nature and the silent tranquility they found everywhere from Joshua Tree National Park to the Yukon Territory, or even on a Navy destroyer in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. This commenter from Seattle only tells us that the experience can be attended by the fear that an investment banker will inevitably arrive, buy the land and start herding cattle with a helicopter.

title: In Search for Alien Life, Researchers Enlist Human Minds
description: HAT CREEK, Calif.  On a chilly morning last week, Jill Tarter sat in a makeshift corner office facing the Allen Telescope Array, pondering a set of parallel lines that striped a window in her MacBook.

title: Five Dishes at North End Grill
description: Under review this week is North End Grill, Floyd Cardozs welcome return after his 12-year run at the Indian-fusion restaurant Tabla. This time, hes not tethered to any one cuisine, giving him freedom to cook simple dishes like scrambled eggs and whole grilled turbot. Still, he retains a profound understanding of how to build flavors through spices, as became clear in my phone conversation with him this week. Here are some dishes worth trying at North End Grill, and the stories behind them.

title: Mexican Quake Posed No Threat to Presidents Daughter
description: Malia Obama, the presidents older daughter, was never threatened by the earthquake Tuesday afternoon that shook central and southern Mexico, where she was visiting with a school group, according to a spokeswoman for the presidents wife, Michelle.

title: Illinois Congressional Primaries Make Captivating Undercard
description: The highest-profile primary in Illinois on Tuesday may be between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum, but a slew of interesting House primaries are also on the stove, many of them proxies for various political engagements around the country.

title: Alderson Says Settlement Wont Change Much Right Away
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Tuesday that the settlement reached between the clubs owners and the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs vast fraud would have a negligible short-term effect on the Mets payroll.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: Dying by Degrees
description: Ira Byock has been writing books about the way Americans die since 1998, when he published Dying Well. For most of that time, he has been appalled.

title: Another Teacher Arrested on Sex Abuse Charges
