Out of the game he went, and in came a strong and physical runner named Steve Taylor to gain that final yard. The switch prevented Flutie from absorbing some big hits, but it also had an unintended consequence.

title: Witnesses Testify That Espada Used Nonprofit Groups Checks to Pay for Personal Services
description: A videographer who was hired by former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. to film a private birthday party testified on Thursday that she had been pressured by Mr. Espadas assistant to lie about the work she performed and claim in an invoice that she had actually filmed a public event.

title: Taking On Police Tactic, Critics Hit Racial Divide
description: ALBANY  Black and Latino lawmakers, fed up over the frequency with which New York City police officers are stopping and frisking minority men, are battling what they say is a racial divide as they push legislation to rein in the practice.

title: Fixing New Yorks Budget
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and legislative leaders are scrambling to conclude negotiations on the $132.5 billion 2012-13 state budget by March 31. As they push to finish their main piece of business, a few important items in the budget deserve notice:

title: Out of Bounds
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell has taken a good step toward repairing the National Football Leagues reputation for dirty play, gratuitous violence and neglect of player safety. To punish the New Orleans Saints for tolerating the payment of bounties to players for targeting and injuring opponents, Mr. Goodell suspended its head coach, Sean Payton, for a year without pay.

title: In Hearings, Titanics Story Took Shape
description: On an April night 100 years ago, a ship of the Cunard lines called the R.M.S. Carpathia moved up the Hudson River in a ferocious rain, sailing past the lines home berth at Pier 54, instead going north to Pier 59, near 18th Street.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2012

title: Syrian Activists Say U.S. Journalist Is No Spy
description: Syrian activists in the city of Homs, who are struggling to draw attention to what they describe as a continued assault by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad on rebellious districts, took time out from that work on Thursday to issue a statement defending an American journalist accused of spying on them for the government.

title: Hip Device Phaseout Followed F.D.A. Data Request
description: Johnson & Johnson executives decided in 2009 to phase out a hip implant and sell off its inventories for use in patients just weeks after the Food and Drug Administration asked the company in a letter for added safety data about the implant, administration documents and corporate records show.

title: I Like Ike (and His Memorial)
description: Philadelphia

title: In Shift, a Queens School Will Sell Land to the City
description: A financially troubled private school in Jackson Heights, Queens, has agreed to sell an athletic field to New York City rather than follow through on a controversial plan to sell it to a private developer.

title: A Class Trip Meant Much to Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  After weighing the risks of traveling to Mexico, the parents of one American teenager decided to allow her to join a school trip to Oaxaca, where students volunteered at an orphanage, visited archaeological sites and sipped vanilla milkshakes on the honey-colored town plaza.

title: Inching Toward Energy Independence
description: The oil and gas industry is vastly increasing production, reversing two decades of decline. Michael Levi, an energy expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, discusses the trend.

title: Wisconsin Misses in Final Seconds, and Orange Advance
description: BOSTON  As Syracuse streaked through its most unusual of seasons  winning games in bunches on the court and enduring explosive scandals off it  there was always a plan in place.

title: A Glitzy Execution in a Religious Revival
description: Spoiler alert! Oh, just kidding. It will surely come as a surprise to no one that the title character in Jesus Christ Superstar does not come to a happy end, drifting blissfully into old age and obscurity on the sands of Judea. His gruesome death is depicted with unusually lavish flair in the director Des McAnuffs flashy revival of the pop-rock musical by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber that opened Thursday night at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: Ice Cream Gobblers Woe
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I knew I was going to like this puzzle as soon as I scrawled in BRAIN FREEZE in the northwest. Its been used once before in the New York Times crossword, and as painful as it is, its such a fun entry that Im surprised its not used more often.

title: SAS Makes Its Bid to Democratize Data Analysis
description: SAS Institute, the worlds largest private software company, has built its lucrative business by being the pioneer of sophisticated data-analysis tools. SAS software, down to its own programming language, is used by most large corporations for things like detecting credit card fraud for banks and fine-tuning pricing for retailers.

title: At Mayors Spring Dinner, Rivalry Is Served
description: They converged, one by one, on a nondescript Manhattan high-rise, stepping out of sport utility vehicles and hurrying in with briefcases: a quiet gathering of New York City governments highest-ranking officials.

title: Islam in the Melting Pot of Marseille
The Aftermath in Toulouse
description: Mohammed Merah, the man who claimed responsibility for killing three French soldiers, a rabbi and three young children at a Jewish school, was killed by French security forces on Thursday. But his murderous rampage is likely to fuel anxiety over the threat of homegrown terrorism.

title: Does It Matter Whether God Exists?
description: Discussions of religion are typically about God. Atheists reject religion because they dont believe in God; Jews, Christians and Muslims take belief in God as fundamental to their religious commitment. The philosopher John Gray, however, has recently been arguing that belief in God should have little or nothing to do with religion. He points out that in many cases  for instance, polytheism, Hinduism and Buddhism, Daoism and Shinto, many strands of Judaism and some Christian and Muslim traditions  belief is of little or no importance. Rather, practice  ritual, meditation, a way of life  is what counts. He goes on to say that its only religious fundamentalists and ignorant rationalists who think the myths we live by are literal truths and that what we believe doesnt in the end matter very much. What matters is how we live.

title: Seeking Out Tough Opposition, N.C. State Reaps the Rewards
description: ST. LOUIS  One of Mark Gottfrieds tasks after taking over as coach at North Carolina State involved overhauling the Wolfpacks cupcake-laden nonconference schedule. Rather than wait a year, Gottfried convinced Athletic Director Debbie Yow to cancel a contract with Houston Baptist, a mid-major, and pull out of the eight-team Las Vegas Invitational, which featured four mid-majors.

title: The Cardinals Keep Surging, Eliminating a No. 1 Seed
description: PHOENIX  Louisville, which lost in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament the last two seasons, which dropped consecutive games less than a month ago, which supposedly lacked the toughness or inside presence of Michigan State, won another game Thursday.

title: Shooting Focuses Attention on a Program That Seeks to Avoid Guns
description: SANFORD, Fla.  Last August, Wendy Dorival got a call about setting up a local neighborhood watch. As the volunteer coordinator for the Police Department here, she gets such calls regularly, and the city already had at least 10 active watch groups. So she thought nothing of this call, from George Zimmerman.

title: Jesus Christ Superstar
description: Scenes from the Broadway revival at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: Angry at Pension Vote, Unions Plan to Skip Hispanic Event
description: ALBANY  It is a tradition of the annual spring conference for Hispanic legislators in the capital: a union-sponsored breakfast where lawmakers rub shoulders with labor leaders, whose endorsements are coveted come election season.

title: In Cape Town, Apartheids Scars Run Deep
description: For countless foreign visitors, Cape Town symbolizes the beauty and promise of post-apartheid South Africa, a historic mix of races and cultures. But for many black South Africans, this city is the last bastion of white rule.

title: Rise of Ohio Coach Fueled by Drive (and Coffee)
description: Ohio University Coach John Groce once drank nearly five cups of coffee a day. Sometimes, he would chase them with Mountain Dew. The caffeine binges ended a few years ago when he took a trip to the doctor because an eye began to twitch.

title: Stronger Hand for Judges in the Bazaar of Plea Deals
description: For years, the nations highest court has devoted the majority of its criminal justice efforts to ensuring that defendants get a fair day in court and a fair sentence once a trial is concluded. But in two decisions on Wednesday, the Supreme Court tacitly acknowledged that it has been enforcing an image of the system that is very different from the real, workaday world inhabited by prosecutors and defense lawyers across the country.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 22
description: Michigan State lost to Louisville to became the first No. 1 seed knocked out of the tournament, and Syracuse survived a close game with Wisconsin.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,896 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Corrections: March 23
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: No. 15 Not a Jets Prime Number, but Pretty Close
description: In the teams 52-year history, the most distinguished Jet (or Titan) to wear No. 15 was Babe Parilli, a backup quarterback to Joe Namath. Parilli was 38 and his years as a starter with the Boston Patriots were behind him. Parillis distinction will end when Tim Tebow, the Jets newest backup, puts on his No. 15 jersey.

title: Three Plead Guilty to Hate Crimes in Killing of Black Man in Mississippi
description: ATLANTA  Federal hate-crime charges for the racially motivated murder of James C. Anderson in Jackson, Miss., were unsealed Thursday, leading to three guilty pleas from white men who admitted they used to drive into the city from a neighboring county determined to find blacks to assault.

title: The Electoral Math of Romneys Stance on Trade With China
description: WASHINGTON  Among all the elements of Mitt Romneys 59-point economic plan, his vow to crack down on Chinas trade policy would seem the most out of place.

title: A Jayhawks Star Triumphs After Tragedy
description: ST. LOUIS  Summers for Kansas Coach Bill Self mean leisurely mornings. Usually he arrives at his Allen Fieldhouse office in Lawrence, between 9:30 and 10 a.m., to the sound of players dribbling and shooting on the adjacent practice court.

title: Crisis in Toulouse Alters Campaigns Tone in Sarkozys Favor
description: PARIS  With the candidate of the National Front, Marine Le Pen, calling for a war on these fundamentalist political religious groups who are killing our children, it was easy for President Nicolas Sarkozy to take the high road in the sharp political reaction to the terrorist acts of Mohammed Merah, who was killed by the police on Thursday in Toulouse after himself claiming responsibility for killing seven people.

title: Murray Lender, Who Gave All America a Taste of Bagels, Dies at 81
description: Murray Lender, who with his brothers took over what started as their fathers bakery in a backyard garage and built it into a business that brought the bagel  the Jewish English muffin, as he called it  into kitchens across the country, frozen, died on Wednesday in Miami. He was 81.

title: Ron Erhardt, Super Bowl-Winning Offensive Coach, Dies at 81
description: Ron Erhardt, who devised the offensive schemes for two Super Bowl championship teams with the Giants in the Bill Parcells era, died on Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 81.

title: The Storm Over Womens Health Care Had Been Brewing
description: In the battle between state leaders and the Obama administration over Texas decision to oust health care providers affiliated with abortion clinics from a five-year-old contraception and cancer-screening program, both sides believe they are the victims.

title: With Opener in Mind, Wright Returns to Action
description: PORT. ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Precisely two weeks before opening day, David Wright pushed the reset button on his spring training preparations.

title: Obama Seizes Chance to Score as an Everyman
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama loves basketball, as everyone is reminded in March  especially in an election year in which he has been jumping through you-know-whats to assert as much.

title: Valentine Fumes as Yankees Settle for Tie
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Before Thursdays spring training game at Fenway South, Red Sox Manager Bobby Valentine and his Yankees counterpart, Joe Girardi, chatted amiably on the field. But things were not nearly as cordial after the game, and may not be going into the regular season.

title: The Wildcat: Loosely Applied, Sparingly Used
description: Tim Tebow and the Broncos ran exactly zero Wildcat plays during the 2011 regular season.

title: U.S. Rejects Environmental Reviews on Mortgages Linked to Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  Federal agriculture officials will not require an extensive environmental review before issuing mortgages to people who have leased their land for oil and gas drilling, according to a notice released by the Department of Agriculture this week.

title: Knicks Slow Down and Take Off
description: The Mike DAntoni era ended not with a bang but a thud, with the Knicks losing the last six games he coached.

title: Word of the Day | headstrong
description: headstrong \hed-strN\ adjective

title: Tonino Guerra, Poetic Italian Screenwriter, Dies at 92
description: Tonino Guerra, a prolific Italian screenwriter and poet whose roster of film collaborators, including Michelangelo Antonioni, Federico Fellini, Andrei Tarkovsky and Theo Angelopoulos, amounted to a whos who of European cinemas golden age, died on Wednesday at his home in Santarcangelo di Romagna, in northern Italy near the Adriatic coast. He was 92.

title: Joining the Winners Circle
description: AMES, Iowa  Cathy Krieger arrived at Hilton Coliseum here last Monday primed to yell and stomp her feet for her beloved Kentucky Wildcats. So did her mother, grandmother and aunt, all in Kentucky T-shirts, as well as two daughters of a neighbor. All eagerly shook the blue-and-white pompoms passed out by Kentuckys cheerleaders.

title: China: Vietnamese Fishermen Detained
description: China has detained 21 Vietnamese fishermen in the South China Sea, according to reports on Thursday that cited Vietnamese officials. An official from Quang Ngai Province, where the fishermen are from, told The Associated Press that they were detained on March 3 near the Paracel Islands, which are controlled by Chinas military. Vietnam claims sovereignty over the islands, whose territory it once shared with China. The Vietnamese official said China was demanding $11,000 for the release of the fishermen. Tensions over the territorial disputes in the South China Sea have been rising in recent years.

title: When the Ground Goes Bump in the Night
description: CLINTONVILLE, Wis.  It was a quiet night last Sunday when the sounds began, and some residents have barely slept since.

title: Finally, Texas May Play Role in G.O.P. Race for President
description: Texas is usually flyover country in the battle for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Portugal: Strike Disrupts Transportation
description: The Lisbon subway and some of Portugals major rail and ferry routes were shut down Thursday as workers staged a strike to protest labor law changes and austerity cuts. The strike crippled parts of the transport network, but its impact was limited because a major union did not take part. The one-day strike was called by the largest labor confederation, which opposes an overhaul of labor legislation that will make it easier and cheaper for employers to lay off employees.

title: Garcia Prefers to Stay With Yankees, but Would Consider Trade
description: TAMPA, Fla.  By rule, the Yankees are not allowed to trade Freddy Garcia before June 16 without his permission. But if the Yankees find a trade partner that suits Garcia  a team that offers him a chance to be in the starting rotation  then Garcia will probably give his approval.

title: Player Has Promise and Plenty of Critics
description: ATLANTA  Baylor forward Quincy Acy leaned into the microphone and muttered, Its Bash Perry Day, on the interview dais. The questions were coming at Baylors Perry Jones III about his erratic season, as if points were the only measure of a game: 22 points one night, 5 another. Why doesnt he shoot more? Why the fluctuation in point totals? He was expected to be a superstar this season, but there were nights when he looked all reputation: 2-for-12 shooting at Missouri, 3 for 14 at Texas.

title: Union College May Be Small, but It Has Extra-Large Dreams
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Playoff beards are also fashionable among college hockey players, except for those who play at Union College. The Dutchmen must shave before class each Monday morning, no matter the time of year.

title: Buckeyes 17-1 Run Puts Away Bearcats
description: BOSTON  It had been a half century since Ohio State and Cincinnati met in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Since that game, the teams had met once  in 2006  amid complaints from the Bearcats that the Buckeyes ignored them.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/23/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/23/2012

title: Review of Texas Association Sought
description: The Texas Catholic Conference called for a comprehensive review of the Texas Association of Private and Parochial Schools, or Tapps, a group that organizes athletic competition for 200 schools in the state. The conference cited Tappss handling of the admission of Islamic schools to the group and its refusal to reschedule a state semifinal boys basketball game for an Orthodox Jewish day school. A Tapps representative did not immediately respond to request for comment.

title: The Evolution of a G.O.P. Leader With Her Eye on Bigger Things
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: U.S. Opens Tournament With Win
description: The United States opened the Olympic qualifying tournament with a 6-0 win over Cuba in Nashville. Joe Corona had a hat trick and the captain Freddy Adu and Juan Agudelo of the Red Bulls also scored. The game was essentially over in the 20th minute after Cubas Dayron Macias elbowed Agudelo in the eye and was sent off.

title: The Closer: Mets Pitchers Catch a Break
description: With Pat Burrell having retired after last season, and Chipper Jones announcing that he will do the same after 2012, the Mets pitching staff can soon relax.

title: Romney Goes to Capitol Hill, Looking for Allies
description: Mitt Romney stepped up his efforts to rally Republicans around his candidacy on Thursday with several hours of private appeals to lawmakers on Capitol Hill and renewed pressure on his rivals to bow to political reality.

title: Florida Wins and Sets Up a Reunion for Its Coach
description: PHOENIX  What seemed unlikely early Thursday surprisingly came to fruition later, after both Florida and Louisville staged N.C.A.A. tournament upsets in the West Region, setting up a Saturday reunion with a Final Four berth at stake.

title: Made in Hayward: Bus Maker Finally Wins a Local Contract
description: For the past decade, Jose Luis Tejeda felt insulted every time he saw an Alameda-Contra Costa Transit District bus drive past his place of work.

title: Sometimes a Museum Needs to Get Outdoors More
description: When Shawn Lani biked to work at the Exploratorium in San Francisco on a recent sunny morning in March, his thoughts turned to light.

title: Hold That Bridge! This Dilapidated Warehouse Is a Landmark
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Law, Order and a Life in Robes
description: As he had many times before, Judge Vaughn R. Walker  impeccably dressed in a gray suit and muted red tie  took command of the room.

title: Indias Decrepit, Unsafe Railways
description: Dinesh Trivedi: If you do not increase the fares, you are going to turn the railway coaches into coffins.

title: News Quiz | March 23, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays newspaper.

title: A Hunger Artist
description: On Monday, in a display of rank opportunism, the celebrity anticorruption campaigner Anna Hazare jumped onto the bandwagon of a leading Indian environmentalist who is on the 42nd day of a hunger strike to protect the Ganges River, Dan Morrison writes for the Latitude blog in The New York Times.

title: March 23, 1983 | Reagan Proposes Star Wars Missile Defense System
description: On March 23, 1983, in a nationally televised address on national security, President Ronald Reagan proposed the development of the technology to intercept enemy nuclear missiles. The plan, called the Strategic Defense Initiative, or S.D.I., was dubbed Star Wars by its critics.

title: When Youre a Jet
description: WHO are Tim Tebow and Mark Sanchez?

title: Test Yourself | English, March 23, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The Downside of a Balmy Winter? Long Walks With the Dog Arent Carefree.

title: Redeeming a Life in Photography
description: Through blacklists, dashed friendships and averted gazes, Miriam Grossman Cohen waited half her life for redemption. Instead, she would have to endure the old slights, which hurt as much as ever, against her husband, Sid Grossman: That he was the Communist in the Photo League. That he cared more about politics than art. That his life was summed up more by what others said than by what he did.

title: Dharun Ravi Denies Anti-Gay Bias
description: Dharun Ravi was found guilty on all 15 counts he was charged with, including bias intimidation, in connection to the 2010 death of his gay former roommate, Tyler Clementi.

title: What Is Your Reaction to the Trayvon Martin Case?
description: The fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, 17, in Florida has spurred a national response that is taking numerous forms, including rallies in multiple cities and active discussion on social media. What do you know about the case? What is your personal response? What questions and issues does it raise for you?

title: Jets Tannenbaum on How Trade Affects Sanchez
description: In making the radio show rounds on Thursday, General Manager Mike Tannenbaum repeatedely said that the Jets acquisition of Tim Tebow had nothing to with selling merchandise or personal seat licenses, or winning the headlines from the Super Bowl champion Giants. Winning was the only consideration. Readers will have to be the judge of that. Here is a sampling of Tannenbaums discussion with Boomer and Carton on WFAN 660 AM in New York, focusing on how the move will affect Mark Sanchez:

title: Pick a College. Reconsider. Repeat Until April 1.
description: April 1, the day high school seniors eagerly await, is fast approaching. This date signals the time when most seniors find out the admission decisions from all their colleges. Some may hear a few days earlier or later depending on the college, but for most seniors, this is the day to which the entire college process has led. In some respects, this day is the beginning of the most difficult part of the college process: the decision.

title: Who Shouldnt Go to College?
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Scouting the Draft: Clemsons Dwayne Allen
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: The Early Word: Data
description: In Todays Times:

title: Fantasy Focus: Yes, Just Spring Statistics, But
description: The general rule is to ignore almost all spring training stats, not only because the data sample is small but also because there is simply no way to know if an established player is tinkering with his mechanics or working on a new pitch. However, performance in March shouldnt always be totally overlooked, as it can affect playing time for those battling for jobs, and it can clarify health matters. So while its probably safe to ignore Robinson Canos current .182/.222/.333 line and Roy Halladays 6.59 earned run average, here are a few players who are having terrific or extremely poor springs that may mean something in the regular season. (All statistics are current through Thursday.)

title: Arab Institute in Paris Reopens  Exhibition Rooms With Lavish Displays
description: In years past, the exhibition halls of LInstitut du Monde Arabein Paris looked a lot more forlorn than did its lovely, lacy Jean Nouvel-designed exterior. Last month, after closing for two years for a five-million-euro renovation, the institute reopened with refreshed galleries in which to display hundreds of works of art and artifacts as well as video and audio meant to bring the Arab-speaking world to life.

title: How to Manage (and Avoid) Entitled Employees
description: Last week, I met a good friend and fellow small-business owner, George Elliman, for a drink. George is the publisher of an Austin, Tex., lifestyle magazine, Tribeza. When we get together, we always talk shop. This time, the subject of employees who have an overdeveloped sense of entitlement came up, and we quickly went from shooting the breeze and peeling beer labels to pleas of, Dont get me started!

title: Hello, Cruel World
description: The 1.7 million members of the Class of 2011 witnessed, within the four-year span of their college careers, one of the greatest bull markets in United States history and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. Last spring, they shed their caps and gowns and joined a kind of B.A. bread line. Unemployment among recent liberal-arts graduates, at 9.4 percent, was higher than the national average, and student-loan debt, at an average of nearly $25,000, had reached record levels. Worse still, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics was reporting that only 5 of the 20 jobs projected to grow fastest over the coming decade would require a bachelors degree. Though the statistics still show that a college degree correlates with both higher income and lower unemployment in the long run, diplomas didnt seem very valuable when they were handed out last May.

title: Tebow, Manning and Pat Robertson
description: Steve Politi of The Star-Ledger makes a valiant try in arguing that people are overreacting about the impact of Tim Tebows arrival in New York, writing that a lot of people not from around here are telling us how this experience is going to completely rock our world, as if this is some kind of distant sports outpost.

title: From Engineering Marvels, a Turnaround in U.S. Oil Output
description: As Eric Lipton and I write in The Times, oil production is increasing rapidly in the United States even as gasoline consumption is falling.

title: Credit Suisse Cuts Chief Executives Pay in Half
description: LONDON  Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of the Swiss financial giant Credit Suisse, experience a 54 percent cut in his compensation last year after the firm reported its first quarterly loss in three years.

title: Fears About North Korea and Iran Will Dominate Nuclear Summit Meeting in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Obama will join the leaders of more than 50 countries here next week for a nuclear security summit meeting, where fears about two rogue states, North Korea and Iran, will loom over a gathering ostensibly about the perils of nuclear terrorism.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: The Parsis, Once Indias Curators, Now Shrug as History Rots
description: In the course of over one year of archival research in India, I have been heartened to see how, in a few institutions like the National Archives, the countrys rotting history now has a fighting chance of survival. However, I have been deeply dismayed by one observation: the inability of my own community, the Parsis, to properly protect our own history and heritage. In many ways, the Parsi experience reflects a colossal stumbling block toward proper historical preservation in India: a dearth of public activism, support and interest, even amongst the educated and affluent.

title: Delivering Verse in Naughty Positions
description: Cheek by Jowls production of Tis Pity Shes a Whore never seems to get out of bed. This is not to suggest that Declan Donnellans overheated, modern-dress interpretation of John Fords notorious 17th-century tragedy, which runs through March 31 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is in any way sleepy or sluggish.

title: Tebowing and Freeing Drew Stanton
description: Five links for your consideration:

title: Etch A Sketch Highlights Missed Opportunities for Romneys Rivals
description: Im sympathetic to the notion that the news medias coverage of the Etch A Sketch comments made by one of Mr. Romneys top aides has been excessive. At the same time, the comments made by the adviser, Eric Fehrnstrom, will serve to remind voters of a major issue in the campaign: that Mr. Romney has substantially altered his positions on a wide range of issues since he ran for governor in Massachusetts in 2002.

title: Zynga to Sell $687 Million of Stock
description: Public shareholders will be able to get an even bigger piece of Zynga, the online gaming company.

title: VIPshop of China Tumbles in American Debut
description: 10:13 a.m. | Updated

title: Opinion Report: Mohammed Merah
description: From the editorial page

title: Are There Lessons in the Trayvon Martin Tragedy?
Friday Reading: Getting to Know New Zealand on the Cheap
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Daily Report: New Rules on Anti-Terror Data Mining
description: The Obama administration is moving to relax restrictions on how counterterrorism analysts may retrieve, store and search through data on Americans that was gathered for purposes other than national security threats, Charlie Savage reports on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Entire Clans and Villages Fleeing Syria, Inquiry Finds
description: A United Nations commission on rights abuses in the Syria conflict offered grim new details on Friday of the governments repression, including the uprooting of extended clans and villages forced to flee into neighboring countries by security forces bent on crushing armed resistance.

title: China Moves to Stop Transplants of Organs After Executions
description: HONG KONG  China said on Friday that within three to five years it planned to end the practice of transplanting organs from executed prisoners, a step that would address what for decades has been one of the countrys most criticized human rights issues.

title: France After, and in Spite of, Toulouse
description: Despite the failure of the French state to catch Mohammed Merah before his murderous rampage, the events of the last few weeks have nonetheless altered the tone of the French presidential campaign, tilting it, at least for now, in favor of Nicolas Sarkozy, the incumbent who has been trailing his main rival in the polls. Read Steven Erlangers analysis.

title: After Palin, Expect a More Intense Vetting Process
description: Lets say youre moving steadily toward wrapping up the Republican presidential nomination and you allow yourself to begin thinking ahead to the question of a running mate.

title: Bookshelf
description: The interior designer Marco Pasanella is now enjoying a robust second act as a vintner, but first he had to triple his mortgage, max out his credit cards and risk his marriage. He details his metamorphosis in a new memoir, Uncorked (Clarkson Potter, $24). File this under perfect pairings: The psychedelic dot enthusiast Yayoi Kusama illustrates a new edition of Alices Adventures in Wonderland (Penguin Global, $35). It appears at the same time as her big Tate Modern museum show, which moves to the Whitney in June. Mona Talbotts Zuppe (The Little Book Room, $19) is as much a collection of inspiring Italian soup recipes  like pured pea with mint  as it is a window into the eco-conscious, seasonal kitchen of the American Academy in Rome. And The Uninvited Guests (Harper, $25), a devilish comic novel by Sadie Jones, is set inside a strange, shallow red-brick manor house in Downton Abbey-era England.

title: From Mourning to Electioneering
description: The Mohammed Merah siege is over. The French national of Algerian descent who claimed responsibility for killing three French paratroopers, a rabbi and three Jewish school children died during a police raid yesterday. One immediate question now is how the rampage will play out in the upcoming French presidential elections.

title: Fill-In | Hunger Games Fan Mania
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this article from the New York Region section, Hunger Games Brings Out Legions of Fans, and Inflatable Mattresses.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: G.M. Looks to Add a Little MTV, and Whitney Houstons Death
description: It would once have been a slam-dunk assignment: getting young people excited to buy cars. Next, getting squirrels interested in acorns. But as a new generation of first-car buyers arrive on the scene, carmakers are seeing a significant lack of interest, Amy Chozick reports. General Motors has hired MTV Scratch, which consults on making brands more attractive to young people, to rethink the car buying and car driving experience, ranging from the test drive to the dashboard.

title: Whats 4 + 4 + 4?
description: ISTANBUL  The answer is 12, the number of years that legislation now steamrolling its way through the Turkish Parliament would require children to spend in school. The law proposes to increase compulsory schooling by four years, up from eight grades.

title: An toile Is Born
description: PARISIn the best theatrical tradition, the leading lady was injured, the talented newcomer stepped in at the 11th hour, and, lo! a star was born. Quite literally so at the Opera Bastille Thursday night, where the Paris Opera Ballet director, Brigitte Lefvre, came onstage at the end of the companys performance of La Bayadre to announce that Ludmila Pagliero, who had just danced the role of Gamzatti, had been promoted to the coveted and elusive title of toile, or star.

title: Old Anti-Semitism and New in Europe
description: LONDON  Israels liberal Haaretz newspaper sounded a note of caution on Friday against the temptation to cry anti-Semitism after the tragic events in France.

title: Image of the Day: March 23
Morning Buzz, March 23: Borrowing a Technique From 007
description: Good morning. The warm spell will continue Friday with highs around 75 degrees and partly cloudy skies.

title: Friday Night Music: For What Its Worth
description: Yes, I know its actually morning. But an early musical posting given todays column:

title: College President Is Obamas Pick for World Bank Chief
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Friday named Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College and a global health expert, as its nominee to lead the World Bank.

title: On Our Radar: Polluted Rivers
description: The Ohio River ranks first among American waterways in toxic discharges from industry, followed by the Mississippi and the New River in Virginia and North Carolina, based on 2010 figures. Industrial facilities dumped 226 million pounds of toxic chemicals into American waterways that year, according to federal statistics. [Environment California]

title: Leading Off: Shield Your Eyes, the Tournament Is Back On
description: If you were looking for beauty in this N.C.A.A. mens tournament, you have clearly come to the wrong place. It is also notably lacking in buzzer-beaters, successful teams from west of the Mississippi and unless Ohio can topple North Carolina Friday night, mid-majors smiting the system. But if the tragic fashion trend in uniform design hasnt been enough to make you cringe by the opening tip-off, many of the games themselves have taken on the qualify of getting a cavity filled without Novocaine.

title: State Senate Race Spotlights a Feeble Democratic Party
description: Taken together, the Democratic Party of Brooklyn and Queens is the El Cid of city politics: Inside its impressive looking armor, there is barely a pulse.

title: The Macro Wars Are Not Over
description: Noah Smith has a post on the current state of the macro controversy thats justifiably getting a lot of attention.By and large I agree with his points: Keynesian revivalists like Brad DeLong and yours truly have not managed to get a dramatic reversal in policy, nor have we persuaded the freshwater side that its all wrong. But we have managed to change the conversation.

title: Lay on Macduff, and Quaff Thee a Duff
description: THERE are a few Simpsonisms  Ned Flanderss okely-dokely and, of course the famed doh  in Rick Millers MacHomer, a one-man show in which he puts Shakespeares words into the mouths of Homer, Marge and 50 other characters from The Simpsons. But Mr. Miller, a Canadian comedian and actor perhaps best known here as host of the short-lived hidden-camera TV show Just for Laughs, estimates that about 85 percent of the text is from the original.

title: Who Wants to Operate With Power Tools?
description: As a physician assistant practicing in oncology for the last 30 years, I can speak to the competencies of nonphysician medical providers (physician assistants and nurse practitioners) who are able to cover many, if not most, of the challenges of everyday medicine. The cost of training these providers is a fraction of the time and money invested in physicians, and if programmatically applied in countries like Zambia could go a long way in meeting the challenges of health care provision. Rather than bemoaning the choices facing physicians like Dr. Kunj Desai, advocating for programs that could lessen the impact of whatever choice he makes is the only real choice that countries like Zambia can make.

title: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy
description: The stigma regarding mental illness continues to exist. The phrase its all in their heads is quite offensive to individuals whose illness is psychologically based  literally in their minds. Why do we find

title: Why Talk Therapy Is on the Wane and Writing Workshops Are on the Rise
description: 1. In Which the Author Reveals a Scandalous Motive for Attending Grad School

title: Rare Grooves, All Night Long
description: Another revival for Northern Soul.

title: Who Made That Granola?
description: You can trace breakfast cereal back to gruel-eating ancient Greeks, but it wasnt until the 19th century that the idea of eating cold cereal was embraced. In 1863, Dr. James Caleb Jackson, a health reformer who believed illness was rooted in the stomach, began experimenting with cold cereal to augment the mineral-spring treatments at his sanitarium in upstate New York. He baked graham flour into brittle cakes, which he then crumbled and baked again. It was not an immediate success; in fact, it was edible only when soaked in milk overnight. Even so, Jacksons granula, as he called it, would soon have competition. It was not long before Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, a Michigan man with a sanitarium of his own, was also promoting a healthful cold cereal. Kellogg ran the Battle Creek Sanitarium, popular with luminaries like Amelia Earhart. He, too, was a digestive evangelist, and in the late 1870s or early 80s, Kellogg combined wheat flour, oatmeal and cornmeal into a mixture that he also called granula. Jackson sued. Kellogg duly switched the u to an o, and by 1889, he was selling two tons of granola a week. Kellogg went on to invent the cereal flake, which led to the Kelloggs cereal empire, which led to Froot Loops and Cocoa Krispies.

title: You Cant Ruffle Sandra Lee
description: For years you have pooh-poohed the notion that youre the next Martha Stewart. But Kmart dropped Stewarts Everyday line in 2009, and your Sandra by Sandra Lee home line is about to be introduced at both Kmart and Sears. Do you feel as if youve knocked a giant from the top of the mountain?  Im the only personality that has Sears and Kmart. Thats not something that anyone in my category has been able to do. But Im not arrogant that way. Marthas not thrown off anywhere. Did she throw Julia Child off? Julia was Julia, Martha is Martha and I am me. Period.

title: A Suitable Man
description: I wept when I read this fine story aloud to my wife. We are in our 60s, friends and lovers for 10 years and married for the past 18 months. We are deliriously happy together, not least because she enjoys my reading to her as much as I do. It is not trips to Paris but these little everyday moments that matter most and, as the essay shows, that remain available to the very end.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: He marshaled a national roll-out of specialty coffee drinks. He championed expanded menus and double-lane drive-throughs. Hes 48 years old. And hes the first African-American chief executive of McDonalds. His name is Don Thompson (above), and hell take over the chains 33,000 restaurants in 119 countries in June when the current leader, Jim Skinner, retires. (If you dont subscribe to the Journal, check out the Chicago Tribune.)  Glenn Collins

title: Forehead Lift
description: A slide show depicting forehead lifts.

title: Divisions and Irritation in Food Co-ops Debate
description: A graphic designer came to buy ingredients for dinner. So did an entrepreneur and a musician, an engineer and a law firm employee  all streaming into the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn for its bounty of organic produce, artisan cheese and fair-trade coffee.

title: Equities Edge Higher as Iran Sanctions Raise Oil Prices
description: Stock prices rose modestly on Friday, trimming the second weekly drop so far this year for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as gains in commodity and energy companies amid rising oil prices offset an unexpected decline in new-home sales.

title: Floating in Time, Hiding in Sight
description: RECENTLY I met the Japanese jazz pianist Masabumi Kikuchi at a West Village restaurant about 10 blocks from the Chelsea apartment where he has lived for half his life. Mr. Kikuchi, 72, belongs in a line with the most aesthetically stubborn jazz musicians, those who sidestep traditional notions of technique and embody more than they express: Thelonious Monk, Miles Davis, Paul Bley, Paul Motian. Even among them hes an extreme case.

title: No Apologies
description: On our Op-Ed page yesterday Bill Maher called for an end to fake outrage  and playacted hurt, and asked Americans to stop apologizing.

title: Chin Augmentation
description: A slide show explaining a surgical procedure to reshape or enhance the size of the chin.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ILLUMINATION,  by Kevin Brockmeier (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Human pain has been made literally visible in Brockmeiers deeply felt novel: headaches and broken bones glow with an otherworldly light. In the aftermath of a fatal car accident, the narrative follows a journal of love notes, written by a husband to his wife, as it passes through the hands of a data analyst, a photographer, a schoolboy, a missionary, a writer and a street vendor.

title: Editors Choice
description: FLAGRANT CONDUCT: The Story of Lawrence v. Texas: How a Bedroom Arrest Decriminalized Gay Americans,  by Dale Carpenter (Norton, $29.95.) Carpenter stirringly describes the 2003 Supreme Court decision that overturned the Texas sodomy law.

title: Up Front
description: William Saletan, Slates national correspondent, has written previously for the Book Review about the rights of embryos, the risks of genetic enhancement and the mysteries of human individuality. This week, assessing The Righteous Mind, by Jonathan Haidt, he approaches a topic of equal magnitude: Can the study of human nature explain our ethical convictions and remedy our political conflicts?

title: Gardens of Unearthly Delights
description: At 65, the British scholar Marina Warner is a veteran magus, and an adept mythographer of the vast global traditions of magic, metaphor and myth. Also an accomplished novelist, she augments her learning with her narrative skills. As a fan of her prolific enterprise for the last quarter-century, I regret that I have never met her, so delightful is her verve.

title: Seeing Is Unbelieving
description: Unless the pursuit of dreadfulness results in a tie, each year will possess its own worst book. But identifying the winner in this dubious competition poses difficulties. Surely even a well-read literary editor of The New Republic must wonder whether among all those inevitably unturned pages lurks something even more atrocious than his favorite candidate. How then could Leon Wieseltier select THE ATHEISTS GUIDE TO REALITY: Enjoying Life Without Illusions (Norton, $25.95), by Alex Rosenberg, as the worst book of 2011?

title: On the Origin of Everything
description: Lawrence M. Krauss, a well-known cosmologist and prolific popular-science writer, apparently means to announce to the world, in this new book, that the laws of quantum mechanics have in them the makings of a thoroughly scientific and adamantly secular explanation of why there is something rather than nothing. Period. Case closed. End of story. I kid you not. Look at the subtitle. Look at how Richard Dawkins sums it up in his afterword: Even the last remaining trump card of the theologian, Why is there something rather than nothing?, shrivels up before your eyes as you read these pages. If On the Origin of Species was biologys deadliest blow to supernaturalism, we may come to see A Universe From Nothing as the equivalent from cosmology. The title means exactly what it says. And what it says is devastating.

title: Mar. 25  31
description: A FAMILY reunion of sorts is taking place at the Vineyard Theater, where the new musical NOW. HERE. THIS. opens this week. The gang that brought the world [title of show], the infectious and seriously self-referential musical with a similarly eccentric title, has reunited to create a show that promises to be just as idiosyncratic and as personal as their first.

title: Elbow Room | Jack Foxleys Dapper Patches
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: DOGMA By Lars Iyer.Melville House, paper, $14.95.

title: Sealy Challenges Activist Investor
description: The Sealy Corporation is striking back against a top investor that is pushing to remake the board of the mattress maker.

title: Prisoner of Fashion
description: The humor in this first novel is nothing to laugh at. Though youre not really supposed to get that until youre nearly done.

title: Mall Rats
description: Nobody ever hated the contemporary world with as much intensity and conviction as J. G. Ballard. In five decades of unforgiving literary production, he drowned it, scorched it, flayed it with whirlwinds, deluged it with Martian sand, even transformed it into a crystalline jungle populated by jewel-skinned crocodiles, people and parrots. His characters have been sodomized in car crashes, driven crazy by scientific researchers, hounded by billboards and forced to observe atrocities looping endlessly on movie screens until even Zapruders exploding bullets seemed as mundane and predictable as elevator music. For Ballard, who died in 2009 at the age of 78, the true horrors of our collective future dont concern what might happen hundreds of years from now in a spaceship; rather, they reverberate in the very ordinary now-ness of freeway overpasses, sports stadiums, high-rise apartment complexes and gated communities. In other words, dont bother watching out for zombies or mutant beasts or whatever. The ones you really need to watch out for are those mall-walkers.

title: Masters
description: Golf fans these days live in what amounts to a twilight era of one-man rule: that of Tiger Woods, still clinging to the throne even as usurpers rise up around him. Before Woods there was a duumvirate at the top of golf  Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer  and before them there was the triumvirate of James Dodsons new book: Sam Snead, Byron Nelson and Ben Hogan. More at the top is better, it turns out, or at least more interesting, and Dodsons book evokes an era when golf was more vivid and less corporate than it seems now.

title: The Sixth Ward
description: In 1845, Edgar Allan Poes poem The Raven appeared in The New York Mirror; the New York Knickerbockers organized themselves into an official baseball club; and the New York City Police Department was established. Theres nothing about Poe or the Knicks in Lyndsay Fayes rollicking historical novel, THE GODS OF GOTHAM (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $25.95), but she does offer a sensational account of what early police work was like for those untested and ill-trained copper stars who patrolled the city in 16-hour shifts, trying to keep members of the populace from robbing, swindling, thrashing, raping and murdering one another.

title: I Was Wrong About Paul Ryan
description: No, I havent lost my mind. Hes still the same flim-flamming fiscal phony he always was.

title: Compatibility Tests
description: Adam Levins new story collection, Hot Pink, is about how love  family love, romantic love, love between friends  turns us into people we never thought wed become. Today youre one person, tomorrow  enter love, and all bets are off. You could turn out to be anybody.

title: A Wedding and a Funeral
description: A very good book is not only more satisfying, memorable and coherent than its lesser neighbors on the shelves. Its also more relaxing to read. That wary inhalation as you take in the first lines  Will I believe in these characters? How distracted will I be by implausible dialogue, or forced plotlines?  lasts a page or two and then gives over to a long, slow breath of relief. You dont have to worry. This writer knows exactly what shes doing. She wont let you down.

title: Life and Limb
description: There was a restless instinct in the family, an appetite for geography and change. Presentiments like this come early and often in Peter Behrenss otherwise impressive new novel, The OBriens, which follows four generations of an Irish family from the wilds of Quebec at the turn of the 20th century through British Columbia, California, New York, Montreal, Europe and finally to Maine in the 1960s. The dominant figure is Joe OBrien, who, while still an adolescent, supports the family by cutting and delivering firewood to his neighbors. His father has died in the Boer War, his mother is sickly and his younger siblings are dependent on him.

title: Edison Illuminated
description: The tantalizing thing about electricity, that fundamental force that lights our nights and floods our nanocircuits, is that no one has ever been able to say just what it is. Easy enough to see and feel what it does  even taste it, as schoolboys do when they grab each others tongues and touch a battery. But when electricity isnt going someplace, it has no color, no character.

title: Why Wont They Listen?
description: Youre smart. Youre liberal. Youre well informed. You think conservatives are narrow-minded. You cant understand why working-class Americans vote Republican. You figure theyre being duped. Youre wrong.

title: Inside the List
description: THE ICK FACTOR: For his academic research into morality, the psychologist Jonathan Haidt  his new book, The Righteous Mind, is at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list  likes to ask the kind of hypothetical questions that are more commonly the province of seventh-grade slumber parties. Would you drink apple juice if you knew a sterilized cockroach had touched it? Would you sign a nonbinding contract to sell your soul? If you find your dog dead on the road, killed by a passing car, is it O.K. to carry it home and cook it up for dinner? Haidts book is a serious study of divergent moral viewpoints in politics and religion, but he obviously gets a kick out of confronting his subjects with the ick factor: If you are not a liberal or libertarian Westerner, he writes in his first chapter, you probably think its wrong  morally wrong  for someone to have sex with a chicken carcass and then eat it. Haidt doesnt say where he comes down on the chicken question, but he did tell The Boston Globe recently that his book initially stemmed from a desire to advance liberal positions. When I switched over into studying politics in 2004, he said, I did it expressly to help the Democrats beat the Republicans. I wanted to use moral psychology to help my team! But in the process of learning about all sides, and delving deeply into political psychology, I sort of lost the partisan fervor, and now Im fascinated. Thats what I hope moral psychology can do for people  replace demonization with fascination.

title: U.S. Sergeant Charged With 17 Counts of Murder in Afghan Killings
description: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales was charged on Friday with 17 counts of premeditated murder and six counts of assault and attempted murder in connection with a March 11 attack on Afghan civilians, American forces in Afghanistan said.

title: Obama Speaks Out on Trayvon Martin Killing
description: 1:20 p.m. | Updated President Obama spoke in highly personal terms on Friday about how the shooting in Florida of a 17-year-old black youth named Trayvon Martin had affected him, saying that if I had a son, hed look like Trayvon.

title: Learning to Worship Together in a Combined Parish
description: St. Augustine Church in the Bronx long sat atop a slight hill, like a beacon to the surrounding African-American community for whom it was home and haven. Today, the cavernous church is silent, closed down earlier this year after mounting costs and dwindling resources.

title: How Much Is That Jersey in the Window?
description: Same formula, much better result.

title: Assuming the Right Locks for the Part
description: FROM the first Shakespearean performer ever cast as Ophelia, wigs have been a necessary staple in the toolbox of props that aid an actor in assuming a character. Theyve allowed Elizabeth Taylor her austere and almost incomprehensibly silky Cleopatra hair, Cher her dowdiness and her dazzle in Moonstruck, and Steve Van Zandt a screen career that doesnt require his E Street Band do-rag.

title: Where the Avant-Garde Is Childs Play
description: AT first glance the ensemble setting up in a fifth-floor classroom at the Kaufman Center on West 67th Street in Manhattan seems like any other student group and exactly what you would expect to find in a building that houses two music schools and Merkin Concert Hall. Teenage string and brass players tune their instruments and play fragments of pieces they are working on; saxophonists see to their reeds; percussionists contribute spiritedly to the din; and a guitarist and a bassist quietly pluck figures from the scores on their music stands.

title: So, There Were These Three Storytellers
description: THE eight people in David Crabbs Wednesday night class had been asked not to walk like themselves. So the students shuffled or pranced, puffed out their stomachs, clutched their backs. They all had their own gaits, and no one made eye contact.

title: Online Show Wins Fans in High Places
description: THE moon morphs into a talking dog and implores a young man to kill his friend. A peyote-powered bachelor party goes majestically off the rails, leading to cross-dressing and cannibalism. An aspiring comedian in search of ever-stronger narcotics, bottles, then huffs the souls of the freshly dead in Hollywood.

title: A Flamenco-Playing Sitar and an Asymmetrical Groove
description: Anoushka Shankar

title: Wheelies: The $25,000 Question Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Ancient Hawaiians Caught More By Fishing Less
description: Centuries ago, Hawaiians caught three times more fish annually than scientists generally consider to be sustainable in modern times  and maintained this level of harvest for more than 400 years, researchers report in a new study in the journal Fish and Fisheries.

title: Parental Quandary: Disciplining a Strangers Child
description: F. is a dad with a quandary  a social situation thats bound to come up again. The other day, my wife and I were in a restaurant with our three sons (ages 2, 3 and 7), he writes. This restaurant has an area designated for kids, with toys, TV, etc. Our sons were playing there and we were keeping an eye on them.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Jeanette Winterson discusses her new memoir; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jonathan Haidt talks about his new book, The Righteous Mind; Charles McGrath revisits a golden age of golf; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Friendly FRED
description: Joe Weisenthal has a very nice report about the wonderful FRED data website. I truly wish that Eurostat  an excellent source, which Ive been using a lot  were a tenth as user-friendly.

title: Police Commissioner Shares a Secret Recipe
description: In an annual City Hall tradition, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg invites the highest-ranking officials in his administration to a friendly bureaucrats night out. This years event took place last week at the Institute of Culinary Education in Manhattan, where New York Citys biggest municipal names prepared a three-course dinner of pasta, dessert, and an entree choice of char, chicken, or steak.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (6), Cuba (0)
description: Scoring a hat trick in an Olympic qualifier is a pretty big deal for a 21-year-old midfielder, but Joe Corona looked downright sheepish after his third goal flew past Odisnel Cooper and gave the United States a 6-0 victory over Cuba.

title: Funny, You Dont Look Fetish
description: Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: All-Access Hockey Broadcasts Spread to Campuses
description: In each of the last two seasons, HBOs 24/7: Road to the N.H.L. Winter Classic series has brought new viewers to the N.H.L., thanks to its storytelling, production values and access.

title: Growth Spurts Considered
description: Kiernan Shipka, 12, plays Sally Draper on AMCs Mad Men, which starts its fifth season on Sunday. She was born in Chicago and began acting professionally when she was 6. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: If I Had a Son, Hed Look Like Trayvon, Obama Says
description: As my colleague Michael Shear reports, at the White House on Friday morning, President Obama briefly addressed the national uproar over the killing of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed African-American high school student who was shot by a neighborhood watch captain in Florida last month.

title: Business Day Live | March 23, 2012
description: Edward Wyatt reports on the JOBS Act; columnist James. B. Stewart looks at Representative Paul Ryan's tax cut plan; and American energy production is on the rise.

title: A Spelling Champ Whose E-U-O-N-Y-M Should Have Been 'Joy'
Preparing to Face a Shot Swatter
description: DES MOINES  As McNeese State of Louisiana prepared to face top-ranked Baylor and its 6-foot-8 center, Brittney Griner, in December, the Cowgirls had no way to simulate Griners height and reach on a basketball court. So their coach took a kayak paddle to practice.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A barbecue contest called Grillin on the Bay and the Brooklyn Chili Smackdown is on Saturday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at St. Mark School, East 18th Street (Avenue Z), in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. There will be barbecue for sale starting at 11 a.m. and the chili competition kicks off at 1 p.m. Guests can taste and judge for $10.

title: World Bank Nominee  and Rap Star
description: As my colleague Annie Lowrey reported, the Obama administration announced its nomination for the next World Bank president: Jim Yong Kim.

title: World Bank Pick Rapped at Dartmouth
description: President Obamas pick to be the next leader of the World Bank, Jim Yong Kim, has a hidden talent: he raps.

title: Shopping for Art in Hong Kong
description: Much can be learned about Chinese art at Hong Kongs auctions, museums, galleries and shops.

title: President Obama on Trayvon Martin Case
description: At a press conference in the Rose Garden Friday, President Obama was asked to comment on the killing of Trayvon Martin.

title: Apps, Anyone? Managing Your Energy Consumption
description: Amid the debate in Washington over federal energy policy, at least one of the administrations ideas seems to be gaining widespread support. On President Obamas four-state tour to promote his all of the above energy agenda, nine of the countrys largest utility companies pledged to support the White Houses Green Button program by making information on energy usage available to their customers. The announcement came on Thursday during an event at Ohio State University where several of the utilities chief executives appeared with the president.

title: The Haves Who Gave
description: Edith Minturn Stokes and Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes are best known today as the patrician subjects of this 1897 portrait by John Singer Sargent, which hangs in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Banking and shipping heirs, Newton and Edith were at once wealthy globe-trotters and reform-minded New York liberals whose good deeds have endured even as the couple themselves drifted into obscurity. In a brisk, admiring dual biography, Love, Fiercely (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26), Jean Zimmerman argues that theirs was perhaps the greatest love story never told.

title: How the West Was Filled With Loss
description: FOR his 1948 Fort Apache, the first movie in his celebrated cavalry trilogy, John Ford brought together four of the five leading men most closely associated with his career: George OBrien, the star of The Iron Horse (1924), Fords first major critical and commercial success; Victor McLaglen, whose 12 films with Ford include an Oscar-winning performance in The Informer (1935); Henry Fonda, the Tom Joad of Fords Grapes of Wrath (1940); and John Wayne, who first worked with Ford as a prop man and extra in the late 1920s but only became an A-list actor with Fords Stagecoach in 1939.

title: Marquez Back and Red Bulls Back at Home
description: HARRISON, N.J.  With a flip of a switch on Friday, Rafael Marquez of the Red Bulls will ignite the tower lights at the Empire State Building in Manhattan in the teams colors (red, white and blue) and at the same time hope to set alight the clubs foundering 2012 Major League Soccer season. The Red Bulls are off to an 0-2 start after two losses on the road, and they open at home Sunday afternoon against Colorado at Red Bull Arena.

title: The View from St. Bonaventure: Ready for the Challenge of Notre Dame
description: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: India in One, Two or Three Weeks
description: THE connection between travel and a Coco Chanel dictum may not be that obvious. The French designer once purportedly said that a woman should stop before leaving the house, gaze in the mirror and then remove one piece of jewelry. The operative principle was to simplify.

title: Off the Charts: Among the Best Presidents or the Worst, in Economic Terms
description: Measured by stock market performance since he entered office, President Obamas administration has been among the most successful of the last hundred years. Measured by economic growth, it ranks near the bottom.

title: Chamberlain Dislocates Ankle and Has Surgery
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain, the charismatic Yankees relief pitcher whose career has gone through a variety of peaks and valleys, sustained an ankle injury Thursday afternoon that required surgery, General Manager Brian Cashman said, casting in doubt his season, if not his career.

title: After Stock Debut, BATS Pulls I.P.O.
description: 3:46 p.m. | Updated It should have been a day of celebration for BATS Global Markets.

title: Russia to Ease Law on Forming Political Parties
description: MOSCOW  Responding to the outcry over disputed parliamentary elections in December and the huge street protests in Moscow that followed, Russian lawmakers on Friday unanimously approved legislation to make it easier to form and maintain new political parties.

title: Mothers of Children With Autism Earn Less
description: Mothers of children with an autism spectrum disorder are less likely to be employed than mothers of children with no health limitations. They work seven hours less per week, on average, and they earn less: 35 percent less than mothers of children with another health limitation, and 56 percent less than the mothers of children with no health limitations.

title: Judge a Tax Plan by Its Loopholes
description: Having touched the third rail of American politics last year  proposed cuts to entitlements like Medicare  and lived to fight another day, Representative Paul Ryan was back this week with a revised Republican budget proposal and another storm of criticism. His budget slashes the safety net to pay for tax cuts mostly for wealthy Americans(a column in The Washington Post); is one in which the rich pay less in taxes than the unfairly low rates they pay now (an editorial in The New York Times); and would shower the wealthiest few Americans with an average tax cut of at least $150,000 (the White House).

title: Book Review Podcast: Jeanette Winterson on the Operatic Dimensions of Her Mother
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Kathryn Harrison reviews Jeanette Wintersons wonderfully titled new memoir, Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal? The book addresses Ms. Wintersons difficult childhood with her troubled, abusive mother, a subject that also appeared in fictional form in her 1985 debut novel, Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit. Ms. Harrison writes:

title: If I Had a Son Hed Look Like Trayvon
description: After President Obama spoke with Sandra Fluke, the Georgetown Law student that Rush Limbaugh called a slut, he explained his concern in personal terms. He said he reached out to Ms. Fluke because he had his two daughters in mind.

title: Republicans Cry Foul on Obama Catchphrase
description: As taglines go, All of the above is not exactly phenomenal, lacking the sex appeal of its energy-policy sister, Drill, baby, drill, and the historic resonance of, say, Wheres the beef? It conjures a standardized test more than economic stimulus.

title: From the Police Commissioner, a Mysterious Meatball
description: You could call it a police procedural: the favorite meatball recipe of New York Citys police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly (right). But by Dining section standards, the thing is a bit short on procedure.

title: Lawmakers Ask Apple App Makers About Privacy
description: Two members of Congress are pushing ahead with an investigation into privacy issues in Apples App Store. After contacting Apple earlier this month with questions about app privacy, the lawmakers have now sent letters to 34 app developers requesting information about their data-collection techniques.

title: The View from Ohio University: The Focus Will Be on Speed
description: During the N.C.A.A. tournament, The Quad will feature posts from reporters at newspapers on campuses of teams that have the potential to be the Cinderellas of 2012.

title: Public Theater Artistic Director Says Our Audience Was Misled by  Daisey
description: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has put more distance between the theater and the monologist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, which just finished a hugely successful run at the Public.

title: Landbrot, a German Bakery Times Two
description: A new German bakery, unlike any other in New York City, has its roots in Swabia, a region of Bavaria. Its name, Landbrot (which means country or farm bread), is that of its signature loaf, a round dark rye that is briefly baked a second time to bestow a distinctive heavy crust. The bread is one of about two dozen varieties baked on the second floor of the marble-sheathed shop, cafe and bar, which opens on April 1 in Greenwich Village.

title: Wrestling Empire Joins Tag Teams With Studios
description: STAMFORD, Conn.

title: Owner of Historical House Injured as Floor Gives Way
description: There was much to discover in the nooks and crannies of the massive Revolutionary War-era sandstone house on Staten Island. An October listing by the Gateway Arms Realty Corporation proclaimed the historical relevance of the Neville-Tysen house, named for a retired naval officer on land overlooking the Kill Van Kull.

title: Steps Set for Livestock Antibiotic Ban
description: The Obama administration mustwarn drug makers that the government may soon banagricultural uses of some popular antibioticsthat many scientists say encourage the proliferation of dangerous infectionsand imperil public health, a federal magistrate judge ruled on Thursday.

title: Arts Clubs Ex-President May Return, Judge Rules
description: Did somebody say reset button?

title: What Stocks and G.D.P. Say About Obamas Chances
description: AS the presidential election campaign heats up, two measures of the economic success of President Obamas administration provide drastically different views of how he has done.

title: Pope Arrives in Mexico, Lamenting Drug Violence
description: SILAO, Mexico  Pope Benedict XVI landed here Friday, starting his first trip to Spanish-speaking Latin America with a warm greeting from Mexicos president, Felipe Caldern, and thousands of Roman Catholics from all over Mexico who waved flags, shouted and cheered at the mere sound of his approach.

title: Biodiversity, and Green Slugs, in Action
description: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

title: A Midnight Bonanza for The Hunger Games
description: And the money came rolling in: The Hunger Games took in about $19.7 million at 12:01 a.m. shows on Friday  the highest midnight screenings total ever for a nonsequel, not accounting for inflation, according to Paul Dergarabedian, a box office analyst for Hollywood.com.

title: Pengrowth Energy to Buy NAL Energy
description: OTTAWA  Pengrowth Energy, a producer of oil and natural gas, said Friday that it would acquire NAL Energy, a smaller competitor based in Calgary, Alberta, in an all-stock transaction valued at 1.3 billion Canadian dollars.

title: A Times Sq. Ad for Greek Tourism, Financed by a Crowd
description: Greeks around the world, in an effort to help the beleaguered economy of Greece, have teamed up to buy digital advertising in Times Square that promotes Greek tourism.

title: Guest Post | 10 Ways to Talk to Students About Sensitive Issues in the News
description: This week it might be the Trayvon Martin shooting, while last week it could have been the Kony 2012 viral video, the soldier in Afghanistan accused of massacring women and children, or the outcry over Rush Limbaughs criticism of Sandra Fluke: In a flat social media world, parents and teachers are no longer the gatekeepers, and news of all kinds reaches children  sometimes even before it gets to adults.

title: TimesCast | March 23, 2012
description: A black teenager's death raises questions on on "Stand Your Ground" law | Dartmouth's president is nominated to lead the World Bank | President Obama projects an everyman image.

title: Suspect Called French School Attack Improvised, Spy Chief Says
description: TOULOUSE, France  The director of a French intelligence service said Friday that the confessed killer of seven who was slain after a 33-hour standoff with security services had improvised his attack on a Jewish school after failing to find a soldier to kill the same morning.

title: Recessions Lasting Effects
description: More grim ruminations on our economic prospects: What if recessions do permanent damage, diminishing a nations productive capacity?

title: Forget the Plot. What Nail Polish Is She Wearing?
description: IT made me laugh. It made me cry. It made me buy lip gloss.

title: Lead Producer of Smash Is Said to Step Down
description: Executives at NBC are confirming reports that the playwright Theresa Rebeck, who is listed as the creator of the networks Broadway-based drama Smash, has stepped down as the lead producer on the series.

title: Business Day Live: The Energy Rush
description: Edward Wyatt reports on the JOBS Act; columnist James. B. Stewart looks at Representative Paul Ryans tax cut plan; and American energy production is on the rise.

title: T Spring Design | Must Haves
description: Fresh color, floral pattern and subtle texture bring spring home. More

title: Recipes From the Cabbage Patch
description: Farmers markets have a reputation for being on the pricey side at times. But as Martha Rose Shulman points out in this weeks Recipes for Health, one vegetable that often presents a bargain is the cabbage.

title: Before a Carousels 100th Birthday, a Visit From the Doctor
description: When Todd W. Goings travels from his home in Ohio to tend to his patients in New York City, he knows he faces a heavy lift. Many are centenarians, with creaky limbs, unsteady gaits and wan complexions. Some are missing their tails.

title: Bulgari Family Tries to Become a Name in Wine
description: PALAZZONE, Italy  The Bulgari name has long been associated with luxury jewelry worn by some of the most famous celebrities in the world, like Elizabeth Taylor and Julianne Moore.

title: Notre Dame Women Take Aim at Another Final Four
description: This is not the time for Notre Dame womens basketball staff to worry about looking well-rested.

title: Less of a Frenzy for Lin in Toronto This Time
description: TORONTO  Jeremy Lins last trip to Canada began with a standing-room-only news conference and ended with a standing-room-only news conference, with a game-winning 3-pointer in between.

title: North Korean Orchestra Visit to United States Seems Unlikely
description: A small Atlanta aid organization that works mainly in North Korea wants to bring an orchestra from the isolated dictatorship to the United States, but comments from the State Department indicate that it wont be happening soon.

title: Jets Tebow Can Trace His Lineage to New Jersey
description: Tim Tebow arrives in New Jersey, where the Jets practice and play, as the worlds most famous backup quarterback. It is a homecoming, of sorts, centuries in the making, because Tebow appears to be the great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-grandson of a man from Hackensack.

title: Helping Small-Business Owners Find the Perfect Mentor
description: VICE ADM. EDWARD M. STRAW was a bit skeptical when he was asked to donate his time and expertise to a program that helps small-business owners. He had mentored students hoping to get into his alma mater, the Naval Academy, and service members on their way out of the military.

title: A Shorebird, a Crab and a Call to Action
description: The red knot has begun its 9,300-mile migration from its wintering areas in the Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego regions of Argentina to its mating grounds in the Canadian Arctic. Like clockwork, the shorebird makes a crucial two-week stop each May in Delaware Bay; it is estimated that nearly 90 percent of the surviving Atlantic red knot population can be found there on a single May day.

title: Arcade Fire and the World Bank
description: Not a connection you might have expected  and yes, theres a bit of Kevin Bacon about it. But when I heard about the (inspired) choice of Jim Kim for the Banks presidency, I immediately saw it. Kim is a co-founder of Partners in Health, an organization profiled in Tracy Kidders Mountains Beyond Mountains. And the book in turn inspired an Arcade Fire song off their latest album (AF are big PIH supporters, and Regine Chassagne is of Haitian ancestry):

title: Praise Is Fleeting, but Brickbats We Recall
description: MY sisters and I have often marveled that the stories we tell over and over about our childhood tend to focus on what went wrong. We talk about the time my older sister got her finger crushed by a train door on a trip in Scandinavia. We recount the time we almost missed the plane to Israel because my younger sister lost her stuffed animal in the airport terminal.

title: Police Blotter Tweet of the Day
description: After earlier reports on social networks, Marylands Montgomery County Police Department confirmed on Friday that a caped crusader was indeed stopped by officers two days ago, for driving through the town of Silver Spring with a license plate on the rear of his vehicle that bore only the stylized logo of a bat.

title: Elaborate Weddings, Minus the Guests
description: IT was minutes before the wedding, and the planner left nothing to chance. The reception hall, a plank-floored farmhouse in the Santa Barbara, Calif., wine country, had been decorated in peonies. The dinner menu, rendered in calligraphy, promised wild mushroom tortellini and halibut with verjus. In a field outside, a photographer and videographer stood at the ready, near a ceremonial canopy draped in velvet and the aisle strewn with guinea feathers.

title: The Tennessee Monkey Bill
description: The Tennessee Senate approved legislation this week that some are calling a monkey bill  after the Scopes Monkey Trial, which also took place in Tennessee. In fairness to the state, its not quite that bad.

title: Santorum Refines Comments About Obama and Romney
description: WEST MONROE, La.  Rick Santorum on Friday recalibrated a remark he made a day earlier suggesting that the United States would be just as well off re-electing President Obama as it would be electing Mitt Romney in November.

title: Will Geithner or Paulson Occupy Dartmouth?
description: The news that Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College, is the front-runner to run the World Bank raises a question: if Mr. Kim leaves Dartmouth, who will replace him?

title: After Wisconsins Exit, Taylor Praises His Teammates
description: BOSTON  The Wisconsin Badgers season ended with a heartbreaking thud Thursday night once Jordan Taylors last-second heave fell short, but it began with outside expectations that made a a Round of 16 berth seem laughable.

title: Marina Salye, Politician Who Tried to Prosecute Putin, Dies at 77
