description: MOSCOW  Marina Salye, a Russian politician and former Soviet dissident who in the early 1990s led a thwarted inquiry into corruption in the office of Vladimir V. Putin, then a little-known deputy to the mayor of St. Petersburg, died on Wednesday in Ozero, Russia. She was 77.

title: More Than a Throwaway
description: Unlike many companies, the Vermont yogurt maker Stonyfield Farm has made significant inroads in recycling through a partnership with Whole Foods.

title: The Comeback and the Fall
description: A year after his return to racing, the legendary jockey Jacky Martin was paralyzed from the neck down after being thrown from his horse.

title: When Booze Comes Off the Battlefield
description: Editors note: This post follows one on Thursday that discussed alcohol use and regulation in combat zones. Alcohol clearly looms large in the minds of some service members in the wake of the killing of Afghan civilians in the Panjwai district of Kandahar Province and accusations that the man accused in the shootings, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales had been drinking.

title: The Most Dangerous Track
description: Labor Day weekend is the climax of the horseracing season at Ruidoso Downs in New Mexico. Last year, the weekend also underscored the dangers of horseracing in America.

title: Seriously Retro: Some 78s for Record Store Day
description: Record Store Day, the annual retail promotion started in 2008 to help struggling independent record stores, has to a great degree been about the fetish of collecting vinyl records. If youre interested in that Pavement or Big Star record available only on that day you better get in line early, because there may be 500 collectors ahead of you trying to get one of the 300 copies available (and then put it on eBay).

title: Soccer Hooligans in Israel Bring Racist Chants to Shopping Mall
description: Updated | 7:42 p.m. Notorious for their racist chants at soccer matches, hooligan supporters of the Israeli team Beitar Jerusalem flooded a Jerusalem mall this week and beat up several Arab employees, Israeli media reported.

title: Republican Hopefuls React to Trayvon Martin Killing
description: The Republican candidates for president on Friday condemned the shooting of an African-American teenager in Florida that occurred several weeks ago, calling it a tragedy that demanded further investigation.

title: Companies Pick Up Used Packaging, and Recyclings Cost
description: Brushing your teeth with a yogurt container? Wiping your mouth with a coffee cup?

title: What an Early Spring Has Sown on City Streets
description: Spring weather usually tosses a lot of bad fashion trends onto the citys sidewalks. But this year, with our strangely early spring, the journey between my house and Bergdorfs is absolutely perilous. I worry  I do!  about those late-middle-aged women in super-high platforms and skinny J Brand jeans. A ballerina in toe shoes would have more contact with the pavement than these babes do.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: There's No Place Like Home
In India, Palaces, Markets and History
description: The plans you made at home when you were planning your trip to India are seldom the final word on the matter.

title: No Need to Fear the Common Core Standards
In the Philippines, Missonis First Condo
description: From Milan to Kuwait City to Dubai to Edinburgh, Italian luxury fashion houses have clearly conquered the hotel business. Now it seems condominiums might be their next avenue of expansion. This week, the polychromatic money machine Missoni released renderings for its very first residential project, a condominium tower in a $315 million master-planned community in the Philippines.

title: Northern Soul, Revived Again
description: A short film by Elaine Constantine of a seventies dance craze to sixties music, brought to modern-day London.

title: Gamblings in the Air
description: In case further evidence is needed that ours is the Age of Gambling, a few recent random headlines help stack the deck some more:

title: Gulf Dolphins Exposed to Oil Are Seriously Ill, Agency Says
description: Dolphins in Barataria Bay off Louisiana, which was hit hard by the BP oil spill in 2010, are seriously ill, and their ailments are probably related to toxic substances in the petroleum, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration suggested on Friday.

title: Once Imperiled, U.S. Aid to Egypt Is Restored
description: WASHINGTON  An intense debate within the Obama administration over resuming military assistance to Egypt, which in the end was approved Friday by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, turned in part on a question that had nothing to do with democratic progress in Egypt but rather with American jobs at home.

title: Spain Is Not Out of the Woods Yet
description: MADRID  Officials from Washington to Frankfurt have recently declared that the worst is over for the euro zone.

title: Panel Extends Ethics Reviews of 2 House Members
description: WASHINGTON  The House Ethics Committee announced on Friday that it was extending its reviews of two members of Congress who have been accused in separate cases of improprieties involving their outside business interests.

title: After Tragedy, a Fresh Start for IndyCar
description: On Sunday, the Izod IndyCar Series begins its 2012 season on the street circuit of St. Petersburg, Fla. The event will feature a redesigned car, renewed competition among engine suppliers and not a negligible measure of sorrow.

title: Shrinking School Budgets Have Parents Filling the Gaps
Sara Gartland and David Lomel
description: WHEN an opera audience eagerly watches a young tenor excel as Alfredo, the conflicted young lover in La Traviata, its joy and exuberance can radiate through the sort of applause and cheers that rang in David Lomels ears when he made his San Francisco Opera debut in the role in June 2009.

title: Flying High Without the Wings
description: TESTED: 2012 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG Roadster

title: A Solid Luxury Option With a Lot of Options
description: EACH morning as the sun rises over Stuttgart, Mercedes-Benz executives must give thanks for the rise, fall, evolution and endurance of the S.U.V.

title: Getting the Hang of This S.U.V. Thing
description: Todays luxury S.U.V. buyers want comfort and safety, a combination that Mercedes-Benz is well suited to provide. With the ML350, the company does just that.

title: TimesCast | Self-Defense Law Questioned
description: March 23, 2012 -  The controversial shooting of 17-year old Trayvon Martin raises questions about the 'Stand your Ground' defense law.

title: Read This, or Be the Worst Parent Ever
description: When my wife was pregnant with our first child, I read every parenting and pregnancy book I could get my hands on. Then I panicked.

title: For Boston College, the Focus Is on the First Round
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: A Birthday Present: Accepted to the School of My Dreams
description: I received the good news on my birthday: The school Ive been waiting for has finally accepted me. I will be attending San Diego State University in the fall. The stress is finally over! I cant wait to officially become an Aztec.

title: Wedding Bells Still Chime
description: If you believe marriage is in decline, think again. A new government report has found that 8 in 10 women will get married by the time they turn 40, a figure that is virtually unchanged from the 1990s, before the drop in middle-income jobs reduced the supply of marriageable men.

title: Real Mad Men Pitched Safety to Sell Volvos
description: THE fifth season of Mad Men, the acclaimed drama series that depicts the fiercely competitive world of Madison Avenue advertising in the 1960s, will begin Sunday night on the AMC cable channel.

title: The Man Who Helped Volvo Mean Safe
description: Volvos reputation for crash safety was solidified in its advertising from the 1960s to the 80s under the direction of Ed McCabe, a co-founder of the agency Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: In the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Baylor Is All Business
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: Spring Staples | Back to Flats
description: Seasons change and so must accessories.

title: Auditioning for Real Chase Scenes
description: AS if the dispatcher had just barked out a 10-13  the New York police radio code for an officer needing assistance  Capt. Anthony J. Raganella put the cruiser in gear and floored the accelerator. Seconds later, he was cornering hard. The tires were squealing.

title: Readers Photos  My First Car
description: The attitude young people have toward cars is vastly different from a time when the car was at the center of youth culture. Take a look at a selection of photos sent by readers of their first cars.

title: Drafting Tebow for Social Scene
description: IT didnt take long. Within hours of the signing of Tim Tebow by the Jets, People magazine was already polling its readers about who was now the hottest Jets quarterback, Mark Sanchez, 25, or Mr. Tebow, 24 (as of Friday afternoon, Mr. Tebow had the clear lead), and Manhattan publicists were starting to strategize about how to attract the citys newest sports star to their red carpet events.

title: N.Y.U.s 1997 National Title Team Is Still Doing Well
description: Fifteen years ago this week, Marsha Harriss hands delivered a basketball through the net and made New York University history.

title: TimesCast | Obama Courts 'Everyman' Vote
description: The Obama campaign has been polishing up the Presidents ordinary-guy image.

title: Variety Is Being Put Up for Sale
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated Variety, the trade publication that has chronicled the entertainment industry for more than a century but has struggled financially in recent years, will be put up for sale, its parent company, Reed Business Information, said Friday.

title: Time to Tune Up the Portfolio
description: So much of our financial lives requires regular maintenance  whether its updating whos going to inherit what, checking that youre not paying too much for car insurance or making sure your investments, particularly your retirements savings, are still working for you.

title: Andalusia Looks Ready to Overturn Socialist Power
description: MADRID  The governing Popular Party of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy seemed poised to extend its control over Spain on Sunday, when voters in Andalusia, the countrys most populated region, were expected to overturn three decades of Socialist Party dominance.

title: Arrival of Pujols Brings Joy, and Risk, to Angels
description: Tempe, Ariz.

title: Even Bigger in Japan | Tokyo Gets Its Own Dover Street Market
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: More Partners Leave Dewey & LeBoeuf
description: Six partners at Dewey & LeBoeuf resigned on Friday, the latest in a series of defections at the embattled New York law firm.

title: A Program That Matches Mentor to Small Business
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about a mentoring program that matches small-business owners with successful business people. The program, a joint venture of the Clinton Foundation and UBS, is one of dozens that aim to help small businesses. And some are more successful than others.

title: The Predators of the Corporate Depths
description: Sharks Before Drowning, a dance by Molly Shanahan, opens and closes with the not-so-subtle sound  given the title  of lapping water. At the start, three dancers stand upstage, their outlines traced in shadow on the back wall. Inching forward, they assume the stances of nightclub singers, with gestures that include resting their hands on their hearts, pointing their fingers and reaching their arms imploringly.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Wolverine Leads X-Force on a Mission
description: When the title of a comic purposely evokes one of the most-beloved X-Men stories of all time, The Dark Phoenix Saga, it can lead to exceedingly high expectations and cynicism about whether those expectations will be met. Uncanny X-Force, Vol. 4, which contains the second half of The Dark Angel Saga and comes in at No. 7 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week, does not have this problem. Its a worthy successor to that classic tale in both execution and scope.

title: Decency Battles Debauchery, as a King Takes on a God
description: As the many empty seats for the New York Philharmonics subscription concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening clearly showed, conservative audiences often still shun unusual or contemporary repertory.

title: A Smartphone Future? But Not Yet
description: THE occasion of taking out my cellphone has provoked considerable mockery in the last 18 months or so.

title: Providers That Make It Easy to Rebalance Your Investment Portfolio
description: This weeks Your Money column examines the best approach to rebalancing your investment portfolio  in other words, reshuffling your investments back to their original mix to reduce your risks in the market.

title: The Animals That Make Us Human
description: Temple Grandin, the extraordinary expert on animal behavior who wrote Animals Make Us Human, is remarkable in many ways  among them through her ability to surmount, and to some extent enlist, her autism in creating a career in livestock management, research and authorship.

title: Heat Players Wear Hoodies as Statement in Martin Slaying
description: Miami Heat players have delved into an area athletes usually strenuously avoid, making a strong political statement in the outrage over the shooting death of the unarmed teen, Trayvon Martin, in Sanford, Fla. After the Heat posed together in hoodies, Dwyane Wade and LeBron James made quick work of publicizing the photo via their vast audience on Twitter. Wade also changed his Twitter photo to one of him in a hoodie.

title: A Kitchen Garden Worth the Digging
description: Despite its bucolic title, the new issue of Country Living magazine contains some wonderfully graphic food pornography. Specifically, produce porn, in the form of a detailed feature on The Ultimate American Kitchen Garden.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 23
description: Subjects include the St. Patricks Day Parade, a building collapse in Upper Manhattan and a City Hall photographer.

title: Europe Moves to Phase 2 in Review of Universal Bid for EMI
description: The European Commission said Friday that it had moved into the second phase of its review of Universals $1.9 billion bid for the recorded-music division of EMI, a move that was expected but could still cause problems for the Universal Music Group.

title: Israeli Officials Denounce U.N. Rights Council Bid to Study Effects of Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli officials on Friday rejected any prospect of cooperation with an inquiry called for a day earlier by the United Nations Human Rights Council into how Israeli settlements affect the rights of Palestinians.

title: DealBooks Week in Review: The Electric Cars Future
description: We visited a financial crisis SWAT team in Athens, met some electric car owners and found out why Wall Street firms had such boring Twitter feeds. A look back on our reporting of the last weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: A Democratic Embrace for ObamaCare
description: After two years, ObamaCare is an epithet no more. The Obama campaign says so.

title: No-Fear Celery Root
description: Dont know what to do with celery root? Melissa Clark shows you how to work with the aesthetically challenged root vegetable.

title: From Exile to Everywhere
description: AT 8 p.m. on a rainy Tuesday last month, Salman Rushdie strode into Junoon, a Flatiron district restaurant where 90 people awaited his arrival, some sipping chamomile-infused vodka cocktails. Mr. Rushdie, the Indian-born British author, was the guest of honor at a dinner sponsored by Dom Prignon and Booktrack, the maker of an app that synchronizes music to e-books.

title: Fte Accompli | Wild for Rewilding
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Young, and Grappling With Black Identity
description: Since early February, Danspace Project has played host to the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones as a curator, with his revisiting of Parallels, the thoughtful and thought-provoking program he created 30 years ago to interrogate ideas surrounding black dance. The ghost of the 1982 Parallels has been marvelously present in this Platform series, with many of its original participants contributing to this iteration.

title: A Program Matches Small Business Owners With Mentors
description: Paul Sullivan, who writes The Timess Wealth Matters column, has written an article about a new mentorship program that was developed jointly by the Clinton Foundation and UBS that pairs small-business owners with successful business people. The column gives several examples of businesses that have received mentoring. If you have thoughts about the effectiveness of these kinds of programs, you can leave a comment on the Bucks blog.

title: Gay Marriage Effort Attracts a Novel Group of Donors
description: LOS ANGELES  On a warm Friday afternoon three years ago, Rob Reiner, the director, arrived for lunch at the Beverly Hills estate of David Geffen, the entertainment mogul. Mr. Reiner and his political adviser, Chad H. Griffin, had spent six months drafting an ambitious legal campaign aimed at persuading the United States Supreme Court to establish a constitutional right of same-sex marriage.

title: Mastering Celery Root
description: In this weeks video, I demonstrate how to master celery root. Once youve done that, heres something you can make with it. Celery roots will soon be pushed to the sidelines as new spring vegetables start showing up in markets, so try this salad now. Or, save it for next winter when celery roots are pretty much all you can get.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: A new leader was nominated for the World Bank, the United States added tariffs to Chinese solar panels and Britains new budget maintained austerity measures.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, Tunisia, and Washington, D.C.

title: After Hospitalization, Mental Trouble for Elderly Patients
description: Many older people fear that a hospital stay could leave them even more disabled than they were before. Unfortunately, theres new reason to believe this fear is justified. Elderly patients who are hospitalized are at much higher risk of cognitive problems afterward, according to a study published on Wednesday in the journal Neurology.

title: If Forever Doesnt Work Out: The Same-Sex Prenup
description: WHEN Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi were married in 2008, people wanted to know two things: What did they wear? And was there a prenup?

title: Utah Asks U.S. to Return 20 Million Acres of Land
description: DENVER  The conservative political movement that has rallied behind the cry of states rights in recent years on fronts including immigration and health care is now focusing its energies on a much older question in the American West: public lands.

title: A Lower-Cost Filling Solution for the Mercedes-Benz ML350 Bluetec
description: For Sundays Automobiles section, I review gas- and diesel-burning versions of the third-generation ML350, the midsize sport utility vehicle from Mercedes-Benz.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 23
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 23
description: More Photographs

title: Polenta Lasagna, Buoyed by Noodles
description: SOME dishes come together as easily on the plate as they do in my head. I envision something and cook it for dinner, and the resulting recipe more or less matches what I craved.

title: History Carved Out of the Hills
description: SALT LAKE CITY  All museums are temples of sorts, monuments to collectors or cultures, declarations of identity, gathering places for tribute. But museums of natural history have an even more distinctive stature. Their focus is not human history, measured in centuries, but natural history, measured in eons. And their subject is not a particular culture and its accomplishments, but a world that seems to stand beyond culture altogether. Natural history museums seek their ground in the earth itself.

title: The Road to Gardiners Store
description: On New Years Day, 1862, Col. George Crook led six companies of his 36th Ohio Infantry out of Summersville, Virginia  now West Virginia  and raced north into what one local paper, The Marietta Home News, called the very heart of Africa.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Restaurants Hacked, and Employers Seeking Passwords
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: An Ordinary Bulb Turns Up the Wattage With Tarts
description: AS we wait impatiently for spring vegetables to arrive, its nice to remember that the all-season onion is standing by, like a good friend. Yes, the ordinary onion.

title: Maastricht Art Fair Draws Well-Heeled Buyers
description: The sort of buyers one sees at the Maastricht art fair are not only gratified by their own monograms or cyphers, but also have titles and crests.

title: New Details Emerge on MF Global, but No Smoking Gun
description: New details have emerged about MF Globals chaotic final days and a critical transfer of customer money that has become a central focus in the wide-ranging federal investigation into the firms collapse.

title: At the Maastricht Art Fair, a Flight to Beauty
description: Maastricht, the Netherlands

title: Boy Bands Are Back, Wholesome or Sexy
description: When the boy band One Direction this week became the first British group to top the Billboard 200 chart with its debut album  a feat not even the Beatles or Coldplay could pull off  many music fans caught onto a trend that tech-savvy teenage girls have known about for months: Boy bands are hot again.

title: Chic in Review | The Kate Moss Diet
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Santorums Catholicism Proves a Draw to Evangelicals
description: Carissa Wilson began paying attention to Rick Santorum last fall, when her high school class in American government was assigned to watch several of the Republican presidential debates. About three weeks ago, she attended a campaign speech that Mr. Santorum delivered at her school near Dayton, Ohio. The next day, March 6, Miss Wilson cast the first vote of her life, balloting for Mr. Santorum in the Ohio presidential primary.

title: Yeasted Dough for a Rustic Tart
description: This weeks City Kitchen column focuses on an onion tart. Well, actually, there are two onion tarts. Both are based upon the classic Alsatian tarte flambe, which is a simple pizza-like treat. The topping is lightly stewed onions, flecked with smoked bacon and dabbed with crme frache. Though this kind of tart is delicious year-round, it is sometimes associated with cooler weather. So I also made a vegetarian onion tart that is somewhat lighter, with green olives, thyme and goat cheese. Long story short, each version was so good, it seemed a shame not to offer both. The recipe gives details for the slight differences between the two.

title: Cage and Cunningham, Reunited, Restaged
description: It is 100 years since the composer John Cage was born, 20 since he died, and 70 since he began an enduring relationship, both artistic and personal, with the dancer-choreographer Merce Cunningham. In the years following Cages death, Cunningham (who died in 2009) made two new pieces that were accompanied by Cage music; he also made a few whose choreography suggested, with characteristic ambiguity, aspects of death, transcendence, different realms of existence.

title: Niese Gives Up 4 Runs; Mets Happy
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Jon Niese gave up two triples in the first inning of the Mets 9-4 loss to the Atlanta Braves on Friday afternoon.

title: Syrian Activists Respond to Report on Rights Abuses by Armed Rebels
description: As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Stephen Castle report, a United Nations inquiry commission on rights abuses in Syria offered grim new details on Friday of the continuing crackdown by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

title: At the Co-op, Tofu, Kale and Cocoa Puffs
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Excerpt: 'Ball Boys'
description: The ABS series explores the sports memorabilia business.

title: Blends Stand Out at a Tasting
description: Richard Olsen-Harbich of Bedell Cellars, a Long Island winemaker since 1981, favors blends over single-grape wines. An instrumental solo, while beautiful, cannot be as complex as chamber music, he said in an e-mail.

title: Blekko Works With Lavasoft on Spam-Free Search
description: The search engine Blekko is not content to be the underdog. It wants to be your guard dog too.

title: Bill Cunningham | Pow
description: The award for the weeks best dressed goes not to any pedestrian, as stylish as the ones here were, but to Mother Nature.

title: An Unfriendly Greeting at Americas Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors Win Court Round Over Wind Farm Noise
description: A legal petition aimed at reinstating a state rule for limiting noise at a controversial wind farm in Maine can proceed, a judge ruled on Friday, denying a motion from the farms developer, Fox Islands Wind, for dismissal.

title: A New Italian Spot, Quartered in History
description: ERIC LOMANDO has done it again. The talented, young chef-restaurateur, responsible for the success of Kitchen a Bistro and Kitchen a Trattoria, has added a rustic Italian spot in Miller Place to his collection: Orto.

title: Week in Pictures for March 23
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the St. Patricks Day Parade, a building collapse in Upper Manhattan and a City Hall photographer.

title: Girardi Not Yet Rising to Red Sox Bait
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In an almost identical repeat of the minor flap that occurred earlier this spring, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi refused to respond to criticisms leveled on him and the team by Bobby Valentine, the new manager of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Spring North American Championships
description: MEMPHIS  At the Spring North American Championships here on Wednesday, the Rockwell Mixed Pairs was won by Sheila Gabay of Newton, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass. They finished about half a board ahead of Bernace De Young of Miami and Richard Reitman of Los Gatos, Calif. Third were Les and Gloria Bart, a married couple from Bradenton, Fla.

title: The Tournament Pays Off
description: ATLANTA  The N.C.A.A. tournament is a bonanza for conferences that can get multiple teams into it. Each game a university plays is worth $242,204 for six years. So each game is worth $1,453,224.

title: In Arsne They Trust  Again
description: At roughly 2 p.m. on Feb. 26, a chant of You dont know what youre doing  aimed at Arsne Wenger  rang through the Emirates Stadium in London.

title: For Ohio States Craft, Defensive Mind-Set Was Nurtured at Home
description: BOSTON  When watching Ohio State point guard Aaron Craft on the court, it is easy to imagine that he was born in a defensive position: feet apart, arms up, eyes watching for the slightest sign of movement.

title: Sentencing for Juvenile Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Czech Ensemble Makes Its New York Debut With Sounds of Native Sons
description: At times you can believe, or at least hope, that classical music, after decades spent mainly in the splendid isolation of major institutions, is reintegrating itself into the fabric of New Yorks cultural life. The club scene is thriving, with an emphasis on new music; early-music groups have added salon presentations to their rich activity in churches; and now significant international events are sprouting in unexpected, intimate locations.

title: Art Has Legs
description: IT may seem an insignificant power spat in the small village of Sag Harbor, on Long Island. It isnt. It is a quintessential example of a continuing, centuries-old battle over what can be deemed art, what cant and who can rightfully judge the difference. I should say who among the living, for time has a way of sorting it all out.

title: Mahers Attacks on Women
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Poison Tongue, Putting a Smile on a Nations Aging Faces
description: KOBE, Japan

title: Syrians in the U.S. Are Given Protected Immigration Status
description: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano on Friday granted temporary immigration status to Syrians in the United States, sparing them from having to return home, in a new sign that Washington believes security conditions in Syria are going from bad to worse.

title: With Tebow in Fold, Jets Trade Stanton to Colts
description: Drew Stantons tenure as Mark Sanchezs backup lasted precisely one week, and it was a successful turn. He did not throw an incompletion or turn the ball over or create locker-room disharmony. For his troubles he received a nice consolation prize: a $500,000 signing bonus.

title: Downtown Atmosphere Meets a Varied Menu
description: THE restaurant MK Valencia is one of those places that seem to be popping up all over northern New Jersey these days: a combination of upscale watering hole with happy-hour specials and $11 litchi martinis, and a serious, sleekly designed dining establishment that might have emigrated from Gansevoort Street in Manhattan.

title: Chvez Strengthens Cuban Ties With Plan for Ice Cream Factory
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela sends Cuba oil. Now Cuba will send Venezuela ice cream.

title: The John Demjanjuk Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Sold! (But Check the Fine Print)
description: For a few minutes  O.K., a few seconds  the report of a new buyer for the Mets sounded plausible. Well, maybe not plausible. But worth checking out because, well, you never know. Last year, the Mets nearly sold one-third of the team to one rich guy, only to recently complete the sale of a big chunk of the franchise to a hodgepodge of rich guys, family members and business partners.

title: Bohemian Hub for Entertainment, Still Unprotected
description: Connoisseurs of Greenwich Village may believe that it is a singular neighborhood that is well protected by landmark designations. But, in fact, preservationists say a vital piece in the Village jigsaw is still at risk  the raffish quarter of coffeehouses and nightclubs where Bob Dylan warbled, Lenny Bruce told off-color jokes, Allen Ginsberg tried out his poems and a variety of nonconformists and wannabes forged the nations avatar of bohemia.

title: Greener in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: State-Run Pension Plans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Extravagant Cuisine, Without the Pretension
description: ON a recent visit to North Star, in Pound Ridge, looking to confirm that the two shining meals I had eaten there in late winter hadnt been a fluke, I ordered an extravagant lobster dish that is a signature of the chef, Franz Fruhmann. Described on the menu as meat from a 1 -pound butter-poached lobster, English pea tortellini, chorizo, glazed salsify, lobster beet sauce, it left me with an even higher regard for Mr. Fruhmann, a native of Austria who has cooked at Lespinasse and Raouls, in Manhattan; at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, in Pocantico Hills; and at the Dressing Room, in Westport, Conn.

title: Torre Returns to Commissioners Office Post
description: Joe Torre returned to the commissioners office as the executive vice president for baseball operations. He left in early January to be part of a group that tried to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Floridas Disastrous Self-Defense Law
description: Manama, Bahrain

title: Contractor Offers Explanation for Building Collapse in West Harlem
description: A contractor at the West Harlem site where a worker was killed on Thursday in a building collapse said Friday that an unusual condition in a structural beam was to blame.

title: Court Reverses E.P.A. on Big Mining Project
description: WASHINGTON  In a sharp rebuke, a federal judge on Friday reversed a decision by the Environmental Protection Agency to revoke a critical permit for one of the nations largest mountaintop removal mining projects.

title: Dogs Life Is Upended After Murder of His Owner
description: Police officers from the Bronx crossed into Manhattan and drove to the animal shelter on 110th Street with a dog in a cage. It wore no tag. Workers at the shelter passed a scanner across the scruff of his thick neck, looking for a microchip. Nothing.

title: Nimble Wordplay and Wink at History
description: There are two ways to approach Travesties. You can put your brain on red alert, sit up straight and listen intently to all of Tom Stoppards clever wordplay, spoken by and about Lenin, James Joyce, a Dadaist poet named Tzara and a few lesser-known figures. Or you can relax, sit back and allow the play to wash over you, appreciating the verbal gems that come through clearly and letting the others pass. I did a bit of both on the opening night of the McCarter Theater Centers beautifully done (but still highly challenging) new production.

title: 19th-Century Themes, Some Resonant Today
description: Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Who Doesnt Love a List?
description: The ONLY SIX THINGS you need to know right now about the presidential race:

title: St. Johns No Longer Has to Dream of California
description: FRESNO, Calif.  DaShena Stevens, a Connecticut snowbird, gazed lovingly at a long row of palm trees in front of the Save Mart Center here. Shenneika Smith, a daughter of Brooklyn, adored the sunny skies over her head and the lack of earthquakes going on under her feet.

title: A Bizarre Outcome on Generic Drugs
description: Dozens of suits against drug companies have been dismissed in federal and state courts because of a decision by the Supreme Court last year that makes it virtually impossible to sue generic manufacturers for failing to provide adequate warning of a prescription drugs dangers. This outrageous denial of a patients right to recover fair damages makes it imperative that Congress or the Food and Drug Administration fashion a remedy.

title: Woods Shares the Lead; McDowell Is One Back
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With 36 holes to play, Tiger Woods finds himself in a strange but familiar position at the Arnold Palmer Invitational. Woods shot a seven-under-par 65 on Friday, moving into a tie for the lead with Charlie Wi, who carded a 68, at 10-under 134.

title: New Leader, Old Tactics
description: The Obama administration refrained from exulting over last months modest nuclear deal with North Korea for good reason. The North has a long history of provocations and violating commitments. But nobody expected the deal would be pushed to the verge of collapse in a mere 17 days.

title: Readers Favorite Mini-Narratives
description: This is a follow-up to Tuesdays column The Sentence as a Miniature Narrative.

title: A Fast-Paced Stock Exchange Trips Over Itself
description: The stock market claimed an unlikely victim on Friday: one of its own.

title: Sex Discrimination and Medical Leaves
description: In 2003, the Supreme Court held that state governments could be sued for violating their employees right to take time off for family emergencies, guaranteed in the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993.

title: A View of the 2012 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
description: The 2012 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is a wrap, but now you can enjoy selected moments from the tournament.

title: Pieces of the Civil War With the Power to Unsettle
description: Two flags tell much of the story. One is the familiar stars and stripes, spangled with only 34 stars. Its smudged with dirt and dotted with the bullet holes it acquired in 1863, when it flew over a Union ironclad trying to pierce the defenses of Charleston harbor. The second flag is in even worse shape: a shredded, grimy Confederate banner with holes a cannonball could pass through and several of its 11 stars missing one or more of their points. It was captured 150 years ago this month, when Union soldiers defeated a contingent of Confederates at New Bern, N.C.

title: Now, Syracuse Guard Restricts Clashes to the Court
description: BOSTON  Everything should come easily for Syracuse guard Dion Waiters. His knack for scoring makes him a projected top 20 pick in the N.B.A. draft. His chiseled frame, with 4 percent body fat, looks genetically engineered to play professional basketball. Waiters has a blazing first step, an uncanny ability to make difficult shots and a confident aura on the court.

title: An Ex-Housing Official Took $2.5 Million in Bribes
description: A former senior official of the New York City agency that helps build housing for people with moderate incomes pleaded guilty on Friday to accepting about $2.5 million in bribes and other benefits since 1998  more than four times the $600,000 he was at first alleged to have accepted.

title: For-Profit Education Scams
description: Attorneys general from more than 20 states have joined forces to investigate for-profit colleges that too often saddle students with crippling debt while furnishing them valueless degrees. The investigations have just begun. But it is already clear from testimony before a Senate committee that Congress must do more to rein in the schools and protect students.

title: Could This Be the End of Health Care Reform?
description: What if the Supreme Court declares unconstitutional the Affordable Care Acts requirement that everyone buy health insurance? What if it strikes down all the acts insurance provisions, including the requirement that insurance companies cover everyone, regardless of pre-existing illnesses? Would this totally put an end to the health care reforms we have passed in the last three years?

title: When a South Bronx Collective Went International
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.

title: Private Comey Steals Away to Battle
description: A feeling of impending victory swept over the Union forces assembled in Virginias Shenandoah Valley, on the outskirts of the hamlet of Kernstown, on Sunday morning, March 23, 1862. Stonewall Jackson and his rebels would be whipped on their home turf in Virginia, and the war would soon be over!

title: Corrections: March 24
description: NATIONAL

title: To Clear Space, a Pit Orchestra in the Basement
description: The latest experiment in New York theater is taking place in a tiny, L-shaped third-floor room with water-stained ceilings and dirty gray carpeting that served for decades as a dumping ground for old props. At 8:05 p.m. on a recent Saturday, seven musicians, squeezed nearly knee to knee there in the Lucille Lortel Theater, struck the opening chords to the musical Carrie, as the actors stepped onstage two floors below.

title: A Coaching Reunion That Neither One Wanted
description: PHOENIX  The police pulled over the bus that carried the Providence basketball team from New York City to Rhode Island on March 8, 1987, and asked Coach Rick Pitino and his wife to step outside. They walked to a nearby pay phone, shaken, scared.

title: Call Me Ehsaan
description: A look at the war in Afghanistan through the eyes of Lt. Col. John Darin Loftis, one of the U.S. Air Forces prized experts in Afghan language and culture, who was killed in Kabul on Feb. 25, 2012.

title: The Joys of Couch Time
description: The pop singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelsons latest release, Human Again, made its debut at No. 5 on the Billboard charts. As a fortuitous bit of executive-level preparation for her coming 28-date tour, she performed this month at the fund-raiser for President Obama hosted by Deepak Chopra and Russell Simmons at ABC Kitchen in Manhattan. Ms. Michaelson, 32, a native of Staten Island, lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, with her husband and fellow musician, Greg Laswell, 37, and their Border terrier, Shep Proudfoot (named for the addled character in Fargo). Her tour concludes at Terminal 5 in Manhattan on May 17.

title: Ex-Goldman Worker Said to Seek Book Deal
description: Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs executive who resigned in spectacular fashion last week by blasting the firm in an Op-Ed page article in The New York Times, is now shopping a book proposal to major publishers in New York, several people with knowledge of the conversations said.

title: Leaders of Malis Military Coup Seem to Have Uncertain Grasp on Power
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Malis military coup leaders struggled on three fronts Friday, as international condemnation mounted, an insurrection by nomadic tribesmen in the north gained ground and the junta was forced to condemn looting by its own troops in the capital, Bamako.

title: A Personal Note as Obama Speaks on Death of Boy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama did not mention race even as he addressed it on Friday, instead letting his person and his words say it all: If I had a son, hed look like Trayvon.

title: Razzamatazz
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Gorgeous. Fun, tough and clean. The very definition of what a Saturday crossword puzzle should be. Or maybe Ive finally recuperated from the A.C.P.T. and am in an exceptionally good mood. But I think its the puzzle.

title: Call Me Ehsaan
description: Call Me Ehsaan is a look at the United States war in Afghanistan through the eyes of Lt. Col. John Darin Loftis, who was killed in February while working at the Ministry of Interior in Kabul. I met Colonel Loftis when he was a public information officer attached to the provincial reconstruction team in Zabul Province in 2010. He told me he was one of only three Pashto speakers in the United States Air Force. He was deeply interested in the Afghan people and their culture, learning the poetry of Rahman Baba and reciting it at a poetry reading in Zabul. His Afghan name was Ehsaan, a name he picked out of a hat, which has been translated variously as to owe someone a favor or beholden under obligation.

title: Inconsistent Florida Is Consistent in Tournament
description: PHOENIX  Florida is perhaps the most confounding team remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament. To that end, the Gators have been asked about their inconsistency dozens of times, a consistent line of questioning, including Friday.

title: For Baylor Big Man, an Effort Even Brighter Than His Uniform
description: ATLANTA  Baylor walked on the floor Friday night in uniforms that looked as if they required batteries. They were a loud lime green, but they were still not as loud as the dunks and message sent by the Bears Quincy Acy.

title: Traded for M&Ms, Only on Twitter
description: OVER one long day, he was celebrated, mocked, untraded, lamented, traded again in a Twitter hoax, hailed briefly by the city of Jacksonville, Fla., traded again for real and  at long last, late on Wednesday  the Denver Broncos Tim Tebow was welcomed to the woebegone New York Jets.

title: Standing Up to the N.C.A.A.
description: Over the past few months, I have used this column to explore the various injustices perpetrated by the N.C.A.A. I have written about the way it terrorizes the parents of athletes it is investigating  athletes, I should note, who are invariably suspended before they are even told the charges against them. I have questioned the N.C.A.A.s lack of due process and its indifference to the most rudimentary concepts of fairness. I have pointed out that its rules enforcing amateurism discriminate against black athletes from disadvantaged backgrounds.

title: Chamberlain Hurts Ankle, Jeopardizing His Career
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Joba Chamberlain came on the scene in electric fashion in the second half of the 2007 season, the Yankees were so protective of his health that they devised the so-called Joba Rules, a set of guidelines intended to maximize his talent while avoiding the dangers of throwing too many pitches.

title: Want a Cab? He Owns the Keys
description: MOST mornings at 3:45, Stanley Wissak, 84, leaves his Sutton Place apartment on the East Side of Manhattan and drives across the Queensboro Bridge in his Mercedes-Benz sedan with a license plate that reads, OFFDUTE.

title: First Loss for Woodson as Toronto Halts Knicks Streak
description: TORONTO  For eight days, across five games and three cities, the Knicks scrambled and scrapped, chasing after their own lost identity in the wake of a debilitating losing streak and the stunning resignation of their coach.

title: Friends With Yogi, and Other Tales
description: JUST in time for opening day, Harvey Araton, a sports reporter for The New York Times, recalls the enduring friendship between the Yankees Yogi Berra and Ron Guidry.

title: On the Right, Santorum Has Womens Vote
description: MANDEVILLE, La.  Rick Santorum was running late, and about 250 people were growing restless at a rally sponsored by the Tea Party. So the Harris sisters, a country singing duo, took the stage.

title: Uproar Over Shooting of Teenager Spreads Online and in the Streets
description: Updated | Saturday | 11:35 a.m. LeBron James joined the online protest over the fatal shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin in Florida when he uploaded a photo onto Twitter of himself and other members of the Miami Heat wearing hoodies on Friday.

title: Im Just Walkin
description: Matt Green is determined to walk every street in all five boroughs of New York City. The distance is around 8,000 miles and is expected to take him over two years to complete.

title: After a Scare, North Carolina Prevails in Overtime
description: ST. LOUIS  The frantic finish and the subsequent overtime left North Carolina drained of emotion, joy, even a sense of accomplishment. Center Tyler Zeller, after one of the most dominant performances by a big man in Tar Heels history, refused to savor North Carolinas 73-65 victory over Ohio on Friday in a Midwest Regional semifinal, because he knew how close his team had come to losing.

title: After Unity Over a Rampage in France, Politics Drives In Wedges
description: TOULOUSE, France  Shock and solidarity gave way to political recrimination and criticism here on Friday, one day after the police killed a 23-year-old self-proclaimed jihadist, as government officials were put on the defensive about whether intelligence failures cost his seven victims their lives.

title: The Out-of-View Orchestras of Carrie and Spider-Man
description: Musicians play not from a pit but from a third-floor office space and a basement.

title: Al Ross, Cartoonist for The New Yorker, Dies at 100
description: Al Ross, whose droll cartoons featuring married couples, bar habitus, anthropomorphic animals, philosophizing prisoners, art and publishing world denizens, anachronistic mythological figures and loyal Mets fans appeared in The New Yorker for more than 60 years, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 100.

title: Leaving His Footprints on the City
description: IN 2010, Matt Green, 31, a former civil engineer, walked across the United States from Rockaway Beach, Queens, to Rockaway Beach, Ore. The journey took five months, during which he averaged 20 miles a day, pitched his tent on front lawns and wore through three pairs of Timberland Chocorua Trail boots.

title: African Union to Make Push Against Rebels
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The African Union announced Friday that it would launch a new regional military operation against the Lords Resistance Army, the vicious Ugandan rebel group that has been terrorizing parts of central Africa for more than 20 years.

title: Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, Former Somali Strongman, Dies at 77
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, a cantankerous former warlord who led Somalias beleaguered transitional government as president from 2004 to 2008 and was forced to resign as the country sank deeper into chaos, died on Friday in Abu Dhabi. He was 77. The cause was complications of pneumonia, his family said. Mr. Yusuf, who was granted asylum in Yemen after he stepped down, had gone to Abu Dhabi for treatment, government officials said. He had undergone a liver transplant in 1996.

title: Rangers Are Overwhelmed by Sabres Rushes
description: Enduring a night of watching his team repeatedly outnumbered on the rush can take the smile off even one of the leagues most jovial goaltenders. After the Rangers lost to the Sabres, 4-1, Friday night, the usually bright-eyed Henrik Lundqvist was dour in the quiet of the home team locker room at Madison Square Garden.

title: David L. Waltz, Computer Science Pioneer, Dies at 68
description: David L. Waltz, a computer scientist whose early research in information retrieval provided the foundation for todays Internet search engines, died on Thursday in Princeton, N.J. He was 68.

title: Russia: Police Begin Investigation of a Restyled Political Activist
description: The Moscow police on Friday opened a criminal case against Kseniya Sobchak, a television star, after her altercation with a journalist this month. Ms. Sobchak is accused of destroying the journalists camera and taking a flash drive, a police spokesman said. Ms. Sobchak, whose family is close to Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, made waves last year when she spoke at antigovernment rallies. She has attracted attention from a pro-Kremlin Web site, Lifenews.ru, which has run exposs of protest leaders. From Miami, where she is traveling, Ms. Sobchak said she would sue the Web sites owner for disseminating misinformation. It is unfortunate that I live in a country of absurdity and lies, she wrote.

title: John Payton, Lawyer Who Fought for Civil Rights, Dies at 65
description: John Payton, who as president of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund guided it to several major victories before the Supreme Court, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 65 and lived in Washington.

title: Officer in Bell Killing Is Fired; 3 Others to Be Forced Out
description: The New York City police detective who fired the first shots in the 50-bullet barrage that killed Sean Bell in 2006 has been fired, and three others involved in the shooting are being forced to resign, law enforcement officials said on Friday.

title: The Liberator of Dead Dog Beach
description: Christina Beckles, who lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is the founder of the Sato Project, a rescue organization that brings abandoned and abused dogs to the continental United States from Puerto Rico.

title: Albuquerque Mayor Urges Police Union to Stop Payments to Officers in Shootings
description: The mayor of Albuquerque called Friday for an end to a police union practice of paying officers involved in fatal shootings as much as $500  a program that critics have compared to a bounty system that promotes and legitimizes brutality.

title: The Formerly Routine Is Now the Tendentious
description: WASHINGTON  Some things that Congress does are meant to be difficult: budgets, tax law changes, the health care overhaul, the undoing of the health care overhaul.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 23
description: North Carolina survived an upset scare from Ohio in overtime, and Baylor outlasted Xavier with dominant play from its big men.

title: Santorum on Defensive Over Remark on Romney
description: WEST MONROE, La.  Rick Santorum on Friday recalibrated a remark he made a day earlier suggesting that the United States would be just as well off re-electing President Obama as it would be electing Mitt Romney in November.

title: Operation Paws
description: ON a Sunday morning in March, the cavernous arrival hall at Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport was virtually deserted save for a cluster of people wearing white T-shirts with black Sato Project logos huddled near the cargo entrance. But when American Airlines Flight 648 from San Juan, P.R., touched down and a small, tanned woman wearing a white fedora and blue sweat pants emerged, the group snapped to attention. Christina Beckles, 39, a former Golden Gloves boxing champion and the founder of the Sato Project, a rescue organization that brings abandoned and abused dogs to the continental United States from Puerto Rico, had just landed with 17 animals in tow.

title: Man Hit by Train in Brooklyn After Fight Spills Onto Tracks
description: A man was seriously injured late Friday night when he was hit by a train in Brooklyn after an apparent tussle that sent him and another man tumbling onto the subway tracks, the authorities said.

title: Not-So-Mad Ideas About Taxes
description: This month, the Roosevelt Hotel, on East 45th Street, initiated a special offer in commemoration of Mad Men, whose return to television on Sunday night for a fifth season is something surely known now even to preschoolers of merely middling sophistication. For $495 a night, guests at the Roosevelt receive a room, a DVD of the fourth season of Mad Men, a Mad Men cookbook and period cocktails  the period, of course, being 1960s New York, when, in the shows imagination, any Scotch consumed after 10 a.m. betrayed a restrained and focused temperament. (I didnt call the hotel to learn how many drinks were included in the price for fear that any answer short of unlimited would have compelled me to accuse management of purveying historical falsehoods.)

title: Top-Seeded Wildcats Use Talented Cast to End Hoosiers Run
description: ATLANTA  No. 1 Kentucky did not survive Friday night solely with their usual play above the rim or bursts of speed and shot-making. The Wildcats showcased their talent in as calm a place as can be found inside a Dome with 24,731 feverish fans: at the free-throw line.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: On a Special Night, Coming of Age
description: Rebecca Greenfield, 36, began photographing quinceaeras three years ago, documenting the elaborate festivities celebrating budding womanhood.

title: Implications Are Far-Reaching in States Challenge of Federal Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  A major issue in the Supreme Court battle over the new health care law is whether Congress can force states to make a huge expansion of Medicaid, to add millions of low-income people to the rolls.

title: Neighbors Join in Modest Efforts to Embrace Abandoned Properties
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  When the grand Queen Anne on Portage Avenue lost its last occupants a few years ago, plunging into foreclosure and abandonment, the century-old gem risked the same fate as hundreds of empty houses here: collapse or demolition. Either way, what had been a lumber barons masterpiece was bound to become just another forgotten lot on the Rust Belt.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 23, 2012

title: Kim Jong-un May See Rise in His Power
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Saturday that its Parliament would convene on April 13 for a session that should give the countrys new leader, Kim Jong-un, an opportunity to further consolidate his grip on power.

title: Nothings the Matter With Kansas
description: ST. LOUIS  For the first few minutes Friday night, Kansass Midwest Regional semifinal with North Carolina State suspiciously resembled its third-round tussle with Purdue. The Wolfpack, like the Boilermakers, jumped out to an early lead and made the second-seeded Jayhawks sweat right to the finish.

title: Restoring South Bend
description: Neighbors in Indiana put free labor and their own money into revitalizing the shabby and historic homes left for dead in their small town.

title: Union Calls on Speaker Silver to Save the Teacher Centers
Raising the Bar for Vetting a No. 2
description: WASHINGTON  Lets say youre moving steadily toward wrapping up the Republican presidential nomination and you allow yourself to begin thinking ahead to the question of a running mate.

title: A Lawyer Who Can Simplify the Complex Draws a Big One: Obamas Health Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  If history is any guide, Donald B. Verrilli Jr. will hole up in a hotel close to the Supreme Court building, eat only salmon for dinner because it is said to help brain function, and give his undivided attention to the final preparations for what promises to be the biggest case of his life.

title: Islamist Victors in Egypt Seeking Shift by Hamas
description: CAIRO  As it prepares to take power in Egypt, the Muslim Brotherhood is overhauling its relations with the two main Palestinian factions in an effort to put new pressure on Israel for an independent Palestinian state.

title: Trayvon Martin Furor Echoes British Campaign for Justice
description: LONDON  The outcry in the United States over the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, a black Florida teenager, by a crime watch volunteer has prompted parallels with a British case that forced a shake-up in policing and public attitudes on issues of justice and civil rights.

title: Saints  Payton Is Sorry for What Has Happened
description: Two days after the N.F.L. suspended him for the 2012 season, New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton issued a statement Friday in which he never used the word bounty while saying that he was sorry for what has happened.

title: Spring in Barcelona Means Its Calot Season
description: Each year, the calot, a sweet onion variety similar in appearance to the leek, is harvested all over Catalunya just before spring and served by the dozens in restaurants and on dining room tables across the region. Translated, the tradition known locally as la calotada would be something like, the eating of the spring onion. That doesnt quite capture it, though.

title: The Weekend Word: Trayvon
description: In Todays Times:

title: Space Station Crew Scrambles as Debris Passes Nearby
description: HONG KONG  Crew members aboard the International Space Station temporarily scrambled into spacecraft capable of returning them to Earth early on Saturday as remnants of a discarded Russian satellite passed nearby, the latest episode spotlighting the growing amount of space debris encircling the planet.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: A car blast rocked southern Kashmir on Thursday, killing one person and injuring 14 others including four security personnel, the Hindustan Times reports. The 27-year-old driver who was blown up in the blast was a resident of south Kashmirs Pulwama district.

title: Don Draper, Gearhead?
description: In this Sundays Automobiles section, Stuart Schwartzapfel profiles Ed McCabe, a real-life advertising star of the Mad Men era who was responsible for many of Volvos brand-making campaigns of the 1960s and 70s.

title: Lotus Position in Paddock and a Qualifying Again Dominated by McLaren
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Interesting that the Lotus Formula One team of this season finally won its case against the Malaysian-based Lotus Formula One team of last year  now known as Caterham  and all it took for Lotus this year to find a little bad luck was to come to Malaysia. The team  which is based in Enstone, England  had a fire in its hospitality building overnight when a refrigerator short-circuited. No one was injured, but the team ceased all hospitality for the rest of the weekend, and its media staff set up office amongst the journalists in the media center of the track.

title: 2012 N.F.L. Mock Draft
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Illegal Immigrants Number 11.5. Million
description: About 11.5 million illegal immigrants were living in the United States in January 2011, a figure essentially unchanged from the 11.6 million in 2010, according to the latest estimates by the Department of Homeland Security, which were based on 2010 census figures. Georgia saw the greatest increase between 2000 and 2011, with the number of illegal immigrants there increasing by 95 percent to 440,000. The number of illegal immigrants in the country peaked in 2007 at 11.8 million, the demographers found, and has been declining.

title: California: Charges in Coliseum Scheme
description: Six people have been indicted on charges that they siphoned millions of dollars from the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. The indictment, unsealed on Friday, details schemes in which concert promoters are accused of paying officials at the Coliseum in exchange for lower costs and other perks. Two concert promoters, Insomniac and Go Ventures, are accused of paying more than $1.8 million to Coliseum officials to ensure that they could continue to hold raves at the venue, even after a 15-year-old girl died of a drug overdose there during an Insomniac event. Four defendants have pleaded not guilty; they are Patrick Lynch, the former general manager of the coliseum; Todd DeStefano, the former events manager; Pasquale Rotella, the owner of Insomniac; and Reza Gerami, the owner of Go Ventures. The other two defendants are out of the country and have not been arrested.

title: JetBlue and Korean Air Combine, Electronically
description: JetBlue and Korean Air recently announced a partnership allowing fliers to book trips that combine legs on both airlines on a single ticket.

title: Travel Is Behind Wests Early Edge in M.L.S.
description: Major League Soccer commentators and fans have been quick to condemn the Eastern Conference after Western teams won 9 of 11 interconference games during the new seasons first two weeks

title: On Hollywood
description: I began with the concept of psychogeographical drive, an approach analyzed by the French writer Guy Debord.

title: Macroeconomic Chutzpah
description: Chutzpah, according to the old definition, is when you murder your parents, then plead for mercy because youre an orphan. I found myself thinking of that definition when reading Justin Foxs description of recent remarks by Jean-Claude Trichet. (Via Mark Thoma).

title: Macroeconomic Policy Wagers
description: One of key arguments made by the proponents of fiscal austerity, even in a deeply depressed economy, has involved a sort of macroeconomic version of Pascals wager. Yes, the more open-minded admit, borrowing costs are very low in the US and the UK. Yes, the arithmetic suggests that cutting spending now will do very little to improve the long-run fiscal prospect. But you never know  maybe the last trillion dollars of spending will be what causes a sudden loss of market confidence, turning you into Greeeeeeece. (Cue scary noises).

title: Singapore Is Widening Its Cruise Ship Berth
description: Singapore is opening a cruise terminal by midyear to accommodate a growing number of cruise passengers and larger ships like Royal Caribbeans Oasis of the Seas, its tourism board announced recently.

title: The Electric Car, Unplugged
description: THE future would appear bright for the electric car. Gasoline prices are high. The government is spending billions on battery technology. Auto companies are preparing to roll out a dozen new electrified models. Concern is growing about the climate impacts of burning oil. And tough new fuel economy standards are looming.

title: Monti Braces for a Fight Over Labor Law Changes
description: ROME  In his effort to turn around the Italian economy, and Italys deeply ingrained workplace culture, Prime Minister Mario Monti is gearing up for a struggle in Parliament over his proposal to change Italian labor laws.

title: Romney Advisers Have History With the Candidate
description: Until Wednesday, few Americans knew Eric Fehrnstrom as a top adviser to Mitt Romney. Now, his name is (apologies) etched into the public consciousness.

title: James Murdoch Resigns From Another Corporate Board
description: In a continuing effort to distance himself from News Corporations embattled British newspaper unit, James Murdoch has stepped down from the board of Times Newspapers Holdings.

title: Variety: An Eloquacious Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you go strictly by the quote in todays acrostic puzzle, the author doesnt appear to have much faith in the evolutionary power of language. She compares the tenacity of emergent words  some plausible, some not  to the power of belief in fairies bringing them closer to reality, yet she spent nearly a quarter century hunting these words down in her column in The Atlantic Monthly.

title: The End of an Era in Indiana
description: ANDERSON, Ind.  At its peak, the Wigwam attracted 5,000 season-ticket holders to Anderson High School boys basketball games. The teams and the crowds measured up to the gyms 8,996-seat capacity. That made the Wigwam the second-biggest high school gym in America, but Anderson athletic directors still found themselves testifying in divorce hearings over the custody of season tickets.

title: After Paytons Suspension, Saints Scramble to Fill Void
description: Little more than two years ago, hours after the New Orleans Saints won the Super Bowl, Sean Payton held a bleary-eyed morning news conference. With Mardi Gras beads around his neck and the Lombardi Trophy slung over one shoulder, Payton appeared to be celebrating the sublime revival of a city brought low by Hurricane Katrina as well as the dominance of a defense against three likely Hall of Fame quarterbacks. Near the end, Payton noted that with quarterback Drew Brees in his prime, the Saints burned to separate themselves further from the rest of the N.F.L.

title: Insuring Hollywood Against Falls (but Not Flops)
description: HERES one for The Hunger Games crowd: What if, in that blood-tingling climactic scene near the Cornucopia, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) had skewered poor Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) with a wayward silver arrow?

title: Just the Facts. Yes, All of Them.
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: Syria Continues Drive to Retake Rebel Strongholds as Diplomacy Suffers a Setback
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian troops continued their drive on Saturday to retake rebel strongholds, even as there were indications that diplomatic efforts to end the violence could still prove elusive just days after Western officials had claimed a breakthrough.

title: A Bailout by Another Name
description: ED DeMARCO is a marked man.

title: As Displaced Return to Iraq, New Tensions for Neighbors
description: BAGHDAD  Even after death squads began killing his neighbors, after corpses appeared in the streets around his home and his family fled in fear, Walid al-Bahadli still believed in his once affluent and diverse neighborhood of Al Adel.

title: Want to Innovate? Feed a Cookie to the Monster
description: This interview with Terry Tietzen, founder and C.E.O. of Edatanetworks, a developer of customer loyalty software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Suicides Highlight Failures of Veterans Support System
description: Francis Guilfoyle, a 55-year-old homeless veteran, drove his 1985 Toyota Camry to the Department of Veterans Affairs campus in Menlo Park early in the morning of Dec. 3, took a stepladder and a rope out of the car, threw the rope over a tree limb and hanged himself.

title: Hiring the Blind, While Making a Green Statement
description: WHEN Chris Yura, chief executive of the apparel company SustainU, was looking for a factory to produce 24,000 T-shirts, it was important that it be within 200 miles of where the fabric was made.

title: Avalanches of Words, Sifted and Sorted
description: IT just keeps growing  the vast electronic archive of books, journals and scholarly literature stored on the Web. But scientists are aiming to keep up with this trove of collective knowledge by devising computer-based tools to winnow and quantify it.

title: Two Striking Exceptions to the Power of Free Swingers
description: Goodyear, Ariz.

title: Both Coasts Watch Closely as San Francisco Faces Erosion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The explosive waves of Ocean Beach, a 3.5-mile stretch separating the city from the gray edge of the Pacific Ocean, have long been a draw for tourists, local families and an international tribe of surfers.

title: Counting the Mets Up to Opening Day
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A yellow legal pad on Mets Manager Terry Collinss desk at Digital Domain Park bears a handwritten record of his preoccupations.

title: The Age of the Shadow Bank Run
description: I RECENTLY asked a group of colleagues  and myself  to identify the single most important development to emerge from Americas financial crisis. Most of us had a common answer: The age of the bank run has returned.

title: Pink Slime Is Vanishing From School Cafeterias
description: BOSTON  Andy Gomez, a ninth grader at Brighton High School, was not sure why hamburgers and meatballs had disappeared from the cafeteria, but he was not happy about it. Today I just ate peanut butter and jelly, he said. I dont like the chicken patty.

title: Passing Flaws May Negate Tebows Physical Gifts
description: Denvers playoff victory against Pittsburgh in January showcased the best, and the worst, of Tim Tebow.

title: This Bull Market Is Hard to Pin Down
description: HISTORY says that standard bull markets typically have a shelf life of less than four years. So when the bull that sprang to life in March 2009 turned 3 this month, it understandably raised some concerns.

title: Whats Your Sign? It Could Be a Cram
description: WE return in this episode to that perpetual source of digital age fury, the cellphone bill.

title: Lessons From The Great Canadian Slump
description: So, is there still a lot of slack in U.S. labor markets? On the face of it, that seems an absurd question to ask, given the persistence of very high unemployment and an employment-population ratio far below pre-crisis levels. Yet it is being asked, partly because we dont see strong evidence of falling inflation.

title: The Tebow Party Moves Its Big Tent East
description: I was not a Jets fan on Wednesday morning. Like many football fans around the country, I was reveling in the schadenfreude of the Jets folly, of Rex Ryans busted guarantees, of the circular firing squad in the locker room, of Mark Sanchezs high-profile failures.

title: Russian TV Broadcast Besmirching Protesters Draws a Furious Reaction
description: MOSCOW  Anatomy of a Protest, a pseudodocumentary broadcast this month on Russias NTV television station, had the familiar earmarks of a hatchet job against opponents of the Kremlin  a darkly insinuating voice-over, accusations of shocking treachery and blurry surveillance film acquired from law enforcement services.

title: Political Geography: Louisiana
description: Louisiana, where Republicans are holding a presidential primary on Saturday, is a Deep South state with a small twist. The states Republican voters are similar to Mississippis and Alabamas, however, there are modest differences that could lead to a substantial electoral difference.

title: Overseas Internships Can Benefit, for a Price
description: AS the world becomes more interconnected, employers are clamoring for global experience in their work forces. So it should come as no surprise that college internships are going global, too.

title: Voter Turnout Appears Light in Louisiana Primary
description: METAIRIE, La.  As Louisiana became the 28th state to head to the polls in a drawn-out Republican presidential race, turnout appeared very light at several sites around New Orleans, a combination perhaps of campaign fatigue and the competition of a lovely Saturday morning ideal for gardening and visiting crawfish festivals, which are back in season.

title: Towering Figure Still Reaching Out
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is the only athlete to be voted the most outstanding player of the N.C.A.A. tournament three times  he was known as Lew Alcindor as his U.C.L.A. teams won three championships. He received the first Naismith Award as the college player of the year in 1969 and went on to a 20-year record-setting N.B.A. career.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Jets trade with Denver for quarterback Tim Tebow to back up Mark Sanchez drew reactions from many readers. Here are a few of their letters and online comments.

title: For Horse and Jockey, Risks Vary by State
description: The estimated breakdown and injury rates at the 62 tracks where thoroughbreds or quarter horses race.

title: Experience in Israel Fuels an N.B.A. Dream
description: TEL AVIV Before Chinese-Americans had Jeremy Lin, Jews had Jon Scheyer. Nicknamed the Jewish Jordan as a high school phenomenon in the Chicago suburbs, Scheyer personified the hoop dreams of a people with few basketball role models.

title: What I Learned at Age 8
description: I GREW up in a suburb of Richmond, Va., and attended an all-black school in first and second grade. In 1954, the Supreme Court abolished segregation in schools, and in 1966, when Virginia acknowledged that decision, I had the choice of going to an all-white school in third grade. I remember sitting on the floor outside my bedroom and crying when my parents insisted that I switch schools.

title: Letters: My Own Space
description: To the Editor:

title: At UConn, Playing Defense Is the Key to Playing at All
description: Women who play basketball usually go to Connecticut with spectacular dossiers that highlight their abilities to put a ball into a basket. Coach Geno Auriemma likes it that way because he can get them to concentrate on less glamorous responsibilities, like playing defense.

title: Letters: No Obstacle to Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Delays Keep Former Qaeda Child Soldier at Guantnamo, Despite Plea Deal
description: WASHINGTON  When Omar Khadr, a former child soldier for Al Qaeda, agreed to plead guilty in a high-profile case before a military commission 17 months ago, the terms of his plea deal strongly signaled that after November 2011 he would be transferred to his native Canada to serve the remainder of his sentence.

title: After Falling Behind Early, Lady Vols Rally for the Victory
description: DES MOINES  A season hung in the balance. So, perhaps, did Pat Summitts peerless career. Tennessee appeared listless in the womens N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday. Kansas was quicker, more determined. Not once all season had the Lady Vols won a game after trailing at halftime.

title: Chamberlain Is Expected to Leave Hospital, and the Early Signs Are Encouraging
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain is expected to be released from St. Josephs Hospital in Tampa on Sunday, three days after he had surgery to repair an open dislocation of his right ankle, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said.

title: Coup Leaders in Mali Struggle to Assert Their Control
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Residents of Bamako, the capital of Mali, waited in tension and uncertainty on Saturday for the outcome of a military coup dtat that overthrew the countrys elected government last week, ending more than 20 years of democracy in the nation.

title: Breakdown: Disarray at the Track
description: Some say a culture of drugs and lax regulation at racetracks is behind the nations high fatality rate for horses.

title: Breakdown: A Jockeys Story
description: Jockeys are on the front lines of the risky business of horse racing. Twenty-four horses a week die at racetracks around the country.

title: A Mother and Her Wiggly Children
description: Dear Diary:

title: Isner, New to the Top 10, Credits College Play for His Team-First Attitude
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  The pro-wrestling fan and tennis player John Isner knows what his character should be were he ever to take to the ring.

title: Sandusky Investigation Drew Psychologists Alert in 1998, Report Says
description: More than a decade before the former Penn State football assistant Jerry Sandusky was charged with child sexual abuse, a psychologist warned the university police in an investigation into a suspected assault of an 11-year-old boy that Sanduskys actions in that case fit a likely pedophiles pattern. But the university seemed to do nothing about Sandusky in the wake of that report in 1998.

title: Mangled Horses, Maimed Jockeys
description: RUIDOSO, N.M.  At 2:11 p.m., as two ambulances waited with motors running, 10 horses burst from the starting gate at Ruidoso Downs Race Track 6,900 feet up in New Mexicos Sacramento Mountains.

title: Jockeys on the Front Lines
description: An always-dangerous sport has become even more so as the economics of racing have changed. Racetracks facing a steep loss of customers have increasingly added casinos. That has brought higher purses but has given trainers an incentive to race unfit horses, putting both horse and rider at risk. New Mexico jockeys have been hit particularly hard.

title: Baylor Coachs Family All In During Big Win
description: ATLANTA  By the standards of major college basketball, Baylor Coach Scott Drew has been remarkably adaptable this season. For example, Drew instituted a three-guard lineup in late February that changed the look of his team, an admission that the plan for his high-profile but underachieving team was not working and needed adjustments midflight.

title: How the Times Analyzed Data on Horse Injuries
description: To assess how often horses break down or get injured, The Times purchased official data covering more than 150,000 race results from 2009 through 2011. The data are compiled by trained chart callers, and used to compile result charts that bettors use to evaluate horses. The Times searched the data for terms indicating that a horse encountered a physical problem: broke down, vanned off, injured, lame, euthanized, died, collapsed, bleeding or went wrong.

title: When Poverty Was White
description: CARRIE BUCK, or rather her last name, appears just once in the books of Charles Murray, the conservative sociologist and author of the recent work Coming Apart: The State of White America, 1960-2010, his portrait of the decline of poor white Americans. To find it, you have to look through the endnotes for the introduction to his most famous book, The Bell Curve, in which he cites Buck v. Bell, the 1927 Supreme Court case that approved Ms. Bucks involuntary sterilization.

title: G.O.P. Campaign Could End Soon  But Not in Louisiana
