description: Rick Santorum is likely to win the Louisiana Republican primary on Saturday. He has had a clear and fairly consistent lead of about 14 percentage points in recent polls there.

title: The Thrill of Disaster
description: MY college roommates and I chased firetrucks.

title: A Fly Crawls Into a Bar ...
description: Fruit flies apparently self-medicate just like many humans do, drowning their sorrows or frustrations for some of the same reasons. ...Male flies subjected to what amounted to a long tease ... preferred food spiked with alcohol far more than male flies that were able to mate.

title: NATOs Secrecy Stance
description: SOMETIME late last Aug. 8, NATO warplanes flying from Europe arrived over the Libyan farming village of Majer, where forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi were withdrawing and anti-Qaddafi forces were claiming ground. Civilians were in motion, too  seeking pockets of safety away from the roaming sides, neither of which fought with precision or clear rules. This is the type of situation in which air support can be especially risky and in which, even with a careful calculus of modern target planning, mistakes are likely.

title: Manic Wednesday Leaves N.F.L. Gasping for Breath
description: Robert Griffin III rescheduled his pro day workout at Baylor University to Wednesday from Thursday so he could have the day all to himself. He would perform passing drills one day before Andrew Luck, another top prospect, and with no N.C.A.A. basketball or other diversions on the schedule, Griffins workout could command the undivided attention of the sports news media.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Equitable Health Care
description: Readers respond to a writers defense of the health reform law.

title: The Case for Sleep Medicine
description: ACCORDING to a new study in the journal BMJ that has received wide media coverage, people who regularly took sleeping pills were nearly five times more likely to die over a two and a half year period than those who didnt take them.

title: Turkeys Challenges
description: In Istanbul and Ankara, high-rise apartments and office towers are changing the landscape. With recent economic growth rates that exceed those in many European countries, Turkey is often cited as a success story in a region in turmoil.

title: How Much Was That Treatment?
description: Analysts are finding huge disparities in the amounts that private insurance plans pay for common medical procedures. This goes largely undetected by patients and their doctors because hospitals and private insurance plans treat their negotiated prices as confidential.

title: The Full-Employment Congress
description: Representative Ron Pauls signature libertarianism takes on a whole new meaning with the disclosure that he has paid more than $300,000 in salaries and fees to his daughter, brother, grandson, daughters mother-in-law, granddaughter and grandson-in-law. There is no Congressional ethics rule against employing family members in the pursuit of public service, as the office of Mr. Paul, Texas Republican and presidential candidate, points out.

title: A Boy to Be Sacrificed
description: Paris

title: Managers Search for Meaning in Meaningless Games
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  When diligent scouts from opposing teams arrived early at Tampa Bay Rays training camp recently, they found they were locked out. For the first several days of camp, they had been allowed in the stadium at 9:30 a.m. to watch batting practice and roam free. But now their entry was barred until 10:20 a.m.

title: A Moment of Truth for Health Care Reform
description: The Supreme Courts decision on the Affordable Care Act will have immense political importance. The law, which rivals Medicare in scope, is the biggest achievement of the Obama administration. Striking it down has become a Republican crusade.

title: Things I Saw  No. 1
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: On Hollywood
description: A series of photographs of women who live in Los Angeles.

title: In Popes Mexico Visit, the Pastoral Is Political
description: LEN, Mexico  Pope Benedict XVI met with President Felipe Caldern on Saturday evening in what was described by the Vatican as a courtesy visit in the middle of a purely pastoral trip to Mexico and Cuba.

title: Quirk Often Penalizes Better Teams
description: The N.H.L. has long maintained that there is no perfect postseason format, but the shortcomings of the current system are becoming more evident.

title: Boston University Aims to Rise Above Scandal
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: China Attacks Dalai Lama in Online Burst
description: BEIJING  As the Chinese governments relationship with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, has gone from bad to worse over the years, Beijings propaganda machine has churned out increasingly florid descriptions of him. He has been called a jackal, a wolf in sheeps clothing and, routinely, a splittist.

title: Giant Movers in the Cloud
description: Last week three of the biggest companies in technology were busy positioning themselves for the future. Collectively, their actions tell you a lot about the kind of turmoil headed for the rest of the business world.

title: The Brain on Love
description: A RELATIVELY new field, called interpersonal neurobiology, draws its vigor from one of the great discoveries of our era: that the brain is constantly rewiring itself based on daily life. In the end, what we pay the most attention to defines us. How you choose to spend the irreplaceable hours of your life literally transforms you.

title: The Outsourced Party
description: Who speaks for the Republican party? The answer is that everyone does  and therefore, no one does.

title: Knee Injury Knocks Agudelo Off U.S. Team
description: U.S. Soccer revealed Saturday that Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo sustained a torn meniscus in his left knee during the under-23 teams 6-0 win over Cuba Thursday in its opening game of Olympic qualifying in the Concacaf region.

title: Vincent Kartheiser
description: Vincent Kartheiser is an actor probably best known for his role as Pete Campbell on Mad Men, which begins its fifth season on AMC tonight.

title: Text to Driver: Thats My Space
description: ANYBODY who has ever hunted for a parking space along a city street or in a shopping mall garage knows how the choreography is supposed to work. Driver seeking a precious spot crawls along, sees someone climbing into a car, then pumps fist to celebrate good fortune.

title: How Oedipus Wrecks
description: WHEN Mike Nichols had his dazzling comedy act with Elaine May, one of their sketches began with a Jewish mother calling her son and saying, Hello, this is your mother, do you remember me?

title: Rethinking His Religion
description: I MOVED into my freshman-year dorm at the University of North Carolina after many of the other men on the hall. One had already begun decorating. I spotted the poster above his desk right away. It showed a loaf of bread and a chalice of red wine, with these words: Jesus invites you to a banquet in his honor.

title: Tebow in Babylon
description: THE Prophet Jonah was sent to Nineveh. St. Paul was sent to Athens, Macedonia, Rome. And now Tim Tebow has been sent to New York City.

title: A Festival of Lies
description: THE historian Victor Davis Hanson recently wrote a brutally clear-eyed piece in The National Review, looking back at Americas different approaches to Iraq, Iran, Libya, Syria, Egypt, Pakistan and Afghanistan and how, sadly, none of them could be said to have worked yet.

title: The False Debate About Attacking Iran
description: I WONDER if we in the news media arent inadvertently leaving the impression that there is a genuine debate among experts about whether an Israeli military strike on Iran makes sense this year.

title: A Long Road to Regulating Derivatives
description: If there is one lesson from the financial crisis that should be indelible, it is that unregulated derivatives are prone to catastrophic failure. And yet, nearly four years after the crash, and nearly two years since the passage of the Dodd-Frank law, the multitrillion-dollar derivatives market is still dominated by a handful of big banks, and regulation is a slow work in progress.

title: Rival N.B.A. Siblings Share the Room in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  When the first bus of Utah Jazz players and team personnel arrived at Staples Center for a 6:30 p.m. game against the Los Angeles Lakers last Sunday, players made their way to the locker room, only to stop and remain in the hallway.

title: For Lawyer in Afghan Killings, the Latest in a Series of Challenging Defenses
description: SEATTLE  The Vietnam War was raging, and John Henry Browne believed it was unjust. When his draft number came up, he refused to go.

title: Chandler Approaching Historic Pace
description: Studies of N.B.A. statistical records often eliminate Wilt Chamberlain from consideration because he was so dominant, and so far ahead of his time, that his numbers were almost comical.

title: Payments to Albuquerque Officers Are Called a Bounty System
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Mike Gomez has been angry with the police officer here who shot and killed his 22-year-old son, Alan, last year, after officers responded to a report that the young man was acting erratically and firing a rifle. But Mr. Gomez became even angrier just days ago after he learned that the officer, Sean Wallace, received a $500 payment from the Albuquerque police union shortly after the shooting.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 25
description: The presidential race will share the spotlight with several other issues on the Sunday talk shows, including the coming Supreme Court decision over the health care law and the shooting of an unarmed Florida teenager by a neighborhood watch volunteer.

title: Years After Ten Commandments Fight, Ex-Justice Plans Return
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  On the campaign trail, Roy Moore wears a metal pin of a cross on his suit jackets, praises almighty God and refers to the United States as a Christian nation.

title: In Europe, Where Art Is Life, Ax Falls on Public Financing
description: European governments are cutting their support for culture, and American arts lovers are starting to feel the results.

title: Pelfrey Gives Up Five Runs; Hes Happy
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. Mike Pelfrey, who has been hit hard in spring training, said he was happy with his start against the St. Louis Cardinals on Saturday afternoon, crediting his comfort on the mound to a minor adjustment in his mechanics.

title: Man, 20, Dies After Impact With L Train
description: Investigators were searching on Saturday for a man who was involved in a fight with a young Queens man who fell to the tracks in a Brooklyn subway station and was killed by a train, the authorities said.

title: Two-for-One Special
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Im not exactly sure what to call this theme, but we certainly do get two-for-one today with Patrick Berrys puzzle.

title: Ailments Found in Gulf Dolphins
description: Dolphins in Barataria Bay off Louisiana, which was hit hard by the BP oil spill in 2010, are seriously ill, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Friday.

title: Obama Arrives in South Korea for Nuclear Meeting and Visit to DMZ
description: PANMUNJOM, South Korea  President Obama landed here shortly after dawn on Sunday for a three-day visit during which he will promote efforts to secure the worlds nuclear stockpiles and get a firsthand look at one of the worlds most unpredictable nuclear states, North Korea.

title: A.C.C. Looks to Get Back in Womens Final Four
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The Atlantic Coast Conference usually produces its share of Top 25 and even Top 10 teams each year, but you have to go back to 2007 to find the last time an A.C.C. team (North Carolina) made it to the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament. And the A.C.C. has captured only one national championship in the last 17 years  Maryland in 2006.

title: Santorum Unveils Obamaville Video, Scary Music Included
description: In a new video from Rick Santorum, it is hardly morning in America. It is more like apocalypse in America.

title: U.S. Plans No Charges Over Deadly Strike in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military has decided that no service members will face disciplinary charges for their involvement in a NATO airstrike in November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers, an accident that plunged relations between the two countries to new depths and has greatly complicated the allied mission in Afghanistan.

title: Thumbs Down From Calipari
description: ATLANTA  Dont tell this to Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum, but Kentucky Coach John Calipari is not in their demographic.

title: Groups Blanket Supreme Court on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Clarence Thomas likens all the outside political pressure that the Supreme Court is facing over its review of the Obama administrations sweeping health care law to the distraction faced by a free-throw shooter confronted with fans waving wildly behind the basket. Neither, in his view, has much impact in the end.

title: Sexual Abuse Case Clouds The Popes Visit to Mexico
description: LEN, Mexico  The shadow of the disgraced Mexican founder of a powerful religious order darkened the visit of Pope Benedict XVI here this weekend, as former victims and authors organized news conferences to call attention to the churchs failure to combat what they called a systemic culture of sexual abuse.

title: When Packaging Oversteps the Facts
description: A NEWS article ultimately is judged on much more than its raw factual ingredients. Its points of emphasis, headline, length and position on the page combine to couch the article in a way that delivers its intended meaning and significance.

title: Agudelo Sustains Knee Injury in U.S. Game
description: U.S. Soccer revealed Saturday that Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo had sustained a torn meniscus in his left knee during the under-23 teams 6-0 win over Cuba Thursday in its opening game of Olympic qualifying in the Concacaf region.

title: Whos in Center (Not on First)?
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets have found themselves cautiously feeling their way through a murky situation in center field.

title: Louisville Storms Back Late Against Florida and Into Final Four
description: PHOENIX  Peyton Siva Sr. stood in the front row at the US Airways Center, clad in his lucky jersey, the black one  Louisville, No. 3. The stains on the jersey told the story of the Cardinals last eight games, all victories, many of them upsets.

title: For Santorum, Its Three Strikes in a Row in Wisconsin
description: SHEBOYGAN, Wis.  Rick Santorum often says that he offers the clearest contrast with President Obama, and on Saturday, he was able to prove that  in at least one way.

title: Griner Leads Baylor to Rout of Georgia Tech
description: DES MOINES  Brittney Griner, Baylors dominant 6-foot-8 center, scored 35 points, grabbed 10 rebounds and blocked six shots as the top-seeded Bears defeated fourth-seeded Georgia Tech, 83-68, in the semifinals of the Des Moines Region.

title: Kennedy Helped Shape Romneys Career, and Still Haunts It
description: BOSTON  When Gov. Mitt Romney signed legislation in April 2006 requiring most Massachusetts residents to have health coverage, Senator Edward M. Kennedy stood by his side, beaming like a proud father. They were onstage at historic Faneuil Hall in Boston, a setting that had a special resonance for the two.

title: Kentucky Braces for a Zone Not of Its Own
description: ATLANTA  John Calipari, the Kentucky coach, is convinced Baylor is going to play a zone defense in Sundays N.C.A.A. South Region championship game. The Bears play a 1-3-1 and that must cause immediate heartburn for Kentucky fans.

title: Trying to Divide Six Into Five
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  With a little less than two weeks remaining until opening day, there is no resolution yet to the issue of the starting rotation. The Yankees have six viable pitchers for five positions, and that includes Freddy Garcia, who had a terrific outing on Saturday.

title: Reader Comments on Iran
description: My Sunday column argues that there isnt a real debate over a military strike on Iran, but a false debate: experts overwhelmingly think a strike now would be an abominable idea. And I cite some reasons why thats so.

title: For Cheney, 71, New Heart Ends 20-Month Wait
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney had a heart transplant on Saturday after 20 months on a waiting list, and was recovering in a Virginia hospital, a statement from his office said.

title: Arrests at Occupy Wall Street Rally
description: The police arrested several people on Saturday during an Occupy Wall Street march that organizers said was meant to protest police tactics and brutality. In part, protesters said, the march was meant to object to the police decision last Saturday to close Zuccotti Park and arrest more than 70 people gathered there.

title: Afghan Shootings Carried Out in 2 Operations, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Military investigators suspect that the American soldier charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder and other charges in connection with the attacks against Afghan civilians this month committed the shootings during two separate operations, a United States official said Saturday.

title: Man Tries to Climb Times Building
description: A 31-year-old man who appeared to be psychologically unstable attempted to climb the outside of The New York Times Building on Saturday morning, the police said.

title: North Carolinas Marshall Practices
description: ST. LOUIS  Sitting in front of his locker after practice Saturday, North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall had ice wraps on his right wrist and his right elbow. The wrist  the broken scaphoid bone from his third-round tumble against Creighton last Sunday  everyone knows about. But the elbow?

title: St. Bonaventure Takes On a Womens Basketball Titan
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw could not help marveling that some of the titans of womens basketball were all placed in the N.C.A.A. tournaments Raleigh Region.

title: Paraguays Fading Forest
description: A surging land rush is threatening Paraguays Chaco forest. As cattle ranchers from Brazil and German-speaking Mennonites prosper, indigenous people and the environment suffer.

title: Vast Tracts in Paraguay Forest Being Replaced by Ranches
description: FILADELFIA, Paraguay  The Chaco thorn forest, a domain with 118-degree temperatures so forbidding that Paraguayans call it their green hell, covers an expanse about the size of Poland. Hunter-gatherers still live in its vast mazes of quebracho trees.

title: Can Anybody Beat Kentucky?
description: ATLANTA  No. 1 Kentucky scored 102 points against Indiana and committed just 6 turnovers.

title: Confident on the Greens, Woods Has the Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Much has happened to Tiger Woods since he won the Arnold Palmer Invitational for the sixth time in 2009. His aura of invincibility suffered a total eclipse as a result of injuries and the intrepid play of Y. E. Yang, who chased him down to win the 2009 P.G.A. Championship, and Graeme McDowell, who charged from behind to defeat Woods in a playoff at the 2010 Chevron World Challenge.

title: Santorum Gets a Boost in Winning Louisiana
description: Rick Santorum easily won the Louisiana Republican primary Saturday night, capturing a deeply conservative state with a hefty portion of the kind of evangelical Christian voters who have helped him claim victories in 10 other states.

title: Homicides in El Salvador Dip, and Questions Arise
description: MEXICO CITY  Suddenly, killings have plummeted in El Salvador, one of the most violent countries in Central America and a source of growing worry over gangs and organized crime.

title: Victory in Defeat
description: In March 1862, the Souths experiment in disunion seemed destined to meet a near and violent end. February had brought a numbing string of strategic defeats in the vast Western Theater (the area between the Appalachian Mountains and the Mississippi River.) Spearheaded by Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grants victories at Forts Henry and Donelson, Union forces had overrun Kentucky, Missouri and the greater part of Tennessee. Equally troubling, European recognition had eluded the Confederacy. Recent defeats have depressed the weak and are depriving us of the aid of the wavering, lamented Confederate President Jefferson Davis. The military paradox, that impossibilities must be rendered possible, had never better occasion for application.

title: A Tar Heel Needling
description: ST. LOUIS  North Carolina Coach Roy Williams apparently cant resist needling his backup point guard Stilman White, who played 32 minutes in his first college start while filling in for the injured Kendall Marshall on Friday.

title: Taking the Game to the Smaller Screen
description: Chess promoters have long searched for a way to make the game suitable for television. But there are two problems: it can be hard to understand, and it moves too slowly (except for blitz games).

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 24, 2012

title: Kansas Centers Reach Has Foes Grasping at Straws
description: ST. LOUIS  It takes a lot to deter Kansas guard Tyshawn Taylor, a normally fearless senior from Hoboken, N.J., who starred for Coach Bob Hurley at St. Anthony High School. Three years ago, in one of Jeff Witheys first practices after transferring from Arizona, Taylor sized up the soft-spoken 7-footer and decided, just for giggles, to go Michael Jordan on him.

title: Corrections: March 25
description: SPORTS

title: Cris Alexander, Actor and Photographer, Dies at 92
description: New Yorkers tend to believe that creative people trapped in Americas hinterlands hunger to come to their big, pulsating city to fulfill their dreams. In the case of Cris Alexander, it was true.

title: Melvyn Kaufman, Whimsical Developer, Dies at 87
description: The Sopwith Camel at 77 Water Street was in customary repose on the roof last week, the naked lady at 747 Third Avenue held court in her usual place in the lobby, and the chess game in progress on the wall outside 767 Third Avenue looked like the image shown here.

title: Rangers Find Victory, but Still Seek Rhythm
description: TORONTO  Being a hockey goalie can be the cruelest job in sports. Even if a player succeeds 90 percent of the time, it is not really good enough.

title: Louisiana Results Suggest a Two-Man Race
description: Is the Republican presidential contest now a two-man race?

title: Buckeyes Zero In on Oranges Weak Spot
description: BOSTON  The artwork on the bathroom wall of the Ohio State star Jared Sullinger showed just how much a trip to the Final Four meant to him. After last seasons upset loss in the Round of 16 to Kentucky, Sullinger printed out a photo of Wildcats guard Brandon Knights winning shot and hung it up for motivation.

title: Lincoln Hall, Climber Who Survived on Everest, Dies at 56
description: Lincoln Hall, an Australian mountaineer who in May 2006 was rescued on Mount Everest after being left for dead and surviving a night alone at more than 28,000 feet, died on Tuesday in Sydney. He was 56.

title: Shall He Dance?
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Those who were frightened by the sight of Gary Blair, the Texas A&M womens basketball coach, doing the dougie dance after last years national championship better hope the Aggies dont win it all again this year. Blair is threatening to dance once again if they repeat.

title: Knicks Rout Detroit; Stoudemire Exits With Sore Back
description: It was a Saturday night affair that felt as if it had a case of the Mondays for most of the first half. It was the Knicks, playing their fourth game in five nights, against a Pistons team that had lost four straight, including a Friday night defeat at the hands of the Miami Heat.

title: Samiramis Imports
description: For decades, Samiramis Imports has been a go-to for Middle Eastern breads, music, films and its revered Turkish coffee. Craving zaatar? The grocery carries four varieties of that popular spice, made from salt, sesame seeds and herbs. The Syrian mix is spicy and the Lebanese blend is salty, but the stores manager, Wadee Imseeh, says the Palestinian blend is perfect on pita with a drizzle of Jordanian olive oil.

title: Similar Show for New Coach, With Lin Still in Picture
description: In 11 days as the Knicks coach, Mike Woodson has done everything that was expected, except for the part where he burns Mike DAntonis playbook and buries Jeremy Lin.

title: Sheriff Is Set for Classes in Antiviolence
description: Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi of San Francisco called Hamish Sinclair last week to inquire about enrolling in Man Alive Violence Prevention Services. Man Alive conducts domestic violence prevention classes around the Bay Area, and works inside the jail that Mr. Mirkarimis department operates.

title: Oakland Police Try to Fill the Ranks, but Keep Falling Behind
description: About 930 police recruits lined up last week outside the Oakland Convention Center to take the entry-level examination to become an Oakland police officer.

title: Syracuses Season of Excellence Amid Turbulence Ends in Opportunity Gone Awry
description: BOSTON  Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim insists that coaching isnt fun. He acknowledged that he does it for the money. Fun for him, he said, is a round of golf, which he will now be able to enjoy at his convenience after Syracuses 77-70 loss to Ohio State on Saturday night in the East Region final.

title: Doubts in Cold Case That Was Thought Solved
description: For 26 years, the beating death of Natalie Antonetti remained a mystery. The Austin police could not find anyone with motive to hurt the 38-year-old mother who thrived on music and who often invited friends over for haircuts and home-cooked meals.

title: Razing of a Rodeo Arena Closes the Door on History
description: With barely a peep from preservationists, another piece of Texas history was razed in mid-January as bulldozers unceremoniously demolished the prison rodeo arena in Huntsville.

title: Vessel Tossed to Sea in Japans Tsunami Nears Canada
description: Updated | 11:09 a.m. A Japanese fishing boat, lost at sea last year after an earthquake and tsunami killed several thousand people, has been spotted off the coast of British Columbia in western Canada.

title: Duke Women Put a Stop to St. Johns Run
description: FRESNO, Calif.  The senior DaShena Stevens came back from off-season knee surgery, helped stall Connecticuts home winning streak at 99 games and carried St. Johns to its first Round of 16 showing.

title: Jenifer Marsh, Thomas Nassim
description: Jenifer Jo Ann Marsh and Thomas Edward David Nassim were married Saturday at the Little Sanctuary of St. Albans School on the grounds of the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest and the former senior chaplain of the school, performed the ceremony.

title: Nicholas De Baun and Peter Noah
description: Nicholas Hall De Baun and Peter Francis Noah were married Saturday at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York. Bruce Allen, an acting State Supreme Court justice in New York, officiated.

title: Lucy Moore and Harald Fuller-Bennett
description: Lucy Eleanor Moore and Harald Fuller-Bennett were married Saturday evening at Home Moravian Church in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Carl S. Southerland, a Moravian minister and a pastor at the church, led the ceremony.

title: Robert Burns, Gary Schiro
description: Robert Burns and Gary Schiro were married Friday in the Parish Hall of the Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Judge Laura Taylor Swain of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

title: Jessica Fox, James Bergman
description: Jessica Loren Fox and James Henry Bergman were married Saturday evening at the de Seversky Mansion at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. Joseph P. Spinola, a former New York State Supreme Court justice, officiated.

title: Sara Friedlander, Matthew Siegel
description: Sara Ariana Friedlander, a daughter of Rabbi Joy D. Levitt of Manhattan and Rabbi Lee M. Friedlander of Roslyn, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Louis Siegel, a son of Maxine Siegel and Joel Siegel of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum officiated at the Metropolitan Building, a restored factory in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Bonnie Williams, Marco Anasetti
description: Bonnie Faye Williams, a daughter of Dale B. Williams and Guy T. Williams of New Orleans, was married there Saturday to Marco Alan Anasetti, the son of Simone Anasetti and Dr. Claudio Anasetti of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. David Crosby performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church.

title: Julie Yufe and Michael Dreyer
description: Julie Leeat Yufe, the daughter of Avivith Oppenheim of New York and Dr. Robert Yufe of Toronto, was married on Saturday evening to Michael Dreyer, a son of Louise Dreyer and Stephen Dreyer of London. Cantor Howard M. Stahl officiated at the Solage Calistoga Resort in Calistoga, Calif.

title: Kelly Zimmerman, Stephen Rickard
description: Kelly Naamah Zimmerman and Stephen Fletcher Rickard are to be married Sunday in Frederick, Md. The Rev. Jasmine Loney, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Ceresville Mansion.

title: Rebecca Riddick, Daniel Ostrovsky
description: Rebecca Shendelman Riddick, a daughter of Deborah Shendelman and Thomas Riddick of Dunwoody, Ga., is to be married Sunday to Daniel Ostrovsky, the son of Nora Ostrovsky of Manhattan and Michael Ostrovsky of Brooklyn. Rabbi Fred Margulies, the uncle of the bride, is to officiate in Monterey Square in Savannah, Ga., which has a monument to Count Casimir Pulaski, a general who died fighting the British in the Battle of Savannah.

title: Rachel Butler, William Kamens
description: Rachel Darcy Butler, a daughter of Jamie G. Butler and Stuart M. Butler of Washington, is to be married Sunday to William Munroe Kamens, the son of Mary Ellen Miller and Edward B. Kamens of New Haven. Rabbi James E. Ponet is to officiate at the McLean Gardens Ballroom, an event space in Washington.

title: Robert de Michiell and Jeffrey Wilson
description: Robert de Michiell, an illustrator, and Jeffrey Michael Wilson, a theatrical general manager, are to be married Sunday evening in the lobby of the Al Hirschfeld Theater in New York. The theater producer Roger Horchow, who is also a Universal Life minister, is to officiate. Poetry readings are to be performed by the actor Richard Chamberlain and the actress Judith Light, friends of the couple.

title: Lisa Robateau and Stephen Epps
description: Lisa Diana Robateau and Stephen Emmanuel Epps were married Friday evening at the Astor House, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Alvin O. Jackson, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Victoria Namkung, Timothy Koch
description: Victoria Kerry Namkung and Timothy Roger Koch were married Saturday evening at the Viceroy Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Andrew Woodfin Jones, a friend of the couple who was named a temporary deputy marriage commissioner for the event by San Diego County, officiated.

title: Fight Over Lawsuits Now Shapes State Politics
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Heather Baharestani, Peter Hopkins
description: Heather Rachel Baharestani and Peter Edwin Hopkins were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated, with the Rev. Deborah Steen Ross, an interfaith minister, taking part in a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Christian traditions.

title: Candidate Is the Issue in a Democratic Race
description: HOUSTON  Both candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat held for two decades by Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, are unusual.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 24
description: Rick Pitino bested his protg Billy Donovan as Louisville defeated Florida, and Ohio State beat Syracuse after leading most of the game.

title: U.S. Falls to Canada, Complicating Its Plans to Qualify for the London Olympics
description: NASHVILLE  The United States under-23 national team lost to Canada, 2-0, on Saturday night, jeopardizing its chances of qualifying for this summers Olympics in London.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (0), Canada (2)
description: The United States under-23 squads 6-0 thrashing of Cuba on Thursday raised a number of intriguing questions. Were the Americans really that good? Or was it just that Cuba was that bad? And what would happen when the Americans faced stiffer competition on their path toward the 2012 Olympic Games?

title: Pro-Beijing Elite Elects Chief Executive of Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Leung Chun-ying, a pro-Beijing real estate surveyor, won election on Sunday morning to become the next chief executive of Hong Kong.

title: In Japan, Lonely Deaths in Societys Margins
description: HONG KONG  The utilities are cut off. The mail piles up. No sounds come from the apartment. The neighbors dont knock. Nobody comes. Nobody goes.

title: In South Korea Visit, Obama Visits Border and Warns North
description: PANMUNJOM, South Korea  President Obama warned North Korea on Sunday that its threats and provocations would only deepen its international isolation and jeopardize the resumption of American food aid, and he called on the North to scrap its plans to launch a satellite next month.

title: Checking Out the Militarized Zone
description: HONG KONG  First of all, calling it the Demilitarized Zone, they got the name all wrong.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: The latest piece by Booker Prize-winning author and activist Arundhati Roy in Outlook Magazine is titled Capitalism: A Ghost Story. It is a story that begins at Antilla, the most expensive dwelling ever built, which belongs to the richest man in India, Mukesh Ambani, Ms. Roy writes.

title: Greg Cosell on Luck, Griffin and Tebow
description: Greg Cosell, the executive producer of ESPNs N.F.L. Matchup, is widely respected as a film evaluator. When he speaks, people around the league listen.

title: Hong Kong, Divided Over Future, Gets a New Leader
description: HONG KONG  After the political and business elite of Hong Kong elected a real estate surveyor with close ties to Beijing and the Chinese Communist Party on Sunday to become the territorys next chief executive, the victor quickly tried to allay fears that he would restrict civil liberties in Hong Kong or interrupt its gradual progress toward greater democracy.

title: Intergenerational Transportation
description: Dear Diary:

title: Luxury Hotels Lay Out Welcome Mats in India
description: Luxury hotels like the Oberoi and the Taj Mahal have long been part of the fabric of the Indian hospitality industry, but several high-end hoteliers are starting new outposts in the country.

title: U.S. Pays Families of Afghan Victims in Massacre by Soldier
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The families of 16 Afghan villagers who were killed this month by a rampaging American soldier were given $50,000 by the United States for each of their relatives who died, Afghan and American officials said.

title: Romney and Kennedy: Strange Bedfellows
description: Politicians and analysts in Massachusetts explain the nuances of a relationship that brought together the Republican candidate and the iconic Democratic senator.

title: Hunger Games Ticket Sales Set Record
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hunger Games hit the box-office bulls-eye over the weekend, taking in a record $155 million in North America and setting up what promises to be one of the biggest film franchises of this decade.

title: Despite Victory, Santorum Delegate Haul Is Modest
description: Former Senator Rick Santorum may have scored big in the popular vote in Louisiana on Saturday, but he netted only five delegates more than Mitt Romney, doing little to advance himself in the all-important delegate race to claim the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Pitinos Record Puts Him in Rare Territory
description: PHOENIX  When Rick Pitino coached Louisville, the fourth seed in the West Region, past seventh-seeded Florida on Saturday, he ascended higher into the realm of historys most successful college basketball coaches.

title: In Slain Teenagers Case, a Long Route to National Attention
description: Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, was fatally shot on Feb. 26 in Sanford, Fla. The next day his death was a top story on the Fox-affiliated television station in Orlando, the closest big city to Sanford. Within a week it was being covered by newspapers around the state.

title: Killing of Iraqi Woman in San Diego Draws Global Condemnation Online
description: The death in San Diego on Saturday of an Iraqi immigrant, the victim of what appeared to be a hate crime, provoked a wave of outraged comments from bloggers who compared the killing to the shooting of an unarmed Florida teenager last month. The woman, Shaima Alawadi, died three days after her daughter discovered her body in a pool of blood inside their home along with a note that said, Go back to your country, you terrorist.

title: French Authorities File Charges Against Brother of Gunman in Toulouse Killings
description: PARIS  Investigating judges on Sunday filed preliminary murder and terrorism charges against the older brother of the man who confessed to killing seven people in southwest France, saying that the killer acted with the guidance of his brother, an Islamic radical who reportedly had ties to at least one jihadist network. The brother denies involvement in the fatal shootings, his lawyer said.

title: Disruptions: At Amazon, the Robot World Comes a Little Closer
description: Last week Amazon, the online retailer, announced it was buying a robot maker called Kiva Systems for $775 million in cash. Before you get excited that Amazon may offer a robot that can tuck you into bed at night and read Kindle books to you, this isnt that kind of robot company. Instead, Kiva Systems orange robots are designed to move around warehouses and stock shelves.

title: Lanier Voices Support for St. Bonaventure
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Bob Lanier, who averaged 20 points and 10 rebounds in a 14-year N.B.A. career that led him to the Basketball Hall of Fame, also led tiny St. Bonaventure to the 1970 Final Four. The Reilly Center basketball court is named after Lanier.

title: Defense Hides Many of Louisvilles Flaws
description: PHOENIX  On paper, Louisville does not possess a frightening basketball team, nor a Final Four-caliber one.

title: Boston Colleges Kreider Gets Tournament Wake-Up Call
description: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the countrys top-ranked teams.

title: Finding Clues in the Fearful Brain
description: A few weeks agoI wrote in this series about the difference between fear and anxiety. In simple terms, I described fear as a response to an immediately present stimulus and anxiety as a worry or rumination about something that has yet to occur, or may never occur. These are normal, adaptive processes that have evolved in the brain because they help animals, including humans, survive and thrive.

title: At Belmont, a Place to Keep the Workers Children Safe
description: Maria Flores and her husband, Marco Muoz, finished work one recent afternoon and embarked on a short drive to pick up their son, Sebastian, at a nearby day care center in the Elmont section of Nassau County.

title: Bay Hit in Arm by Strasburg
description: VIERA, Fla.  Jason Bay exited the Mets game against the Washington Nationals at Space Coast Stadium on Sunday after getting hit in the right forearm by a fastball from Stephen Strasburg.

title: Problematic Panemetrics
description: Stressful column-writing, so no substantive posts today.

title: Lessons Learned in a Loss to Federer
description: Before Roger Federer was Roger Federer, he was Ryan Harrison.

title: At Mass in Mexico, Pope Urges Humility and Trust
description: LEN, Mexico  Speaking before more than half a million people at an open-air Mass here in a nation wracked by drug violence, Pope Benedict XVI urged the faithful to seek a humble and pure heart and trust in God in the face of evil.

title: In Health Care Case, Lawyers Train for 3-Day Marathon
description: WASHINGTON  The three days of Supreme Court arguments that start Monday on the constitutionality of President Obamas health care law will be a legal marathon, and the lawyers involved have been training.

title: Character and Its Discontents
description: Yes, thats what I like about me, at least one of the things, that I can say, Up the Republic!, for example, or, Sweetheart!, for example, without having to wonder whether I should not rather have cut my tongue out, or said something else.

title: Maryland Eliminates Defending National Champion Texas A&M
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  It has been six years since Maryland reached the N.C.A.A. womens Final Four. But the last time the Terrapins were there, they won it all.

title: Industries Fear the Ripple Effects of Proposed Postal Service Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Wine wholesalers and amateur beer makers want Congress to repeal a law that makes it illegal to ship alcohol by mail.

title: Home Video Company Cashing In on British Revivals
description: Spurred on by new episodes of the British serial Upstairs, Downstairs on PBS last April, many viewers went in search of the 40-year-old original. They found it in the catalog of Acorn Media, which had released the vintage series a month earlier as a complete 21-disc DVD set.

title: Stretching Vocal Cords Across Time
description: With its sweeping survey of vocal groups from the early 1930s into the mid-70s the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics & Lyricists series moved further into rock n roll territory on Saturday evening than I can remember it venturing. At the first of five shows, songs by Abba, the Beatles, the Beach Boys and the Ronettes shared common ground with the Boswell Sisters, the Andrews Sisters and the Mills Brothers. The unlikely host and artistic director, the gifted conductor and musical theater archivist Rob Fisher, was not the person you would expect to oversee such a project.

title: A Broad Sampling of New Classical Works
description: It has always been the American Composers Orchestras mandate to explore the full range of American classical music, and in its 35 seasons it has done so without a trace of dogmatic ax grinding. Still, the orchestra has often compartmentalized, devoting a program to one or two approaches, and the next to a couple more. That makes sense. If you try to show everything at once, you may end up with the kind of motley program that George Manahan led on Thursday at Zankel Hall.

title: Proxy Fight Looming, Yahoo Names 3 to Board
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Looking Back, With Little Hope of Going Back
description: Every March for the last several seasons, Dwane Casey has looked from his perch as an N.B.A. coach to see how the N.C.A.A. tournament is treating his Kentucky Wildcats. After all these years, Caseys heart still bleeds Kentucky blue.

title: Sharing a Legacy of Loss Among Three Generations
description: After experiencing the warmly satisfying revival of Lost in Yonkers at the Beckett Theater it seems inconceivable that it has taken two decades for this Pulitzer- and Tony-winning 1991 Neil Simon play to return to a New York stage.

title: Tar Heels Missing Marshall
description: ST. LOUIS  North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall (broken right wrist) was not in uniform for Sundays Midwest Region championship game against Kansas, according to a Tar Heels spokesman.

title: New Gant Ads Focus on Old School Tie
description: For those consumers who did not go to Yale but wish they could have, a new shirt may be all that is needed to fill the void.

title: In 2008 Crane Collapse, Scrutiny on Supplier of Part
description: The worker began scouring the Internet, following his bosss orders to find someone who could build a turntable for a crane, and finish it faster and for less money than the estimates given by two American companies.

title: Volleys of Words From a Writer of No Brevity
description: A field of bright yellow tennis balls greets audiences at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, where the director Daniel Fish and a cast of five are lobbing the words of the celebrated writer David Foster Wallace in staggering doses. The show, in which the performers repeat verbatim thick slices from Wallaces nonfiction prose as well as interviews with him, bears the appropriately lengthy title A (radically condensed and expanded) SUPPOSEDLY FUN THING ILL NEVER DO AGAIN (after David Foster Wallace).

title: Notre Dame Rolls as St. Bonaventures Run Comes to End
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The team records St. Bonaventure set this season might never be matched, the heights perhaps never reached again. And that is what the Bonnies can take from a season in which they made the N.C.A.A. womens tournament for the first time in history and advanced all the way to the Raleigh Region semifinals.

title: Bell Tones Are Ringing in Percussion and Piano Program
description: The composer George Crumb, in program notes for a classic 1975 recording of his Music for a Summer Evening (Makrokosmos III), cited as a primary influence Bartoks groundbreaking Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion. It is curious that other composers did not subsequently contribute to the genre, he wrote. Not so curious, perhaps, if you consider the labor entailed in transporting and arranging the disparate, bulky equipment involved.

title: Serenity That Barely Masks the Passion and the Whimsy
description: Yefim Bronfman, an accomplished, admired and much-traveled pianist, did not have the best 2011, it would seem. The last time he was scheduled to present a solo recital at Carnegie Hall, almost a year ago, he canceled because of exhaustion. In October he missed an Oregon engagement because of an ear infection, and he fractured a finger during a recital in Berkeley, Calif., that month, causing further cancellations.

title: Kentucky in Final Four; Its Next Goal Is a State Title
description: ATLANTA  Kentucky was not bothered by Baylors height or its players wingspans, and it was not bothered by the Bears 1-3-1 zone defense. Nor were the Wildcats unnerved by their ragged play in the second half, which enabled Baylor to make a brief challenge in the N.C.A.A. tournaments South Region championship game on Sunday. Kentucky also handled a scary fall by its all-American center, Anthony Davis, and the strain of second-half foul trouble on its seven-man rotation.

title: TNT Promotes New Version of Dallas Series
description: The cable channel TNT will bring a new meaning to April showers to promote the return of a familiar series known for the most celebrated shower scene since Psycho.

title: Living Large and Falling Out in Deepest Brooklyn
description: There is no rest for the defenders of Italian-American dignity in the greater New York area. MTVs Jersey Shore may have finished its season, but on the horizon are TLCs Mamas Boys of the Bronx (April 9), about Arthur Avenue homeboys who live with their mothers, and A&Es Rambug (May 5), about a brawny group of hard-working, over-the-top Italian exterminators from Brooklyn.

title: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Final
description: MEMPHIS  The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was played in Memphis on Sunday, the last day of the Spring North American Championships.

title: A Far-Off Island Where the American Dream Curdles
description: The main character in P. F. Kluges stingingly funny new novel, The Master Blaster, isnt a person. Its a location: Saipan, a very small island with a big, bizarre place in history. Saipan is one of the Northern Mariana Islands in the western Pacific, north of the Solomons and west of the Marshalls. It was a site of brutal fighting during World War II, grimly commemorated by one cliff nicknamed Suicide and another called Banzai. Its neighbor is Tinian, the island from which the Enola Gay took off to bomb Hiroshima.

title: A Down Dog
description: Dear Diary:

title: Follow That Grid
description: Administrivial New Puzzle Book Alert! My Fearless Leader from the Onion/A.V. Club puzzles, the highly talented and extremely dangerous Ben Tausig, has a fabulous new puzzle book out called Crosswords From the Underground, a compilation of his work in alternative newspapers. These puzzles, along with his commentary, are Not Safe For Work or the Easily Offended, but if you want to try some grids that are very different from your New York Times fare, clicky here.

title: They Work Hard For The Money
description: OK, I wasnt going to post anything else, but as Robert Farley says, this WaPo piece on underworked college teachers is outrageous.

title: Fiona Apple Performs
description: Images from Fiona Apples concert at the Music Hall of Williamsburg.

title: Fiona Apple Returns to the Faithful
description: Fiona Apple has control. Thats clear from the moment she took the stage on Friday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn. She opened with some patter about missing her dog (of whom she had a painting), an insistence that people in the crowd not talk during the show and then announced, I will give you everything I can possibly give you, before opening her first New York concert in five years with a staggeringly loud, brightly alive Fast as You Can, spitting out her syllables in carefully measured cadences, her body shivering with vigor.

title: From Stage to Screen, Still Intact
description: During the intermissions of the live broadcast of the Royal Ballets Romeo and Juliet on Thursday from the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, enthusiastic tweets were streamed onto the screen from viewers in Prague, Buenos Aires and New York, as well as parts of Britain. Heres hoping this series of transmissions continues to develop. They do much to give us an immediate sense of how dance companies far away are looking.

title: Obama Warns North Korea
description: At a news conference in South Korea, President Obama urged China to use its influence to stop North Korea from proceeding with plans to launch a satellite.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: On Aging: Look at the Brighter Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Policing Medicaid Fraud: The View From Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Minerals From Congo
description: To the Editor:

title: In Malaysia, Alonso Wins Race but Perez Wins Stardom
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Just when it seemed that Formula One could not come up with any more fairy-tale race scenarios, the rain in Malaysia produced a race like none other we had seen before, with the unlikely revival of Fernando Alonso and the Ferrari team winning while in the throes of a tortuous season debut, and the even more unlikely surfacing of a new star. That was Sergio Perez, the 22-year-old Mexican driver who finished second in the race in the Sauber car.

title: Measuring Quality of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Natural Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: A Game Explodes and Changes Life Overnight at a Struggling Start-Up
description: At a cocktail party on the second floor of the expensive Bowery Hotel in Manhattan on Thursday night, as trays of stuffed mushrooms and thinly sliced filet mignon circulated, Charles Forman was marveling at how quickly things can change.

title: With Summit of Arab Leaders, Iraq Seeks to Shift Image
description: BAGHDAD  As Arab leaders converge on Baghdad for a landmark summit meeting this week, they will be treated to carefully chosen glimpses of a new Iraq: gleaming hotel lobbies, renovated palaces and young palm trees lining an airport highway once called the Road of Death.

title: Indian Activist Attempts Revival of Antigraft Drive
description: NEW DELHI  The activist Anna Hazare returned to the spotlight with a protest on Sunday, wearing his familiar white Gandhian cap and sitting cross-legged for a one-day hunger strike against corruption. The crowds again chanted his name and again wore I Am Anna hats, as his cohort of advisers shouted slogans against the government.

title: Rehabilitating the Alienated and Addicted
description: The second half of the 41st annual New Directors/New Films has arrived with more yowzas than yawns. What a relief! In recent years this venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, which aims to showcase worthy emerging filmmakers, has at times struggled to find enough good movies to fill out its 12 days. This weeks lineup includes several standouts, notably Oslo, August 31st (yes, from Norway) by Joachim Trier, one of the discoveries from the 2011 Cannes Film Festival. Just as crucial, even some of the lesser selections offer something for viewers to consider, if only an aesthetic or a worldview to argue against, or maybe hate.

title: Dance in India
description: Images of some of the dance companies in India.

title: Visions of India Dancing and Dancing and Dancing
description: When an illustrious Indian dance company performs in New York, as the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble did at the Joyce Theater last week, we can take both pleasure and instruction from it. Music and dance operate in thrilling proximity; the visual sensuousness is in many ways exceptional; the levels of technical achievement and stylistic polish are high. Best of all were given a window into a culture far from our own.

title: Auriemma Growls, and UConn Roars to a Convincing Win
description: KINGSTON, R.I.  Penn State started slowly Sunday, the players nerves jangled by the size of the challenge in front of them. But this is a team that fashions itself as an offensive dynamo, and it cut a 14-point deficit to 5 in hardly any time at all.

title: Filmmaker in Submarine Voyages to Bottom of Sea
description: James Cameron, the filmmaker whose credits include Avatar and Titanic, plunged on Sunday in a minisubmarine of his own design to the bottom of the planets deepest recess, sinking through the dark waters of the western Pacific to a depth of nearly seven miles.

title: When a Parking Lot Is So Much More
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Anita Steckel, Artist Who Created Erotic Works, Dies at 82
description: Anita Steckel, whose playful and sometimes unsettling erotic works were little known outside the mostly underground world of feminist art until she was discovered in her 70s and her creations acclaimed as masterly and groundbreaking, died on March 16 in Manhattan. She was 82.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include pending home sales for February (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for January and consumer confidence for March (Tuesday); durable goods orders for February (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the final gross domestic product for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and personal income and spending for February, the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for March and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday)

title: The Rich Get Even Richer
description: NEW statistics show an ever-more-startling divergence between the fortunes of the wealthy and everybody else  and the desperate need to address this wrenching problem. Even in a country that sometimes seems inured to income inequality, these takeaways are truly stunning.

title: After 923 Days, Its Official: Woods Ends Tour Drought
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For the 54-hole leader, the final round of a PGA Tour event is a mirror that reflects his flaws, his fears, his focus and his facility. On Sunday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, the eyes of the golf world were on Tiger Woods to see which face he put forward.

title: U.S. and Turkey to Step Up Nonlethal Aid to Rebels in Syria
description: BEIRUT  Turkey and the United States plan to provide nonlethal assistance, like communications equipment and medical supplies, directly to opposition groups inside Syria, and will urge other allies to do so as well, the White House deputy national security adviser said on Sunday, after President Obama met with the prime minister of Turkey at a nuclear security conference in Seoul, South Korea.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Queens G.O.P. Endorses Halloran for Congress
description: The Queens Republican Party on Sunday endorsed Councilman Daniel J. Halloran III as its Congressional candidate in a new district that has been carved out of the one represented by Gary L. Ackerman, a veteran congressman who abruptly announced his retirement this month.

title: Pitching the Ad Life to the Digital Set
description: THE leading trade organization for advertising agencies is intensifying efforts to cast a wider net when recruiting employees with an initiative aimed not only at students, but also at talented younger people who work in other industries.

title: Hashtag Activism, and Its Limits
description: If you like something, does that mean you care about it?

title: With North Carolina Cracking, Kansas Keeps Its Cool
description: ST. LOUIS  Roy Williams cries as easily as some people take jump shots. Williams, the North Carolina coach, figured to be teary after the Tar Heels let a chance at their 19th Final Four appearance slip away in the final minutes on Sunday against Kansas. And the worst part was admitting what happened.

title: Chvez in Cuba for Treatment, but Hasnt Sought Visit With Pope
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela flew to Cuba over the weekend to begin radiation therapy to treat the return of his cancer, he said Sunday. He will be there during Pope Benedict XVIs visit to Cuba, which begins Monday.

title: No Longer Burning, the South Bronx Gentrifies
description: When William Casari moved to the Grand Concourse seven years ago, some people passing him on the sidewalk figured he was either an undercover police officer or a Yankees fan who had wandered off from the stadium.

title: What Gender Gap? Washington State Has a History of Women Who Lead
description: SEATTLE  It was 2009, floods had inundated western Washington and the states politicians were flown up to survey the damage. When asked who would scoot down to the open end of the C-17 cargo plane, where they would have to be tethered down for safety, Gov. Christine Gregoire and Senators Maria Cantwell and Patty Murray volunteered.

title: Israels Top Court Orders Settlers to Leave Outpost
description: JERUSALEM  Israels Supreme Court on Sunday ordered a West Bank settlers outpost built on private Palestinian land to be dismantled by Aug. 1, rejecting a government compromise with the settlers that would have allowed them to stay put for another three years.

title: Bringing an Open-Source Ethos to Bands
description: When Maggie Vail first heard about open-source software, she said, it felt like punk rock.

title: Tough End for Baylor, but Future Is Promising
description: ATLANTA  Baylor warmed up for its regional final matchup with Kentucky on Sunday wearing matching T-shirts that read, One Team, One God, One Goal.

title: How a Short Sale Works
description: An investor who expects a stock to fall in price may execute a short sale. If the price of the stock does fall, he can make a profit.

title: BATS Trading Error Bolsters Case for Curbs
description: The exchange operator BATS Global Markets styled itself as the future of stock trading  faster, more efficient  when it began in 2005. Its name stood for Better Alternative Trading System.

title: Tebow May Play Various Roles, Ryan Suggests
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Tim Tebow will be at the center of the most well-attended news conference in backup quarterback history Monday. But on Sunday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan opened the door to something more: that Tebow could be used at other positions.

title: A Turbulence-Free Election in Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The elderly president of this West African nation conceded defeat after elections here on Sunday, a rare example of a prompt and peaceful political turnover in a region tormented by coups and leaders who refuse to give up power.

title: Transcript of Depositions in Case (Note: Some passages include vulgar language)
description: Testifying recently in a lawsuit that is unrelated to Copper Rivers closing, Marc Cohedes maintained that actions taken in the fall of 2008 by Goldman Sachs had done irreparable damage to his fund. (Note: Some passages include vulgar language).

title: Lobbyists, Guns and Money
description: Floridas now-infamous Stand Your Ground law, which lets you shoot someone you consider threatening without facing arrest, let alone prosecution, sounds crazy  and it is. And its tempting to dismiss this law as the work of ignorant yahoos. But similar laws have been pushed across the nation, not by ignorant yahoos but by big corporations.

title: Pineda Hits the Gas, and His Fastballs Speed Jumps
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With a solid performance Sunday, Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda might have quelled for now some of the near panic over the mysterious loss of three or four miles per hour on his fastball.

title: I Regret Eating My Placenta
description: Its not as gross as it sounds, but then, it couldnt possibly be, right? As a first-time pregnant lady living in crunchy Santa Monica, Calif., next to a raw food restaurant and a seemingly oxymoronic homeopathic pharmacy, hiring a so-called celebrity placenta processor seemed to make sense. Even the hospital birth class had suggested the practice of eating ones own placenta as a natural way to ward off postpartum depression. Its normal. Its natural. Even January Jones is doing it.

title: Santorum Calls Romney Worst Republican to Run Against Obama
description: RACINE, Wis.  Rick Santorum urged Republicans here Sunday evening to carefully study the record of Mitt Romney, declaring: He is the worst Republican in the country to put up against Barack Obama.

title: Wagner Promotes Assistant to Replace Hurley
description: Wagner has promoted assistant Bashir Mason to be its head basketball coach, replacing Dan Hurley, who left for the Rhode Island coaching job.

title: Anger at Goldman Still Simmers
description: Just before the financial crisis began in September 2008, a prominent hedge fund appeared well positioned to take advantage of any turmoil in the markets. That fund, Copper River Partners, had made sizable bets months earlier against companies whose stocks it expected to suffer.

title: In Pakistan, Hindus Say Womans Conversion to Islam Was Coerced
description: GHOTKI, Pakistan  Banditry is an old scourge in this impoverished district of southern Pakistan, on the plains between the mighty river Indus and a sprawling desert, where roving gangs rob and kidnap with abandon. Lately, though, local passions have stirred with allegations of an unusual theft: that of a young womans heart.

title: Passing Motion Evolves, but Scrutiny Is Constant
description: Tim Tebows tenure at Florida was defined by team greatness and individual excellence, a stretch of success epitomized by his final game with the Gators, when he completed 31 of 35 passes for 482 yards in a Sugar Bowl victory against Cincinnati. His dazzling college career complete, Tebow did what anyone else in his position would do: he set off to rebuild himself.

title: In Jackson Heights, Movers Respect Turf Rules
description: It is a well-established fact in Jackson Heights, Queens, that the moving men of La Noventa and the moving men of La Ciento y Tres do not mix.

title: Waiting (and Sleeping) in Line, for View of Health Care History
description: WASHINGTON  Time becomes an abstract concept after you have spent 47 hours sitting on the sidewalk outside the Supreme Court.

title: A Mothers Grace and Grieving
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.

title: Managing a Planet Under Pressure
description: March 27, 4:29 a.m. | Updated Heres a Twitter feed of comments on the conference, which is live on the Web:

title: Not Worth the Paper Its Built On
description: DUBLIN  As an emblem of the modern Irish condition, Frank Buckley is almost too apt. Dead broke, he lives in a house made of money.

title: Red Bulls Quickly Change the Mood at Home
description: HARRISON, N.J.  After a sputtering, mistake-laden start to their season in which they lost two games on the road, the Red Bulls needed a mere six minutes Sunday afternoon to turn Red Bull Arena into a nearly impregnable fortress.

title: After Detectives Firing, Tensions Linger in Bell Case
description: The dismissal of the undercover detective who fired the first of the 50 police bullets when Sean Bell was killed more than five years ago may close the final chapter of that drawn-out story. But on the Queens streets near the site of Mr. Bells shooting, residents expressed anger, and resentments that remain unresolved.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 25, 2012

title: E-Mail to Corzine Said Transfer Was Not Customer Money
description: Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, was told during the brokerage firms final day of business that a crucial transfer of $175 million came from the firms own money, not from a customer account, according to an internal e-mail.

title: Young Met Faces a Peer; Similarities End There
description: VIERA, Fla.  The humdrum days of spring training can be enlivened by games like these, ones that invite observers to imagine the future through a lens of intrigue.

title: Catholic Church Deals With a Diminished Role in Cuban Life
description: HAVANA  At an evangelical church booming with pounding drums, crashing cymbals and a throaty bass, members of an overflow crowd danced in the aisles, sang over a soaring trumpet and swept their arms in prayer. One woman shook violently, her hand aloft as if to say enough, or perhaps more.

title: Egypt Ruling Council Says Brotherhood Is Trying to Undermine It
description: CAIRO  Egypts ruling military council lashed out at the powerful Muslim Brotherhood on Sunday, accusing the group of trying to undermine the government and of questioning the motives of the military rulers. The statement was a sign of mounting tensions between the countrys increasingly assertive Islamists and often intractable military rulers, as Egypt prepares for a presidential election to begin in May.

title: Abduction and Hotel Attack Spotlight Libyas Disarray
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Fighters from the town of Zintan stormed into and shot up the luxury hotel that is the de facto base for members of Libyas ruling Transitional National Council over the weekend, days after members of the council acknowledged that a rival militia from Misurata had kidnapped and briefly detained two of its members last week.

title: Summitt Retains Her Essence but Lets Go of the Reins
description: DES MOINES

title: When Other Voices Are Drowned Out
description: The Supreme Courts 5-to-4 ruling in Citizens United in 2010 was shaped by an extreme view of the First Amendment: money equals speech, and independent spending by wealthy organizations and individuals poses no problem to the political system. The court cavalierly dismissed worries that those with big bank accounts  and big megaphones  have an unfair advantage in exerting political power. It simply asserted that the people have the ultimate influence over elected officials  as if campaigns were not in the business of influencing and manipulating voters.

title: Good Wife Watch: Alicia Florrick v. the Patriarchy
description: Which was worse in Blue Ribbon Panel, Sunday nights episode of The Good Wife (which began 20 minutes late, this time because of college basketball)?

title: The Wall Between Contractors and Politics
description: Since 1940, it has been illegal for federal government contractors to contribute to federal political campaigns or parties. But in the new unregulated, unlimited jungle of campaign finance, Mitt Romneys super PAC is allowing some contractors to violate that historic ban, taking yet another dangerous step toward a culture where government business is done on a pay-to-play basis.

title: At Ailing Brooklyn Hospital, Insider Deals and Lavish Perks
description: In recent years, Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn has often gone hat in hand to the city and state, lamenting cuts in government assistance and questioning whether officials truly understood the burden of running a nonprofit hospital in Bushwick, one of the citys poorest neighborhoods.

title: Wielding Fire, Islamists Target Nigeria Schools
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  The teenager in the immaculate white robe stood in the ruins of what had been his school. There were no classrooms, no desks or chairs, no intact blackboards  there was, in fact, no longer any reason for him to be there.

title: Once Neighboring Congressmen, Iowans Compete for Same Seat
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  Representative Tom Latham cut into a frosted cinnamon roll roughly the size of his face and listened intently as a group of small-business owners lit into him about sprinkler rules and federal financial regulations. It was the second of a dozen meetings on a recent Wednesday in one of the counties in his native Iowa that Mr. Latham, a Republican, has not represented before in Congress.

title: Dementia Behind Bars
description: The get-tough-on-crime and mandatory sentencing policies that swept America beginning in the 1970s did more than drive up the inmate population and prison costs. They also ensured that inmates who once might have been seen as rehabilitated and given parole would grow old and even die behind bars. As a result, prisons are struggling to furnish costly, specialized care to ever more inmates who suffer from age-related infirmities, especially dementia.

title: Is the Court Being Thoughtful or Partisan?
London Suddenly Further Away for U.S. Soccer Team
description: NASHVILLE  After a surprising 2-0 loss to Canada on Saturday night put its Olympic hopes in jeopardy, the United States under-23 team is preparing for a must-win game against El Salvador on Monday.

title: Red Bulls Get a Win; U.S. Under-23s Need One Badly
description: On Sunday afternoon, the Red Bulls won their home opener, beating the Colorado Rapids, 4-1, to give their fans something to think about other than their poor performances in two season-opening losses on the road. (Highlights here.) On Monday night, the United States under-23 team will face El Salvador in Nashville in a game critical to its hopes of playing in the London Olympics this summer. Jack Bell of The Times was at the Red Bulls win, and Brian Sciaretta previewed the Olympic teams predicament.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Photo Replay: March 25
description: Kentucky reached the Final Four with a dominant win over Baylor, 82-70. Kansas defeated North Carolina, 80-67, to earn its second berth in five years.

title: Gingrich Is Soldiering On, Despite Dearth of Victories
description: Primary by primary, Newt Gingrichs reasons for remaining in the presidential race keep getting knocked down.

title: Santorum Ignores Pressure to Bow Out to Romney
description: RACINE, Wis.  Mitt Romney remains his biggest foe, but Rick Santorum is increasingly confronting an even more daunting obstacle: a rising chorus of Republicans calling for the divisive presidential contest to end so the party can turn its full attention to defeating President Obama.

title: Fighting to Control the Meaning of Obamacare
description: How the parties have used or tried to use an invented word to shape public opinion.

title: Mad Men Recap: In the Season 5 Premiere, After a Long Layoff, a Party
description: Season 5, Episode 1Our initial Mad Men recap of Season 5 will be brief; for a more complete examination of Sundays two-hour-plus season premiere and the return of AMCs wildly popular show after a 17-month hiatus, please refer to Alessandra Stanleys TV Watch from this past Friday.

title: Corrections: March 26
description: NATIONAL

title: Police Critically Wound Man Who Shot at Them in Harlem
description: A man was critically wounded by the police Sunday night after an exchange of gunfire with one of two officers who had been following him in West Harlem, the authorities said.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: Images from campaign stops and polling places in Illinois and Louisiana.

title: Batter With Quirky Stance Now Has Job Tweaking Them
description: PEORIA, Ariz.

title: Qantas in China Venture for Budget Airline
description: HONG KONG  Qantas Airways of Australia announced Monday that it was teaming up with one of the biggest carriers in China to form a low-cost airline based in Hong Kong, the latest in a string of airline ventures in Asia as carriers race to position themselves in anticipation of a major increase in air travel.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: Images from campaign stops and polling places in Illinois and Louisiana.  Go to the slide show.

title: Learning That Even New Yorks Finest Have to Eat, and Other City Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Putting Babies to Bed Safely
description: Nearly two decades after a public health campaign began promoting sleep safety for babies, many parents and caretakers are still unaware of the habits that can lead to sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS, a new study suggests.

title: Microsoft Raids Tackle Internet Crime
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft employees, accompanied by United States marshals, raided two nondescript office buildings in Pennsylvania and Illinois on Friday, aiming to disrupt one of the most pernicious forms of online crime today  botnets, or groups of computers that help harvest bank account passwords and other personal information from millions of other computers.

title: Word of the Day | forestall
description: forestall \fr-stl\ verb

title: Venus Williams Saves Match Point and Rallies to Win
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Though Venus Williams has been playing professional tennis since 1994, it is nearly impossible to know what comes next from her.

title: BATS Chief on Fridays Troubles: My Stomach Sank
description: Friday morning did not go quite the way Joe Ratterman had expected.

title: For Cheney, Pros and Cons in New Heart
description: It was the first time he was offered a transplant in the 20 months he had been on the waiting list, and Dick Cheney, the former vice president, decided to take it, his principal cardiologist said in a telephone interview Sunday, the day after the successful seven-hour operation.

title: Building a House Brings Members of a Community Closer
description: In Glastonbury, Conn., a series of interactions that led to the construction of a veterans new home is seen as more than just luck.

title: Irving Louis Horowitz, Sociologist and Ideological Critic, Dies at 82
description: Irving Louis Horowitz, an eminent sociologist and prolific author who started a leading journal in his field but who came to fear that his discipline risked being captured by left-wing ideologues, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. He was 82.

title: Town Jumps on Board to Embrace a Marine
description: GLASTONBURY, Conn.  Ask people in this Hartford suburb how the campaign to build Mannys house went viral, and they may consult a spreadsheet or sketch a Venn diagram or two. Trust them when they say, Its complicated.

title: The Ups and Downs of the Games Greats Who Moved On Late
description: Old soldiers never die, Gen. Douglas MacArthur once said, they just fade away. Old quarterbacks also never die, they just fade into a different uniform.

title: Sisters on Stanford Take the Teammate Bond to Another Level
description: FRESNO, Calif.  The play-by-play sheet did not mark the exact moment, and there was no telephone changing booth in sight. Just the same, Nnemkadi Ogwumike somehow switched from Stanford teammate to Super Sister the split second Chiney Ogwumike crumpled with a yelp to the hardwood floor of the Save Mart Center on Saturday night.

title: Chamberlain Exits Hospital With a Positive Prognosis
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain was released from St. Josephs Hospital on Sunday and will spend the next six weeks in a cast as he recovers from surgery to repair a dislocated right ankle.

title: The Renegade Republicans
description: For nearly three decades, South Carolina served as the bulwark of the Republican establishment. The state has been the killing ground of insurgent presidential bids again and again: John Connollys 1980 challenge to Ronald Reagan, who finally had the backing of the party establishment; Pat Buchanans attempt to oust George Bush in 1992; John McCains bid to push aside George W. Bush in 2000; and most recently Mike Huckabees 2008 assault on McCain.

title: Neither Phones, Nor Cameras, Nor Tweets in the Court
description: WASHINGTON  There was a time  before Twitter, cable TV, bloggers and mobile apps  when political reporters in Washington waited until the end of a big campaign rally, court case or Congressional hearing before rushing to tap out their stories or call in their scoops.

title: Anna Hazare Tries to Renew Anticorruption Movement
description: The activist Anna Hazare returned to the spotlight with a protest on Sunday, wearing his familiar white Gandhian cap and sitting cross-legged for a one-day hunger strike against corruption, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. The crowds again chanted his name and again wore I Am Anna hats, as his cohort of advisers shouted slogans against the government.

title: Rushworth M. Kidder, Journalist Who Studied Ethics, Dies at 67
description: Rushworth M. Kidder, an academic-turned-journalist who founded a research institute dedicated to mapping approaches to ethical dilemmas and propounded his ideas in books, speeches and seminars, died on March 5 at a nursing home in Davie, Fla. He was 67.

title: Socialists.com Yields a Presidential Result
description: The evidence is unmistakable, the presidents opponents say. Type socialists.com into your Web browser. Press enter. And behold the smiling face of President Obama, greeting visitors to his campaign Web site.

title: School District Told to Replace Web Filter Blocking Pro-Gay Sites
description: CAMDENTON, Mo.  Students using the computers at Camdenton High School here in central Missouri have been able to access the Web sites for Exodus International, as well as People Can Change, antigay organizations that counsel men and women on how to become heterosexual.

title: Debate Shifts From the Trail to the Capital
description: For months, the political debate in Washington has been defined largely by the seemingly constant confrontations on the Republican presidential campaign trail. That is about to change, at least for a while.

title: Your Suggestions for India in One, Two or Three Weeks
