description: India in One, Two or Three Weeks, an article by Guy Trebay in the Travel section of The New York Times, advises a policy of less is more is always sensible in India, in order to limit the shock the place inevitably delivers to an average Westerners system.

title: Giants Mara Defends Ruling Against Cowboys and Redskins
description: The Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys, two of the N.F.L.s highest-profile and richest teams, have filed for arbitration in their dispute with the league over its decision to strip them of a combined $46 million in salary-cap space.

title: Visions of India Dancing and Dancing and Dancing
description: New York hosts several first-rate Indian companies or dance soloists each year, Alastair Macaulay writes in The New York Times.

title: Paying a Price Amid the Fog of War
description: HONG KONG  Call it assistance, call it regrettable, call it $50,000 for each dead body, but do not call it compensation.

title: Obama Urges China to Restrain North Korea as He Praises Souths Successes
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Obama took North Koreas untested new leader, Kim Jong-un, to task on Monday, demanding that China curb his belligerent behavior and declaring that South Koreas economic and democratic achievements would inevitably triumph over the failure and isolation of the North.

title: News Quiz | March 26, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: NYT Front Page for 03/26/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/26/2012

title: Britain Seeks Investigation of Businessmans Death in China
description: BEIJING  Britain has asked China to open an inquiry into the death in November of a British citizen linked to the family of Bo Xilai, the Chinese Politburo member whose dismissal this month as Communist Party secretary of Chongqing was widely said to reveal a deep split among the nations leaders.

title: Spains Ruling Party Disappointed in Regional Ballot
description: MADRID  Prime minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain insisted on Monday that his government would forge ahead with further austerity cuts and economic reforms, even after his Popular Party suffered its first disappointment at the polls since taking office, failing to win an absolute majority in an election in Andalusia, the countrys most populous region.

title: March 26, 1979 | Israel and Egypt Sign Peace Treaty
description: On March 26, 1979, in a ceremony hosted by U.S. President Jimmy Carter at the White House, Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat signed the Israel-Egypt Peace Treaty, the first peace treaty between Israel and an Arab country.

title: Mumbai Gets Its Own Walk of Fame
description: If staring at Bollywood stars houses, waiting patiently for them to go grocery shopping, or living vicariously through gossip columns is not enough for you, theres Indias brand-new, star-studded walk of fame.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 26, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article N.C.A.A. Builds Solid Brackets From a Shaky Foundation.

title: Lelyveld on Writing About Gandhi
description: In a talk hosted by India Ink and Caravan Magazine last month, Joseph Lelyveld, author of Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India, spoke with Ananya Vajpeyi, a visiting fellow at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies, about the inspiration behind his book and how he researched his study of one of the 20th centurys most written about men.

title: In Moscow, Little Girl Soldiers
description: They prepare for classes and make their beds together, gently setting a teddy bear and a stuffed crocodile on pillows. They look intently at themselves as they fix oversize white bows, meant to symbolize purity, in their hair.

title: 3 NATO Soldiers Killed by Afghan Security Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three NATO soldiers were shot to death on Monday in two separate confrontations involving Afghan security forces, officials said, adding to a string of green on blue killings that have complicated the relationship between Afghanistan and its Western allies.

title: Turkey and Norway Shut Embassies in Syria; New Shelling Is Reported in Homs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey and Norway closed their embassies in Syria on Monday and ordered all diplomatic staff withdrawn in response to the governments harsh repression of the year-old uprising, as opposition activists reported a new spasm of army shelling in Homs, the rebellious city that Syrian security forces had proclaimed purged of insurgents just a few weeks ago.

title: Health Act Arguments Open With Obstacle From 1867
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday starts three days of hearings on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul law, an epic clash that could recast the very structure of American government. But it begins with a 90-minute argument on what a lawyer in the case has called the most boring jurisdictional stuff one can imagine.

title: Roche Extends Deadline for Illumina Offer
description: Roche Holding is not taking no for an answer.

title: Every Block, Every Borough
description: WHO is Matt Green?

title: The Start of BigFuture, a New College Planning Web Site
description: The College Board, the nonprofit association of colleges and universities that oversees the SAT and Advanced Placement program, has introduced a new college planning Web site that it hopes will help a wide range of students, including first-generation college students who may not know much about the college admissions process.

title: The Early Word: Marathon
The Nurture of Nuclear Power
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Fantasy Focus: Five Big Questions
description: As fantasy owners look toward opening day, a number of questions remain on playing time, roles and the merits of spring statistics in determining regular-season performance. Heres a look at five situations on many an owners mind:

title: Robert Bales and the Twin Lessons of Afghanistan, 170 Years Apart
description: It was already very old news when William Tecumseh Sherman remarked in 1872 that war is hell. In the specific case of Afghanistan, armies have been seeing that firsthand since Alexander the Great gave up on Kandahar in the third century B.C.

title: Bullitt Shadow Looms Large Over Alcatraz Finale
description: The series takes place in San Francisco, so we thought wed tip our hat to it and do an homage, Jack Bender, an executive producer of Foxs science-fiction series Alcatraz, said in an interview. Mr. Benders hat was tipped toward Bullitt, the 1968 film starring Steve McQueen, in particular its chase scene, perhaps the most closely studied car sequence in cinema.

title: What Can Other Schools Learn  and Copy  From Your School?
description: Think about your schoolits routines, schedule, even traditions and unofficial habits that are all part of the average day. How does it work? How many teachers do you have? How much time do you spend in eachs classroom? Do your teachers collaborate with each other on projects? What successful aspects of your school could other schools could learn from?

title: Fragile Freedoms in Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Until just recently, I would have said that if you didnt want to risk getting arrested in Myanmar, you should stay away from that red and gold insignia with the fighting peacock.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Takes Down Botnets
description: Microsoft employees, accompanied by United States marshals, raided two office buildings in Pennsylvania and Illinois on Friday, aiming to disrupt one of the most pernicious forms of online crime today: botnets, or groups of computers that help harvest bank account passwords and other personal information from millions of other computers.

title: The Hummingbird on West 81st Street
description: New Yorkers werent the only ones who enjoyed the mild winter this year. Thanks to the warm temperatures and absent flurries, a Rufous hummingbird called the American Museum of Natural History home, to the delight of museumgoers and staff members alike.

description: More Americans continue to disapprove of the federal health care legislation than support it, with a deep partisan divide underscoring their views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Survey Suggests Domestic Demand Is Rising in Germany
description: FRANKFURT  Germanys famously thrifty consumers may finally be more willing to spend, according to data released Monday, raising the prospect that domestic demand could take the place of flagging exports and help pull the rest of Europe out of recession.

title: Bernanke Says Faster Growth Is Needed to Bolster Job Market
description: WASHINGTON  In a speech that sought by turns to deflate optimism and pessimism about the labor market, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Monday that the Feds efforts to stimulate growth were gradually reducing unemployment, but that the scale and duration of the problem could leave lasting scars on the economy.

title: Britain Fines Coutts Over Rules Against Money Laundering
description: LONDON  British regulators on Monday fined the private bank Coutts 8.75 million ($13.9 million) over failing to follow standards intended to fight money laundering.

title: Afghan in Army Uniform Kills 2 NATO Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A man wearing an Afghan military uniform turned his weapon on British soldiers in southern Helmand Province on Monday, killing two of them before being shot to death himself, officials said, in what appeared to be the latest in a disturbing string of retaliatory attacks against Western forces in Afghanistan.

title: An Inventor of Russian Democracy
description: MOSCOW  I wanted to write her story for a long time. To be precise, I wanted to write this story: She was Vladimir Putins oldest enemy, and she lived to see his demise.

title: Mike Daisey Apologizes for Falsehoods in Monologue About Apple
description: After several days at the center of a storm of controversy and often heated debate about the boundaries between journalism and theater, the performer Mike Daisey has offered an apology for the exaggerations and falsehoods in his show The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, writing on his blog that he had failed to honor the contract Id established with my audiences over many years and many shows.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Hunger Games Changes the Rules, and How News of Trayvon Martin Spread
description: The Hunger Games took in $155 million over the weekend, a huge total that broke new ground in box office results, Brooks Barnes reported. First, it was the largest weekend for a spring release, demonstrating that blockbusters dont have to open in the summer; also, with the end of the Harry Potter series, and the coming finale of the Twilight series, it positions Hunger Games as the next popular movie franchise.

title: Remembering DiMaggio as More Than Just a Ballplayer
description: There was an exquisite side-by-side placement of two obituaries in this newspaper just before the weekend, one of Murray Lender and the other of Samuel Glazer. Mr. Lender, who was 81, made bagels, lots of them. Mr. Glazer, 89, was a creator of Mr. Coffee, once the hottest thing in coffee since Juan Valdez.

title: Jimmy Kimmel to Host Emmys Telecast
description: The Emmy Awards, to be televised on ABC in September, will be hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, the networks late-night comedian. ABC announced the booking on Monday morning, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kimmel has never hosted the Emmys before.

title: Congress Keeps Its Focus on Jobs
description: The House is expected this week to give the final nod to a bipartisan jobs bill as Congressional attempts to encourage employment continue in this election year.

title: Permira Said to Be Considering Sale of Frozen Food Company
description: LONDON  The European private equity firm Permira is exploring a sale of the Iglo Group, a frozen food company, for as much as 3 billion euros ($4 billion), according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Image of the Day: March 26
Creepy Cronyism
description: Just a small note about todays column: doing the research, I found myself feeling as if I had turned over a rock and found a lot of creepy-crawly things underneath. This is really upsetting stuff.

title: On Our Radar: The State of the Planet
description: Some 2,500 experts gather in London for a three-day conference on the state of the planet and on how global sustainability might be assured. Some 150 public events are planned around the world in tandem with the forum, called Planet Under Pressure. [Dot Earth]

title: Supreme Thoughts
description: I havent been weighing in on the ACA hearing at the Supreme Court; Im not a lawyer, and while most legal experts seem to think that the case for striking the law down is very weak, these days everything is political.

title: Updates on the Supreme Court Hearings on the Health Care Law
description: On Monday, The Lede followed the first of three days of Supreme Court hearings on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul law. As our colleague Michael Shear explains, during the hearings, reporters will not be allowed to file from the chamber. Updates below mix breaking news alerts from journalists who leave the courtroom with reports from our colleagues in Washington on demonstrations outside the court and reactions from scholars, advocates and experts.

title: Leading Off: Bluegrass Blues
description: Kentucky is the greatest team in college basketball. Maybe ever. John Calipari is a great coach, an incredibly smart hire by the Wildcats despite all those niggling N.C.A.A. investigations and vacated Final Fours. That his players hang around campus only slightly longer than the average grocery store visit, this is unimportant. See how fired up the faithful are? This is Kentucky. Anything less is unthinkable.

title: Tibetan in Delhi Sets Self Alight to Protest Chinese Leaders Visit
description: A protest march in New Delhi took a dramatic turn after a Tibetan exile self-immolated Monday afternoon.

title: Profile in Style | Tom Delavan
description: The New York designer is known for effortless-looking rooms in which comfy upholstered pieces cohabitate happily with classical 18th- and 19th-century furniture and art and design from the 1960s and 70s. For Delavan, who is the creative director of the online shopping site Gilt Home and the former editor-at-large of Domino magazine, its important that a house reflects the history of its inhabitants. His own home  an Anglo-Italianate town house in downtown Manhattan  showcases his aesthetic roots (I grew up in Connecticut in the 70s, with that WASPy Ice Storm sort of dcor, he says) and contains works by his favorite artists and furniture designers (Joe Colombo and Vico Magistretti, to name two). Most precious, though, are pieces made by his friends  a vase by Hugo Guinness, a box by John Derian. These are the things that make a house a home. More

title: The Last, Lush Hours of Bills Gay Nineties
description: Bills Gay Nineties Restaurant and Piano Bar did not go into that good night with a bang, or a whimper, but with a proclamation. Posted above the heritage bar of the 88-year-old watering hole  which shut its doors for good at 57 East 54th Street after 3 a.m. on Sunday  was a mayoral proclamation declaring Saturday Bills Gay Nineties Day.

title: Microphone Picks Up Obamas Private Exchange With Medvedev
description: A live microphone caught a private moment of candor by President Obama on Monday as he told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, during a discussion of the contentious issue of missile defense, that after my election I have more flexibility.

title: Tebow Meets the Press
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Striking a hopeful tone about his whirlwind arrival, Tim Tebow formally began his career as the Jets backup quarterback on Monday, saying he looked forward to joining the at-times dysfunctional team and believed he would mesh with the starter Mark Sanchez.

title: Parkour Traceurs, Take Your Mark
description: My latest Global Athlete column focuses on Ryan Doyle, one of the worlds most prominent practitioners of the sport of parkour, who can be seen here in action in Santorini. Also known as free running or street tumbling, parkour is basically a form of outdoor gymnastics that originated in France and has become a global phenomenon over the past decade.

description: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

title: Breaking Down the N.B.A.s Transition Specialists
description: There is no greater fuel for an offense than the live-ball turnover. By its very nature, it stilts the orientation of opposing defenses before they can be properly established; switches are forced, driving lanes open, and the offense is positioned to exploit an opponent in flux.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Nathaniel Rich on New Orleanss Changing Landscape
description: Nathaniel Rich wrote this weeks cover story on the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans. He is the author of The Mayors Tongue; his second novel will be published next year by Farrar, Straus & Giroux. His last article for the magazine was about the annual Turkey-Lurkey Bowl in Central Park.

title: For Schoolyard Gardens, a Global Network
description: Its hard to find fresh produce in San Franciscos Hunters Point district, classified as an urban food desert by the Department of Agriculture because of a lack of supermarkets and an abundance of toxic soil. Many of the neighborhoods 34,000 residents live below the poverty line, a legacy of separation from the rest of the city and the areas history as a former naval shipyard where radiological research and ordnance testing were carried out.

title: Nokias Lumia 900 Gets a Price and Release Date
description: The moment of truth has come for Microsoft and Nokia. On April 8, they will release the new Windows phone, the Lumia 900, at a bold $100 price tag for its high-end features. The question is: Will Americans be tempted by this phone, which runs Microsofts new mobile operating system, Windows Phone 7, and choose it over the wildly popular Apple iPhone and phones using Googles Android operating system?

title: Knicks Defeat Milwaukee, but Mounting Injuries Raise Concerns

title: A 600-Horsepower Dodge Dart, Coming to a 70-Foot Gap Jump Near You
description: On Monday, Dodge announced that its recently introduced Dart compact sedan would compete in the Global RallyCross Championship. The race format, which began as an X-Games demonstration and became a full-fledged series last year, combines European-style rallycross with X-Games-inspired stunts. The closed-circuit tracks where the events take place include dirt, asphalt and a 70-foot gap jump.

description: Fifty Shades of Grey, the erotic novel that went from X-rated underground sensation to mainstream literary phenomenon, is poised to become a Hollywood movie.

title: Flash-Sales Web Site Is a New Outlet for Madonnas Album
description: Fab.com, a fast-growing flash-sales Web site that specializes in art and design, has joined iTunes and Amazon in selling music online, and its first artist, fittingly, has ties to high fashion: Madonna.

title: Indias Top Army Official Alleges Corruption in Deals
description: The Indian Armys top official has alleged that he was offered a bribe by a lobbyist selling vehicles to the military, raising new questions about how defense contracts are handled by India, the  worlds top arms buyer.

title: Progress Toward a  Single Gambling Commission for New York
description: ALBANY  As the state moves toward legalizing full-scale casinos, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers have agreed to overhaul the regulation of gambling, concentrating power in a panel that would be largely controlled by the governor.

title: In Pakistan, Hindus Say Womans Conversion to Islam Was Coerced
description: In the predawn darkness on Feb. 24, Rinkel Kumari, a 19-year-old student from a Hindu family, disappeared from her home in Mirpur Mathelo, a small village off a busy highway in Sindh Province, Declan Walsh writes in The New York Times. Hours later, she resurfaced 12 miles away, at the home of a prominent Muslim cleric who phoned her parents with news that distressed them: Their daughter wished to convert to Islam, he said.

title: Gunmans Account of Beating by Teenager Is Detailed
description: SANFORD, Fla.  In an account given to the Sanford police that was passed on to the state attorneys office, George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who shot 17-year-old Trayvon Martin on Feb. 26, said that Trayvon had punched him and then repeatedly slammed his head into the sidewalk in the moments leading up to the shooting.

title: Hype at The Wall Street Journal
description: For a minute there, it sure looked like The Wall Street Journal had itself quite the little scoop. Late Friday afternoon, the paper moved a story claiming that former MF Global CEO Jon Corzine gave specific instructions to an MF Global employee in Chicago to move $200 million from a segregated customer account just days before the firms collapse. As Ive noted before, taking money from a segregated customer account is the sin of sins for anyone in the brokerage business, and brokerage executives who do so knowingly are committing a crime and should go to jail. As Ive also noted, Corzine has been emphatic in saying that he had no knowledge that segregated customer accounts had been raided in those final, chaotic dayswhich, if true, would mean that he could not be charged with any crime. Thus, the Journals story was incendiaryperhaps even the smoking gun prosecutors have been looking for.

title: Introspection for a Pop Star: Just Remember Her Name
description: Im gonna be O.K./I dont care what people say, Madonna sings on her new album, MDNA. That may be the least necessary assurance in pop-music history.

title: Its Never Quiet on the Newt Front
description: As the inevitable Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, gets closer and closer to becoming the actual nominee, Newt Gingrich is surely, but very slowly, dropping out of public view. Soon hell go back to sitting on the front porch of the right-wing, shaking his fist at passing ideas. Hell go back, in other words, to the post hes occupied since he was drummed out of the House Speakers job in 1998.

title: Models Based on Fundamentals Have Failed at Predicting Presidential Elections
description: The 1988 presidential election was a victory for political science. Michael Dukakis had led George Bush in the polls for much of the spring and summer. But Mr. Bush had some fundamental advantages  the economy was sound, and he was the vice president to a popular incumbent, Ronald Reagan. As the fall came, Mr. Dukakiss numbers wilted, and Mr. Bush captured a decisive victory, winning 426 electoral votes and taking the popular vote by about nine percentage points.

title: Julie Otsuka Wins PEN/Faulkner Award
description: 2:49 p.m. | Updated Julie Otsuka is the winner of the 2012 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for her novel The Buddha in the Attic (Alfred A. Knopf), the directors of the award announced on Monday. The book, which traces the lives of six Japanese mail-order brides who sail to San Francisco in the early 20th century, was chosen from more than 350 novels and short-story collections, all by American authors and all published in 2011.

title: Checking a Bank Balance on Your Phone, No Log-In Needed
description: For a remote island nation, New Zealand produces some cool stuff (The director of Lord of the Rings, Peter Jackson, for instance).

description: Mad Men rode a flood of publicity  and praise from critics overcome with longing for the series after an extended absence  to reach its largest audience on Sunday night.

description: The first time Jillian Serpa tried to learn to drive, the family car wound up straddling a creek next to her home in Ringwood, N.J.

description: Bert Sugar, boxings human encyclopedia, a prolific writer and editor and a flamboyant and ubiquitous presence in the world of the ring, died on Sunday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Ral Castro Greets Pope Benedict at Start of Closely Watched Visit
description: SANTIAGO DE CUBA  Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Cuba on Monday, declaring himself a pilgrim of charity and urging the island to move toward greater openness, freedom and religious devotion.

title: France Says It Will Bar Some Clerics From a Conference
description: PARIS  France will bar certain Muslim clerics who are considered too radical from entering the country for a conference next month, President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Monday.

title: Securing an Apartment With Help From a Love Letter
description: David Motta and Michele Pagnotta met on 87th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues six years ago while they were out walking their dogs, Jake and Pancho. Slowly, after many walks, they started dating. A few years later, they were married.

title: Digital Notes: After Steep Declines, Music Sales in 2011 Held Steady
description: Two of the music industrys top trade groups on Monday released detailed sales reports for 2011, and for the most part they tell a familiar story. After many years of steep declines, overall music sales are starting to level off in many parts of the world, or at least not fall quite so hard. In the fine print the reports point to rapid expansion of digital services around the world.

title: Wright Plays Four Innings, and Says He Feels Good
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Playing in his first spring training game, Mets third baseman David Wright got in a good mixture of action at the plate, on the base paths and in the field. Wright played through two at-bats, and it was enough to get in a variety of situational baseball.

title: Johnny Hallyday to Perform in New York
description: The French rock star Johnny Hallyday will perform a concert at the Beacon Theater in October, and it will be one of only a few New York appearances of his 50-year career. Heavily influenced by Elvis Presley, Mr. Hallyday is famous in France as one of that countrys best rock n roll singers, known for his deep, raspy voice, his energetic shows and his wild lifestyle. (He has 21 platinum albums.)

title: Female Condom Giveaway Is Expensive, but Still Cost-Effective, Report Says
description: An experiment in giving away free female condoms in the nations capital is a highly productive use of public health investment, according to a new study by scientists at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

title: Others in the I.P.O. Hall of Shame
description: After the horrible, ruinous Murphys Law-abiding fiasco that was the initial public stock offering of BATS Global Markets, many are wondering if the companys glitch-filled offering was the biggest I.P.O. botch in history.

title: Spiegelworld Tent to Go Up in Midtown in May
description: After previously pitching its lavishly decorated tent at the South Street Seaport, the traveling troupe Spiegelworld will be moving uptown for a 15-week summer engagement with a new work, Empire. The show will display Spiegelworlds circus, cabaret and burlesque acts in a 440-seat tent, which will be erected on West 45th Street, near Eighth Avenue. Previews are set to begin May 22, with opening night scheduled for May 31. Tickets can be purchased at (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com.

title: A Smaller Route to Solar Success
description: There are at least a dozen major ways to turn sunlight into electricity, but one of the more interesting is using a field of mirrors to focus the suns energy on a power tower where the heat is captured and used later to spin a turbine and turn a generator. As I have previously written, two companies are now planning to build such systems in the desert Southwest with hardware that will store the heat for a rainy day or for the period right after sunset when power demand is still high.

title: BMW Recalls Nearly 1.3 Million Vehicles Worldwide for Battery-Cable Flaw
description: 4:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Galvanized by a Court Case
description: The Supreme Court began hearings on the 2010 health care overhaul law on Monday, attracting crowds of demonstrators.

title: Jury in Officers Trial Is at an Impasse Over Rape Charges
description: The jury deliberating the charges against a police officer accused of raping a woman at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan last August indicated on Monday that it had reached a verdict on several of the charges, but was stuck on others.

title: Justices Send Back Gene Case
description: The Supreme Court on Monday ordered an appeals court to reconsider its decision to uphold patents held by Myriad Genetics on two genes associated with a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer.

title: Drilling Down: What Small Businesses Should Know About Pinterest
description: In this weeks Dashboard, we quoted from a guide to using Pinterest prepared by Jay Ehret, a marketing specialist. As you may have heard, Pinterest is a fast-growing new Web site where users can create sites of photos pinned from other parts of the Web. We went back to Mr. Ehret with a few questions about how small businesses can use Pinterest.

title: Times in Food Fight Over Cookbook Ghostwriter Story
description: I am not a foodie, to be candid. Food and I have a transactional relationship. I eat it but I dont contemplate it.

title: Annies Lifts Price Range of I.P.O.
description: Annies Inc. apparently expects to reap a bounty in its initial public offering: The pasta maker has raised the price range for the sale, according to an amended prospectus filed on Monday. The company now expects to price its shares between $16 and $18, up from a previous range of $14 to $16.

title: Does Helping a Student Add to My Value?
Driving With Attention Deficit Disorder
description: Learning to drive can be a difficult task for teenagers. Distractions on the road are abundant, and driving is one of the most dangerous activities for adolescents.

title: For Li Na, a Focus on the Olympics
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  After becoming the first Asian woman to win a Grand Slam singles title at the 2011 French Open, Li Na struggled to put together wins for the rest of the season. She began her 2012 season strongly, winning three matches in the Hopman Cup and making the finals in Sydney. But she then suffered a devastating loss at the Australian Open to Kim Clijsters, in which she failed to convert on four match points, and walked out of her postmatch news conference in tears.

title: Profiting From Medicine (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring Mariana Trench (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gastrointestinal Infections (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Invading Your Privacy
description: Its a security-hawk clich that if youve done nothing wrong, then you have nothing to fear from ever-more aggressive surveillance tactics. When the National Security Agency was caught eavesdropping without a warrant on international communications, the Bush administration assured critics that if the agents scraped up information on innocent Americans, they would delete it. When the F.B.I. announced its Next Generation Identification databasethe worlds biggest biometric archiveThomas E. Bush, the FBI assistant director in 2007,  told the BBC that  what we deal with is bad guys  suspected terrorists and criminals, and that for everyone else it was a non-issue.

title: Seeing Bogeymen in the Fog Around Brain Death
description: Like creatures battling undersea, pro-life and right-to-die forces are locked in mortal but only intermittently visible combat. The last prominent battle ended almost seven years ago, after the death of Terri Schiavo, the Florida woman with brain damage whose feeding tube was removed by court order in the spring of 2005. Since then, all has been quiet on the surface, belying the continuing turmoil in hospitals and courtrooms over what, exactly, marks the end of life.

title: Snowe Praises Brown for His Work on Womens Issues
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts appeared alongside a fellow moderate Republican, Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, on Monday to kick off a Women for Brown committee, the latest step in his concerted effort to appeal to female voters in his campaign for re-election.

title: Hawk Cam: A Rat in the Nest
description: A rat in the nest high above Washington Square Park, as captured by the City Room Hawk Cam.

title: High Line May Mix Past With Koonss Vision
description: Visitors to the High Line, the elevated park on a formerly derelict rail line, might someday be greeted by a vision even more improbable than the park itself, which has become one of Manhattans top tourist draws: A massive locomotive dangling from a crane.

title: Trayvon Martin and the Talk Black Parents Have With Their Teenage Sons
description: Late last week, a colleague asked me if there would be a Motherlode post about the talk black parents have with their sons after the shooting of Trayvon Martin, who was killed last month in Sanford, Fla., while walking from a convenience store to the home of his fathers girlfriend.

title: Sometimes All the Rooms Look the Same
description: BECAUSE I travel so much for Kiwi Collection I have learned not to bring a lot of clothing and other things with me. I can make do with a carry-on bag, even if Im gone for more than a week or so. My itinerary is such that I jump around either from country to country or to different locations within the same country to review hotels. If my checked bag got lost, no one would ever find me, and I really dont have time to go buy new clothes if my bag got lost.

title: Arguing That Health Mandate Is Not a Tax, Except When It Is
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout the two-year history of the health care litigation, judges have mocked the Obama administrations have-your-cake approach to the central question debated at the Supreme Court on Monday: whether the constitutional challenge is even ripe for judicial review before the law takes full effect in 2014. During the opening 90 minutes of oral argument, the justices found that they too could not resist.

title: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Tests Better Than Statin
description: An experimental drug that works in a novel way to lower cholesterol proved even more effective than statins and had few undesirable side effects, newly released data shows.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, India, Myanmar and South Korea.

title: Noise Pollution Is Changing Forests
description: A few years ago, researchers discovered that in areas polluted by human-made noise, a species of hummingbird seemed to increase in population, while a jay species seemed to decrease.

title: Victims of Tighter Tipping
description: Tipping for hotel concierges, bellhops and housekeepers moves up and down with the economy, but lately it has also been affected by changes in corporate, airline and hotel policies.

title: Gentleman Who Finds Terrorism Amusing
description: An Evelyn Waugh-inspired satire that uses Sept. 11 at its end for a kicker? A comic novel about terrorism featuring a misanthropic hero striving to take credit for deadly bombings around the world? This is the off-putting premise of Lionel Shrivers very unfunny new novel, The New Republic.

title: The Get | Ishvara Sandals
description: In Hindu philosophy, ishvara is the Sanskrit word for lord or god. There must be soul in what you do, says Jose Marco, the designer of the sandal brand that bears the name. Whatever it may be  cooking, caring for a plant, choosing a beautiful piece of leather to make sandals  soul is needed. Having designed and sold Ishvaras classic tanned-leather Mediterranean sandals from a tiny beach storefront in Formentera, Spain (the brand is based in Ibiza), since 1982, Marco is finally bringing his casual, colorful flats to the states. These python albarcas, modeled after ones commonly worn by fishermen in the Balearic Islands, are a standout. Sole (or should I say soul) searching has never been easier.

title: Michaels Stores Prepares for an I.P.O.
description: Michaels Stores, the arts and crafts retailer owned by the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital, plans to file to go public as soon as next week, according to people briefed on the matter. The initial public offering could be one of the biggest of the year.

title: Ask About A.D.H.D., Aspergers and Driving
description: Learning to drive is tough for many teenagers, but tougher for those with an attention disorder or learning disability  and for their parents. In todays Science Times, Learning to Drive With A.D.H.D., I examine the situation for young people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. But learning to drive can also be challenge for those with Asperger syndrome or other forms of autism.

title: Ballet Fans Truly Know How to Feel the Moves
description: Ballet lovers may truly feel that they are dancing when they watch a performance, researchers have found after measuring the brain activity of experienced spectators.

title: Death Penalty Death Watch: Angela Johnson
description: Until last week, Angela Johnson was one of only two women on federal death row  for the 1993 murders of five people, including two children.

title: Spring Veal Stew
description: Mark Bittman prepares a veal stew loaded with spring vegetables.

title: The Chocolate Diet?
description: Chocolate may not be as hazardous to your waistline as you think  at least in moderation.

title: City Will Add Seats to Schools, but Still Fall Short of Demand
FX Landed Louis C.K. With Creative Freedom and by Wiring $200,000
description: Rather than invest millions of dollars in its original comedies, the basic cable channel FX traffics in a different, rarer currency: creative freedom. We take small bets economically, but big bets creatively, said John Landgraf, president and general manager of FX Networks.

title: The Minimalist: Spring Veal Stew
description: I dont cook veal very often, but this dish is one of my favorites. Its a wonderful springtime stew loaded with spring onions or shallots, fresh tarragon and peas (over the years, Ive increased the amount of vegetables and decreased the amount of veal). Much of the flavor comes from browning the veal cubes, but because Im not a fastidious cook in the least, I brown the veal extremely well on just one side, then add the onions and shallots. In my experience, there will be more than enough crusty, meaty bits to scrape off the bottom of the pan.

title: In Pakistan, No Quick End to Islam Conversion Case
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hopes for the rapid resolution of a controversy over the conversion of a Hindu woman to Islam that has seized the Pakistani public were dashed on Monday, when the Supreme Court declined to decide the matter for at least three more weeks.

title: At Bottom of Pacific, Director Sees Dark Frontier
description: No sea monsters. No strange life. No fish. Just amphipods  tiny shrimplike creatures swimming across a featureless plane of ooze that stretched off into the primal darkness.

title: Decades-Old Housing Emergency Continues, and So Does Rent Regulation
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill on Monday that extended the citys participation in rent regulation for another three years by redeclaring a state of housing emergency, even as a challenge to rent regulation laws looms in the United States Supreme Court.

title: The Real Estate Mogul as an Artist
description: What to do when youve been accused, by various publications and Web sites, of all manner of misbehavior: money laundering, blowing $5 million on your daughters wedding and massacring mustangs to use their skins for upholstery?

title: MF Global C.F.O. Says He Was Not Involved in Customer Money
description: MF Globals current chief financial officer, Henri J. Steenkamp, is to appear again before Congress on Wednesday in the latest hearing to examine the collapse of the brokerage firm.

title: Frank E-Mails Reveal Negotiations at Art Gallery
description: Of the adjectives often used to describe the art market  complex, unregulated and opaque  the last has always been truest. Glimpses into negotiations between high-end galleries and collectors are rare. But a lawsuit in state court in Manhattan is providing a view into the dealings of not just any gallery, but the worlds most successful one, owned by Larry Gagosian.

title: German Leader Agrees to More Bailout Money for Euro Zone Nations
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union took a big step on Monday toward building a financial firewall strong enough to prevent the spread of fiscal contagion to major economies like Spain. The move came after Germany dropped its opposition to bringing the Continents total bailout capacity to more than 690 billion euros ( $916 billion).

title: It Could Be a Garden Party, Even the Final One
description: The layers of information come fast and furious in David Neumanns work. And what finally arrives is never straightforward; the messages are scrambled, sometimes hopelessly so.

title: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?
description: More than 40 million American adults already take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease. Now many more are weighing the pros and cons of daily aspirin use in light of new studies finding that it also may reduce the risk of many cancers and stop the spread of tumors.

title: A Piano Virtuoso Balanced and Buoyant
description: There are some composers, like Chopin, whose works almost all pianists perform publicly during their careers. Many soloists, on the other hand, never play Bach in recital. Murray Perahia, who has made a specialty of Bach since the 1990s, is one of the most rewarding interpreters both live and on disc.

title: Added to a Program, the Sound of Opportunity Taken
description: A little more than midway through a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening the refined tenor Michael Schade went off script to reflect on words a distinguished friend, the conductor Nikolaus Harnoncourt, once shared with him: Out of the greatest impossibilities rise the greatest possibilities.

title: Meditations on a Boroughs History, Through Booms and Bad Times
description: Its particularly meaningful to see so many of you here tonight in light of the financial panic that has made all of our lives so terribly difficult, the conductor Alan Pierson said as he welcomed audience members to a Brooklyn Philharmonic concert presented at Roulette in downtown Brooklyn on Saturday evening.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: iPad Heat Test and Windows Phone Updates
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Prevention: Easy Way to Head Off Altitude Sickness
description: A small randomized trial has found that acute mountain sickness  the headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea and vomiting that can occur at altitudes above 8,000 feet  can effectively be prevented with a common and inexpensive over-the-counter medicine: ibuprofen, sold as Advil and other brands.

title: Support in U.S. for Afghan War Drops Sharply, Poll Finds
description: WASHINGTON  After a series of violent episodes and setbacks, support for the war in Afghanistan has dropped sharply among both Republicans and Democrats, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Bausch & Lomb to Buy ISTA Pharmaceuticals for $500 Million
description: Bausch & Lomb, the eye care company, agreed on Monday to acquire the eye drug maker ISTA Pharmaceuticals for about $500 million.

title: Another Passion Rises to Prominence This Season
description: Of Bachs two surviving Passions, the St. Matthew is the more widely revered and usually the more often performed. In recent decades, especially, the St. John has been deemed problematic, and undoubtedly avoided by some, for its texts many references to the Jews as those clamoring for Jesus death (references stemming from Luthers translation of Johns Gospel).

title: A Man Caught Up in Bo Xilais Crackdown
description: Fan Qihang was arrested during one of Bo Xilais crackdowns in 2009. His lawyer made this video public, hoping to dissuade the court from the death sentence.

title: Risks: Older Kidneys Work Fine for Transplants
description: For most transplant patients, a kidney received from a donor as old as 64 is just as likely to be successful as one from a younger person, according to a new analysis.

title: A Composer and Virtuoso Dresses Up the Mandolin
description: Is the mandolin about to have its moment as a classical solo instrument? Its repertory back catalog is slim  a couple of Vivaldi concertos and some early Beethoven, most notably, as well as parts in Mahlers Seventh Symphony and Das Lied von der Erde  but its contemporary repertory is colorful and growing.

title: Results of The New York Times/CBS News Poll
description: Poll finds support dropping for the Health Care law and the war in Afghanistan.

description: Times reporters offer analysis of the arguments before the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law.

description: The rivalry between Kentucky and Louisville will be dissected and analyzed this week, but there is one thing that the two fan bases have in common: an appreciation of horse racing.

title: A Czanne Resurfaces, Shedding Light on a Series
description: For nearly six decades a Czanne watercolor depicting Paulin Paulet, a gardener on the artists family estate near Aix-en-Provence, was familiar to scholars only as a black-and-white photograph. No one knew if the actual work, a study for Czannes celebrated Card Players paintings, still existed and, if it did, who owned it.

title: Exploring Our Own Alien World

title: Americans on the 2010 Health Care Law
description: Two years after President Obamas overhaul of the health care system was signed into law, Americans are still disapproving.

title: The Catholic Vote
description: How Catholics have voted in general elections and in this years primaries.

title: Tasty Burgers, Without the Meat
description: It was just a coincidence that I had decided to broaden my repertory of vegetarian burgers for this weeks column and was busily testing recipes on the same day that a new Harvard School of Public Health study linking red meat consumption and early death was released. Then there was the news about pink slime in ground beef used in school lunches. The timing couldnt have been better.

title: LArc-en-Ciel at Madison Square Garden
description: The performed with all the trappings of an arena-rock band thats 20 years into a million-selling career.

description: RALEIGH, N.C.  A replay of last years N.C.A.A. womens tournament championship game was on television Monday morning as Notre Dames players waited in their hotel rooms to leave for practice.

title: Attention deficit on the road; a human ally for the worlds sharks; and 200 years of fossils, fish, flamingos and more.
description: Attention deficit on the road; a human ally for the worlds sharks; and 200 years of fossils, fish, flamingos and more.

title: Step to the Center
description: On May 23-24, 1865, the victorious Union armies marched through Washington. The columns of troops stretched back 25 miles. They marched as a single mass, clad in blue, their bayonets pointing skyward.

title: As Health Law Is Contested, Developing a Plan B
description: State officials and insurance executives are devising possible alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance, even as the Supreme Court hears arguments about the constitutionality of the mandate.

title: Tebow Can Push Sanchez, but Where?
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

title: Chief of Canadian Firm Steps Down After Inquiry
description: OTTAWA  The chief executive of SNC-Lavalin, a major Canadian engineering and construction firm that had extensive business operations in Libya, left the company on Monday after the release of a report indicating that he had authorized 56 million Canadian dollars in improperly documented payments to unidentified agents, the companys chairman said Monday.

title: Across Africa, Steady Steps Toward Democracy
description: DAKAR, Senegal  After 50 years of independence, the path to democracy does not follow an obvious, straight line in this region, just as it did not in the West  the model for most citizens here  where it was centuries in the making.

title: A Farewell to Newt
description: Its not easy letting him go. Not easy at all. Sort of like swearing off bedtime Ben & Jerrys: theres valor and the promise of self-improvement in the sacrifice, but also the sad awareness that the world just got a little less naughty. A little less fun.

title: Citing Chapter and Verse: Which Scripture Is the Right One?
description: The topic this past Sunday on the show Up w/ Chris Hayes (MSNBC) was the statistical correlation between deniers of global warming and religious believers. Participants included such luminaries as Richard Dawkins, author of The God Delusion, and Steven Pinker, author of The Better Angels of Our Nature, a new book arguing that the world has gotten less violent as the tide of fundamentalist faith has receded and given way to the dictates of reason. It was no surprise that the panels default position, stated almost explicitly by Susan Jacoby, was that religion clouds the mind of those who, if they were only sufficiently educated, would arrive at the conclusion supported by the overwhelming preponderance of scientific evidence and reject the blind adherence to revealed or ecclesiastical authority that characterizes religious belief.

title: Judged a Failure by the Data, a School Succeeds Where It Counts
description: Aniah McAllister was a lost girl of New York, one of tens of thousands of children edging toward an adulthood drained of hope.

title: Financing for M.T.A. Projects Is Shored Up
description: New York State lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have reached an agreement to finance the remaining three years of the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys five-year capital plan, preserving some of the regions largest transportation projects, transportation officials said Monday.

title: Sticking to Business as Others Celebrate Her Career
description: DES MOINES

title: Private Jets, Buffett and Taxes
description: Get this: Uncle Sam is suing Warren Buffetts company over taxes. Yes, taxes.

title: Priscilla Buckley, Editor at National Review, Dies at 90
description: Priscilla L. Buckley, a journalist who was the longtime managing editor of National Review, the conservative magazine founded by her brother William F. Buckley Jr., died on Sunday at her home in Sharon, Conn. She was 90.

title: Getting to the Merits
description: Before ruling on whether Congress has power to require Americans to obtain health insurance, the Supreme Court must decide whether it is barred from taking up that question by the federal Anti-Injunction Act, which prohibits courts from hearing lawsuits that seek to block a tax before the tax is actually paid.

title: Rangel and His Campaign to Pay $23,000 Fine Over Misuse of Rent Law
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Charles B. Rangel and his campaign have agreed to pay a civil fine of $23,000 stemming from his use of a rent-stabilized apartment as a campaign office, according to Federal Election Commission records.

title: Boycott Plan at Food Co-op Is Opposed by City Officials
description: Many of New York Citys leading politicians said Monday that they opposed a boycott of Israeli products by the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn, speaking out on the day before the market is expected to hold an initial vote on the proposal.

title: MF Globals Top Lawyer Will Break Her Silence
description: MF Globals top lawyer is expected to break her five-month silence on Wednesday to tell Congress that she was unaware of a gaping shortfall in customer money until hours before the brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 26, 2012

title: In a Dozen Plans, Ideas for Restoring the Thrill to a Westchester Amusement Park
description: RYE, N.Y.  Would Playland still be Playland without rides?

title: A Continent Apart, Two Quarterbacks Vow They Will Work Together
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Missing from the spectacle at Jets headquarters Monday was a Goodyear blimp circling overhead, transmitting panoramic images of this woodsy suburban pocket that was overtaken by something no organization had ever done. The wide-angle views could have captured the scope  lines of cars at the security booth seeking entry; drive-through credential stations; satellite truck after satellite truck, a dozen in all  without intruding into the event itself.

title: Microphone Catches a Candid Obama
description: President Obama found his private moment of political candor caught by a live microphone on Monday as he told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia that he would have more flexibility to negotiate on the delicate issue of missile defense after the November election, which Mr. Obama apparently feels confident he will win.

title: A Picture of Language
description: The curious art of diagramming sentences was invented 165 years ago by S.W. Clark, a schoolmaster in Homer, N.Y. [1] His book, published in 1847, was called A Practical Grammar: In which Words, Phrases, and Sentences Are Classified According to Their Offices and Their Various Relations to One Another. His goal was to simplify the teaching of English grammar. It was more than 300 pages long, contained information on such things as unipersonal verbs and rhetorico-grammatical figures, and provided a long section on Prosody, which he defined as that part of the Science of Language which treats of utterance.

title: Governments Not Dead Yet
description: Washington

title: Enabling Egypts Military Rulers
description: The United States has built its relationship with Egypt around the Army, which it has supported with more than $39 billion in military aid over the last three decades. Egypts year-old, pro-democracy revolution gave Washington a chance  and a reason  to alter that relationship to support civil society. The Obama administration made a serious error in choosing not to do so. Even worse, the purpose was largely to protect American arms manufacturers who produce the weapons sent to Egypt.

title: Private Schools Mine Parents Data, and Wallets
description: Shortly after she enrolled her 3-year-old son in a prestigious, $21,000-a-year Upper East Side preschool, Rachael Combe, an editor at Elle, received an invitation from the head of the school to come by for a visit. She assumed the meeting was to discuss how her son was adapting to the schools curriculum.

title: HSN Plans Event to Sell Snow White, the Merchandise
description: IN the continuing quest for ardent fans and movie ticket sales, studios are expanding their marketing arsenal to appeal to home shoppers, a largely female audience of proven purchasers.

title: An Incomplete DNA Deal
description: A major expansion of New York States DNA database signed into law last week by Gov. Andrew Cuomo will enhance the ability of law enforcement to convict the guilty and, in some cases, exonerate the innocent. But, disappointingly, the measure still leaves New York State without certain protections to avoid wrongful convictions.

title: Symantec Dissolves a Chinese Alliance
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Less than four years after Huawei Technologies and Symantec teamed up to develop computer network security products, the joint venture is being dismantled because Symantec feared the alliance with the Chinese company would prevent it from obtaining United States government classified information about cyberthreats.

title: Survey Gives Glimpse Into Minds of Recent Veterans
description: The 2012 edition of Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of Americas annual survey of its members came out on Monday. The largest such survey by the group to date, its results provide some interesting insights into whats on the minds of recent veterans today.

title: Vindication for Challenger of Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress passed legislation requiring nearly all Americans to obtain health insurance, Randy E. Barnett, a passionate libertarian who teaches law at Georgetown, argued that the bill was unconstitutional. Many of his colleagues, on both the left and the right, dismissed the idea as ridiculous  and still do.

title: Two Powers Raise Rivalry to New Heights
description: As the governor of Kentucky, John Y. Brown Jr. once revived a rivalry that now ranks among the greatest in college basketball. It is an in-state affair that started in 1913, stopped in 1922 and went dormant, save the rare chance meeting, for more than six decades.

title: Horses to the Slaughter
description: Thoroughbred racing trades on bucolic imagery and glossy beauty, but a report in The Times on Sunday documented the real pillars of its success: the casual and continual mistreatment of vulnerable, overmedicated and ultimately disposable athletes. Reporters who analyzed tens of thousands of races and combed through reports of injuries and medical tests found a culture of rampant cheating and feeble regulation, where injured and fragile horses are forced to run while drugged, to the great peril of both animals and jockeys.

title: New Ideas on Pensions: Use States
description: As growing numbers of baby boomers face retirement with inadequate savings, some state officials are considering a novel proposal to rebuild Americas ailing retirement system  having state pension funds run retirement plans for companies.

title: Crime Crackdown Adds to Scandal Surrounding Former Chinese Official
description: BEIJING  As Bo Xilai, the dismissed Chongqing party chief, becomes immersed in an ever-more tangled scandal, disturbing details are emerging about one of his best-known initiatives, a crusade against organized crime on which he built a national reputation.

title: A Grid in the Hand
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  If this puzzle doesnt convince you that its spring, no puzzle will. As soon as I spotted the ROBIN in the circled squares of Todd McClarys grid, I knew we were about to work a puzzle that was strictly for the  well, you know.

title: In Queens, Taking a Step Back From Numbered Streets
description: Forty-four years ago, Bill Sievers moved into his neo-Colonial house in Douglaston, Queens, on bucolic Poplar Street, lined with stately trees and equally stately homes. A few years later, the oak and Norwegian maple trees and the manor houses were still there, but the street was no more.

title: Cuomo and Top Legislators Near Accord on the Budget
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders were nearing a deal on Monday night on a spending plan of about $132.5 billion for New York States next fiscal year, slightly reducing overall spending while increasing financing for schools and accelerating scores of public works projects.

title: Outside the International Spotlight, but Still Something to Play For
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario  As the final seconds ticked down, the team in the familiar bleu, blanc et rouge sweaters threw down sticks and gloves and gathered in a joyous embrace, famous international players ready to lift the cup again.

title: Seeking a Softer Justice System, Closer to Home, for New Yorks Juvenile Offenders
description: The teenage boys living in a Brooklyn row house board a van every morning to go to school. When they return, they cook their own meals, do their own laundry, play video games and discuss life. They receive visits from their families each week and sometimes take field trips to the movies or to a bowling alley.

title: The Face, and Arm, for Left-Handers Everywhere
description: Left-handers are amply represented in the successful ranks of nearly every walk of life. Five of the last seven presidents have been left-handed. Albert Einstein was left-handed. So were Benjamin Franklin, W. C. Fields, Julius Caesar and Michelangelo. Sports have overflowed with left-handed stars, from Babe Ruth to John McEnroe to Larry Bird to Pel.

title: Tibetan Exile Sets Self Afire in Protest Act
description: NEW DELHI  Over the past year, nearly 30 Tibetans in remote areas of western China have set fire to themselves to draw attention to what they call Chinese government repression, but the visual images of their protests have seldom been seen by outsiders. Censorship authorities in China, which regards the immolation as a form of terrorism, have made sure of it.

title: Colorado Revisits Law That Gives Prosecutors Wide Power to Try Youths as Adults
description: DENVER  It was called the summer of violence: a rash of crime that swept through Denver in 1993 and prompted state lawmakers to pass tough legislation intended to crack down on juvenile offenders. Nearly 20 years later, Colorado is revisiting a law that gives prosecutors the power to charge youths as adults in serious crimes without first getting approval from a judge.

title: Stopping Assad, Saving Syria
Supervising Priest Goes on Trial in Abuse Case
description: The landmark trial of a senior official of the Philadelphia Archdiocese who is accused of shielding priests who sexually abused children and reassigning them to unwary parishes began on Monday with prosecutors charging that the official paid lip service to child protection and protected the church at all costs.

title: Tunisia Says Constitution Will Not Cite Islamic Law
description: CAIRO  Tunisias ruling Islamist party, Ennahda, said on Monday that the countrys post-revolution constitution would not mention Islamic law as a source of legislation, signaling a forceful break with ultraconservatives who have been demanding an Islamic state.

title: Bounty Investigation Remains Open, Goodell Says
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Monday that the league continued to investigate the possibility of bounties on teams other than the New Orleans Saints, whose coach, Sean Payton, was suspended for a year for his role in a bounty system on his team.

title: Michigan Governor Sees Hope for a Deal With Detroit
description: DETROIT  With time running out on this citys dismal finances and tensions bubbling over, Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan said Monday that he was hopeful a deal could still be worked out in the next few days to avoid appointing an outside emergency manager to run Detroit.

title: Bariatric Surgery
description: Two studies found that obese and overweight people who had an operation to modify the stomach and small intestine were more likely to have a complete remission of Type 2 diabetes than people given non-surgical treatment.

title: Late Goal Ends U.S. Bid for Place in the Olympics
description: NASHVILLE  The American players, almost to a man, sank to their knees in shock and exhaustion.

title: Corrections: March 27
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Santorum Fails to Capture Catholic Vote
description: Cathy Willauer, who is Roman Catholic and a mother of four, says that her religion is important to her and that she shares the same values as Rick Santorum.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,898 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Silencing the Guns
description: When Gabrielle Giffords tendered her resignation from the House of Representatives to Speaker John Boehner because she did not feel she could continue to serve at her current level of disability, the entire House erupted in a rare moment of bipartisan unity, supporting their brave colleague who had survived a bullet through the brain at point-blank range.

title: Ogwumike and Stanford Return to Final Four
description: FRESNO, Calif  Nnemkadi Ogwumike is taking Stanford back to the Final Four, and all Dukes zone concepts, double-team defenses and elbows to the face would not convince her otherwise.

title: Word of the Day | don
description: don \dn\ noun and verb

title: Wright and Santana Progress by Playing Without Pain
description: JUPITER, Fla.  They sat side by side in the visitors training room at Roger Dean Stadium, one with the left side of his abdomen wrapped in ice and the other with his left shoulder entwined the same way. From outside, the faint sounds of a spring training game whispered into the Mets clubhouse.

title: Queen Elizabeths Common Touch
description: Our colleague Alan Cowell in his new Page Two column writes about Queen Elizabeth II and her effort to reconnect her reign and her family to her subjects as her Diamond Jubilee year picks up steam.

title: Brazils Unique Culture Group Stays Busy Sharing the Wealth
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  All over the world cultural organizations are tightening their budgets and paring back productions. But Danilo Miranda faces a different challenge, one that makes him the envy of his peers. As the director of the leading arts financing entity in Brazil, his budget is growing by 10 percent or more annually, and he must figure out ways to spend that bounty, which amounts to $600 million a year.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/27/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/27/2012

title: New Limit Pending on Emissions
description: After months of delay, the Obama administration is about to unveil the first federal standards to explicitly limit greenhouse-gas emissions from new electric power plants  one of the chief sources of carbon dioxide emissions linked to climate change.

title: In North India, Palaces, Markets and History
description: We recently asked for your suggestions for one, two and three week trips through India, inspired by this article by Guy Trebay.

title: Two Pedigreed Players Find Theyre a World Apart
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On Field No. 1 at the Yankees minor league complex, Dante Bichette Jr. ripped a double into the right-field corner Monday. Bichette, the son of a former major league standout and the Yankees top draft pick last June, is only 19, but he has stardom projected for him.

title: From Exile to Everywhere
description: At 8 p.m. on a rainy Tuesday last month, Salman Rushdie strode into Junoon, a Flatiron district restaurant where 90 people awaited his arrival, some sipping chamomile-infused vodka cocktails, Laura M. Holson writes in The New York Times. Mr. Rushdie, the Indian-born British author, was the guest of honor at a dinner sponsored by Dom Prignon and Booktrack, the maker of an app that synchronizes music to e-books, Ms. Holson writes.

title: The Pope in Cuba
description: Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Cuba on Monday, declaring himself a pilgrim of charity and urging the island to move toward greater openness, freedom and religious devotion.

title: For Soccer Fans, Showing Support in Song
description: If you watch the Champions League quarterfinals Tuesday and Wednesday, you will hear soccer fans in their full-throated glory. Here is a look at popular chants among supporters of Tuesdays home teams.

title: Roddick Stuns Federer at Sony Ericsson Open
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  After an easy first-round win at the Sony Ericsson Open on Saturday, Andy Roddick said, I feel like something good is coming. It did not take long for his premonition to be proved right.

title: Canada: Brothel Ban Illegal, Court Says
description: An appeals court upheld a ruling striking down most Canadian laws that prevent prostitution, including a ban on brothels. While prostitution is legal in Canada, several laws effectively make it impossible for sex workers to engage in the practice without facing the prospect of arrest. The Court of Appeal for Ontario ruled that most of those laws were unconstitutional, saying that they endangered prostitutes by forcing them to work on the streets rather than in controlled circumstances indoors and prevented them from taking certain safety precautions, like hiring bodyguards. But the court did uphold laws against soliciting. The federal government is likely to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court of Canada.

title: France: Strauss-Kahn Is Charged in Connection With Prostitution Ring
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was released on bail on Monday after he was charged with involvement in a prostitution ring in Lille. The filing of the preliminary charges allows for further investigation. His lawyer, Richard Malka, has argued that Mr. Strauss-Kahn did not know that the women in question were prostitutes hired by his hosts, including for evenings in Washington and Paris, and that he did not pay them. His lawyers will also be in court on Wednesday in New York for the first hearing in a civil case brought against him by Nafissatou Diallo, a hotel housekeeper who has accused him of sexually assaulting her.

title: Winnipegs Playoff Hopes Suffer Blow
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  The Jets playoff dream was all but dashed Monday night, and their defeat will probably put another Canadian club out of Stanley Cup contention.

title: When Daycare Slips Into Night Care
description: This new bi-monthly column on India Ink will track the lives of the men and women who have flocked to Bangalore in recent years, making it one of the countrys fastest-growing, youngest metropolises. Well look at rapid changes afoot in the working, playing, thinking, eating and mating habits in Bangalore.

title: Bucks Squander Chance to Gain Ground, but Remain Threat in Playoff Race
description: The Milwaukee Bucks, the team with the most realistic chance of catching the Knicks for the eighth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, are vastly different from the Knicks, who beat them by 89-80 on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Turkey: Trial of Ex-Chief of Army Starts
description: Turkeys former military chief, Gen. Ilker Basbug, went on trial on Monday, charged with leading an illegal network that aimed to overthrow the government. He is the most senior officer to face trial in an investigation that began in 2008 and has resulted in the jailing of hundreds of suspects, including military officers, academics and government critics. The government defends the prosecution as necessary to defend Turkeys democratization process, but human rights groups have criticized legal irregularities in the case, including long imprisonments without convictions.

title: Larry Stevenson, Innovative Skateboard Designer, Is Dead at 81
description: Larry Stevenson was working as a lifeguard in Southern California in the early 1960s when he noticed surfers darting around a parking lot on crude skateboards cobbled together from planks and roller skates on days when the waves were tame. Mr. Stevenson, an avid swimmer and surfer, thought he could do better.

title: The Tortuous Path to Justice in Cambodia
description: HONG KONG  To watch the court proceedings, to hear the lawyers objections, to sit through the delays and the quibbles and the endless parsing of words, its enough to make a good number of Cambodians want to simply unshackle the prisoners and set them free. Game over.

title: News Quiz | March 27, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: Henry S. Ruth, Who Helped Lead Watergate Prosecution, Dies at 80
description: Henry S. Ruth Jr., who helped lead the criminal prosecution of Nixon administration officials involved in covering up the Watergate break-in and kept it on track when President Richard M. Nixon fired the special prosecutor Archibald Cox, died on March 16 in Tucson. He was 80.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (3), El Salvador (3)
description: United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann has made the point early and often: he believes the Olympics are an important international tournament, and he felt strongly that the United States should put its best foot forward in the upcoming London Games.

title: Strauss-Kahn Charged in Prostitution Case
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was released on bail on Monday after he was charged with involvement in a prostitution ring in Lille. The filing of the preliminary charges allows for further investigation.

title: Bosman and the Champions League: Win-Win
description: The quarterfinal first legs of the UEFA Champions League will be played this week and a new study from the University of Illinois-Chicago written by John J. Binder, an associate professor of finance, and Murray Findlay, vice president of Soccer Success in St. Charles, Ill., asserts that the Bosman ruling, which gave European players a new form of free agency, has helped transform the competition into one of the most, if not the most, compelling soccer tournaments in the world.

title: Nuclear Conference in Korea Collides With U.S. Election
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Politics, diplomats like to say, stops at the waters edge. But this week, the American presidential campaign crashed into a nuclear security summit meeting half a world away.

title: March 27, 1958 | Nikita Khrushchev Consolidates Power and Becomes Soviet Premier
description: On March 27, 1958, Nikita Khrushchev became Soviet premier in addition to First Secretary of the Communist Party. The March 28 New York Times wrote, Mr. Khrushchev has now succeeded to the posts that Stalin had formally combined. He is not only the acknowledged architect of all Soviet foreign and domestic policies but the leader of the disciplined party ranks and the extensive ministerial apparatus that administers and enforces the policies.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 27, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Both Coasts Watch Closely as San Francisco Faces Erosion.

title: Health Ruling Hinges on How Justices Frame the Core Issue
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday is hearing arguments on the central question in the constitutional challenges to President Obamas health care overhaul law. How it answers the question depends in large part on how the justices decide to frame the core issue.

title: A Victory for Tiger Woods
description: WHO is Tiger Woods?WHO is Graeme McDowell?

title: The Real Oil Shock
description: Like a lot of carless New Yorkers, I am generally confused by bursts of populist outrage over high gas prices. But I have always assumed that the anger is genuine  that hard-working Americans, who already spend a lot on gas, are thrown into turmoil when they have to spend even more. After all, 63 percent of Americans insist that these price increases have caused them some financial hardship.

title: Kazakhstans Capital, Outside and In
description: Astana, Kazakhstans young and gleaming capital, has quickly become known for its space-age look: vibrant, toylike buildings pop against the frosty landscape. It is, as Rowan Moore wrote for The Observer in Britain, a rare but persistent type, the capital from zero.

title: What Do You Hope to Be Doing the Year After You Graduate From College?
description: The Sunday Magazine analyzed what 226 members of the class of 2011 at one college, Drew University, are doing now, nearly a year after graduation, and the news is not good: most have acutely felt the stresses of the bad economy. Read what several of them are doing and why, then tell us what you dream youll be doing the year after you graduate from college.

title: Assad Accepts Cease-Fire; Opponents Are Skeptical
description: AL QAA, Lebanon  Seeking to project an image of responsibility and reason, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria formally accepted a United Nations envoys cease-fire proposal on Tuesday and conducted a televised walking tour through the shell-shocked city of Homs, a center of the year-old uprising against him.

title: North Korea Reaffirms Plan to Launch Satellite
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea intends to press ahead with its plan to launch a satellite into orbit next month, according to a government statement issued Tuesday, rebuffing President Obama and other world leaders who have told the country to cancel the launching or face the loss of food aid and additional sanctions.

title: Europe Urged to Increase Firewall to a Trillion Euros
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union should increase its financial firewall to about 1 trillion euros to restore market confidence in the euro zone and prevent the spread of fiscal contagion, the head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, ngel Gurra, said on Tuesday.

title: Student Debt Collectors Are Incentivized to Violate Federal-Aid Laws, Bloomberg Reports
description: People who have defaulted on their student loans are sometimes forced into paying back more per month than they can afford  and more than the federal government requires  because private debt collectors are given incentives to violate federal-aid laws, Bloomberg reported this week.

title: Fantasy Focus: Stars and Scrubs, and How
description: For most of this spring, my colleague Jeff Erickson and I have been running mock drafts during our Sirius-XM radio show, often replicating the 15-team mixed league formats used by the National Fantasy Baseball Championship. That process allowed us to determine where we would like to draft in the main event, as draft slots are chosen Kentucky Derby style, meaning that the first choice simply affords an owner to pick his own seat.

title: Britains Experience in Raising the Top Tax Rate
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: The Early Word: Constitutionality
description: Todays Times

title: The Long Arm of Beijing
description: It was supposed to be a boring exercise in non-democracy. Since the decision rested with a 1,200-strong Election Committee largely under Beijings yoke, the election  or selection  of Leung Chun-ying as new chief executive of Hong Kong, the territorys highest office, was a foregone conclusion.

title: With Tebow Arriving, Revisiting Contract for Sanchez
description: Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk.com first reported in December that the Jets were beginning to realize that Sanchez may not be the answer at the position.

title: When Will India Get the Cricket Board it Deserves?
description: It is hard to believe how much the fortunes of Indian cricket have swung in the last 12 months. This time last year the team, and by extension everyone else in the country, was immersed in the 2011 World Cup. That tournament, of course, ended well for India.

title: Tebow Lights Up When Speaking About Foundation
description: Tim Tebow handled his news conference skillfully Monday. Yes, he might have overdone his expressions of excitement about being a Jet. But beyond that script, he was polite and charming and disciplined in avoiding controversy.
