He might have been most excited to answer the question about whether he would establish a foundation in New Jersey.

title: Al Jazeera Will Not Show French Rampage Video
description: PARIS  The Al Jazeera broadcaster said on Tuesday that it would not broadcast gruesome footage received by its Paris bureau that appears to show the killings of three Jewish schoolchildren, a rabbi and three French soldiers in southwestern France earlier this month.

title: Parcells Considered as Replacement for Saints Payton
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Saints Coach Sean Payton may address his yearlong suspension with the news media during the annual N.F.L. meetings, but first he may discuss his job with his mentor,Bill Parcells. ESPN reported Monday that Payton planned totalk to Parcells about filling in for him during his suspension. Parcells attended the Mets spring training game against the Cardinals on Monday, and when asked about the possibility that he could join the Saints, he responded, I have nothing to say.

title: Karen Mills, S.B.A. Chief, Takes Reader Questions
description: Much has changed since Karen Mills, the administrator for the Small Business Administration, first sat down with us back in the fall of 2009. The economy is improving, unemployment is falling, and S.B.A. lending is back to pre-recession levels. Ms. Millss agency, however, still faces pressing challenges. Fewer S.B.A. loans are reaching the smallest, underserved businesses. And both the agency and the Obama administration are under intense pressure to show that they are creating jobs, even as the White House proposes new cuts to the S.B.A. budget.

title: Answering Cries of Longing for Poetrys Return to the Subway
description: Goodness only knows what was rattling around F. Scott Fitzgeralds brain when he said there were no second acts in American lives. As often as that line is quoted, thats about how often it has been proved wrong. Now, the flaw in Fitzgeralds train of thought is being demonstrated yet again.

title: Attack of the Prison People
description: Update: OK, by popular request, the text of the letter after the jump.

title: Beware, Were Having a Heat Wave
description: LONDON  Northern Europe is basking in record springtime temperatures, to use the headline writers favorite weather word. Wall to wall sunshine, the Irish Times gushed, as the mercury rose higher than in Mediterranean sunspots such as Barcelona and Crete.

title: Report of Bomb Plot Puts Afghan Defense Ministry in Lockdown
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Defense Ministry went into a near-total lockdown on Tuesday after the discovery of 10 suicide vests and the arrests of more than a dozen Afghan soldiers suspected of plotting to attack the ministry and blow up commuter buses for government employees, Afghan and Western officials said.

title: The Challengers Deep-Sea Brethren
description: On Monday, the film director and explorer James Cameron became the first human to travel on his own to the worlds deepest abyss, the Challenger Deep, which lies 62 miles southwest of Guam in the Pacific Ocean. (As William J. Broad writes in The Times, Mr. Cameron found a bleak terrain that was all but barren of life.)

title: Answer for N.F.L. Replay Review Is Up in the Booth
description: All of the N.F.L. power players are in Florida for the owners meetings. Being discussed, among other things, are possible rule changes for 2012 and beyond. One proposal from the Buffalo Bills is for the replay process to be confined to the booth. This idea is long overdue. It was written about in the Fifth Down blogin December after a replay procedure took over 10 minutes in a Raiders-Packers game.

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Sony Offers Concessions to Win Approval for EMI Bid
description: LONDON  A group of investors led by Sony has submitted concessions to win European regulatory approval for its $2.2 billion purchase of EMIs publishing unit.

title: Harry Potters New Adventure: Going Digital in E-Books
description: The fantasy series that sent droves of eager children to buy hardcover books at midnight parties at bookstores is finally for sale as e-books.

title: Private School Parents Targeted for Giving
Foxconn Gets Japan Foothold With Stake in Sharp
description: TOKYO  In another sign of Chinas manufacturing ascent as Japan struggles, the Taiwanese giant Foxconn Technology will become the largest shareholder in Sharp, a former exemplar of Japans electronics empire that has fallen on hard times.

title: Opinion Report: The Anti-Injunction Act
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MF Globals Top Lawyer to Break Her Silence | MF Globals top lawyer is expected to break her five-month silence on Wednesday to tell Congress that she was unaware of a gaping shortfall in customer money until hours before the brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 31.

title: A Language Lesson in Arabic
description: Dear Diary:

title: Will Santorums Flashes of Anger Help or Hurt Him?
description: Can showing anger help get a candidate elected president?

title: At Edge of Paris, a Housing Project Becomes a Beacon
description: PARIS  Hard by the noisy highway, overlooking a cemetery and a former garbage dump, La Tour Bois-le-Prtre glimmers on a spring morning. Sheathed in a fresh cloak of glass balconies and corrugated aluminum panels, it rises on the edge of this city amid a landscape of decaying cement-and-brick housing blocks.

title: A Conversation With: Gorkha Leader Bimal Gurung
description: Bimal Gurung has been a major force in the movement to carve out a separate state for Nepali-speaking Indians, or Gorkhas, from West Bengal, since 2007.

title: Now Reading | Plan of Action
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Tuesday Reading: Can Chocolate Aid Weight Control?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: K.K.R. Hires Mack as Senior Adviser
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Tuesday that it had hired John J. Mack, a former chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, as one of its most prominent senior advisers yet.

title: Morning Buzz, March 27: A Path Through Midtown
description: Good morning. Today will climb only to a sunny 50 degrees, down from last weeks blast of heat, which is probably for the best.

title: Image of the Day: March 27
A Matter of Character
description: Ive always keenly appreciated Matt Zoller Seitzs criticism, and I cant think of anyone better qualified to judge the inevitable The Sopranos or The Wire final round of New York Magazines tournament of television. But I can also pinpoint the exact moment when his discussion of the two series goes astray. Hes comparing the two shows as exercises in characterization, and he gives the advantage to David Simons Baltimore drama:

title: Documentary on Bullying to Open With No Rating
description: LOS ANGELES  After weeks of storm, stress and no small amount of pressure  online and otherwise  over the R rating assigned to the antibullying documentary Bully, the Weinstein Company said late Monday that it would release the film without a rating.

title: What Were Reading
description: ESPN.com: Here, now, the engineering specifications for the new Tim Tebow sandwich at the Carnegie Deli. Name: The Jetbow (surely not Carnegies cleverest moniker). Weight: 3.5 pounds. Ingredients: corned beef, pastrami, roast beef, lettuce, tomato, American cheese (naturally), white bread (of course), mayonnaise (necessarily). Price: $22.22 (mystifyingly, the sum of Mr. Tebows number 15, Mark Sanchezs number 6, plus another unexplained $1.22).  Glenn Collins

title: The Pope Is Dead. Long Live the Pope.
description: CAIRO  Thousands of distraught Christians gathered on March 20 for the funeral of Pope Shenouda III, the only pope many of them had ever known. Shenouda led the Coptic Church of Egypt for four decades, becoming both the leader and the symbol of the countrys Christian community of about 10 million. Without him, many now worry about their future in an increasingly Islamic Egypt.

title: Day Two: Updates on the Supreme Court Hearings on the Health Care Law
description: The Lede followed the second of three days of Supreme Court hearings on the health care law. As our colleague, Adam Liptak reports, the justices asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate provision of the health care law during Tuesdays hearing. In a news analysis, David Leonhardt, Washington Bureau Chief, notes that many court experts expressed surprise at the apparent agreement among the conservatives, including Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, the likeliest swing vote. Updates below include a mix of breaking news alerts from journalists who leave the courtroom, reports from our colleagues in Washington on demonstrations outside the court and reactions from scholars, advocates and experts.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Rules for Data Trackers, and a Familiar Script for FX
description: The Federal Trade Commission released its long-awaited report on privacy on Monday and the results could be bad news for the burgeoning online advertising industry, write Edward Wyatt and Tanzina Vega. The commission wants to regulate data brokers like Experian and Acxiom that collect and sell personal information. It also wants to push the industry to respect the wishes of consumers who not only dont want to be tracked online but want no data collected on them whatsoever. One technology executive, who declined to be identified talking about negotiations for the government, said that do not collect is basically death for online advertising.

title: Financial Watchdog Is Answering Questions Online
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been encouraging consumers to contact it with complaints about various financial products, including mortgages, credit cards and student loans.

title: On Our Radar: Gas Leak in the North Sea
description: Gas leaking from a platform forces the evacuation of a second drilling rig operated in the North Sea by the French oil giant Total, and the authorities ban ships and aircraft from traveling within miles of the accident off Scotlands eastern coast. Total says the leak is the worst problem it has encountered in the North Sea in a decade. [Agence France-Presse]

title: Group Led by Magic Johnson Wins Auction to Buy Dodgers for $2.15 Billion
description: In a quick, dramatic end to the year-long financial crisis of the Los Angeles Dodgers, the teams owner, Frank McCourt, agreed to sell the team Tuesday night for $2.15 billion to a group headed by Magic Johnson, the Lakers Hall of Famer.

title: Daily Report: Security Issues Break Up Symantec-Huawei Venture
description: Less than four years after Huawei Technologies and Symantec teamed up to develop computer network security products, the joint venture is being dismantled, Nicole Perlroth and John Markoff report in Tuesdays New York Times. Symantec feared that the alliance with Huawei, a major Chinese telecommunications company, would prevent it from obtaining United States government classified information about online security threats.

title: A Bold Move
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Floridas New Election Law Blunts Voter Drives
description: Florida, which is expected to be a vital swing state once again in this years presidential election, is enrolling fewer new voters than it did four years ago as prominent civic organizations have suspended registration drives because of what they describe as onerous restrictions imposed last year by Republican state officials.

title: Business Day Live | March 27, 2012
description: States prepare alternatives in case the health care law is struck down; proposed restrictions on the selling of personal information; and the chief of the Small Business Administration on loans.

title: Wheelies: The Crucible Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Business Day Live: Plan B for Health Care
description: States prepare alternatives in case the health care law is struck down; proposed restrictions on the selling of personal information; and the chief of the Small Business Administration on loans.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Americas Global Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting a 7-Year-Old on a Diet
description: Let us say that your 4-year-old needs size 8 clothing  not for the length, but for the width. That when shes 5, friends and family are directly addressing what usually goes unspoken: her desserts, her juice intake, the way you handle her meals. Her teacher notes that she doesnt self-regulate at snack time. By the time shes 6, the pediatrician is in on it: you need to do something about her weight. And at 7, after a year of inconsistent effort, with a daughter who is 4 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 93 pounds, you put your child on a diet.

title: Tester Up With First Ad in Montana
description: Senator Jon Tester, the endangered Montana Democrat with the farm-state buzz cut, launched the first television ad of his first Senate re-election campaign on Monday, reintroducing his folksy ways and never mentioning his party.

title: Calling All Start-Ups
description: Have you heard about our Make Your Pitch contest? Yes, thats right: We here at The Timess Small-Business Desk are hosting a special contest for our entrepreneurial readers. All of the videos that meet our guidelines will be published, and the lucky winners will be featured on Youre the Boss, their pitches evaluated by a business strategist, Carol Roth.

title: The Meaning of Religious Freedom
description: During the recent debate over birth control insurance coverage, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops defined religious freedom as their freedom from government.

title: Mandates Impact May Be Limited, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  In legal terms, the issue before the Supreme Court on Tuesday could not be more momentous. The courts ruling on the constitutionality of the health care laws requirement that most Americans obtain medical insurance may define the boundaries of Congress authority to regulate interstate commerce for generations.

title: The Tracks of an Authors, and a Readers, Tears
description: Its not very manly, the topic of weeping while reading. Yet for a book critic tears are an occupational hazard. Luckily, perhaps, books dont make me cry very often  Im a thrice-a-year man, at best. Turning pages, Im practically Steve McQueen.

title: $1.2 Million Fine for Indian Point Fire
description: The owner of the Indian Point nuclear plant has agreed to pay a $1.2 million penalty for a transformer explosion at its Unit 2 reactor that spilled oil into the Hudson River in November 2010. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said that longstanding structural conditions led to the failure of a containment system that should have prevented the oil from flowing into the river.

title: Ask the Hunger Games Director Your Questions
description: After a record $155 million opening weekend, The Hunger Games is poised to become Hollywoods next major franchise. Its director Gary Ross, whose filmography includes Seabiscuit and Pleasantville, was presented with a few challenges when adapting the popular novel, including how to portray the child-on-child violence in a PG-13 way and how to give visual shape to characters and scenes that existed so vividly on the page for readers.

title: Arbitron Agrees to Improve How It Counts Minority Radio Listeners
description: Arbitron, the largest radio ratings service, has settled a lawsuit in California over how it measures minority audiences, agreeing to pay $400,000 and to abide by certain research methods in tracking black and Latino radio listeners.

title: For a Romney Running Mate, Dont Bet on a Governor
description: Governors might make for better presidential candidates than senators do, but they have not had an advantage when it comes time for a party to pick its vice-presidential nominee.

title: S.E.C. Told to Share Notes in Insider Trading Case
description: A federal judge has ordered Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers to turn over their notes to federal prosecutors handling the criminal case against Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs.

title: Group Manages to Post Live Updates From Health Care Arguments  for a While
description: 3:58 p.m. | Updated Want to know what is happening inside the Supreme Court in real time as the health care law is debated? You are out of luck. The courts rules strictly prohibit any communication from inside the building during the arguments.

title: MF Global Executive Saw Early Warning Sign on Customer Money
description: An internal MF Global document suggested that the firm was putting customer money at risk days before its bankruptcy filing, an executive said in prepared testimony that was released on Tuesday for a Congressional hearing on Wednesday.

title: Poll: Support for the War in Afghanistan Falls
description: In Tuesdays New York Times, Elisabeth Bumiller and Allison Kopicki write about findings from the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, which found two-thirds of those polled  69 percent  thought that the United States should not be at war in Afghanistan.

title: Hilton Kramer, Art Critic and Champion of Tradition in Culture Wars, Dies at 84
description: Hilton Kramer, whose clear, incisive style and combative temperament made him one of the most influential critics of his era, both at The New York Times, where he was the chief art critic for almost a decade, and at The New Criterion, which he edited from its founding in 1982, died early Tuesday in Harpswell, Me. He was 84.

title: Minsky and Methodology (Wonkish)
description: Steve Keen has a new post up (with a link to a new paper) about Minksyan (Minskyite?) economics, and how people like me get it wrong. Good for him; debates like this are always productive, and I wish domestic responsibilities werent keeping me from going to the Berlin conference.

title: SAT and ACT to Tighten Rules After Cheating Scandal
description: Stung by a cheating scandal involving dozens of Long Island high school students, the SAT and ACT college entrance exams will now require students to provide a photograph when they sign up for the exams, and officials will check those images against the identification the students present when they take the test.

title: The Challenge of Driving With Aspergers
description: Over the last two decades, researchers have examined the risks faced by young drivers with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and tried to find ways to help them to learn to drive safely, an issue explored in this weeks Science Times. Now those researchers and driving instructors are finding themselves faced with a new challenge: the growing number of teenagers with Asperger syndrome and other forms of autism, conditions defined by deficits in social skills and obsessive interests that can make learning to drive especially difficult.

title: A Deservedly Smug iPhone Photo App
description: Update: Addresses new features added today.

title: Its Singers Over Dancers on Monday Night
description: The fight between two branches of performing arts  voice and dance  tipped decidedly to the singers Monday night in the area that counts most in television, younger adult viewers.

title: In Court, Sharp Questions on Health Care Laws Mandate
description: WASHINGTON  With the fate of President Obamas health care law hanging in the balance, a lawyer for the administration faced a barrage of skeptical questions on Tuesday from four of the Supreme Courts more conservative justices, suggesting that a 5-to-4 decision to strike down the law was a live possibility.

title: The Get | Valextras Avietta 48h Case
description: In the spirit of Valextras original 24h travel bag  a prize-winning attach created in the 1950s by the founder Giovanni Fontana for quick overnight trips  the steel-frame Avietta 48h, first introduced in 1964, accommodates a two-night stay in an equally elegant way. The compact carrier, which is about the size of a pillow and nearly as light, features a proper briefcase handle (no lazy elbow hooking here), buttery soft leather and the companys signature rhodium brushed zippers and pulls (so discreet and smooth to use). Inside, buckled straps secure things in place. Luxury, meet efficiency at its finest.

title: A Counterfeiting Conspiracy?
description: In March 1862, an unusual ad began appearing in Northern newspapers. Among the shops selling pianos and patent medicines, sheet music and sewing machines, this one stood out: it promised perfect fac-similes of Confederate currency. There were seven kinds of notes for sale, and testimonials from The New York Tribune and others praising the replicas for their high quality and low prices. Five cents bought you one. Two dollars bought a hundred. Fifteen dollars bought a thousand. The word counterfeits never appeared. These were Mementos of the Rebellion, sold by a Philadelphia shopkeeper named Samuel Curtis Upham.

title: Where Have I Seen You Before?
description: ADAPTATIONS, a k a blatant knockoffs, have always been a part of fashion, but they used to occur at a more civilized pace. Coco Chanel was famously relaxed about the issue; despite banding with Madeleine Vionnet to sue one particularly shameless copyist in the 1930s, when Paris was the undisputed center of the industry, she later authorized American dressmakers like David Kidd of Jablow to clone her signature nubby tweed suits for the common folk.

title: Hawk Cam Video Highlight: Cooperation in the Nest
description: On Sunday, a reader known as HawkTalk in the Hawk Cam 2012 chat room witnessed an interesting bit of cooperation between the mates in the nest. An edited version of the events appears above. (Please ignore the Please stand by while we adjust the Hawk Cam overlay. It was captured as part of the archived segment, and cannot be removed.)

title: New Insight Into a 1973 Mayoral Hopefuls Losing Gambit
description: Former United States Representative Mario A. Biaggis mayoral campaign imploded in 1973 after the release of grand jury testimony confirming that he had refused to testify about certain financial matters and later lied by denying that he had invoked the Fifth Amendment. A new biography of a federal judge suggests that Mr. Biaggi, a Democrat from the Bronx, came a lot closer to getting elected than most New Yorkers realized.

title: Business Day Live | Small Business Loans
description: March 27, 2012 - Karen Mills, chief of the Small Business Administration, answers questions about loans.

title: War Over a One-Horse Town
description: About 125 millennia ago, the southern end of the strait between Africa and Arabia was much narrower, and may have been the springboard for one of early humanitys great migratory leaps. [1] A big deal for everyone who has come along since, but the question of where, exactly, those first people out of Africa came from matters immensely to two very antagonistic neighbors. At this moment, in some Internet chat room, the locals are fighting over the nationality of those Red Sea pedestrians: did they originate in Eritrea, or in Ethiopia?

title: Getting Your Media Retina-Ready
description: Now that the new iPad supports so-called retina resolution  namely the uber-HD 20481536 pixels that delivers crisp text and and great 3-D gaming  most of the video media youre probably viewing on your older devices will probably look like an unmitigated mess. What to do?

title: App Smart Extra: Gardening Apps
description: Strangely enough, there are few great gardening apps available, as last weeks App Smart column pointed out. But this is such a big market opportunity that niche media companies will inevitably join the fray.

title: In Paris, a Housing Tower Transformed
description: La Tour Bois-le-Prtre, a public housing tower on the outskirts of Paris, has been upgraded and now features an exterior of glass and aluminum.

title: Anti-Gay Marriage Group Recommends Creating Tension Between Gays and Blacks
description: 9:05 p.m. | Updated An internal memorandum from one of the countrys leading organizations against same-sex marriage outlined a plan to help its cause by exploiting unease among blacks over the issue.

title: The History Damaged Tree Rings Might Tell
description: Kevin Anchukaitis, an assistant research professor at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, is conducting a tree-ring study to analyze drought patterns in Guatemala.

title: Equipment Stolen From Romney Campaign Vehicle
description: SAN DIEGO  Its hardly Watergate West, but Mitt Romneys campaign faced a break-in of its own on Friday night in California.

title: Grieving for Pets and Humans: Is There a Difference?
description: Can the death of a pet hurt as much as the loss of a relative? The Washington Post food editor Joe Yonan recently wrote about his grieving process after the death of his dog Red compared with his feelings after losing two human family members. He writes:

title: Hints of a $199 Tablet and 3-D Chromebook
description: Nvidia is a scrappy semiconductor company that used to be known for chips that richly rendered gaming graphics, but is now getting its advanced chips inside tablets and supercomputers. Last week the company released a new computer chip architecture that promises sharper graphics and less power consumption in desktops and ultrabooks.

title: TimesCast | March 27, 2012
description: The Supreme Court holds the second day of hearings on the 2010 health care law | Upholding or repealing the law could have surprising political implications.

title: The Muppets Strike Back at Goldman Sachs
description: The resignation manifesto read round the world  the Op-Ed page article published two weeks ago in The New York Times by Greg Smith, the disheartened Goldman Sachs executive  has already spawned more than its share of parodies, most of them in mock-serious epistolary prose. But the comedy Web site Funny or Die has gone these parodies one better with a slickly produced short sketch starring Kyle MacLachlan as a Goldman Sachs honcho bemoaning the firms bad press when his meeting is suddenly interrupted by three Muppets bearing their own grudge.

title: Which Crowdfunding Bill Will It Be?
description: The most ballyhooed part of the House JOBS bill  and the only part changed by the Senate when it passed the legislation last week, is the so-called crowdfunding proposal to allow small companies to raise small amounts of money from large groups of small investors. Its backed by the president, and by high-profile entrepreneurs, like Steve Case.

title: Asylum Claims Rose 20 Percent Last Year, U.N. Refugee Agency Says
description: Escapees from new uprisings in the Middle East and Africa, combined with a rising tide of people fleeing chronic conflicts like those in Afghanistan and Iraq, contributed to a 20 percent increase in requests for asylum in industrialized countries last year, the United Nations refugee agency reported Tuesday.

title: A Victory for Pat Summitt, Even in Defeat
description: The end of the Baylor-Tennessee game in the womens N.C.A.A. tournament was hard for everyone, with the 400-pound elephant in attendance at Des Moiness Wells Fargo Arena representing the scary question of what the loss meant for Tennessee Coach Pat Summitt, whether it spelled the end of her legendary career and how big a toll her early-onset dementia would take on her in the coming years.

title: Join Our Live Discussion About the Supreme Court Health Care Debate
description: At noon Eastern time on Thursday, Adam Liptak, the Supreme Court correspondent for The New York Times, and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care for the papers Business Day section, will be answering readers questions on Facebook about the legal battle over the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, President Obamas signature legislative achievement, which is being challenged in historic Supreme Court arguments.

title: Iraqi Immigrants in California Town Fear a Hate Crime in a Womans Killing
description: EL CAJON, Calif.  Shaima Alawadis family says they found the first note taped to the front door of their house on a quiet suburban street here. It said: This is my country. Go back to yours, terrorist, according to her 15-year-old son, Mohammed.

title: A Surge in Learning the Language of the Internet
description: Parlez-vous Python? What about Rails or JavaScript? Foreign languages tend to wax and wane in popularity, but the language du jour is computer code.

title: Driving With A.D.H.D.
description: Distracted driving is a problem for anyone, but clinical disorders like Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder make both learning to drive and earning a drivers license feel nearly insurmountable for many. John ONeil writes about the challenges for the Science section  of The Times today: young drivers with A.D.H.D. are two to four times as likely as those without the condition to have an accident  meaning that they are at a higher risk of wrecking the car than an adult who is legally drunk.

title: Timely | Sophie Aschauer: Knotty, Knotty
description: Sophie Aschauer has been fascinated by puzzles since she was a child. But it wasnt until she picked up a book of sailors knots last year on a trip to Nantucket, Mass., that she put this interest to any practical use. I was mesmerized, says Aschauer, a New York-based, Austrian-born graduate of Central Saint Martins, who designs under the label SerpentSea. Right away, I knew I was going to make them into mats. Each of her small but weighty rugs incorporates about 150 feet of repurposed nautical and mountaineering rope, which she coaxes into intricate patterns that loop and twine like baroque infinity symbols. The hands-on process takes about four hours per rug; devising the patterns can take considerably longer. She has three models available, all named for famous pirates  Drake, Bonny and Morgan  and a larger area rug is in the works. People love them as bathmats, Aschauer says. They feel very nice under bare feet.

title: In Paradise, and Closer Than Ever to Disaster
description: For many of us who live in temperate zones, inland regions and the industrialized West, global warming is a source of anxiety  even terror  and something of an abstraction. The mildness of this past winter on the Eastern Seaboard might have seemed ominous, yes, but it was also pleasant, and much of the time other social, economic and political problems have a way of seeming more urgent than human survival.

title: Q&A: iOS Printing Without AirPrint
description: Q.

title: WICs Fresh Produce Program Cut 30 Percent
description: In the appropriations bill for 2012, funding for the Women, Infants and Children Farmers Market Nutrition Program (WIC FMNP) was cut by approximately 30 percent. WICs FMNP helps provide underserved families across the country with fresh produce, and is not only a critical subsidy for families that might not otherwise have sufficient access to high-quality, nutritious food, but also for the small and mid-scale farmers and farmers markets that operate in low-income communities and rely on WICs FMNP dollars as a major source of revenue. By some estimates the 30 percent cut will decrease benefits for 300,000 families.

title: On New Zealands South Island, Farm Stays With Friendly Hosts
description: Jogging down a rural stretch of road on the scantly populated and mountainous South Island of New Zealand last week, I noticed a herd of cattle staring at me.

title: National Archives Announces Discovery of Nazi Looted-Art Volumes
description: The National Archives announced Tuesday that two new leather-bound volumes of an infamous catalog of looted art compiled for Hitler during World War II had been discovered among the possessions of former American soldiers. The albums were compiled by a special Nazi task force, the Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg, to document the plundering of French museums and private collections undertaken in part for a museum Hitler planned to build in his hometown, Linz, Austria.

title: F.D.A. Approves New Anemia Drug
description: It has been one of the most lucrative monopolies of all time, yielding the biotechnology company Amgen roughly $40 billion in sales over 23 years.

title: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 2 Transcript
description: On the second day of arguments challenging President Obamas 2010 health care law, conservative members of the Supreme Court asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate, a core provision of the legislation.

title: New Way to Raise Cash: A Picture With Gingrich for $50
description: Newt Gingrich, who has encouraged donations of as little as $2.50, has turned to an unusual tactic for his financially troubled campaign: charging $50 for a photograph with him.

title: Del Negro Gets Vote of Support from Clippers
description: It cant be an N.B.A. season, even a lockout-shortened one, without some Los Angeles Clippers drama. The current brouhaha involves the fate of Coach Vinny Del Negro, who may or may not be in danger of losing his job. The Clippers are 28-21, second in the Pacific division and are safely occupying a playoff spot. But the Clippers are 8-9 in March, including a three-game losing streak over the past week, putting some heat on Del Negro.

title: In the Court, Split Seems Partisan
description: Many legal scholars, including some conservatives, have been predicting that the Supreme Court will uphold the 2010 health care overhaul. But after Tuesdays arguments, when several justices asked skeptical questions about the heart of the law, a political lens seemed relevant, too.

title: Adam Liptak on the Health Care Hearings
description: The Times's Adam Liptak discusses the fallout from the second day of hearings at the Supreme Court on the 2010 health care law.

title: A Fateful Superman Check Is Up for Auction
description: Is a check for $412 really worth $412? Thats a question that has comic book fans intrigued this week. The check in question is the one endorsed by Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster when they signed over their rights for creating Superman, whose adventures are published by DC Comics. Now the auction site Comicconnect.com is putting the check up for sale. The auction began on Monday and ends on April 16. The 12 bids have already pushed the price to $25,500.

title: Squares Mobile Payment App Gets New Name and Look
description: The next time you stop into a small business, Square hopes you will Pay With Square. Thats the new, more straightforward name for Squares mobile payments app, previously called Card Case.

title: Creative License
description: The most inspired  and inspiring  fashion show of the spring 2012 season took place not in Paris, Milan or London but on a makeshift runway in Oakland, Calif. On March 16, Creative Growth, the nonprofit organization that serves adult artists with developmental, mental and physical disabilities, presented Beyond Trend, a fund-raiser that kicked off with a street parade and culminated in a runway show. As if anyone needed further evidence of the incredible talent on display that day, many of the looks were not only designed, but also modeled, by Creative Growth artists. The filmmaker Cheryl Dunn captured the magic.

title: Pilots Erratic Behavior Forces Flight From Kennedy to Be Diverted
description: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | A JetBlue flight to Las Vegas from John F. Kennedy International Airport was diverted to Amarillo, Tex., on Tuesday morning when the captain started behaving erratically and had to be removed from the cockpit, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Quietly, a Budget Deal Is Reached in Albany
description: ALBANY  No flash. No sizzle. No last-minute protests, and no late-night dramatics.

title: Parking Lots, Ready for a Close-Up and a Spruce-Up
description: As he argued in a piece that appeared Monday in The Timess Opinion Pages, Eran Ben-Joseph, a professor of landscape architecture and planning at M.I.T., claims that the worlds parking lots are deeply flawed.

title: Kadima Party in Israel Replaces Livni as Leader
description: JERUSALEM  Tzipi Livni, who not long ago was a popular and leading force in Israeli politics, lost the leadership of her centrist Kadima Party on Tuesday by a large margin to an archrival, according to results of the primary election.

title: Olympic Mascots Inspire Imitations
description: The 1968 Winter Games in Grenoble, France, opened the floodgates for Olympic mascots by giving the world Schuss, a cartoon character that became known as the Skiing Sperm. All manner of misshapen and barely identifiable creatures have followed, from Waldi the multicolored dachshund (Munich, 1972) to Magique the star-shaped snow imp (Albertville, France, 1992) to Izzy the computer-generated ... something (Atlanta, 1996).

title: A Clearer Picture of Tropical Carbon
description: Tropical forests, alongside boreal forests and wetlands, are prime ecosystems for storing carbon. Now, researchers have created a new high-resolution map of carbon storage in tropical forests that could play an important role in effective forest management.

title: A Mayor Who Never Slept Here (Gracie Mansion) Says No Successor Should
description: It has been a shipping magnates country residence, has housed public restrooms and classes for immigrants and has even done a stint as an ice cream shop. But for the past 70 years, Gracie Mansion has been home to nine New York City mayors, from Fiorello H. La Guardia to Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Before the Law: Understanding the Supreme Court Case on the Affordable Care Act
description: Overview | What are the issues at stake in the Supreme Court challenges to President Obamas health care law? In this lesson, students create a television news segment to inform their schools community about the questions regarding Affordable Health Care Act that are being considered by the Supreme Court.

title: Computer-Hacking Allegations Made Against News Corporation
description: News Corporation faced fresh scrutiny in Britain on Tuesday after a BBC documentary reported that a company affiliated with the media conglomerate used computer hacking to advance the business interests of the broadcaster BSkyB.

title: Wines of Europe Look to Asia to Offset Slowdown at Home
description: VERONA, Italy  Long gone are the days when French soldiers or Italian farmhands were issued their daily ration of a liter of wine. Even the three-hour Parisian lunch, accompanied by a few glasses of red, white or sparkling, is threatened by the ravages of globalization.

title: Bronx Museum to Be Free to Visitors
description: Joining a sizable roster of museums around the country, the Bronx Museum of the Arts has decided to go free. As a way of marking its 40th anniversary, the museum, on the Grand Concourse not far from Yankee Stadium, will eliminate its suggested admission fee of $5 beginning March 29.

title: Video of Assad in Battered City Is Broadcast on Syrian State Television
description: Updated | 7:32 p.m. As my colleagues Anne Barnard and Alan Cowell report, Syrian state television broadcast footage of President Bashar al-Assad on Tuesday in the city of Homs, touring the ruined neighborhood of Baba Amr, which was recently brought back under government control after a weeks-long military assault.

title: JPMorgan Promotes Lawyer
description: JPMorgan Chase promoted Matthew Biben to general counsel for all of the banks consumer businesses, according to an internal memo on Tuesday. Mr. Biben joined JPMorgan Chase last March as general counsel, overseeing the banks mortgage banking operations.

title: Begin the Bidet
description: The bidet may be a fixture in bathrooms the world over, but it has never really caught on in the United States. Instead of washing with water after relieving ourselves, wed rather deforest millions of acres to produce toilet paper. We think bidets are too European, maybe. Or we suspect that they have something to do with s-e-x.

title: In Pursuit of EMI, Sony and Universal Will Sell Music-Publishing Assets
description: The purchase of EMI by Sony and Universal, if approved, would result in further consolidation of the music industry, which over the last 15 years has gone from six major players to four. But as a byproduct of this deal, hundreds of millions of dollars in music assets will be hitting the market, either to help those companies finance the purchase or to appease regulatory authorities in the United States and Europe.

title: For Romney, a Four-Car Garage With Its Own Elevator
description: SAN DIEGO  If the news last summer that Mitt Romney had a $12 million expansion planned for his oceanfront property here helped portray him as a member of the top 1 percent, the new disclosure that the renovation includes elevators for his four-car garage is not likely to burnish his image as a man of the people.

title: Officer Convicted in Sexual Assault
description: A New York City police officer was found guilty on Tuesday of predatory sexual assault in an attack on a 25-year-old woman at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan in August, and faced a possible sentence of life in prison.

title: Baby Boomers Confidence Dented by Recession
description: The last five years have been tough on Americans financial confidence, particularly among baby boomers thought of as upbeat and affluent, a new survey has found.

title: TimesCast: Supreme Court Hearings Continue
description: David Leonhardt reports on developments from the second day of hearings on the 2010 health care law at the Supreme Court, and Michael D. Shear breaks down the political implications of the eventual ruling on the 2012 presidential campaign.

title: Look of The Moment | January Jones
description: The Look: Party Pieces. A peekaboo back and thigh-high slit add drama to a minimally adorned black dress.

title: Cost Complaints, an Olympic Rite, Voiced in Britain
description: LONDON  Money was so scarce at the 1948 London Olympics that the athletes brought their own towels, shipped food in from abroad and slept in army barracks and college dormitories. The 760,000 budget was paid by sponsors after Prime Minister Clement Attlee declared that a depleted country struggling in the aftermath of World War II should not have to shoulder the burden of the Games, too.

title: Cuban Official Rules Out Reforms Urged by Pope
description: HAVANA  Just after Pope Benedict XVI prayed at a revered shrine in Cuba on Tuesday, calling for the country to move forward along the way of renewal and hope, a top government minister made clear that the sweeping economic changes under way here would not be accompanied by political reforms that the pope has urged.

title: Photo Replay: March 27
description: The day in sports included the world team table tennis championships in Dortmund, Germany, and the world figure skating championships in Nice, France.

title: For New Generation of Power Plants, a New Emission Rule From the E.P.A.
description: The Obama administrations proposed rule to control greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants  the first ever  could go far toward closing out the era of old-fashioned coal-burning power generation.

title: Beyond Trend: Creative Growth Art Center
description: A runway event for Creative Growth Art Center.

title: Styling Steve Kazee
description: The actor Steve Kazee in trend-centric polka dots for Ts photo shoot.

title: Learning to Breast-Feed From an Avatar
description: When two Northeastern University professors, one in health sciences and the other in computer and information science, came together to try to develop a system to help women breast-feed more successfully, their project joined their common interest and their two worlds. They created a lactation avatar: Tanya.

title: Food Co-op Rejects Effort to Boycott Israeli-Made Products
description: Members of the Park Slope Food Co-op voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday night against a motion that would have moved the organization closer to joining an international boycott against products made in Israel. The vote settled a debate that had embroiled the venerable neighborhood institution for many months and divided its membership.

title: This Little Piggy Stayed Home
description: BACON has nudged its way into every cranny of culinary fashion, be it vodka cocktails, short-rib braises or caramel cupcakes. Its everywhere. Still. And for good reason: A little bit of bacon packs an umami-rich punch for simple salads, soups or pots of otherwise virtuous greens  not to mention the role it plays in Sunday mornings alchemy of coffee and newsprint.

title: Banking Mysticism
description: Reading the comments on my Steve Keen post, I had an insight: banking is where left and right meet. Both the Austrians  who believe that whatever the market does is right, unless its fractional reserve banking, which is somehow terrible  and the self-proclaimed true Minskyites view banks as institutions that are somehow outside the rules that apply to the rest of the economy, as having unique powers for good and/or evil.

title: Good Golly, Miss Molly
description: Molly Ivins award dinner, June 7.

title: Artifacts | The Rondinone Spirit
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Tibetan Exiles Rally Around Delhi Self-Immolator
description: DHARAMSALA, India  By Tuesday afternoon, posters of the man in flames were plastered along the narrow streets of this town adopted by Tibetan exiles. Monks, merchants and tourists stared. In the early evening, more than 200 people walked through the town center waving Tibetan flags and carrying banners that proclaimed the critically injured man, Jamphel Yeshi, a martyr.

title: Pairings: Stuffed Trout With Porter Sauce
description: Porters are deceiving. They show dark richness in the glass, but on the palate, the beers are refreshingly dry, not heavy, and can harmonize with more foods than a fruit-forward cabernet. Every match is welcome, from a plate of briny oysters to a rack of ribs rimmed with char. If the dish mirrors some of the beers subtle notes of chocolate, coffee, spice, toast and smoke, all the better. I roasted a good-size trout seasoned with soy sauce  another flavor that showed up in the beers  and stuffed it with toasted bread crumbs. A healthy splash of porter also went into the pan to make a sauce. The fish can be readied for roasting well in advance. And the recipe can easily be doubled, serving four or more for a dinner party.

title: Ale to Usher in Baseball Season
description: IVE been a baseball fanatic most of my life. When I was a child I knew the starting lineup of every team in both leagues. Statistics slipped through my lips as easily as lies would through a politicians.

title: U.S. Navy Program to Study How Troops Use Intuition
description: The United States Navy has started a program to investigate how members of the military can be trained to improve their sixth sense, or intuitive ability, during combat and other missions.

title: For Kevin Anderson, Concerns About Tennis in South Africa
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.Now at his career-high ranking of No. 28, the 6-foot-8 South African Kevin Anderson is one of a growing number of tall, big-serving players blasting their way to the upper echelon of tennis.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kyrgyzstan, Indonesia, Turkey and Gaza.

title: Hilton Kramers Provocative Time at The Times
description: Hilton Kramer, who died Tuesday at 84, arrived at The New York Times in 1965, and became the papers chief art critic in 1973. His 1981 review of an exhibit of Milton Averys paintings included this distillation of his preference for the aesthetic over the political in art:

title: Watch Bullitt Homage, and a Making-of Minidocumentary, From Alcatraz
description: As John Pearley Huffman wrote Monday, the season finale of Alcatraz, which was broadcast Monday night on Fox, contained an homage to the chase scene from Bullitt, the 1968 police drama starring Steve McQueen.

title: Off Limits
description: If youre a Republican candidate for the presidency, and youre trying to figure out if youve reached the limits of acceptability in attacking Barack Obama, heres an easy marker: Even House Speaker John Boehner thinks youre tactless.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Whiskey Tasting

title: The Case for Raising Top Tax Rates
description: The wealthy are feeling defensive about their taxes. Most Americans may think the rich pay too little but, not surprisingly, only 30 percent of the rich agree. More than two-thirds of families earning a quarter of a million dollars a year or more tell Gallups pollsters that their taxes are too high.

title: Horseradish and Beet Tartare
description: Adapted from Mark Spangenthal, Kutshers Tribeca

title: Joan Nathans Matzo Chremsel
description: Adapted from Joan Nathan

title: Pear Haroseth With Pecans and Figs
description: Adapted from Michael Selig

title: Joan Nathans Matzo Balls
description: Adapted from Joan Nathan

title: Passover Seder, Smoothly Done
description: MY 98-year-old mother calls my Passover seder a gantzeh megillah  a big production. Shes right. For me, the seder is the hardest event of the year to prepare for. Yet it is by far the most meaningful because it commemorates the defining chapter in Judaism, when the Jews fled slavery in Egypt to freedom in the promised land.

title: Joan Nathans Matzo Balls
description: Joan Nathan, the Jewish cooking maven, shares her matzo ball recipe with Melissa Clark.

title: Dewey Overhauls Leadership Amid Financial Difficulties
description: The troubled New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has overhauled its leadership amid questions about its financial condition and a stream of partner defections.

title: Bernanke, the Anti-Garbo
description: Investors are said to hang on every word spoken by the chairman of the Federal Reserve. The current chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, must be testing their patience.

title: Resetting the Table
description: FOR a lot of people who spent the Clinton years eating in and around Midtown Manhattan, 1996 was all about the crackling pork shank.

title: Pettittes Positive Day
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte inched closer to pitching in a game Tuesday when he threw 35 pitches of batting practice to Nick Swisher and Chris Dickerson, and came away with a glowing review of his performance.

title: Are Taxes Too High? People Invariably Think So
description: A study shows that Americans thinks the tax rate needs to be lower.

title: Show Time: The Cooking Comes Tableside
description: WHEN a revamped Maloney & Porcelli opens its doors next week, diners will be able to order martinis from a cart wheeled around the dining room. If theyre hungry for the Bronson Pinchot, a revved-up steak au poivre, a chef will create that at a tableside cart, too. The same goes for the grasshopper pie, whose rich topping of boozy cream will be whisked a few inches from your seat.

title: The Reinvented Maloney & Porcelli
description: Inside the chophouse, founded in 1996, that is looking back at retro styles in order to get ahead.

title: Don Draper and the Delicate Art of Restaurant Renovation
description: Im sorry, readers. I know Im supposed to be focused on writing this blog post, but I cant stop murmuring zoobeezoobee zoo, zoobeezoobee zoo. Or, more precisely, ZouBisouBisou.

title: Senate Defers Work on Post Office Overhaul
description: The Senate on Tuesday voted down a motion to begin work on legislation that would have overhauled the financially ailing Postal Service, a measure that postal officials said did not go far enough in allowing them to cut costs, and that some postal unions said would make the post offices financial situation even worse.

title: Administration Faces Questions on Health Care
description: On the second day of arguments challenging President Obamas 2010 health care law, conservative members of the Supreme Court asked skeptical questions about the individual mandate, a core provision of the legislation.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Mad Men GIFS and iPad Charging
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

title: Giddy Beats Celebrating Female Empowerment
description: When the women of Nimbaya! start breaking taboos, taboos should watch out. This all-female company comes from Guinea, West Africa, where tradition dictates that only men play drums. Every time these women perform, they smash that prohibition and dance to celebrate.

title: SAT Reforms May Have Negative Impact on Students, Counselors Say
description: Students who take the SAT and ACT will soon be required to upload photos of themselves when they register for the college entrance exams, our colleagues report.

description: To the Editor:

title: La Mar Cebicheria Peruana
description: Inside the Manhattan outpost of Peruvian restaurant chain, housed in the former Tabla space.

title: Storming New York With Ceviche
description: ON one of the few nights this winter when the temperature sagged below freezing, the host at La Mar Cebicheria Peruana led my party to an upstairs table without offering to take our coats. This was a surprise, because the coat check had been in full swing on a warmer night weeks earlier.

title: Nuclear Decommissioning
description: To the Editor:

title: A Striver Comes to an Ignoble End
description: Massenets Manon clings to a place in the standard repertory, though just barely. It is a popular but problematic work. The title role of an alluring French girl from a small town with a fatal attraction to riches and pleasures has long been an irresistible vehicle for a star soprano.

title: What Car Buyers Want
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best Coffee
description: To the Editor:

title: Final Approval by House Sends Jobs Bill to President for Signature
description: WASHINGTON  The House gave overwhelming final approval on Tuesday to a package of measures intended to ease access to capital and investments for entrepreneurs, sending the bipartisan legislation to President Obama, who has said he will sign it.

title: Overlooked Songwriter Finally Gets His Due
description: When the New York Philharmonic meets Broadway, wonderful things can happen. At the orchestras spring gala at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, the songs of the chronically overlooked Frank Loesser received well-deserved royal treatment. Conducted by Ted Sperling, the concert sustained an ideal, acoustically perfect mixture of brassy confidence and vaulting romanticism.

title: Rucola
description: 190 Dean Street (at Bond Street), Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 576-3209, rucolabrooklyn.com.

title: On Way to Worlds, a Stop in North Korea
description: The world championships will be in Nathalie Pchalats home country, France, this week, and so the ice dancer will apply tape to her broken nose and makeup to cover the bruising, and glide onto the ice with the requisite smile to compete in Nice on Wednesday.

title: This Year, Its Idol Chasing the Voice
description: A couple of weeks ago on The Voice, during one of the battle rounds, Adam Levine was twisted into one of his signature poses meant to communicate agony and indecision. Angel Taylor and Katrina Parker had just squared off singing Leona Lewiss Bleeding Love, and Mr. Levine, their coach, was being pulled in conflicting directions. Should he choose Ms. Taylor, a telegenic singer with a wispy voice whod previously been signed to a major label? Or should he choose Ms. Parker, the less obvious star of the two, but who outsang Ms. Taylor during the battle?

title: Bring Out Your Ringtones, and Other Requests for Accompaniment
description: Instead of the usual admonition about silencing cellphones, So Percussion prefaced its concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening by telling listeners to turn theirs on, to make sure that the volume was all the way up, and to set an alarm  the more obnoxious the better  for 1 hour 18 minutes into the program.

title: Cochinita
description: 922 Fulton Street (St. James Place), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 789-7700; tacoscochinita.com.

title: A Lacy Tribute to Italian Jews
description: Judith Norell, an owner of Silver Moon Bakery on the Upper West Side, has baked matzos for a few years. But now she is expanding the line to include whole wheat, poppy seed and sesame seed matzos, in addition to plain.

title: Homemade Marshmallows, Not Just for Kids
description: Commercial marshmallows pale next to these big, handmade ones from California. Their subtle flavors, dazzling colors and firm yet supple texture make them treats for all ages. Pop a few into the Easter basket, or pile them in a dish to accompany dessert at a brunch. The company that makes them, Split Bean Coffee in Van Nuys, Calif., also specializes in alfajores, the delicious South American filled shortbread cookies, using a family recipe.

title: Tucsons School Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,899 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: School Administrator Resigns After Inquiry Into Wife's Job
Detention Is No Holiday
description: MiamiLAMAR SMITH, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, is presiding over a hearing Wednesday on new guidelines for immigration detention that were issued last month and are now beginning to go into effect. The official (and facetious) title of the hearing is Holiday on ICE, in reference to the more humane treatment undocumented immigrants should now receive after being picked up by Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

title: Yankees Chamberlain Reflecting on an Injury, Minus Regret
description: TAMPA, Fla.  While a distraught Joba Chamberlain was lying in his bed at St. Josephs Hospital, recovering from surgery to repair a severe ankle injury, a nurse came in last weekend and asked what had happened.

title: Expected Flood of Opportunities in Europe Is Still a Trickle
description: LONDON  American private equity firms are playing a waiting game in Europe.

title: Comcast Streaming Service Raises Net-Neutrality Concerns
description: 12:35 p.m., March 31 | Updated  Adding statement from Comcast at end.

title: Bad Wire in Heart Device Led to 22 Deaths, Study Says
description: A defect in wires that connect hearts to defibrillators caused at least 22 deaths, possibly as a result of a short circuit that is difficult to detect during routine monitoring, according to a study in the journal Heart Rhythm.

title: Slain Teenagers Parents Appear on Capitol Hill
description: The parents of Trayvon Martin called on the public on Tuesday to refrain from violence and from trying to apprehend the man who fatally shot their son last month. We recognize that a lot of people are doing things on behalf of Trayvon Martin, his mother, Sybrina Fulton, said at a news conference after briefly appearing at a forum on Capitol Hill organized by House Democrats. We decided that we want this done peacefully. We want you to protest, we want you to rally. But we want to make sure its a peaceful rally so your voices can be heard. A lawyer for the family, Benjamin Crump, said relatives dont want anyone making an arrest of George Zimmerman, the man who shot the teenager on Feb. 26, other than the authorities. A group called the New Black Panthers has said it will give a $10,000 reward to anyone who captures Mr. Zimmerman, who has been in hiding.

title: Schools Will Be Protected From Cuts Next Year, Walcott Says
Judge Bars Imported Drugs in Executions
description: A federal judge has prohibited the use of imported death penalty drugs and has ordered the Food and Drug Administration to collect the drugs from any states that have imported them. Judge Richard J. Leon of the Federal District Court in Washington ruled Tuesday in a case brought on behalf of death row inmates in Arizona, California and Tennessee. States that use sodium thiopental to render prisoners unconscious as part of their execution protocols reached out to foreign suppliers when the sole domestic manufacturer stopped producing the drug, which had not been approved for importation. The F.D.A. said it had no jurisdiction over execution drugs. Judge Leon wrote that the agency appears to be simply wrapping itself in the flag of law enforcement discretion to justify its authority and masquerade an otherwise seemingly callous indifference to the health consequences of those imminently facing the executioners needle. How utterly disappointing! Bradford Berenson, a lawyer for the inmates, said the decision proved that even death row inmates are entitled to the protection of the law.

title: Excerpts From Dickeys New Book
description: R.A. Dickeys new memoir, Wherever I Wind Up: My Quest for Truth, Authenticity and the Perfect Knuckleball, written with the Daily News reporter Wayne Coffey, is a refreshingly frank look at his troubled childhood, his success as a high school and college player, and his rocky 16-year professional career. Here are some excerpts:

title: Payton Continues to Plan for the Off-Season: His Own and the Saints
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  The setting seemed incongruous for such an unsavory subject. But nearly a week after he was suspended for the 2012 season amid revelations of a bounty system employed by the New Orleans Saints, Coach Sean Payton stepped in front of a towering arrangement of pink blossoms in the lobby of the Breakers Hotel and publicly addressed for the first time his role in the scandal that has shaken the franchise and preoccupied the rest of the N.F.L.

title: Giants and Cowboys in Opener
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  The Giants will host the Dallas Cowboys in the N.F.L.s season opener Sept. 5 at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Since 2004, the Super Bowl champion has hosted the opener, with the home team going 8-0 in those games.

title: Doctors Have Feelings, Too
description: IT was a little bit like looking in the mirror. We were the same height and build, the same age  mid-30s  and both of us had two young children at home. In another world, had we been friends, we could have easily shared clothing. But today it was me with the white coat, and her with the death sentence.

title: Get a Deal and a Reward, Just by Using Your Card
description: GIVEN that the market for daily deals is saturated with offers from Web sites like Groupon, flash sale sites like Gilt.com and credit card companies offering cash back and airline miles, it might appear that small businesses are raking in profits from customers seduced by such great deals.

title: Warning Flags Were Raised in MF Global Transfers
description: Some MF Global employees were aware of a shortfall in the firms customer accounts days before filing for bankruptcy on Oct. 31, according to people involved in the case, a revelation that raises questions about why the firm failed to safeguard client money and whether it withheld information from authorities.

title: Passengers Restrain Captain After Crisis on JetBlue Flight
description: HOUSTON  The captain of a JetBlue flight from New York to Las Vegas suffered a bizarre midair breakdown on Tuesday morning, forcing passengers to restrain him as the plane made an emergency landing in Amarillo, Tex., where he was removed from the aircraft and hospitalized.

title: Foreclosure Deal Credits Banks for Routine Efforts
description: In February, JPMorgan Chase donated a home to an Iraq war veteran in Bucoda, Wash., and Bank of America waived the $140,000 debt that a Florida man still owed after the sale of his foreclosed home. Over the last year, Wells Fargo has demolished about a dozen houses in Cleveland.

title: The Right to Sell Kids Junk
description: The First Amendment to the Constitution, which tops our Bill of Rights, guarantees  theoretically, at least  things we all care about. So much is here: freedom of religion, of the press, of speech, the right to assemble and more. Yet its stealthily and incredibly being invoked to safeguard the nearly unimpeded right of a handful of powerful corporations to market junk food to children.

title: Independent Agency Gets New Powers to Prosecute New York Police Officers
description: Lawyers for the independent agency that investigates allegations of police abuse in New York have been given wide new powers to prosecute officers in misconduct cases under an agreement city officials reached on Tuesday.

title: Parents of Florida Teenager Killed in Shooting Call for Peaceful Protest
description: The parents of Trayvon Martin called on the public on Tuesday to refrain from violence or trying to apprehend the man who fatally shot their son last month.

title: Witness Testifies How Plot to Kill Officer Was Set Up
description: An admitted hit man for the Mafia recalled a ride he took with his boss through the streets of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

title: Knowing Cost, the Customer Sets the Price
description: P. T. Vineburgh has a sense of how much things should cost, and on a recent trip to the Boston jeweler Shreve, Crump & Low, he was not afraid to say so.

title: Massachusetts Residents Who Dont Comply With the Health Coverage Mandate
description: A demographic breakdown of the 2 percent of Massachusetts residents who illegally abstain from having health insurance

title: Soccer Rivals Face Off in Verse
description: If you watch the Champions League quarterfinals, you will hear soccer fans in their full-throated glory. Here is a look at popular chants among supporters of Wednesdays home teams.

title: With Empty Homes All Over the Globe, an Easy Position to Take
description: Ever since Gracie Mansion became the official residence for New York mayors, in 1942, very few of the 10 eligible tenants have turned up their noses at the chance to live, rent free, in the stately riverside home.

title: The Ryan Budget: Policy, or Just Politics?
In Massachusetts, Insurance Mandate Stirs Some Dissent
description: BOSTON  Wayde Lodor is part of the 2 percent: the roughly 120,000 residents of Massachusetts who lack health insurance despite the states landmark 2006 law requiring almost every adult in the state to have it. He is likely to face a penalty this year, having made enough money under the states guidelines to afford a health plan. But Mr. Lodor, an independent product development consultant from Leominster, remains defiant.

title: Elephants Down Under
description: Christchurch, New Zealand

title: On Tonight Show, Romney Is Quizzed on Potential Vice Presidents
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Mitt Romney came on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno to tape an appearance set to broadcast Tuesday evening, and found himself in a game of word association pegged to some potential vice presidential picks, should he win the Republican presidential nomination.

title: The Supreme Courts Momentous Test
description: In ruling on the constitutionality of requiring most Americans to obtain health insurance, the Supreme Court faces a central test: whether it will recognize limits on its own authority to overturn well-founded acts of Congress.

title: Tebow, a Careful Evangelical
description: Tim Tebow may be the most popular Christian in sports. He is a cross-cultural phenomenon, a preacher in a football players body.

title: Food Start-Ups Find a Home in Brooklyn
description: The rise of artisanal food like small-batch pickles, basement-cured charcuterie and hand-churned ice cream has been a boon to Brooklyns image. Now those products are helping the borough revive its manufacturing base, in a former pharmaceutical factory in South Williamsburg.

title: Israels Top Court vs. Outposts
description: Israels Supreme Court made an important contribution to justice and kept alive hope for a two-state solution with the Palestinians, when it ruled this week that Migron, an illegal outpost built by Israeli settlers, must be dismantled by Aug. 1. Now it is up to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to comply promptly, while making clear to the settlers that violent resistance will not be tolerated.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 27, 2012

title: A Dream Act Without the Dream
description: Republican politicians have overwhelmingly embraced an approach to immigration reform that offers only misery, arrest and punishment to the undocumented. That is popular with partys hard-right base, but toxic with Hispanic voters  which has led some Republicans to come up with proposals that seem to shimmer with promise but lead to the same no-future dead end.

title: Swedish Golfer Confronts Toughest Foe: Her Stutter
description: PHOENIX  On a recent Tuesday, the golfer Sophie Gustafson set about videotaping a six-and-a-half-minute speech she had composed for an awards dinner in conjunction with the Masters in April. Alone with a video camera in her Orlando, Fla., home, Gustafson expected the taping to go off without a hitch.

title: Fugitive Slave Mentality
description: Before he temporarily stepped down from his position last week as chief of the Sanford, Fla., police department, Bill Lee Jr., gave an explanation of his decision not to arrest George Zimmerman for killing Trayvon Martin. Lee said he had no reason to doubt Zimmermans claim of self-defense. Though Lee is no longer in the spotlight, his words linger for at least one compelling reason: his explanation bears an eerie resemblance to cases brought under the Fugitive Slave Law during the Antebellum period. Today, a legal standard that allowed the police chief to take Zimmerman at his word recalls the dark past of slave-owners claiming their property. The writings of Martin Delany, the African American political philosopher and activist, shed light on the uncanny resemblance.

title: Rezoning Transforms Character of Harlem Boulevard
description: The fragile yet promising community of new businesses around Frederick Douglass Boulevard from 110th to 125th Street in Harlem is struggling to maintain the charm that has attracted new residents, shoppers and diners in the face of large-scale development nearby and a still-shaky economy.

title: At Wagner, a New Coachs Rapid Rise
description: Bashir Masons first call after he was hired as the Wagners mens basketball coach Sunday night was to his mother, Kathy, in Jersey City.

title: Clean Water and the Spruce Mine
description: The Obama administrations decision last year to revoke a permit for a huge mine in West Virginia inspired hope that mountaintop mining, which has caused immense environmental damage across Appalachia, would soon be coming to an end. Now a Federal District Court judge in the District of Columbia has ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency exceeded its legal authority in blocking the mine. The administration must appeal. The Clean Water Act is on its side, as are the people of West Virginia.

title: Ex-Firefighter Hurt in 1989 Still Fights for Full Pension
description: Until that day in 1989, when he was badly injured in a fall while battling an arson fire at a vacant synagogue in Brooklyn, Firefighter Michael T. Romanelli was always ready for the next call.

title: Two Are Accused of Holding Woman Captive in Queens
description: When Nicole Nettleford had not seen her next-door neighbor for about a year, she assumed that the woman had left Rockaway Beach, Queens, for Pennsylvania with the rest of her family. A month ago, Ms. Nettleford said, she realized her mistake: The neighbor, Maureen Murray, was at a window, screaming for help.

title: Hal Fetner
description: Mr. Fetner, 51, is the president and chief executive of Durst Fetner Residential, a partnership formed in 2008 between Sidney Fetner Associates and the Durst Organization. The company focuses mainly on rentals, and its portfolio includes the 400-unit Epic in Midtown South and the Chesapeake on the Upper East Side.

title: 2 Israeli Leaders Make the Iran Issue Their Own
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak have turned into the odd couple of Israeli politics in whose hands sits the prospect of an attack on Iran. From opposite political traditions with distinct experiences and worldviews, the two have forged a tight bond, often excluding the rest of the Israeli leadership.

title: A Vintage Postcard From Splitsville, U.S.A.
description: Regrets, a new play by the British writer Matt Charman, is set in a humble motel near Reno, Nev., in 1954. Its a dusty, depressing way station for men whose marriages have hit the skids. Here they must park themselves for the requisite six weeks to earn official residency in the state of Nevada, which has always made it easy to untie the bonds of matrimony.

title: Theyve Got Us Surrounded
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Wow. At first, probably because of the way I solved it, I thought this was the most feminine grid I had ever worked. A tribute to us womenfolk, as it were. Then I ran into ED.

title: In Memoir, Dickey Details Sexual Abuse
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  If R. A. Dickey felt any anxiety Tuesday as reporters approached him at his locker, he did not let it show. With his familiar forthright demeanor, with teammates in earshot, he answered one question after another about being sexually abused as a child, and cheating on his wife as an adult, all of it revealed in his newly published memoir.

title: Strength and Weakness in the Campaign of Ron Paul
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Whatever happened to Ron Paul?

title: Fish Is Discovering His Best Form
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  It took a few months, but Mardy Fish, the No. 8 player in the world and top American, is finally playing up to his billing.

title: Gas Leak on Offshore Platform Forces Evacuation in North Sea
description: LONDON  A major gas leak on an offshore platform in the North Sea forced crews to evacuate it and other equipment in the area on Tuesday because of the risk of explosion, and ships and aircraft were ordered to stay miles away. Total, the French energy company that operates the platform, said it might take as long as six months to stop the release of gas.

title: Though Battered, Hayes Lifts UConn to Final Four
description: KINGSTON, R.I.  As she was ripping down another rebound early in the second half, the Connecticut senior Tiffany Hayes was fouled hard, and her head bounced off the floor. She went to the bench for all of 15 seconds, then returned, just as ferocious as before.

title: Link to Starry Past Lifts Stanford to Final
description: In his fifth season at Stanford, Josh Owens is a bridge to better times, when the Cardinal were still an N.C.A.A. tournament regular and a powerhouse in a strong Pacific-10 Conference.

title: Group Allied With Cuomo Tops Albany Spending List
description: ALBANY  Highlighting a shift in the way money is spent to influence government, the group that spent the most on lobbying in New York last year was a coalition of business leaders allied with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, according to a report released on Tuesday by the states Joint Commission on Public Ethics.

title: U.S. Judge in Michigan Acquits Militia Members of Sedition
description: DETROIT  Members of a Christian militia accused of plotting an antigovernment uprising were acquitted on sedition and conspiracy charges on Tuesday by a federal judge who said prosecutors had failed to prove that the group had concrete plans to attack anyone.

title: Al Jazeera Decides Against Showing Video Made by Gunman in Toulouse
description: The video, by all accounts, is gruesome.

title: Could Defeat in Court Help Obama Win?
description: If the Supreme Court decides to strike down the new health care laws individual mandate to purchase insurance, it will represent a remarkable election-year rebuke for President Obama  the rejection, by the nations highest court, of a central provision of his main domestic policy accomplishment.

title: Contingency Plans Are Few if Court Strikes Down Insurance Requirement
description: WASHINGTON  After a day punctuated by seeming skepticism from Supreme Court conservatives about the constitutionality of requiring Americans to buy health insurance, the justices will turn their attention on Wednesday to how much of the 2010 health care law might survive if they strike down that mandate.

title: With Late Goal, Rangers Find Bit of Breathing Room at the Top
description: ST. PAUL  As the nights of the regular season dwindle to a precious few, the Rangers coaches and players profess almost no interest in whether they can stave off the surging Pittsburgh Penguins and finish first in the Eastern Conference.

title: Corrections: March 28
description: NATIONAL

title: Gingrich Trims Staff, Focusing on Convention
description: 11:43 p.m. | Updated Read a revised version of this post.

title: Polish Ex-Official Charged With Aiding C.I.A.
description: WARSAW  The former head of Polands intelligence service has been charged with aiding the Central Intelligence Agency in setting up a secret prison to detain suspected members of Al Qaeda, a leading newspaper here reported on Tuesday, the first high-profile case in which a former senior official of any government has been prosecuted in connection with the agencys program.

title: On Street, Crowd Gives Louder Side of Health Law Argument
description: WASHINGTON  The arguments inside the Supreme Court building on Tuesday may have been about the finer points of law, but on the sidewalk outside, they were pure politics, delivered bluntly with megaphones, microphones and a lot of shouting.

title: Israel Group Adds a Softer Voice to Debate on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Memo to Congress: Not all American Jews support a military strike on Iran, either by Israel or by the United States.

title: Irish Return to Final Four With Ease
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  With a Final Four berth at stake and an encounter with rival Connecticut for a shot at a national title, Notre Dame could have showed up for Tuesday nights Raleigh regional final against Maryland tense and vulnerable.

title: U.S. and Pakistan Take Step to Mend Relations
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Obama took a symbolic step toward improving ties with Pakistan on Tuesday when he met with Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on the sidelines of a nuclear summit meeting in South Korea.

title: Gingrich Is Cutting Staff to Shift Focus to Convention
