description: Newt Gingrich is acknowledging that it is impossible for him to win the Republican presidential nomination outright and is cutting back on his staff and campaign schedule to focus on emerging victorious at the partys convention this summer.

title: After Killings in France, Muslims Fear a Culture of Diversity Is at Risk
description: TOULOUSE, France  As near to the Spanish border as it is to the Mediterranean, this sunny red-brick city has long been known as a place of welcome and diversity, far removed from the divisive politics of Paris. In contrast to much of the French south, the far right, with its virulent anti-immigrant stance, has little presence here. Nor does radical Islam.

title: Perception and Peak Performance
description: Like many of us during March Madness, Jessica Witt is a college basketball fan. She is also a professor of psychology at Purdue University. Those interests converged recently at a Purdue basketball game, as she watched fans noisily try to distract the opposing players during free throws. The fans hooted, stomped and waved streamers  but it didnt seem to have any effect on the outcome.

title: Word of the Day | filigree
description: filigree \fi-l-gre\ noun and verb

title: For the Knicks, a Busy Day Off
description: On a day when the Knicks canceled practice to rest their battered bodies, they were seen and heard around New York City.

title: The Closer: Baseball Begins, Quality to Follow
description: American League play  yes, the regular season  begins Wednesday, when the Oakland As and the Seattle Mariners face off in Japan starting at 6:10 a.m. Eastern. In reality, though, there is likely to be better baseball played in both the Cactus and Grapefruit Leagues as spring training begins to wind down.

title: When Home Is No Refuge for Women
description: This month, two womens stories, told courageously, helped to underline the reality of domestic violence in India, Nilanjana S. Roy writes about Nita Bhalla, a journalist, who wrote for the BBC about being physically assaulted by her partner and Meena Kandasamy, a poet and writer on social issues who wrote in Outlook, a national newsmagazine, of surviving a violent marriage: My skin has seen enough hurt to tell its own story, Ms. Kandasamy wrote.

title: Iran: U.S. Broadens Sanctions
description: The United States added an Iranian cargo airline, three officials from Irans Revolutionary Guards and a Nigerian trading agent to its Iran sanctions blacklist on Tuesday, on evidence they had conspired to funnel illicit weapons shipments to Syria and Africa disguised as humanitarian aid and building materials. The Treasury Department said the airline, Yas Air, had tried to transport AK-47 rifles, machine guns, mortar shells and ammunition to Syria as part of Irans support for Syria, which is also subject to American sanctions. David S. Cohen, under secretary for terrorism and financial intelligence, said the Treasurys action exposes Irans malign influence in the Middle East, Africa and beyond. Iran has previously denied sending weapons to Syria.

title: Italian Monti Seeks to Avoid Catching the Spanish Disease
description: MADRID  After Prime Minister Mario Monti of Italy last month held his first meeting with Mariano Rajoy, his Spanish counterpart, the Italian leader said that he had been positively very impressed by the reforms undertaken by Mr. Rajoy.

title: Egypt: Brotherhood Reaches No Consensus on Candidate
description: Leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood met Tuesday to decide whether the group should field its own candidate for president, a proposition that would require the Islamist group to abandon a pledge to back an outside candidate. But the meeting broke up late Tuesday without reaching a consensus, said Mahmoud Hussein, the Brotherhoods secretary general. A decision by the Brotherhood, Egypts most popular political organization, to run its own candidate could upend the presidential race, which is scheduled to begin in May. Mr. Hussein said the group would reconvene next Tuesday.

title: Eric Lowen, Half of a Singing-Writing Duo, Dies at 60
description: Eric Lowen, a singer and songwriter who was half of Lowen & Navarro, the duo that wrote We Belong, a pensive, urgent lovers plea that became a hit for Pat Benatar in 1984, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/28/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/28/2012

title: Zuckerberg in China: Let the Rumors Begin
description: HONG KONG  Mark Zuckerberg was spotted walking around Shanghai on Tuesday, which naturally led to a spike in online speculation about Facebook entering the Chinese market.

title: Tibetan Exiles Rally Around Delhi Self-Immolator
description: By Tuesday afternoon, posters of the man in flames were plastered along the narrow streets of Dharamsala, a hill station in northern India that is the home of the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the government-in-exile, Edward Wong writes in The New York Times.

title: Murdochs News Ltd. Rejects TV Piracy Claim in Australia
description: The News Corporation faced new accusations of hacking on Wednesday after media reports in Britain and Australia claimed that an affiliate of the media conglomerate had hacked into pay-television rivals to undermine their operations.

title: News Quiz | March 28, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: Boxs New Cloud Storage Shuns Microsoft
description: All the different computers and mobile devices that are used in todays offices are a headache for information technology managers, but they could turn into a strategic advantage for some companies. Just not, perhaps, Microsoft.

title: Is the $1.5 Million Maid an Isolated Case?
description: Shanti Gurung, a 22 year-old Indian maid, was recently awarded $1.5 million in damages by a United States district judge after her three years of service with an Indian diplomat and her husband.

title: Hong Kong Court Overturns Ruling on Domestic Workers
description: HONG KONG  A Hong Kong court on Wednesday overturned a ruling from last year that would have allowed foreign-born domestic workers to apply for permanent residency, the latest decision in a closely watched case.

title: U.N. Leader Presses Assad on Peace Plan
description: AL QAA, Lebanon  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, strongly urged President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Wednesday to immediately put into effect a peace plan he is said to have accepted that would rein in security forces in advance of negotiations to end a year of bloody revolt, but activist groups reported more assaults throughout the country.

title: March 28, 1979 | Nuclear Accident Occurs at Three Mile Island Plant
description: On March 28, 1979, Americas worst commercial nuclear accident occurred inside the Unit Two reactor at the Three Mile Island plant near Middletown, Pa.

title: The Abominable Snowman
description: MONTREAL  Nobody much minded Borough Mayor Luc Ferrandezs campaign to green up his hip Montreal neighborhood so long as it was a matter of planting flower beds and widening sidewalks near schools. Plans to slow traffic by changing circulation rules in residential streets did create some blowback, but nothing like the storm he set off when his brand of urban environmentalism took a turn for the radical.

title: Tibetan Who Self-Immolated in Delhi Dies
description: Jamphel Yeshi, the young Tibetan who set himself on fire Monday in New Delhi to protest Chinas policies in Tibet, died on Wednesday from his burns.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 28, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by David Prince at Math for America from the article Bypassing the Password.

title: Teenage Drivers and A.D.H.D.
description: WHO are the largest, and most closely studied, group of challenged teenage drivers?

title: Playing the Debt Deal Blame Game
description: A more surprising picture emerges of what led to the falling apart of the so-called grand bargain.

title: Obama vs. Boehner: Who Killed the Debt Deal?
description: Almost immediately after the so-called grand bargain between President Obama and the Republican speaker of the house, John Boehner, unraveled last July, the two sides quickly settled into dueling, self-serving narratives of what transpired behind closed doors. In the months that followed, some of Washingtons most connected Democrats and Republicans told me in casual conversations that they didnt know whose story to believe, or even what, exactly, had been on the table during the negotiations. A few mentioned, independently of one another, that the entire affair reminded them of Rashomon, the classic Kurosawa film in which four characters filter the same murder plot through their different perspectives. Over time, the whole debacle became the perfect metaphor for a city in which the two parties seem more and more to occupy not just opposing places on the political spectrum, but distinct realities altogether.

title: Following Weegees Footsteps
description: Its an obvious teaching moment. A group of about 25 photo-tourists are gathered,necks craned, on Centre Market Place in Manhattans Little Italy. A flash goes off every few seconds as someone tries to capture the perfect angle on the building before them, a modern condo.

title: Who Killed the Debt Deal?': Painting a Cover
description: Our cover story for this Sundays magazine is Matt Bais behind-the-scenes account of what went wrong in the debt deal negotiations in Washington. To illustrate the cover, we started with the headline Who Killed the Debt Deal?

title: What Small Things Have You Seen and Taken Note of Today?
description: Have you ever heard the phrase stop and smell the roses (that is, slow down and enjoy life)? How much do you think youre able to do that? Review today in your mind, from the time you woke up until now: what small, pleasant or interesting things have you noticed so far?

title: Tibetan Exiles Rally Around Delhi Self-Immolator
description: DHARAMSALA, India  By Tuesday afternoon, posters of the man in flames were plastered along the narrow streets of this town adopted by Tibetan exiles. Monks, merchants and tourists stared. In the early evening, more than 200 people walked through the town center waving Tibetan flags and carrying banners that proclaimed Jamphel Yeshi, who died on Wednesday, a martyr.

title: Tip of the Week: Customizing the Windows Start Menu
description: The Windows Start menu lists programs in alphabetical order by default, but if you would prefer to arrange things in your own way, you can override the alphabet. Just right-click on the Start button, choose Properties from the contextual menu and click on the Start menu tab in the Properties box. Click the Customize button, scroll down and remove the checkmark from the box next to Sort All Programs menu by name. Click O.K. to close the Properties box and apply the new settings. You can now drag programs into your preferred order on the Start menu.

title: The Early Word: Skepticism
description: Todays Times

title: Marital Status, the Safety Net and the Recession
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Fantasy Focus: The Ones Who Got Away
description: I will be playing in about 15 leagues this year (I havent done the final count, but I stop counting after 10) in various formats, including Scoresheet, Strat-O-Matic and Ottoneu in addition to a number of different roto-style formats. You would think with as many leagues that Im in, Id own pretty much anyone that I like, aside from maybe a couple of the elite guys thanks to my draft position or that player being kept in all of my keeper leagues, limiting my shots at him. But this player pool is so vast that there are plenty of my pet players that I annually get locked out from getting. Here are some of those that got away.

title: Iranian Official Cites April 13 as Date for Nuclear Talks
description: LONDON  A senior Iranian official was quoted on Wednesday as saying that long-awaited talks with world powers on his countrys disputed nuclear program would begin on April 13 and he hoped the venue would be Istanbul.

title: Belichick and Jets Ryan Running in Opposite Directions
description: Rex Ryan and the Jets are talking about getting back to their roots as a running team. Acquiring Tim Tebow is part of that shift.What is Bill Belichick doing?

title: Out of Jail, and Into a Job
description: About two months ago, Angel Padilla was walking near Madison Square Garden when the driver of a linen service truck started shouting and waving at him. Hey Angel! C.E.O.! the driver said. Look at me  Im driving now!

title: Do Good Bosses Have to Be Cutthroat?
description: The question came from a 20-something son sitting next to his 50-something father, who I hope was proud because the question was thoughtful and, Im sure, on the minds of many. Also, it took some guts.

title: Nokia Pins Smartphone Hopes on China
description: BERLIN  Nokia said Wednesday that it would begin selling its new line of Lumia phones in China next month through one of the countrys largest mobile operators as it looks to speed its recovery in the lucrative market for smartphones.

title: Bertelsmann Weighs I.P.O. to Finance Expansion
description: 2:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Kurds, Marginalized, Could Be Key to Syrian Revolts Success
description: LONDON  The Kurds of Syria could provide the tipping point in a year-long revolt against the dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad. But on Tuesday night their delegates walked out of opposition unity talks in Istanbul over the failure of their Arab partners to acknowledge their national rights.

title: India Tightens New Delhis Tibetan Districts on Eve of Summit
description: NEW DELHI  With President Hu Jintao of China arriving here for a diplomatic summit meeting, the Indian authorities sought on Wednesday to prevent Tibetans from staging anti-China protests, as paramilitary officers closed down the citys Tibetan neighborhoods. Tibetan activists said more than 250 people were jailed.

title: Jesus for Jews
description: JERUSALEM  Last week on Monday morning, in the busy dining room of the Inbal hotel, Tim Burt,an associate pastor at Living Word Christian Center in Minneapolis, told me a story of mistrust.

title: A Thriving Community of Banana Slugs
description: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

title: If Health Law Is Overturned, What Will Liberals Do?
description: If the Supreme Court strikes down all or part of President Obamas health care law, it will have unraveled a legislative compromise that many liberals had viewed with suspicion from the beginning.

title: A Clarion Call on the Food Supply
description: For anyone who thought the run-up in food prices in recent years was a fluke or a short-term blip, it might be time to reconsider.

title: Prick Up Your Ears
description: To understand what Jonathan Weiss, the founder of Oswaldsmill Audio, is doing in the world of sound reproduction  or what the general public refers to as stereo systems  you have to forget what you know. Or what you think you know. That stack of little black boxes connected by wires in your living room? Sorry, but as far as Weiss is concerned, that equipment has more in common with your microwave than anything he plays music on. The tunes you hear when you are on the treadmill, ear buds lodged in your auditory canals? If that noise were a visual, it would be a bad Xerox. Horrible, Weiss says.

title: Climate Prophet in Hot Water
description: Mumbai

title: SAT and ACT Test-Takers Face Tighter Security
Opinion Report: Supreme Health
description: From the editorial page

title: Dementia, From the Inside
description: Scott Kirschenbaums new film, Youre Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Dont, was supposed to be scripted and cast  a coherent story with a beginning, a middle and an end. Then he found his unlikely star: Lee Gorewitz, 78, who lives in dementia unit at Reutlinger Community for Jewish Living in Danville, Calif.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Tyco to Merge Flow Unit With Pentair in All-Stock Deal
description: Tyco International agreed on Wednesday to merge its flow control unit with Pentair Inc. in an all-stock deal, creating a new powerhouse in the business of industrial pumps and valves.

title: A Close Encounter With a Tufted Titmouse
description: I entered Central Park on a lovely Saturday morning a couple of weeks ago with my camera and the goal of taking a picture of the tufted titmice I had glimpsed briefly on an earlier visit. After several attempts that resulted in nothing more than gray-and-white blurs in my photos, I noticed a woman who was feeding the birds and had attracted quite a crowd of them.

title: British Economy Shrinks More Than Expected
description: LONDON  The British economy shrank more than previously expected in the fourth quarter of 2011, but some economists said that improving conditions in Europe could keep the country from falling back into a recession.

title: How About a Do Not Treat List?
description: At least some members of the Supreme Court seem to be persuaded by the idea that the government does not have the power to force us to buy health insurance. The whole idea seems specious and anti-free-market to me: if the government could legally enact Medicare for all, and tax all of us to pay for it, why is mandatory insurance not legal? It accomplishes the same thing, while minimizing government control of the health system.

title: Indias Minister for Sanitation Promises End to Open Defecation in a Decade
description: Sanitation in India is a dump.

title: Watchlist: Huge Group of Girls
description: Yes, its really catchy. And its pretty funny, especially the drunk girl roll call. (Becky  the drunkest one. Theresa  someones cousin.) And yes, I have observed the phenomenon it satirizes, though in my experience such groups tend to be less huge, both collectively and individually.

title: Scouting the Draft: Mississippi States Fletcher Cox
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Cybersecurity Researchers Team Up to Combat Online Crime
description: Last Friday, Microsoft employees and federal marshals raided command centers in Pennsylvania and Illinois used by criminals to run a botnet, a cluster of infected computers used to steal personal and financial information from millions of victims.

title: Daily Report: Do You Speak Computer Code?
description: The market for night classes and online instruction in programming and Web construction, as well as for iPhone apps that teach, is booming, reports Jenna Wortham in Wednesdays New York Times. People taking those classes say they are preparing for a future in which the Internet is the foundation for entertainment, education and nearly everything else. Some hope that they might become the next Mark Zuckerberg. But most say they are just trying to keep up with their regular jobs, which require a better knowledge of Internet tools.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Rise on Equipment Demand
description: Orders for durable goods rose in February for the fourth time in the last five months, the Commerce Department said Wednesday.

title: Forum for New Diplomacy
description: Lawrence H. Summers, president emeritus of Harvard University, and Roger Cohen, columnist with the International Herald Tribune, discuss economic policy, the United States, China and Europe.

title: European Lawmakers Reach Deal to Extend Caps on Roaming Fees
description: BERLIN  European lawmakers agreed Wednesday to extend the Continents system of retail price controls on mobile phone roaming charges for five years and enacted price caps on mobile Internet fees paid by traveling smartphone users.

title: Morning Buzz, March 28: Lighting the Wonder Wheel
description: Good morning. We might have a thunderstorm-y evening, but at least well have highs in the upper 60s.

title: Tibetan Activist Who Self-Immolated Leaves Letter Behind
description: Tibetan exile Jamphel Yeshi, who set himself alight on Monday in New Delhi and died on Wednesday, left a letter behind which seems to be an attempt to explain his actions.

title: Stroke of Genius
description: When Coach enlisted the talents of James Nares, it didnt ask the artist to riff on the brands logo  it literally gave him a blank canvas. A double-layered Italian canvas, that is. Five of Naress dynamic single brush-stroke paintings provide the motif for a collection of striking limited-edition totes, 175 each in black, green, blue, orange and fuchsia (above). $798 at coach.com.

title: Supreme Ignorance
description: Ill have much more to say about the Scotus/ACA stuff later this week; right now, I have travel (and teaching tomorrow, so time will be tight until Friday).

title: Image of the Day: March 28
Bout Asks Judge to Throw Out Conviction
description: Updated 11:30 a.m. | Viktor Bout, a former Soviet Air Force officer who was convicted in November of conspiring to sell anti-aircraft missiles and other weapons to men he believed were terrorists intending to kill Americans, apparently believes that he does not deserve the mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years  or any sentence, for that matter.

title: Its Always Time For Austerity
description: Jonathan Portes makes a nice catch: when the rating agencies upgraded the UK outlook, the Cameron government hailed this as proof that austerity was working; when they downgraded it due to poor economic performance, the Cameron government declared that this showed the need for even more austerity.

title: What Were Reading
description: Eater: The flamboyant mixologist Albert Trummers Theater Bar, which closed late last year for what were called minor renovations, will not reopen, according to a representative for Mr. Trummer.  Robert Simonson

title: Shares Dip Lower, Led by Oil Prices
description: The Wall Street rally of 2012 lost some steam on Wednesday as commodity prices fell, sending stocks lower as investors weighed the possibility that the time had come for the market to pull back.

title: Day Three: Supreme Court Hearings on Health Care
description: The Lede followed the third and final day of Supreme Court hearings on the health care overhaul law. Our colleague, Adam Liptak reports that several justices were considering either striking down the so-called individual mandate, or the entire law. On Thursday, please join Mr. Liptak and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care, for a discussion on Facebook at noon Eastern Time. They will be answering readers questions for an hour on The Timess Facebook page.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Bertelsmann Mulls an I.P.O., and Obama Is on Pinterest
description: Bertelsmann, the Germany-based media company that owns, among other things, the TV company RTL and the publisher Random House, said it was considering an initial public stock offering to finance the expansion of its digital and international businesses, DealBook reported Wednesday morning. The move would represent a major change in thinking by the Mohn family, which controls Bertelsmann.

title: Wednesday Reading: Get Your Harry Potter E-Books, Finally
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Lending Growth Slows in Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  Bank lending to consumers and businesses continued to grow very slowly in the euro zone in February, according to figures issued Wednesday, a sign that the so-called wall of money unleashed by the European Central Bank in recent months has not yet reached borrowers.

title: Ford Appoints New Director of Global Interior Design
description: As reported by Car Design News, Amko Leenarts, a 12-year veteran of Peugeot, was recently appointed to lead interior design strategy for Ford. The report was confirmed by Francesca Montini, a Ford spokeswoman.

title: The Enduring Consequences of Unemployment
description: Our economic malaise has spurred a wave of research about the impact of unemployment on individuals and the broader economy. The findings are disheartening. The consequences are both devastating and enduring.

title: Why the Debt Deal Failed
description: Matt Bai offers a primer in less than 60 seconds.

title: Leading Off: The Accidental Billionaire
description: O.K., lets see if weve got this straight. As Los Angeles Dodgers owner, Frank McCourt turned a storied franchise into a ridiculous melodrama centered on his dissolving marriage, alienated its loyal fans, let the iconic stadium languish, arguably turned a blind eye to the darkness gathering in Chavez Ravines parking lots, oversaw the whole Mannywood fiasco, ran up debt like a spoiled teenager with a parents platinum card, angered nearly everyone in Major League Baseball by being arrogant about it and then just escaped bankruptcy by selling the team for more than $2 billion.

title: Stoudemire Expected to Be Out Four Weeks
description: The Knicks are beginning a daunting playoff push, with 15 games remaining, 9 against probable playoff teams. And they must equip themselves for much or all of that time without Amare Stoudemire, who will be sidelined for at least two to four weeks with a bulging disk, the team said Wednesday.

title: Annies Shares Soar on Debut
description: 5:21 p.m. | Updated  includes closing price of stock.

title: Settlement in Battle Over Astor Estate Is Reached
description: Brooke Astors only son saw his inheritance slashed in half and had his control of the estates powerful charitable contributions stripped away as part of a settlement that ended a bitter, five-year dispute over the familys millions.

title: Comeback Keeps Rangers on Track
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  Brian Boyle, a fresh gap adorning his grin, scored a strange goal 3 minutes 7 seconds into the third period Wednesday night, sparking the Rangers to a 4-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Avengers to Close Tribeca Film Festival
description: While the Tribeca Film Festival has never been shy in scheduling Hollywood studio movies for its opening or closing nights (like The Interpreter with Nicole Kidman or Baby Mama with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler), blockbuster action pictures are not typically part of its usual fare. But this year, Marvels superhero team The Avengers will be the final act of the annual gathering, on April 28. The Avengers, starring Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo, Scarlett Johansson and Samuel L. Jackson, was directed by Joss Whedon, best known for the television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer. The comic, first published in 1963, unites Iron Man, the Incredible Hulk, Thor, Hawkeye, Black Widow and Captain America to battle evildoers. The movie, which will be released nationally on May 4, is expected to be one of the biggest box-office draws this summer.

title: Borrowers, Beware of Mortgage Relief Fraud
description: Mortgage relief fraud schemes are still around, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Trying to Let Go of My Wandering (Adult) Son
description: When my 22-year-old, world-traveling son was a toddler, he was already an inveterate wanderer. In the playground, he would seem engrossed in a game of follow-the-leader, and I would let down my guard and start a conversation with another mother. Seconds later, I would glance up to find my son on the edge of the park, chatting up the man with the four giant dogs.

title: The Daily Show Visits the Food Co-op
description: This could have been predicted. The torturous, rancorous debate among members of the Park Slope Food Co-op over joining an international boycott against products made in Israel became fodder for a segment on Tuesdays episode of The Daily Show With Jon Stewart on Comedy Central.

title: Santorum Loses Ground to Romney in Pennsylvania, Poll Finds
description: Rick Santorum, who once held a wide lead in the polls in his home state of Pennsylvania, has lost substantial ground to Mitt Romney among Republican voters over the last month, according to a new poll.

title: When the World Tackled an Environmental Threat, and Won
description: In 1974, Dr. Sherwood Rowland, a young research scientist, warned the world that chlorofluorocarbons, man-made chemicals found in aerosol sprays and refrigerators, were damaging the earths ozone layer. It took 13 years of bitter debate among governments, business leaders, scientists and concerned citizens before the world accepted his findings and moved to ban these chemicals through an international treaty, the Montreal Protocol, in 1987.

title: Business Day Live | March 28, 2012
description: MF Global executives will appear before Congress; the market for instruction in computer programming is booming; why higher taxes for the rich makes economic sense.

title: Business Day Live: Raising Top Tax Rates
description: MF Global executives will appear before Congress; the market for instruction in computer programming is booming; why higher taxes on the rich makes economic sense.

title: Town Hall Named National Historic Landmark
description: The Town Hall on West 43rd Street, whose stage has featured speakers from Eleanor Roosevelt to President Obama and performers like Billie Holiday and Bob Dylan, has been designated a National Historic Landmark. The announcement, made by the secretary of the Interior, Ken Salazar, makes the Town Hall the only new entry to the list of National Historic Landmarks in New York City.

title: New York Police Dept. Is Sued Over Stops in Private Buildings
description: A civil rights group filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday accusing the New York Police Department of illegally stopping tens of thousands of people in privately owned buildings across the city where officers had been given permission to enter by landlords.

title: James Nares at Work
description: Meredith Danluck visits Nares in his studio and discovers that his process is as mesmerizing as the work itself.

title: Pilati: Past, Present and Future
description: Making his first public comments since his final fashion show for Yves Saint Laurent, the designer Stefano Pilati, interviewed onstage at the French Institute Alliance Franaise on Tuesday evening by Pamela Golbin, made some witty remarks about his tenure at the house. When Ms. Golbin noted that the occasion marked the one-month anniversary of the announcement of his departure, Mr. Pilati replied, Yes, I thought it was quite chic to be here.

title: Your Knees, Their Seat: Discuss
description: GETTING a good seat in coach is a hot topic among fliers these days. Responding to the March 14 Practical Traveler column, How to Avoid That Cramped Seat, more than 200 readers weighed in on the subject, posting comments at nytimes.com/travel.

title: A Baghdad of Fresh Flowers, New Paint and Armored Delegations
description: BAGHDAD  These days, I barely recognize my hometown of Baghdad. It has been spruced up, painstakingly manicured for the Arab Leagues first meeting here in two decades  as my colleague Jack Healy writes.

title: JPMorgan Lawyer Says MF Global Gave Assurances About Transfer
description: MF Global employees repeatedly gave oral assurances to JPMorgan Chase that a crucial payment to cover an overdraft at the bank was not funded by customer money, a lawyer for the bank is expected to tell a Congressional panel on Wednesday.

title: The Source | Bright Ideas
description: With these chandeliers and sconces, everything is illuminated. More

title: For Sabres Fans, a Welcome Rerun
description: When it was all over, the only fans left in Washingtons Verizon Center were on their feet, decked out in blue and gold giving the visiting team a rousing ovation. Their team, all but dead and buried nine weeks ago in last place in the conference, had just pummeled the Capitals 5-1 on their home ice in what both teams acknowledged was their biggest game of the season.

title: Elder George Bush to Endorse Romney
description: The elder George Bush is set to officially endorse Mitt Romney in Houston on Thursday, campaign officials confirmed.

title: Forget Zou Bisou Bisou, the Sarkozy Trade Is the Hot French Export
description: If Nicolas Sarkozy loses Frances presidential election, he may want to set up a hedge fund.

title: Brittney Griner Has a Fan in Lisa Leslie
description: In her college days, Lisa Leslie occupied the space Baylors Brittney Griner does now: she was not only college basketballs It girl, but represented the next step up in the evolution of the game. She was a 6-5 center with all-court athleticism who could dunk and flash a 500-watt smile. She would go on to star in the W.N.B.A., winning two league championships with the Los Angeles Sparks, and win four Olympic gold medals with Team USA.

title: Greenery
description: At this time of year, grown-ups who have lived through many winters peer anxiously at treetops, yearning for even the barest indication of spring, and sigh in relief when those tiny buds first begin to swell. (Or maybe not, if they have allergies.) But for young children, each new spring seems like the very first, an occasion for wonder.

title: Reducing Nuclear Arms Is Not Alarming. Its Necessary.
description: A couple of readers have compared President Obamas live-microphone remark about flexibility after the election to the Etch A Sketch line from Mitt Romneys political adviser, and wondered why I came down harder on the latter than the former.

title: On Day 3, Justices Weigh What-Ifs of Health Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The day after the Supreme Court suggested that President Obamas health care law might be in danger of being held unconstitutional, the justices on Wednesday turned their attention to the practical consequences and political realities of such a ruling.

title: Banking Regulator Calls for End of Too Big to Fail
description: An annual report from a regional Federal Reserve bank is typically a collection of banalities and clichs with some pictures of local worthies who serve on the board.

title: Court Rules Against Pilot Penalized for Hiding His H.I.V. Status
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a private pilot whose H.I.V.-positive status was improperly shared between government agencies cannot collect damages for the emotional distress he suffered when he was punished for hiding his medical condition from the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: New Polls Show Worries Over Gas Prices
description: New national and state polls show that the Republican candidates are still struggling to capture the attention and backing of voters, and while the public sees President Obama more favorably, he continues to face serious challenges to his re-election, particularly with the economy, gas prices and Afghanistan.

title: Dance Comes to MoMA
description: The Whitney isnt the only museum to involve dance artists in its programming. The Museum of Modern Art has commissioned the artist and choreographer Ralph Lemon to create a three-week program of dance performances entitled Some Sweet Day to be presented in the Donald B. and Catherine C. Marron Atrium Oct. 15 to Nov. 4.

title: Scene City: Dining by Design
description: Ralph Lauren and others are honored at a benefit for DIFFA.

title: Fighting on Fumes
description: The two armies, so evenly matched, could not have been more different as they set out to find each other on the cold New Mexico morning of March 28, 1862.

title: A Dizzying Display, by Design
description: CONSIDER the dining table. Then consider it again and again, and you have Dining by Design. The benefit dinner for Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, the event brought 460 guests to Pier 94 in Midtown on Monday to eat at 44 tables designed and set with dizzying and kaleidoscopic imagination by industry insiders.

title: Hogwarts on 42nd Street? Speedy Potter Parody Show Has Eye on New York Run
description: Following popular runs in Toronto and London, the stage play Potted Potter  an unauthorized parody of the seven Harry Potter books, performed by two actors at a breakneck 70 minutes  may arrive in New York this summer in time to capitalize on the family tourist market.

title: The Malevolent Metropolis
description: When you have a book or movie phenomenon on the scale of The Hunger Games, you invariably have a story that straddles multiple fault lines at once, tapping into more than a few of lifes broadest and most enduring conflicts, accommodating several allegorical interpretations. The more that can be taken away from it, the more it draws audiences in.

title: Coastal California Fog Carries Toxic Mercury, Study Finds
description: Fog blankets the coast of central California each summer, hydrating the regions majestic redwood trees and chilling beachgoers. New research out of the University of California, Santa Cruz shows that the moist air also carries methylmercury, an especially toxic form of the heavy metal mercury.

title: On Mad Men, an Opening Scene Straight From Page 1
description: The opening scenes of the Season 5 premiere of Mad Men, set in 1966, depicted a sort of knucklehead-racism at work, when young men from the advertising agency Young & Rubicam dropped bags filled with water on protesters picketing on the Madison Avenue sidewalk below. Wet and angry, several protesters came upstairs to demand to know who at the firm had dropped the water bombs.

title: A Buzz Below: Cadillac Creates a Vibrating Seat Cushion, for Safetys Sake
description: If you feel a tingle in your backside while driving the Cadillac XTS sedan, you ought to pay attention.

title: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Islanders Edition
description: In this special edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Brian Compton of NHL.com joins Christopher Botta in studio and Scott Cullen of TSN calls in to discuss all things Islanders.

title: Stedelijk Museum Announces Reopening Plans
description: Closed for nearly a decade, the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam is set to reopen to the public this fall, on Sept. 23, with a grand exhibition of its permanent collection.

title: How New Girl on Fox Lost Its Ratings Mojo
description: Whats happened to New Girl? The Fox sitcom that exploded at the start of the fall season with bona fide hit ratings has moved into a pattern that is approaching a tailspin.

title: Moral Arguments
description: David: Oh my, my. We spend years arguing about Obamacare (now its official bipartisan name) and after all that muss and fuss it may be struck down. Thats certainly how it looks as the oral arguments come to a close. The view among people who know about this stuff was that the lawyer for the opponents of the law, Paul Clement, was like LeBron James on a fast break while the Solicitor General, Donald Verrilli, was like, well, me on a fast break. Somehow less than impressive.

title: Pope Calls for Authentic Freedom in Cuba
description: HAVANA  In the heart of Revolution Square in Cuba, with towering images of guerrilla heroes staring back at him, Pope Benedict XVI called Wednesday for authentic freedom in one of the worlds most authoritarian states.

title: Fossil Foot Indicates New Prehuman Species
description: Now it seems that Lucy shared eastern Africa with another prehuman species, one that may have spent more time in trees than on the ground.

title: Beyond Kony: How to Prevent Atrocities Before They Happen
description: The last few weeks have brought more evidence of the power of individualswhether movie stars like George Clooney in Sudan or the little known creators of the Kony 2012 viral videoto shine a light on the worlds worst crimes. This kind of attention is usually for the good, forcing government leaders to confront dire situations that do not typically get the kind of policy focus they deserve.

title: Mushroom and Grain Cheeseburgers
description: Barley is a traditional hearty partner for mushrooms, but brown rice is just as tasty in this burger.

title: Mistrial on Final Charges Day After Officers Conviction in Sex Attack
description: A day after a New York City police officer was convicted of sexually attacking a woman at gunpoint last August, a judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday on the remaining two counts of rape and related charges that had left the jury deadlocked.

title: On Our Radar: The Maldives Movie
description: Writing in The Times, Vikas Bajaj recounts how the political turmoil in the Maldives overtook The Island President, a new film about how climate change is threatening that island country and the planet. Reviewing the movie, A. O. Scott writes: The hope that infuses this movie makes it all the more upsetting to walk out of the theater and contemplate a looming disaster that the worlds leaders seem unable to prevent. [The New York Times]

title: Kentuckys Overlooked Weapon: Caliparis Offense
description: It does not take much insight to note that the Kentucky Wildcats are the most athletic team in the country. It pops off the screen; the Wildcats are bigger, stronger and faster than their opponents. That advantage starts with Anthony Davis but continues on through a roster that has five probable first-round picks in the next N.B.A. draft.

title: Vain Glorious | Aedes de Venustas Signature Eau de Parfum
description: Karl Bradl and Robert Gerstner established their jewel-box store on Christopher Street, Aedes de Venustas, as a premier source for elegant and avant-garde fragrances years ago. So it comes as no surprise that the aroma experts have now created a namesake Signature Eau de Parfum. Enlisting the help of the master perfumer Bertrand Duchaufour, whose previous credits include collaborations with LArtisan Parfumeur, the duo decided against a traditional perfume pyramid structure, which features top, base and bottom notes, in favor of a more even equation: hints of rhubarb and Madagascan vetiver meld in unison with rich incense of wood and leaf. The fragrance is contained in a decadent burgundy glass decanter with a gold atomizer and crest, a suitable match for the stores grand, gilded interior. A candle ($85) in a matching scent will be available on May 1. Get a whiff!

title: TimesCast | March 28, 2012
description: As Pope Benedict XVI wraps up his three-day visit to Cuba, a government official rules out some of the reforms urged by the pontiff.

title: Style.com/Print Returns for Season Two
description: The second issue of Style.com/Print (the new physical magazine from the editors of Style.com) is already printed, just 20 days after the end of the fall fashion season, and headed to newsstands next week. While its a bit thinner than the first issue, its more readable, partly thanks to a cleaner font used for the articles, and partly because it was an awfully newsy season, what with the departures of Stefano Pilati at YSL and Raf Simons at Jil Sander.

title: On House Floor, a Sweatshirt in Honor of Trayvon Martin
description: Breaching House decorum, Representative Bobby L. Rush donned a hooded sweatshirt and sunglasses on the House floor on Wednesday in honor of Trayvon Martin, the teenager fatally shot in Florida in a case that has gained national attention.

title: Moral Crimes Land Afghan Women in Jail
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Asma W., 36, ran away from her husband after he beat her, threw boiling water on her, gave her a sexually transmitted disease and announced that he would marry his mistress.

title: Team of Action Figure Designers Soldiers On
description: Last week, we published a case study that looked at a team of four toy designers  Chris Dahlberg, H. Eric Mayse, Jim Preziosi and Eric Treadaway  faced with a quandary: how to expand their business so that they are not so dependent on their one big client, Mattel. Their company, the Four Horsemen Toy Design Studio, has revenue of more than $500,000 a year, most of it from its contract work for Mattel. They have a staff of three to help with sculpting, painting and shipping in their workshop in Butler, N.J.

title: Business Day Live | Coding Catches On
description: March 28, 2012 - The market for instruction in computer programming is booming.

title: Language Deemed Offensive Is Removed From F.B.I. Training Materials
description: WASHINGTON  Training material used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation said agents had the ability to bend or suspend the law and impinge on freedoms of others, but that language has now been removed, according to a briefing the bureau recently provided to Congress.

title: The Danes Do Murder Differently
description: LAST June the first season of The Killing on AMC ended without a bang. A gun was pointed at a murder suspects head, and then there was a quick cut to the credits. The explosion came later, when complaints poured in that the show had failed to solve the season-long mystery the network had advertised with the teasing slogan Who Killed Rosie Larsen?

title: Maple Leafs Miss Playoffs Again, Draw Fans Ire
description: It seems to be a rite of spring in Toronto: the tulips come up and the trees flower, the birds start building their nests, and the Maple Leafs are mathematically eliminated from the playoffs.

title: Reaction to the Final Hearing on the Health Law
description: Reaction to Wednesday mornings Supreme Court hearing on the health care overhaul was more varied than reaction to Tuesdays hearing. Adam Liptak covered the hearing for The Times, and The Lede is following the case with a live blog. A sampling of other analysis and reaction follows.

title: Photo Replay: March 28
description: A view of the day in sports, with Canada holding its Olympic swimming trials in Montreal, and the world figure skating championships continuing in Nice, France.

title: Blast Risk Declines at Leaking Gas Rig, Company Says
description: LONDON  After the risk of explosion forced the evacuation of a leaking offshore platform in the North Sea, the French oil company Total said Wednesday that the situation was stable but that it was still examining how to stop the gas leak.

title: Business Bets on the G.O.P. May Be Backfiring
description: WASHINGTON  Big business groups like the Chamber of Commerce spent millions of dollars in 2010 to elect Republican candidates running for the House. The return on investment has not always met expectations.

title: Controversial Leonardo Restoration to Be Unveiled in Major Louvre Show
description: PARIS  When Londons National Gallery mounted its blockbuster Leonardo da Vinci exhibition late last year, advance tickets sold out the first week, online scalpers pocketed up to $400 per ticket and crowds lined up around the block at dawn for the paltry number of tickets still for sale.

title: Loeb to Yahoos Chief: Im Not a Short-Term Shareholder
description: The head of Third Point, Daniel S. Loeb, would like Yahoo to know that he is concerned about the technology companys long-term health, and is not pursuing an activist campaign just to generate short-term profit.

title: The Best Thing for the Democrats?
description: Now that the conventional wisdom on the health-care hearing has shiftedfrom a 6-3 or even 7-2 ruling in favor of the individual mandates constitutionality to a 5-4 ruling againstthe Democrats have to be thinking, if nothing else, about a public relations plan.

title: American Dance Festival Unveils New Executive Directors First Lineup
description: This summers 79th edition of the American Dance Festival, the first under its new director, Jodee Nimerichter, will feature world premieres from Jodi Melnick, Helen Simoneau and Reggie Wilson along with performances from festival regulars including the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Mark Morris Dance Group. Ms. Nimerichter took over the modern dance festival set in Durham, N.C., earlier this year, replacing Charles L. Reinhart, who retired at the end of 2011 after 43 years as director.

title: Ford Explorer Gets EcoBoost V-6 and a Touch of Swagger
description: On Wednesday, Ford introduced the 2013 Ford Explorer Sport, a performance version of its bread-and-butter S.U.V.

title: TiVo and DirecTV: Together Again
description: Its been three years since TiVo promised that a high-definition version of its DirecTV-compatible digital videorecorder would be available shortly. And now, it finally is.

title: N.F.L. Adopts Playoff Overtime Rule for the Regular Season
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Last season, the N.F.L.s postseason overtime rule got its first and only tests in two games, when the Denver Broncos beat the Pittsburgh Steelers with a touchdown pass on the first play of overtime in their playoff matchup and the Giants beat the San Francisco 49ers with a field goal in the N.F.C. championship.

title: Eiko Ishiokas Otherworldly Creations
description: The work of costume designer Eiko Ishioka, who died in January, has fascinated designers as diverse as Alexander McQueen, Issey Miyake and Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

title: On the Road to Recovery? Analyzing Economic Indicators
description: Overview | How do we know when the economy is recovering? What key indicators do economists and politicians use to judge the health of our economic system? In this lesson, students use New York Times resources to investigate and chart the current state of key economic indicators like household income and unemployment. By researching and analyzing each indicator and sharing their results, students develop a sense of how we identify economic recoveries.

title: For Group of 5 Nations, Acronym Is Easy, but Common Ground Is Hard
description: NEW DELHI  As the shock waves of the global recession convulsed Europe and the United States three years ago, the leaders of Brazil, Russia, India and China gathered for a meeting that seemed to signal a new era. They had global buzz as rising economic powers, a catchy acronym, BRIC, and an ambitious agenda to remake an international monetary system long dominated by the West.

title: City Submits Plans to Close and Reopen 33 Schools
Summoning the Fairest of Them All
description: NOW, I am no film critic, but I can say with some certainty that a sizable portion of the audience for Mirror Mirror, the Snow White film set for release on Friday, will be more interested in the clothes than the acting. This is because the film, starring Julia Roberts and Lily Collins, contains the final work of the costume designer Eiko Ishioka, who died in January and whose otherworldly creations have fascinated designers as diverse as Alexander McQueen, Issey Miyake and Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

title: Family Visits Rights Lawyer Held in China
description: BEIJING  Gao Zhisheng, the Chinese human rights lawyer whose whereabouts and well-being have been something of a mystery for the past two years, is alive and in good health, according to relatives who visited him in prison last weekend.

title: United MileagePlus Club Cards Perks for Frequent Fliers
description: Frequent fliers may want to take a look at the new United MileagePlus Club Card from Chase, which offers 1.5 miles for every dollar spent, membership in Uniteds airport clubs and a menu of other perks.

title: Europe Levies Big Fines for Freight Cartel
description: BRUSSELS  The participants in a freight cartel were caught not so much red-handed as green-fingered.

title: Bank of America Chiefs Pay Jumps to $8.1 Million
description: Brian T. Moynihan, chief executive of Bank of America, earned $8.1 million in 2011, a sharp increase from the $1.9 million payout he received in 2010.

title: The Old Rabbi Authenticated as a Rembrandt
description: For more than 50 years the portrait of an old man hung high on a wall in the private library of Woburn Abbey, the family home of the dukes of Bedford in Bedfordshire, England. Although the art collection there is world famous and includes 10 paintings by Van Dyck, 12 by Reynolds, 3 Gainsborourghs and a room wallpapered with 24 Canalettos, this painting was not considered anything special, just one of scores of lesser old masters lining the walls.

title: Divining the Supreme Court Health Care Arguments
description: There is no tea-leaf reading like Supreme Court tea-leaf reading. And in the immediate aftermath of Tuesdays landmark argument on the constitutionality of the health care laws insurance mandate, there was no shortage of attempted divination among the legal commentariat. The subject of obsessive fascination, not surprisingly, was the every utterance by the two justices considered most in play, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.

title: Only Provoke | Helmut Newton at the Grand Palais
description: Throw your chest out, Helmut Newton bellows to Cindy Crawford on a photo shoot in Monaco, in a scene from the documentary Helmut by June, currently on view at the Grand Palais in Paris in the first major show since the photographers death in 2004. The more chest I get, the better it will be.

title: JFK Library Unveils Hemingway Letters
description: Ernest Hemingway first met Gianfranco Ivancich at a bar in Venice in 1949, where the two struck up a conversation about their war experiences. It was the beginning of a epistolary friendship. Hemingway remained close to Mr. Ivancich and his sister, Adriana, whom he credited with inspiring his 1952 Pulitzer-prize winning novel The Old Man and the Sea during her visit to Cuba in 1950. Now the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation is making available 15 letters it bought from Mr. Ivancich, now in his early 80s, that Hemingway wrote between 1953 and 1960 as he wandered through Cuba; Ketchum, Idaho; Kilimanjaro; Nairobi; Paris; and Madrid. The library also acquired a manuscript of The Faithful Bull, a tale that Hemingway wrote for Mr. Ivancichs nephew.

title: Digital Notes: Sirius XM Claims Industrywide Conspiracy on Licenses
description: Last year, Sirius XM Radio drew criticism in the music industry for its decision to pursue direct licensing deals with record companies instead of dealing with SoundExchange, a nonprofit agency set up to process royalties for online streams and satellite radio. Now Sirius is suing SoundExchange and the American Association of Independent Music, a trade organization, saying those groups have violated federal antitrust law and erected an industrywide conspiracy to prevent it from making direct deals with labels.

title: Baghdads Last Summit, and the Very, Very Important People Who Never Came
description: TORONTO  How much Iraq, my home country, has changed. And I know all too well that the changes did not happen overnight. It was, and is, systematic destruction, and for me it started three decades ago during the run up to Baghdads last planned summit.

title: Motivation, Now at Hand
description: A friend lost 45 pounds and crowed that he owed his life to a fitness gadget the size of a lipstick. I had to investigate.

title: A Bevy of Beauties, and So PC
description: Whats an ultrabook?

title: Bringing Up an E-Reader
description: Julianna Huth, a second grader at Green Primary School, in Green, Ohio, is a convert to the digital word.

title: Harsh Words as Lawmakers Begin MF Global Hearing
description: The latest round of what happened at MF Global has just started, and already the sparks are flying.

title: Tracking Major League Baseball, a Perfect Sport for an App
description: Apps for football, basketball or hockey fans suffer from a nagging built-in problem: who wants to stop watching the game to take in more information through the app?

title: Starting Early, and Young
description: DR. AMI SHAH NAGARAJAN, 38, a specialist in integrative medicine who lives in Manhattan, estimates that she spends $150 a month on Mustela and California Baby products for her 3-year-old twins. I spend more on my kids than I do for myself, she said. Its worth it to me to get something pure for them.

title: Tablets for Children, Including Apps
description: Ready or not, here comes a swarm of Android touch-screen tablets just for children.

title: Test Results You Can't Rely On
Manhattan School of Musics Robert Sirota to Step Down
description: Robert Sirota, a composer and longtime educator, will step down as president of the Manhattan School of Music next fall, the school announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sirota took the job in 2005 with a commitment to serve for five years.Increasingly, he says in a statement, my opportunities as a composer have become more than I can handle on a part-time basis, and I am eager to pursue new commissions and projects.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Literary writers can sometimes forget their obligation to entertain. But this month brings a selection of novels and short stories that can hold their own with a thriller, in this case the third installment of Olen Steinhauers brisk Milo Weaver spy series.

title: Super Linda
description: NEGOTIATING the space between food and fun, New Yorkers could ask for no better architects than Matt Abramcyk  owner of Smith and Mills, the Bunker and Tinys  and Serge Becker, whose design credits include Miss Lilys and La Esquina. In February, they opened Super Linda, a tribute to South American food and drink in TriBeCa.

title: Goldmans Passage to India
description: 10:36 a.m. | Updated

title: Marketing Obesity to Children
description: What gives corporations the right to market junk food to children? The First Amendment, of course, which guarantees us all, and particularly those with lots of money, the right to express our views about everything from politics to the way Pop Tarts so deliciously fit our busy lifestyle.

title: Four New (Very Old) Landmarks
description: New York Citys newest landmarks are among its oldest.

title: Chris Rock Sells Late-Night Show to FX
description: FX is adding a new late-night show from Chris Rock featuring the comedian W. Kamau Bell to its lineup of original comedy series. During the weekly half-hour, of which the network has ordered six installments, Mr. Bell will take on provocative issues including politics, race, religion, media and sex, said Nick Grad, the executive vice president of original programming at FX. Mr. Bell is a founding member of the comedy group Laughter Against the Machine. I think Kamau is one of the funniest guys out there, said Mr. Rock, who is the shows executive producer.

title: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 3 Transcripts
description: The Supreme Court heard two cases on the third and final day of arguments challenging President Obamas 2010 health care law.

title: Academic Built Case for Mandate in Health Care Law
description: After Massachusetts, California came calling. So did Connecticut, Delaware, Kansas, Minnesota, Oregon, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

title: 5-Foot-8? Designed for You
description: AT 5-foot-8, Peter Manning isnt remarkably short. Still, he said, he has struggled to find clothes that fit him well since he was 10. My pants always had to be shortened, Mr. Manning said. Over the years, he guessed that he has paid hundreds, maybe thousands, of dollars in what he called a tailor tax.

title: Homes for $350,000
description: Properties in Charlotte, Phoenix and New Hampshire.

title: What You Get for ... $350,000
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

title: A Three-Bedroom Contemporary In Mexico City
description: This two-story glass-walled modern house pays homage to the stark and the industrial.

title: House Hunting in ...Mexico City
description: THREE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY IN MEXICO CITY

title: Brooke Astor Estate Settlement
description: The settlement documents in the court battle over the estate of Brooke Astor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, Cuba, India and Spain.

title: Report Shows Syrian Video Activists at Work, Breaking Some Rules
description: A new report by a French photographer who was in the Syrian city of Homs last month, during a period of intense shelling by government forces, shows that some of the activists who risked their lives to document the bombardment on video also embellished some of their footage, to make the dire situation seem worse.

title: An Artist in the Moment
description: AT the Paris opening earlier this month of Louis Vuitton Marc Jacobs, the exhibition at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs contrasting the Vuitton founder with its artistic director since 1997, a 6-foot-4 bearded fellow was explaining a tableau. It was a group of mannequins, one suspended from the ceiling on wires, with electric blue resin balloons for heads.

title: Wing Chairs
description: Kerry Joyce, a Los Angeles-based interior designer, searched for chairs that engulf you in their wings.

title: City Council Approves Wage Bill and Condemns Florida Killing
description: The City Council approved a measure on Wednesday that would require higher wages for some private-sector blue-collar workers, taking a step long advocated by labor unions but opposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the business community.

title: Polls Show Romney on Track for Win in Wisconsin
description: If Mitt Romney was harmed by the Etch A Sketch comment made by one of his advisers or by his loss in Louisiana over the weekend, it doesnt seem to be preventing him from being in position to win in Wisconsin, which holds its primary on Tuesday.

title: Council Bans Stickers of Shame, Overriding Mayors Veto
description: Neon colors may be back in fashion, but neon stickers are officially out  at least at the citys Sanitation Department.

title: Augustas New Issue: A Woman Runs I.B.M.
description: It has been nine years since a rather futile protest brought the issue of Augusta Nationals lack of female members to the fore, but this year it has risen again  in a much thornier form for the club that hosts the Masters.

title: Silent Partners No Longer
description: WHATEVER happened to omert? For decades, Mafioso from Joseph Valachi (The Valachi Papers) to Henry Hill (Wise Guys and Goodfellas) to Salvatore Gravano (Underboss) have violated the traditional code of silence, looking to cash in on their criminal pasts with potentially lucrative careers as newly minted truth-tellers.

title: An Updated Vertical Garden
description: The Vertical Garden: From Nature to the City, by Patrick Blanc, the French botanist who has devoted his life to turning the bare walls of buildings, inside and out, into green living worlds, has been revised and updated by W. W. Norton, which published the first English edition in 2008.

title: Just Opened | American Two Shot
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Where Math Teachers Go to Get Energized
Don Draper on the White Carpet
description: During the premiere of the fifth season of Mad Men on Sunday, one thing was clear: Don Draper finally has a home befitting a 1960s ad executive.

title: A New Vintage Marketplace From One Kings Lane
description: For those who like to decorate their homes themselves, two of the best-known online sources for vintage furnishings can present problems. Sifting through eBays vast selection can yield bargains, but it can also eat up a lot of time. And shopping on 1stdibs yields treasures but can eat up your whole budget. So Susan Feldman, a founder of the home-furnishings flash-sale site One Kings Lane, decided to create an online marketplace that could function as a cross between an edited-down version of eBay and a marked-down version of 1stdibs.

title: Nike Sues Reebok Over Tebow Apparel
description: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Nike won a temporary restraining order on Wednesday against Reebok, stopping it from selling Tim Tebow shirts and other apparel.

title: MF Global Employees Say They Are Cooperating With Investigation
description: Three of the four executives at MF Global called to testify before a House panel on Wednesday said that they were cooperating with federal authorities.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Economic vs. Political Change in Cuba
description: Marc Lacey, a deputy foreign editor, and Harvard Universitys Jorge I. Domnguez discuss whether Cuba can continue to evolve economically, but stay the course politically.

title: Motherlode Book Club: Accepting an Adult Childs Choices
description: The writer Anne Lamott has always struggled with acceptance. Its her modus operandi, her general state of being: she would prefer that things be one way, yet things, be they political or health-related or her only sons choices in life, persist in being otherwise. Id argue that we all feel that way, but Ms. Lamott experiences and articulates it with an intensity that most of us will never achieve.

title: Tortilla Factory Owner Arrested Over Business Practices
description: The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died after falling into a mixing machine has been arrested on charges of underpaying employees, falsifying business records and violating workers compensation and unemployment insurance laws, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Life on the Other Side of the Lens
description: FOR a while, the photographer Maxwell Snows favorite subject was people with guns. He hung out and took pictures with gang members in South Central Los Angeles, attended a meet-up of white supremacists in Kentucky, embedded with an Army unit in Afghanistanand did an S-and-M-inspired fashion shoot in which one of the well-dressed models pointed a rifle at his head.

title: A Trios Fourth Member Is Intuition
description: Erudition and clarity come naturally to the jazz pianist Enrico Pieranunzi, who has led a charmed career in his native Italy stretching back some 40 years. A fluid technician with a foothold in the classical tradition, he has always done well to indulge his exploratory urges, pushing beyond the respectable sprawl of his comfort zone. Otherwise he runs the risk of sounding dry and a little calculating, too much like a figure of the conservatory.

title: Arranging the Garden, Inside and Out
description: Almost any flower, leaf or branch can look good in the right vase. The combination is a study in texture, color, shape, the reflection of light.

title: The Weird World of Sports
description: While other sports photographers head to Florida for spring training, Sol Neelman drives through the mountains of Idaho looking for K-9 keg pulls and a skijoring event (skiers, pulled by horses). His itineraries are not shaped by the N.F.L. season or the P.G.A. tour, but by the schedules of weekend warriors pursuing oddball pastimes.

title: Bill-Signing Ceremonies? Oh, My!
description: President Obama next week will perform a function of his office that he has eschewed since November: signing legislation in public and in the presence of the lawmakers who helped pass it.

title: Going on Hikes and the Web in Search of Black Dance
description: Ive lost control of the platform Im curating, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones said at Danspace Project on Tuesday. He was referring to Parallels, a performance series he organized to pursue questions about black dance, questions he first raised in a series also called Parallels in 1982. This iteration, which has been running since early February, is in its last week, and Tuesdays program was a pleasant miscellany.

title: For Skittles, Death Brings Both Profit and Risk
description: Skittles are the candy of the moment.

title: Googles Driverless Cars Can Now Fetch Food
description: In late 2010, John Markoff of The New York Times broke the story that Google had developed cars that could drive themselves. Now, two years later, the company has taken this innovation to a new level, teaching the cars to do something really useful: Navigating a fast food restaurant drive-through.

title: Old-School Keyboard, Expressive Still
description: The pianist Alexei Lubimov has an unusually broad range of specialties, and he touched on the extremes during a short residency at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Last week he demonstrated his fascination with new music in two performances of John Cages 55-minute Four Walls (1944) in a staging of Four Walls/Doubletoss Interludes, with choreography created by Cages longtime partner, Merce Cunningham.

title: How War Came Home to Stay
description: A squabble is a noisy quarrel over a trivial matter. A polemic is an aggressive attack on the opinions and principles of others. A screaming match is a contest in which contradictory points are stubbornly reiterated, with no regard for whatever else has been said. A political talk show is a gladiatorial contest in which squabbles, polemics and screaming matches are exploited for their entertainment value.

title: Principal Named to Children's Aid Charter
Military Injustices Stay Fresh in Memory
description: Court-Martial at Fort Devens, at the Castillo Theater, depicts a little-remembered insurrection in the waning months of World War II. A detachment of black members of the Womens Army Corps, who had enlisted to be trained as medical technicians at Fort Devens in Massachusetts, had their classifications changed and were reassigned to work as hospital orderlies. After striking, then refusing orders to return to work, two of the women faced a court-martial. While largely overlooked, the conflict was covered by the black press, with an N.A.A.C.P. lawyer taking part in what was considered a battle for racial equality in the military. Even Eleanor Roosevelt got involved.

title: Romneys Humorous Tale of a Factory Closing
description: Mitt Romney opened a tele-town hall with Wisconsin voters on Wednesday afternoon with what he described as a humorous story highlighting his connections to the state. But not everyone found the story, about his father closing a Michigan factory, quite so funny.

title: A Trek Script Is Grounded in Cyberspace
description: For Star Trek fans it was like finding a lost Shakespeare play  only to have it snatched away by the playwrights heirs.

title: On Location | Athens
description: Peter Poulos has filled his 1,500-square-foot apartment with an eclectic mix of vintage finds.

title: Street Style, in Athens
description: IF its Sunday morning in Athens, Peter Poulos will most likely be on his way to the flea market. In five years of living in Greece, he has rarely missed it.

title: Clashes Raise Global Worries Over Sudan and South Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  After a brief, halting step toward reconciliation, military clashes along the long, disputed border between Sudan and newly independent South Sudan have stirred fears of a renewed conflict between the two sides.

title: A Settlement in the Astor Case
description: The Times reported on Wednesday that a settlement had been reached in the court battle over the estate of Brooke Astor, the queen of New York society who died in 2007 at age 105 after a long struggle with dementia. Her son, Anthony Marshall, and Francis X. Morrissey Jr., a lawyer who did estate planning for Mrs. Astor, were convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of defrauding and stealing from her. Both have appealed.

title: Mattresses Without the Spring
description: For a city that doesnt sleep, New York has a lot of mattress stores. The latest, Coco-Mat, opens Thursday in SoHo, in a 5,650-square-foot space on Mercer Street. The company was founded in 1989 and has 60 stores in 11 countries. Its mattresses are all handmade in Greece, from natural materials like seaweed, horsehair, goose down, wool and coconut or cactus fibers. No metal is used.

title: The Only Guy Out There
description: LUCIN, Utah

title: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Hastens and Others
description: Some cookware and knives are up to 60 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through April 1 (a Wsthof Classic forged six-inch cooks knife, originally $210, is about $90 and comes with a free paring knife, pictured); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

title: Wooing and Celebrating With Seasonal, Sustainable Blooms
description: True love and the convenience-store rose: One is perishable, the other oddly undying. (And both, in the end, can feel cheap and disposable.)

title: In Remote Utah, the Ultimate Man Cave
description: Ivo Zdarsky, who escaped from Communist Czechoslovakia in an aircraft he built himself, has made a home in an airplane hangar.

title: Son of Jersey Shore Hangs a Left
description: Paul DelVecchio, a k a Pauly D of MTVs Jersey Shore, belongs to a select category of performers who have turned their haircuts into careers. (Hes in the great tradition of Jennifer Aniston, before she became more famous for her breakups.)

title: Some Like It Hotter
description: IT was 105 degrees  as hot as a typical steam room  at Pure Yoga on the Upper East Side on a recent Saturday, but for the 16 women already perspiring through a series of pli squats in a ballet-based barre method workout, it wasnt blistering enough.

title: Outlaws Who Play It a Little Bit Safe
description: Eric Church came out in a puff of smoke, alone, baseball cap pulled low over his eyes, at the beginning of his sold-out concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom this month, singing Country Music Jesus: We need a second coming worse than bad/Some long-haired hippie prophet preaching from the book of Johnny Cash.

title: A Critical Test of the Health Care Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawker Beechcraft Is Said to Be Preparing for Bankruptcy Filing
description: The business jet maker Hawker Beechcraft is readying a bankruptcy filing, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, dealing a blow to its private equity owners, Goldman Sachs and Onex Partners.

title: New Editor at Billboard Magazine
description: Joe Levy, the veteran music journalist, was appointed the editor of Billboard magazine, the magazine reported on its Web site on Wednesday. He replaces Danyel Smith, who was appointed editor in early 2011 and stepped down in February.

title: Giants West:  Brandon Jacobs Joins Niners
description: The Giants already knew they would be seeing one familiar face in their visit to San Francisco next season. Now they will go against two.

title: Rexnord Prices I.P.O. at $18, at Bottom of Expected Range
description: The Rexnord Corporation, an industrial parts maker owned by Apollo Global Management, priced its initial public offering at $18 a share, at the bottom of its expected range.

title: Sluggish Venus Williams Falls to Radwanska
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Venus Williams stared straight ahead, her left hand resting on her leg, waiting for the half-dozen fresh balls needed for the 17th game of the match to be rolled out.

title: Hunger Games, the Soundtrack, Also a Hit
description: The Hunger Games cleaned up at the box office over the weekend, and its soundtrack has been a hit too. The album, featuring songs by Taylor Swift, Arcade Fire and Maroon 5, sold 175,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported.

title: Playwright, Producer Will Stretch in Premiere at Dallas Theater Center
description: The playwright Rajiv Joseph, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, and the Tony Award-winning musician Bill Sherman are collaborating on the new musical Fly, a darker re-telling of the Peter Pan story, which will have its world premiere in July 2013 at Dallas Theater Center, executives at the theater plan to announce on Thursday.

title: The Lighter Side of Destroying Jobs
description: Another candidate might have stayed away from a joke about closing auto plants. Considering that Mitt Romneys private equity company forced thousands of layoffs at companies it purchased, and that he opposed a bailout of the auto industry that saved hundreds of thousands of jobs, its a subject he would be well-advised to avoid.

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Hot Yoga Clothes
description: Inspiration for dealing with hot yoga's perspiration.

title: Designs for the Digital Age
description: Furniture that accommodates new technology and the changing ways we live with at home.

title: Furniture Meets the Digital Age
description: PHILIPPE STARCK was in town last week, ostensibly to introduce the Zik wireless headphones he designed for the French company Parrot. But Mr. Starck, who had just flown in from Paris, seemed more interested in holding forth on the future of design.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I want to replace my bathtub with a luxury walk-in shower. Would that be good or bad for resale?

title: The Arts and Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook I.P.O. and Superfast Security Cameras
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

title: Building Your Own Pit
description: IN 1968, Thurman Roberts and his son Scott built the first barbecue pit for the family business, the Salt Lick, in Driftwood, Tex. That pit, which is still in operation, helped establish the Salt Lick as one of the nations premier barbecue destinations.

title: Gearing Up to Grill
description: IM surrounded by neighbors who grill and smoke meats year round. I like to think its a coincidence that every time they grill, the wind blows in my direction.

title: Airport Screeners
description: To the Editor:

title: Outlaws in New York
description: Jason Aldean performed at Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday, and Eric Church performed at the Hammerstein Ballroom earlier this month.

title: Unflinching View of a Wandering Mind, No Breadcrumb Trail in Sight
description: Perhaps years from now, after a scientific breakthrough has turned Alzheimers disease into a memory as distant as polio wards are to younger Americans today, someone will stumble upon Scott Kirschenbaums hard-to-watch documentary, Youre Looking at Me Like I Live Here and I Dont, and be stunned. Ive read about Alzheimers, this person will say, but I had no idea what it was actually like.

title: Wing Chairs
description: AFTER a run of springlike weather, Mother Nature threw New York City a curve ball this week with winterlike temperatures. Its the kind of weather that makes you want to sit in front of a fire in a comfortable chair. A wing chair, perhaps.

title: Further Reading on Mr. Mandate
description: I have a profile now online about Jonathan Gruber, an economics professor at M.I.T. He helped design both the universal health care overhaul in Massachusetts and the Affordable Care Act, and is probably the economist most closely associated with the idea of an individual insurance mandate.

title: The States Ethics Record
description: To the Editor:

title: When Reacting Isnt Enough
description: William C. Rhoden discusses the protests by N.B.A. players over the Trayvon Martin killing.

title: Video: When Reacting Isnt Enough
description: William C. Rhoden discusses the protests by N.B.A. players over the Trayvon Martin killing.

title: When Stealing Isnt Stealing
description: THE Justice Department is building its case against Megaupload, the hugely popular file-sharing site that was indicted earlier this year on multiple counts of copyright infringement and related crimes. The companys servers have been shut down, its assets seized and top employees arrested.
