And, as is usual in such cases, prosecutors and their allies in the music and movie industries have sought to invoke the language of theft and stealing to frame the prosecutions and, presumably, obtain the moral high ground.

title: Adrienne Rich, Influential Feminist Poet, Dies at 82
description: Adrienne Rich, a poet of towering reputation and towering rage, whose work  distinguished by an unswerving progressive vision and a dazzling, empathic ferocity  brought the oppression of women and lesbians to the forefront of poetic discourse and kept it there for nearly a half-century, died on Tuesday at her home in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 82.

title: The Politics and Poems of Adrienne Rich
description: In 1973, reviewing Adrienne Richs seventh book of poems, Diving Into the Wreck, Margaret Atwood called it one of those rare books that forces you to decide not just what you think about it; but what you think about yourself. It is a book that takes risks, and it forces the reader to take them also. Ms. Rich, who died on Wednesday at 82, spent her career forcing such confrontations.

title: The Radon Threat Is Still With Us
description: Iowa City

title: Once Paytons Status Settled, Coaching Move Could Occur
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, headed home from the N.F.L. meetings Wednesday with the immediate future of his franchise still in flux. One thing seems clear, though: Bill Parcells is strongly considering the chance to coach, or at least consult for, the Saints while his friend Sean Payton is suspended for his role in the teams bounty program.

title: 3 Titles Won at North American Championships
description: On Sunday, the last day of the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships in Memphis, three major titles were decided.

title: Business Major Adds Marketing Deal to Major Title
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Standing on the tee box with their futures stretched in front of them like a long dogleg par-4, more women are choosing to try to cut the corner. Following the lead of pros like Jennifer Johnson and Natalie Gulbis, they are leaving their college programs early. Or, like Lexi Thompson and Jessica Korda, they are choosing not to attend college at all.

title: Claim of Fraud as Votes Are Counted in Brooklyn Special Election
description: What began as a pleasant day of official vote-counting in the undecided special election for state senator in south Brooklyn devolved into claims of fraud and disenfranchisement from both campaigns on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Bizarre Insights From Big Data
description: Sometimes unexpected data sources offer big insights.

title: Few Minds Are Changed by Arguments in Court
description: The morning arguments before the Supreme Court had grown tense just as the lunch crowd was packing into the food court at a downtown Atlanta office complex to watch news coverage of the hearing.

title: Fracas on JetBlue Flight Shows Gap in Screening
description: Airplane cockpits are meant to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors. But what if the threat comes from the cockpit itself?

title: Boehner Asks Obama for More Clarity on Flexibility Message to Russia
description: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, has asked President Obama to provide a better explanation of a private message he asked the Russian president to pass along to his successor.

title: Facelift Project for Hollywood Stirs Divisions
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood, once a sketchy neighborhood in a spiral of petty crime and decay, has been well on its way over the past 10 years to becoming a bustling tourist destination and nightlife district. But now it is on the verge of another transformation: to a decidedly un-Californian urban enclave pierced by skyscrapers, clustered around public transportation and animated pedestrian street life.

title: SATs Student Photo Database Draws Comparisons to Facebook Profiles
description: The advice college counselors give to students is consistent: Dont put anything online that you wouldnt want your mother to see. If upheld, the principle would help college applicants keep a clean public image, especially if college admissions officers ever investigate students photos online (they rarely do, says one admissions official).

title: From South Sudan to Yale
description: NEW HAVEN

title: A Young Spin on Incontinence, in Spots Skirting Images of Aging
description: SINCE its introduction in 1984, advertising for Depend, the adult incontinence brand by Kimberly-Clark, has tended to feature elderly actors golfing, gardening or fawning over grandchildren. The message, naturally, was that the products enabled them to be active without fear of embarrassment.

title: Details Offered on How Suspect Could Have Left Afghan Base
description: It is among the more intriguing mysteries swirling around the killings of civilian villagers in southern Afghanistan: How could the Army staff sergeant charged with 17 counts of murder have left his combat outpost, located in a dangerous region, not once but twice in the middle of the night to commit the shootings, as the Army says he did?

title: News Corp. Said to Weigh a Channel to Rival ESPN
description: News Corporation is in discussions to create a cable sports network that would compete with the industry leader, ESPN.

title: The Never-Ending Cold War
description: Two decades after the end of the cold war, Mitt Romney still considers Russia to be Americas No. 1 geopolitical foe. His comments display either a shocking lack of knowledge about international affairs or just craven politics. Either way, they are reckless and unworthy of a major presidential contender.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 28, 2012

title: Parties Brace for Fallout in Courts Ruling on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The law professor side of President Obama is highly intrigued by the Supreme Court hearings over the constitutionality of his health care law. He studied a summary of the arguments aboard Air Force One as he flew back from a nuclear summit meeting in South Korea.

title: Stock Market Flaws Not So Rare, Data Shows
description: Stock market disruptions like the ones last week that temporarily shut down part of the nations third-largest exchange and briefly halted the trading of Apple shares are more common than investors may think.

title: Silence, Then Frustration at MF Global Hearing
Things I Saw  No. 2
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: More Guns, Fewer Hoodies
description: The debate over the shooting death of Trayvon Martin seems to be devolving into an argument about the right to wear hoodies, but it really does not appear to be a promising development.

title: As His Numbers Go Up, Cano Moves Up in the Batting Order
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Robinson Cano talks about how it does not matter where he bats in the Yankees lineup. Of course, he can talk all he wants. It is his smile that belies him.

title: Activism and the Roberts Court
description: The ideological nature of the health care case was obvious on the last day of oral argument. By the time the proceedings were over, much of what the conservative justices said in court seemed like part of a politically driven exercise  especially because the issues addressed on Wednesday were not largely constitutional in nature. In fact, they were the kinds of policy questions that are properly left to Congress and state governments to answer, not the Supreme Court.

title: Second Suit Accuses Knoedler Gallery of Selling Fake Art
description: A South Carolina family filed a $25 million lawsuit in Manhattan Federal Court on Wednesday against what had been New Yorks oldest art gallery, Knoedler & Company, charging that the dealer and its former president conspired to sell it a fake Mark Rothko painting.

title: New Rules for New Power Plants
description: Power plants account for about 40 percent of Americas global warming emissions  with the bulk of that coming from coal-fired plants. On Tuesday, the Obama administration took another important step for public health and the environment, proposing the first nationwide limits on carbon dioxide from new power plants. If approved, the new limits will accelerate the shift from coal to natural gas and cleaner alternative fuels.

title: Young Takes First Steps Into Uncertain Future
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Chris Young said after his start on May 1 last season that he was likely to remember the night for a long time.

title: Third Day of Arguments on Health Care
description: On the third and final day of Supreme Court arguments over President Obamas health care overhaul law, the justices continued their questioning.

title: Where Are the Good-Government Republicans?
description: Senator John McCain recently denounced the Supreme Courts Citizens United decision as nave and politically ignorant, telling Roll Call, the Capitol Hill newspaper, that the consequences are manifesting themselves every day in what will someday be, sooner rather than later, a huge scandal. But Mr. McCain has no corrective, and the rest of the Republican Party seems determined to block any reform. Meanwhile, checkbook politicking has already hijacked this years Republican primary campaign.

title: A Teams Huge Price Tag Is Tied to a TV Windfall
description: By agreeing to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers for $2.15 billion, the group led by Magic Johnson is paying nearly two and a half times the $845 million paid to acquire the Chicago Cubs in 2009. The price tag is so big that it eclipses by around 50 percent what Malcolm Glazer and his family paid for the soccer giant Manchester United in 2005.

title: A Stamp Collection With Rare Delights Leaves a Familys Holdings for Auction
description: Many families have some treasures in the attic. Fred Frelinghuysen knew he had something, too, but he realized its significance only when the time came to let it go.

title: A Place in the Universe for a Daffy Musical
description: Good news, ardent fans of offbeat musical theater. The lovable gang from [title of show] is back with an endearingly goofy new diversion called Now. Here. This. Thin as a vanilla wafer but just as sweet, it opened on Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater, where the same collaborators first show played before its little-engine-that-could chug to Broadway. (It closed pretty quickly, but still: Broadway!)

title: Sing Along With Milo
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  If you ever attended kindergarten, youll appreciate this one.

title: Diplomatic Moves Increase Pressure on Assad
description: With his country unraveling in what looks like a sectarian civil war, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has been projecting himself as a confident and popular leader on the verge of victory, possibly, analysts said, borrowing lessons drawn from his only remaining regional ally, Iran, on how to resist outside pressure in a crisis.

title: Espada Aide Is Inconsistent as She Testifies in Fraud Trial
description: She was a prosecution witness, a longtime aide to former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. who was granted immunity to testify against the man she loved like a brother.

title: Examining Fans Rights to Jeer at Games
description: At a North Carolina State mens basketball game last month, the former Wolfpack stars Tom Gugliotta and Chris Corchiani were ejected from the arena  at the request of a referee  for protesting the officials calls. Gugliotta and Corchiani were seated behind the scorers table, and officials from both teams and others seated nearby said neither one used vulgarity or threatened the referees.

title: Anthony Takes Control, and Knicks Win Again
description: Amare Stoudemire was already a Knicks star when Carmelo Anthony came to the team last year. A season later, while Anthony was sidelined to injury, Jeremy Lin became a national sensation. What the Knicks were before Anthony arrived and what the Knicks have been in his absence has stubbornly framed the substance and the appraisal of Anthonys entire tenure with the Knicks.

title: Taking Heed of Criticism, Santorum Tones Down Attacks
description: LA CROSSE, Wis.  Rick Santorum has eased up on using phrases like worst Republican in the country when tearing into Mitt Romney. And he is no longer saying that a vote for Mr. Romney would be basically the same thing as a vote for President Obama.

title: For Top Judge, Tough Lessons on Family Court Bench
description: The couple stood awkwardly in front of the judge in Queens Family Court. He put his hands around your neck and choked you, the judge read from claims the woman had made. He told you if you ever left him, he would kill you.

title: Councilman Weighing Run for Comptroller
description: Daniel R. Garodnick, a Democratic councilman from the East Side of Manhattan, has told labor leaders, elected officials and others that he is likely to run for comptroller in 2013, even if that means challenging the embattled incumbent, John C. Liu, according to people who have talked to Mr. Garodnick in recent weeks.

title: Strauss-Kahn Wants Judge to Dismiss Accusers Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, whom prosecutors accused of raping a hotel housekeeper before dropping charges against him last year, asked a judge on Wednesday to dismiss a civil lawsuit against their client, saying his former position as head of the International Monetary Fund bestowed absolute immunity upon him.

title: Will Ferrell, No, Make That Ron Burgundy, Announces Anchorman Sequel
description: Will Ferrell donned the 1970s period garb (and mustache) of the titular newscaster he portrayed in the 2004 hit Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy to announce on Conan Wednesday night that he would be making a follow-up to that film.

title: Ron Stewart, Star of Maple Leafs Champs, Dies at 79
description: Ron Stewart played 21 seasons in the National Hockey League, was an All-Star wing and was on three Stanley Cup championship teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs. He also played for the New York Rangers and coached them. From the 1950s to the 1970s he had 276 goals, but he did a lot more than score.

title: Fit for Climbing
description: Paleontologists have found a partial foot of a prehuman species that lived at the same time as Lucys species.

title: In Congo, Self-Defense Can Offer Its Own Risk
description: CHULWE, Democratic Republic of Congo  When his brother was kidnapped and cut to pieces in the forest in 2008, neither the Congolese Army nor the United Nations peacekeepers stationed here did anything to protect him, said Guillaume Sadiki Bantu. When his nephew was killed in another attack just last month, he added, it was the same.

title: Union Chief Says New U.S. Rules for Immigration Detention Are Flawed
description: The leader of a union representing thousands of federal officers responsible for detaining and deporting illegal immigrants said Wednesday that new rules issued by the Obama administration for immigration detention centers nationwide were flawed and would make the system more dangerous.

title: Syrians Find Refuge in Lebanon
description: Sunni Muslims who have fled Syria described a government crackdown that is more pervasive and more sectarian than previously understood.

title: Weather Runs Hot and Cold, So Scientists Look to the Ice
description: Some people call what has been happening the last few years weather weirding, and March is turning out to be a fine example.

title: Zynga Prices Secondary Offering at $12 a Share
description: Zyngas insiders are set for a generous pay day.

title: Rubio Endorses Romney, Dismissing Vice Presidential Talk
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida endorsed Mitt Romney on Wednesday night on Fox Newss Hannity show, calling Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, a stark contrast to the presidents record.

title: Managing the Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation
description: Special report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

title: Neighbors Said to Be at Violent Odds in Syrian Crackdown
description: AL QAA, Lebanon  Sunni Muslims who have fled Syria described a government crackdown that is more pervasive and more sectarian than previously understood, with civilians affiliated with President Bashar al-Assads minority religious sect shooting at their onetime neighbors as the military presses what many Sunnis see as a campaign to force them to flee their homes and villages in some sections of the country.

title: The Power of Young Adult Fiction
Hollywoods Small-Town Charm Meets Mini-City Planning
description: A rezoning plan that would turn parts of Hollywood into a mini-city has won the support of key Los Angeles officials and set off a storm of opposition from residents.

title: Video Shows Man Who Shot Trayvon Martin Arriving at Police Station
description: Police surveillance video obtained by ABC News shows George Zimmerman, the Florida man who has sparked national outrage over his killing of an unarmed teenager in February, as he arrived at the Sanford, Fla., police station on the night of the shooting.

title: Feedback From Students Becomes a Campus Staple, but Some Go Further
description: BOSTON  Every other Monday, right before class ends, Muhammad Zaman, a Boston University biomedical engineering professor, hands out a one-page form asking students to anonymously rate him and the course on a scale of one to five.

title: Take Back the Senate, Senators
description: The current condition of the Senate constitutes a national emergency. Not long ago, Americans looked to the Senate to be, in Walter Mondales words, the national mediator, reconciling regional and ideological differences through thoughtful legislating, serious debate, hard bargaining and principled compromise. Today, however, after a 20-year downward spiral, the once great Senate is polarized, paralyzed and dysfunctional. Last month, as she announced her decision to retire, Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, described a Senate that routinely jettisons regular order, serially legislates by political brinksmanship and habitually eschews full debate and an open amendment process in favor of competing, up-or-down, take it or leave it proposals. In The New Yorker, George Packer described the Senate as the empty chamber.

title: Corrections: March 29
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Brutality Jolts Russia Into Action on Police
description: KAZAN, Russia  Even now, after the police officers who brutalized him have been fired and jailed, after federal investigators swooped in from Moscow to take charge of a widening abuse scandal, after an avalanche of attention from major human rights organizations and the international media, Oskar Krylov is still afraid  afraid of the police, afraid to live in Russia.

title: The Closer: Van Gundys Views Refreshing
description: It is often easy, especially in March, to get carried away when talking about college basketball. The hype surrounding the N.C.A.A. tournament tends to be all-encompassing.

title: Elevator Worker Electrocuted in Midtown
description: An elevator worker was electrocuted in a commercial building in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

title: Life, Interrupted: Facing Cancer in Your 20s
description: I was so excited for what lay ahead, I nearly forgot to wave goodbye to my parents. Armed with a college diploma, my first job offer, a one-way ticket to Paris and a new pair of heels, I was ready to take on anything. Little did I know, I would be back in New York seven short months later. But my parents would not be taking pictures at the airport or chatting about my future plans. I would be in a wheelchair, too weak to walk.

title: New U.S. Research Will Aim at Flood of Digital Data
description: The federal government is beginning a major research initiative in big data computing. The effort, which will be announced on Thursday, involves several government agencies and departments, and commitments for the programs total $200 million.

title: Word of the Day | moodiness
description: moodiness \m-de-ns\ noun

title: Goldmans Passage to India
description: Nestled in the diplomatic enclave of the capital city here sits the Leela Palace hotel. This week, its ninth floor has been home to the board of Goldman Sachs.

title: BRICS: Policy Block or Photo Op?
description: The new BRIC era has yet to arrive, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times ahead of the meeting of the groups leaders in New Delhi Thursday.

title: Waiting to Exhale in Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  The last time Burma held an election that was anything close to being fair, the military didnt care for the results and tossed them aside, as if the whole thing had never happened. The generals went about their jackboot business, cozied up to China and kept the main opposition leader under arrest for most of the next two decades. It was North Korea Lite.

title: Campaign Treasurer Accused in Fraud Will Enter a Plea
description: Kinde Durkee, the former campaign treasurer accused of embezzling millions from the campaigns of Senator Dianne Feinstein and other California Democrats, will enter a plea this week to multiple felony charges, according to a statement from the United States attorneys office in Sacramento.

title: Charles de Gaulle on Board for an Upgrade
description: PARIS  Charles de Gaulle is Europes second-largest airport in terms of passengers  61 million last year  and the seventh largest worldwide. Yet it doesnt get much love.

title: A Fashion Magazine Unshy About Baring a Bit of Piety
description: ISTANBUL  Across a neon-lighted corridor in a hyper-designed modernist loft here, a group of Eastern European models posed coquettishly for a magazine spread, their heads covered in brightly colored scarves.

title: Germanys New President Offers a Counterpoint in Style to the Chancellor
description: ROSTOCK, Germany  Now that Joachim Gauck has been sworn in as Germanys 11th postwar president, the countrys two highest-ranking officials share a worldview shaped by decades spent longing for freedom from East Germanys Communist system. But the paths of Mr. Gauck and Angela Merkel, Germanys chancellor since 2005, diverged once democracy dawned.

title: How India Sold Outsourcing to the United States
description: An inoffensive history of the Indian software industry, written by a good-natured man who frequently uses the word proactive in its telling, was released this week, Manu Joseph writes in The International Herald Tribune about the book The Coalition of Competitors, by Kiran Karnik.

title: Canada: Coins Pour Onto Highway
description: About one million Canadian dollars spilled across a remote portion of the Trans-Canada Highway when a Brinks tractor-trailer hit a rocky outcropping early Wednesday, the police said. Constable Marc Depatie of the South Porcupine detachment of the Ontario Provincial Police said a minivan and two more trucks plowed into the wreck. One of the other trucks broke apart, mixing its load of candy with the one- and two-dollar coins, which the police estimated to be worth more than $1 million. The Royal Canadian Mint, which was shipping the money from its plant in Winnipeg, Manitoba, declined to confirm the value of the coins. The driver of the Brinks truck and a passenger were critically injured. Constable Depatie said that a crane with a large electromagnet would be used to collect the coins.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/29/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/29/2012

title: Pakistan: A Summit of Generals
description: The Pakistani Army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, met with American military commanders  Gen. James Mattis, the central command leader, and Gen. John R. Allen, the top commander in Afghanistan  for the first time since American warplanes killed 24 Pakistani soldiers last November, in a visit that was seen as a first step in clearing the air between uneasy allies. The Pakistani news media reported that General Kayani told his visitors that he rejected the American military inquiry into the Nov. 26 airstrikes  a position the army has previously expressed in public. The American report found fault with both sides for the episode, which caused Pakistan to close NATO supply lines into Afghanistan. Pakistan insists that United States forces were entirely at fault and has demanded an apology. The meeting coincided with the official start in Islamabad of a parliamentary debate on diplomatic relations with Washington.

title: Yemen: Saudi Diplomat Abducted
description: A Saudi Arabian diplomat was kidnapped from the port city of Aden on Wednesday, in another sign of the breakdown of the rule of law, especially in the south. A Yemeni government spokesman, Mohammed Albasha, confirmed that the diplomat, Abdullah al-Khaldi, who works at the Saudi Consulate in Aden, was abducted as he left his home. Kidnappings as a means of extortion by tribes are relatively frequent in Yemen, and Saudi diplomats have been targets before.

title: Earl Scruggs, Bluegrass Pioneer, Dies at 88
description: Earl Scruggs, the bluegrass banjo player whose hard-driving picking style influenced generations of musicians and helped shape the sound of 20th-century country music with his guitar-strumming partner, Lester Flatt, died on Wednesday in a Nashville hospital. He was 88.

title: Crackdown on Tibetans in Delhi Includes Young Women
description: Tight security has gripped Indias capital since the Wednesday afternoon arrival of the Chinese president for an economic summit.

title: News Quiz | March 29, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: $7 Billion Public-Private Plan in Chicago Aims to Fix Transit, Schools and Parks
description: Chicago is embarking on a $7 billion plan to transform the citys infrastructure from the skies above to the pipes underground.

title: March 29, 1961 | District of Columbia Awarded Right to Vote in Presidential Election
description: On March 29, 1961, the 23rd Amendment was ratified, granting residents of the District of Columbia the right to vote for electors in presidential elections for the first time. The number of electors was fixed at the number awarded to the smallest state.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 29, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article In a Park Fountain, All of Those Coins Add Up.

title: Finding the Moments New Yorkers Ignore
description: Dimitri Mellos once imagined flying to exotic locales to take award-winning photos. He regretted coming to New York from Greece to pursue a Ph.D. in psychology at the City University of New York.

title: Who Captured the Fed?
description: Daron Acemoglu is Elizabeth and James Killian Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and co-author of Why Nations Fail: The Origins of Power, Prosperity and Poverty. Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Do You Know How to Code?
description: Instruction resources for learning Internet programming and coding are surging in popularity. How much do you know about Internet programming? Are you interested in learning how to develop Web and digital resources?

title: Spanish Trade Unions Start General Strike
description: MADRID  Heavy industry and large parts of the transportation network were disrupted on Thursday by Spains first general strike since the Popular Party of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy came to power late last year.

title: For Some Adolescent Girls in India, a Struggle to Stay in School
description: When 11-year-old Durga Jadav awoke to find that shed begun to menstruate, she wondered if shed return to school.

title: Whats in Your Envelope?
description: If there were an event like the Super Bowl that capped the college admissions season, then it would probably be Thursday night  beginning at 5 p.m. on the East Coast.

title: Tibetans Protest for Swaraj in Delhi Thursday
description: Tibetan protests continued in New Delhi on Thursday, despite a police crackdown in the city that started Wednesday.

title: Should Jets Go for Two With Tebow?
description: The Jets have said they are planning to use Tim Tebow in a variety of ways. Jason Lisk, a football analyst for the Big Lead,  has a suggestion:

title: The Early Word: Contingency Plans
description: In Todays Times:The Supreme Court appears divided over whether the 2010 health care law can survive without a provision called the individual mandate, Adam Liptak reports. As the justices heard arguments for the third and final day, they focused on the real world consequences of invalidating all or part of the law.

title: Syrian Rebels Continue Assassination Campaign, Killing 2 Military Officials
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian insurgents appear to have stepped up a campaign to assassinate senior military officials with a series of attacks that reinforce and exacerbate the hostility between the Syrian government and rebel fighters who argue that armed struggle is their only chance for survival.

title: Indian Students Look Regionally for Higher Education
description: While finishing high school near Pune, India, Pooja Modi started looking for university engineering programs online. Eighteen years old at the time, she knew she wanted to become a solar energy expert, Christopher F. Schuetze writes in The International Herald Tribune.

title: Peter Dinklage Was Smart to Say No
description: In January, the actor Peter Dinklage surprised himself during his own Golden Globe acceptance speech. Dinklage had won the award for best supporting actor in a TV series for his portrayal of the complex, sharp-tongued Tyrion Lannister, whos the closest thing to a hero in HBOs epic swords-and-sex hit Game of Thrones, which returns for its second season on April 1. As he took the statue from the presenter, Piper Perabo, the onstage microphone stand quietly lowered into the floor to accommodate the 4-foot-5 actor.
