description: 1/4 cup honey

title: East Coast Grill Corn Bread
description: 2 cups all-purpose flour

title: Peter Dinklage on Screen
description: Various roles played by the actor throughout the years.

title: The Corn Bread Matters Most
description: Chris Schlesinger opened the East Coast Grill in Cambridge, Mass., in the late summer of 1985, Tears for Fears on the radio and wood smoke in the air. It was a casual restaurant serving beach-town cuisine prepared over live fire by a classically trained chef with a surf rats bona fides. The food was bold and full-flavored, a menu born in the South but educated in the Caribbean, Asia  wherever waves crash and the sun-kissed sit barefoot, eating with their fingers as salt dries on their skin.

title: The Customer Is Always (Convinced That Hes) Right
description: Im sitting in the Milwaukee airport, having just met with a client near Sheboygan. This is the second visit Ive made to this client. The first was in late December, when I went to close a deal for a new boardroom table. I wouldnt normally jump on a plane to make a sale, but this was a decent-sized job for us  a little more than $50,000  and its for a company you may have heard of that has more than a billion dollars a year in sales. The company was building a new boardroom that would include video conferencing.

title: Europe Cracks Down on Cybercrime
description: LONDON  The European Union is preparing new steps to crack down on bot-herders, identity thieves, web hijackers and other online fraudsters who are skimming millions of euros a day from a growing number of its half billion citizens.

title: Leonardos Saint Anne, After Her Makeover
description: PARIS  When Londons National Gallery mounted its blockbuster Leonardo da Vinci exhibition late last year, advance tickets sold out the first week, online scalpers pocketed up to $400 per ticket and crowds lined up around the block at dawn for the paltry number of tickets still for sale.

title: Daily Report: New U.S. Research Aims at Digital Data Flood
description: The federal government is beginning a major research initiative in big data computing. The effort, to be announced on Thursday, involves several government agencies and departments, and financial commitments that total $200 million, reports Steve Lohr of The New York Times.

title: Little Talk of Tough Issues at Arab League Meeting
description: BAGHDAD  The last time leaders from the Arab world gathered for their annual summit meeting, a cozy ritual of speeches and self-congratulation, the date was March 2010, the host was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and the venue was a seaside Libyan town named Surt. The main topic was Jerusalem. Change and reform were not high on the agenda.

title: Time Is Nigh for Global Action, Manifesto Warns
description: An era has dawned in which humanitys impact on the earth could prove to be as great as ice ages or meteoric collisions, scientists, government officials and business leaders warned this week at a big environmental conference in London. The worlds approach to tackling environmental problems therefore must change rapidly if disaster is to be avoided, they said.

title: For a Week, Couric Will Co-Host Good Morning America
description: Next week, Katie Couric will co-host the news on ABCs Good Morning America.

title: They Just Cant Wait to Be King
description: Midway through Season 1 of Game of Thrones, viewers were treated to a particularly gruesome scene that showed a lovely princess named Daenerys Targaryen eating the raw heart of a horse.

title: N.F.L. Rule Changes and an 18-Game Season
description: News item from Judy Battista:

title: The Other Basketball Game
Helen Chaitman Doesnt Know When to Quit
description: Last week, in writing about the settlement between Irving Picard, the Madoff trustee, and Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the New York Mets, I mentioned the ongoing litigation brought against the trustee by a lawyer named Helen Davis Chaitman, who claims to represent some 800 Madoff victims, both net losers and net winners (who, I should point out, have very divergent interests). Inevitably, I received some emails from Chaitman clients who chastised me for daring to criticize, as one of them put it, a woman who has been a champion to so many elderly victims, logging many pro bono hours, fighting for victims whose gains would mean her own loss, and giving those victims a voice in the courts. Et cetera.

title: Off the Deep End
description: Just because the artist Jason Hackenwerth can create almost anything  including a frighteningly tentacled cyclops  out of balloons, doesnt mean hell work your childs birthday party. A graduate of the Savannah College of Art and Design, Hackenwerth formed a 13-foot-tall T out of thousands of inflated latex balloons. Like all of Hackenwerths creations, his T will deflate in a matter of months. Such impermanence is a big part of the artists practice. We need to learn how to let go, he says, because everything in life is temporary.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Silence, Then Frustration at MF Global Hearing | Top MF Global executives and their lawyers have been meeting with federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global and the firms misuse of customer money, according to testimony before a Congressional panel on Wednesday.

title: Opinion Report: Americas No. 1 Foe
description: From the editorial page

title: Thursday Reading: Cadillac Creates Vibrating Seat To Warn of Risks
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Apples Chief Visits iPhone Factory in China
description: HONG KONG  Following a string of critical reports about its contracting practices in China, Apples chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, visited Foxconn Technologys manufacturing plant for the iPhone earlier this week, media reports said on Thursday.

title: Rape Case Against Saudi Is Dismissed
description: MADRID  A panel of Spanish judges has dismissed a rape case against Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, a billionaire investor and nephew of King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, citing a lack of evidence.

title: Commenters in a Silly Tizzy Over Testing Topic Ban
A New Private School Consultant Enters the (Lucrative) Field
Roche Raises Its Hostile Bid for Illumina
description: 9:06 a.m. | Updated  with copy of Roches letter

title: Amazon Web Services Big Free Genetic Database
description: Amazons cloud computing unit, Amazon Web Services, will store for public use the entire contents of the National Institutes of Healths 1000 Genomes Project, a survey of genetic information from 1,700 individuals that is some 200 terabytes in size. Anyone can access the information for free, and there is no requirement to share any research results.

title: Deciding Foreign Policy in the Aisles of the Co-op
description: By a reasonably solid majority, the earnest burghers of Park Slope, Brooklyn, have struck a blow for olive paste, couscous, organic paprika and not one but two styles of kosher marshmallows. As a result of their vote Tuesday night, there will be no referendum  not now, anyway  on whether their Park Slope Food Co-op should join an international boycott of those products, whose cardinal sin is that they are made in Israel.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: News Corp. in the News, and Apples Chief in China
description: News Corporation was in the news on a number of fronts.

title: Image of the Day: March 29
For Walkers, a Sixth-and-a-Half Ave. May Take Shape
description: First came the bike lanes, creeping like overgrown ivy across the city streetscape.

title: A New Weapon in the Fracking Wars
description: In recent months, efforts to restrict future natural gas drilling in New York State have ranged from proposed buffer zones around gas wells for the protection of watersheds and aqueducts to outright drilling bans enacted by towns and villages.

title: Poetry Pairing | Station
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Maria Hummels Station with a 2011 article, Patient Voices: The Youngest Casualties of Cancer.

title: The Anti-Marriage Battle Plan
description: Its common knowledge that politicians and political organizations devise less-than-wholesome schemes for winning over voters. But its one thing to know that, in the abstract, and quite another to actually read a strategy memo thats not intended for public consumption.

title: Morning Buzz, March 29: A New Mayor at City Hall
description: Good morning. This Smoke and Mirrors Day will be mostly sunny and hover in the low 50s, casting doubt that this will actually become the warmest March on record.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: That guy on the front of the Quaker Oats box has he had work done?  Jeff Gordinier

title: France Suggests Deal Is Near on Tapping Oil Reserve
description: PARIS  Franois Fillon, the French prime minister, suggested Thursday that a deal was near among developed countries, including the United States, to tap strategic petroleum reserves to reduce gasoline prices.

title: Tsonga Rails Against Pro-Nadal Bias After Loss in Miami
description: After bemoaning his own play in a sloppy 6-2, 5-7, 6-4 loss in the quarterfinals of the Sony Ericsson Open in Miami, sixth-ranked Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France turned his ire toward the officials for what he perceived as bias toward his opponent, No. 2 Rafael Nadal, the 10-time Grand Slam champion.

title: Gefilteria: Upscale Fish Without the Fuss
description: When it comes to elaborate meal preparation, a Passover seder beats Thanksgiving hands down. And if some people are daunted by roasting a turkey, consider making gefilte fish from scratch. Most cooks do not even try. The default gefilte for most is a jar from the supermarket.

title: Leading Off: For the Dodgers, a Different Kind of Moneyball
description: New York may be the center of the financial world, but Los Angeles seems to be the center of the fantasy world. The two worlds collided this week when a group led by Magic Johnson announced that it had bought the Dodgers for a record $2.15 billion.

title: Vain Glorious | BB Creams Are Here!
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Toronto-Dominion Prepares for C.E.O. Transition
description: 5:20 p.m. | Updated  with comments from Ed Clark

title: Best Use of the 3? In Moderation
description: The 3-point shot has become one of basketballs most exciting ways to close a gap late in the game. Jeremy Lin launched Linsanity with key 3s that sealed Knicks wins. But if you are on the 3-point bandwagon, you might want to jump off. The team shooting a lower percentage from beyond the arc won 32 of the first 48 N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament games this season (after the play-in games), won 7 of 8 Round-of-16 matchups and all four regional finals. Thats 11 of 12 down the stretch to the Final Four, in the games that expose any weakness a team has and rewards strengths.

title: Fantasy Focus: Interpreting Past Performance
description: Theres not a huge range of values for established, healthy prime-age players like Dustin Pedroia or Robinson Cano. Maybe you get them for $1 cheaper than you thought, or someone pays $2 more, but for the most part, we know where they slot. The more interesting and variant players are those whose past performance (as measured by their stats) made a sharp jump or decline last year, and also those who because of youth and inexperience, or injuries and age, might change drastically. The question when evaluating these more difficult players is how to interpret their past performance. Or, put differently, how much to ignore it.

title: British Review Faults Banks for Weak Checks Against Corruption
description: LONDON  A review of 15 investment banks released on Thursday by Britains financial regulator showed that a majority lacked adequate anticorruption and bribery checks.

title: After 4 Years, Woman Accused in Babys Death Leaves Rikers
description: A Rikers Island correction officer looked confused on Wednesday morning when a group of Chinese immigrants  trailed by a crush of reporters from local Chinese news outlets  arrived to pick up an inmate who had been in the jail for four years.

title: $1 Million Gift to PBSs Masterpiece
description: After attracting record ratings for its British drama Downton Abbey, PBSs Masterpiece has received a $1 million gift from a San Diego donor.

title: Behind Every Harassed Child? A Whole Lot of Clueless Adults
description: Bully, Lee Hirschs moving and troubling documentary about the misery some children inflict upon others, arrives at a moment when bullying, long tolerated as a fact of life, is being redefined as a social problem. Just kids being kids can no longer be an acceptable response to the kind of sustained physical and emotional abuse that damages the lives of young people whose only sin is appearing weak or weird to their peers.

title: Royals Have an Emerging Star Without a Supernova Salary
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.

title: $200-a-Month Beauty Products for Babies?
description: In writing about the $180,000-a year nanny in The Times Magazine last week, Adam Davidson referred to credence goods: things whose value to the consumer cant be determined. Youre more likely to overpay for a credence good in the hope that a higher cost increases the likelihood of a benefit, he explained.

title: Off the Deep End
description: Jason Hackenwerth creates a sculpture for T Magazine's Spring Design issue.

title: What Might Replace Pink Slime?
description: Like many Americans, I have been both fascinated and repulsed by the recent discussion about so-called pink slime  low-cost, ammonia-treated beef trimmings that are used in making some hamburger patties.

title: James Endler, Who Oversaw Construction of World Trade Center, Dies at 82
description: James R. Endler, an engineer who helped manage some of the biggest construction projects of the 1970s, 80s and 90s, including the World Trade Center, Epcot Center at Walt Disney World, and the Renaissance Center in Detroit, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Business Day Live | March 29, 2012
description: The $2.15 billion price tag for the Los Angeles Dodgers; stock exchange disruptions occur frequently; and how airlines screen pilots for fitness to fly.

title: Maneuvering for an Immunity Deal
description: When a witness has valuable information and may be implicated in a violation, there are delicate maneuvers between prosecutors and defense lawyers. That is playing out behind the scenes for Edith OBrien, an assistant treasurer at MF Global, who could have crucial information about how millions of dollars of customer money went missing in the firms final days.

title: How to Teach Art in 89 Simple Lessons
description: When the American painter, sculptor and installation artist Paul Thek (1933-88) taught art classes at Cooper Union in the late 1970s, he wrote and then gave to his students a long, provocative and now famous list of questions and marching orders he titled Teaching Notes.

title: The Politics of the Mandate
description: In my Campaign Stops column this week, I make a version of the fashionably counterintuitive case that it would actually be good news for the presidents re-election hopes if the Supreme Court were to strike down the individual mandate while leaving the rest of the health care bill intact. (Notwithstanding the tenor of the oral arguments, this still seems to me like the second-likeliest outcome from the case less likely, even after the last few days, than an Anthony Kennedy-led decision affirming the mandates constitutionality, and more likely than a decision striking down the bill completely)

title: Business Day Live: The Value of a Sports Team
description: The $2.15 billion price tag for the Los Angeles Dodgers; stock exchange disruptions occur frequently; and how airlines screen pilots for fitness to fly.

title: A Bet on Mobile, Millennial Media Soars on Debut
description: Millennial Media, a mobile advertising network, surged in its debut on Thursday, as investors placed a big bet on the future of mobile communications.

title: Chinas Rumor Mill
description: BEIJING  A milestone in the history of Weibo, Chinas most popular microblogging platform, came and went rather quietly on March 16: a new requirement to register with your real name, ending the ability of Chinas netizens to post anonymously.

title: In Defense of Presidential Forecasting Models
description: Nate Silver has criticized election forecasting models before, but his latest post is perhaps the most thorough critique. I am not an elections forecaster, but I am a political scientist and consumer of these models. Nate has kindly let me abuse my privilege as an occasional guest blogger here at FiveThirtyEight to respond to his critique.

title: Obama Repeats Call to End Oil Subsidies
description: 3:25 p.m. | Updated President Obama called on Congress to end $4 billion in tax subsidies for oil and natural gas companies on Thursday, casting the issue as a choice between plumbing scarce resources versus investing in clean energy research.

title: Scientists Call for Practical Steps to Smooth Humanitys Journey
description: Planet Under Pressure, a four-day conference exploring how science can identify and limit risks in the face of increasing human impacts on the Earth, has ended* with a call for urgent action against the the unrelenting buildup of greenhouse gases. [April1, 9:17 a.m. | Update | An excellent summary has been posted on the Green blog.] But the prime focus, refreshingly, was on boosting science education and interdisciplinary inquiry and maintaining investments in systems and agencies devoted to comprehending environmental change.

title: Aerosmith Plans New Album and Tour
description: Aerosmith has teamed up again with Jack Douglas, who produced the bands blockbuster albums of the 1970s, and plans to release a long-delayed collection of new songs this summer to coincide with a North American tour.

title: GDF Suez Offers $9.5 Billion for Remaining Stake in British Utility
description: PARIS  GDF Suez, the giant French utility, is bidding $9.5 billion for the 30 percent of the British utility International Power that it does not already own, the two companies said Thursday.

title: Calling All Artists
description: A new book, Draw It With Your Eyes Closed: The Art of the Art Assignment, published by Paper Monument, is a collection of art teacher folk wisdom  the best classroom assignments that the contributors, most of them artists or art teachers, have given or received or even heard of.

title: Digital Notes: Spotify Extends Unlimited Free Listening in U.S.
description: When Spotify opened in the United States last summer, it offered new users six months of free listening without limits. After some confusion early this year about whether it would begin to add restrictions, as it has in Europe, the company announced on Thursday morning that it had extended the honeymoon for unlimited free listening.

title: Among Doctors, Fierce Reluctance to Let Go
description: The conversation took place two years ago, but Dr. Daniel Matlock still recalls it quite vividly. You tend to remember when a physician colleague essentially brands you a Nazi.

title: Illumina Shares Rise Above Roches New Offer as Fight Continues
description: Despite a new and higher offer from Roche Holding, the battle for Illumina appears to be far from over.

title: Around the Corner of Loss
description: The corner of McGuinness and Kent, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has undergone a minor face-lift in the seven years since my aunt Liz was struck and killed there. The Budget Rental Center that occupied the east corner is now an Enterprise Rent-A-Car, and theres a new BP service station across the street from it, in what used to be a vacant lot. You can no longer park on the east side of McGuinness, because the gas stations driveway flows out into the street there. Seven years ago, before the gas station, a row of parked trucks lined the curb, and it is for that reason that the driver of the Budget rental van, turning left onto Kent, was unable to see Liz as she rode her bike from the sidewalk to the street.

title: From Joe, a Richly Stocked Shop for Coffee Pros
description: The new store that Joe will open in Chelsea on Wednesday will be less a coffee shop than a coffee workshop. The shallow storefront will have a brew bar, a lever espresso machine and carry a comprehensive selection of home and professional gear.

title: Survey Points to Fragile Recovery in Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  An official gauge of the mood among consumers and businesses showed Thursday that the euro zone economy remained fragile, with manufacturers and builders growing more pessimistic about their prospects even though the sovereign debt crisis seemed to have eased.

title: Is the Economy Growing Faster Than We Knew?
description: There is a pleasant surprise in the latest batch of economic data released Thursday by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. Buried deep inside the governments revised estimate of fourth-quarter growth (revised but unchanged at 3 percent annualized) is an alternate measure of economic activity that is winning increased attention. And by that alternate measure, gross domestic income, the annualized pace of growth in the final three months of 2011 actually climbed to 4.4 percent.

title: News Corp. Steps Up Defense in TV-Code-Hacking Accusations
description: News Corporation fired back late Wednesday night against accusations that the NDS Group, a technology firm that it has a minority stake in, had hacked into satellite TV rivals in Britain and Australia.

title: Japan Nuclear Plant May Be Worse Off Than Thought
description: TOKYO  The damage to one of three stricken reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be worse than previously thought, a recent internal investigation has shown, raising new concerns over the plants stability and complicating the post-disaster cleanup.

title: Wheelies: The Long Arm of the Law Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Cologne, Germany
description: One of the oldest cities in Germany, Cologne has been drawing visitors since at least 50 A.D.

title: A Short History of Blood Chits: Greetings From the Lost, Seeking Help
description: Today, At War looks at the use of blood chits, a little-known and partially classified American military system designed to help lost or stranded service members find their way to safety.

title: On Our Radar: Organized Environmental Crime
description: At a conference in France, a high-ranking Interpol official calls for a crackdown on serious, organized and often transnational environmental crimes like elephant poaching for ivory, the killing of rhinos for their horns and illegal logging. Ounce for ounce, rhinoceros horn is now more valuable than gold, an expert on trade in endangered species tells delegates. [The Guardian]

title: 36 Hours: Cologne, Germany
description: ONE of the oldest cities in Germany, Cologne has been drawing visitors since at least the year 50 A.D., when it was officially founded as the Roman outpost of Colonia. Today the big attractions are the citys ancient (and gargantuan) cathedral, vibrant night life, a great native beer called Klsch, and eau de cologne, invented here in 1709, not to mention the ever-present Rhine River. But the city the Germans know as Kln is hardly resting on its former achievements. New surprises just keep showing up. After crossing off bucket-list items like exploring the cathedral and crawling through legendary Klsch pubs, you can easily spend an entire weekend focusing on the shops, restaurants and hotels that have opened (or reopened) within the past few years.

title: London Underground | Domestic Arts
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: 2-Year College, Squeezed, Sets 2-Tier Tuition
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  For years now, administrators at the community college here have been inundated with woeful tales from students unable to register for the courses they need. Classes they want for essential job training or to fulfill requirements to transfer to four-year universities fill up within hours. Hundreds of students resort to crying and begging to enroll in a class, lining up at the doors of instructors and academic counselors.

title: A New Payment Plan
description: My husband, who is long divorced, pays his ex-wife much more than required child support. And hes financed their childrens college accounts by twice the agreed amount. He does this because his ex-wife claims she is broke, even though she remarried a rich man and lives a lavish life. Worse, hes started hiding his payments from me. Its admirable that hes so generous, but after six years of marriage, with my own child entering college, I feel taken advantage of. Do I have the right to speak up?

title: Under Woodson, Genuine Signs of Improvement
description: When the Knicks rattled off five consecutive wins under Mike Woodson, it appeared as if the players were merely experiencing a honeymoon effect under their new coach. It seemed normal to think the novelty would wear off and the team would return to its mediocre ways.

title: Woman Grazed as Officers Gun Discharges in Raid a Floor Away
description: 6:37 p.m. | Updated A woman sleeping inside a Brooklyn apartment was grazed by a bullet or small debris on Thursday after a plainclothes New York City police officers gun discharged during a drug raid in an apartment a floor above her, the police said.

title: Unions Relish Idea of Romney as Nominee
description: Many Republican leaders are eager for Mitt Romney to clinch the presidential nomination, but an unlikely group  the nations union leaders  also relishes that prospect.

title: Second Afghan Insurgent Group Suspends Peace Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Stalled peace efforts in Afghanistan suffered another setback on Thursday when a second insurgent faction  one that has squared off against both the American-led coalition and the Taliban  announced it was suspending formal peace negotiations with the Afghan government, as the Taliban did earlier this month.

title: Stop Worrying About Raising a Mamas Boy
description: Whats a mamas boy? A wimp, of course, a child tied too tightly to his mothers apron strings, overly sensitive, incapable of detaching, ready to run to mama at the slightest hint of adversity. Norman Bates. Oedipus. Robert, the awkward brother on Everybody Loves Raymond. The men are ineffectual, the mamas domineering  and if youre looking for an analogous stereotype in the world of fathers and daughters (think father-daughter dances and Daddys Girl), you wont find one.

title: Old Power Plants Need New Rules
description: THE Environmental Protection Agencys proposal earlier this week to reduce greenhouse gases from new power plants was hailed by many environmentalists, but unless steps are taken quickly to bring existing plants under the rule, it will create a perverse incentive for companies to keep running older, more heavily polluting power plants. Thats bad economics that could lead to dirtier air.

title: Where the Hiring Is Strongest
description: Hiring started to pick up toward the end of last year, but you might be surprised to learn which cities were strongest in job creation.

title: Diagnoses of Autism on the Rise, Report Says
description: The likelihood of a childs being given a diagnosis of autism, Asperger syndrome or a related disorder increased more than 20 percent from 2006 to 2008, according to a report released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Trying to Inject Entrepreneurship Into the Greek Economy
description: Its not easy being Greek. Thats doubly so if youre an entrepreneur.

title: TimesCast | March 29, 2012
description: Syrian refugees say the Assad regime is leading a sectarian military campaign | Supreme Court hearings conclude | Earl Scruggs dies at 88.

title: Ivanka Trumps Turn on the Runway
description: My favorite look from the Ivanka Trump fashion show that took place on the fifth floor of Lord & Taylor on Wednesday evening, before an audience of everyday customers and most of the Trump clan, was the one Ivanka herself was wearing, a loose and light orange blouse tucked into tight off-white pants with equestrian patches. It was a little strange, though, to also see a model wearing the same pants on Ms. Trumps runway.

title: When Less Treatment Is More
description: The patient, a slender middle-aged woman whod had multiple operations and radiation for a cancer in her belly several years earlier, was struggling with nausea and vomiting again. Initially, the pattern was familiar: She would vomit every time she tried to eat. After a day or two, the problem, probably a kink in her intestines caused by residual scar tissue, would resolve on its own.

title: Rexnord Opens Above I.P.O. Price
description: If trading in shares of the Rexnord Corporation are any indication, investors are warming up to initial public offerings again.

title: Look of The Moment | Mlanie Laurent
description: The Look:  Dark Shadows. A frilly, lace-edged dress in black gets a feminine boost from coral sandals.

title: Ex-Councilwoman and Admirer Are Found Guilty in Yonkers Case
description: In the end, love did not set them free.

title: Baylor Armed With More Than Griner
description: Its quite understandable that Baylor junior center Brittney Griner is always the focus of attention. Being 6-foot-9, able to block shots, dunk and dominate down low justifies her unanimous selection to the all-America team.

title: The Floral Parade Has Begun
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: AT&T Plans Marketing Deluge for Nokia Windows Phone
description: AT&T is going all in with the upcoming release of the Nokia Lumia 900 smartphone. The carrier claims that the release, set for April 8, will be its biggest product introduction ever  surpassing even the release of the iPhone.

title: Mighty FC Concept: From On High, Jeep Delivers a History Lesson
description: To promote its Moab Easter Jeep Safari, the brands annual off-roading confab, Jeep unveiled a half-dozen concept vehicles this week. In composite, the six may stir memories of a scene in the first Toy Story film, when parts of the playthings are indiscriminately mixed and matched, with surreal results.

title: Surreal Moments Caught on the Street
description: These pictures might inspire an afternoon walk.

title: 'Art Breaks': Mickalene Thomas
description: The video art piece ReVay, from Mickalene Thomas, as featured in the MTV video series Art Breaks.

title: Touring the Harry Potter Film Studio
description: Visitors to the Warner Bros. lot northwest of London can ride a broomstick or pose in the Great Hall of Hogwarts.

title: Studio Tour Casts Spells Just Like Harry
description: MY daughter and I were halfway through the new Making of Harry Potter studio tour when we met Dan, whose job was to attend to our Harry Potter needs.

title: Restaurant Review: Upstairs at the Ten Bells in London
description: Theres a neon sign next to a dingy staircase in the back corner of the Ten Bells, a lively pub opposite Spitalfields Market in East London with Victorian-era tilework and a salacious history (the lore: two victims of Jack the Ripper were last seen drinking here).

title: Seeing Things | Pedro Guerreros Modern Times
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Britains Nuclear Plans Suffer Setback
description: LONDON  Britains plans for a new generation of nuclear reactors suffered a serious setback Thursday when two German energy companies decided to abandon a multibillion-dollar nuclear power project because of costs.

title: After Santorum Jokes About Pink Bowling Ball, Critics Pounce
description: LA CROSSE, Wis. If youre Rick Santorum, making a crack about a pink bowling ball is sure to draw some unwanted attention.

title: Into the Wild With a Dog at Your Side
description: AS a nature writer and former wilderness ranger, Ceiridwen Terrill has spent a lot of time roaming the wilderness, often with her dogs. Her treks with Inyo, a wolf and husky mix she adopted as a traveling companion, are the subject of her new book Part Wild. And her shepherd mix, Argos, has been trained to carry his own backpack. Even at 12 years old, he can put in the miles, she said on the phone from Portland, Ore., where she lives and teaches at Concordia University.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Did I miss the secret frugal way of getting to New Zealand (In Auckland, New Zealand, a Frugal Trifecta, Frugal Traveler blog, March 20)? Ive been dreaming about visiting for years but the airfare has always been a show-stopper.

title: Double Improvisation: Trinity Choir Changes Plans for Improvised Passion
description: The Trinity Choir, which had announced a performance of an improvised Passion based on a text of the St. John Passion created by the National Conference of Christians and Jews (now the National Conference for Community and Justice) at Trinity Wall Street on Sunday morning, has changed its plans.

title: Join Us to Talk About the Coming Baseball Season
description: The Final Four and the smell of cut grass mean only one thing: the start of the baseball season is upon us. The Timess baseball writers  Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh  will preview the 2012 season during a Google-plus video hangout on Monday, April 2, at 11:30 a.m. EDT. And wed like to invite selected readers to join them in the conversation. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to tell us what kind of a baseball fan you are, who you root for, and what questions you have about the upcoming season. Please also include a link to your Google-plus profile page and note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile and a video camera-enabled computer. We look forward to it.

title: St. Helena, Cursed Rock of Napoleons Exile
description: I STOOD on the aft deck of the 128-passenger Royal Mail Ship St. Helena in the gloom of a predawn morning last fall, my eyes riveted to an island that seemed to rise from the scalloped sea, a ruined cathedral of volcanic rock shrouded in mist. It was a steep natural fortress augmented by man-made battlements, bristling with rusty cannons that commanded the far reaches of the surrounding ocean. As the sun rose, its palette morphed from black to slate to tawny.

title: 2 Studies Point to Common Pesticide as a Culprit in Declining Bee Colonies
description: Scientists have been alarmed and puzzled by declines in bee populations in the United States and other parts of the world. They have suspected that pesticides are playing a part, but to date their experiments have yielded conflicting, ambiguous results.

title: Euro Zones Next Debate: How Big of a Bailout Fund?
description: COPENHAGEN  How big is big enough for a permanent bailout fund for the euro zone?

title: Secrets and Lies
description: Governments have good reasons for keeping secrets  to protect soldiers in battle, or nuclear launch codes, or the identities of intelligence sources, undercover agents and witnesses against the mob. (Naturally thats not an exhaustive list.) Governments also have bad reasons for keeping secrets  to avoid embarrassment, evade oversight or escape legal accountability.

title: Hard Line on Iran Places White House in a Bind
description: WASHINGTON  As American and European diplomats prepare for crucial negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program, the White House finds itself caught in a bind: for the diplomatic effort to work, American officials say, the Iranian government must believe that President Obama is ready and willing to take military action.

title: In New Orleans, Hotels Lure a Local Fan Base
description: MIDWAY through a Friday happy-hour gig, the bandleader Shannon Powell started taking requests.

title: The Trouble With Exchange Traded Notes
description: Over the past week or so, the market for exchange traded notes has become a bit unhinged  with two notes in particular coming in for wild trading swings.

title: Getting to That Safe Place
description: I MET him at the coffee place where I was working after Id dropped out of graduate school out West, many states and several states of mind away from the New England college town to which Id returned. I was floating between Gen X jobs, living in the aftermath of an emotionally and physically abusive relationship that had left me dazed and shaky, still absently rubbing my arms where bruises had marbled them, unable to look much in mirrors because I felt exposed, vulnerable.

title: Mark Leyners Other Other Career
description: In last Sundays magazine, Adam Sternbergh wrote about the re-emergence of beloved cult novelist Mark Leyner. Not included in Sternberghs account of Leyners whereabouts over the years is the authors stint at George, the politics and pop-culture magazine founded by John F. Kennedy Jr. For the second issue of the magazine in late 1995  that is Robert DeNiro dressed up as George Washington on the cover, somewhat less fetching than Cindy Crawford was on the debut issue  Leyner wrote about John Brabender, a political media guru who had just recently guided an unknown Rick Santorum to the U.S. Senate. Brabender, as you may know, is still very much a Santorum man, recently inaugurating a series of apocalyptic ads on the theme of Obamaville.

title: Artifacts | Bat-Sugar Bombshell
description: Shes the life of the party and shes going bats. Her golden hair fanning out in the wind and ribbons  or are they cocktail straws? rivulets of blood?  flying from her mouth, she kicks up her heels and heads into the dark, dive-bombing the target of her vampires kiss.

title: Met Opera to Broadcast Ring Cycle in Movie Theaters in May
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced that concurrent with its final live presentation of the Robert Lepage production of Wagners Ring des Nibelungen this spring (May 5-12), it will begin broadcasting the complete Ring cycle to movie theaters around the world, recycling the HD transmissions of the individual operas as they appeared over the last two seasons. On May 7, in the United States, Canada and some other countries, the Met will present Wagners Dream, a documentary on the production by Susan Froemke. The opera screenings will take place in the United States on May 9 (Das Rheingold), May 14 (Die Walkre), May 16 (Siegfried) and May 19 (Gtterdmmerung). Screenings abroad will take place at various times, extending in some cases into summer and, in Japan, through August. This is said by the Met to be the first time a Ring cycle has been presented on a big screen, though the production will not be entirely unified, since the first two operas were recorded with James Levine conducting, the last two with Fabio Luisi.

title: Creation and Expression: Reflecting on Text and Context in Art
description: Overview | What does art tell us about the time and place of its creation, and what does the context tell us about an artwork? In this lesson, students consider the work of Keith Haring in the late 1970s and early 1980s, which can be used as a framework for studying any artist and era. Students research historically and culturally significant events as a potential means to understand artists and their works. They create and present slide shows that incorporate images of the work with commentary that place the pieces in their historical and cultural context. Finally, they trace the legacy of their chosen artist via the work of artists who came later or their effect on culture.

title: An Online Tool  for Comparing Checking Account Fees
description: Comparing checking account fees isnt easy to do, as you know if youve ever tried to shop for a new account. Account disclosure formats vary, despite recent attempts at simplifying the way in which banks present information about fees, minimum balance requirements and other details to consumers.

title: Special Poetry Pairing | Adrienne Rich
description: Were posting a second Poetry Pairing today to honor the life of Adrienne Rich, who died on Tuesday.

title: Congress Extends Road Funds by 90 Days
description: WASHINGTON  Unable to come to agreement on highway funding and eager to start a two-week recess, Congress on Thursday passed a 90-day stopgap measure to continue paying for the nations highways and infrastructure programs, averting a halt in road and infrastructure projects because of the inability of lawmakers to agree on a broader transportation measure.

title: Duke Study Finds Miseducation From History-Based Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  This just in: Movie history can be hazardous to your intellectual health.

title: Couric on Good Morning America Could End No. 1 Streak at Today
description: With the news that Katie Couric will be co-hosting Good Morning America on ABC next week, the prospect that the Today show could finally lose a week has suddenly become more real than at any time in the last seven years.

title: A 1971 Armstrong Performance to Be Released as Album
description: Just five months before he died, Louis Armstrong gave a performance at the National Press Club in Washington, singing and playing the trumpet for nearly a half-hour at a party for the clubs newly elected president. That concert was recorded by CBS newsmen who attended the event, and the press club later pressed about 300 vinyl copies and distributed them to journalists who had attended. It was never released as a commercial album, even though it was one of the last times the jazz trumpeter performed before his death in July 1971.

title: A Readers Companion to Ultrabooks
description: In my Times column today, I reviewed practically the entire marketplace of ultrabooks. Thats Intels name for MacBook Air-type, superthin, metal-clad, $1,000-ish high-end luxury laptops. In all, I tried out models from seven companies.

title: A Coho Salmons Journey
description: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

title: A Very Long Road for Military Nuclear Waste
description: Slowly, slowly, the Energy Department is moving forward with solidifying the liquid nuclear wastes left over from cold-war weapons production. On Thursday, the department said it had closed two more of the 51 underground tanks at the Savannah River Site in western South Carolina. The high-level waste was mixed with molten glass to keep it chemically locked up for millennia, and the lower-level material was mixed with a kind of cement that is supposed to keep it in place until the radioactivity dies down.

title: In a Shift, the World Banks Next Likely President Is Facing 2 Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time, the World Bank is considering more than one candidate for its five-year presidency  a change that reflects the fast-growing clout of emerging economies, even as it raises questions over whether that change is coming quickly enough.

title: Snapguide Makes Anyone a Guide
description: This weekend Im going to learn how to make tofu. Im not going to take a class, or use a cookbook, Im going to follow instructions from a new iPhone and iPad application called Snapguide.

title: Five-Ku: Golden Age of the American Action Film Edition
description: What Rambo teachesAbout Green Berets. They doEverything shirtless.

title: Gingrich Backer Says Candidacy Is Nearing End
description: 8:59 p.m. | Updated Sheldon Adelson, the Las Vegas billionaire who has been the biggest backer to a group supporting Newt Gingrich, said this week that Mr. Gingrich had reached the end of his line in his bid for the presidency.

title: Albany Money Will Aid Effort to Remember the War of 1812
description: The War of 1812 is finally getting some respect.

title: Burk: Augusta Gender Issue Is Now I.B.M.s
description: For the second straight day, I.B.M. has taken the no-comment route on whether its new chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, should be extended an invitation to join Augusta National as I.B.M. chief executives traditionally have been. This is, of course, an issue because Augusta National has rather vehemently defended its male-only membership over the years and now that tradition clashes with an important corporate sponsor.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: How to Let People Know Theyre Not Invited

title: Clip: We Have a Pope
description: A scene from Nanni Morettis film about a newly elected pope who has an anxiety attack.

title: House Passes Republican Budget Plan
description: A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended Thursday with House passage of a blueprint that would transform Medicare, cut domestic spending to levels not seen since World War II and order up a significant overhaul of the tax code.

title: Leah & Seth
description: In this homemade video, Leah Raful and Seth Goldberg tell the story of their first date which they arranged through an online singles website.

title: Will Annan Save Assad?
description: Washington

title: Sitting on Cash and a Reason to Hire
description: Even when the recovery was in a much more sluggish mode, corporate profits stood out for their blistering growth, and companies were sitting on large piles of cash.

title: Collection of 24 Lotus Cars to Be Auctioned at Goodwood
description: One of the largest private collections of Lotus cars will be dismantled in June during the 2012 Goodwood Festival of Speed, the annual motoring celebration at the grounds of Goodwood House in West Sussex, England.

title: Colorful Realm at the National Gallery
description: A new exhibition in Washington brings together for the first time outside of Japan a suite of paintings that Ito Jakuchu made between 1757 and 1766.

title: Electronic Giant Vowing Reforms in China Plants
description: Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, the manufacturing giant Foxconn has pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside Chinese plants making electronic products for Apple and others. The move could improve working conditions across China.

title: Parental Quandary: Telling My Daughter About My Abusive Mother
description: E. writes that she comes from a pretty messed-up background. She never met her father, and her mother was a very difficult woman and estranged from most of her family.

title: Coachs Frank Approach Appeals to the Rangers
description: John Tortorella had a point to make to Ryan McDonagh, and he was not about to let the locker room celebration after the Rangers overtime victory over Columbus stop him.

title: Harry Crews, a Darkly Comic Novelist, Dies at 76
description: Harry Crews, whose novels out-Gothic Southern Gothic by conjuring a world of hard-drinking, punch-throwing, knife-fighting, snake-oil-selling characters whose myriad physical, mental, social and sexual deviations render them entirely normal and eminently sympathetic, died on Wednesday at his home in Gainseville, Fla. He was 76.

title: Laboring at Foxconn
description: The Fair Labor Association found widespread problems in labor practices at Foxconn, the electronics giant that supplies Apple and other companies.

title: Sprawling, Digital Roots Behind a Syrian Uprising
description: Karam Nachar wants to topple President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

title: Teeming With Transcendent Life
description: WASHINGTON  Have you ever felt put off by the imperturbable serenity exuded by the Buddha in countless artistic images? Maybe it is my American DNA or my underdeveloped consciousness, but I sometimes feel almost as alienated by his Teflon-like immunity to excitation as by the idealized agony of the crucified Jesus. They both seem so unnaturally abstract.

title: The Super PAC Pact
description: Congress desperately needs to overhaul the campaign finance system. Like most other things Congress desperately needs to do, it probably wontat least not in the near-term.

title: Wholesome Songsmiths Visit Steinbecks Brothel
description: Unless you happen to be a marine biologist, Pipe Dream is probably not your favorite Rodgers and Hammerstein musical. This little-cherished 1955 show, based on John Steinbeck novels and set among the bottom feeders of Cannery Row in Monterey, Calif., had a troubled gestation  Richard Rodgers underwent surgery for cancer just as it went into rehearsals  and it played just seven months on Broadway after a cool reception from the critics.

title: The Brightest of Creatures
description: The fact that living creatures produce sounds is not particularly startling, nor is the fact that they emit smells. But light is another affair. It is just as incorporeal, but there is something uncanny about the idea of organisms creating light, as if occult powers were at play. Such beings are so rare in human experience, and their habitats so distant and fragile, that they can even seem exotically angelic  or, in some cases, demonic.

title: Creatures of Light
description: The exhibition, opening Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History, explores bioluminescence.

title: Harry Crews, Beyond the Bravado
description: How do you like your blue eyed boy, Mr. Death?

title: Telling Scary Stories and Then Living Them
description: The monster that creeps into the satisfyingly shivery horror film Intruders doesnt just hide under the bed, it also lurks in dark corners, including those dimmed by your own imagination. The Spanish director Juan Carlos Fresnadillo knows that cinema is, like campfire tales and radio shows once were, a wonderful training ground. The movies are where many of us first learn to shudder at creaking floorboards, slow-turning doorknobs and all the other delicious, familiar frights that repeatedly bring us back for another genre helping. Horror stories, in other words, teach you how to be afraid and how to conquer your fear, which turns out to be the deft, amusing moral of this one.

title: Citys Jobless Rate Continues to Rise Faster Than Job Creation Rate
description: Updated 5:45 p.m.  New York City keeps on adding jobs but not fast enough to stop its unemployment rate from rising.

title: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Spain, Yemen, Indonesia and Mali.

title: Half of American Mobile Customers Own Smartphones, Says Nielsen
description: In the United States, smartphones are on track to outnumber traditional cellphones in 2012.As of February, about half of all Americans with cellphones were using smartphones, according to Nielsen, a research firm.

title: Parachuting to Land of Post-its and Cage
description: No conductor talks about music more engagingly than Michael Tilson Thomas. But he was curiously mum on Tuesday night, when the San Francisco Symphony opened a series of four American Mavericks programs at Carnegie Hall. With works by Cage, Cowell and Varse, and a new piece by John Adams on the program, I expected Mr. Thomas to be at his chattiest.

title: A Brawler With a Soft Side
description: An infantile way for a man to spend his adult years, sniffs Dr. Glatt (Eugene Levy), a pompous New England physician, when his son Doug (Seann William Scott) declares that a hockey enforcer, or goon, is his choice of occupation.

title: Whos the Most Self-Absorbed of Them All?
description: Is it possible for filmmakers to still peddle the old once upon a time in the age of Katniss Everdeen, the ferocious teenage warrior from The Hunger Games? The answer, from the evidence of Tarsem Singhs Mirror Mirror, a would-be comic and cheeky redo of Snow White, is yes, but not persuasively. The princess (Lily Collins) here smiles obligingly while flouncing about in a gown, but she also helps write her own happily ever after with a sword. Whether that makes her a feminist heroine or just another self-actualized Disneyesque waif may depend on your idea of empowerment. (In June the fairy tale gets another makeover in Snow White and the Huntsman.)

title: Sarah Charlesworth: Available Light
description: Susan Inglett

title: Jazz, Gospel, Dante
description: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including drama, readings, processions and a seder. Admission is free unless noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: BlackBerry Maker Posts Another Loss as a Former Chief Leaves Its Board
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion, the beleaguered BlackBerry maker, is open to selling or licensing parts of its business, its chief executive said Thursday after the company announced a fourth-quarter loss of $125 million and a higher-than-anticipated decline in BlackBerry sales.

title: Tavern on the Green Draws At Least Two Bidders  and Many No, Thank Yous
description: After kicking the tires of Tavern on the Green, the site of the former glamorous landmark in Central Park, at least two restaurateurs say they will put in a bid on Friday with the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation for a 20-year license to establish a restaurant and bar there.

title: Apollos Leon Black Donates $48 Million to Dartmouth
description: The financier Leon Black and his wife, Debra, are contributing $48 million toward a new visual arts center at Dartmouth College, the school announced on Thursday.

title: Sacred Music for the Holy Season
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Capturing the Body
description: No one person gets credit for inventing photography. The honor tends to be spread among several individuals, mostly in France and Britain in the 1830s and 40s, who were responsible for the innovations that set the medium in motion toward its many modern incarnations.

title: In SoHo, OnStar Stages a Show for Helicopter Parents
description: To demonstrate its new Family Link feature, OnStar, the in-vehicle safety and connectivity system, employed some method acting in New York this week.

title: Budget Analysis: Charter Spending Squeezing Education Budget
Out There | Pati Hertlings Night Job
description: Pati Hertling occupies a position in the art world that is both organic and anomalous. She is webbed among family, friends and lovers who populate a rising bicontinental scene: her twin brother, Alexander, is a co-owner of the upstart Parisian gallery Balice Hertling, which in 2011 opened a branch in New York called Balice Hertling & Lewis; her girlfriend is K8 Hardy, the chameleon performance artist whose photographs are in the current Whitney Biennial; her ex-girlfriend is Elizabeth Peyton, the portraitist-bard of high culture hipsterdom. Born in Berlin, Hertling exudes German reserve and discretion (though usually not in the eye makeup department), perhaps exaggerated by the fact that she is a practicing restitution lawyer. What ties it all together, loosely enough, is that she moonlights as a curator. A group show she organized is on view at the Swiss Institute in SoHo until April 15.

title: Is Gambling Immoral?
description: Michael Sokoloves cover article on casinos initiated a debate among our readers over the impact casinos have on communities and whether gambling is morally wrong.

title: Mets Cuts Resolve Some Positional Battles
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There were more empty lockers, more upturned clubhouse stools, as the Mets on Thursday continued to winnow their roster before opening day.

title: Artists in Dialogue at the Kitchen
description: The kitchen of the Misers childhood home was the place to discuss life. I confided in my mother as she prepared dinner, and debated with my father while he washed dishes  and sometimes a grubby child  in the sink. It was where they taught me about where I came from, and where we argued about where I was going, with a constant stream of commentary from siblings and grandparents as they passed in and out to refill their coffee cups.

title: Looking at the Body Through the Lens
description: Naked Before the Camera, which opened this week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, is a sweeping examination of photography showcasing the naked body. The show presents works mostly from Europe and the United States from 1850 to the present, including photographs by Nadar, Eakins, Muybridge, Brassa and Mapplethorpe.

title: Theater Listings for March 30-April 5
description: Theater

title: Online Features Expanded
description: AS buyers begin searching for mortgages this spring, they may notice that many of the major online shopping sites have been adding new user-friendly features. And if they look hard enough, they will also find another new service joining the crowd  this one from a man who calls himself the mortgage professor.

title: Dr. John Revamped
description: FOR decades Dr. John, the New Orleans pianist and songwriter, has stubbornly inhabited the psychedelic voodoo stage persona he created in the late 1960s. He still walks around with an African staff adorned with totems, bones, an alligator tooth, a vial full of a friends ashes and a juju bag.

title: Sectarian Killings In Syria
description: March 29, 2012  Syrian refugees who have fled to Lebanon say the Assad regime is leading a sectarian military campaign.

title: Morphing Figures, Mismatched and Distorted
description: In the Surrealist parlor game exquisite corpse, artists build a figure on an absurd assembly line. Typically a piece of paper is folded into sections and passed around; the challenge is that each artist must work on one particular segment without having seen the others. The results are often monstrous, or at least mismatched.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,901 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Antiques
description: THOU SHALT NOT FORGET

title: Former Ambassador to U.S. Cites Threats in Pakistan Over Memo Case
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Husain Haqqani, the former Pakistani ambassador to the United States, has told his countrys top court that he faces threats to his life if he returns from Washington to testify before a judicial inquiry into whether the government sought American help to stave off a military coup last year.

title: Collectors Personal Connections Lead to a Special Auction
description: It all started on their honeymoon in Rome. We were having breakfast at the Hassler, and all of a sudden my husband got terribly excited, Geraldine Pincus, a Philadelphia philanthropist and collector, recalled during a recent telephone interview. Henry Moore was sitting right near us. He was an artist David really admired.

title: Etch A Sketch Starts Its Own Campaign
description: The maker of Etch A Sketch is trying to put a positive spin on its status as a political insult with a new advertisement campaign.

title: What Is the Right Way to Honor Ike?
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Recommends More Testing for Obesity Drugs
description: Obesity drugs should undergo clinical trials to ensure that they do not cause heart attacks, federal advisers said Thursday, a requirement that could make it harder for such drugs to gain approval.

title: For Hard-Hit Seniors, Rental Options
description: ON a fixed income, Antonio and Nan LaGuidice struggle to meet the $1,700-a-month rent for their two-bedroom apartment in New Rochelle, and the costs of doctor visits, cancer treatments and medication that Mrs. LaGuidice, 72, requires. The couple, who share their place with an adult daughter, manage only by cutting costs so close to the bone that Mr. LaGuidice, 90, a former building superintendent and school bus driver who needs a hearing aid, cannot spare the money for one.

title: Closing Generation Gaps
description: In the post-everything era, whose advent coincided with the rise of digitization in photography, it has often seemed, paradoxically, as if nothing new can be done. The negative consequence of this is that contemporary photographs can look a lot like vintage ones; the positive outcome is that new and intriguing connections are often made between past and present. Luckily, there are many examples of the latter at the AIPAD Photography Show New York.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Googles Android Earnings and Fewer AOL Servers
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

title: Best Friends Rolling in the Hay (and in Flour, Too)
description: The youngish couples who swap partners in Four Lovers, Antony Cordiers shallow erotic daydream, are so attractive that to observe them making love repeatedly and intensely doesnt make you worry that you might be consuming soft-core pornography, although thats really what it is. The movie, originally titled Happy Few, is French, after all. French culture is very relaxed when it comes to portraying sex without shame, and the actors going through the motions are very good at it.

title: Challenge From the Right Tests Texas Speaker, Again
description: SAN ANTONIO  House Speaker Joe Straus easily quelled the Tea Party rebellion that threatened his reign in early 2011.

title: Three Dudes of Magic, Working the Strip (Mall)

description: FOR those living or working near flood plains along New Jerseys ocean or river fronts, its been nothing but bad news lately.

title: The JetBlue Incident
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Kentucky Beat an N.B.A. Team? Calipari Doesnt Think So
description: NEW ORLEANS  Over the past two weeks, as Kentucky did not advance in the N.C.A.A. tournament so much as it obliterated all opponents, the drumbeat, however absurd, that these Wildcats could beat an N.B.A. team grew louder and louder. The Wildcats, supporters argued, were that good, were among the best college teams that has ever played.

title: Homesick in the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Conflict Over How Open Do Not Track Talks Will Be
description: WASHINGTON  Technology companies want to talk with the government about protecting privacy on the Internet. They just want those talks to be private.

title: Its Official: Elder Bush Backs Romney
description: The elder George Bush formally endorsed Mitt Romney on Thursday, calling him an old friend and saying he would make a great president.

title: Trying Out the Neighborhood
description: BACK in 2008, Jennifer Donatelli and her family sold their small starter house in southeastern Huntington in record time (the kind of thing that used to happen routinely before the housing crash) and had to get out in two months. We wanted a better neighborhood and a bigger home, said Ms. Donatelli, a former TV producer who now works at the Huntington Y.M.C.A.

title: Swimming With Devils in the Deep
description: Kate Mathieson, Halle Berrys character in the maritime adventure film Dark Tide, is a so-called shark whisperer. She is the rare individual with the courage, stamina and intuition to communicate with great white sharks well enough to be able to touch their snouts and even safely swim beside them.

title: New Intensity, and Better Numbers, for Carmelo Anthony
description: Carmelo Anthonys recent admission that the new coach Mike Woodson had succeeded in coaxing an admittedly dormant energy out of him  particularly on the defensive end  raised eyebrows and ire in equal measure. Those certain that Mike DAntonis sudden resignation pointed to a mutiny by Anthony finally, it seemed, had proof.

title: What Do You Think the BRICS Can Build?
description: The leaders of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa announced on Thursday that they would investigate establishing a system that would allow them to bypass the dollar and other global currencies when trading among themselves.

title: Older Women Struggle to Make Ends Meet
description: The United States is aging, and a new report from Wider Opportunities for Women sheds some light on what that may mean and underscores the importance of saving for retirement.

title: Another Good Day for I.P.O.s as Millennial Media Nearly Doubles
description: The market for initial public stock offerings is riding high as another company has soared in its first day of trading.

title: A Building as a Catalyst for Jewish Culture
description: WITH 110 units priced from $435,000 to over $1 million, the new condominium development at 371 Madison Street, in the long-dormant former Public School 12, is bound to make an impact on its quiet corner of the Lower East Side when sales start this spring.

title: Stuck in a Roundabout on the Way to London
description: London is not calling for the United States under-23 mens national team.

title: The Hemming In of the Singer Tower
description: Q Ernest Flaggs Singer Building was crowded right from the start by the City Investing Building, erected almost simultaneously just feet away. Why didnt Flagg push his tower a little farther back? ... Arnold Merriam, New Rochelle , N.Y.

title: A Bill to Loosen Hedge Fund Marketing
description: Investors may soon get a keyhole view into the cloistered world of hedge funds and private equity firms, thanks to a little-known provision in a new bill that would relax rules on how investment firms can market themselves to the public.

title: A Good Kitchen, on a First-Home Budget
description: FOR four years, Vani Mehra had a pleasant roommate situation, sharing a large one-bedroom with two others. The two additional bedrooms, including hers, were created from temporary walls sectioning off the living room.

title: No Need to Hide the Scary Spreadsheet
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: The Gated Community Mentality
description: AS a black man who has been mugged at gunpoint by a black teenager late at night, I am not nave: I know firsthand the awkward conundrums surrounding race, fear and crime. Trayvon Martins killing at the hands of George Zimmerman baffles this nation. While the youths supporters declare in solidarity We are all Trayvon, the question is raised, to what extent is the United States also all George Zimmerman?

title: In the Broadcast Booth, Hearing Her Late Husbands Voice
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The voice in her ear told Judy Rankin it was time to return to the broadcast booth. It belonged not to any producer or director but to her husband, Walter, who died last month after an extended illness at the age of 71.

title: Outraged by Fatal Assault on Young Woman, Ukrainians Force an Investigation
description: MOSCOW  The crime was shocking enough: an 18-year-old woman gang-raped, half strangled, set on fire and left for dead. But what sent hundreds of Ukrainians into the streets and rushing to her hospitalto give blood this month was a police decision to free two suspects rumored to be politically connected.

title: Key Official Would Trim N.Y.U. Plan to Expand
description: New York University is having a hard time selling its ambitious plan to expand its Greenwich Village campus to Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, who is expected in the next two weeks to make a pivotal recommendation on the projects future.

title: Insight Into Louisvilles Pitino
description: NEW ORLEANS  As Rick Pitino readies Louisville for a national semifinal against heavily-favored Kentucky on Saturday, his closest coaching confidant, Ralph Willard, provided some insight into Pitino, his methods and his potential Hall of Fame induction this weekend.

title: Philadelphia Newspapers Set to Be Sold to Local Leaders
description: A consortium of local business and political leaders is poised to purchase the Philadelphia Media Network, publisher of The Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, according to several people familiar with the negotiations.

title: Yankees Still Arent Certain About Rotation
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees are in the final week of spring training and are inching closer to a decision on the five pitchers who will comprise their starting rotation. But according to Manager Joe Girardi, the decision has not been made yet.

title: Proudly Isolated Texas Power Grid Reaches Out a Bit
description: Last summer, when the brutal heat strained Texas electric grid and increased worries about blackouts, the grid imported a modest amount of power from Mexico and elsewhere in the United States.

title: Supreme Court May Be Most Conservative in Modern History
description: If President Obamas health care bill is stricken by the Supreme Court, liberals will take it as evidence of judicial overreach, or at least that the court has shifted far to the right. One statistical method for analyzing the Supreme Court, in fact, already finds that the current court is the most conservative since at least the 1930s.

title: Burning Mans Cry for Help
description: LOTS of people think that going to Burning Man for the art is like reading Playboy for the articles.

title: For Renewed Wright, Sport Is a Game Again
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Lindsey Wright was buoyant Thursday after an opening-round five-under-par 67 brought her one step closer to the waters edge of Poppies Pond, the hazard that beckons the winner of the Kraft Nabisco Championship.

title: Netting Tiny Eels and Big Profits
description: The next two months will bring sleepless nights and high anxiety  and quite possibly an extraordinary windfall  for a small universe of people in Maine. They are the lucky few with licenses to catch elvers  young, tiny eels that look like cellophane noodles and by some accounts are fetching up to $2,200 per pound this spring.

title: Home-Court Advantage Suits Sharapova
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Long before Maria Sharapova won Wimbledon at age 17 to become a star in womens tennis, she dreamed of winning the Sony Ericsson Open.

title: Broccoli and Bad Faith
description: Nobody knows what the Supreme Court will decide with regard to the Affordable Care Act. But, after this weeks hearings, it seems quite possible that the court will strike down the mandate  the requirement that individuals purchase health insurance  and maybe the whole law. Removing the mandate would make the law much less workable, while striking down the whole thing would mean denying health coverage to 30 million or more Americans.

title: Profile, Always High, Keeps Current Too
description: IT was sometime in the mid-1980s, Carol Peligian recalls, that she told her broker not to telephone her until shed found her an apartment among the run-down, sparsely populated commercial blocks of Fifth Avenue between 14th and 23rd Streets. The brokers response was succinct: Youre out of your mind.

title: Living In | The Flatiron District
description: A wave of conversions has added over 1,000 housing units in the last decade.

title: State Court Allows False-Confession Experts, but Bar Is High
description: ALBANY  New Yorks highest court said for the first time on Thursday that expert testimony about false confessions should be allowed at trial if it is relevant to the facts of a case.

title: Neighborhood Bookies Putting Lines Online
description: The local street bookie  whose illegal business for decades relied on little more than phones, pencils, notebooks and a burly goon to break the occasional leg  has finally been seduced by the modern conveniences of the Internet.

title: House Passes G.O.P. Budget Plan, Mostly Along Party Lines
description: WASHINGTON  A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended Thursday with House passage of a blueprint that would transform Medicare, cut domestic spending to levels not seen since World War II and order up a drastic overhaul of the tax code.

title: Neighborhood Joint | King David Kosher Restaurant
description: For a Bukharian Jew, the festive eatery in Queens is a place not just for weddings and bar mitzvahs, but also for baby showers and first birthdays.

title: A List of Labor Concerns at Foxconn
description: A list of labor concerns at Foxconn.

title: Here to There, It All Hinges on One Person
description: No, the spokeswoman said, Pedro Espada Jr. is not currently serving as president of the Soundview Health Care Network that he set up in the Bronx more than 30 years ago.

title: Charles de Gaulle Airport Hopes to Win Traffic With Smiles and Shorter Lines
description: PARIS  Charles de Gaulle is the second-largest European airport in terms of passengers  61 million last year  and the seventh-largest worldwide. Yet it doesnt get much love.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A two-bedroom Chelsea co-op and an Upper West Side two-bedroom.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Mount Vernon colonial, a New Canaan co-op and a North Syosset colonial.

title: Low-Major Guy Hits Biggest Stage
description: NEW ORLEANS  Thad and Barb Matta were married in August on a sweltering Thursday evening in North Carolina, 11 days after their engagement. Barb bought a dress in Asheville, ordered a small white cake and planned a reception for a handful of family and friends in their $200-a-month faculty housing apartment.

title: Nature-Deficit Disorder
description: TUCSON  Your day breaks, your mind aches for something stimulating to match the stirrings of the season. The gate at the urban edge is open, here to the Santa Catalina Mountains, and yet you turn inward, to pixels and particle-board vistas.

title: A Place to Celebrate Bukharian Life
description: ANYONE stepping from the roar of Queens Boulevard into the din of the King David Kosher Restaurant one recent Tuesday evening could have been forgiven for thinking that he or she had just gate-crashed a wedding.

title: Tied Together in Aisle 5: Country Acts and a Cause
description: MARKETERS working for record labels once commonly used in-store promotions, including advertisements near record bins and stand-alone product displays with cardboard cutouts of musicians.

title: Jockey Club Proposes Ban on Race-Day Drugs
description: The Jockey Club, among the most influential groups in horse racing, on Friday will propose a ban on the use of drugs for horses on race day, along with stiff penalties, including a lifetime ban for repeat offenders.

title: A Moderate Conservative Dilemma
description: Nathan Fletcher was raised in Arkansas, played college baseball in California and enlisted in the Marines as a reserve in 1997. He saw combat in 2004, based in the Sunni Triangle in Iraq.

title: In Canada, the Lowly Pennys Time to Shine Nears an End
description: OTTAWA  Jim Flaherty, the finance minister of Canada, pronounced a death sentence on the countrys penny during his budget speech on Thursday.

title: Selling Condos? Its Childs Play
description: THE McDonalds Happy Meal, which upended fast-food dining when it was first rolled out nationally in 1979, was a brilliantly simple concept: add a toy with some marketing tie-in to a colorful box with a burger, fries, a soft drink and cookies, and make children harass their parents until they steered for the double arches.

title: Three Major Banks Prepare for Possible Credit Downgrades
description: Some of Wall Streets biggest banks are bracing for fallout from a possible cut in their credit ratings.

title: A Strategy to Vote Dead Shares
description: There was an old joke in which a man said that when he died he hoped to be buried in Chicago, so that he could continue to vote.

title: NATOs Duty
description: Tragic mistakes all too often accompany combat operations, even when the military objectives are humanitarian. That is what seems to have happened in the Libyan farming village of Majer last August. Amid the confusion of a rebel advance and a retreat by Qaddafi loyalists, successive NATO bomb runs there killed at least 34 Libyan civilians, including women and small children, according to journalists, human rights organizations and United Nations investigators.

title: A Cruel Budget
description: In February, after embarrassing himself by saying he was not concerned about the very poor, Mitt Romney explained that the governments safety net would take care of them, and he promised to repair any holes in the net. That promise didnt last very long. On Thursday, House Republicans approved, on a party-line vote, a disastrous new budget that would leave millions of struggling families desperate for food, shelter and health care  and Mr. Romney has embraced it.

title: With Tablet Plan, Google Goes After Apple and Amazon
description: Googles long-awaited tablet might finally be on the way to becoming a reality. For at least two years, there have been reports that the search giant was working on something that could compete with Apples iPad. A Google employee briefed on the project now says it will be out later this year. The employee declined to be named because the product has not been announced.

title: Q & A
description: When a Subtenant Brings in a Roommate

title: Woodson a Reflection of His Famed Mentors
description: Eighteen summers ago, Mike Woodson was lured to Phoenix with the promise of brilliant blue skies, lush green fairways and a bottomless bucket of bright-white Titleists. He landed in a gymnasium, with a whistle in his mouth and a roster of N.B.A. rookies.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 29, 2012

title: The Fatal Flaw in Florida-Style Gun Laws
description: As the investigation of the shooting death of the teenager Trayvon Martin by a self-appointed neighborhood watchman goes forward in Florida, news accounts are reporting a toll of shootings, knifings and other violent homicides in which the states dangerous Stand Your Ground law was successfully claimed as a defense.

title: Pasadena Police Arrest 911 Caller After Unarmed Suspect Is Killed
description: LOS ANGELES  On a 911 call to the Pasadena police Saturday night, the caller said two young black men had put a gun in his face and had stolen his backpack.

title: Combating Age Discrimination
description: In a 2009 ruling, the Supreme Court disregarded longstanding legal precedent and made it much harder for older workers who are victims of age discrimination to win in court. The 5-to-4 decision shifted the burden of proof under the federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act so that older workers have to show their age was the deciding factor in an adverse employment decision  an unfairly hard standard to meet.
