Previously, if a worker had showed that age bias was one of the factors in a dismissal or demotion, the employer would then have to demonstrate that it had acted for valid and nondiscriminatory reasons.

title: BRICS Leaders Fail to Create Rival to World Bank
description: NEW DELHI  Leaders of five emerging world economic powers convened on Thursday for a one-day diplomatic meeting, pledging to expand mutual trade while urging faster reforms of the Western-dominated global financial system. They also called for dialogue, not military intervention, in addressing the violence in Syria and Irans disputed nuclear ambitions.

title: In Hollywood, an 80s Moment
description: LOS ANGELES  21 Jump Street is a hit. RoboCop and Dirty Dancing are on the way. Arnold Schwarzenegger is juggling a bunch of action flicks.

title: Quinn Exempts Part of Hudson Yards From Living-Wage Bill
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, already facing skepticism over her handling of legislation that would raise wages for some private-sector workers, has decided to add an exemption for one of New Yorks biggest pending developments, Hudson Yards.

title: Louisville Roommates Have One Thing in Common: Winning
description: NEW ORLEANS  The most unlikely roommates in college basketball did not arrive at Louisville just from different cities. These sophomores came from different continents. In regard to size, personality, position, playing style, sleeping habits, musical taste and room dcor, they might as well be from different planets.

title: Romney Supporters Yearning for the Personal Side
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  The voters were pleading with Mitt Romney to share personal details of his life. They stood at town-hall-style meetings and chatted before rallies, clamoring for a story or an anecdote that would help them connect with the real Mitt Romney.

title: Urchins With Punctuation
description: Since our subject today is newspapers and the people who hawk them, Im going to ask you to try to imagine a special kind of supertabloid. It would consist of nothing but headlines, all set in extra-large type, all goal-posted with exclamation points and all proclaiming essentially the same thing.

title: Rather Colloquial
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  A tough one, but with enough new stuff and fun wordplay to make me smile. I really enjoyed this Friday fare from Joe Krozel.

title: Muddying of Beloved Creek Is Last Straw for Neighbors of a City Reservoir
description: SAUGERTIES, N.Y.  For years, the resentment simmered as residents of Ulster County endured development bans, flooded basements and ruined crops, all for the sake of protecting New York Citys water supply.

title: Amid Jelly Beans, Santorum Wraps Himself in Mantle of Reagan
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif.  Rick Santorum asked cheering supporters on Thursday to help me out here in the next few weeks, and to help us build a great organization in California.

title: Remembering Earl Scruggs
description: Earl Scruggs, the virtuoso banjo player, died on March 28 at the age of 88. Musicians, including Steve Martin, celebrated his legacy by playing his signature songs.

title: Bay Looking Inward, Searching for Stroke
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There is a popular image of Jason Bay as a lost soul, a man untethered from his true self.

title: Chinas Hierarchy Strives to Regain Unity After Chongqing Leaders Ouster
description: BEIJING  Chinas top leaders are retaking the initiative after the countrys worst political crisis in a generation, showcasing a united front and moving forward with plans for a major leadership reshuffle later this year.

title: In Number of Questions Asked, Hints on the Courts Views
description: Studies have found that justices tend to ask more questions of the lawyers whose positions they oppose. During arguments this week over three questions on the health care law, like-minded justices tended to focus their questions on the same lawyers.

title: Stanfords Resurgence Culminates in a Title
description: With the football team commanding the athletic spotlight on Stanfords campus, its easy to forget that the basketball program was not long ago the perennial powerhouse in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Iran Suspends Reuters Over Faulty Headline
description: After being wrongly maligned as assassins in a Reuters news report last month, female ninjas in Iran may have found the pen momentarily mightier than the sword. But as Reuters discovered after correcting the report, the heavy hand of government can be even stronger in Iran.

title: Bloggers Cherry-Pick From Social Media to Cast Trayvon Martin as a Menace
description: Last Updated | Friday | 5:19 p.m. For the second time in a week, a conservative blog has published excerpts from what it described as a Twitter feed maintained by Trayvon Martin, the Florida teenager who was shot and killed last month by a neighborhood watch volunteer patrolling a gated community.

title: Brazils Racial Identity Challenge
Six Sellers, Eight Dishwashers
description: Prewar apartments listed for sale in Manhattan, each of which has at least one dishwasher:

title: Give the Sink a Break
description: AMONG the indignities that one may suffer when renting a Manhattan apartment  too little space for too much money, dismal natural light, tiresome flights of stairs, creepy neighbors  the lack of a dishwasher is high on many lists.

title: Case Based in China Puts a Face on Persistent Hacking
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university  putting a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups.

title: Williams Auction to Be Held at Fenway
description: For nearly 10 years since her fathers death, Claudia Williams has contemplated how and when to sell his collection of memorabilia and personal items.

title: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Osama bin Laden spent nine years on the run in Pakistan after the Sept. 11 attacks, during which time he moved among five safe houses and fathered four children, at least two of whom were born in a government hospital, his youngest wife has told Pakistani investigators.

title: Corrections: March 30
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: In Rural China, a Preserved Dynastic Village
description: Tourism companies are trying to preserve the lavish villas built by merchants of the dynastic era across the Huizhou region of China.

title: In Rural China, Temples to Past Merchant Wealth Endure
description: XIDI, China  In the spring, as rapeseed flowers bloom, this fertile swath of central China is transformed into a sea of yellow. In the summer, when rainstorms descend, the fields pulsate emerald green and canals brim with brown water.

title: Albuquerque Police Union to End Officer Payments
description: Under pressure over its policy of paying officers involved in shootings, the Albuquerque Police Officers Association said Thursday that it was ending the practice.

title: She Lets Her Sexuality Loose, and the Phone Bills Mount
description: Our first glimpse of Alma (Helene Bergsholm), the hormonal 15-year-old heroine of Turn Me On, Dammit!, is from above, as she masturbates ecstatically on her living-room floor. In her ear, the chipper voice of a phone-sex worker eggs her on  Alma is one of his regulars at Wild Wet Dreams  while the family dog watches impassively.

title: Tale of Card Reflects the Knicks Season
description: Yair Rozmaryn watched Jeremy Lin in his 25-point breakout game against the Nets in early February and was excited, and intrigued, by what he saw.

title: Large Hedge Funds Fared Well in 2011
description: Hedge funds have endured a rough year. Tumultuous markets. Tighter regulations. An insider trading crackdown.

title: Strung Out and Baked in Veracruz
description: Slow, deliberate and art house ready, Parasos Artificiales (Artificial Paradises), the first feature by the Mexican director Yulene Olaizola, teeters between the dreamy and the soporific. The dreamy part makes sense. The title comes from Baudelaires book about the effects of intoxicants (hashish, opium, wine) on the mind, and drugs are the artificial paradises indulged in by Luisa and Salomn, the main characters in Ms. Olaizolas film. The soporific part is a problem.

title: Merger With Investigative Unit Likely to Mean Major Shift in Bay Citizen Coverage
description: As the journalism world looks to the nonprofit model for salvation in these challenging times for the industry, one of the oldest journalism nonprofits, the Center for Investigative Reporting, announced Tuesday that it would merge with one of the newest, The Bay Citizen.

title: You Cant Always Clone What You Want
description: No amount of therapy could fix the central characters in Womb, a morally ripe science-fiction tale remodeled as shockingly inert love story. If the 20-odd seconds of blank screen squatting pointlessly amid the opening credits arent enough warning that youre in for some seriously sluggish storytelling, then the adoption of a snail as one of the central motifs should drive the point home.

title: An Old Utopian Makes a Comeback, Domes and All
description: In the winter of 1975, R. Buckminster Fuller made a movie called Everything I Know. Over a two-week period, a crew filmed him sitting in a chair, speaking extemporaneously to the camera about anticipatory design, the geometry of the universe and his invention of the geodesic dome. By the time he had finished talking, the film was 42 hours.

title: Young Is Paired With Old, and Slap Downs Ensue
description: The Grammy people are really taking their honor-thy-father-and-mother mission seriously these days. In February the Grammy Awards broadcast was peppered with performances that paired people like Glen Campbell and the Beach Boys with younger stars, and now the organization is pushing Re:Generation Music Project, a documentary by Amir Bar-Lev in which five D.J.s were assigned unlikely partners, most of them several generations older, and ordered to make music.

title: Toulouse Killers Path to Radicalism a Bitter Puzzle
description: TOULOUSE, France  During the long standoff that ultimately ended his life, a boastful Mohammed Merah told law enforcement officials that he had been trained by Al Qaeda. He described being driven to kill his seven victims in a shooting rampage that terrorized this city by his resentment over the fate of the Palestinians, and Frances military presence in Afghanistan and ban on the full Muslim veil.

title: Berkeley Police Chief at Center of Free Speech Furor
description: On Tuesday, minutes after the end of a Berkeley Police Department promotion ceremony, reporters rushed over to interview Chief Michael Meehan.

title: Fisherman Off to a Mission in the Underworld
description: Hey, Perseus! Youve just dispatched Medusa, a horde of Furies and the dreaded Kraken, and rescued Andromeda and the city of Argos. Where are you off to now? Fishing?

title: Auld Times
description: City of Bohane, the extraordinary first novel by the Irish writer Kevin Barry, is full of marvels. They are all literary marvels, of course: marvels of language, invention, surprise. Savage brutality is here, but so is laughter. And humanity. And the abiding ache of tragedy.

title: American Idol Recap: Heejun Han Is Cut From Top 9
description: Heejun Han, the loveable goofball from Queens, was voted off American Idol on Fox on Thursday night, after a week in which several of the remaining nine contestants gave strong performances and received standing ovations from the judges.

title: A Death, a Conviction, and a Disputed Confession
description: Scenes of a Crime is a critical exploration of modern interrogation, specifically the Reid Technique, shown in a police training video, whose goal is to extract a confession using sophisticated psychological manipulation. Although the technique is far from the much rougher, old-fashioned method known as the third degree, which involved physical torture, its use still raises questions about what constitutes coercion.

title: Photo Replay: March 29
description: A view of the day in sports, including Europa League quarterfinal matches across Europe and the N.I.T. mens basketball championship at Madison Square Garden.

title: Whats Landing Next at Charles de Gaulle
description: PARIS  Yesterday I wrote about the stiffening competition Charles de Gaulle and its operator, Aroports de Paris, face from airports undergoing billion-euro facelifts. And I noted that Charles de Gaulle gets little love from international travelers.

title: Suppress the Vote!
description: The grip of the super PAC on the Republican primary season has been well-documented. They are wrecking balls operating outside the candidates direct control, fueled by massive influxes of cash from a handful of wealthy patrons. The millions spent by the pro-Santorum Red, White and Blue Fund and the pro-Gingrich super PAC, Winning Our Future, have prolonged their respective candidates rivalry with the front-runner, Mitt Romney, whose own Restore Our Future has bludgeoned the competition from Iowa to Florida to Michigan.

title: Trying to Prepare for the Toughest of Jobs
description: Inspector Ken Esposto is looking forward to retirement after 31 years on the San Francisco police force. He has spent the past seven of them working mostly by himself, staring at a computer screen in a closed room. Earlier this month he began training his replacement, Officer Andrea Weyl, an energetic 33-year-old who is willing to trade the excitement of chasing criminals on the street for Mr. Espostos lonely work.

title: A Paris Boardinghouse Only a Beatnik Could Love
description: A well-worn stop on the timeline of American postwar culture, the Beats havent wanted for attention and citation by admirers of their work (or their play). The arts documentarian Alan Govenar takes his turn at burnishing the legend with The Beat Hotel, a mild-mannered primer centered on the cheapo Paris boardinghouse that was expat headquarters for Allen Ginsberg, William S. Burroughs, Gregory Corso and others who dug that establishments low rents and high tolerance.

title: Word of the Day | laud
description: laud \ld\ verb

title: All-Consuming Love Affair With Their Louboutins
description: Watching God Save My Shoes, Julie Benasras blithely blinkered documentary, is like gorging on empty calories: flavorful, diverting and with a slightly nauseating aftertaste.

title: Sex and the City, From Hong Kong to Beijing
description: Theres charm aplenty in Pang Ho-Cheungs Love in the Buff, a romantic comedy that is as interesting for its glimpse into contemporary urban China as it is for the charisma of its leads. A sequel to his Love in a Puff, from 2010, Buff follows a 30-ish Hong Kong couple, Cherie (Miriam Yeung) and Jimmy (Shawn Yue), as they struggle to maintain their bond, first as live-in lovers and then while seeing others in Beijing.

title: U.S. and China Press for Influence in Myanmar
description: HSIPAW, Myanmar  As Chinese workers in hard hats and red overalls bulldoze deep trenches into the orange soil across northern Myanmar for gas and oil pipelines to China, Chinas largest energy conglomerate is paying cash for land and trees in the pipelines path, and building schools and health clinics for some of the poorest people on earth.

title: Chinas Influence at Stake as Myanmar Eyes Democracy
description: As Myanmar loosens the grip of military dictatorship and improves ties with the United States, China fears a threat to its strategic partnership that offers access to the Indian Ocean.

title: NYT Front Page for 03/30/2012
description: NYT Front Page for 03/30/2012

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: George Zimmermans Brother Defends Trayvon Martin Shooting as New Video Is Released
description: In an interview Thursday night on CNNs Piers Morgan Tonight, George Zimmermans brother, Robert Zimmerman Jr., addressed the accusations against his brother of racial bias and unwarranted violence in the killing of Trayvon Martin, 17, last month, calling his brother the neighbor that everybody would want to have.

title: Harry Crews, Writer of Dark Fiction, Is Dead at 76
description: Harry Crews, whose novels out-Gothic Southern Gothic by conjuring a world of hard-drinking, punch-throwing, snake-oil-selling characters whose physical, mental, social and sexual deviations render them somehow entirely normal and eminently sympathetic, died on Wednesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 76.

title: Warren Stevens, Busy Character Actor, Dies at 92
description: Warren Stevens, a lanky, square-jawed actor with swept-back hair and a husky voice whose face became familiar through his more than 100 roles on television and in movies over six decades, died on Tuesday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 92.

title: Chinese Grad Student Hacks Indian Military Research Firms
description: Indias military preparedness and the possibility of defense breaches has dominated the news after Army chief V.K.. Singhs letter to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh surfaced recently calling Indias weapons obsolete.

title: Tunisia: U.S. Offers Financial Assistance
description: The United States announced on Thursday that it would provide Tunisia a $100 million cash infusion to pay its debts to the World Bank and other international banks. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said that the assistance would allow Tunisia to spend its resources instead on economic development and jobs. A senior administration official said that improving Tunisias struggling economy was crucial to cementing the countrys transition toward democracy.

title: El Salvador: Church Role in Gang Truce
description: A truce among gangs that has led to a precipitous drop in homicides this month was the result of mediation by the Roman Catholic Church and not a pact with the government, President Mauricio Funes said this week. Mr. Funes did say the government supported the churchs efforts and transferred 30 gang leaders from a maximum-security prison to lower-security jails to facilitate the gangs efforts to call a cease-fire. It was the latest of several explanations the government has offered for the transfer.

title: In Health Case, Appeals to a Justices Idea of Liberty
description: WASHINGTON  The way to frame a Supreme Court argument meant to persuade Justice Anthony M. Kennedy is to talk about liberty. It is his touchstone and guiding principle, and his conception of liberty is likely to determine the future of President Obamas health care law.

title: News Quiz | March 30, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays newspaper.

title: French Police Seize 17 in Raids After Killings in Toulouse
description: PARIS  Eight days after the police shot dead the self-confessed killer of four Jews and three French paratroopers in Toulouse, the French police on Friday detained 17 people described as Islamic militants in that city and other parts of France.

title: Japan Readies in Case Rocket From North Korea Poses Risk
description: TOKYO  Japan is deploying guided-missile destroyers and antiaircraft batteries with orders to shoot down a North Korean rocket if it falls toward Japanese territory, Japans defense minister said Friday.

title: South Asian Talent Showcase at SubDrift
description: A Nigerian rapper, a braces-wearing would-be Whitney Houston, and an Indian-American psychiatrist/stand-up comedian walked into a bar one Friday night.

title: March 30, 1981 | President Reagan Is Shot
description: On March 30, 1981, President Ronald Reagan was shot and seriously injured outside a Washington hotel by John W. Hinckley Jr. Also wounded were the White House news secretary James Brady, who was left paralyzed by the shooting, a Secret Service agent and a District of Columbia police officer.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 30, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The Officiant Among Us.

title: What Science Suggests About Weather Weirding
description: HOW has this March been a good example of weather weirding?

title: With Images of Rare Diseases, a Hope to Spur Action
description: My head turned when I saw the poster.

title: What Movies, Shows or Books Do You Wish Had Sequels, Spinoffs or New Episodes?
description: Will Ferrell has announced that an Anchorman sequel is in the works, Pauly D of MTVs Jersey Shore has a spinoff reality show that began Thursday night, and Star Trek fans are hoping that a forgotten, unused script  will soon be produced. What movies, television shows or books have you loved so much that you wish they could continue in some way? How  whether through a sequel, spin-off, or missing chapter, episode or scene  would you bring the story or characters back?

title: Pain Persists Among Europes Ailing Economies
description: LONDON  For anyone tempted to think that the ailing economies of Europe are over the worst, there were fresh indications in recent days that the pain would continue for a while yet.

title: For BRICS, Bouquets and Brickbats
description: Whether the BRICS meeting in New Delhi Thursday was a massive triumph or a disappointment seems to depend a bit on who you ask.

title: U.S. Envoy to Russia Accuses TV Station of Spying on Him
description: MOSCOW  The State Department on Friday formally expressed concern to the Russian Federation about the security of its ambassador to Moscow, Michael A. McFaul, who has complained that crews from state-controlled television have gained access to his schedule by hacking his e-mail or his phones.

title: Disagreements Among Syrian Rebels Over Foreign Arms Shipments
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Just days before a major international meeting on how to aid Syrias rebels, the countrys fractious opposition movement continued to bicker, most notably about a crucial question to be considered at the gathering: whether to provide arms to the rebel fighters.

title: Fantasy Focus: Predictions for 2012
description: Hanley Ramirez Is a Top-Three Fantasy Player

title: Light Blue Skies Ahead for Glasgow Rangers
description: GLASGOW  In the 140 years of Glasgow Rangers history, the past six weeks have arguably been the most turbulent, as the defending champions in Scotlands Premier League faced the prospect of ceasing operations as the club went into administration (the British form of bankruptcy) because of financial mismanagement.

title: Tibetan Protests in Delhi
description: When Jampa Yeshi doused himself in gasoline and lit a match, he became one of around 30 Tibetans who chose self-immolation as a form of protest over the past year. What set Yeshi apart is that he set himself alight in New Delhi, days before President Hu Jintao of China was scheduled to arrive in India. The image traveled the world. Eager to avoid embarrassing its guest, Indias security forces cracked down on potential protesters.Meanwhile, the rest of the world seems indifferent. One self-immolation in Tunisia shocked the world and triggered the Arab spring, writes Isabel Hilton in the Guardian. Thirty self-immolations in Tibet have received little international attention.

title: Scouting the Draft: Michigan States Jerel Worthy
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Walking the Talk: Automakers Employees Champion Energy Efficiency at Work and at Home
description: Car companies have phalanxes of assembly workers, engineers, marketers and lawyers working to speed the adoption of energy-efficient vehicles. For some of these employees, the work of minimizing environmental impacts follows them home.

title: The Early Word: Kennedy
description: In Todays Times:

title: The Supreme Court and the National Conversation on Health Care Reform
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Who Died and Made You Pope?
description: THE Vatican is often portrayed as a hotbed of power politics and ecclesiastical intrigue. But does anybody really want to be pope? Following the most recent papal conclave, in 2005, it was reported that Benedict XVI had prayed that he wouldnt be chosen. Back in the 1950s, when the future Pope John XXIII was the patriarch of Venice, he wrote to his sister, Who wants to be more than a cardinal? And few have made their aversion more apparent than Celestine V, the hermit-monk elected in 1294 by a deadlocked College of Cardinals.

title: Questioned by a Coach, an Owner Rethinks Her Manufacturing Issues
description: In my last post, Susan Martin, a business coach, pressed Alexandra Mayzler to articulate her vision for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. Ms. Mayzler was clear that she wanted to see a revolution in education that elevated the importance of study skills. She was less clear, however, about what role her company might play in this revolution.

title: Puberty Before Age 10: A New Normal?
description: One day last year when her daughter, Ainsley, was 9, Tracee Sioux pulled her out of her elementary school in Fort Collins, Colo., and drove her an hour south, to Longmont, in hopes of finding a satisfying reason that Ainsley began growing pubic hair at age 6. Ainsley was the tallest child in her third-grade class. She had a thick, enviable blond-streaked ponytail and big feet, like a puppys. The curves of her Levis matched her mothers.

title: Violence, Mad Men and Football
description: Links for your consideration, amid the biggest off-season in N.F.L. history:

title: Making Sense of the Wacky Weather
description: Like many people, Ive been struggling to understand what is going on with the weather. As I flipped on my air conditioner one day in the middle of March to cool down an unbearably hot apartment, I thought, this is just weird. In recent years, we have lived through one weather extreme after another, sometimes whipsawing between them rather quickly.

title: Europe Agrees to Bailout Fund for Euro of Over $1 Trillion
description: COPENHAGEN  Seeking to reaffirm their determination to put the two-year-old euro crisis behind them, European finance ministers agreed Friday to create a permanent bailout fund for the euro zone with an effective firepower of almost 800 billion.

title: Hi, Diane Keaton!
description: Everything I do is in the moment, says Tierney Gearon, the photographer whose work appears in this weeks Look column. She came up with the idea for the colored-shapes project  which she hopes to turn into book  when she observed her son Walker place a clear plastic filing bin over her baby daughter Grace. (It sounds dangerous, but it was charming.)

title: Militia Member Drugs and Kills Afghan Colleagues
description: KHOST, Afghanistan  A member of a militia promoted by the American military to protect rural villages drugged his Afghan colleagues and killed at least nine of them as they slept on Friday, a police official said, in the third deadly episode involving the irregular guard force in March.

title: Paul Ryan Endorses Romney for President
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin on Friday endorsed the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, saying Republicans do not have the luxury of waiting until the partys convention this summer to rally behind a nominee and start confronting President Obama.

title: Sound Garden
description: A man who makes films about people who never stop moving would seem unlikely to set down roots. Yet the artist Doug Aitken has built himself a house in Venice, Calif., that is too much fun to leave  even to go to the nearby studio where he created Black Mirror, his film project with Chlo Sevigny as a nomad who spends her days checking into and out of anonymous motels.

title: Humanitys Discomfort, Punctured With a Pen
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: Chickpea Nostalgia
description: Dear Diary:

title: Doug Aitkens Acid Modernism
description: The artist Doug Aitkens house, a block away from the Pacific Ocean, is in tune with its surroundings in more ways than one. In an exclusive video, Aitken, with the help of his girlfriend Gemma Ponsa and a few of their friends, activate its more hidden charms, revealing that its a house that sounds as cool as it looks. More

title: Dunkin Brands Prices Secondary Offering at $29.50
description: 8:51 a.m. | Updated

title: Opinion Report: Age Discrimination
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Doug Aitken | Acid Modernism
description: Inside Aitkens residence in Venice, Calif.

title: Friday Reading: Two-Year College to Charge More for Top Classes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them togjobless benefitsether here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sealys Governance Attacked by Second Investor
description: The mattress maker Sealy faced another round of investor criticism over its corporate governance on Friday for appearing to allow Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to wield deep influence over its board.

title: Reporter Q. and A. on the Health Care Arguments
description: On The Timess Facebook page on Thursday, Adam Liptak, the newspapers Supreme Court correspondent, and Reed Abelson, a reporter covering health care for the Business Day section, hosted a discussion with readers about the legal battle over the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Below is a transcript of highlights from the question-and-answer session.

title: Oaktree I.P.O. May Raise Up to $517.5 Million
description: The Oaktree Capital Group said Friday that it expected to price its initial public offering at $43 to $46 per stock unit, potentially raising up to $517.5 million in its market debut.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Foxconn Vows to Change, and an 80s Rewind
description: Foxconn, the giant China-based electronics manufacturer that supplies products to Apple and others, pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside its factories after an investigation found widespread problems, Charles Duhigg and Steven Greenhouse reported. On Thursday, the Fair Labor Association, a monitoring group, issued a report detailing violations of Chinese laws and regulations, and numerous instances where Foxconn defied industry codes of conduct.

title: Beyond the Meadow
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: How the White House Thinks It Can Bring Jobs Back to America
description: Call it the triumph of Rhineland capitalism. For decades, the Anglo-Saxon consensus has been that manufacturing was in decline and that its replacement by the service sector  as most glitteringly represented by finance  was both inevitable and welcome. Only dirigiste Europeans, the transatlantic conventional wisdom had it, thought the government could or should try to hang on to its industrial base.

title: In Nod to Past, MTV Revives Art Breaks
description: In its never-ending quest to reach young viewers, MTV is going back to the past, and to a generation weaned on its early videos. The network announced Friday that it is reviving Art Breaks, a pioneering 1985 series that broadcast TV spots created by a vanguard of downtown artists.

title: Wisconsin Primary Overshadowed by Recall
description: For most of this year, the arrival of the Republican presidential contest in town has quickly become the biggest political story of the day in those places.

title: Fill-In | Olympic Mascots  and Mash-Ups
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this sports section article, Olympic Mascots Inspire Imitations.

title: Crankocracy
description: Timothy Noah makes an interesting point: at least so far, the most visible effect of the Citizens United decision has been not so much a flood of corporate cash into politics as a flood of cash from billionaire cranks into politics. Rich crackpots of the world, unite!

title: Image of the Day: March 30
Compensation for Ford Chief Rose to $29.5 Million Last Year
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, received compensation for 2011 of $29.5 million, the most in his six years in the position, the automaker disclosed in a regulatory filing Friday.

title: School Budget Picture Evolving
We Dont Need No Education
description: Jared Bernstein has a heartfelt lament about the priorities of the American right, and in particular the way its determined to slash taxes for the wealthy while slashing student aid. And he gives us this chart:

title: On Our Radar: Cuts in German Solar Subsidies
description: Germanys parliament approves deep cuts in subsidies for solar power. The government argues that the subsidies have driven up electricity prices for consumers while propping up photovoltaic panel prices for domestic manufacturers. [Bloomberg Businessweek]

title: The Cartoonists Goal
description: The best-selling graphic novelist Daniel Clowes talks about his art.

title: The FT Does Iceland
description: I think I was one of the first econopundits to point out that Iceland, the poster child for financial excess, was actually having a surprisingly non-catastrophic aftermath thanks to heterodox economic policies. I got many attacks over this observation, with the usual accusations of cherry-picked data and failure to understand the wonders of austerity in, say, Latvia.

title: Morning Buzz, March 30: No More Synthetic Marijuana
description: Good morning. Today promises sunny skies and a high of 56 degrees. Prepare for rain tonight, though.

title: After First-Quarter Rally, Prospect of a Slip Looms
description: Stocks shot out of the gate in 2012 to post their best first quarter in 14 years, but a familiar anxiety is creeping back into the markets.

title: The Shape of Things
description: People and pets in Plexiglas boxes.

title: Market Watch | Baselworld 2012
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: What Were Reading
description: Vice: Panic attacks, nausea, skin rashes  its bananaphobia! A chat with those who fear and loathe the elongated yellow fruit.  (Via Grub Street.)

title: Leading Off: The Great Final Four Debate
description: As you get ready for the weekends action, wed like to welcome you officially to the one-and-done mens Final Four. You can get started by wringing your hands earnestly, as everyone will in New Orleans while contemplating the scourge of college basketball. No, this is not a new issue and yes, college basketball has a long list of other scourges, but this one will take center stage because everyone recently noticed that Kentucky has become the fast-food stop of the college basketball world, its players not sticking around long enough for their fries to get cold, and Kentucky is the overwhelming favorite to win this national championship.

title: The Rise of Mofaz
description: TEL AVIV  I live not far from Tzipi Livnis home, and Wednesday morning, as I was driving in the neighborhood, photographers were laying on the street, awaiting the defeated politician to emerge and say something, anything, about her future plans.

title: Daily Report: Hacking Attacks Are Linked to Man at Chinese Firm
description: A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university, Nicole Perlroth writes on Friday in The New York Times. The case puts a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups.

title: In Europe, Starbucks Adjusts to a Cafe Culture
description: PARIS  On a recent sunny morning in this citys chic Marais district, Marion Bayod squeezed behind a tiny table at Le Cactus, a neighborhood cafe she has frequented for years. She cast a sidelong glance at a Starbucks across the street.

title: Up Front
description: Ben Macintyre contributes a weekly column to The Times of London on history, art, politics, foreign affairs  and espionage. Although he has never written a novel, his books are filled with colorful characters, from Adam Worth (the real Professor Moriarty) to Ian Fleming, creator of James Bond. The first volume of Macintyres World War II espionage trilogy, Agent Zigzag, featured a real-life criminal and double agent who played a pivotal role in the early part of the war. The second, Operation Mincemeat, told the story of a secret plan involving a corpse carrying forged papers in the run-up to the invasion of Sicily in 1943, a deception made famous by the film The Man Who Never Was.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHY BE HAPPY WHEN YOU COULD BE NORMAL?,  by Jeanette Winterson (Grove, $25.) Wintersons unconventional and winning memoir wrings humor from adversity as it describes her upbringing by a wildly deranged mother.

title: Paperback Row
description: SO MUCH PRETTY,  by Cara Hoffman (Simon & Schuster, $16.) The disappearance of a local waitress foments an atmosphere of paranoia in an upstate New York town in Hoffmans first novel, which addresses rural poverty, domestic abuse, teenage violence and pollution. Over the course of 17 years, the story moves among the towns inhabitants, many of whom remain willfully blind to the deeper causes of the tragedy.

title: Religion for Atheists
description: To the Editor:

title: What Russia Is Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: That Parachute Anchor
description: To the Editor:

title: Satantango, the Movie
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Defensive
description: Given the mounting evidence of long-term and even fatal effects of brain injuries incurred by professional football players, is it ethical for us to watch the games? JENNA BEDNAR, ANN ARBOR, MICH.

title: Former Goldman Executive Is Said to Complete Book Deal
description: Greg Smith, the former Goldman Sachs executive whose book proposal about his 12 years at the firm set off a fierce bidding war among New York publishers, has made a deal with Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said Friday.

title: Freedoms Gardener
description: To the Editor:

title: A Trip Across Water, and Time, From Seattle
description: UNBEKNOWNST to the rest of us, the Washington State Department of Transportation has invented a time machine. Sure, it looks like a ferry, running the route between Seattle and Vashon Island dozens of times a day. But how else to explain what you find when you arrive on Vashon?

title: Riding the Subway, From A to Z in 22:52:35 or Bust
description: Its an endeavor many train enthusiasts have dreamed about trying: ride every inch of a transportation network, traversing every subway line and station  and do it all, not in a week or a month, but in a day.

title: Rockers at Sea
description: THINGS were a little weird from the moment I stepped onto the Weezer Cruise. Like a lot of my fellow passengers  indie-rock fans who had signed up for a three-day voyage full of bands and beverages  Id never been on a cruise before. So I dont know whether most of them begin with a staff member high-fiving each and every person who comes off the gangway. But Im relatively certain most dont have a welcome center with a D.J. playing a reggae version of Nirvanas Heart Shaped Box.

title: Lohans Long-Running Probation Comes to an End
description: To the consternation of tabloid editors everywhere, a judge on Thursday ended Lindsay Lohans long-running probation for a 2007 drunk driving case after a string of violations, jail sentences and rehab stints, wire services reported. Ms. Lohan, 25, remains on informal probation for taking a necklace without permission last year, but she no longer must report to a probation officer, limit her travel or show up for weekly cleaning shifts at a morgue.

title: Romney Leads in Wisconsin, but Republicans Focus Is on Recall Election
description: Mitt Romney has a seven-point advantage over Rick Santorum in the Wisconsin presidential primary, according to an NBC News/Marist poll released Friday.

title: Birds Do It, Bees Do It (Fill Screens)
description: ITS unclear if humans are any more fascinated with animals than they ever have been, but its safe to say that the visual manifestations of this fascination are on the rise. Blue-chip wildlife documentaries like Planet Earth and the current Frozen Planet, feats of extreme-condition, high-definition shooting, are blockbuster events. On the lowbrow end of the spectrum animal attacks and rogue pets are staples of cable television, and YouTube is an infinite virtual menagerie of cat videos and creature memes.

title: To Play Judy, Sing Till It Hurts and Be Fearless
description: JUDY GARLAND pops a great many pills in Act II of End of the Rainbow, the new Broadway show about the consequences of her fame, set six months before her fatal overdose in 1969. Yet at a recent rehearsal Tracie Bennett, the actress portraying Garland, wasnt feeling sufficiently strung out as she sang Come Rain or Come Shine with her six-man orchestra in the show, which weaves famous Garland numbers with scenes set in her London hotel suite.

title: Haunted by Ghost Tale? Call an Expert
description: ATLANTA

title: Broccoli Mandates and the Commerce Clause
description: If the government can do this, what, what else can it not do? asked Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia this week in arguments on the constitutionality of the requirement that nearly all Americans buy health care insurance or face a penalty.

title: A New Leaf
description: In the vibrant hothouse that is Chris Garofalos Chicago studio, nearly every surface holds carefully composed displays  natural specimens, souvenir postcards, family photos and random objects, like a petrified frog or lurid blue ceramic eggplants. A framed, somewhat faded dinosaur mural reigns over the space; herds of small plastic animals roam the shelf above her worktable. Sometimes its hard to tell the found objects from the art.

title: Our Third Annual New York Times Found Poem Student Contest
description: Update: May 2012 We are publishing the winners every day through May 25 here. You might also be interested in our reflections on this years contest. Thanks for participating!

title: Honda Recalls 554,000 CR-Vs and Pilots for Headlight Failure
description: Following an investigation initiated last year by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Honda announced Friday that it would recall about 554,000 of its 2002-4 CR-Vs and the 2003 Pilot sport utility vehicles because the low-beam headlights might fail.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Mark Leyner discusses his new novel, The Sugar Frosted Nutsack; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Meg Wolitzer on the cultural reception of fiction written by women; Tim Weiner talks about his new history of the F.B.I.; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Helping Girls Through Early Puberty
description: Are girls going through puberty earlier? Yes and no, and maybe  as Elizabeth Weil writes in  Puberty Before Age 10: A New Normal? for The New York Times Magazine, it depends on how you define puberty. Well-respected researchers at three big institutions  Cincinnati Childrens Hospital, Kaiser Permanente of Northern California, Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York  published [a] study in Pediatrics, finding that by age 7, 10 percent of white girls, 23 percent of black girls, 15 percent of Hispanic girls and 2 percent of Asian girls had started developing breasts.

title: Whisper of the Wild
description: I lived in the Fairbanks, Alaska, area for almost 14 years and spent a great deal of time in the bush. I appreciated the silence there, psychologically depended on it. I spent many hours just sitting in places where quiet filled my ears, but there were also many times that the sounds of nature were almost deafening (the mosquitoes!). I always found that natures silence, that is, what remains when the din of human presence is subtracted, far superior as an affirmation of being. Only there can I really become aware of the effect of my presence. Here in the New York-Boston corridor, noise is everywhere, almost impossible to bear. I cant separate my presence from the noise. I miss the silence and my absence within it.

title: When Countries Fail
description: In addressing the question of why nations fail, economists would do better to abandon the search for the one answer. Being neither scientists nor theocrats, they would be better advised to explore how different facts interact under different circumstances. This would yield more explanatory light than rhetorical heat.

title: Meet the New Lefty Dreamboat
description: Last year, you started a liberal antidote to the Tea Party that is now called Rebuild the Dream. You said, Hold onto your hats for an October offensive. Then I didnt hear much else. . . .  We were pointing at the possibility of a very explosive populist movement from the left. It happened at the grass-roots level, and it was called Occupy. Rebuild hasnt got the same press attention, but we have 600,000 members and a presence in every Congressional district.

title: Who Made That Whoopee Cushion?
description: Some insist that the whoopee cushion originated in medieval courts where jesters turned pig bladders into flatulence simulators. Its likely an apocryphal story, but it stands to reason, says Jim Dawson, the author of Who Cut the Cheese. The real story behind the pranks rise to April Fools Day pre-eminence begins in another locus of bathroom humor: 1930s Canada. It was there that JEM, a Toronto rubber company, introduced a contraption known alternatively as the poo-poo cushion and the boop-boop a doop, until, in 1932, it settled on whoopee. A collector named Stan Timm owns an early model: its green, with a wooden mouth and a drawing of a gun-toting boy wearing a devious smile and a kilt.

title: Survivalist Instinct
description: Heather Havrileskys Riff on pioneer life is based on a false premise: a distinction between self-reliance and community. We live as a family in the wild woods. This does not mean that we spend our time staring at one another or at bears  we spend our time growing community. We have more solid relations (and communities) out here than what I ever found in city.

title: A Big Bet Gone Bad
description: Large-scale gambling used for tax revenue is bad economics and worse public policy. A casino is an economic win for a region only if most gamblers come from elsewhere. If most come from nearby  as is now common, with casinos in so many places  then as one gambling scholar said, You simply cannot grow an economy by taking money out of it. You drain local wallets while shifting the tax burden to the lower-income folks who are hurt most by their losses. Then add the sad stories Ive heard from public officials in casino areas across the country. Bankruptcies, embezzlement, broken families  were seeing it now, here in Pennsylvania.

title: How the American Action Movie Went Kablooey
description: The action film  like automobiles, televisions and team-oriented basketball  is an American invention that is now produced much better elsewhere in the world. The latest example of this (and there are many examples from points all over the globe) is The Raid: Redemption, a modest but irresistible action film from Indonesia that recently high-kicked (and punched and stomped and shot and throttled) its way into American theaters. The film has been rapturously celebrated; at last glance, its positive rating at Rotten Tomatoes hovered around 90 percent. In a rare dissenting opinion, Roger Ebert wrote: This film is about violence. All violence. Wall-to-wall violence, which is true but also a bit like complaining that a comedy is too full of jokes.

title: The High Road
description: In the summer of 1995, a 26-year-old woman who had never been backpacking before set out to hike the Pacific Crest Trail. She had already separated from her husband, quit her waitressing job and sold most of her belongings. Now she went to the outdoors store REI to purchase almost everything she could possibly think of for her three-month journey: fleece pants and an anorak, a thermal shirt, two pairs of wool socks and underwear, a sleeping bag, a camp chair, a head lamp, five bungee cords, a water purifier, a tiny collapsible stove, a canister of gas and a small pink lighter, two cooking pots, utensils, a thermometer, a tarp, a snakebite kit, a Swiss Army knife, binoculars, a compass, a book called Staying Found to teach herself how to use the compass, a first-aid kit, toiletries, a menstrual sponge, a lantern, water bottles, iodine pills, a foldable saw (for what, I did not know), two pens and three books in addition to Staying Found: The Pacific Crest Trail, Vol. 1: California, William Faulkners As I Lay Dying and Adrienne Richs Dream of a Common Language. She also bought a 200-page sketchbook to use as a journal.

title: Business Day Live | March 30, 2012
description: Starbucks struggles to make headway in Europe; a look at mobile mapping software; James B. Stewart on the Supreme Court and the health care bill.

title: Pawns Move
description: Comrade Col. Xin Zhu, obese spy and head of the Expedition Agency within the Sixth Bureau of the Ministry of State Security, suspects there is a C.I.A. mole burrowing into Chinas secrets. But he is under threat from Wu Liang and his ally, Yang Qing-Nian, of the Supervision and Liaison Committee, an offshoot of the Central Committees Political and Legislative Affairs Committee. Zhu believes Zhang Guo of the Supreme Peoples Procuratorate is on his side, probably, but he is less sure of the veteran schemer Comrade Lt. Gen. Sun Bingjun.

title: Signs of Life
description: How dead would you like to be before your organs are harvested for donation? According to Dick Teresi in The Undead, pretty dead is good enough for transplant surgeons. If you wait for everything to be a hundred percent, a physician tells him, youd never have organ donation.

title: Ye Gods
description: Mark Leyner writes in a genre that could be called Mark Leyner: gun-to-the-head comedy delivered with a stratospheric I.Q. Leyners fiction isnt narrative so much as a thundering procession of twisted skits, pinging from brainiac literary theory to the latest disgraces of reality TV. Just when it seems that, line by line, there might be no smarter writer on the planet, Leyner indulges in gleefully juvenile sprees of lewdness, asserting the sublime pleasures of the absurd. He is either a genius or a freak, and it may not matter which, because his books are compulsively readable, created by a literary mind that seems to have no precedent.

title: Plenty to Go Around
description: The past few years have been trying ones for the worlds optimists. In rapid succession, our global crises have ranged from the environmental to the economic  from tsunamis leveling entire regions of Asia and destroying seemingly impregnable nuclear reactors, to debt and unemployment crushing ostensibly healthy nations. Meanwhile, as the planet warms, ice caps melt, oceans acidify and dry regions desertify. To choose just one metric of doom, about 30 percent of the worlds fish populations have either collapsed or are on their way to collapse; to choose another, global carbon emissions rose by a record 5.9 percent in 2010, a worrisome development considering that the period was characterized by slow economic growth. (What happens when things start booming again?) I could go on, but you get the gist. It seems self-evident that things are getting worse, doesnt it?

title: Foiled Again
description: On Dec. 31, President Obama signed the National Defense Authorization Act, which allows for the indefinite military detention, without trial, of any American citizen who was a part of or substantially supported Al Qaeda, the Taliban or associated forces that are engaged in hostilities against the United States or its coalition partners. This act effectively abrogates the Bill of Rights and removes one of the cornerstones of Western liberty.

title: The Ground Beneath Her Feet
description: Running an Ivy League university isnt all its cracked up to be, at least not for Meredith Ruth Neukirchen, known as M.R., the protagonist of Joyce Carol Oatess new novel. Shes the first woman to be president of an unnamed school in New Jersey, an obvious stand-in for Princeton, where Oates is the Roger S. Berlind distinguished professor of the humanities. M.R. is renowned in academic circles, an eminent philosopher, a diplomatic administrator and a selfless hard worker. But a creeping distress threatens to engulf her. Living by herself in the museumlike presidents house has proved lonely and uncomfortable. She has no intimate friends. Her secret, much older lover is not only long married to someone else and ensconced at far-off Harvard, he has begun staying away entirely, seeming less than thrilled by her professional ascent. In unguarded moments, M.R. admits that even her nonstop work is a trial, her laptop attached to her like a colostomy bag.

title: Winging It
description: Megan Mayhew Bergmans first story collection, Birds of a Lesser Paradise, begins with a woman driving hundreds of miles to see a parrot. She cant stand the bird, which sings Patsy Cline tunes and tells off imaginary telemarketers, but it has one trick worth listening to: It sounds just like her dead mother. The two women didnt get along, but now that the mother is gone, the daughter longs to hear her familiar voice, even coming from a beady-eyed mimic.

title: In the Pink
description: For a long time, I assumed that bow ties  not regular ties  were the usual thing for men to wear, Charlotte Silver writes in her wistful memoir, Charlotte au Chocolat. Such were the perils of growing up in the same building as the Hasty Pudding Club, Harvards oldest social club, where for 20 years Silvers mother, Deborah Hughes, along with a business partner, Mary-Catherine Deibel, ran the four-star restaurant Upstairs at the Pudding, housed on the clubs third floor.

title: Chaos Under Heaven
description: By the time Qing imperial forces caught and dismembered Hong Rengan in late 1864, an estimated 20 million to 70 million people had perished in the turmoil of the Taiping rebellion. Hong, once a bookish assistant to European preachers, ended up the prime minister of a Chinese movement that almost deposed the Qing dynasty of the Manchus, who had conquered China more than two centuries earlier.

title: Enchanted Hunter
description: Shortly before coming to America in 1940, on a ship that would be sunk by Nazi U-boats on its next voyage, Vladimir Nabokov wrote a novel about biography and art entitled The Real Life of Sebastian Knight. In it we are advised to remember that what you are told is really threefold: shaped by the teller, reshaped by the listener, concealed from both by the dead man of the tale. No words might be better kept in mind while reading Brian Boyds Stalking Nabokov.

title: The Second Shelf
description: If The Marriage Plot, by Jeffrey Eugenides, had been written by a woman yet still had the same title and wedding ring on its cover, would it have received a great deal of serious literary attention? Or would this novel (which I loved) have been relegated to Womens Fiction, that close-quartered lower shelf where books emphasizing relationships and the interior lives of women are often relegated? Certainly The Marriage Plot, Eugenidess first novel since his Pulitzer Prize-winning Middlesex, was poised to receive tremendous literary interest regardless of subject matter, but the presence of a female protagonist, the gracefulness, the sometimes nostalgic tone and the relationship-heavy nature of the book only highlight the fact that many first-rate books by women and about womens lives never find a way to escape Womens Fiction and make the leap onto the upper shelf where certain books, most of them written by men (and, yes, some women  more about them later), are prominently displayed and admired.

title: Easter Among Strangers
description: Upon leaving the Finnish fundamentalist faith of my youth, I made my parents a promise that I would still attend church on Christmas and Easter. It was my fifth such Easter, but I was still anxious, aware that everyone would be looking to see what unbelieving had done to me. I removed my nail polish and earrings, arriving late to avoid conversation, only to discover that the church was full  there was not even space by the bad kids in the back. I was forced instead to parade to the front, feeling underdressed and like the prodigal child, and take a seat next to my little cousins.

title: Tracking Twitter, Raising Red Flags
description: The business plan of Varsity Monitor is simple. Major universities like North Carolina, Nebraska and Oklahoma pay $7,000 to $10,000 a year and Varsity Monitor keeps an online eye on their athletes.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Parent Power, Power Parents
On Vashon Island, Farms, Art and Country Roads
description: In the islands main town, shopkeepers greet their patrons by name, and the only traffic jams are found on the sidewalk.

title: Parnells Knuckle-Curve Makes a Difference
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  As the Mets revamped their bullpen this winter, Bobby Parnell found himself at the start of spring training once again battling to prove his worth.

title: Inside the List
description: HELP, THANKS, WOW: There was a time, three or four years ago, when it seemed every novelist had a blog, and why not? Blogging gave writers another way to reach readers, to promote their work or air their grievances or test their ideas in mini-essays that played to their strengths. But technology evolves, and despite some notable holdouts (Elif Batuman is one) Twitter has killed the blogging star. Now writers connect with their publics in 140 characters or fewer. The medium especially favors authors with distinct voices, preferably funny ones, who can toss off pithy observations or one-liners  authors like Anne Lamott, say, whose new book, Some Assembly Required, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9. Lamotts best writing has always had the dashed-off immediacy of a good tweet; her excellent 1993 book Operating Instructions strung together one punch line after another to capture the joys and anxieties of her sons first year of life. The new book is a sequel  her son (and co-author), Sam, now has a son of his own  and to promote it, Lamott has been posting her daffy, neurotic, inspirational shtick in the telegraphic shorthand that Twitter followers are used to. From an airplane on the first leg of her recent book tour, she wrote: New low @ 30,000 feet  checked Amazon sales rank of Some Assembly . . .  @samlamott trying to wrestle iPad out of my hands. I need air marshal. Later, in Washington, she was more reflective: D.C.; cherry blossoms in full pink pyrotechnic bloom. Humbling & convincing (but Im easy). 3rd great prayer, after Help and Thanks, is Wow! Almost 20 years ago I sat in on Lamotts writing class in Marin County, Calif., where one of the students turned out to be her former elementary school principal. Even in second grade shed been a bundle of comic nervous energy, he told me. We all knew she was going to be a star.

title: Ahead of I.P.O., Mark Zuckerbergs Lawyers Expedite Disclosures
description: Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, is rushing to clear all his paperwork ahead of the social networks highly anticipated initial public offering.

title: Turning a Bloody Attack Into a Musical
description: It was a grisly story of two immigrant cabdrivers whose taxi-sharing partnership ended with one attacking the other with a meat cleaver and then jumping to his death from the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The fourth annual New Jersey Wine and Food Festival, at Crystal Springs in Hardyston, N.J., runs through Sunday, with many New York City chefs participating. The chef Thomas Keller is being honored this year. Some events have sold out, but tickets are still available for various lunches, meet-and-greet sessions with chefs, wine seminars and more. The festival benefits the James Beard Foundation and Bocuse dOr USA. Tickets are available online or by calling (973) 827-5996, extension 3.

title: Video: A Bluegrass Tribute to Earl Scruggs
description: The death of Earl Scruggs, the virtuoso banjo player, in Nashville on Wednesday was mourned throughout the tight-knit bluegrass music world.

title: A Rivalry Moves Downcourt to Center Stage
description: SOMETHING felt wrong to Magic Johnson when he watched a recent rehearsal of Magic/Bird, a new Broadway play about his rivalry turned friendship with Larry Bird, the fellow basketball superstar with whom he is indelibly linked.

title: Inside the 3-D Conversion of Titanic
description: Using a frame from Titanic, James Cameron explains elements of the work that went into converting the film to 3-D.

title: For Struggling RIM, Sale Prospects Appear Tough
description: It took an awful quarter for Research in Motion to acknowledge on Thursday that it needed to explore strategic opportunities, something the BlackBerry maker scoffed at even two months ago.

title: A More Diet-Friendly Doughnut, Baked by Butterfield
description: The venerable Butterfield Market, a carriage-trade grocer on the Upper East Side, traces its beginnings to 1915 but is now focused on innovation: doughnuts that are baked, not fried.

title: Why Bully Is a Family Film
description: In a widely publicized decision, the ratings board of the Motion Picture Association of America insisted on an R rating for the movie Bully, a documentary about children who are bullied, their tormenters and the adults who let both of them down, because of profanity in the film. An R rating means the children who could most benefit from the film would not be able to see it without their parents.

title: With Lamb, Flavor Comes in Small Packages
description: WE think of spring as the season of the lamb, but in truth, the term spring lamb is a misnomer. The lamb you see in shops now is from animals 6 to 9 months old, which means they were born last fall at the earliest. The exception is suckling or milk-fed lamb, only a few weeks old, which is a delicacy prized in Europe but rarely available in the United States. If you can find it, it is extraordinary.

title: In Portugal, a Street in Porto Finds Its Groove
description: In Porto, Portugal, the faded town houses on Rua do Rosrio are filling with upstart designers and fine food.

title: An Impeccable toile Dared to Be More
description: PARIS

title: Putting In Their 2 Cents
description: ON a weeknight in mid-March, a room in the Park Slope Armory Y.M.C.A. that is frequently used for childrens birthday parties was packed with tables draped in pale yellow, 99-cent-store, vinyl coverings and topped with propped-up tri-fold poster boards.

title: Chic Relief | Fashion Girls for Japan Benefit Sale
description: Last year, in the wake of Japans devastating earthquake and tsunami, a group of enterprising New York women (many of them Japanese American) working in the fashion industry wanted to do something tangible to help recovery and relief efforts. They formed Fashion Girls for Japan and quickly organized a benefit sale of designer clothes. More than 60 designers pledged to donate one rolling rack each of clothing and accessories and the Fashion Girls raised an astonishing $275,000, all of which was donated to the Japan Societys Japan Earthquake Relief Fund.

title: A Career That Moves in Mysterious Ways
description: Geneva

title: At NoMad, Bottle Service Goes D.I.Y.
description: Bottle service doesnt have a good reputation in self-respecting bartender circles. It conjures up images of ill-mannered but well-moneyed night trollers loudly swilling $500 bottles of Grey Goose vodka in the cordoned-off V.I.P. corners of ostentatiously swanky clubs and lounges. Its not the style of drinking a genteel bartender condones.

title: The Steward-Turned-Spy
description: During the last weeks of March 1862 some 121,000 troops from the Army of the Potomac  the Unions largest military force  began arriving on the Virginia Peninsula, the first step in what Northerners hoped would be a successful jab at Richmond, the Confederate capital. For over three weeks, hundreds of boats transported the men, 14,000 horses and incalculable tons of matriel southward down the Chesapeake Bay to Union-held Fort Monroe on the peninsulas tip.

title: Liberty and Justice for Non-Muslims
description: Since the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, genuine concerns about national security as well as politicking and fear have led to a shift in the balance between civil liberties and law enforcement. That much is indisputable, and widely discussed. Yet its rarely acknowledged that the attacks have also led to whats essentially a separate justice system for Muslims.

title: Upstate vs. Downstate: A Slow Boil Over Water Issues
description: As I report in The Times, upstate-downstate tensions have soared over New York Citys management of the watershed that supplies drinking water to its residents.

title: Michaels Stores Files for I.P.O.
description: Michaels Stores, the Texas-based purveyor of knitting needles and pipe cleaners, is planning to raise as much as $500 million in its public debut, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

title: April 1  7
description: HOW much do you know about Philadelphias contemporary performance scene? Im embarrassed to admit that I know very little, despite how close the city is to New York and how regularly I hear reports of cross-pollination.

title: Rethinking the Value of Pets
description: Think an elderly family member is better off with a pet? You may want to think again.

title: Business Day Live | Mobile Mapping
description: March 30, 2012 - A look at mobile mapping software, Steve Jobs' personality, and the iPad's high video resolution.

title: Quandary Considered: Disciplining a Strangers Child
description: F. has what amounted to a social parenting quandary: unknown kids, in a public play area, bothering his child enough that he felt the other parent ought to step in, but with no other parent in sight. The last time it happened, he intervened  only to face the angry fellow parent later, accusing him of traumatizing the other child. Should I, F. asked, have tried harder to find the absentee parents of the offending child, or was it O.K. to speak up?

title: Recall Election for Wisconsin Governor Who Battled Unions
description: Wisconsin officials announced on Friday that critics of Gov. Scott Walker had met the requirements for a recall election, starting a bitterly contentious campaign cycle all over again.

title: A Vegetarian Burger Bash
description: For burger lovers who want to cut back on meat, vegetarian burgers can be a tasty and healthful way to recreate the burger experience. In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five ways to create vegetarian burgers at home. She writes:

title: Another View: March Badness
description: As March comes to an end and the NCAA basketball tournament heads into the Final Four, most office pools are likely to be in tatters. But Joshua Brown  a financial adviser for Fusion Analytics Investment Partners who blogs and tweets as The Reformed Broker  is giving Wall Street fans another chance at bracket dominance.

title: Burmese Dissident Resumes Campaign
description: YANGON, Myanmar  As campaigning for a landmark election in Myanmar reached its final days, the leader of the countrys democracy movement, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, emerged from a week of convalescence on Friday still feeling delicate but hopeful that the election would help lay a foundation stone for the future of democracy.

title: Right Eye, Meet Left Eye
description: THE ship still sinks, the director James Cameron said back in October when he was in New York to present some scenes from the updated Titanic to the news media. While the version returning to theaters on Wednesday is the same cut that was released 15 years ago, the films 4K digital remastering and its meticulous 3-D conversion make for a fresh visual experience. The process spanned over 60 weeks and cost about $18 million to achieve a look that seems as if it had been originally shot with 3-D cameras.

title: About Those Lifeboats ...
description: THE coming 100th anniversary of the Titanic disaster (on April 15) hasnt escaped the notice of the home video industry, whose eagle-eyed marketing executives have pounced on the opportunity to release what seems to be every known basic-cable documentary, television mini-series and feature film to examine the subject.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Cultures Beliefs About Fiction Written by Women
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Meg Wolitzer addresses an ongoing debate about the lack of attention for female fiction writers. Ms. Wolitzer writes:

title: TimesCast | March 30, 2012
description: Mexicos presidential campaign begins | More endorsements for Mitt Romney | The actor Frank Langella speaks on his new book, Dropped Names.

title: What Baseball Does to the Soul
description: IT was long before baseball ever enchanted me, and long before I ever knew anything of the Yankees, and long before I learned that a pitch could swerve, yet it came back to me, years later, sitting in the bleachers at Yankee Stadium, a curveball from the past.

title: In Store | Stijl Council
description: Piet Hein Eeks World At the Dutchmans sprawling Eindhoven studio-factory-storegallery-restaurant, great design extends from bureaus to brooms. More

title: Fire Safety for Passover Traditions
description: In 2004, four people were hurt after a fire that erupted during a Passover bread-burning ritual on a Brooklyn street, officials said.

title: In Afghanistan, Businesses Plan Their Own Exits
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  America may be struggling to come up with a viable exit plan for Afghanistan, but Abdul Wasay Manani is sure of his.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $16,500,000
description: One of Park Avenues oldest surviving town houses, once the home of the abstract painter and philanthropist Judith Rothschild, has sold for $16.5 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

title: In Afghanistan, a Rush for the Exits
description: With the United States preparing to wind down aid and troop levels, Afghan entrepreneurs are starting to relocate their businesses and assets out of the country. And international interests are also beginning to pull out or reduce their investment.

title: Anthony Is Hurt Late and Knicks Fade Fast
description: ATLANTA  Carmelo Anthony said he felt the twinge of pain in his groin in the fourth quarter after he stripped the ball from Atlantas Josh Smith and saved it from going out of bounds. He knew he was in trouble, and so were the Knicks.

title: For Stanfords Joslyn Tinkle, a Chance to Have an Impact
description: A year can definitely change many things, as Stanfords Joslyn Tinkle can attest. Shes one of the important parts of Stanfords 2012 Final Four team, serving as its main 3-point threat. The No. 1-seeded Cardinal (35-1) will play another top seed, Baylor, on Sunday at the Pepsi Center in Denver. The winner advances to play the either Connecticut or Notre Dame, also both No. 1 seeds, for the N.C.A.A. title on Tuesday.

title: Adrienne Rich, Beyond the Anger
description: American poets rarely become public figures, and those who do  Allen Ginsberg, Robert Frost  usually pay a price for it. Sometimes that price is measured in a temporary decline in their literary reputation (other poets find fame hard to forgive), but more often its a simple matter of becoming papered over with expectations. The more the public looks at a poet, the harder she becomes to see.

title: Video: Mobile Mapping
Habitats | Red Hook
description: The dcor of Joseph Hart and Anika Selhorsts apartment is spare, but weaves together multiple strands of their professional and personal lives.

title: Where New York Comes Up for Air
description: JOSEPH HART and Anika Selhorst were the ultimate college sweethearts. They have been an item ever since they crossed paths 13 years ago in a college darkroom in Providence, R.I., in a meeting that Ms. Selhorst describes as a scene out of a movie.

title: Tribunal Suspends Approval of Posco Steel Project in India
description: MUMBAI  An Indian tribunal dealt a fresh blow on Friday to a long-delayed, high-profile steel project proposed by the South Korean company Posco by suspending its environmental approval and directing regulators to review the project again.

title: Q. and A.: North Koreas Choked Environment
description: Although it remains one of the worlds most implacably closed societies, North Korea has become more open to gingerly discussing its environmental problems in recent years in the hope of finding solutions.

title: Consumer Budgeting Around the World
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently released a fascinating report on how American consumers spend their money, and how that compares to spending behavior of their counterparts in other rich countries.

title: Party Affiliations in Car-Buying Choices: A Thorny Patch of Consumer Analysis
description: Are some vehicle models more popular with Democrats, and others with Republicans? That is the suggestion of a study conducted by Strategic Vision, a marketing research and industry forecasting firm.

title: The View from Kansas: Toughness and Energy
description: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect on Saturday.

title: Its Gotta Be the Shoes
description: Have you ever wanted to see Cristiano Ronaldo try to juggle with a tennis ball? What about getting a chance to see Rafael Nadal try his hand (or foot) at soccer? If so, you are in luck.

title: Spring Staples | Happy Feet
description: The latest spring accessory: bright, petal-colored pumps pour les pieds. Here, the actress Stacey Dash beams in a daffodil yellow dress with matching platforms; Blake Lively puts a prim spin on a polished color-blocked look with rosy toes; and Beyonc adds a pop of sunny color to all-gray with forsythia-like stilettos and sweet, tulip pink lips.

title: Obama Finds Oil in Markets Is Sufficient to Sideline Iran
description: WASHINGTON  After careful analysis of oil prices and months of negotiations, President Obama on Friday determined that there was sufficient oil in world markets to allow countries to significantly reduce their Iranian imports, clearing the way for Washington to impose severe new sanctions intended to slash Irans oil revenue and press Tehran to abandon its nuclear ambitions.

title: With Lin Out, Davis Re-Enters the Spotlight
description: Baron Daviss off-season arrival in New York was initially met with the highest of expectations. But his inability to take the court (missing the first 31 games of the season) left the Knicks in a vulnerable spot. The void raised questions about the teams overall prospects for the season, and if not for the emergence of Jeremy Lin, perhaps the Knicks would have only a lottery-type finish to show for it.

title: Palestinians and Israeli Troops Clash Amid Protests
description: JERUSALEM  Thousands of Palestinians protested on Friday against Israeli policies of land seizure and control of Jerusalem, leading to clashes with Israeli troops in which a 20-year-old was killed and scores of others were injured.

title: Tibetan Exiles March for One of Their Own Who Died in Flames
description: DHARAMSALA, India  The body was late for the funeral. It had left New Delhi on Thursday morning for the winding 12-hour drive to this Himalayan hill town. The Tibetan exiles here talked with anticipation about a mourning ceremony on Thursday night. But the ambulance carrying the body stopped overnight in the town of Chandigarh, and in the early morning continued the climb toward the snow peaks.

title: Backup to Starter to Phenomenon. Repeat.
description: JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla.  The sometimes surreal, always entertaining movie that is Tim Tebows life played most famously in Gainesville, Fla., and Denver before opening in New York last week. As always, Tebows arrival prompted an immediate and frenzied curiosity, and it did not take long for the typical questions to percolate:

title: Shushannah & Ari
description: In this self-made video, Shushannah Walshe and Ari Yasgur share the story of how they met through Ari's sister. Despite not having much in common, after several dates they fell in love.

title: Nila Do and Joshua Simon
description: FOR Nila Do a good time is eating grilled chicken wings (she once ate 52 at one meal during her college days), playing soccer or flag football and watching University of Florida sporting events.

title: John Patrick Shanleys Storefront Church Gets Its Congregation
description: Fresh from his gripping performance as Gustavo Fring in the television drama Breaking Bad, Giancarlo Esposito has been cast as the lead in John Patrick Shanleys new play, Storefront Church, which the Atlantic Theater Company will produce this spring, the company said Friday.

title: U.S. Denies Visa Renewal for Red Bulls Rodgers
description: The Red Bulls are in the market for another striker after the United States government quashed the visa renewal for the English striker Luke Rodgers. The leagues transfer period end April 15.

title: MasterCard and Visa Investigate Data Breach
description: Visa and MasterCard are investigating whether a data security breach at one of the main companies that processes transactions improperly exposed private customer information, bank officials said Friday. The event highlighted a crucial vulnerability that could affect millions of credit card holders.

title: Whats So Funny About Whoopee Cushions?
description: In this weeks Makers feature Who Made That Whoopee Cushion? in the Magazine, the flatulence expert Jim Dawson  who has authored books like Who Cut the Cheese? Blame It on the Dog and, most recently, Did Somebody Step on a Duck?  says that the fake-flatulent noises made by the toy are funny because they deflate people.

title: The View from Ohio State: It Could Be a Classic
description: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect on Saturday.

title: Business Day Live: Starbucks Struggles
description: Starbucks struggles to make headway in Europe; a look at mobile mapping software; James B. Stewart on the Supreme Court and the health care law.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Zombies, Mutants and Bats
description: The hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week has one new title, but you have to scroll past a lot of zombies to get to it.
