The top seven slots on the list belong to The Walking Dead, the epic about a world overrun by zombies, by Robert Kirkman, Tony Moore and Charlie Adlard. The seven collected editions, published by Image Comics, will get readers from the first issue to No. 84 of the series. Issue No. 95 hit comic book stores this week. New to the hardcover list, at No. 10, is X-Men: Season One, by Dennis Hopeless and Jamie McKelvie. Its a modern take on the early days of Marvels favorite mutants. While my colleague Adam Kepler and I enjoyed Fantastic Four: Season One, we were less thrilled by the X-Mens turn.

title: Jon Gruden Interrogates Andrew Luck
description: Programming alert: ESPN begins Jon Grudens QB Camp series tonight at 7, with Andrew Luck as the first quarterback in the interrogation dock. This link will take you to a longer version of the video above, and is highly recommended. Gruden dissects a late interception thrown by Luck against U.S.C. on a routine Stanford play called Spider 3 Y Banana.

title: Gary Ross Answers Reader Questions About The Hunger Games
description: You asked and he answered. Gary Ross, the director of The Hunger Games, took on a wide range of questions from readers about his film version of the Suzanne Collins novel. Mr. Ross selected some of the best questions and has responded below.

title: Spanish Government Calls for Budget Cuts to Reassure Investors
description: MADRID  The government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain introduced sharp budgetary cuts on Friday to reassure investors that Madrid would meet its deficit-reduction pledges and avoid deepening the European debt crisis.

title: For Romney, a Widening Gap Between Urban and Rural Support
description: After several early roadblocks, Mitt Romney now has a fairly certain path to the Republican nomination. He has received less support, however, among rural and more conservative voters  the base of the Republican Party in recent elections.

title: Samurai Shopper | True Grit
description: The Samurai Shopper is decidedly laissez-faire about spring cleaning: dust bunnies, Easter bunnies, its all good. But now its time to exorcise winter with a brisk facial scrub. Trouble is, every skin-care line has an exfoliator to banish dead skin cells, unplug pores, impart radiance, etc. From the eco-impeccable Kiss My Face Start Up Exfoliating Face Wash to St. Ivess innumerable specialty scrubs. You can hit the high notes with La Prairies Cellular Microdermabrasion Cream, where mildly abrasive diamond and pearl powders exist in perfect ratio to velvety creams laced with botanical extracts.

title: For Baylor, Reaching the Final Four Is Not Enough
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: The Motherwell Is Real, but Theres a Hitch
description: When a German art conservator recently sought to authenticate an early painting by Robert Motherwell that she had inherited, the director of the artists New York foundation told her there was both good news and bad news. The work, Figuration, a charming 1947 oil on masonite, was real. But, the art conservator was told, the painting was stolen.

title: West 50th Street Near Broadway, 1:32 P.M.
6 Tips About College Admissions Results
description: For students, the results of the college application process can be both an exhilarating and painful experience. There are the surprises of being accepted into reach schools, and the rejections from colleges once considered shoe-ins. And, of course, the purgatory of the wait list.

title: For Asian-American Couples, a Tie That Binds
description: WHEN she was a philosophy student at Harvard College eight years ago, Liane Young never thought twice about all the interracial couples who flitted across campus, arm and arm, hand in hand. Most of her Asian friends had white boyfriends or girlfriends. In her social circles, it was simply the way of the world.

title: Maryland Lacrosse Has a Winning Streak, and Challenging Games Ahead
description: The Maryland womens lacrosse team is nearing the end of its regular season, and despite a few hiccups, its play has been just as impressive as it has been in recent years.

title: A Republican Meteorologist Tries to Remove Liberal Label from Climate Concern
description: March 31, 11:18 p.m. | Updated below |I encourage you to pop over to Shawn Ottos blog below and read A Message from a Republican Meteorologist on Climate Change, a guest post in which Paul Douglas, an experienced meteorologist, energy entrepreneur and founder of the Web site Weather Nation, explains that acknowledging evidence of a growing human influence on climate doesnt make you a liberal. (Hat tip to Climate Progress.) Heres the opening section and link:

title: Weeding a Garden of the Soul
description: North Hollywood, Calif.

title: Spirituality in Jazz, Some Old 70s Soul and New Heavy Metal
description: Mary Stallings

title: When a Beloved Teacher Is Also a Rapist
description: This is the thing I dont want to say: My sons beloved community theater teacher raped one of his former students.

title: TimesCast | Mexico's Elections Begin
description: March 30, 2012 - Mexico's presidential campaign began at midnight with a campaign rally for the leading contender, Enrique Pea Nieto.

title: A Little Lamb, a Lot of Vegetables
description: With all the arguments about meat-eating, I almost hesitated to write this weeks City Kitchen column about lamb. But I am an omnivore, which means at times I am a carnivore. Certainly I could live without meat and often do, and vegetables make up a large part of my diet. I prefer and recommend meat that is sustainably and humanely raised, and I agree with others that most people eat too much of it. For me, the ideal balance is a meal with a little meat and a lot of vegetables, along with the old-fashioned notion that meat is something for special occasions.

title: Honoring a Service Members Ultimate Sacrifice, Whether It Was Made on the Battlefield or Not
description: In a post on March 15 , Gary Farwell eloquently described how some families of our fallen military personnel are issued different types of gold star pins or not allowed to have gold star license tags by the states that issue them. At the heart of this issue is the memorialization of our fallen military. Gold star license tags are only the tip of the iceberg.

title: MTV2 to Resurrect Hollywood Squares
description: MTV2 plans to resurrect the game show Hollywood Squares with a twist: producers will fill many of the nine spots in the giant tic-tac-toe grid with figures from the hip-hop world, the network announced on Friday. The new show will be called Hip Hop Squares and will be hosted by Peter Rosenberg, a D.J. from the radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) in New York.

title: Want an Active Investment Manager? Heres What to Look For
description: IF there is one warning label that seems to have little effect, it is the one on the bottom of a securities prospectus: Past performance is no indication of future results.

title: Arrest Made After Death of Woman Who Plummeted From 14th-Floor Balcony
description: 12:18 a.m. | Updated The 911 operator knew immediately that the situation was serious. Whoever phoned for help was silent, but in the background, several female voices were making threats.

title: The Know-It-All
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Rajaratnam Prosecutor Andrew Michaelson to Join Boies Schiller
description: One of the lead prosecutors in the insider trading trial of the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam is leaving public service for private practice.

title: Marriage Maintenance When Money Is Tight
description: Chronic unemployment is putting many couples marital vows to the test  particularly the part that refers to for richer, for poorer.

title: Protesters Scuffle with Forces
description: Thousands of Palestinians protested on Friday against Israeli policies of land seizure and control of Jerusalem, leading to clashes with Israeli troops in which a 20-year-old was killed and scores of others were injured.

title: DealBooks Week in Review: Reading MF Globals E-Mails
description: We watched a stock exchange trip over itself, found the irony in Warren Buffetts tax problem, read MF Global e-mails and braced for credit downgrades at big banks. A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Hes Awful. But Ill Be His Running Mate.
description: This week, the not-Romney presidential candidates are taking a slight break from their relentless effort to persuade Republicans that the frontrunner is a liar, an elitist and a fake conservative who will bring the world to a shuddering halt if he is nominated. Instead, theyre entertaining discussion about serving as his vice president.

title: CBS and Fox Split Ratings Spoils
description: In the battle for Thursday ratings supremacy, Fox and CBS split the spoils, as the former finished first in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic loved by advertisers and the latter reached the highest overall viewership. Foxs American Idol averaged 15.3 million total viewers and at least temporarily ended its slide in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic after a month of drops.

title: Editors Letter
description: Last winter I had the pleasure of visiting the studio of Chris Garofalo, an artist from Chicago whose works in porcelain had come to my attention when they were exhibited in a show curated by Thomas Demand. Garofalo creates her fantastical botanically inclined pieces  her sculptures resemble plant life but are in no way beholden to natures designs   in a neat sliver of a building, designed by her late husband, that sits at the edge of her back garden. The portrait by Brooke Hodge and Jason Schmidt reveals it as the most wonderful place, crammed with porcelains, photographs, childrens party favors, cactuses and shells. One feels as though one has entered a terrarium, a feeling that lingers as one crosses the garden back to her house and spies, nestled in the plantings, more of Garofalos delightful porcelain wonders. Its marvelous to encounter such a harmonious place where there are no walls between that which is interior (creativity and love, for a start) and that which is exterior.

title: Prolific Forger Gets an Exhibition with His Name Attached
description: One of the most prolific art forgers in America is getting a show this weekend at the University of Cincinnati. Curators say they are putting on display more than 90 forgeries by Mark A. Landis, an eccentric painter who donated dozens of phony works to museums around the country for more than 25 years before being found out in 2008.

title: Air Force Officials Discussed Burial at Sea for Remains From Pentagon Attack
description: WASHINGTON  American military officials discussed scattering at sea some unidentified remains of victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the Pentagon, but the officials were overruled and the remains were burned and dumped in a landfill, according to Defense Department documents released on Friday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza, the West Bank, Jerusalem and France.

title: A Singular Influence
description: BARELY a year and a half has passed since the release of Pink Friday, the platinum debut album by Nicki Minaj, but her style is well honed. Shes a sparkling rapper with a gift for comic accents and unexpected turns of phrase. Shes a walking exaggeration, outsize in sound, personality and look. And shes a rapid evolver, discarding old modes as easily as adopting new ones. This hard and complex work has paid off: when she releases her second album, Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded, this week, it will be as the most influential female rapper of all time.

title: Nicki Minajs Singular Influence
description: Less than two years after releasing her debut album, Ms. Minaj has become the most influential female rapper of all time.

title: Pitino Flashes Back to Role of Underdog
description: When the team from 1987 gathered earlier this season to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Cinderella, Jodi DiRaimo made the trip back to Rhode Island and couldnt help noticing how joyous the occasion was for his old friend Rick Pitino.

title: A View From Kentucky: Rivalry Ratchets Up
description: The Quad asked writers at newspapers on the campuses of teams that made the Final Four for reports on what to expect Saturday.

title: A Basic, but Often Ignored, Rule of Investing
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column this week about a basic rule in investing that many people dont heed  past performance is no indication of future results.

title: The Bologna Is on Bass
description: If, as people keep saying these days, food is the new indie rock, then it was probably only a matter of time before the two cultural fixations fused in a heretofore unseen way.

title: Older Works Made Fresh in Company of Youth
description: At his death in 1972, the choreographer Jos Limn left behind The Waldstein Sonata, a work that would have remain unfinished if not for the efforts of Daniel Lewis, a former member of the Limn company who completed it and set it for the Juilliard Dance Ensemble in 1975.

title: When For Richer, For Poorer Is Put to the Test
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses how long-term unemployment can take a toll on couples relationships.

title: Three Mallards, a Merganser and a Bufflehead
description: Aliette Frank, a postdoctoral scholar at Royal Roads University, explores sustainable community development on the coast of British Columbia.

title: A Martyr for Tibet is Mourned
description: Jamphel Yeshi set himself on fire on Monday in New Delhi during a large protest before a visit by President Hu Jintao of China. He died two days later.

title: Old Miami Beach: Sun, Schmaltz, Murder
description: BEN DIAMOND, known as the Butcher, a suntanned sociopath, grew up in an Orthodox Jewish orphanage. He orders sable by the pool and in passing conversation mentions the story of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

title: Prom Night
description: The photographer Mary Ellen Mark documents a rite of passage for American youth.

title: The Shelby Cobra at 50, an Icon of Sex and Power
description: FIFTY years have passed since the first Shelby A.C. Cobra, CSX2000, landed, heralding the emergence of an automotive sex symbol and a racetrack legend from a modest display stand at the New York auto show.

title: A Half-Century of Horsepower
description: With voluptuous lines that continue to transcend time, and blistering performance, the Shelby Cobra readily achieved canonization in the car-collecting church.

title: Prom Night
description: THE prom is a rite of passage that has always been one of the most important rituals of American youth. It is a day in our lives that we never forget  a day full of hopes and dreams.

title: A Complex Choreographers Retrospective, With Unusual Breadth
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Companys first season at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center ends this weekend. Over the season 22 dances were performed, including Esplanade, Mr. Taylors best-loved work, which I saw on Wednesday.

title: At the Factory, BMW Tries to Minimize Its Carbon Footprint
description: BMW is pursuing goals to reduce the environmental footprint of its plant in Spartanburg, S.C. Sean Noonan, chief financial officer at the BMW Manufacturing Company and head of sustainability program planning, said in an interview Thursday that much of the heavy lifting had already been done and that further progress at the plant would be measured in smaller steps.

title: Young Lives, Big Night
description: Mary Ellen Markwent to the prom in 1958. She wore a white patterned dress with pearls and open-toed shoes. In a snapshot taken that evening, she beams besides her date,Stuart  just a friend.It was, she said, a less formal, less elaborate event than what many proms are today. No stretch limos. No ballgowns.

title: Girls Around Me: An App Takes Creepy to a New Level
description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Foursquare.

title: After Bills Gay Nineties Closes, a Fight Over Its Antiques
description: Bills Gay Nineties, a Prohibition-era piano bar and restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, closed last week. But as regulars mourned the loss, the owner, Barbara Bart Olmsted, assured them that the watering hole would rise again: She would simply move the pubs signature wooden bar top, swinging doors and assorted memorabilia to a new home.

title: Current TV Dismisses Keith Olbermann
description: 10:06 p.m. | Updated For nearly a year now, Al Gore and Joel Hyatt have been building their liberal cable news channel, Current TV, with the mercurial television anchorman Keith Olbermann at its center.

title: Now Online | T Design Spring 2012
description: Bold statements set the tone for the spring 2012 issue of T Design. The artist Doug Aitkens house in Southern California sounds as striking as it looks, while a London town house contrasts historic architecture with opinionated, contemporary decorating. T visits a wind-swept West Coast garden with a personal style and a Chicago artist whose ceramic plants evoke a garden on another planet. We also meet a design-world style maker, a guru of bespoke speakers, an artist whose subject is almost everything, a couple who made a big move to the Midwest and, courtesy of The Selby, we stop in at the delightfully primal Brooklyn restaurant Isa. See all the stories here.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 30
description: Subjects include a heated battle at the Park Slope Food Coop, a rescue of abused and abandoned dogs from Puerto Rico and a new plan for Midtown pedestrians.

title: Jewish Rogues Gallery
description: Jewish villains are rare on television but there are some examples.

title: Keren & Landis
description: In this self-made video, Keren Sachs and Landis Kauffman share the story of how they worked at the same company but their romance began after they ran into each other at an airport.

title: Brighter Skies and a Flying Car, Too
description: THE New York auto show opens for press previews on Wednesday with spring in the air  and not just because of the weather.

title: Designers Big Dreams Roll Into Manhattan
description: DREAMS have always been the currency of auto shows, where the admission price buys unlimited fantasies of awe-inspiring cars that never get dirty, break down or gulp premium unleaded at $4.50 a gallon.

title: Five Visions of the Future
description: Five designers share their inspirations for cars that will move audiences at the Javits Center when the New York auto show opens on Friday.

title: Claire & Ethan
description: In this self-made video, Claire James and Ethan Ravetch tetl the story of how they met in High School and despite some missed signals in senior year, they became a couple.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 30
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Banking Mysticism, Continued
description: Update: Its obvious that many commenters dont get the distinction between the proposition that banks create money  which every economics textbook, mine included, says they do (thats what the money multiplier is all about)  and the proposition that their ability to create money is not constrained by the monetary base. Sigh.

title: Panel Says Flu Research Is Safe to Publish
description: After a public furor over experiments that made a dangerous flu virus more contagious, a panel of scientific advisers reversed itself on Friday and recommended that full details of the research be published in scientific journals.

title: Health Overhaul Is Backdrop as Obama Returns to Stump
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  President Obama made no mention of this weeks closely watched Supreme Court hearing on the constitutionality of the 2010 health care overhaul when he delivered his standard stump speech at a fund-raiser attended by the party faithful here on Friday.

title: The Wedding Expo Is Over. Now Its Time for Divorce.
description: At the Metropolitan Pavilion on West 18th Street, divorce is following marriage, just as it does in life.

title: Not Your Sunny Summer Fantasy
description: The sweet melodies that open Alfred Schnittkes unsettling (K)ein Sommernachtstraum ([Not] a Midsummer Nights Dream) sound later as if they had been filtered through shards of glass. An acidic undercurrent darkens the works playful exterior; cheery Neo-Classical and Baroque allusions soon become dissonant and even nightmarish. At one point a creepy tuba melody lurches below what sounds like a deranged circus band.

title: Forestry Company From China Is Bankrupt
description: OTTAWA  Sino-Forest, a Chinese company that trades on the Toronto Stock Exchange, filed for bankruptcy protection in a Toronto court on Friday and said that it would try to sell or restructure its operations.

title: Taming the Tiger of Achievement
Saving a Dynasty From Enemies Both Familiar and Not
description: I knew when my son had to die.

title: Just Try to Get This One on a Plane
description: A spring warning for puttering-in-the-garden types who have occasionally been startled by a garter snake as they pull the weeds: Soon you may be seeing a cousin of that garter lolling in your flowerbed. This snake will be fairly easy to distinguish from the other. Itll be the one thats longer than your house.

title: Chasing Ghosts of Poets Past
description: ON 12th Street between Avenue A and First Avenue in the East Village, there is an empty lot, a dusty, fenced-in patch next to a school playground. On a recent sunny afternoon, some children were tossing around a baseball there, beneath two wildly flowering cherry blossom trees, oblivious to the history around them.

title: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga Unveiled
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Lawyer Says Zuccotti Park Demonstrators Broke No Law
description: When hundreds of police officers entered Zuccotti Park early on Nov. 15, they dismantled tents and other structures that had been erected by Occupy Wall Street protesters in defiance of rules established in September by the parks owner, Brookfield Properties.

title: Friday Night Music: Sour Times
description: Special double-shot edition, original artist and cover:

title: New York States 2012 Budget Sails Through Albany
description: ALBANY  The State Legislature approved a $132.6 billion spending plan on Friday for the fiscal year that begins Sunday, bringing to a punctual conclusion one of the smoothest state budget negotiations at the Capitol in years.

title: Groupons Shares Fall on Revision
description: Groupon revised its financial results on Friday, an unexpected restatement that deepened losses for the daily deals site and once again raised questions about the accounting practices of the newly public company.

title: Previewing the 2012 New York Auto Show
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett previews the New York auto show, which visits the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center next week, with press previews beginning Wednesday.

title: Irrelevant Dirt on Trayvon Martin
description: It was inevitable that the media blitz on the killing of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, would breed skepticism in some circles. No story that seems so open-and-shutthat seems like such a textbook example of criminalized walking-while-blackcan, or should, pass without scrutiny.

title: Plush Short Ribs Displace Stringy Brisket
description: SEVERAL years ago, my family banished brisket from our Seder.

title: All You Can Eat, and Then Some
description: FOR almost 20 years, Churrasqueira Bairrada Rodizio Restaurant has been a popular spot in Mineola for all-you-can-eat Portuguese-style barbecue. So when Brasa Rodizio, with a similar format, opened not far away in September, I had to wonder, does the town need another restaurant serving the same kind of food? To judge from the size of the crowd and the smiles on customers faces at the new place on a recent Friday, Id say the answer is yes.

title: That Thing Called Good Taste
description: Before brands were brands, they were just companies with stories and nice carpeting. I remember going into the Mark Cross store on Fifth Avenue with my parents. (This was in the late 60s.) There was an unfussy elegance to that store, just as there was to the main floor of Tiffany up the street, and its not hard to picture guys in sack suits and skinny ties, maybe a rumpled khaki raincoat, going to check out the desk blotters.

title: Where Voter Turnout Was Up, and Down
description: The total number of voters in the Republican primary contests this year has increased from 2008, but turnout as a percentage of the eligible voting population is down.

title: Flavors of Cuba, With a Haven for Cigars
description: THE restaurant Azcar  Spanish for sugar, and the rallying cry of the queen of salsa, Clia Cruz  has the ingredients of a fine place. It has a lively bar scene. It offers a glimpse of sailboats masts, if not the boats themselves, along the Hudson nearby. And its executive chef and owner, Nick Vazquez, won the Food Networks Throwdown! With Bobby Flay with his Cuban sandwich last year.

title: A Firm Look for Exercise
description: TODAY, when you hear the words poker face, you dont think of Senate subcommittee hearings. You think of Lady Gaga. But when it comes to doling out credit, one would have to hand out a goodly share of responsibility for our real-world poker-face pandemic to Dr. Fredric Brandt, a dermatologist. Some 15-odd years ago, Dr. Brandt burst onto the scene as a leading practitioner of (and proselytizer for) an alarming-sounding method of easing wrinkles by paralyzing subcutaneous muscles with injections of botulism toxin.

title: Spring Nationals in Memphis
description: On the final day of the Spring Nationals in Memphis, the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams was decided in the last round. The leaders, Kasper Konow, Anders Hagen, Gregers Bjarnarson and Michael Askgaard from Denmark, played against the team lying second, Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla., Larry Kozlove of Louisville, Ky., Peter Boyd of Darnestown, Md., Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., Fred Stewart of Bloomington, N.Y., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif.

title: Behold the Speckled Eggs
description: Shortly after 5:30p.m. on Friday, Bobby arrived on the ledge with a rodent for his mate, Rosie, who was busy brooding the eggs. He stood sentinel for several minutes before diving out of sight with the long-tailed creature clutched in his beak. Rosie slowly roused herself from the nest to join him, leaving two speckled eggs exposed to the world, but not for long. In flew Bobby, who briefly took over warming duty, while Rosie stretched her wings and had an evening meal.

title: Search Is On in New Mexico for Revered Ultrarunner
description: Micah True, a mythic figure among extreme-distance runners, went for a 12-mile run Tuesday morning and has yet to return, setting off a search in the Gila Wilderness of southwestern New Mexico.

title: Baby, Its Cold (Hot?) Outside
description: EUGENIA GONZALEZ RUIZ-OLLOQUI was not happy. Both a stylish young socialite used to having her photo in Vogue and the longtime public relations director for the designer Michael Bastian, Ms. Ruiz-Olloqui had a problem that, until lately, was new to her. She just couldnt figure out what to wear.

title: Lets Talk About Early Puberty
description: Elizabeth Weils article on girls starting to show signs of puberty as young as 6 and 7 has already generated some great discussion in the comments section.

title: For Passover, Something Old or Something New?
description: Im gearing up for Passover cooking, trying to plan the menu for the seder meal. A few things have already been decided. For a main course, my family braises short ribs in place of the usual brisket. Of course, there will be matzo ball soup, made by my mother (though Joan Nathans matzo balls were delicious). We will have three kinds of charoset: Ashkenazi, Sephardic and possibly one from Yemen made with dates, figs and spices, and then rolled into balls. Well serve gefilte fish, garnished with salmon roe (so pretty!).

title: Week in Pictures for March 30
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. The subjects include a heated battle over at the Park Slope Food Co-op over whether to boycott Israeli-made goods, a rescue of abused and abandoned dogs from Puerto Rico and a new plan for Midtown pedestrians.

title: Montreals Marsch Speaks M.L.S. Fluently, French Haltingly
description: It would not be entirely accurate to say that Montreal Impact Coach Jesse Marsch sat in his hot-tub time machine many years ago when he was in middle school contemplating the value of taking French.

title: Gas Costs More, or Less?
description: Are gas prices soaring, or collapsing? It depends which gas you are talking about. Gasoline prices are up sharply, but natural gas prices in the United States have fallen to their lowest levels in a decade.

title: Money Behind Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: One on One: Clay Johnson, Author of The Information Diet
description: Clay Johnson, the former director of Sunlight Labs, a group within The Sunlight Foundation, a non-profit that uses data to promote transparency in government, discusses his new book, The Information Diet. He says consumers have to take responsibility for the type of information they consume, much like consumer must take responsibility for the foods they eat. He says we have to create a sustainable news movement, much like weve created a sustainable food movement. Here is an edited version of my interview which covers bias, data and why reading about Snooki is like smoking in public:

title: Not Waiting to Say Goodbye
description: BOB BERGERON was so relentlessly cheery that people sometimes found it off-putting. If you ran into him at the David Barton Gym on West 23rd Street, where he worked out nearly ever morning at 7, and you complained about the rain, he would smile and say youd be better off focusing on a problem you could fix.

title: The Perils of the American Racetrack
description: To the Editor:

title: In Wisconsin Speech, Romney Makes His Case Against Obama
description: APPLETON, Wis.  Just days before the Republican presidential primary, Mitt Romney swept into Wisconsin, sounding general election themes and offering a forceful, and at times lyrical, speech laying out a stark and clear contrast between himself and President Obama.

title: A Voice Thats So Sultry You Might Get Burned
description: Gregory Generet has a voice so strong and forceful that it seems to erupt from deep within. As he performed at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, several inner storytellers jostled to be heard in a show made up equally of jazz, soul and blues. In his more volcanic performances, your impulse was to run for cover.

title: Another Feast for the Jilted Bride
description: Just when Downton Abbey made America fall back in love with British costume dramas, here comes Great Expectations to break the spell.

title: Tiger Mom, Meet Diet Enforcer
description: THE high-achieving mother publicly laid out her methods, strict and punishing. She wrote of how her young daughter, told that she needed to change, resisted, rebelled, sometimes threw a tantrum. But in the end, the mother proclaimed, her tactics triumphed.

title: Why One Gas Is Cheap and One Isnt
description: THE price of gas has risen rapidly this year.

title: NATO and Libya Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Ah, the Beloved Cars of My Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vegan Retreat for Carnivores, Too
description: THE dcor at G-Zen  mandalas and other Eastern art forms, wooden tables with woven place mats  gives this Branford restaurant the feel of an upscale spiritual retreat center. The menu is entirely vegan, with lots of gluten-free dishes and a few raw ones. As noted on its Web site, G-Zen aims to appeal to a nonvegan audience, too: a tall order for a restaurant offering vegan versions of well-loved classics, like pizza and crab cakes, in addition to familiar vegetarian fare. But G-Zen often succeeds, and many of the best dishes here are the most daring.

title: Romney Wont Play the Lottery
description: FOND DU LAC, Wis.  At an unplanned stop at Schreiners Restaurant here Friday evening, Mitt Romney bought four slices of cherry pie, chatted with diners and waded into the fever over the Mega Millions lottery, whose jackpot is estimated at $640 million.

title: Turning Trout Into a Trophy Dish
description: THE first day of April marks the opening of trout season in Westchester and nearby counties. But if you arent ready to pull on hip waders and venture into the areas well-stocked streams, you might want to try your luck with one of the many trout dishes surfacing this spring on local restaurant menus.

title: 2 Families Tangle Over Diamonds
description: In the mezzanine gallery of the Natural History Museum in London are some of its cherished treasures: the 1,384-carat Devonshire Emerald; a replica of Queen Victorias Koh-i-noor diamond; and the Aurora Pyramid of Hope, a rare collection of 295 naturally colored diamonds.

title: Taking Responsibility for Death
description: I WAS standing by my 89-year-old mothers hospital bed when she asked a doctor, Is there anything you can do here to give me back the life I had last year, when I wasnt in pain every minute? The young medical resident, stunned by the directness of the question, blurted out, Honestly, maam, no.

title: Top Derby Contender Lightly Tested, and Healthy
description: Despite a narrow loss in the Breeders Cup Juvenile, Union Rags exited 2011 with his reputation intact. Most thought he was the best 2-year-old in the sport and the most likely winner of the 2012 Kentucky Derby. All that the trainer Michael Matz had to do was to get him there, healthy and on top of his game.

title: Pragmatism on the Prairie
description: REPUBLICANS often accuse Democrats of being socialists. But in North Dakota, socialism has been thriving for decades. It is the only state with a state-owned bank and a profitable state-owned grain elevator and flour mill, both of which the good people of North Dakota, who mostly vote Republican in presidential elections, embrace and value. Both institutions began embroiled in controversy. With all the vitriol about socialism and radicalism in the national debate today, is there anything we can learn from North Dakota?

title: A German Playboy, With a Well-Kept, Earnest Past
description: BERLIN

title: In Myanmar, an Election Doomed to Fail
description: Provo, Utah

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook Ban and Jumping Robot
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: Trying to Rein In a Shakespearean Fury
description: If only King Leontes, the main character in Shakespeares dark romance The Winters Tale, were a little more like Hamlet! He would think twice before jailing his queen, the spotless Hermione, on charges of treason, conspiracy and adultery. He would pause before insisting that their newborn daughter be left to die far from their home in Sicilia. And he would shrink from ordering the murder of the man he is sure is Hermiones paramour, his lifelong best friend, King Polixenes of Bohemia.

title: The Biggest Stage, Literally
description: NEW ORLEANS  They say the N.C.A.A. tournament is the biggest stage in college basketball.

title: Fighting Terrorism, French-Style
description: PARIS

title: Friday Food Links
description: A federal court ruled last week that the F.D.A. must finally decide whether the routine practice of feeding antibiotics to healthy farm animals poses a serious danger to human health. If the F.D.A. concludes that it does, they must ban the practice. (My best guess is that the F.D.A. will hold true to form and wind up caving to the meat industry, but if Im wrong Ill apologize and join the celebration.)

title: Warned of an Attack on the Internet, and Getting Ready
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a quiet Sunday in mid-February, something curious attracted the attention of the behind-the-scenes engineers who scour the Internet for signs of trouble. There, among the ubiquitous boasts posted by the hacking collective Anonymous, was a call to attack some of the networks most crucial parts.

title: Tale of Love and Illness Ends in Deaths
description: His was a love story, Charles D. Snelling wrote  a tale of a shiftless dreamer and the woman who saved him, of the life they built over six decades and the disease that stood no chance of erasing it. By the end, he said, their time together had become a case study in reciprocity.

title: A Cardboard Fountain, Braving the Elements
description: DOLPHINS dance in cresting waves alongside scaly-tailed seahorses bearing trumpeting angels and a wild-haired harpy. Conches rest on boulders that emerge from the sea, where Poseidon grips his trident and towers 14 feet above them all.

title: Knee Injury Leads Nadal to Pull Out of Semifinal
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  With a shot at a record seventh French Open title two months away, Rafael Nadal passed up a chance at the biggest title he has failed to win.

title: Linking Multiple Shootings to One Gun, With a Microscope and a Great Memory
description: The trigger of a semiautomatic pistol is pulled, and a firing pin in the back of the gun darts forward, slamming into the primer on the rear of the cartridge holding the bullet and causing a small explosion. This ignites the gunpowder in the cartridge, blasting the bullet out of the barrel with tens of thousands of pounds of pressure. That blast goes both ways, driving the left-behind shell casing backward hard enough to leave an impression from the inside of the gun on the shiny brass.

title: Training in Baseballs Cradle? Its a Spring Break Option
description: For years, some New York private schools have sent their baseball teams for spring training in Florida, using their spring break week to play some warm-weather ball and live out a Derek Jeter fantasy, with chaperones.

title: Overcoming Physics Envy
description: HOW scientific are the social sciences?

title: New Trophy Video Recorded by Syrian Soldier Is Leaked to Activists
description: Disturbing video posted online by Syrian activists on Friday, said to have been recorded recently in the Damascus suburb of Eastern Ghouta, appeared to offer fresh evidence of the brutal crackdown by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

title: After Howls of Protest, WTA Will Address Shrieks
description: Years ago, grunting in sports was the province of wrestlers, shot-putters and linemen in football.

title: An Enduring Tale of Bigotry and Justice
description: Scanning a listing of theater productions can be like looking at a menu. What do you feel like having? Are you in the mood for something new? Or craving some familiar comfort food?

title: After a Merger, a Show About Rebirth
description: MARK SPINA and Bev Sheehan have crossed professional paths frequently over the years. He is the founder and artistic director of the Theater Project, which was based for many years in Cranford; she was until recently the artistic director of her own company, What Exit?, in Maplewood.

title: In Manhattan Pizza War, Price of Slice Keeps Dropping
description: In the amped-up war of commerce and 75-cent pizza on the Avenue of the Americas in Midtown, a perilous moment is approaching. Circumstances suggest that ravenous New Yorkers might soon witness 50-cent pizza, 25-cent pizza or, yes, free pizza.

title: Celebrating Poetry Out Loud
description: APRIL is National Poetry Month, which means different things in different places on Long Island, but at least three events will celebrate Walt Whitman, the islands own good gray poet, who was born in West Hills in 1819.

title: Saints Coach Files Appeal of Suspension; Decision Is Expected Soon
description: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton, who was scheduled to begin a one-year suspension on Sunday for his role in the teams bounty system, appealed the ban Friday.

title: Rape-Case Juror Called District Attorney Wonderful Friend in Note
description: In late 2008, Lloyd E. Constantine, a lawyer and longtime adviser to former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, nearly gushed with affection when he explained in a letter to two candidates that he was not choosing one over the other in the election for Manhattan district attorney.

title: Limit on Public Sector Unions Is Voided
description: A federal judge concluded on Friday that parts of a law limiting public sector unions in Wisconsin  the law that started a political battle between Republican officials and labor leaders in the state a year ago  violate the Constitution.

title: Groucho Lives! (In Two Places)
description: For the Groucho Marx fans of this column who continue to plead for more, the information contained herein, if new to you, might just make your day.

title: Competitors on the Court, but Economic Teammates
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The rivalry between Kentuckys two best college basketball teams, which will face off in the N.C.A.A. semifinals on Saturday night, is nothing short of a state civil war. Team flags are flying from car windows, mayors have wagered, and a brawl between two fans, one of them hooked up to a dialysis machine, had to be stopped by the police.

title: Time to Elect the Worst Idea
description: Our topic today is picking the worst new trend of the political season.

title: Bill Cunningham | Adagio
description: Women seem to be taking cues from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum's Renaissance portraits, experimenting with elaborate hairstyles decorated with jewels.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 30, 2012

title: Chinese Company and Employee Deny Any Involvement in Hacking Attacks
description: SHANGHAI  Tencent, a Chinese Internet company, denied on Friday that one of its employees had been involved in a recent breach of computers belonging to Japanese and Indian companies, as well as Tibetan activists.

title: Orwell and March Madness
description: If youve been watching the N.C.A.A. mens basketball championship  a k a March Madness  youve undoubtedly seen the commercial. Its an N.C.A.A. ad that shows college athletes pumping iron, running sprints and playing games. The voice-over, though, talks not about athletic achievement but academic accomplishment. African-American males who are student-athletes are 10 percent more likely to graduate, says the narrator. As the ad concludes, a female athlete looks into the camera and says, Still think were just a bunch of dumb jocks?

title: Primary Turnout Could Signal Trouble for G.O.P.
description: After presidential primaries or caucuses in 28 states, voters are sending a potentially troubling message to the Republican Party: We arent necessarily as excited about the campaign as you think.

title: Bottling Up the Big Men
description: NEW ORLEANS  This year, the Final Four is about the big men. There has been too much talk of rivalries instead of post moves and famous coaches instead of box-outs. The best player on the three best teams remaining is a big man; Kentuckys Anthony Davis, Kansas Thomas Robinson and Ohio States Jared Sullinger all expect to be N.B.A. lottery draft picks. Louisvilles post stalwart is no slouch. Gorgui Dieng has excelled in tournament play and anchors the countrys stingiest defense.

title: Big Oils Bogus Campaign
description: President Obama and the Senate Democrats have again fallen short in their quest to eliminate billions of dollars in unnecessary tax breaks for an oil industry that is rolling in enormous profits. A big reason for that failure is that some of those profits are being continuously recycled to win the support of pliable legislators, underwrite misleading advertising campaigns and advance an energy policy defined solely by more oil and gas production.

title: Gov. Cuomo Budgets His Way
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and state legislators are celebrating the completion of a new state budget  on time, for a second year in a row. This budget increases much-needed funds for schools and relieves local governments of increases in Medicaid costs, saving New York City alone more than $1 billion in the next five years. Public transit in the city did O.K., as did upstate residents who will get some help with roads and bridges.

title: Inside Republican Primary Zaniness, Actual Debate
description: Much media attention has been paid to some of the more outlandish aspects of the Republican nominating contest, writes Anand Giridharadas in his latest Page Two column: Newt Gingrichs call for colonizing the moon, Mitt Romney baptizing dead non-Mormons long ago, or Ron Paul half-joking that New York ought to be renamed Welfaria, Rapetown or Dirtburg.

title: Leading the World Bank
description: President Obamas nomination of Jim Yong Kim to head the World Bank is an inspired choice. The South Korean-born medical doctor and president of Dartmouth College has a stellar reputation as a global health expert.

title: Shirley May France Setters, Long-Distance Swimmer, Dies at 79
description: Shirley May Dares the Sea, the headline in The New York World-Telegram declared on Aug. 1, 1949  one of hundreds in publications on both sides of the Atlantic that trumpeted the derring-do and physical attributes of a 17-year-old girl from Somerset, Mass., who tried, and tried again, to conquer the roiling currents of the English Channel.

title: Chickens on the Loose
description: On fair days, Ive been letting the chickens have the run of the farm. I come out of the house, and the birds are waiting at the chicken-yard fence like petitioners in some Russian novel but with boundless optimism instead of resignation and despair. Out they come, except for the hens, who are busy laying. It is a 30-bird flock of many breeds  Appenzeller, Penedesenca, Orpington, Campine.

title: Pressels Fashion Statement
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Its a match made in heaven, as was obvious to anyone who saw Morgan Pressel walking arm in arm with her fianc, Andy Bush, on Fridayat Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Italy: A Warning on Corruption
description: Italy lacks effective safeguards against corruption, the global anticorruption organization Transparency International said Friday. Lorenzo Segato, director of the Research Center on Security and Crime, which carried out the study for Transparency International, said Italy fell short on many counts, with questionable institutional integrity, weak regulations, biased news media and a social code that condones certain illegalities. Officials say corruption costs Italy about $80 billion a year. The organization called for Italy to set up an independent anticorruption agency.

title: Two Sides to Labor in China
description: HONG KONG  The shorter workweeks and higher pay that Apples biggest contract manufacturer, Foxconn, has promised would mean fundamental changes to factory work in China  assuming enough workers can be found in the first place.

title: Labor Audit on Foxconn Is Thorough, Experts Say
description: The Fair Labor Association, the global monitoring group, has for many years weathered criticism from workers advocates that it is cozy with the companies it audits and soft in its findings.

title: Worker Presumed Dead After Fall From Throgs Neck Bridge
description: A 35-year-old construction worker on his second day as a painter on the Throgs Neck Bridge was killed on Friday, the authorities said, when he slipped from a platform and fell 130 feet into the water below.

title: Corrections: March 31
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Disabled Britons Say Changes to Aid Endanger Them
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron says he wants to end Britains sick-note culture of fraudulent disability claims. But his new get-tough policy has left his coalition government in conflict with thousands of ill and disabled Britons.

title: Local Chamber Music, World-Class Fare
description: CHAMBER music long ago left the chamber, migrating to the concert hall and all manner of modest stages. But even in this age of musical democratization, it is noteworthy when ordinary music lovers year after year band together to bring first-rate chamber fare to their communities. That is what Friends of Music has done.

title: Role Player Tailors Abilities to Fit Mets Needs
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Temple of Apollo at Delphi had inscribed on its portico an aphorism that went tragically unheeded by numerous figures in Greek mythology: Know thyself.

title: The Grid Menagerie
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This one was tough, as Saturdays are wont to be, but it wasnt a brain breaker. Your mileage might have varied. But there sure were a lot of animals in this puzzle, right?

title: This Time, Sullinger Will Play
description: NEW ORLEANS  As Kansas and Ohio State prepare to meet for the second time this season, they are constantly reminded about their earlier encounter. Kansas won that first meeting, at home, fairly easily. The score was 78-67, advantage Jayhawks, last Dec. 10.

title: Canadian Gave Intelligence to Russia, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  A Canadian naval officer accused of a major security breach had access to secrets circulating in a five-nation intelligence alliance and was passing information to Russia, American officials confirmed this week.

title: Speak Up? Raise Your Hand? That May No Longer Be Necessary
description: When sororities elect officers, this is how they typically conduct voting: Members write names on paper slips, which are then folded, collected, unfolded and counted. And if there are runoffs? Repeat process. When youre electing 13 officers, the evening becomes a triumph of sisterly dedication over marathon tedium.

title: Pineda, Sore and Struggling, Could Be Odd Man Out
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The mystery surrounding the Yankees starting rotation might have finally been settled Friday night, but certainly not in a good way for the team.

title: Looking for the Right Blend in Europe
description: The performance of Starbucks stores in Europe has been lackluster.

title: Pressed on All Sides, Leader of Coup in Mali Digs In
description: BAMAKO, Mali  The motorcade bristles with guns, just for him. Freshly minted buttons with his photograph are pinned to his officers. The new Constitution makes him supreme boss and wipes out Parliament. The harassment and imprisonment of the opposition are under way.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Albert Hadley, High Societys Decorator, Dies at 91
description: Albert Hadley, a renowned interior designer whose brave and creative eye, distilling both classic and contemporary styles, made him a standard-bearing decorator for the rich and powerful in American society, died on Thursday in Nashville. He was 91.

title: Sense of Peril for Health Law Gives Insurers Pause
description: As the Supreme Court considers the constitutionality of the federal health care law, one option that had seemed unthinkable to its designers and supporters now seems at least possible: that the court could strike down the entire law.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Activist Presses for Inquiry Into Senior Putin Deputy
description: MOSCOW  Aleksei Navalny, Russias most prominent anticorruption activist, added to the pressure on the Russian government to investigate allegations of what he called corrupt financial practices by a senior deputy to Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Letter From Lloyd E. Constantine
description: Lloyd E. Constantine, a juror in the Michael Pena rape case, sent this letter to Cyrus R. Vance Jr. and Richard Aborn in 2008.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Merger of Performers Unions Approved
description: LOS ANGELES  Members of two performers unions have overwhelmingly approved a merger plan, creating a combined union representing about 150,000 actors, broadcasters, news writers and others in the entertainment and media industries, their representatives said on Friday.

title: Prosecutors Seek Life Sentence for Arms Trafficker
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan asked a judge on Friday to impose a life sentence on Viktor Bout, a former Soviet military officer convicted in November in an arms trafficking and terrorism conspiracy, a court filing shows.

title: Rangers Move Closer to Clinching Top Mark in East
description: Ryan Callahan, the Rangers captain, was handed the Steven McDonald Extra Effort Award before Fridays game. As if he needed to show he was really worthy, Callahan made a sharp pass, checked an opponent to the ice and thwarted a rush with a poke check  all within 30 seconds.

title: Nuclear Commission Clears Reactors in South Carolina
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 on Friday to approve a plan to build two reactors at a power plant in South Carolina, the second nuclear plant construction permit to be in granted less than two months after a 34-year hiatus. The Scana Corporation plans to build the reactors at the Virgil C. Summer plant northwest of Columbia. The company plans to cover 55 percent of the projects estimated $10.2 billion cost, with Santee Cooper, South Carolinas largest power producer, paying the remainder. Based in Cayce, S.C., Scana, which submitted its application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in March 2008, said its first unit would not begin operating until 2017, about a year behind schedule, because of delays in the commissions licensing process. The second is expected to start running in 2018.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: A Legacy of Solitary
description: California has for decades used long-term solitary confinement as a way to combat the gang violence in its overcrowded prisons. But the state is now proposing changes in its policy that could decrease the use of isolation.

title: Fighting a Drawn-Out Battle Against Solitary Confinement
description: ATWATER, Calif.  Ernesto Lira is not a murderer. He has never participated in a prison riot. The crime that landed him behind bars was carrying three foil-wrapped grams of methamphetamine in his car.

title: Senate Confirms 2 for Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Thursday night to confirm Michael E. Horowitz to be the Justice Departments inspector general and Kathryn Keneally as the assistant attorney general for the tax division, filling two important vacancies.

title: Photo Replay: March 30
description: A view of the day in sports, from figure skating in France to swimming in Indianapolis.

title: Keeping Up With Tseng
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  By the time Lindsey Wright teed off Friday afternoon, Yani Tseng had posted her second straight 68 to move to the top of the leader board at the Kraft Nabisco Championship, the first womens major of the year.

title: Blogs, Books and Biscuits
description: Ed Hamilton, 51, runs the Living With Legends: Hotel Chelsea Blog out of his 220-square-foot room on the eighth floor of the hotel, which once housed Leonard Cohen, Dylan Thomas, Sid Vicious, Jack Kerouac and Patti Smith, among many luminous others. It was shut to guests last summer, before new owners began renovating. Mr. Hamilton, the author of Legends of the Chelsea Hotel: Living With Artists and Outlaws in New Yorks Rebel Mecca, and his wife, Debbie Martin, 51, both from Kentucky, have shared the wee room at the hotel since 1997 and, along with other residents, are fighting eviction efforts. They spend their Sundays ambulating the city, trying to avoid crowds and tracking down Southern food.

title: Rodgers Wont Return to Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls are in the market for a striker after the United States denied a visa renewal for Luke Rodgers of England. No reason was given for the denial. Rodgers scored nine goals for the Red Bulls last season and energized the offense. The club must quickly find another striker, especially with a knee injury to Juan Agudelo that will sideline him for six weeks and perhaps more. Late Friday, the Red Bulls sold Rodgers to Lillestrom of the Norwegian first division.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,902 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Hunger Talk, Topped With Ham
description: The muse at Tertulia, a rustic simulation of the taverns and cerveceras that Seamus Mullen, the chef and owner, frequented in northern Spain in his younger days, is the Ibrico ham, which studs the menu like confetti. A hunk of it sits in a slicer at the end of the marble bar for patrons in need of instant salty gratification with their $16 Martinez (Plymouth gin, Perucchi vermouth) and $14 medley of Tanqueray and sparkling cider served via spigot from an oak cask.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Take the 8 Train?

title: Romney Skips G.O.P. Rivals in Anti-Obama Speech
description: APPLETON, Wis.  Four days before the Republican presidential primary here, Mitt Romney swept into Wisconsin, sounding general election themes and offering a forceful  and at times lyrical  speech laying out a stark and clear contrast between himself and President Obama.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Republicans have proved less receptive to some business groups aims and a crucial Apple supplier pledged to improve its factories conditions.

title: Where Would You Live if Life Were an App?
description: APP Upwardly Mobile

title: U.S. Soldiers Lawyer Says Access Denied to Evidence
description: The lawyer representing Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier charged with 17 counts of murder in the deaths of Afghan civilians this month, said that military prosecutors had denied members of his legal team access to witnesses at a Kandahar hospital, as well as to investigative files, medical records and surveillance video.

title: The Word of God, on Mixtape
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, when bulky twin-speaker cassette players were still popular, Leyland E. George bought a nice, loud Panasonic for $90, clipped a shoulder strap to it and began his boombox ministry in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: Campaign Treasurer Is Guilty of Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES  Kinde Durkee, a former campaign treasurer for a number of California Democrats, pleaded guilty on Friday to five counts of mail fraud involving a long-running scheme in which she stole millions of dollars from candidates.

title: Young, in School and Employed
description: Emily Berl, a photographer based in Brooklyn, turned her lens on young people juggling demanding jobs and the rigors of high school.

title: Giants Running Back Is Suspended
description: Andre Brown, a reserve running back for the Giants perhaps best known for coming up with a song celebrating the teams Super Bowl championship, was suspended for four games for violating the N.F.L. policy on performance-enhancing drugs, the league announced. Brown, who spent last season on the practice squad, is eligible to participate in off-season and preseason activities and exhibition games but cannot take part in regular-season work until after the Giants Week 4 game.

title: Muamba Posts Picture on Twitter
description: The picture was posted on Muambas Twitter account on Friday. He looks pretty good for a man who doctors said was effectively dead for 78 minutes after he collapsed on the field during an F.A. Cup match on March 17.

title: U.S. Has No Need to Test Atomic Arsenal, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States does not need to explode nuclear weapons in order to be sure its aging arsenal is still potent, and its ability to detect weapons tests by others is good, according to a report released Friday by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Childbirth Is Taking Longer, Study Finds
description: Women spend much more time in labor than they did 50 years ago, a new study has found, and one reason may be that obstetric practices have changed.

title: Building a Business on Churches for Sale
description: AZUSA, Calif.  In better economic times, workers in this dusty inland town east of Los Angeles built motor homes in the low-slung complex at 975 West First Street.

title: Excited for the Playoffs? How About Now?
description: Heres a look at the latest spot in the N.H.L.s Stanley Cup playoffs advertising campaign Because Its The Cup. Called Outside, it will make its TV debut during Sunday afternoons Philadelphia Flyers-Pittsburgh Penguins game on NBC.

title: Tibetan Exiles March for One of Their Own Who Died in Flames
description: It was with some fanfare that the body of Jamphel Yeshi arrived beneath cloudless skies at the main temple of Dharamsala on Friday morning, Edward Wong writes in The New York Times.

title: Barenboim Presides Over Berlin Music Festival
description: The 10-day classical music festival Staatsoper Festtage returned to Berlin on Friday with a roster of performances featuring international stars. Even in Berlins crowded music calendar, the festival stands out with its lineup of high-profile collaborations with La Scala and other European heavyweights. The events include not only brand-new productions, but also the previous years headliner, Die Walkre, which was met with enthusiastic cheers (as well as loud boos) during its premiere in 2011.

title: The Early Word: Oil
description: Todays Times

title: Coup Rumors Spur China to Hem in Social Networking Sites
description: BEIJING  China started a sweeping crackdown of its vibrant social networking media over the weekend, detaining six people, closing 16 Web sites and shutting off the comment function for two gigantic microblog services.

title: Tribunal Suspends Approval of Posco Steel Project in India
description: An Indian tribunal dealt a fresh blow on Friday to a long-delayed, high-profile steel project proposed by the South Korean company Posco by suspending its environmental approval and directing regulators to review the project again, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times.

title: Ryan Leafs Statement After His Arrest
description: The former Chargers quarterback Ryan Leaf, who has battled an addiction to prescription drugs but who had appeared to right his life recently, was arrested Friday in his hometown in Montana, Great Falls, on burglary and drug possession charges, the police said. He later released a statement:

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, chief of the moderate faction of Hurriyat Conference, a coalition of separatist groups in Kashmir, is supported and controlled by Pakistans spy agency, Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), an American attorney said before a U.S. district court in Alexandria, Virginia, Kashmir Live reports. This claim was made on Friday by the attorney ahead of the scheduled sentencing of Syed Ghulam Nabi Fai, an American citizen, charged with illegally working for the ISI and promoting the cause of self-determination in Kashmir (Hindustan Times).

title: What Price a Dead Shark?
description: LONDON  Dont know much about art, but you know what you like? Well, what do you think of Damien Hirst, he of the pickled shark and diamond-encrusted skull?

title: TurboTax for iPad Was Better Than My Accountant
description: For years, I used to go to a fancy accountant to get my taxes done. It cost me around $750, and I always wound up owing at least $1,000 in the end. Very annoying.

title: Floodgates
description: Once again, were hearing warnings  including from some people who should know better  that the floodgates of inflation may be about to open. Its funny how repeated total failures of prediction dont seem to diminish the confidence of inflationistas in their insights.

title: Let Them Eat Charity
description: The other day, at my daughters private school in Sunnyvale, California, a parent handed me a flier soliciting donations for a 7-year-old boy, Ujjwal Sharma, who was recently diagnosed with leukemia. The leaflet showed Ujjwal (who lives in Jhansi, Uttar Pradesh) on a hospital bed, hooked up to all sorts of medical equipment. His parents, the flier said, are nearly broke.

title: Its Panem in N. Carolina For Hunger Games Fans
description: Fans of The Hunger Games books whose thirst for the trilogy wasnt slaked by the opening of the blockbuster film last weekend can still visit the country of Panem, where teenagers are pitted against one another in deadly fights. It takes only a vivid imagination and transportation to North Carolina, where the movie was shot. The North Carolina Division of Tourism has published a four-day self-guided tour as well as a list of spots of interest. Included on the list is the abandoned Henry River Mill Village, outside Hildebran, which was the site of District 12, where the main characters live.

title: U.S. Women Stop in Japan on the Way to the Olympics
description: The United States womens national team is playing two games this week in Japan  Sunday against the hosts in Sendai and Tuesday against Brazil in Chiba  that are part exhibition (what is being called the inaugural Kirin Challenge Cup), and part commemoration of last years earthquake and tsunami that devastated parts of the country.

title: Art Makes a Statement for Business, Too
description: THE artwork that organizations choose for their buildings, or for their grounds, is as important as the art that people select for their homes.

title: Military Metamorphosis
description: MY father, William G. Long Sr., was part of the crew charged with loading the atom bomb into the Enola Gay in World War II. His unit was the 509th Composite Group,  reporting to Col. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the pilot. Dads military service shaped his life, and consequently it shaped mine.

title: At Element Hotels, Power Your Laptop As You Pedal
description: In a green twist on multitasking, Element Hotels has introduced a power-generating stationary bike at its Miami location, offering guests the opportunity to plug in and recharge their cellphones, laptops, MP3 players or other electronic devices while burning calories.

title: The Driver in Fords Amazing Race
description: IN 2008, the Ford Motor Company seemed caught in a death spiral.

title: Computer Science for the Rest of Us
description: READING, writing and  refactoring code?

title: Why Gas Prices Are Out of Any Presidents Control
description: EVERYONE knows its dangerous to ingest gasoline or to inhale its fumes. But I am starting to believe that merely thinking about the price of gasoline can damage cognitive processing. Thus I may be risking some of my precious few remaining brain cells by writing about that topic.

title: Tiger and the Stock Market, Together Again
description: WHAT do Tiger Woods and the S.& P. 500 have in common?

title: United Arab Emirates Shutters U.S.-Backed Group
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  As Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked hard on Saturday to focus attention on deepening security ties with the Arab nations of the Persian Gulf, she found herself having to deal with a surprising act of diplomatic defiance: the decision by the United Arab Emirates, an ally, to shutter the offices of an American-financed group that promotes democracy.

title: The Best Scorecard Is the One You Keep for Yourself
description: This interview with  Charlotte Beers was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Ms. Beers, former chairwoman and C.E.O. of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide,  now runs seminars called The X Factor for women who are leaders.

title: A Suspicious Event in the South Bronx, Maybe
description: Dear Diary:

title: Released but Never Exonerated, a Man Fights for Freedom
description: A couple of Fridays ago, Kerry Max Cook, who was released from Texas death row in 1997 after two decades, went to pick up his 11-year-old son, Kerry Justice, from his North Dallas school. Class was just letting out. As Mr. Cook approached a group of children and their parents, a little girl squirmed out of her mothers arms and ran toward him. Mr. Kerry! she called. He laughed as she jumped into his arms. Haleigh! he shouted, and began tickling her. She adores Mr. Kerry, her mother said.

title: The Human Voice, as Game Changer
description: Burlington, Mass.

title: Distressed Cities Weigh Bold Tactics in a New Fiscal Era
description: PHILADELPHIA  Amid all the sobering discussions of what happens when cities run out of money, fiscal sleight of hand and time, the most telling detail at a conference on distressed municipalities here last week just might have been the one about the fire truck that was the wrong color.

title: How to Prevent a Financial Overdose
description: THE Food and Drug Administration vets new drugs before they reach the market. But imagine if there were a Wall Street version of the F.D.A.  an agency that examined new financial instruments and ensured that they were safe and benefited society, not just bankers.

title: A Wary Mexico Sizes Up Contenders for the Presidency
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  It is essentially a battle, cynical commentators joke, between the Pretty Boy, the Quinceaera Doll and the Tired Has-Been.

title: The Wildcats in So Many Words
description: NEW ORLEANS  Jerry Tipton answered what seemed like an innocuous radio question last week about which Final Four team could give Kentucky the most problems. Tipton, the longtime Wildcats beat reporter for The Lexington Herald-Leader, said Ohio State.

title: Hayden and Madden Will Be in the Spotlight for Baylor
description: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

title: Variety: Split Decisions
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Welcome to our somewhat semi-annual Split Decisions Variety puzzle. I really dont need to tell you what to do here, do I?

title: Out of One Frying Pan, and Into Another
This Years Final Four Could Be the Last One for an N.C.A.A. Official
description: NEW ORLEANS  Few people who fill out tournament brackets and tune in to N.C.A.A. games on television would recognize Greg Shaheen. His official title with the N.C.A.A. is the interim executive vice president for championships and alliances, a jumble of words that essentially means he runs the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament and the organizations 88 other championships.

title: 3 States Sold Winning Mega Millions Tickets
description: What is $640 million divided by three? More math than jackpot winners in Illinois, Kansas and Maryland will ever have to do again.

title: The Fire and the Glow
description: DENVER  Before Baylor left Waco, Tex., for the womens Final Four, Coach Kim Mulkey announced that she had Bells palsy, a treatable nerve disorder that causes weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles.

title: Targets, Instruments, and the Zero Bound (Wonks Only)
description: Ive been rereading Larry Balls impressive and disturbing what-happened-to-Ben-Bernanke analysis  an analysis that, I happen to know, has caused much consternation in some circles. (Surely it cant be just groupthink! There must be very good reasons the Fed hasnt done more!) And I think theres a way to further refine Balls analysis, making more sense of Bernankes retreat from earlier positions  albeit one that still doesnt cast a very flattering light on the Fed.

title: A Changed but Familiar Woods
description: A book arrived in the mail for Tiger Woods, one promising insight into his upended life. Not The Big Miss, the work of pulp friction by his former swing coach Hank Haney, but The Noticer, a thin novel heavy on perspective.

title: In Wisconsin, Romney Nears the Tipping Point
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney is on the cusp of taking firm control of the Republican nominating contest for the first time, neutralizing his most powerful critics and rallying a broad spectrum of conservatives behind him as party leaders grow increasingly eager to take on President Obama.

title: The Birth of Dixie
description: In a New York apartment on a rainy day in March 1859, Daniel Decatur Emmett sat down at his desk to write a song for his employer, Bryants Minstrels, and its upcoming stage show. Then 44 years old, Emmett had been composing minstrel songs  to be performed primarily by white actors in blackface  since he was 15. Looking out his window at the dreary day outside, Emmett took his inspiration from the weather. A single line, I wish I was in Dixie, echoed in his mind. Before long, it would echo across the country.

title: Syria Wont Pull Out of Rebel Centers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian forces will not pull out of towns and cities that have been centers of the yearlong uprising until normal life resumes there, a Syrian government spokesman told state news media, raising new questions about prospects for carrying out a United Nations-backed peace plan as Western and Arab leaders prepared for a high-level meeting in Turkey on the Syrian crisis.

title: After Threats, No Signs of Attack by Hackers
description: A threat to attack a crucial part of the Internet on Saturday by members of the mercurial, leaderless hacker collective called Anonymous appears to have had no discernible impact so far.

title: The Next Big Idea
description: Twenty years ago, under a glorious canopy of sunshine at Baltimores Inner Harbor, Rick Sutcliffe threw the first pitch of a baseball revolution.

title: Uranium Mines Dot Navajo Land, Neglected and Still Perilous
description: CAMERON, Ariz.  In the summer of 2010, a Navajo cattle rancher named Larry Gordy stumbled upon an abandoned uranium mine in the middle of his grazing land and figured he had better call in the feds. Engineers from the Environmental Protection Agency arrived a few months later, Geiger counters in hand, and found radioactivity levels that buried the needles on their equipment.

title: An Uprising in the East
description: As metaphors go, it was powerful and painful. While making the final out of the Philadelphia Phillies season last October, the teams slugging cleanup man, Ryan Howard, broke awkwardly from the box and crumpled to the ground in agony. Howard had ruptured his Achilles tendon. Down went the champs.

title: Tigers Poised to Break Through
description: Follow the blue and orange paw prints on the carpet to the far corner of the Detroit Tigers clubhouse in Lakeland, Fla. They lead to the smoke-filled office of Manager Jim Leyland, whose desk, strewn with lineup cards and Marlboros, faces a five-foot-tall poster bearing the stern face of Ty Cobb.

title: Industry in India Helps Open a Door to the World
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  On the day the Indian trade delegation came across the border, Pakistan was having another political crisis. The prime minister was embroiled in a showdown with the countrys Supreme Court. Early elections were rumored. And Islamists had just staged a rally in Karachi to protest foreign intervention on Pakistani soil.

title: Roger C. Molander, Nuclear Protest Leader, Dies at 71
description: Roger C. Molander, who abandoned what he called the priesthood of cold warriors in the White House and the Pentagon to organize one of the nations largest and most colorful protests against nuclear arms, died on March 25 in Washington. He was 71.

title: Hitchcock Rethinks His Ways and Rejuvenates the Blues
description: ST. LOUIS  Eight St. Louis Blues players formed a circle near a freight elevator at Scottrade Center and kept a soccer ball aloft with their feet and knees. It is a fashionable pregame time-killer, the modern take on the dressing room table tennis, and these Blues went at it with gusto.

title: Patience Abbe, Chronicler of Her Childhood Travels, Dies at 87
description: Patience Abbe was not quite 10 by the time she had waltzed standing tiptoe on Fred Astaires feet, charmed literary critics with her conversation and been promised in marriage to the son of a handsome couple of her parents acquaintance, Hadley and Ernest Hemingway. She and Jack Hemingway, also known as Bumby, were toddlers at the time, living with their expatriate American parents in Paris.

title: Edson W. Spencer, Who Turned Honeywells Attention to the Skies, Dies at 85
description: Edson W. Spencer, who as chief executive and chairman of Honeywell shifted the company away from computers and into aeronautics and industrial controls, died on March 25 at his home in Wayzata, Minn. He was 85.

title: Giffords Keeps Campaign Money, Prompting Talk of a Possible Comeback
description: LOS ANGELES  When Gabrielle Giffords announced that she would step down from Congress in January, she did not shy away from the possibility that she would one day run for office again.

title: Junior, the Kid, the Fight
description: Fifty years later. If you are Lucy Paret, though, the impoverished widow of Benny, a two-time welterweight champion of the world, youre hardly calling this an anniversary. Fifty years ago, you decided to stay home in your Bronx apartment building the night your 25-year-old husband was pummeled to death  March 24, 1962  by the challenger Emile Griffith, a former champion, on live television, an ABC Friday Night Fights special.

title: Watching the Bouncing Balls, College and Pro
description: Steve Kerr, one of the busiest men in basketball this time of year, does not play or coach. He is a TNT game analyst for the N.C.A.A. mens tournament and the N.B.A.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Wisconsin, Santorum Tells Conservatives Not to Give In
description: PEWAUKEE, Wis.  His status as a formidable challenger to Mitt Romney diminished in recent days, Rick Santorum took the stage at a gathering of religious conservatives on Saturday morning and implored them not to sell their convictions short.

title: Alchemists Needed for Mets Golden Anniversary
description: A 50th anniversary is a great time to remember why you fell in love in the first place  the rush of joy, then the recognition that, over the long run, nobody is perfect.

title: In Brazil Cyclists Death, a Clash Between Wealth and Life on the Fringes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  It started out as just another Saturday night in Brazil.

title: A Monotony of Excellence, an Atrophy of Passion
description: Most fans look ahead on opening day, with anticipation and relish. Im no different, I suppose. Now early in my second half-century rooting for the Yankees, I can think of a few intriguing questions about this season.
